reviews.review: One of a kind. The old asian civilization, one of its kind and perfectly preserved. Great for history buffs and landscape enthusiasts 👌🏾

Hi all friends are in over the world . I'm a tuktuk and car driver I always have a good price Small tour only 13$ includes sunrise 18$Grand tour only 15$ includes sunrise or sunset 20$ full days Outside Angkor area,Banteaysrey,Bengmilea and Rolous group for car only 55$ one day If you want go to the lake chongkhneas 10$ but you want to kongpongplok 15$Especially we have others places for recommendations to tourists
Terrible. This isn't real .. it's not even open don't bother your time here ... you can have a better time in a tent by yourself
Renders all other temples pointless. My second visit, girlfriends first. Still breathtaking. Makes visiting most other temples seem to be a waste of time.

This is why siem reap existed..... If you talk about siem reap..you talk about angkor Wat park and angkor wat temple is the famous one.But within the whole park there are numerous other temples and site which are of similar magificence and interestsTake 1 full day and perhaps if you really want buy a 2 day ticket.1 day costs usd20 and 2 days costs usd40. ...clothes are very strict...shorts for men must be belong the knee and women has to wear pants and no shoulders to be shown (this can be quite uncomfortable as it can get quite hot and bothered climbing around the stones)
Lovely place. I used to go there when i was a little kid and now it still the best place and remind my sweet memory.

Visitd 6 Interesting Temples. There are many temples within Angkor Archaeological Site. A 1-Day Visit Pass available at USD 20. Day Visit Pass will be checked at all entrances to temples. Moving around the sites can be on tuk tuk or private aircon car. Tuk tuk travelling time will be twice as much as private aircon car. Witness the majestic sunrise at Angkor Wat. Also visited few importanf temples inside Angkor Archaeological Park, inclusive of Ta Keo, Bantaey Srei, Srah Srang, Ta Prohm, Angkor Thom, Bayon Temple, Terrace of Leper King, Terrace of Elephants, Preah Khan. Proper dress code needed.Enjoyed under the burning 33 degrees heat.

On a small group tour. Loved this. This ticked off a lifetime wish to visit. I had read about this place for years. I knew nothing!!! I was so much more than what i expected.It was sooooooo hot. Take heaps of water. And a brolly. They so lower the temperature.Wear good footwear. And be prepaired fir steps and people

Gone were the days. Angkor wat used to be a nice place to visit when one can take time to look at the bas reliefs and get a guide to talk about the history and architecture of this ancient infrastructure. But with flights now connecting to more places in the world, particularly China, the temple transform into a wailing market, with tourists screaming posing and simply bulldozing everywhere. I supposed this is the aftermath of globalization. But it can be a tormenting experience, and making this park totally overrated. A picture speaks a thousand words, so see attached. Sun rise at Angkor sounds fun - and it sounds fun to at least another 10-20 thousand others too.

The best temple in Cambodia. That was really beautiful temple in Cambodia I had been there per-week but, it wasn't enough for me because the temple was really big I can visited only a few temple and I have met best tour guy to show me all about that temple. i wish i could come again.

While in Cambodia.... While in Cambodia, you'd be doing yourself a disservice by not visiting Angkor - and various temples within the greater Archaeological Park. Much like the Great Pyramids of Egypt, Angkor provides a look in to the ancient history of the region - and one cannot help but marvel at the engineering feats before them and contemplate the greater significance of the sites. The park, as a whole, offers a great number of temples to be seen - some of which are more physically challenging than others. A good book or a guide can help you determine which ones you want to visit - but don't leave without visiting Angkor Wat, specifically.Throughout the park, you'll find areas where gifts are sold - as well as bottled, water, etc. Be warned, though, that there are also children near the major entrances - and they will hound you to buy something from them - "magnet for you - good price," -- "two magnets, $1," -- "sell tee shirt for you good price," -- "you want book, only $1?" This can honestly be a bit annoying - but just keep walking; you may be followed for a few hundred feet, but the moment you buy one thing - then the rest will think it's on and you'll buy from them, as well. There are plenty of places to buy Angkor gifts where you won't be hounded and the price will also be reasonable. This should not, however, impact your desire to visit - because the sites are absolutely worth it regardless.

Been before and still overwhelmed. I am a return visitor, travelling with my brother and sister-in-law. Our guide tried to make it a bit more individual as well as avoiding the crowds and so we went is a different order and approached Angkor Wat in the early afternoon from the rear. This strategy was fairly successful except for Bayon which we visited before lunch. It was almost impossible to move and take photos without hoards in the shots but then it is Angkor and we were lucky to have it good for the rest of the day. It remains amazing,beautiful and all those other superlatives and I would return if the opportunity arose in the future.

Beautiful, interesting and large. I have of course heard for years about Angkor but really hadn't realised that it was one temple in an area of so many over such a vast area. I was also a little concerned about spending several days there for fear of being "templed out". I need never have worried. There area is magnificient. We spent three days there including a preliminary visit to the Angkor National Museum and in the end I could have spent longer. Main piece of advice is read a book or books before you go. You don't absolutely need to. It is incredible enough but it certainly will make your experience even better.
Amazing views. The views of the temples in the distance are fantastic but wish we had started the day alot earlier due to the heat - 6 am start would have been good

Amazing Angkor. The ticket prices are set to double in 2017, but even then it'd be well worth it. Currently $20 for a day pass and $40 for a three day pass and it's money well spent. The sites here are spectacular and like nothing else on Earth. If you've read up before you've arrived you can get by without a guide. Just organise a tuk tuk driver for your stay and tick off the sites one by one. You'll pay upwards of $20-$25 a day for a tuk tuk driver, especially if you're wanting to take in Banteay Srei. Angkor can get overrun with tour groups so make a plan to start early and press on over lunchtime. Most of the buses head back for lunch leaving some of the more popular sites less busy. An amazing few days can be had here with just a little planning.

Tips for the visit... Well I can say a lot about how stunning this sight is and how it worths the money, but there are plenty of such reviews already...So here are some tips:1. Take a guide - If you are interested in more than yet another selfi/photo tour with the Bayon or with the wild trees in Ta Prom you must get a guide and preferably a good one. You should tell him what are your interests (architecture, history, methology..) so he can emphesize the relevant information.2. Visit the museum before - this is a really great way to get a nice background that will help you to really understand the religions and the history behind the carvings and temples (we only had 2 hours in the museum and we didnt go to all the rooms. If you are the kind of people that like to read every word- plan more than just 2 hours..).3. Take your time - If you really want to see the whole beauty of Ankgor, we suggest to take the 3 day tour.4. Sunrise timing - sunrise at Ankgor Watt can be stunning if the weather is good but otherwise its a bit dissapointing so check the weather before.5. Pack your own breakfest - most people that come to sunrise will go back to their hotel to eat breakfest. If you bring your food with you, you get a chance to walk around and it wount that crowded.6. Pack your own lunch - if you dont want to spend 20$ for average sized meal with drinks you can buy some groceries at the supermarkets in the city and make some sandwitches to keep you fed just until you are back in the city.7. Suggested itinerary - 1st day: Kbal Spean, Bantey Srei, Bantey Sumrae, Sunset at Pre Rup (prefer car over tuk tuk for this day because its a long drive). 2nd day: Sunrise at Ankgor Watt and tour, Ankgor Thom north gate, "Grand Tour" - Preah Khan, Neak Poan, Ta Som. 3rd day: Ankgor Thom with the Bayon, Baphoun and the terraces and last but not least - Ta Prom.I also want to recommend the following company for booking a guide and transportation - AnkgorTouchStone (Look for them in TA) , our guide was Mr. Manune which amazed us with his knowledge about the temples.Enjoy!!!
Amazing. Such an astonishing view. A place to visit. Make sure to bring water thou. Its very hot during the summer. But its thebest time to visit.

Visiting this place should be part of your bucket list!. Angkor Archaeological Park hosts the temples which include the Angkor Wat Temple, Bayon Temple, and majority of the interesting and Historical Temples in Siem Reap, all of which would offer you the most breathtaking and amazing views which you need to see at least once in your life. Before entering the temples, you would have to pay for a ticket which would be checked upon entry for every temple. The ticket costs around USD 20 for a day, and you could also purchase the the 40 USD and 60 USD tickets for three and seven days, respectively. It is recommended that you stay in Siem Reap for about three to four days to explore the temples however, since the major and most interesting temples are twenty to thirty minutes apart via Tuk-tuk. The temples are actually grouped into two - The Big Circle, and the Small Circle. The Big Circle is composed chiefly of all the surrounding temples within the park, which are quite interesting and quite far from each other, while the Small Circle is where you get to see Angkor Wat and all the other temples near it. There are also other temples which are not part of these two primary groups which you can also book as an add-on on your tour, like Banteay Srei and the Roulous group.Be warned of the lurking off-duty policeman who would offer to take your photo and ask for a tip of 1 USD, in some of the temples. They are quite friendly, but may also intimidate you. Nonetheless, a tour inside the Angkor Archaeological Park is one must-go places which you should really consider being part of your bucket list.

Must see. A must see complex of temples birth of Siam reap. Scenic views of hundreds of years old temples from the Khmer empire. Amazing experience surely to be had. You will need a tuk tuk for the day for sure to get around.

Simply amazing. Take water, make sure you buy a ticket as the ticket office is some distance from the entrance to the park. The temples are all awe inspiring and you need several days to really explore the place. We had a guide but his English was very poor and we feel we would have enjoyed the experience far better if we had just gone with a tuk tuk driver on our own.

A beautiful piece of art. There is something extraordinary about watching something that has been left as a legacy to us. I maybe an Indian, and this might have been another country, but art, architecture & history holds an appeal that can keep me occupied. From Angkor to Bayon and the Ta Prohm, every monument is different and yet attractive. Some of the pros: There is a huge number of foreign tourist crowding to Cambodia. Don't get disheartened seeing the crowd. Unlike the Indian tourist crowd, there's absolutely no hustle bustle and noise. To watch the sunrise at Angkor, you have to get up by 4 and reach the site by 4.30 max. The ticket counters has a huge line. But the processing is entirely different. He entry pass requires your physical presence. A photograph is taken and a quick ID is made. The pace is valid for all the sites within the park. There are three kinds of pass which you can opt for - 1 day, 3 days, and 1 week. It's difficult to get a spot in the Angkor during the sunrise. Hold your peace and wait it out. One way or the other, you will find a way to get the right place to get the right shot. Con -There are lot of monuments that have steep stairs and requires lot of stamina and physical effort. If you are travelling with family and have elderlies, then you might have to pay attention in how you plan the visit to these structures.

Amazing temple complex! . The angkor temples are amazing. The place is absolutely massive and the temples beautiful. Unfortunately the entrance prices are quite high and there is way to many tourists going to the temples. This kinda ruins the serenity of the place.

Definate Must See. You can't go to this part of the world and not check out Angkor Wat. A day pass is $20 and worth every penny. Hire a guide and driver ahead of time. Our hotel arranged us a half day tour to Angkor Wat and Angkor Tom with guide and tuk tuk for $50. Worth every penny to get the story, history and the good spots. Go early and bring an umbrella and mosquito repellent.

Angkor museum Siem reap . By Thrive. On a very rainy day in Siem reap I was thinking what to do. So I went to the Siem reap Angkor national museum . After buying my entrance ticket I paid for an English audio head set. Inside you will find a well laid out system well set up for a self tour . Main areas along your tour have video screens with multiple chooses of language . This museum helps to answer any question on Angkor and its surrounding Wats culture Gods system and legions. I enjoyed it much. About a 2 hour self tour.

Name for the entire complex served by a single ticket. What some people refer to as Angkor Wat is really the Angkor Archaeological Park consisting of the Angkor Wat temple, the Angkor Thom city (with multiple attractions including the Bayon Temple, Terrace of the Elephants, Phimeanakas Temple, the very attractive Gates at moat crossings and much more), and a bunch of other temple ruins including the Tomb Raider shot location. You can spend three of four days and not see it all. Two days is the minimum
worth the time and the effort. great experience, never miss it if you are around. make sure you go early enough to catch the sunrise, take snacks with you as well as toilet paper

Great visit. The whole park is a wonder! Temples, lakes etc. no wonder it is on the world heritage list as it is clearly one of the most significant archaeological sites in the world.Compares with Pompeii, Machu Picchu etc for its significance to human kinds ancient brilliance.

A Few General Tips - Temples Including Shopping at the Temples. I've done individual reviews for the temples I have reviewed and leave this for a few general tips:1 - Angkor is a must see destination - go - you will be hot, sweaty and hotter and sweatier, but it is worth it, do pack a hat and an umbrella. Even if it is not raining the umbrella can help with persistent sun!2 - A day does not do justice to the surrounds. We found three days was perfect for us. I have a bit of an interest in history (including studying it as a minor at University) and this was enough for complex explanations about most of the sites.3 - the bathrooms are surprisingly good! Do carry tissues and hand sanitiser though just in case.4 - At almost every temple there are a lot of sellers, these women and children (mostly) are very persistent. Do not buy from the children who should be in school. They will nonetheless follow you around. Mr PH had one persistent young girl drop from $1 for a postcard to $1 for ten. We still did not buy.If you do buy from the women, come to a fair price and be aware they start low and won't take no for an answer! I'm still not quite sure how I ended up with three pairs of pants and a top for $12.00 when I was looking at one pair of pants! Also note the pants come in various sizes even though they will tell you they will fit, if you have a booty there is a good chance they will not! I'm a US 6/8 but with a butt and two of my three pairs were too small. Luckily I have slimmer friends! 5 - A guide is well worth the money for their knowledge of the less trodden paths, good angles for photography and the associated history of each site.6 - Temple fatigue is a thing, especially in the heat. I recommend writing the name of each temple down as you enter and photographing that name so you have a reference point when you go through your photos later.7 - there is lots of art for sale as you enter the temples. Your guide may be able to tell you what is actually drawn/painted locally in Cambodia and what is not. We purchased an approx. A4 piece in watercolour for USD $8 but the artist was there creating more as we watched. Note the large Angkor Wat silhouettes are mass produced and of poor quality. 8 - you can easily purchase water, scarves, hats and various tourist tat such as pants, tops and postcards at the temples. Our guide advised us the goods on sale were the same as Angkor Night Market so we did some shopping between temples and skipped the Night Market.9 - The temples are well policed by those who check your tickets, while I'd like to think those who can afford to travel to Cambodia would not think of trying to sneak in for free ,if not - I warn it would not be easy to!

Amazing 3 days seeing the temples. This place was far better that the high expectations we had. Mainly because of the sheer number of vast temple complexes on offer beyond just the famour Angkor Watt. We were unsure of the best itinerary, but based on what we did and what we wished we could do, I'd suggest the following.Spend 2.5 to 3 days - buy the 3 day pass for $40Day 1 - Grand circuit tour starting at Preah Khan and working your way round clockwise. There's definitely time to add on an extension to Banteay Sri and its well worth itDay 2 - Petit circuit. I'd suggest starting at Angkor Thom and working your way round clockwise. That way you'll definitely be way ahead of the large tours which tend to start at Angkor Wat. I'd suggest ending the day at Angkor Wat as the sun will be shining from the West and makes for much better photos of the main west entrance over the water etc. In the morning the sun is usually too bright and photos don't come out properlyDay 3 - Sunrise in Angkor Wat. We never got round to doing this, but wish we had! Then spend the rest of the day seeing things you might have missed or wanted to make a second visit to, or head further afield.

Touts & Beggers marr experience. I also noted that there's a serious lack of monkeys. A few folks were on the roadside keeping them fed so tourist could see a few monkeys. Most have been poached and their numbers are few now.

Cambodian Holiday. TIPS.....Read up about this world heritage region before you get here.....Get a good guide for your group......Plan to spend at least 3 full days exploring....Weeks are better.Do your research and will be rewarded, as this is one of the most interesting places on earth...!!
Excellent.... There are lot of things to see and explore. You need lot of strenght to explore and enjoy the park. Avoid rainy days as the rocks get wet and are too slippery to climb.

Awe inspiring, breath taking. You may think it is just a bunch of stones, but when you really get there, and you see the temples looming ahead, suddenly how insignificant life seems to be. The temples take your breath away, and there are so many to see, all which have different histories. At least a one day visit is required.

Great scenery, calming presence. Cambodia may be a country with a long history, but this archaeological park really stands out. Love the natural scenery, which brings a little calmness if you decides to go there early. Huge place to explore if you're alone, but good to have a tour guide around to explain the history behind it (I won't spill the beans here).

New Center for Buying your Ticket. You must buy a 1,3, or 7 day pass and they take your picture. We didn't have to wait and the process was quick and easy. The park is quite large and a tuk tuk driver can get you to most temples but to go to the more remote you will travel faster with a car.

Prepare yourself for awesoneness! . There is just so much to see here...difficult to know where to start. Get yourself a 3 day pass ($40...3 days for the price of two) a guide and a remorque and off you go.Don't try to do too much each day...take your time. If you only have a day here, you should do Angkor Wat, the Bayon, Ta Prohm and Sra Srang...this will give you the best bits and a little bit of everything.
the scope is surprising.. even though i read about the park before i went the park is huge. square miles. you pass many temples that are seldom visited.

Marvelous. Topnotch destination, especially if you are history buff or enthusiastic to learn about an ancient civilization or just simply wanting to have a nice photo shoot. It was nice reading about Angkor in history classes but is far better to actually see the site itself. 1 day is not enough so i suggest to do a 2-day tour. Avoid the crowds or go against the usual itinerary so you can further appreciate the ruins in its majesty. We made the tour in 1 day just checking the "must-see", so doing it for 2 or more days will be less tiring and more wonderful in terms of relishing the sites. I hope to go back here again.

huge and magnificent. The Angkor park is one of the best archaeological sites I have visited. All temples date back from the 11th century. Originally Hindu later converted to Buddhism and visa versa. The daily pass costs 20 USD and offers unlimited access to every monument in the park. If you purchase a three day pass you get a discount. Th park is very well taken care off. You can take a tuk tuk (motorbike with passenger chariot) and enjoy the ride from temple to temple. Approximately 1km from monument to monument. Toilets are good but scarce. Use when available. Also restaurants are available inside the park.

Holiday. Such a inspiring visit the angkor archaeological site it is so rejuvenating on how khmer civilizations ,made the largest empire by the belief on hindu philosophy so strong,in detail and work very hard on building magnificent temples. A place to be visit in live time.

Worth Seeing Once in Your Lifetime. The archaeological park houses the famous Angkor Wat as well as Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm, Bayon and countless others. It is totally worth seeing once in your lifetime!

More than we realised. The Angkor Archeological area is huge. Like most tourists we thought of just Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm ("Tomb Raider" Temple), but in reality Angkor Wat is a small piece of the picture. You need to plan for at least a couple of days to get a decent look at the area. Angkor Wat takes some time to visit and Angkor Thom is actually a larger area. This is where Bayon temple and the Terrace of the Elephants are, and you can ride elephants there too.Ta Prohm, Preah Khan, Panteay Kdei are all in the same area. We had a tuk-tuk with a guide and it took 5 - 10 minutes between each stop. Each of these is a must do for a study of the history of the temples. I suggest that you buy the 3 day pass for $40US - this allows you to visit on any 3 days within a week of purchasing the ticket. Buy from the Angkor ticket centre. If you're not going with a tour then try to take a waterproof bag / packet for your ticket as if it is damaged they may not honour it (many tours give you a lanyard with a plastic pouch).Overall a magnificent area to visit.

Put this on your bucket list!! . From the moment I saw my first temple at Angkor, I was in love with the beauty and mystery of it all. While you must seek Angkor Wat (the big one you must see at sunrise) and Bayon (the one with all of the faces), if you stop there, you will be missing out. Banteay Srei was built in the 800s and is carved out of pink sandstone. Because of the particular rock used, all of the carvings are in excellent condition. It's also close to the Landmine Museum (so see those two things together). Smaller temples like Chaosay Tevoda and Tahomm Anon were as beautiful as the bigger temples, but had zero tourists (other than my family). That meant my kids could quietly pretend to be Indian Jones without bothering anyone else. Ta Som was a favorite (do not miss the gates in the front and back) Preah Khan, and Pre Rup were also favorites. My kids are 11 and 13, so I never had to worry about them falling off of the temples, but I would be worried with a toddler. Kids under 12 are free! Yay! But they cannot climb to the top of Angkor Wat. Boo. I would also suggest a tour guide. You could do it on your own, but why? You might miss some of the best parts of the temples, or some great photo ops. If you have not been to the temples at Angkor, put it on your bucket list!

As good as you hoped it would be!. The blazing heat aside, the park has an atmosphere reminiscent of an english country estate, bit like Clumber Park on steroids! Really worthy of its Unesco Heritage site status and justifiably one of the worlds top attractions.

Green,clean and great scene. One of the great scene I ever seen in my life before.Can you imagine power of the scene as stone sculpture ancient building of historic time locates at spacious landscape, surrounded by large trees, breezing fresh air, silent water etc.Just sitting and seeing the view will take your breath,I bet.

Worth it but set aside a lot of time . This attraction is the reason you're in Cambodia but make sure you take the necessary time (at least 2 days) to see all of the attractions in this park. Angkor Wat is but just one part - check out the elephant parade, leper monument, bayon temple, etc. it's worth it! And go early - the park opens at 5:30am.

Another World. I've done a fair bit of traveling, but this place takes the cake. It's magical, mystical and peaceful, yet exotic and exciting at the same time. I went in August, which is supposedly the "low season", so perhaps that helped - it wasn't terribly crowded. A big tip, here: wherever you go, go early. It'll be a lot cooler, a lot more magical (especially with the earlier morning light), and a lot less crowded. We went to Ta Prohm at opening time (7:30 am) and there was hardly a soul there. One of the coolest aspects is the sound of the jungle and the sights of nature all around you as you view the remnants of a vast human empire. It's like a competition between man and nature to see who is more awesome, yet it comes out a fusion of the two. To have an even better experience, I recommended bringing a camera and booking a tour with Angkor Wat Photography Tours. Also, do at LEAST a three-day pass; 1 day is no where near enough to enjoy this marvelous place.

Go for the 3-day pass!. After visiting 14 temples over a 3-day period, my conclusion is simple: the 3-day pass (allowing 3 day visits over a one-week period) is the most realistic proposition for most visitors. A 1-day pass is definitely too little and a 7-day pass (over one month) will be out of the question and/or over the top for most people. But over 3 days we had time for less crowded places than the unavoidable Big 3 (Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prom), and could afford repeat visits to favorite places (Ta Prom, for us), as the quality of light and time of day makes such a huge difference. Prah Khan, Ta Som and Srah Srang were places we had almost to ourselves, which makes for a different experience. (A very significant hike in the price of these passes is due to take effect in March 2017, with the 1-day jumping from USD20 to USD37 and the 3-day from USD40 to USD62).

Wheelchair accessibility. Fantastic attraction, but not easy to get around for wheelchair users. Power wheelchair users will struggle, but manual wheelchair users should be able to get help to be lifted up steps. Recommend that manual wheelchair users use a device like a freewheel to lift their caster wheels off the ground.In 2017 prices to enter the Angkor World Heritage park will double, with a 3-day pass almost $US90 (currently $US40).Toilet facilities are not to western standards, are far and few. Temples are most definitely not wheelchair accessible.

Magical place. Great place to explore the temples and the surroundings.Make sure to have your own Tuk tuk as it's a massive placeDon't worry about food and drink as there's plenty of different stools all around

This is the #1 tour site in the world. Follow my tips for a great visit. Start before sunrise on a bicycle. Turn left at Angkor Watt. Make the 1st right. Pass Angkor Watt for now. Immediately after passing through the south gate of Angkor Thom u-turn left and push your bike up to the top of the wall. Ride the wall west and turn North to reach the west gate and then go east to Angkor Thom. Then go east to Ta Prom. Next, further east to Srah Strang Baray. Then Go south and west to reach Bayon and finish the day at Angkor Watt. Taking this route will give you the best light for photography at the three best temples Ta Prom, Bayon and Angkor Watt.

A must visit - get the 3 day pass!. The park is filled with such beauty - I recommend spending 3 days looking at the various temples/wats. I recommend getting a tour guide for at least one of the days so you get more out of the experience.

Totally seduced!. Tour it by tuk tuk is my recommendation - or by bike if you have the energy. The complex is vast and that is what makes it incredible. Take time to just stop and stare and clamber around the smaller temples...

You Won't Be Disappointed!!. What can I say, the whole archaeological park is incredible. Many, many temples, you can get a bit templed out but if you have the time to spread your visit over a few days all the better. We had two full days so had to see as many as we could in that time. The cost of the entry is US$20 per day per person which racks up but it's well worth it, that ticket will get you into everything in the Angkor Park. You could spend weeks here an not see everything. I am still in awe of how these temples were built all those years ago, just how did they do it. If you have the chance GO!! You will not be disappointed. Just remember to take your sun cream, a hat and dress appropriately ie cover shoulders and wear long trousers or a long skirt, you will not be allowed in if you are not wearing the correct dress code.

Wow. A couple of paragraphs simply cannot do justice to the grandeur of this magnificent park. You really have to be here to experience it yourself. We bought the 3-day pass and went there on three half-day trips and still did not see every temple in the park. We visited the Angkor National Museum to soak in some historical information before the temple visits and explored the area on our own. Hiring a Tuk Tuk for the entire day will cost roughly $20-35 dollars depending on how far out of town you want to go. I personally think this is a better option than hiring an air-conditioned car even though it can get quite dusty on the road in Siem Reap. You just feel much closer to the surrounding environment being in a Tuk Tuk. There are a lot of walking on uneven terrain and under the scorching sun so make sure you watch your steps and stay hydrated. Overall one of the best trips I have ever taken anywhere. Would love to be back.

Overall park. This is not a single attraction but a combined area which houses all the famous temples including Angkor Wat , Bayon, Ta Prohm etc, Secret Tip : Do take the pass 1 evening in advance and use the same pass on that evening to visit the beautiful sunset at Phnom Bakheng for free.
Bucket List. Every penny you spend for the Angkor pass to enter this Archaeological Park is well worth. It feels amazing....one of those places which will make you speechless...
amazing temples. I went to the angkor park two years in a row.it is such an original and impressive park.very special to walk through it.
No words in any language. Is the most incredible thing there is. Just go and spend all day walking and feeling humanity cultural heritage. Just see it for yourself.

3 days pass. I'd recommend to get the 3 days pass, $40, and to explore the site on your own, either by renting a bycicle or a scooter. With 3 days you can explore at a moderate pace, without rushing and you have time to get off from the beaten track
A Must See. Wow! It's really nice. We were a little surprised by how clean they keep it. It's really nice 9 (but really hot!)
best visit ever. nowhere can be found such a large and rich site where you could spend hours admiring temples after temples

Magnificent... To me these sites are astonishing..I've visited twice in two years and will come back.
I just find going to various temples an amazing experience..trying to imagine how they constructed these massive and intricate buildings. Also what life must have been like there over the centuries.
To quote a famous Aussie "do your self a favour " 👍

What else would one do in Cambodia...?. Come on, a TripAdvisor listing for one of the most visited temple complexes in the world seems slightly redundant; particularly when calling it a "must see" - well obviously. When one is in South East Asia, particularly Cambodia, it seems to me almost certain that a trip to the Angkor Wat complex is on the cards at some point. As a result, and to save time with reviewing all the multiple temples separately, I will simply write here a few observations from our recent trip, as well as some snippets of advice on which temples of the inner circuit to visit and when. Most people from Siem Reap will take tuk tuks; reasonable price for a day hire seems to be $10-15, though if you pick one up off the street rather than pre-booking they can try and charge anywhere between $20-50. If one feels a little more adventurous, however, there are alternative methods; we chose to hire bicycles at $2 each for the day. The roads are a lot less scary than they look, though poorly maintained, and the heat is enough so that any rain will quickly dry when it stops. Cycling was a lot more fun than tuk tuk, and do not be fooled into thinking one will only need the transport there and back; the entire complex alone spans 250 square miles and Angkor Thom alone is twice the size of Siem Reap. So we cycled up from the city centre, only to get to the front gate of Angkor Wat and be told that we had to buy our tickets back 5 kilometres down the road in the middle of nowhere. The guard was happy to call us a tuk tuk to do it quickly, but absolutely nowhere online, in our hotel, in the tourist map, or in the town was this made clear - so be warned. The ticket purchasing office is a large deserted building in the middle of nowhere, which turns out to be a museum; so don't worry too much when your tuk tuk driver takes you out into the middle of the countryside with no one else about. Eventually getting inside, Angkor Wat was breathtaking. Photos don't do it justice, only being there for yourself can one truly experience it. The temple itself was slightly smaller than I had imagined, but there was a good hour or so of things to see even with the main plateau being closed off on the day of our particular visit. We did this site first, as I am sure most do. Others we were with did Angkor Wat last, however, and reported that the crowds die down here towards the end of the day so doing it in reverse order might be wiser than the traditional clockwise loop.Angkor Thom, the largest of the sites, was a further few kilometres up the road and, in my opinion, a lot more impressive. The central temple itself dwarfed Angkor Wat, and despite current archaeological works provided a much quieter experience with its truly labyrinthine and claustrophobically dark passageways. The summit was a little more crowded, but not too much so. Monks waited at the shrines at the top to give small blessing rituals in exchange for a small tip, and this is where one finds the famous carved stone faces. The elephant wall, slightly further up, is probably much better appreciated from the road going past it than it is on the platform itself. However, if one ventures over its bridge and into the forest there are several smaller temples unmarked on the maps to be found in the trees behind it. Angkor Thom is probably just about doable in a day, it is so big and there are many spread out sites to see, but we had only one day and so we pressed on out of Angkor Thom for some of the smaller structures out in the jungle.The jungle itself made for a nice ride, particularly on the bikes. The other advantage here is that we were free to take things at our own pace, and stop to look at what we wished, without a self-proclaimed expert behind the wheel of a tuk tuk taking us to what he wanted us to see. Some of the smaller structures and market stalls en route to the other temples were really worth exploring and very quiet away from the crowds of the two Angkors.Ta Keo is rather popular for its view, and from the top on a clear day you can just about see the Bayon of Angkor Wat poking out of the trees. Be warned here though, the steps, if you can call them steps as opposed to a climbing wall, are very steep. During our visit a Japanese man slipped over an edge and was carried off by paramedics on a stretcher; children may want to be kept close and the less sure footed left at the bottom. Finally, we did Ta Prohm, the temple made famous by the Tomb Raider films. It was not overly crowded, but numerous American tour groups were repeatedly going past having finished the tour here so doing this temple first before the crowds arrive might be a good idea. The problem with doing this one first, would be however that the other temples simply might not live up to it! Ta Prohm was absolutely magnificent as the structure we saw that had been completely reclaimed by the jungle. Monkeys roam freely and huge trees grow out of the walls; the place has an isolated wild feeling which definitely should not be missed, making it in my opinion the best part of the site.We had originally planned on staying for sunset at the viewing platform between Angkors Wat and Thom; yet when we arrived after the closing of the other temples at 17:30, more than ninety minutes before sunset, the platform was full to capacity and the line waiting for a space was obscenely long. Others in our hostel reported a similar experience in trying for sunrise. My advice, therefore, would be that unless you want to skip half the day waiting on a crowded platform just to take a new Facebook cover photo, you should not bother with dawn or dusk, and instead focus on the rest of the site during opening hours and spend your evening exploring the rest of what Siem Reap has to offer - after a decent sleep the night before.
One of a kind . Most famous attraction of Cambodia and obviously it's a must see on a map of south east Asia.I would recommend 3 days to visit all interesting places.

Even More Impressive than the Pictures. We'd seen the pictures, but were blown away by the size and scale of the architecture, particularly considering its age. Despite the many thousands of tourists exploring the area, there was plenty of room and lots of interesting things to discover at every turn. A MUST SEE.
A cake with many cherries on top.. This is a must see! We went there 3 times (twice on bicycles and once by tuk tuk) and loved each visit.

Well worth the price of admission!. Be sure to hire a Tuk Tuk driver. There is no way you can get to all of the sites on foot. Also, bring your own bottled water and snacks if you can. You will need a digital camera with lots of memory and extra battery.

You could just keep going and keep taking photos. This entire park is stunning. Give yourself plenty of time, at least two days, get yourself a guide and driver US$80 per day and let them take you through the various temples and features. There is so much to see and so much history to this huge complex of temples and cities you could never do it properly by yourself. An amazing insight into the ancient world of the Khmers.
Must see!. Hire a local guide to get a really great overview of the history and majesty. This is a travel bucket list must-see location!
Enormous. We did a MTB-bike tour through the Park and visited several temples. It was great to do and see a lot on a slow pace (biking).
Nice but the seller make me feel uncomfortable . It is a nice place to see ankor wat and take very nice pictures but one of the sides is full of sellers which does not allow you to enjoy the view

A site that truly deserves its reputation. A compulsory visit despite being quite crowded, specially the sunset and sunrise. The most amazing thing is the immensity of the whole Angkor site, with Angkor Wat so well preserved but also with the tour around the site (we did it with a tuk tuk -10$ for the whole visit). Quite cool to have local breakfast in one of the cafeterias at the entrance.

Amazing Archaeological park complex!!. The park includes many temples in its confines, and all the temples are very worth going! The place is beautiful, and I suggest people to find a quiet spot to sit down and rest.

Incredible place to visit. Spent a day visiting many of the sites and Wats. Lots of walking, many people about, however was able to enjoy the magnitude and magnificence all the same.A must see this world wonder!

Must visit. Anyone coming to Siem Reap is there to see the Ankor park and all the temples. This is probably one of the most unique places to visit on earth and also why it is overrun with tourists. Even so, if you are smart about it you can time things to avoid the crowds. We got a car with A/C and guide which is well worth it. In one day we managed to visit Ankor Wat for sunrise, Bayon, Baphuon, Banteay Srei, Ta Prohm, and Pre Rup for sunset not counting sunset the day before as well. I would definitely come back and visit again someday.

It really is massive!. I can now understand why they sell the three day ticket, not only because it is huge and spread out, but you can only really spend the morning there before you begin to melt. Unless you are a reptile and thrive in the heat. Plan ahead and research which temples you want see. Ohhh and watch out for the cheeky monkeys,!

Great site to visit with amazing views and stories. Definitely a world wonder to visit as part of anyone's bucket list. Great restoration works being carried out and a testament to ancient engineering feats. Worth walking in the heat for this. Just that if you eat within Angkor Thom where the stalls for tourists are, be prepared to pay 2-3 times more than what you usually pay at Siem Reap town. Overall pretty dusty to a face mask may be useful. Beggars are not an issue. Just be street savvy and not accept things from people, even monks. Make sure you read the code of conduct to enter the area.

Ancient history, relaxing ambience and sincere people... Never been here before, I assumed that the city will be more or less look like Bangkok or Bali. It is not too wrong for the ambience, Siem Reap is just more quiet and clean, but it is away different when I met and interact with the people.From our Tuktuk rider, the Hotel front office staffs and almost all of the people we've met are so friendly yet polite, warm, and most of all : sincere.We use Viator to reserve a day tour to the Temples, leave the meeting point in the morning after brief introduction given by our tour leader. The tour takes about 2 hours before lunch break and continued about 2 more hours afterwards.Our tour leader is not only told us the history of each Temple and surrounding, but also advise the spots for picture taking, which angle is the best and he often offers to take our pictures too, what a nice guy ! Lunch is simple : 3 tiers food-container for each of us contains rice, Khmer sauted vegetables and beef n potato curry, and some local fruits for desserts - such as longans and "rambutan"After the trip, our tour leader suggest us to have foot or body massage (there are plenty of places offer this service) to relax our muscles after exploring the Temples..We just went across the street, and enjoying the 1,5 hours full body massage and pay not more than US $10 plus tip. We ended the day with Khmer food dinner in the Old Market, ordered the famous Fish Amok, vegetable soup, spring-roll and of course Khmer beer... What a nice day ! Certainly will come back again...

Amazing. Temple after temple after temple, and all different in some way to others.Without our excellent tour guide we would have been overwhelmed. As usual for us, we didn't allow enough time to do the site justice. Two days should be the minimum.The whole site is not really for the mobility-impaired, with long walks and a lot of steps and stairs, but the guides will select the best stuff to suit the psyical condition of travellers.

Well Done, Cambodia. Whoever is managing this park, well done (my tour guide told me it's the Germans). The park is well-organised and clean. The only thing I didn't like were the vendors pushing their weirs at every temple. It got a little annoying and tiring after a while but isn't that what happens at every tourist attraction the world over? I don't hold it against the park, just be prepared for it. There's so much to see in this park. I did a 1-day tour because, living in Southeast Asia for the past few months, I'm a bit templed out. But 1 day is enough to see the highlights, I think. Well done, Cambodia, on using this resource to generate income for your economy, and doing it in a way that preserves the resource. Very well done.
Great. This is one of the highlights of our stay in Cambodia. A very special park charged with historic value.

Amazing place, must visit, dont bring food in the morning. Amazing place and must visit in Cambodia. Bring water, towel, dont bring food in the morning. There are monkeys that will snatch your food. Colorful dress, red or white will be good for photography as the site has black and ash background.

Can not be described in words. Angkor Wat is so beautiful that it is not easy to describe it in words. View from its back, view from its top, view from its front - everything is mind blowing. Its reflection in pond in front of it makes it even more beautiful. My main aim for trip to Cambodia was to visit Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm and I am so happy that I got what I expected.

A site of incredible importance. Few sites on Earth rival the Angkor area for archaeological significance. To think that a thriving kingdom existed here many centuries ago, supporting perhaps as many as a million people, is truly incredible. Beyond the temple ruins themselves, the entire area is very special. The roads are well-kept and the subtropical/tropical forests are largely quiet and peaceful. Cambodians can enter free of charge, so for many, this is a place to come and picnic, relax with friends and family, and enjoy the waterside views of the jungles and temples. We thought it was just a nice area all around, made all the more special by its historical importance.
Speaks for itself!. Amazing! I've wanted to experience Angkor for such a long time! I almost had to pinch myself to make sure I wasn't dreaming...

WORLD CLASS. I have reported on individual temples but would like to add some general thoughts on the whole Angkor Park area.I had one day only to visit the park. Personally that was quite enough and clearly I have not had the chance to visit every single temple site. But I suspect that many people, like me, take the view that you can have too much of a good thing. I would like to return to Angkor in the next few years but suspect that I won't.Like most SE Asian tourists sites (Bagan, Ha Long Bay, Inle Lake etc) you have to pay an entry fee. At Angkor you may buy a variety of passes, for 1, 2 or 3 days and even longer periods. On your first day you go or are taken by your guide or tuk tuk driver to the huge and impressive visitor centre. Don't be alarmed by the number of coaches, buses, minibuses, taxis and tuk tuks waiting in the vast parking area. Inside there are many ticket booths and at busy times they are all staffed. I got my pass in less that 2 minutes.I just hope that all this money is being spent on restoration work and on maintaining the park area and not being creamed off by the local Mr Big and his political cronies. Personal observation was encouraging; the park, unlike Bagan, had extremely good and well maintained roads and they employ an army of litter pickers who do a tremendous job. One final observation on litter in the park; most of it is dumped by the local people and not the tourists.

Make a tuk-tuk 2-days tour!. My suggestion is a 2-days tour with a tuk-tuk.It took us a while to research of the transport to visit Angkor complex. Finally we opted for a tuk-tuk option and were very satisfied. The price we agreed was $35 for 2 days 2 persons. But the guy was so nice, so, we left him $5 more of tips.I definitely recommend to visit the complex in 2 or more days. By this way, you can make the small circle of temples the first day (Angkor Wat, Bayone, Ta Prohm). And a bigger circle the second day. The second day we enjoyed a lot, because there were less people on the road, as most of the people normally opt for a 1-day visit.

Incredible. The many temples are well written in purchased books from the area. The duk duk drivers are well informed when you hire for large loop to see the smaller temples or the small loop to see the largest temples. UNESCO is Angkor Wat's ticket to a fabulous future. However, archeologists have much yet to do as more and more recently uncovered via Lidor exploration. The National Museum in Phenom Penh is worth a visit to see the recent areas in Cambodian rain forests yet to be uncovered and explored by archeologists - the best is Angkor Archeological Park and yet to be!

Unbelievable!. We decided at relatively short notice to add Siem Reap to our holiday so we could see Angkor Wat and surrounds. Getting up early to get our tickets and snag a good spot for sunrise - we weren't disappointed! Luckily for us we scored a great sunrise. We stayed only a short time at Angkor what before putting on our skates and heading to Bayon. Great decision as it turned out as we were 2 of only a few tourists so we were able to get some good shots without anyone in them. By the time we got to Ta Promh the numbers were increasing but still manageable. It was pretty hot though. Our tuk tuk driver found a beaut place with air con for lunch and a respite from the heat. Next time I would go to the ticket office the afternoon before (after 5) to get a pass. One day is enough to do 5 or 6 temples depending on you pace but I would recommend at least 2 days. We went up the top of the nearby hill to watch the sunset but we weren't in luck this time. You need to get up the top early as numbers are limited and they are strict! At each site we encountered a band of musicians who are survivors of land mine explosions. They are quite good and are trying to make a living so we gave to a number of them. It was really moving. I strongly suggest that you hire a guide (we didn't and I regret it very much). You will know them because they wear apricot shirts with an emblem on the sleeve. Check with your hotel or the travel info in Siem Reap.

Do not rush!. All the superlatives are correct. This is an amazing complex which, seen through the lenses of 1000 years, bends the mind and lifts the spirit. The engineering and architectural feats of the Khmer Empire are a wonderful discovery for any westerner. It matches any and all those you've heard about... except, perhaps, the pyramids... but then those are surrounded by arid sand and shanty towns. Angkor is situated in rich tropical lands and the temples are often haloed with butterflies and dragonflies. The complex is vast and requires at least 3 days to savor 50% of it. If your time is tight, be sure to get to BAYON and the BAPHUON Pyramid (inside Angkor Thom), to PREAH KHAN and NEAK PEAN. We (family of 4) stayed a week and this ensured that we didn't get 'templed-out'. We spent 1/2 days at the hotel pool and exploring a bit of Siem Reap a dusty town with noise, rich smells and colors. It can seem a bit sketchy at times, but we never once felt threatened or ill at ease. Nothing much there, but there are bars, restaurants and shops to choose from. We discovered Kuriosity Kafe and went back 3 times. Tried multiple dishes and drinks and found them all to be excellent.You need to purchase personalized tickets at the official offices. All family members must be present for the photos. This can take you anywhere from 10 min. to 2 hours. The lines can be very long in the afternoons. However, there are dedicated booths for 3 day+ tickets and hardly no lines. Tickets are always checked at every temple and at all times.Would have taken a full or half-day bike tour, but back problems stopped this. We think it would be perfect for the Angkor Vat portion. Don't let the crowds or the vendors get to you. Smile and look beyond them into the wonders before you. Take tons of pics and drink gallons of water. Dollars are standard currency. Average dinner per person USD10 including water and a drink. Average Tuk-Tuk transport USD 2. Wi-fi in most places. Last minute SUNRISE tip (as of July 2016): most temples have been closed for sunrise access, so check very carefully before getting up at 4 and heading out into the wild. 3 guaranteed sunrise marvels: Sra Srei (the largest man-made pool on the planet, I'm sure -40min from town), the elevated Phnom Baken temple (close to entrance 15 min. hike up - 30 min from town) and, of course, Angkor Vat.

Sad to see elephants still being used to transport tourists.. overall, a great experience. Lots to see, but lots of walking, climbing and very hot. Go prepared with water and electrolyte salts if possible. No water sold within the grounds of each temple.

See as much as you can!. Incredible history...it's a must see in your lifetime. We were on an Intrepid Tour with a local guide which I highly recommend. You'll learn so much more and avoid any tourist traps.
Part of Angkor Wat. All part of Angkor Wat. Worth all your troubles. Would recommend sunrise over sunset...not as hot...and for us in monsoon season far less chance of rain.

take at least 4 days. The temples are huge and spread out so one day will not be good. we bought our passes the night before and they did not count that night as one of our 3 days on the pass. so we got to see temples for 3.5 days. this was our driver Rithy bou's idea and it was perfect as was everything else he recommended. he is at Cambodia by private driver.
You can't visit Cambodia and not visit Angkor Park!. The sheer size of the park, and the number of temples in it, are amazing; and the carved friezes in Angkor Wat are amazing...
Huge archeological park . Dress smart, drink enough fluids your body will thank you later. Spend a day or two here and be amazed by the historic architectures

Archeological park. You'll need at least a week. Angkor wat is overrated but cool, Ta phrom is gorgeous, Bayon is incredible, don't miss Angkor Thom, and banteay srei is pretty neat though it would not be the temple to see after you’ve seen a bunch of them.

Amazing!!. If you are coming to see Angkor Wat, allow an extra day to visit the smaller temples within the park. This is a village also with many, many families living within the grounds. This is a community that has lived in these grounds for a very long time and there are schools, small health clinics and many small stalls. The smaller temples don't attract the big tour buses which means that you can walk around the temple ruins peacefully.As this is a huge national park, approx 300sq km, hire a tuk tuk to get around, bicycling around is hard work in the heat & you don't see as much.

Spell binding Temple Site. Almost continually in the worlds top three of 'must see' destinations in the world. If your in Cambodia then I'm sure you won't be disappointed with a visit to Angkor Temple complex

A past civilization. This is a 'must do' on all tourists list traveling through Cambodia, so be prepared for crowds and heat. The architecture is amazing and the teams have done a brilliant job of reconstructing much of the surrounding buildings. It takes at least two days to see a majority of the area. Definitely recommend going in the morning and do other activities in the afternoon so it doesn't get too repetitive.
Another Huge Sightseeing. Again another hit not to be passed without spending hours in this parkMany tourist attractions tooIt's really pleasant

Awe inspiring. The world has many natural wonders and awe-inspiring places to see. This is one of the must-see ones.Machu Picchu, and the pyramids of Teotihuacan and Giza are impressive from an engineering perspective, the Grand Canyon and Great Barrier Reef show nature at its most awesome, but from an archeological perspective Angkor compares with the entire Egyptian, Mezo-American and Chinese dynasties in time frame but has the advantage of being in one relatively small, and therefore relatively easier to access, geographical area.If you are a photographer, interested in history, culture or engineering/architecture, or simply curious about how other people live and lived, this is must see place for you.You must be able, however, to ignore the heat, humidity, and disrespectful bus-loss of tourists if you are to fully appreciate the experience.If you have less than a week, I would recommend getting a private guide through a reputable agency to fully enjoy the experience, and let them show you some of the lesser publicised (and far less crowded) places.If you have more than a week I am truly jealous.I have been here multiple times and am still amazed every time I go. If A higher rating than "excellent" was available, this one deserves it.
It's alright if you are into archaeology. It was an ok trip - nothing special - I guess I am not too much into archaeology so I jsut about enjoyed it - nothing specail to brag about.

Amazing. So amazing & powerfull keep going on seen I visit 2nd times in this month!Never let people to stop find out / study them, so what a beautiful Empire of Cambodians! Ps: Rent whole day tuk tuk to survive your needed!

I consider this Archaeological Park one of the wonder of the world and a must see place to understand the kamer culture. I visited the park over 3 days with my wife.We bought a 3 days pass that cost $40 US per person. (one day pass is $20US but you would not have enough time).on the first day we visit Angkor Wat Temple and took us around 4 hours, many photos and going up to the main tower. The second day we visited Bayon and Baphuon and on the third we visited Ta Prohm. Every place is a marvel in itself so it is difficult to said which one I liked most. All I can said is I will treasure this visit more than most of my other travel around the world.

Unavoidably magical. A wonderful park that many of the temples are found in. It is a beautiful place that needs a minimum of 2 days to begin to appreciate. We split our visits with other activities so that we did not get to templed out. Slip slop, slap the sun cream and take plenty of water.
So many temples. This was my second visit. Take a tour and see some of the smaller temples that aren't as crowded. I did a bike trip.
Sublime!. Such a beautiful place, it is very atmospheric, I'd go so far as to say magical.It's a definite must.I must admit to falling for Cambodia...id love to visit again.

Once in a lifetime . As it was said that see Angkor Wat and die, I definitely do it once in a life time. My journey cannot completed without assistance of Mr. Doeurn Angkor, the took took driver. He planned and took us 3 to the temples with a little thoughtfulness of him he pointed small historical information for us. Even the trip started I can say at dawn until dusk, we did not feel so tired during a day. It was enjoyable to see the temples which are magnificent. I am still in doubt and have many questions to find out after came back. You may need 3-4 nights to stay there and read many history before visitting the temples. They await for your once in a life time visit.

Wonderful!. This is truly a world treasure. I'm so glad that so much is being done to preserve it and restore the temples for all to enjoy for many years to come. It is very well organized with excellent English-speaking guides and staff.

Must See. A must to do if you come to Siem Reap, please combine with the national museum and the smiles of Angkor show. You will get more out of the visit if the show and museum are done first. We only did the small circuit but was enough for one day. Look for my other reviews on Siem Reap and am happy to answer any questions if I'm able.
Amazing place to visit. We bought a three day pass so we could spend a lot of time exploring the different temples. Best to start out early to help avoid the heat.

The Angkor Archaeological Park is home to the magnificent temple ruins of Angkor. the historic sites in The Angkor Archaeological Park will be worth for your trip. Not also enriching your knowledge but also enlarging your photo-stock.

Temple Run to Temple Fun. An Angkor Pass serves as admission when visiting any of the temples within the Angkor Archeological Park (with exemption to Beng Mealea and Phnom Kulen which have a separate admission fee). Passes for several durations are available - 1 day at US$ 20; 3 days at US$ 40; or 7 days at US$ 60. Temples are afar from each other so better to hire a tuktuk (car or motodop are the other options). Bring a lot of water and snacks. Sun screen and glasses is a must also. Comfortable shoes and appropriate clothes are recommended.

Don't just visit Angkor Wat - so much more to see. The whole site is awash with history, I believe there are about 200 temples (or what remains of them) in the area. Take a guided tour they can show you the ruins without inteference form the larger tour groups

I neeeeeeed waaaaaaaaaaater. Yes suncream. Water all needed and please enjoy your stay. But make sure that you have water and suncream factor 50 on hot days A great day and we had chill out time after long shifts in the children's hospital

Excellent. I arrived there at 5a.m for sunrise. It was a little bit crowded. I have heard that sunsets gather less people.You can buy there some amazing art (always navigate the price). Some food places available but not great and quite expensive for Cambodian reality.

Nothing Compares!. My daughter and I bought a three day pass for $40 USD each but we only had two days in Siem Reap so were unfortunately rushed to see all we could at Ankor in the time we had.The first day we visited the outlying temple with only our Tuk Tuk driver as our guide which was excellent. He knew how to watch for the tourist busses and avoid the lineups. Dropped us off and then we would walk thru to the other side of the temple where he would pick us up and give us another water bottle. It was 39 degrees celsius the day we where here. We were often exploring an area and totally alone which was very special. Then on the second day we hired a official guide and the same tuk tuk driver to take us to the inner temples.$35 usd for the guide for the day and $15 for the tuk tuk driver for the day. A guide is a good idea as he can explain so much about the history that you could only get by doing a lot of research before your trip. I have so many incredible photos......Its a magnificent massive archeological site. Enjoy it if you can.

One of the best places to visit before your hang your boots. Buy a 3-day pass for the Angkor Archaeological Park (USD 40) and you won't forget the experience for a long time. Stunning piece of world heritage.
Worth visit. A great experience. A magnificent structure spread over 400 square kilometers. Life time experience. Originally dedicated to Hindu gods but later converted to Budhhist temples

Helpful, informative tuk-tuk driver for temple visiting. Based on a recommendation from another friend, I contacted Mr. Kim Eng ( lucky man.angkorwat1@gmail.com) and had a great time with him. I told him all the temples I wanted to visit, and he drove me around for 8 hours, including sunset, for about $18. You can get a tuk-tub driver for cheaper if you bargain, but Kim was a very gracious driver - he keeps a cooler of cold bottled water for his clients - and also a helpful local person with proficient English skills who will try to answer any/all of your questions. He sat down in the same table as me for lunch, and we talked more about his life in Cambodia and the country's political past and present situation. Of course, you should also do some of your own research. He's a good guy!
See my comments on Angkor Wat. The entrance fee helps to support the enormous task of restoration, buy a three day pass and spread your visit if you can, use the afternoons to relax or shop

A remarkable experience. Step back into the Khmer Empire, but give yourself time to wander though in a leisurely, unhurried pace. Choose early morning. If you haven’t prepared yourself by reading one of the well-written guide books like Lonely Planet’s. Engage a licensed guide who speaks English clearly and tell your guide if you want the highlights or great detail. There are hundreds of ancient Khmer sites scatted throughout Cambodia, Rarely visited favorites are the Koh Ker and Beng Mealea temples, two hours by car from Siem Reap City. Helicopter options are also available.

Is a huge park. Huge park full of different temples. Small, medium, big and huge. Plan your journey before heading in. Get your tickets 1 or 2 days before during peak seasons. you doen't want to ques for hours just for a ticket

Top 3 places on Earth. All wow effects everywhere! One of my favorite places on Earth!All the temples and walking through the jungle.Breathe the place, all its mysticism, such a special place! Everyone should go there once in their life... Except because that would mean we would have to share it more.

Stunning. Having visited Cambodia as a change from going all the way to Europe I didn't really take too much time to research Siem Reap. The temples looked interesting and I had not been there before so hey why not! Wow, the temples of the Angkor Wat complex were breath taking and just remarkable as to how they were formed and the history associated with them is amazing. Sunset at Angkor Wat is definately something for the bucket list. It was very hot and tiring exploring the temples but such an amazing place in the world.

World Heritage - Truly wonderful. Very touristy and I can imagine the crowd during the peak season. It is our first stop during our temple run and was awe struck with the temple's carvings! excellent site and discovery

Good for an angled view of Angkor Wat. It is a good spot to take great pictures of the Angkor Wat. I did not find it useful for anything more than that. This may be because my guide did not elaborate that bit.

Dont miss it!. The Angkor archaeological park is a spectacular place to visit and I cannot believe it isn't one of the 7 wonders of the world. Pick your temples carefully otherwise you will be tempted out very quickly. I recommend Bantreay Srei, Angkor Thom (Bayon), Ta Prohm (at sunrise) and Angkor Wat. An absolute must see but don't underestimate the size of the park - it is huge!!

Angkor (Last year). second time in 2 years this time with the kids , a wow place again you can never get enough of Cambodia if you need a tuktuk call Adam we have used him several times a great young man you can find him on whatsapp my wife and i have had contact with him over the last 2 years he can be you personal diver for you entire stay and have a friend if you need more space as we did

The Angkor Archaeological Park is the all inclusive group of temples including Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom and others. We had a tour guide and a driver with a SUV during the first 4 days of our stay and then took a tuk tuk for two more days of re-visits. They are a multitude of important and beautiful temples under the umbrella of the Angkor Archaelogical Park. Most noteable Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom which includes Bayon, Baphuon, the Elephant Terrace and others. There are also other very nice temples in the area and your only limitation is the time you have to visit and explore. Our tour was terrific and comprehensive and also includes temples out side of the Angkor Park. You have to have a pass to visit the Park and it is good for all temples in the Angkor Park (1-3-or 7 days). After our tour we used a tuk tuk to revisit Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom to leisurely photograph and take in the freatures and carvings of the temples. It was a very enjoyable experience.

Great attraction!. We spent 2 days in Angkor Archaelogical Park (40 USD/ticket for 2/3 days) and it was an amazing experience to visit all the old temples and buildings in the woods and learn about the history and culture of the Khmer Empire.We strongly recommend to book a tour guide (at least for the major sites like Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, ...) otherwise it will be just old temples with little meaning.

Stunninf. I'd heard a lot about Angkor and when I finally got to see it myself it went beyond my expectations. Not only are the ancient temples awe inspiring in their design and detail but it's also a really peaceful place to wander around. The grounds around the temples and the forest and reservoirs are also beautiful, with local families picnicking nearby. I didn't see the sunrise but getting their later suited me better because there were less crowds and I wasn't grumpy from getting up at 4am :)

Heaven on land. A hundred of reading, hearing and watching by TV is very different from what you will see when you come for visiting here. Please register your ticket to visit our heritage site and you will see many amazing places with smiling from people at countryside. Welcome to Cambodia.

Vast. Well worth the effort to get here. The vast site that is the Angkor Archaeological Park is a treat to behold. My personal favourites were:1/ Angkor Wat - for its sheer vastness and impressive feel. Yet so much of the structure is covered by intricate carvings.2/ Preah Khan - because I love the way nature and specifically the jungle over powers the temples. As Preah Khan is on the 'grand circuit' it isn't visited as much as the more busy temples on the 'small circuit'. And those fewer people add a richer feel to your experience. 3/ Ta Prom is the best example of nature and temple fighting fluidly in stone. More beautiful than Preah Kahn, but way more crowded too

This UNESCO World Heritage site is a must see!. Plan to spend at least two days enjoying the park. There is so much to see here.We spent two very busy days exploring the park and they were incredible. The second morning, as the sun rose and we took in the view over Angkor Wat, my then boyfriend proposed to me. The beauty of this backdrop, definitely made it all the more romantic. I'm not a morning person, but the 4:30 wake up to be there for sunrise was completely worth it.

a must see for any traveller with a buck list. The Archaeological park certainly presents a well rounded experience... hot steamy jungle.. moats, ponies, baloon ride.. bartering.. shopping.. and more photos than your camera will cope with.. certainly Disneyland for any archaeologist. Be prepared for the constant streem of locals / drivers / buskers trying to sell their stuff.. water.. take your own.. and plenty.. bathrooms? - few and far between.. suncreen.. slather it on thickly.. and an umbrella for the odd shower...

Preparation is key. Firstly, don't think in terms of visiting 'Angkor Wat' because although it is the biggest and (arguably) the most well-known of the Temples, it is not THE destination. The Angkor Archaeological Park covers some 400 kilometres and is made up of many temples, though you're likely to visit in a radius of 6-15 kilometres, depending on which route and temples you choose to visit. Keep in mind that some of the lesser known and smaller ones - the wondeful Baksei Chamkrong being a classic example - are often over-looked by the frenzy of tourists and you may even be fortunate enough to get time alone, as we did, to bask in the history and spirituality.I suggest a 3 day pass @ US40 (as at March 2016). This allows plenty of time to see everything without putting you under pressure. The pass is valid for 7 days which do not have to be consecutive. We skipped a day in-between to recuperate after two nearly 40 degree celcius days and it was enough to recharge the batteries. Do use an English (or other) speaking guide, and a tuk-tuk driver. Both are invaluable. It's about US$30-35 per day for the guide and US$20 for the tuk-tuk and driver. Make sure you understand your guide's English. Some are not as proficient in English and can lead to everything being lost in translation. Don't be shy about insisting on a guide you clearly understand. Talk with your guide BEFORE commencing and plan out your days - what route you'll take, and specifically ask to avoid the circuitous routes used by the majority of guides and visitors as working counter clock-wise can mean you might be lucky enough to arrive at a less crowded time. Understanding the history of what you're seeing brings so much more to the experience, from the architecture itself to why the face off Buddha was obliterated on so many facades. Do take the opposite gate or entrance to what's recommended in guidebooks. You'll be surprised by how small tips like this help beat the crowds. I will never forget the timeless feeling of entering Angkor Wat from the rear East gate - and being the ONLY person there. A fluke, yes, but something that isn't even a remote possibility by heading in the front way!!  As said, both a knowledgeable guide and tuk-tuk driver are invaluable. The Park is huge, it's dusty and dirty, it's breathlessly hot, and the last thing you want is to trudge kilometres between temples, unless your impervious to the searing heat and love trekking, of course! We saw many very tired and unhappy visitors doing the unhappy walk. Do take lots of cold water, and pre-moistened towelettes to regularly freshen up. We were at the park at 8am each morning, and finished by 1pm, avoiding the hottest time of day. Siem Reap is extremely hot and will zap your strength, even the fit and healthy, and regardless of whether your young or older. But its rewards are a once in a lifetime experience.And if you check your map, you might see the Baksei Chamkrong Temple, and you just might climb those extraordinarily precarious stairs with both your feet and hands, and you too might just be blown away by the stunning reclining Buddha hidden in the inner chamber. And if your especially blessed, you might just have ten minutes alone there to feel the spirit of the Khmer ... and your own self ... Written in loving memory of DJK, my spiritual companion on this journey.

Morning visit . Sunrise view in the park was an attraction . Just being in the crowd during sunrise was an exciting event. One has to spend for more than an hour to capture the good sunrise view of the park.

Beautiful experience. Highly recommend the early morning sunrise. This is a great archeological site. The tuk-tuk driver from our hotel got us pre-dawn for one of the greatest views of the temple reflected in water. We came back again after breakfast and spent the entire day around this visiting Ta Prohm and Bayon temple

Absolutely Amazing. I entered for the sunrise over Angkor Wat so very early in the morning there were hundreds if not thousands of people waiting to go in luckily i was there in the first few. The staff were great and quick to get everyone in. I loved it but sadly no more time to get back but i will definately travel here again to revisit with family and friends it is Beautiful.
Fantastic!. Such an impressive place to be! Make sure you'll be there at least 2 days. The smaller and lesser known temples are just as, or even more, impressive than the most popular temples.
Classic photo memory. Like the rest of the ruins, this is so impressive and makes a real memory photo with the water reflection behind you
Fantastic. This is an historical site that everybody should have on their bucket list. Guided tours are recommended so that you get the historical context of the site.

Too beautiful for words!!. I had no idea of what to really expect before we visited Angkor Archaeological Park but it was a place that I had vowed to visit and I was not disappointed. We were in Siem Reap for six days and so purchased a 3 day "Angkor pass" to the park. There are 1 ($20 USD), 3($40 USD) and 7 ($60 USD) day options. One day would not have been sufficient. Three days was a good choice for us but we could have easily used the 7 day pass as there were many places we just did not get the opportunity to explore and in hindsight this may have allowed us to better pace ourselves. The heat is unrelenting and exhausting and the terrain at many of the temples is uneven and sometimes steep with numerous steps. It is advisable to visit in the cooler parts of the day: early morning or late afternoon and always carry water and wear comfortable shoes. To say that the temples are simply amazing is an understatement. Until you see Angkor Wat in person you just cannot fathom it's actual size and complexity. The surrounding parkland is quite lovely and watching the sunrise over Angkor Wat is definitely a must. The other temples are considerably smaller but each unique and beautiful. They all tell their own story and you really need the time to be able to take it all in and really enjoy the reverence of such historical sites. We are definitely planning another visit, especially as we now know how to make the most of it.

Great park, do not understand the open-close schedule of temples?. We visited the temples in Angkor Wat park with a photography tour, so aimed for early morning or late afternoon times for visiting the temples and ruins. The park opens 5:30-17:30, but individual temples open later. It looks like the park is optimised for large party tour operators, not specialised individual visitors, like photographers...I would recommend going back to opeing the park AND all temples at the same time. This allows people to select which temple to visit at what time, spreading the visitors accross the park. Now we all have to follow in the big tour footsteps... We see more people than temples...This was a bit disappointing.

True wonders!. I have always wanted to visit Angkor Wat. Have heard so much about it when I was still studying and also from friends who have already visited. I'm very glad I did went with 3 of my best friends as we have enjoyed 3 days in Siem Reap. I think it would be best to buy the one day pass ($20) prior to your visiting day so you can go see the sunrise which was by the way amazing! We arranged a tuktuk ride from our hotel the day we arrived to buy the pass and we dropped by Angkor Wat to see the sunset. We rented a van (somewhere around $30-40 for about 6 hours, to and fro) from our hotel and we were picked up at around 5-5.30am the next day to see the sunrise.
