I agree with the other people on here, it would be advisable to get a tour guide ($15) to orient you of the best spots to take pictures of the sunrise, of course the history and some added knowledge bout the place and culture. Angkor Wat is truly a beauty. I was so amazed as to how the temple was built with so much intricacies. Attention to detail. Very impressive. Not only the Angkor Wat; Angkor Thom, the Bayon temple, Ta Phrom and a lot more is worth seeing. So make sure to wear comfortable clothing as the weather is too hot plus a pair of very comfortable shoes or sandals as there are tons of walking. Sunblock and lots of water. Also follow dress codes as you are visiting different temples.

Awesome. Angkor Wat was amazing- totally beautiful and just amazing. We went for sunrise which was totally worth getting up for. It was amazingly hot too though, so make sure you have water with you. A LOT of water. I did enjoy seeing all the sights, but I didn't like all the vendors yelling at me from across the way. Definitely this is a half day or all day thing to do.

Hire a tuk tuk of find a bike or bicycle...this is vast. One does not get how vast Angkor archaeological park is when one is not in it. Reading from the books didn't really do justice. The big structures are perhaps somewhat walkable, but other than that, nothing really is...it is hot and humid even in winter so some kind of bike or bicycle options are highly recommended. Buses can't get into some of the temple structures so smaller vehicle is recommended.

Incredible. I've seen nothing like this before. A truly incredible and unique place on earth. There is so much to take in when visiting.3 day passes are available for 40 USD. We only did the 1 day and I wish we spent more time.It will be hot so being lots of water and sunscreen. There are a lot of markers nearby to stock up on supplies as well.It will be busy so expect it. Also consider taking a guide as there is a lot of information. They are likely relatively inexpensive and very friendly.
Spectacular!!. This is one of the must visit places in the world. In my opinion the most impressive temple complex in the world

It goes on and on and on.... Wow....it's the Wandering Yank here. Mrs. Yank and I recently spent 3 days touring the Angkor complex and environs, with a guide and driver, and it was AMAZING. There are the well-known temples of course, but the lesser-visited ones have their own charms, each is unique, plus they'll be much less crowded.A couple of recommendations:Start early, especially in the hot season (April is the hottest), and break by early afternoon. It's hot and a bit strenuous, so you'll be ready for a break and a swim after lunch. Don't burn yourself out by trying to see too much in one day.Have a competent guide. We had a guidebook, but it would not have been nearly as full an experience had we just wandered around the site by ourselves. Because of him, we visited several temples that were not highlighted in the guidebook, but were still unique and memorable, plus there were so few people, we practically had the sites to ourselves. Guides are not very expensive - we spent maybe $120 on our hotel-arranged guide for 3 days, and it was very much worth it. The guides all appear to be officially sanctioned, since they wear similar shirts.Have a great time, and 2 thumbs up!!!
Angkor park. Wonderful place to visit. Unique and truely amazing. A must for a bucket list. Recommend the sunrise tour and spending as much as time as possible at the site.

A must see. From the constructions and the works we can see today, we could learn that the people in the Angkor dynasty were people of wisdom and courage. It is a shame that we know too little about the history of this once most brilliant kingdom in the South East Asia. One should try to learn about the past and present of this country besides admiring on the works which their people had done a thousand years ago.
Great place to visit. Beautiful grounds with lots of things to see. Pay for a guide as they will explain all the history and it's really interesting.

Angkor Wat. A Must See ' Jewels in the Jungle .Amazing Bas - Reliefs The Churning of the Ocean of Milk > The smiling Apsara among hundreds of more ; Beautiful Pond with Shiva reflection at high noon .My Trip number 6 in the past 10 years ,

Wonderful Heritage Site. This is a great site to visit. An early morning visit is recommended as it gets very hot and you are out in the open a lot. If you have a hiking stick, take it. Some of the steps are very steep and don't have any railing.

Great . The park is not just a world heritage site but a significant income source for hundreds of Cambodians hocking various wares, foods and drinks outside temple grounds. I was personally less bothered by all the vendors than I was the large your groups. Numerous bus loads of tourists walking the park in herds make it difficult for individuals, couples and families to enjoy all the sites. I think it'd be appropriate to control access and limit the number of large groups per day. Going early in the morning provides the best opportunity to enjoy the temples. Seeing the smaller temples and less trafficked temples is definitely worth the time.

A must see and do for all travellers. Whenever you plan to visit SEA, don't miss Angkor! It is worthwhile to buy the 3 Day Pass. Get yourself an experienced Tuk-Tuk driver, hire him for 3 days and explore these temples on your own. The Pass is valid for Banteay Srei, too.

The 'real' Angkor - not just a single temple!. The Archaeological Park is what 'should' be advertised, as Angkor Wat is just a small temple in comparison to the magnitude of land this ancient city once occupied! Worth several days exploring (at least) - you'll be baffled at just how big this ancient city was!!

A true wonder.. Give yourselves time with this place, it's huge and it's worth it. A magnificent vast park, you'll need wheels, full of wonderful cities and temples from not so long gone civilizations. The beauty of the buildings encompassed with wild tropical nature is a sight worth to see. Enjoy this place with proper clothing, hat, sunscreen, lots of water and snacks.

Don't go back home, yet...!. If you have flown to Cambodia and have visited the Angkor Wat in Siem Reap, you definitely have to visit the Angkor Archaeological Park also... Don't go back home, yet...!

Very interesting. The entire area of the park is wonderful. There are so many temples to visit, lots of locals to talk to, to buy things from and to just watch. I think the best way to get around is to hire a car with a driver as it can be very hit and it is nice to get into the air conditioning for a break.

What an experience!. What an experience, one of its kind! A definite must see if you're travelling to Cambodia. A wonderful lifetime memory. You really need to visit the remainings of every single temple across this beautiful medieval Khmer empire, so that you can experience different levels of intimacy in regaining contact with this rich though difficult and stormy Cambodian history. Dedicate minimum three days to see all the necessary sites and don't forget to dine in the plentiful open-air Cambodian restaurants across the park so that you can experience the richness of flavours of traditional Khmer dishes.

Memorable experience. We had a tuk-tuk driver meet us at our hotel at 5am to take us to the ticket booth to queue for our photo pass for our one day ticket - $20 each. He then took us to each of the main Temples requested and we were able to leave bottles of water with him for our trip. He had us back to our Hotel by 1pm and that was plenty time for us as we were shattered by the time we finished! He charged us $20. We had no guide but there were many about and your Hotel could probably organise one for you if you felt it was needed. Obviously there are many more smaller sites to visit further afield and for this you would need the three day pass!

A tick on the bucket list. Angkor Wat was the most amazing experience for our family of 5. Even the heat did not dampen the experience. We visited 3 times, at sunset, sunrise and then during the day. It was breathtaking and something we had wanted to do for years. We had a fantastic guide that took us everywhere and was very knowledgeable. We ahd a fantastic lunch in the café opposite the entrance too.

Nice Park. Visit Angkor Wat first. The park has alot of stalls of local handicrafts. Apparently, commercial establishments from outside are not allowed to sell their wares here. The people who sell in this park have been doing so for generations. We were also told that what they sold here was much cheaper than the outside. We had no way of verifying this, as we were not there to shop. You can bargain and get scarfs for as low as USD2. Purchased pretty hats for $USD2.

Highlight of my life. Angkor is heaven for those who appreciate the earth, archeology, trees, spirituality, months, Southeast Asia, hiking, and exploring. It is stunning and shocking. Angkor is truly the highlight of my travel life and perhaps generally, my life.We hired a tuktuk driver through our hotel for our entire stay in Cambodia. Apparently included in that was him taking us to and throughout Angkor for about three days. I do recommend going for about three days if you want to see the main "attractions" (i.e. stunning works of man and nature that will blow your mind). Our driver also provided water and waited for us after each temple, restaurant, etc. I do recommend a driver; without this, we would have probably only been able to see 1/3 of the grounds we did with the driver. He was fabulous.Other practical advice? Dress modestly (i.e. zip off pants, although nerdy, allowed shorts when we wanted and pants when needed). Wear a hat, bring tons of water, train your bladder to grow [general rule in SEASIA] because it's hard to find a bathroom). It is ridiculously hot. Absolutely worth it; I recommend it to everyone and plan to visit again in life.

Sunrise on Angkor Wat. A very special morning watching the sunrise come up over Angkor Wat, a dream come true. This was an awesome experience one I will always cherish. However the rest of the day that we spent at Angkor Wat was not without its difficulties. For one we did not know it was the Khmer New Year when we booked our travels. On the day of our visit to Angkor Wat thousands of Cambodians from all over Cambodia come to the temple to pray, enjoy the festivities and free concerts, even the King comes to Angkor Wat. We also did not realise (our fault) that it is the hottest time of the year in April and coupled with that there has been no rain from November last year causing it to be very dusty all over Siam Reap. The result of all these issues was that we were there at Angkor Wat in the 45 degree heat ( not sure what the humidity was), amongst thousands and thousands of local people, wit the red dust settling into our hair, face and clothes. The temples were amazing and the experience quite difficult. My husband had heat exhaustion and I felt dizzy while we were amongst the throngs. My suggestion is make sure you check dates and weather!
Amazing Historical Place!!!!. Magnicent architecture and design from 100's of years ago. It is a live look at distant times which in itself is magical.

Get a driver. Distances are not small, no matter what it looks like on the map. We thought we could simply walk around, eventually get to the temples and enjoy them. However, the park is 7km out of the central area and it is much better to get tuktuk. Plan ahead and decide where you want to go, since you can only do one tiny fraction in a day. I suggest three days if you are really interested. If you just want to see the most important things because thes is UNESCO heritage site, then one day is enough. Some places you cannot enter unless you are dressed properly so think about that. There is no reading or any written explanation during the visit, so if you want to know more, get a proper guide or at least visit the museum first.You can buy water along the way. Some of the stairs are quite steep.

Wonders of Angkor Park- My Experience. Angkor Archaeological park s massive and you need atleast 3 Days to cover few if the main attractions . I covered some of the main must visit places in my three day trip..Hiring Tuk Tuk for a Day to Angkor Site : 15~20 USD , for long trip add 10 USD.Water bottle: 2.5 Litr = 1USD.Have sufficient water bottles with you as water bottles cost 3$USD in the Angkor park, cocunut water 2$USD .so that you may not get dehydrated in travelling to temples as most of them requires tiring walk and climbing steps...also carry fruits and biscuits..Plz wear coolers and apply sun screen to prevent your skin face from sun burns..and carry wet tissues and soft towels as you ll sweat like anything in humid climate.Umberalla and cap is a must to be taken.Wear nice shoes to protect ur feet .Wear light cotton dress preferably white and light coloured..There are restaurants near opposite to the Terrace of Elephants Leper Kings, basic lunch cost 6$USD min for a basic lunch ..I has chikn shrimp fried rice for 5.5$USD..it has wide range of foods and your tuk tuk driver may assist you ..Best Season to visit : November to February , but the season extend throught the year.Angkor Archaelogical Park Entrance Ticket : Tickets can be purchased at the main entrance of Angkor road..Please keep the pass safe from getting tor as it is required to be presented at every site temples entrance .Angkor Archaelogical Park Opening Hours : 5:30AM to 5:30 PM All Days.1-Day Pass : 20USD$3-Day Pass : $40USD for visits within a week, 7-Day Pass : $60USD for visits within a monthMy Angkor wat Archaelogical Site Tour Itenerary :Day One -Short Circuit order of Visit :Round Distance: 19 Km1. Angkor Wat2. Bahkeng3. Angkor Thom Gate4. Giant Bayon Temple 5. Phimeanakas6. Baphuon7. Terrace of Leper Kings8. Terrace of Elephants9. Royal Palace Grounds10. Banteay Kedi11. Chau Say Tevoda12. Ta Kaeo13. Ta PhromDay 2 Big Tour order of Visit: Round distance: 39 Km1. Preah Khan2. Prasat Prei3. Neak Pean4. Ta Som5. East Mebon6. Pre Roup7. Angkor National Museum8. Night Market WalkDay 3 order of Visit:Round distance: 87 Km1. Bantea Srei-Its A must Visit Place2. Land Mine Museum3. Butterfly Musem4. Bantea Samre5. Rolus Group Temples: 1)Lolei , 2)Preah Ko , 3)Bakong.In my trip of 3 day I tried and covered maximum all must visit places.Trip to Angkor sure can be made esily on a budget if we plan well ahead.Here s my break up of expense.3 Day Angkor Pass : 40$Lunch for 3 days : 14$Tuk tuk 3 days: 15+15+28(Banteay Srei long trip):::> 58 $Cocunut water :4$Breakfast my hostel offered free simple bread and omlet. Also my hotel offered me free pick up from Siem Reap Airport.Street foods ,BBQ : 6$Accommodation : 3 nights:18$(Hostel)Dinner 3 nights : 4 + 6+3 :: 13$Purchase shopping : 15 $Feet massage:: 3$Flight ticket :66$ from Kuala Lumpur Air Asia.Giant Isis Bus tickets to Phnom Penh :16$--online booking, direct booking 15$.
the reason you go to siem reap. to see angkor was my dream sinds i was a young boyand its a dream ,see it in daylight and go back for sunset or sunrise

A Must Visit in Cambodia. If your visiting Siem Riep, you have to visit the temples and Unesco Heritage Site. It is 400 sq. km and has over 1000 temples. Just spectacular. A private guide is the way to go.

A lot more than just Angkor Wat. Angkor Archaeological Park is one of the places that should be on every bucket list. It's not just for history or architecture buffs. Its grandness will impress everyone. If you are not into this kind of things you should still buy a one day pass and spend the day visiting Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm and Bayon. If you are interested in this kind of things you should buy a three day pass and visit all of the temples. If you are a total freak when it comes to temples you should buy a seven day pass and just go crazy. Explore every single corner of the temples, play Indiana Jones or Tomb Raider (just remember, this places are sacred), get to know everything there is to now about Angkorian period and also visit the temples that aren't located at the main park (Banteay Srei, Beng Mealea Phnom Kulen,...) Three day pass is good for any three days within a seven day period and seven day pass is good for any seven days within a thirty day period.

Well, well!. Lot´s of old stones, but it is impressive. We hired our normal tuktuk driver to take us there, at 9AM. Saw 3 temples in 1,5 hour - it is pretty much "same same - but different".HYou have to see it, but in order to use lot´s og hours or even days - you have to have a special interest in this!Ended at Red Piano Bar - much better.

UNESCO has done an amazing job.. Dont miss the opportunity to visit this park while you can. It is truly an amazing experience. So much history and art. And it is big so be prepared to walk, wear light and loose clothing and take lots of water.

It's best when you try to avoid the crowds. You can't visit Cambodia without visiting the Angkor Archaeological Park. It is wonderful and large. The sheer size of the park means that when you see crowds, you just move to the next temple or site and avoid them while still being able to enjoy the park. The crowds do destroy some of the main sites so be prepared to have people push you out of the way or stand in front of you or talk really loudly right next to you. It shows how popular the park is but just be prepared. I hired a guide on the second day and asked to avoid the crowds. We still saw all the main attractions but entered them from the side or back entrances or during the slow times of the day while some of the larger groups had stopped for lunch etc. I had the bas-reliefs at Angkor Wat all to myself because we went in the middle of the day but it was still nice and cool because it was all undercover. I would strongly recommend requesting to avoid the crowds because I still felt like I saw everything (and maybe even more) but at my own pace and in the peace and quiet.
You'll see it when you do temples . This is a beautiful area near the popular temples. It is beautiful and many families will be enjoying the vast open area.

Some Temples May Be Crowded. Go early to avoid large crowds, spend a few mornings, and then relax during your afternoons. I recommend a three-day pass. Hire a tuk-tuk driver to take you to various temples during the three days. The driver will be able to recommend where to visit; you may want to look at a map so that you know which ruins you would like to visit. Be sure to visit Angkor Wat, Bayon, Preah Khan, and Pre Rup. At Pre Rup, there are wooden stairs on the side if you think you cannot handle the front steps.

Massive !!!. You gotta see this place to believe. The temples are amazing and massive! It's hard to imagine how it was built by bare hands and took generations to build. You simply have to see it and expect to be awed!
Awesome place. Its just a place you must to go before thinking of leaving Siem Reap...i sugest getting a bike to ride around

Siem Reap = Angkor Archaeological Park. We came to Siem Reap only to visit this park ;-) lovely to see all the temples inside what used to be the forest (is it still a forest?). we always enjoyed our trip every morning to this site on our tuk-tuk... fresh air, trees...so wonderful and enjoyable ;-)

Excellent Unesco Heritage. An amazing experience to see the Unesco Heritage, excellent site to view sunrise and sunset, although temperature is high, hot and humid, these did not stop tourist coming in to this place.

Sunrise. We loved visiting the site it was outstanding. Don't get up for the sunrise it was very disappointing after waiting an hour and a half for a smog filled sky with a little red ball trying to penetrate the smoke filled sky, stay in bed and enjoy the site later.

Angor Wat. It is a spectacular park. Many temples to visit. It is hard to decide which one is my favorite. We visited some temples early in the morning and some in the afternoon. Although it was very hot during the afternoon we enjoyed those most as there were no crowds. We did not go with an organized tour but rather arranged with our hotel for a private car and tour guide so we could spend as much time as we wanted at any one temple

World Famous Historical Site. Angkor is massive, these archaeological sites are from the period of the Khmer Empire, and were built between the 9th and the 15th century. The temples of Angkor are on the UNESCO World Heritage list. Visitors from around the world flying to Siem Reap just to see Angkor. Today, local Cambodians in Siem Reap are living and depending on tourism

A highlight of any visit to Cambodia. The archeological park is amazing. It's a unique opportunity to learn about how these fascinating structures were built, and what is being done to preserve them. It's hard to understand the scale until you've visited. Even then you have to wrap your head around the fact that 800 or so years ago the Khmer empire was powerful and the Angkor area was a major regional power supporting more than a million people.You need a pass to get into the park. They checked at every temple. Passes come in one, three and seven day increments. Three days ($40) was about right for us. One day probably would not have been enough. But, you've got options to pick something that fits your pace.
No words are enough to describe. Be there to get the feel of this place...it's definitely a one time opportunity in life to relive the history.............

Ancient history meets modern history. To look at the serenity on the faces of the statues of the ancient monuments belies the modern atrocities that happened under their very faces in very recent times makes one seriously consider the condition of man. Even now, today, about 6 people are killed or maimed by the momumentous amount of land mines that were scattered throughout the 1500 temples that make up this archeological with no plans kept of where they were placed. And yet the Cambodian people who survive on less than $600 per year per person have some of the warmest smiles and biggest welcomes in SE Asia.
Amazing Place for sunrise. We spent 2 hours to see this place it amazing and i never seen another place like this place. we when there for sunrise.
great. Great complex. Its one of this places which you have to see before You die. Its on UNESCO list so you have to be there
A must when visiting the region, highlight. A must when visiting the region. This is a highlight of any visit in Cambodia. The site as well as the temple are magnificent.

Easy access tourism to an amazing wonder. Access all sites for a day for $20. Well worth the value. Three day passes also available. Hire a van or tuk tuk or ride a bike or take your time and hike the area. Plenty of ways to experience the area. Tons of decent restaurants near each temple. Guides are available for hire for the day or available at each site. Govt trained and licensed tour guides are present a each temple. They are wearing tan shirts with patches and generally run about $15. Worth investing to really understand what you're looking at...you came all this way.

Wonderful place bucket list material. This place is a must visit go with a small group guide wonderful an interesting history. The size of the temples will leave you wondering how these temples were built and how many were involved. Very hot place go early in the morning and take plenty of water you will not be disappointed.

Amazing place . We visited for the day as part of a cycle charity challenge and this place is just amazing! Take time to explore the temples and view the perfect scenery.Also take the tuc tuc at dawn to see the sunrise, memories that will stay forever.

Definitely a great place to visit! . One of the must-dos in Cambodia is waking up before the sun to witness the sunrise over Angkor Wat Temple. Although the idea to wake up earlier than the birds might sound is not too exciting but it's truly worth the effort! The all encompassing stillness of the sunrise here is definitely a magnificent moment, a unique experience and a fantastic motif! #NoFilter #NoEditing #NothingBeatsASonyShot #AmazingCambodia #Travel #EmbracingLife #Blessed #Grateful #Kolipoki_23 #SiemReap #AngkorWat #TakingABreak #Vacation #LifeAt30 #Temples #Monks #Xperia #TrulyAsia #7WondersOfTheWorld #TooGoodToBeTrue #TheSweetestThing #StressReliever

Magnificent temples - worth at least one full day. Go with a wide brimmed hat, a big bottle of water and,the services of a guide. These are some of the most amazing temples you'll ever get to see. Apparently, prices are set to rise in the near future (perhaps to cover some of the repair /renovation costs). Do get a guide as you'll miss some of the hidden stories of these awesome temples.

The main attraction in Siem Reap. Siam Reap's growing popularity is all due to this place. This is must visit place. There are many temples in Angkor Wat temple complex. To enjoy all the temples one needs to spend 2 or three days. Start early in the morning to avoid big tourists group..
Treat Yourself to History. wow. it is still hard to describe the feeling of wandering these ruins, riding an elephant up to the sunset view, exploring the different temples. wow.

vast and hot. Here you need to have an umbrella or something to cover your skin. It's a bit hot walking under the heat of the sun. Bring lots of water and make sure to hudrate so often. I met a peddler selling pashmina very cheap and ref magnets .

Amazing place, so interesting!. We hired a private guide and airconditioned car for a two day tour, which I would recommend as there is so much to see and the guides know the history so well. They also make sure you see the most interesting parts. You could not possibly see it all trying to do it yourself. We found it a very hot and exhausting couple of days and it does involve a lot of walking including stairs, so we're very glad we changed our minds on doing the 3 days.

The park is HUGE!. Having nearly all the temples covered by one admission fee is a real boon to travelers. It cost $40 for a three day pass which is a great deal. The park is enormous and I found a tuk tuk to be a good way to get around. They charge by the kilometer driven and not by time. It was $17 for the short trip and $25 for the long one. The driver had it all worked out but I changed it so I saw what I wanted before accepting his suggestions. Either way would be good. Start as early as possible- the heat made me quit most days by 2pm.

Awesome - St Paul's Cathedral fits in a corner . We only had one full day from 8am hotel pick up to 4.30pm return - such a vast area n walking around Angkor Wat late afternoon we took 35 photos with concern for mobile phone battery life. So if a couple use a phone in the morning and another in the afternoon.The detailed engraving is amazing - not some bland repeating images but story after story. An example is the little pig behind a cartwheel !Our tour included a stop for food (1 hour) n we needed it, so if you can afford it book a a/c car with driver and a private guide.The cold water for walking around the buildings is necessary n the cold wipes are a blessing when back to your car to move to the next amazing spot.To consider when this series of monuments was built it's amazing n St Paul's Cathedral - London would fit in one corner. Stonehenge is a embarrassment in comparison.No selection of photos can do justice to a place that must be visited - then relax with cheap 0.5$ beers in Siem Reap - ENJOY

The overall park for Angkor Wat and it's surrounding temples. Confession: We didn't do much reading before our trip. This was a wish list item and we were able to tag 24 hours in Siem Reap onto our trip. It was well worth it. If you haven't read this elsewhere, the park is MASSIVE. You need a bike (and good legs), a Tuk-Tuk, or a vehicle. We hired a Tuk-Tuk and a guide and had no regrets. The wind on our face and open air views of the trees and temples was the way to go. incredible history with awe-inspiring temples that leave you asking questions about why and how.

Extraordinary.. There's so many levels to Angkor Park - it could take a lifetime and lots of immersion in the civilization that brought the idea of heaven on earth in this form. Explore both the lesser-known sites as well the the more famous ones. Go early or stay late or take a tour or just sit and 'feel it'. The approach that I used, to try to encompass this area, was to do a chronological 'tour', starting with the earlier sites and working our way through the various eras. It made sense, visually and helped us see the differences and growth of Angkor area. I'd go back in an instant!

Beautiful Park filled with Historical Landmarks. Spend some time wandering the grounds of the Angkor Archaeological Park and you will step back in time! There is so much to see and do it's well worth the price of admission. My suggestion is to hire a tour guide to get the full experience and information about the park, culture and history of Cambodia... Well work it!

Truly one of the seven wonders. Give your self time to see it though rushing. A bit like seeing the Nile sites all in one place. AK is a staggering collection of temples and monuments scattered over a large area. The park is well organized with controlled entry points and ticket checking. Go early on your first day or 5-5.30pm the day before and buy your pass to avoid queues.The Park contains a series of temples and cities that the Khmer king/emperors built over 200-300 years. Ther are several more outside the Park, some covered by the same ticket. The challenge is to pick what to see. Tour guides tend to have a set piece that includes tourist traps like the villages on stilts, a silk farm and a dance, so it is good idea to do some research. A 3 day tour allows you to see good selection at a reasonable pace. Day 1 could start at the step outside the Park which are the beginnings of the empire and are also beautiful (Rolous Group, Banteay Srei) and then work in towards the final of Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat. Do more than just the "top ten" style tour. The quieter places are just as interesting and let you feel the place. Start early so you get a lot done in the morning before the heat, retreat to the hotel and pool, go back as the heat starts to drop. Best gear is trekking lightweight long sleeve shirts and long pants, as well as a UV hat (not cap). The more skin you show the worse you heat exhaustion and dehydration - covering up actually cools you and is also respectful.People obsess about sunrise and sunset, especially at Angkor Wat. To be honest it is overrated, especially sunrise. What's more they look at AW from the West son you dont get the effect of the light coming up on the temples. Sunset is better but again thee is a huge focus on AW and one other site when many quieter spots can be found.Going with an air conditioned car is a big plus, especially if it is hot and when the sun is fully up. Tuc-tucs give you a breeze but less respite. Guides sound like they largely say the same thing unless you go upmarket and get someone who is clearly continually upgrading. So in general the choice was flexibility. We used Tes Chaya +855 92 999 051 chaya220001@gmail.com. In his mid-40s he is flexible, knowledgeable and a good price. his SUV is a bit older than several you will see but is just fine. As with most Cambodians he will not be very forceful about telling you what makes sense in our suggestions but if you tease him out he will make good suggestions.

Can be done in one day (save $20). A 1 day pass is $20 while a 3 day pass is $40 and is valid for any 3 days within 1 week. They allow you to enter for free to see sunrise as long as you buy a ticket that you will use in the upcoming week. You're better off buying a 1 day ticket and getting a super early start with the sunrise and hitting all the places throughout the day, ending at 6PM with sunset. Wish we had gotten this advice and saved $20!

breathtaking. I have visited here several times and each time i find something more magical about the place! Best way to see the temples? by bike FOR SURE! Be sure to take lots of water as the sun bakes you! Also, make sure you cover up for the temples as a sign of respect to the Cambodian culture - this means knees and shoulders covered :)

Awesome. A must if you visit Cambodia. The archeological place is huge and you can find many different things to discover. You can expect to find hundreds of tourist everywhere, so if you are looking to take a good picture you have to be prepared to wait long time.Recommended

Try to avoid tour buses.. This is a must visit whilst in Cambodia however these places can get very crowded with noisy tourists. Whenever we managed to dodge the crowd it was magic. ...then the true energies of the place came through.

So many really interesting temples, more than only Angkor Wat. We bought a 3 day pass, we needed really 3 days to visit most of the temples. All of them are different and worth to visit. There are jungle temples, mountain temples, beautifull decorated temples, architectural interesting temples

3 days was great.. I just finished a 3 day pass on bicycle. Day 1, rode the big circuit: Banteay Kdei, Pre Rup, Preah Khan and many more. Day 2 rode out to Bantey Srei. Day 3 small circuit with Ta Prom, Victory gate, East gate, the Terraces, Bayon, Angkor Wat and many smaller temples. Amazing photos everywhere you look. I think Angkor is an amazing place but the tour buses bring crowds everywhere while the tuk-tuks like to push the pace and get home early, that's why I think bicycle is best. Go at your own pace, in the order you want with plenty of time to explore or even just relax and admire the views. When finished, go get a massage in town. You have earned it.

A Must See! Huge Park with an Interesting Back Drop-Angkor Wat. This is an enormous park, home to Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Angkor Thom and many more temples, forests, lakes, towns etc. We got the $40 3 day tourist pass (they take a digital photo and you are checked at every entrance) so be sure to keep it in a safe place and due to the scope, heat and throngs of tourists, 3 days is a minimum.The sites are downright amazing dating back from the 12th and 13th centuries, each taking sevreal hours to view adequately. Transportation of some sort is a must. While Angkor Wat is the star, the supporting cast is amazing!

You will visit while in Cambodia. If you're planning a trip to Cambodia and not planning on visiting the Angkor Archaeological Park, you are doing something wrong.The park is home to Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Angkor Thom and so on and is one of the highlights from our 4 months of travel. The Taj Mahal did not compare to the beauty which lies inside the Angkor Archaeological Park.There are pros and cons, crowds and hidden gems. There is so much to do and see that people can buy a 7 day pass and still wish they had more time. For lack of funds we got the 1 day and while we saw enough to satisfy us, we wish we could have got the 3 day and spent another couple days exploring the park.Altogether, go here. Not much more to say besides have fun!

Love it. I had the opportunity to visited Angkor archaeological park. I recommend to buy the 3 days pass instead of one day. Too many people and take time to visited all temple. I hired a tuk tuk for $20 dollars a day.
Amazing.. Make sure visit some of the more outlying/smaller temples. The park is well and appropriately looked after with good facilities without swamping it with traders or info.
Temple Ruins!!. We love checking out temple ruins &this whole park is well worth the visit. All the temples in this area are interesting.
Best Temple. In Siem Reap, has many temple and all the temple are very nice. at night time very pretty at the pub street or night market

Amazing Place. Well worth the trip (half way around the world!). Not only are the temples amazing, but so is the forest around it. And, the water views (lakes, moats, etc.) are astounding.Far larger than you might think; some youngsters were on bicycles, but even in a TukTuk the distance were large.Not for those with bad joints -- some of the steps required a second person for me to climb. Some of the walking is like scrambling over boulders. Worth the effort, though!

Amazing Angkor!!. The multitude of temples all share similar locations, but each has something which makes it unique. Your first stop will be to get your Pass, it will bear your digital photo and is printed on thicker than normal paper. As you would expect the country is hot, you will sweat, and there is a fairly good chance that your pass will become damaged, so pack a plastic holder with lanyard, it will preserve the pass and stop you fumbling to find it on the many occasions that you will be asked to show it.
Amazing. It is a huge complex of ancient temples, much bigger that I expected. You need a transportation to move between the sites. motorcycle Ryksha is the most convenient.

Last of the Magical Places on Earth. If you're into adventure,. getting lost, ruins, 1000 year old temples and trees older than that. The Angkor Archaeological Park is the place you want to, definitely check out. The park consists of all the temples and cities that belonged to the Ancient city of Angkor. Basically it contains everything in Siem Reap that is associated with the temples. Top attractions are Angkor Wat, Ankor Thom, Bayorn. You can do that in a day. Tickets are needed. Single day pass is $20 and 3 days is $40 USD. Tuk tuk will cost anywhere from $15 to $25 to take you from Siem reap to the temples. On the first day, I checked out the top attractions which were majestic attractions. Did the sunrise and sunset. Sunset at Angkor Wat was beautiful but the sunrise wasn't all that because it was cloudy. Just make sure the sky is clear when you go for the sunrise. Another pro tip- if you dont want to pay money to see the temples, go after the sunset. There are no guards or anyone present. All you need is a little courage and a sense of adventure, as the dark can be tricky to navigate. Best to go with a few people but some temples are more beautiful at night with the stars in the sky reflecting on water pools.. this does not apply to Angkor Wat or Thom or the major tourist attractions as Guards are always present there. Truly one of the last places on Earth where magic exists.. all you need to do is believe.

Amazing historical place to visit but full of tourists. I was so keen to visit the Angkor area and temples so I had very high expectations. I was quite disappointed by the sheer number of tourists in and around the temples. It felt almost suffocating and the experience would've been much more enjoyable without all the tuk tuks, tourists and overpriced food. Still, what can you do. Better seeing it super busy than not seeing it at all.
Stunning. Took hundreds of photos and none of them do justice of the true beauty of this place.Either go very early in the morning or late afternoon as gets very busy.

Spectacular. This park includes several temples. One can buy 1 day, 3 day and 7 day passes, which are very reasonable. It is vast and worth some time and effort. You can climb a lot or very little in most temples and I can't imagine trying to see too many in one day, especially if Angkor Wat is one!

A cultural sight like no other!!. We went for sunrise at Angkor Wat and stayed for a few more hours to explore the other temples. Our tuktuk driver went counterclockwise, as most groups go clockwise to all the other temples - so we were able to miss a lot of groups until mid morning when the tours start coming in. You can buy 1, 3 or 4 day passes, we just went with the 1. If you're like us, you kind of get temple-d out after awhile. Obviously a must visit when in Cambodia!!!

History alive world community in one place. What's not to love. Magnicent architecture and design from 100's of years ago. It is a live look at distant times which in itself is magical. I had to do return trips to the temples they grabbed me that much. If you don't get this place I really don't understand. I sincerely hope that more money and effort is put into conservation of this area as it is important to the story of Cambodia.

Everyone should have this on their bucket list!. First thing to remember is that it is not just Angkor Wat that you are going to see. This is a huge complex of temples, each one different from the other - and you are certainly not going to appreciate much in just one day, so the three-day pass is essential. Agreeing with other reviewers, take a guide. He will get you to the right place to see the sunrise, in front of all the others, and get you round the temples when there are least tourists around. We have amazing photos when it seems we are the only ones there. The Bayon Temple was probably our favourite (those faces are just something you have to see), closely followed by the Ta Phrom, but this is not to negate the other temples, all of which have something different to offer. Wear sun protection and sensible shoes - apart from the many stairs (beware, these temples are not fit for viewing by the disabled, sad to say) on many occasions we were climbing over the stones themselves. Although undergoing restoration, this is still an ongoing task and many temples still have a long way to go, so don't expect all bas-reliefs, etc. to be pristine, but it is an amazing place to visit.

Keep 2 days to totally give it the due credit!!. The entire archeological park is huge and you need to keep 2 days for seeing all the temples and exploring it. Most important temples to be seen are:Angkor wat: see the sunrise. Be there by 5 amAngkor Thom, Bayon templeTa Prom: full of huge trees and roots growing through the temples and India( archaeological Survey of India) helping in the restoration of the temples which had totally fallen apart! # feeling proud.Even if you are told to go to Phnom Bakheng temple for sunset, u can totally ignore the advice. U need to wait 2 hrs to get to the top n that too for a sunset which is no great.
A must see!. There are so many temples to explore. Whether you are there for one day or several there is so much to do and see. While in Cambodia it is a must see.

BIG, BIG, BIG Park!. Brace yourself! It's a big, big, big park and ruins are far from each other. One can either do your visit by car, tuk tuk, motor cycle and bicycle. Walking is not advisable!Though I love visiting ancient ruins such as those in Central America, I carefully planned and selected the sites I would visit and amount of time needed for the visit of this Park.One day visit of 5-6 major temples is more than enough for me!
amazing. great history at this place. it helps to have a guide - he took us to some none touritsy spots - hardly any people there - great fo photos.

History everywhere you look. EVERYONE should make the effort once in their lives to come and see the great Angkor Wat which has been hailed as one of the wonders of the world.But there is so much more to the Angkor Archaeological Park near Siem Reap than just one site because we are talking about 400 sq kms of temples.To see a good slice of them would be a vast undertaking beyond most people's standard holiday, so you have to cut your cloth.No-one is allowed to visit Park temple sites without a pass. This costs $20 for one day and $40 for three days, so take the three day option. You will need it. Passes are also regularly checked by staff and security so always carry it with you.Another good piece of advice is make sure you get an English speaking guide which will only cost $35 for the entire day. Yes, you can try and arm yourself with a guide book and do it yourself but a guide book won't immediately tell you that toilets are round the back of that stall selling coconuts, it won't point out that important and very tiny carving tucked away at the bottom of a wall and it won't guide your steps away from where massive tour groups will swamp various sections at various times.What a guide will do is share their experience gained over thousands of days guiding tourists round the ruins. Don't forget your happiness is their goal because you aren't going to tip well for a poor experience.So for special occasions they get you out of bed a little earlier than the big groups. I was up at 4am for the stunning experience of seeing the dawn rise over Angkor Wat yet all my great memories and pictures would have been spoiled without my guide's knowledge because he got me to the viewpoint in front of the ruins early before the big tour groups arrived and he got me into what experience had shown him was by far the best spot for photographs.Within 15 minutes of my arrival everywhere behind me was choked with people. Believe me the Russians, Chinese and Japanese were there in their hundreds and they were taking no prisoners in their efforts to try and force their way closer to the edge of a big pond in front of Angkor Wat which offers pictures of the temple backlit by dawn, pictures of the temple silhouetted in the water and great panoramic shots.Because of my good position I have some great photographs and some great memories, but my guide made sure it got even better by encouraging me to walk away from this spot at a set time. The gap I left was immediately snapped up by members of a Chinese group, but my guide wasn't bothered. He knew that spot had gone past its best and he was keen to get me moved away and up a small rise by some palm trees.I had the entire spot to myself apart from three other tourists because the bulk of visitors were still crowded round the pond....so they missed the first sight and pictures of the sun climbing round and above the right hand tower of Angkor Wat which turned out to be one of the best pictures I took.My smiling guide then whipped me away for two other shots of Angkor Wat, one down the long stone entry path and one through other ruins which only worked because of the timing with the position of the sun. Find all that guidance and information in any guide book!!There is more good news for the visitor who hires a guide. By this time it is still only breakfast time, so my guide took me to a nice little tucked away stall for coffee and then encouraged me to see other temples in a specific order designed to reveal their glories to me before the big tour groups got there or after they had left, so I was constantly experiencing these fantastic ruins almost as a lone spectator without them being clogged up with masses of visitors.If Angkor Wat is the jewel in the crown then Ta Prohm runs it a close second.Jungle dominated all the temples for centuries but, whereas some sites are now completely clear and restored, Ta Prohm’s soaring trees and fabulous root formations snaking over ruined stonework remain in many places and provide its famous surreal look as shot in scenes for the film Tomb Raider with Angelina Jolie.There are a host of other temples I could mention, but there is more to the Park than temples and I would advise any visitor to pay special attention to the many superb gates which exist.Their soaring solid stone gateways surmounted by giant stone Buddha faces often covered in moss or greenery are epitomised by the Victory Gate at Angkor Thom, a wonderful sight.There are many other wonderful sights but don’t forget to keep a close eye on terrain and wear good trainers or boots. Whole areas involve clambering round, over or through great piles of tumbled stone, ancient staircases can be near-vertical and have no handrails and the passage of millions of feet can wear stone down so a surface which looks flat is actually sloped and can cause feet to skid. Take pictures but also take care.My final pieces of advice relate not to what you might see but to what you might need.Always carry water with you although, if you hire a tuk tuk and guide at the same time, you often find the tuk tuk driver has a cool box filled with water bottles and ice under the seat you are sitting on which he provides free of charge as part of his service. Still, have at least one bottle yourself to drink while walking round sites.Second – and very important – mosquitoes hunt during the day here as well as at dusk and dawn, so make sure you put suncream on and THEN spray Deet repellent over the top to protect yourself and repeat it at least once during the day. Can’t be too careful.And talk to your guide before you set out. Hear what he or she has to say but don’t be frightened of saying what you’re really interested in, what you’d most like to do, whether you have any physical needs such as frequent toilet breaks or the easiest access possible to sites because of dodgy knees. If you don’t tell your guide these things they are not psychic. Help them to help you.Another good tip – which applies just as much when in town as out – is to carry $10-$20 dollars in small bills, mostly $1, because finding change for $20 bills or higher can sometimes be impossible. Among things I bought when touring temples was a bottle of iced tea, a coffee, a sort of sandwich and a fruit smoothie. They all cost $1 each.You don’t have to follow this snippet but it is useful. Keep a rough list of those places and sights you haven’t been able to get to and see. After all, you’ll need an excuse to come back to Siem Reap...and come back you will. Hope all this has all been of help. Enjoy your holiday. I did.

Gorgeous and extremely big area!. Tip 1: DO NOT CHANGE YOUR USD to KHR. You would actually get screwed over in the long run. Bring lots of small denominations. 1 USD is traded freely around the area.Tip 2: If you are not the sporty/adventurous type, if the Taxi bringing you over to your accommodation offers to bring you around the Angkor area, take it. They may also give guidance along the way (depending on the driver). It will cost 30 USD for the day. This is a fixed price by the government. (They actually show you a paper for it) If you decline, and chose to have a taxi to drive you around from the Hotel, it may rise the standard to 35 USD (That was from my hotel there)Tip 3: If you are at least the adventurous type, you can get a tuk-tuk to drive you around. I'm not sure how much it would cost, but presumably it's about 15-20 USD for the day.Tip 4: Unless you're really only there for the weekend, I'd say go for the 3 day pass. It costs 40 USD. I had paid in Riel, which made me pay 166,000 Riel. There's lots of places to see. And I mean LOTS! You only get to see/explore the 3 most popular ones in a day perhaps. Tip 5: Despite what the taxi driver says, Angkor Area is not "Far" from the Siem Reap center. It is roughly 5 km away just to reach Angkor Wat, so it's quite close by bicycle. There shouldn't be a need to rent a motorbike to reach the Angkor Area. Your ride can be parked for free near any of the temples when you're visiting. Just follow the norm.I went there with a taxi the first day, and then rented a 1 USD/day city-bike to go there for the second day and the third. I unfortunately was there during the brunt of the Chinese New Year time, and so there's tremendous amount of foreign tourists when I went there. Using a bicycle to go around the area is much more relaxing, and you have better control on where you go. Be sure to get a map from your accommodation so you can see around the place. I couldn't stop giggling over how big this place was while cycling!
Fascinating !. it was like traveling back in time and living the myth. a must do for bucket list. just try and avoid summer, we almost died in heat stroke.

We saw a lot over 3 days!. Day 1: Angkor Wat, Bayon, Prahan, Pason; Day 2: Banteay Srei, mountain walk, Banteay Butterfly Centre; Day 3: Beng Mealea, Komplung Klang fishing town, fishing village on the lake. All well worth a visit but good fitness and care required for the mountain walk!

Simply amazing place. This is definitely one of the world's must-see places. The ruins of these amazing old temples, the way nature has started to reclaim some of them, and the fact that you can climb all over and explore them is just fantastic. You can see all of the best preserved, most famous temples and also just walk through the woods enjoying the landscape of overgrown tumbled stones from the ruins. Just amazing. I was here about 15 years ago when it was still fairly new to tourism and there are considerable differences, some good, some bad. They have built wooden stairs and walkways over some parts of some temples, which I think is good to help prevent further damage. But now there are too many huge tour groups allowed to visit the same temples at the same time and it makes for a very unpleasant experience at times. Some of the guides for the big groups will actually try to push you out of the way so their groups can have better vantage points and I think they will have to start regulating this better if they want to avoid a backlash from tourists who don't participate in these mass-travel groups. Also, there's a ton of stalls selling crappy stuff that's not from Cambodia, and people having their children sell stuff instead of going to school. All of this needs to be regulated. Ticket sales seemed like chaos at first but it actually works pretty well. Overall an amazing place worth seeing - I hope they can keep it from being overrun.
So much to see. There is so much to see from Angkor Thom, Banteay Srei, this list goes on. Be sure to check the weather as to what time of year to go. It gets really hot and humid.

Two days is not enough. The travel agency had provided us with one day tickets to the Angkor Archaeological Park, but we gladly payed an additional USD 40,-- for two persons for a second day visit. It is convenient that is is allowed to stagger those two days inside a week. (The tickets are punched by the first check point you encounter). Visitors tickets are obtainable at the ticketing complex close to Angkor Wat. A tuk-tuk is a handy way for moving around in the Park. Tuk-tuk renal is about USD 15,-- a day. (Sometimes included in a hotel booking). Angkor Archaeological Park is a sequence of stunning historical sites; temples eight to ten centuries old in any state of repair. The crown of the visit is of course Angkor Wat, one of the top sites to visit in the world. Unfortunately, also here mass tourism takes its toll. Moving were the small music groups, playing Cambodian folk music; the members of these groups were without exception, victims of land mines. They hoped for a small donation or a sale of a CD. Angkor Archaeological Park is a top attraction in the world, on par with the archaeological treasures in Rome, Italy.

Well organised and maintained . Overall I was very impressed with how the park is organised and maintained and don't mind the cost when you can see the money is being invested.The ticket office runs smoothly and efficiently and the inspectors are polite and helpful. The journey through the park to the temples on it's own is a beautiful journey and it was lovely to find a part of Cambodia relatively unpolluted. Many people seemed to cycle but I'm afraid I'm too lazy :-) If you have a good level of fitness cycling would be pleasurable but walking alone I clocked up around 12km per day so bear that in mind as it's 12km there and back again (minimum) from town.I also loved the fact that touts are kept out of the temple areas and that the temples are smoke free areas.Overall probably one of the most rewarding experiences of my life.

Magical. We arrived before dawn, and has tourches to see us across the bridges. I my opinion it is only worth going at this time of the day if the sky is red, as the sun position leaves the Ankor Wat in shadow.

So much to take in.. Worth a few days of exploration to do the area justice. Angkor Wat, on it's own, with a guide to interpret the site, is a full day's visit. The bas-relief sculpture that surrounds the site is a wonder worth some significant time. Bring plenty of water, comfortable shoes, sun-screen and eyes open to the intricate beauty of the carvings and majestic wonder of the structures. Sunrise over Angkor Wat was worth the early start. Banteay Srei is a bit of a trek, but more than worth the journey, with the most intricate carvings of any of the area temples.
A real eye opener. Take comfortable walking shoes and you will not be disapointed.Not the easiest attraction to get to, but the views are outstanding. Spent a enjoyable couple of hours with friends.

An amazing three days. Be prepared!!!! Get some step fitness in before you travel. Lots of two up and two down steps plus the steep ones to the top of the temples, all a must do. All the steps, together with the heat and humidity make for a long day. After the sunset get you driver to take you straight to Ta Nei temple. 1km of dirt road but close to major temples. Fantastic smal temple with no people, you will pretty much have it to yourself. Then start from the back of the other temples and you will miss a lot of the crowds.

Must do in siem reap. My friend and I visited the park over 2 days. One by tuk-tuk one by bike. It's defenitely the thing to do here and I recommend taking a bike on the 2nd day as it's quite easy to find. Great place to visit

Once in a lifetime experience!. A magnificent sight & an absolute must-do whilst in Cambodia. Don't be pressured into joining a tour group or hiring a guide and being ferried around like sheep. Do your research, plan a route, don't hang around too long and you'll be able to get all the best sights into one day ($20 ticket). We hired a couple of mountain bikes, set off around 4am and bought our tickets from the office en route when it opened at 5am. From there we cycled up without any crowds or noise, and entered the complex via the East gate completely alone (the tour guides take everyone else through the West gate for the sunrise). We were able to wander the corridors of Angkor Wat by torchlight in silence, it was totally mesmerising. Once daylight had reached us we moved quickly around Angkor Wat snapping plenty of photos before cycling to Banteay Kdei, Ta Prohm, Ta Keo temple and through Victory Gate. Here we walked around Terrace of the Elephants, Baphuon temple, Angkor Thom and the mighty Bayon temple. We left our hotel at 4am and were back by 2pm. A relatively long day on its own, with a fair few miles covered on the bike. We managed to avoid the majority of the crowds and queues of tuk tuks and jeeps. I highly recommend hiring a bicycle for this excursion. All the roads are flat and it's very easy to navigate. Just remember, do your research, plan a route (preferable the opposite of the tour guides) and don't hang around too long, you'll feel the crowds starting to thicken if you do. Most of all, enjoy Angkor!

One of the highlights of the trip. We spent 3 days in Angkor and did the morning sunrise of Day 3. Didnt get the glorious red sunrise as you'd expect giving the month but still glorious reflections. Angkor wat a let down though in comparison to the other temples like Bayon and Preah Khan. Definitely hire a tuktuk driver from SR and barter. Ours was great - I think he was called Serat.

A MUST! . You can not come to Siem Reap & not visit The Archaeological Park. You must buy a ticket - either 1,3 or 7 days before you enter to explore the temples. One day is $20. In 1 day you can see a lot but it is a little exhausting, lots of walking & climbing. The ticketing area is set up well & is a quick process even when it is very busy. They take your pic & give you a valid pass. Make sure you keep it on you cause it will be checked mutiple times during the day.

Awesome sites. This park is large and has some of the most amazing archeological sites you will ever see. We only had three days but managed to hurtle around quite a bit of it. We got a three day pass which costs $40. You have to queue up to get a photo pass done. We visited Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, the Bayon and the royal palace with the elephant terrace on the first day with Pre Rup in the evening for sunset, Ta Prohm, Neak Prean, East Mebon and Preah Khan on the second and Banteay Srei, a visit to Tonle Sap and the land mine museum on the third day. Every day was amazing. If you can space it out more then do. It's hard to take all the temples in when rushing from one to the other. I'm still processing them now! I would definitely love to come back now that I have my bearings just to spend more time in these glorious sites.

Not only beautifull temples but also wonderful nature in the area. Absolute must when travellin in Cambodia. Very beautiful ancient temples iconic to this country, and also vivid nature around the area. It was very good to explore the area with bicycle! I'd recommend doing it in maybe 2 days (though there are only options of 1 or 3 day tickets). I did all the main temples in a day though, it is possible but you should arrive there to see the beautifull sunrise over Angkor, and you would be exploring the area all day.The biggest downside is the lack of information signs at the area. Sometimes navigation can be difficult therefore, and it'd also be nice to get some briefing about the site you're entering. Also the area is full of merchants trying to sell you stuff all the time.

Amazing . Hello, everybody if you are planning a trip to Angkor Archaeological Park then you will not be disappointed. This place is amazing and it will take you at least 8hours to see everything you have to see there. I highly recommended you wear shorts and comfortable shoes because you will be doing alot of walking aroun at those temples and it is very humid as well. You will be in a jungle so it be very humid and you will fun into monkey around some of those temples. I took alot of pictures while I was there and I look forward to go to Phnom Pin. I believe Cambodia is going to be the next Thailand.

very impressive experience also for intensive travellers. after a life spent travelling all around the world the chance to be excited visiting a new destination is rather difficult. Angkor Park is right the case of an exemption to the rule. Archaelogy, History, Nature, Anthropology, are all at the same time/place available to you. some days are better than others due to high occupancy (many Koreans now + more and more Chinese looking ahead) but the visiting populations is helping to keep the whole place alive. better to catch a local professional guide who leads you around not to risk limiting the visit to get fantastic snaps oly.

Definitely Unforgettable. It's like walking through a living ancient kingdom (it is actually!) Every single temple in this place is simply magical. Surrounded with vast forests and green lushes, also how the temples are still displaying its real ancientness through the green moss, fractured stupas, giant roots, everything is just eerily magnificent.
Angkor. One of the most beautiful historical complex , Very special just to walk around and feel the ancient history

Amazing archaeological site. Angkor is an an amazing archaeological site which is located in Siem Reap. This site stretches over 400 square kilometres.Angkor Archaeological Park contains the remains of the different capitals of the Khmer Empire, from the 9th to the 15th century. This includes Angkor Wat ,Angkor Thom, the Bayon Temple.This site is UNESCO listed to safeguard the site and its surroundings.This place should be on everybody's bucket list.

Angkor Archaeological Park is huge. Angkor Archaeological Park is huge. Suggest tourists start their exploration of the park at Angkor Wat before proceeding to Phnom Bakheng to be mesmerized by Angkor Wat at sunset.
Very nice!. You get to drive through the village; see water buffalo, fishermen, and the unique architecture. A few crops, farm animals and wares might also be seen.
Amazing. You feel like a modern day Indiana Jones walking around. Simply brilliant. Try go early to avoid the heat as there is a lot of waking.

Khmer Empire Culture at it's Finest. What's to say, this is a sprawling area with different temples and complexes, it's so amazing! Perfect for the history buff, gorgeous. Photo and learning opportunities abound!

Excellent place to visit. There is so much to see, buy the 3 day pass, go as soon as it opens, and leave around 10.30, when it gets really busy and hot.We didnt do the sunrise at Angkor Wat, as it sounded to crowded an unpleasant, but you know that is when and where most of the tourists are going to be, so you have the rest of the temples more or less to your selves.Only wear shoes you can wash, I wore thongs, the orange earth makes everything dirty.If you are in a wheel chair, or have young children in a push chair, you can still get to see some things, especially if you can walk up a few steps to the next level, a few things can be seen from the ground, the Elephant Terrace at Angkor Watt, the outside at Ta Prohm for example.Wear sunblock, take water and a snack, hat,sunglasses,,a face mask or scarf in case it gets windy and the earth blows in your face, go to the toilet before you enter [there are public toilets by the markets outside the larger temples].Dont spend the whole time behind your camera, sit and soak up the atmosphere!!

Fascinating. It is wonderful to be able to wander around the numerous wats still partly standing in this huge area. Some of the most beautiful are the not so popular ones as you can enjoy the quietness without the busloads of noisy tourists.

Siem Reap 's Village a couple miles away from Angkor Wat-and THE FLOATING VILLAGE. My TukTuk driver took me to his home on stilts where I did face painting on his children and some relatives. It was a first for each of them. This man was proud of his command of English and of being a hard worker trying to get ahead. His 99 year old grandmother lived on TOP of the part of the stilted house in which his own family lived. She came out and visited with me too. The "Park" itself seemed to have a pig in the water and I, personally, did not see archaeological ruins. (I have been to So. America and Tikal, Guetamala.) I didn't even see any temple ruins at the interesting places where the driver took me. I, did, however, see much vegetation and water and somefamilies. Earlier that day I attended the Catholic Church where I sat ON THE FLOOR. Had I arrived early, perhaps I would have been given a "handicapped" privilege of a chair off to the side. After the Mass I talked with the priest, who was from Italy and there to learn the language. He told me NOT to allow anyone at the floating village to charge me more than $5.00 maximum to go on a boat to see the "village". He also invited me to join him when he went to say Mass ON one of the houses at the floating village. The Floating Village is right there-on the opposite side of where the Tuk-Tuk took me-to the ticket box--tickets get purchased to go on the water, but tuk tuk driver wanted me to pay him I did not need to as I followed the earlier advice of the priest.

Wonderous. Sunrise viewing is a MUST!! Only 25% of sunrises are breathtaking but if you are lucky enough to catch one, you won't be disappointed. The scope of this place is mind-boggling. Plan to spend at least 3-4 hrs exploring. If you walk enter through the West gate, you will be rewarded with sunrises, f you exit via the East gate, you will be rewarded by monkeys. A very spiritual place that is not to be missed.
Great site. This is an excellent World Heritage site that has great temples and great history lessons. The overall complex is a don't miss.
Anazing. We really enjoyed our 1 day visit to only 8 temples! They are all absolutely amazing, each one being very unique! Our boys favourite was Ta Nei, as they got to explore a destroyed temple!

Unmissable. Such a unique and extraordinary place. Any visit to South-East Asia would be incomplete without Angkor.The whole complex around Siem Reap really requires several days to do it justice. I would recommend a private tour as this allows you to visit at your own pace, and good guides know when to avoid the crowds - plus also little visited places.

Deserves several days. Visiting Cambodia and Angkor complex is once in a lifetime opportunity for many visitors, so take your time and try to see the less-visited outer temples as well, in addition to the more frequently visited and well-known 'inner circuit'. Wish I had a multi-day visit outside a package Cambodia trip so had the chance to walk around and enjoy more of it..

Archaeology . A nice visit to their archaeological park here in Siem Reap.
It's a great start to your holiday here in Siem Reap as it would give you an idea of what's there and what to expect.
Just do it all.. You came all the way to Siem Reap. Take it all in, read as much as you can, explore and let your imagination run wild. I don't think I skipped one temple.

Loved it. We went twice with a tuk tuk driver - the first day we did the 'small' circuit (Angkor, Thom etc) and the second day we did the 'big' circuit. While you can't miss the small tour we actually preferred the second day! Some of the temples were easily just as impressive and the best bit was the lack of other tourists! Definitely go as early as you can, the heat and crowds only get worse with time.

Wonder of the world!. This is the complex with the main 4 or inner circle temples included. The entry fee is $20 for a single day. Passes brought after 5pm, can be used the next day. Hot even in Dec/Jan, when its apparently winters. So wear a hat and carry water

Must go. This is the name for the whole complex that includes the temples of Angkor Wat. Get your self a pass - costs US$40 for a 3 day pass. You have to queue to get your photo taken and then collect the pass to wear around your neck as you visit the temples. They check the pass and your photo at each temple.
Utterly beautiful. A truely great wonder of the world. Comparable to the pyramids of Egypt,or pre Colombian antiquities of south America. Awe inspiring, moving the experience of a lifetime.

So much history to protect. The temples protected in this huge Archelogical park are amazing. The entry fee is $20 for a single day, $40 for 3day pass (3 days in a 7day period) or $60 for a 7 day pass. We had the 3day pass and enjoyed it immensely.

Fantastic temples, many in the same state they were discovered!. ire a guide for 1 day, then just get a tuk-tuk driver for the other days and do it yourself with a guide book (the guide is not even essential for one day really). The 3 day pass can be used non consecutively over the course of a week, but if you buy it after 5PM you can then go that evening as an extra and see the sunset at Angkor Wat, and still have three days. Sunrise at Ankgor Wat is pretty busy (bring a torch), and depends a lot on weather. The image of all these people holding up their selfie sticks to the rising sun is one I will treasure
An amazing array of temples!. You should plan to return to take photos of sunrise and sunset at Angkor Wat, but plan to spend several hours visiting and marveling at various of the famous temples.

Get a Three Day Pass.. There are so many amazing temple ruins in this park, that are so very different, it would be a shame to only visit Angkor Wat and Bayon. However the heat and crowds can make it difficult and tiring to sustain long periods exploring these sights. My husband and I and our teenager daughters found it most pleasant early in the morning (from 7.30 - 10am) and late in the afternoon (4.00-5.30pm).A three day pass is valid for seven days so you don't have to spend three consecutive days in the park.Would also recommend going with a private guide who can give you insights and explanations of the history, carvings, etc.Allow two hours at Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom(which includes Bayon and the Terrace of the Elephants). We spent about an hour at each of Ta Prohm, Banteay Srei and Pre Rup.

A remarkble trip. The whole park consists of many buildings, temples and palaces of the ancient Cambodian. It will take you around 2 or 3days just for visiting. There are many ancient buildings there that worth a trip

we bought 7-day ticket. we took our pace and slowly went around the whole park during our 6-day stay. Strongly recommend to slow down the pace when you visit the temple, otherwise very difficult to observe the details of the beauty. Did two sunrise in Angkor Wat and one sunset in Bakeng, 10km run around Angkor Wat and 21km run around the grand circle. simply amazing

must see - absolutely amazing and awe inspiring experience!. we arrived at angkor in the morning for sunrise and bought a 1 day ticket, and had hired a tuk tuk driver until 1 pm that day for the small circuit. visiting the temples was absolutely amazing, and the sunrise is a must do (however go early to get a good spot)! we finished the small circuit at around 12:30 and by then felt as if we had seen everything we had wanted to see and were a bit 'templed out'. we couldn't imagine spending another two days or even the full week looking at temples. we didn't find the walking difficult, apart from one temple where to get to the top there were several flights of very steep stairs, and the day wasn't too hot either. we would agree with a lot of the reviews about the lack of good management of angkor - the failure to provide a map when buying a ticket, and the proximity of annoying stallholders to the temples. it would be nice to be able to enjoy and take in the temples without having constant begs from sellers to buy 'temple pants' and scarves. however on the other hand, we also understand that this may be their sole livelihood! we would compliment the park on keeping the temples and the general grounds incredibly clean, and we saw countless workers sweeping leaves and tidying the park.

Back in time -bucket list!. Definitely amazing. Read about it but to be there in reality doesn't do it justice. It is simply stunning and magical. Very important to do it with a guide so that you get time to explore every aspect. 1 day is not enough.Tip : sunrise and sunset are the best times to visit, avoid the heat of the day, either early morning or evening to see the different faces of ankorwat . Sunscreen, sunhat, camera, selfie stick and suitable shoes and clothes for visiting temple, ankorwat temple pass

Magical. This is such an amazing place to visit. Dozens of unique, intricately carved and constructed temples are littered across over 400 sq km of park, giving a unique glimpse into the life of an extraordinary empire. Preparation prior to visiting is key, essential to speak to your guide about how to avoid the big crowds.

"See Angkor and Die". I am still shaking my head in wonder.I had read that Angkor was big. After all it was a metropolis with a population of more than 1 million when there was no such city as Bangkok but I had no idea that it would be THAT BIG. It is not just Angkor Wat that you should visit, but many, many other temples and ruins that spread far and wide, each one more beautiful than another. Angkor Wat may be the crown of the Kmer empire, but other temples are the jewels that take the crown to the stratosphere. We spent 7 days in the park and yet were not able to visit them all. Tips:1. Find a place to stay inside the park. It will save you time and the efforts in visiting the major sites.2. Hire a tuk-tuk for the day. If you find a nice, accommodating driver, hire him for the entire stay. The driver will take you from site to site and wait for you until you have visited each site then take you to the next. We were so touched when our tuk-tuk driver had bottles of iced cold water ready for us after each jaunt. You will enjoy your visit much more comfortably. Did I say Angkor is big? Regular fares are $15/day for Angkor Wat/Anglor Thom, $20/day for the smaller surrounding temples, $35 for Banteay Srei, and $40 - $45 for Beng Maelea. $2-3/trip for Siem Reap, $5 for the airport. Tip the driver generously for sunrise/sunset trips and each day.3. Cost: $20/1 day pass, $40/3 day pass, $60/7 day pass for the archeological sites. Keep the pass on you at all time because checkpoints and random checks are everywhere. You will be fined $100 if you are found within the park without your pass. The pass gives you access to all the sites within the park, including Banteay Srei that is 35 km. away, but it does not include Beng Maelea (ticket: $5) that is 52 km. away from Siem Reap. We did not have time for the Roluos Group, so I don't know if the pass will give you access to the temples in that group or not. 4. Wear summer clothing, a wide brim hat and good, comfortable walking shoes. 5. The heat and humidity is brutal and oppressive. The weather is slightly cooler from mid December to mid February. While we were there, it began to cool off on December 17. Note: The air is noticeably cooler inside the park than in Siem Reap thanks to the trees in the park, another good reason to find lodging in the park.6. Wear a facemask if you can. Dust and smoke from burning garbage permeate the air. If you have underlying respiratory problems, beware. My asthma returned with a vengeance and I am still recovering from an upper respiratory infection. 7. Please, please keep your hands to yourselves and your body parts from touching the ruins, refrain from stepping on the stones strewn around and please bring back your garbage and dispose of it elsewhere. It is heart breaking to see so many people touch, rub, lean on the carvings or step on the ruins and to see so much garbage everywhere including inside the temples. Most of all enjoy Angkor, because you will probably not find anything like it anywhere on earth.

A must see but..... Go early as the heat gets very intense. Depending on how into your temples/archaeology/what your budget is decide if you want a 20 dollar one day or 40 dollar three day ticket.If it's quiet enough this is actually a very peaceful place and incredibly profound for world heritage. You'll also see similarities in the jungle book movie and tomb raider. I don't think there's anywhere quite like this.However take food in with you as its generally quite expensive and under no circumstances buy for children, they should be in school not selling you overpriced souvenirs.You can cycle but really a return tuk tuk for two days you could get for 10-15 dollars. (if you go at 5pm for sunset you get in for all the next day on the same ticket)There aren't many signs so read up or get a guide.
Hard to add more to what's already been told. Superb once in a lifetime experience. Go early for sunset and try to fnish your tour before midday sun! It's hammering!

What an amazing place to explore.. No wonder some of the temples were selected as a movie setting for India Jones and Tomb Raiders. There are too many temples ( all different ) to see in one day. As it took me four days to visit most of them. To get there by tuktuk and to hire the driver for the day is about $15 US dollars. A bargain .cant wait to return to these awesome buildings again.
Just amazing.. Seeing the sun rise in the temple is a magical thing, If you have the option to go, do not think it twice!

Bigger than you think!. The whole park is much bigger than most people we talked to thought it would be. Most of the major sites are included in the park, so logically you should know it is big. The area is very woody and full of nature which makes for nice surprises when you turn a corner and out of nowhere is a beautiful temple. Be sure to visit some lesser known sites deeper in the jungle to see what it is like.

Wonderfull Angkor. This place has an unic atmosphere that take you to the XII Century.
