The entrance cost to the temples is about 20$ and We did all the trip by the Sinny' s tuc Tuc: Meansinny@gmail.com, taking us all the trip with water and pinnapple. He explain us a lot of interesting things of each temple, so complete a great Journey.

Wonderful place. My sister and I went in early December and had a wonderful time. Temples are fascinating and people are wonderful. We did a bike tour the first day, flight of the gibbons the second day and a private photography tour the third. Glad we did such diverse activities. Would highly recommend the same for anyone that wants three different experiences in the park.

AMAZING!. It costs 20 dollars for a day's ticket and it is well worth it. There is so much to see. You'll need stout shoes and to dress modestly to get into everything (no short shorts or vests). There are lots of places to buy drinks and a few to purchase food. Hire a tuk tuk (approximately 15 dollars for the smaller of two routes). The driver will wait for you at each site. It is a well worn path and they can be trusted to take you to the highlights but there English and historical knowledge may not be great, so either hire a guide or take a good guide book. We had a guide on our first visit six years ago and he as pretty useless, so go by recommendation if possible. Allow a good seven hours to do the small route.

Top place!. A beautiful place to visit...this includes many temples..a very large area. We bought a 3 days ticket for 40$...consider more than one day to visit the area if you want to see the most beautiful temples.

An absolute must. I visited Banteray Seray, Angkor Wat, the Bayon, and many others. Desperate to go back to see the others. Spend a whole day here, or more! Seeing the sunset or sunrise is well worth it too.

Wonder of the world!. One can easily do the small circuit in the archaeological park in ONE day i.e. Angor Wat, Ta Prom; Bayon, Angkor Thom including terrace of elephant, Buphon AND sunset from Phnom Bakeng.Angkor Wat is an amazing temple in this huge archaeological park. Build about 900 years ago, for the Hindu God Vishnu (currently Buddha idol).It is built on 3 levels. It has intricate carvings of Hindu Mythology like Mahabharata, Churning of the ocean etc.Guide is certainly needed for the Angkor Wat temple (maybe not so much for the entire park). After paying $20 entry fee, Individual full-day guide for entire park costs about $40; full day group tour is $13 each, Individual guide for just the Angkor temple is $15.Group tour includes pick up from hotel. For individual guide, you will have to take a tuk tuk for the entire day for $12 ($3 more for sunrise).Sunrise is nice, but maybe over-rated. However one can see the sunrise, then take a Individual guide for the temple alone, and then branch off on your own to see the rest of the park (Ta Prom; Bayon, Angkor Thom, Phnom Bakeng etc). This option is also good because immediately after sunrise there is almost no waiting to enter the main temple, which is on the 3rd level. Otherwise we encountered 1 hour queue at around 11 am.Bayon and Ta Prohm are amazing temples too.Just a small footnote - Hampi in India is very similar and amazing too, and much lesser crowds
Magnifecient view of the temples. It would be nice to go around the temples but one can wonder how these temples are held together with the moat around them

quite a learning experience. During my tour, I was informed that an ancient Indonesian king reached Cambodia to enlarge trade and create routes from Java to the mainland. In doing so, he brought Indian/Balinese architecture as well as Buddhism to Cambodia - which later spread to Thailand. TRUE!!

Angkor is more than what we saw in Tomb Raider!!!. Talk about an education. Tomb Raider certainly taught me some things, but at no stage did it teach me that the Angkor Wat Park is in fact a complex of some 250 sq kms and contains some 46 structures! Buy a 7 day pass which allows you to visit 3 times over the 7 days. Spread your visits so that you don't get 'templed out'. A highly interesting and beautiful place to visit. Getting a knowledgable guide will enhance the knowledge base and the experience.

Wonderful. No point to comment this beautiful site really. Its a must, if you get a chance to go there in your life, do it! Bike is a great way to go around without having to rush or follow a tour. The site is huge but roads are flat and good and in the shade, biking from the center of siem reap is only like 20 minutes.

See Angkotwat and die. This is worth to going to see one of 7 wonders of the world.Angkor wat is one of the best place to see sun-rise.The entrance fee is 20 USD for Angkorwat and near by historical site.

Such an inspiring place. A ticket must be purchased $20 for one day, $40 for 3 or $60 for a week. We did the Angkor temples in two days and by the end of day two I was a little over it all. The Angkor wat sunrise is well worth getting up at 4am to be at the ticket office at 5am when it opens. Get there at 5am to ensure you get a good spot for photos. Do try and get up the front as most of our photos were ruined by the use of the selfie stick. It would be nice if the selfie stick users moved to the back however its first in first served.
Stunning. Stunning views and spots. If you never been in Angkor you MUST come once in your live! The temples are fantastic, the food is good, people very nice and helpful.

Anger at Angkor. The whole Angkor complex totally lives up to the reputation of being, perhaps, the 8th wonder of the ancient world, in my opinion. The park through which you drive as you enter the temple complexes contain some of the Khmer rouge killing fields. The spice garden you pass on your left as you approach Angkor Wat is one of them. They are not so noted. The Forrest is lovely now. Wild monkeys can be spotted and I found beautiful wild flowers and butterflies. Many families picnic there and leave trash everywhere. Many families appeared to have members who are landmine victims. It's complicated. It's fascinating.

All the temples are impressive. All of the temple ruins, including Ankor Wat, are very impressive and worth seeing. A tuk-tuk can take you around and is very convenient. The pass purchased at the park gates lets you into all the sites. Dress code suggested no bare shoulders and knees covered, but there did not seem to be rigid enforcement of the knees covered as long as the shorts are close to the knees.

Angkor Wat + Angkor Thom = Incredible!!. So I hired a private guide and private car to come here.Angkor Wat:Came here at 5.30am to catch the sunrise. It was PITCH BLACK/ pitch darkness when we arrived. My guide had thankfully brought a small torch light. Still, it was a challenge to walk in pitch darkness!Everyone seems to descend at the lake/.pool where you can take shots of the Angkor Wat sunrise and reflections. There were about 500+ people there at the lake all ready to take the sunrise pics.Thankfully I brought my selfie stick so i could take pics without photographing all the bobbing heads of the 500+ people there!Did I like Angkor Wat? It was underwhelming for me. I had expected something more spectacular. The outside was spectacular. Inside the temple grounds, it was just so-so for me. But this is my personal opinion. You might have a different opinion to mine.Anways, the best time to visit Angkor Wat is to come here before dawn to catch the sun rise. The weather in the early morning is much cooler with lesser crowd. We were at Angkor Wat from 5am to 7.40am.For me, I prefer Ta Prohm.....Ta Prohm:This temple ruins was the place where Lara Croft: Tomb Raider movie was filmed. It is definitely the most eye catching temple ruins in the entire Angkor Archaeological Park!! Imagine seeing huge 500 over years old trees growing out of the temple ruins! Unfortunately, when I was there...escavation works are already in progress to remove all these beautiful trees. This project will be completed within 2 years. So when you go to Ta Prohm in 2018, you will no longer see these Sprung trees growing out of the Ta Prohm Temples :-( I don't know whether this is good or bad...but the uniqueness of this place will be gone. I mean - most people remember Ta Prohm as the place where there are tall Sprung trees growing out of the temple ruins right? I was here from 8am to 9am. This temple ruins is not very large. And with a private guide and car, you can visit the important parts of the temples and skip the uninteresting parts.Bayon:Bayon is the temple with all the many smiley faces. By the time I reached Bayon at 9am, my legs/knees were hurting so bad. I had taken a hard fall in Angkor Wat whilst climbing the narrow and steep steps :-( So sadly, I couldn't walk much.I only managed to skirt around the outer parts of Bayon.I'll be back!Important Reminder:Be prepared to walk and walk...and walk! Thankfully with the private car/driver, I didn't have to walk that much ;-) My driver drove all the way inside the complex to pick me up when I told my private guide my legs hurt. P.S. Check out one of the pics I posted regarding the dress code when visiting Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom.If you don't want to rush and if you prefer a much more leisurely pace, I recommend taking 3 days to visit the temples in Angkor Archaeological Park.

Skip bikes or e-bikes, get tuk tuk and spend at least three days. Wish we had another week to spend, as it is so far spread and there's so much to see. Initially we rented e-bikes, which seem like a good idea, but this park is so massive that we couldn't do everything we wanted to on the bikes. They were very slow, had to be recharged often and were not the most effective use of our time. Tuk tuk all the way. Get the multi day pass and make sure you go to the far reaches where you may literally be alone in some temples.

Worth investing more than 3 days. If you have time, it is worth spending some days here. Do a couple temples a day and then relax in the pool of your hotel. Its a unique place and siem reap can has a unique small town athmosphere with plenty restaurants and shops.
Beautiful place but. Beautiful place but very crowded. Even in winter there is very hot so better is to plan a visit not for noonday...............

A must visit place. We bought the three day pass to the park, the best way to make sure you see as much as you can. If you buy the pass late in the day you can then spend time watching the sunset at Pre Rup, take two days to visit as many sites as you can manage, as well as the compulsory sunrise at Angkor Wat itself. We did the Grand Circuit (larger of the two) the first day, with a great Tuk Tuk driver. Then headed out early the second day (7am-7.30am to beat the crowds) at Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm. On the last day got up very early (arrive at 5am - 5.30am) to get a good viewing position. Whilst it wasn't the best sunrise the day we were there I wouldn't have missed it for anything.

too large to see in one day. I tried biking here from the city, but you will get tired after see Anckor Wat and Bayan. Pay the extra money and hire a tuk tuk instead so you can see several sites. On the road between Angkor and Bayan, there are roadside restaurants that sell grilled chicken. Try it. It's good.

for Angkor Wat. Yep! One of the review (smudge) was perfect article, how to visit Angkor Wat, well the only reason you came to Siem Riep who grew ugly at my taste, in the last 15 years. Like he said "...take a tuk-tuk or a car. It is marginally more expensive but ... You can take a ton of stuff with you....and you only walk in the actual temples, meaning you can spend more time in the temples and less on the road.." The entry fee, with all is around is right (1 day:20$/_3 days in 1 week use 40$/_7 days in a 1 month use: 60$)

Nice view!. Most of the tour guides will take you to this ancient artificial lake, within the park during lunch time. It is a nice place with good restaurants. If you don't have a guide i suggest you take your lunch break as well, at this place.

travel options...... The temples of Angkor are the main reason for most people for coming to Siem Reap and there are several options for getting there. In the lonely planet guide it suggests a couple that I personally think are ridiculous. So here are a couple of things to think about if you have read the LP guide and considering how to do it..1. Walking! This is just plain crazy. It is about 10km from town to angkor wat along a very busy dusty boring road. If you walk it will take you at least 4 hours there and back, and when you get there you will have to spend another 4 or 5 hours walking around the temples. Every second you spend walking along that road is a second less you spent exploring the amazing site. Sure there is another road that is marginally less busy but it has no ticket office on it. Moreover you would need to carry all your stuff with you. It is the most stupid idea I ever read in a LP guide book, and that takes in a lot of territory.2. Biking. A close second to walking comes hiring bikes. Ok so this time you only waste 2 hours slugging up and down the road avoiding being hit by tuk-tuks and motorcycles. But there is another good reason not to bike and that is many of the temple sites are best visited by walking through them. i.e. entering at one side and leaving at the other. For example, Angkor Wat itself is perfect to enter on the west side and leave on the east. On a bike you cant do this because you have to go back to the start to pick up your bike. Then you have all the hassle of what to do if the bike breaks down, as most of the bikes for hire in siem reap are really designed for pottering about town rather than some serious cycling. Sure - bike hire is only 5$ per day.....but a tuk-tuk for 2 is only 15$. 3. Motor bikes. Not actually recommended by LP but much less ludicrous given the saved time. but you still have the same issue about being unable to walk through sites.so basically....take a tuk-tuk or a car. It is marginally more expensive but you are there in about 15-20 mins. You can take a ton of stuff with you, lunch, drinks, camera equipment, kitchen sink..and you dont need to carry any of it.You only walk in the actual temples, meaning you can spend more time in the temples and less on the road,and finally you can easily organise walk through trips by getting your driver to drop you and then pick you up at a pre-arranged spot. Plus if the car or tuk-tuk breaks down it is the drivers problem to solve - not yours. Finally the drivers can generally give you good advice about what is the best time to go where, and they know the best times and places to grab a bite to eat. Hope that helps...!!

Lives up to the hype. Such a magical place, well worth the entrance fee. Tip: go to the ticket booth at 5 pm and purchase your 3 day ticket. That way you can get in the park during sunset and it doesn't count against your 3 days.

Magnificent . Comprises of many temples (Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom & Bayon, Banteay Seri, etc), it takes more than a day to visit the place. Though plenty of walking and climbing (the steps), it sure is worth a visit to see the past glamour of the region. Be prepared and go with comfort shoes, and plenty of water. Can either hire a taxi or tuk tuk to bring you around the several temples, but taxi is the better choice under the hot sun and dusty roads, and it is faster. Entrance is USD 20 for a day, or 40 for 3 days.
A must visit place if you are in Cambodia. This is one of the main reason why people come to Cambodia for, other than the cheap draft beer. A must see before leaving Cambodia.
like!. this is an amazing place!! the tour guide is cute and fun. the whole trip is relaxing and wonderful!!

Spectacular!. An essential part of your trip to Siem Reap is a visit to the Temples of Angkor. There are a number of different tickets you can purchase which allow you to gain access for either one day, three days or seven days and they are completely worth it. I highly recommend braving the 430am start to see Angkor Wat at sunrise - it's a magical experience. If you only have one day - make sure you include the temples that comprise Angkor Thom ("city of temples" - the Bayon is in this section of the park) and Ta Prohm (where 'Tomb Raider') was filmed. There are also a number of temples that are outside the actual park and require additional travel to get to but Banteay Srei (the pink temple) is definitely worth it - it's about 32km outside of Siem Reap. A breathtaking experience in a truly magical place. Make sure you wear appropriate clothing - women in particular need shorts below the knees and shoulders must be covered - this was being enforced rather strictly the day we were there.

Extensive and Awesome. Extensive area from Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom out as far as Kbal Spean and Banteay Srei. A 3 day pass is recommended for this extended area. Angkor Wat is not a one trick pony. It is a large extended area that formed a mega city (so to speak) back in the day. One day is not nearly enough for this experience. Maybe a 1 week pass could see you end up with temple fatigue. If pitched at the right level a 3 day area pass could prove just the ticket. I recommend that a $40.00 (3 days use over 7 days). If you do what most do, you would buy the pass the night before your intended usage. This allows you free access to the site for the sunset photos without using 1 of your 3 days - lots of people do this - arrive about 4.45pm at ticket booth. Booths open about 4.55pm and you will be in and out in no time. You could split your 3 days Day1 Angkor Wat, Ta Phrom and Sunset at Bayon. Day2 Angkor Thom, Elephant Terrace, Leper King. Day3 Slightly out of town about 50km 1 hour or so. Kbal Spean, Banteay Srei. Day 3 allows a countryside environment and away from the crowds for a while. Just an idea.

Off my bucket list. Tickets:$20 one day. $40 for 3 days. We went on the small circuit. So we bought tickets only for 1 day. We went by tuk-tuk that cost $15. We didn’t want to go neither for the sunrise nor the sunset views. We left the hotel at 9.am. and returned at about 4 p.m. The weather was hot and humid. You have to walk a lot. One ruin looks like another. Ta Prohm reminds you of how powerful nature is. You may build but mother nature decides if it remains standing.We visited Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, Ta Prohm, Banteay Kdei

The reason for being in SR. Let's face it. Without the temples you would not visit Siem Reap - ever. But when you are there, the do visit the temples, also the oned on the grande circuit. The smaller ones as fabulous as the bigger ones, but less people so you may sense the atmosphere better.Loads of photographers everywhere so be prepared that you may catch some unfamiliar faces in your frames.

A must see if in Cambodia. We booked the mini tour with Tuk Tuk from our hotel and we were not disappointed. It is the stuff of dreams. You have seen it on tv but the only way to get the real experience is to visit. Put on your bucket list.

Ramayana & Mahabharata retold!!. It was fascinating to see intricately carved bas relief sculptures of scenes from the Ramayana and Mahabharata covering massive walls in the temple of Angkor Wat. This ancient Hindu temple was later taken over by Buddhists, so in one or two places you see a statue of Buddha,with offerings, incense etc. The whole complex is huge, with weather beaten stone pathways and steps. The bas reliefs of apsaras or dancers are exquisite.

Wonderfull. Beautifull.place. very different froma nywhere i have ever been. Very very hot. I suggest people do book a guide. I've booked onde called bum leam ( he has facebook) and he speaks a very good english. I also suggest people to go in a car because the attactions are far away from each other.

Must see in Siem Reap. Probably the reason most tourists came to Cambodia for, it is definitely a must-see when you're in Siem Reap. Known mostly for Angkor Wat, the entire Archaeological park is actually much bigger and consists of many more interesting temples. The tickets are at 20usd per day, 40usd for 3 days or 60usd for 7 days. They are sold at the ticketing centre along the road to Angkor Wat, roughly 4km to the south of the temple.

A must do. This is a must do in Siem Reap. You wouldn't go to Siem Reap without visiting at least a few of the temples. If you start early, you could do major temples in one day, but would involve lots of walking and climbing. Best to split into several days.

Take a look around. There is more to Angkor Wat than the main building itself and it's worth getting lost for a while and seeing the rest of the grounds and enjoying the serenity to be found away from the crowds.

Absolutely spectacular - tick off the bucket list. A truly amazing couple of days. Our teenage sons loved the place as much as we did, all appreciating the genius of design and architecture. The sheer size of Angkor Wat is truly impressive and sunset was worth the stay and wait.Some time to just sit and people watch is well worth the time spent. Take water, plenty of digital camera space and if you have time allow a moment to stop and stare rather than fly in and out.

This is why you come so do it.. We visited for one day. That was all we needed. Wouldn't want to do more. Highly recommend you get a guide so you can learn more. I also think it allows the trip to go faster because someon knows the path and the things to see. Also it is hot so having someone guide you and water when you return to your car is great. Plus they know where the good pictures are and also will take family photos. We traveled with two children ages 8 And 6. They were troopers. Do ask to go to temples that they can climb on as it makes it more fun. Not all allow people or kids to climb.

Gem of Southeast Asia!. Angkor Archaeological Park is one of my favorite places in the world and a must see for anyone visiting Cambodia! Angkor Wat proper is the center of this attraction and is the largest religious structure in the world! What is even more amazing is the fact that this world heritage site was completely forgotten by the world until the advent of flight in the 20th century when it was recognized by pilots.
A Must-Go. Simply the best. The park includes Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and many complex temples. If you plan to go to Cambodia, Angkor Park is a must-go place
Must See. The is one of the top attractions in the world, Make sure you go to the sunrise. Hopefully if you are lucky there won't be hoards of tourists blocking your view.

you will not be disappointed. The number 1 reason why most people visit Cambodia.dozens of unique, intricately carved and constructed temples are litered across over 400 sq km of park, giving a unique glimpse into the life of an extraordinary empire. Preparation prior to visiting is key, essential to speak to your guide about how to avoid the big crowds.

Not to be missed. This is such an amazing place to visit, we went with our guide Rany and he helped plan our 2 day itinerary so we could see the main areas and some of the ones more of the beaten track.We paid $40 dollars each for a 2 day pass, it would have been the same price for a 3 day pass, but we only had 2 full days to cover the sights.We managed a sunrise and a sunset at Angkor Wat, it was great but not as spectacular as we hoped for, a bit of a hit or miss with the weather unfortunately.

A brief walk for photo taking. After finished touring Angkor Wat, we stopped here for a quick walk to take photos. Not so much to see and you have to be careful of on coming cars on both sides of the road leading to the entrance.

A MUST SEE World Heritage Site. This is my fourth trip to the Angkor ruins ...my favorite ruins in the world. I made the most of my three day pass this year, spending three full days exploring not only the major sites, but the less visited ones as well. I'm a huge fan of ruins, and this site is very diverse with every temple very unique. The three day pass is the only way to go, and even then you can never really explore it as thoroughly as it deserves. My two faves are the Bayon and Ta Phrom, but they're all amazing.
Go at sunrise. Catch the sun rise have a good tuk tuk driver and bring clothing to cover up as some temple's require you to do so

Unbelievable place to visit!. Absolutely amazing place. Its not just all about Angkor Wat, there are many other beautiful temples to visit. Very popular place - we arrived at 0430 to be there for the classic sunrise over Angkor Wat photo and the place was packed!! You do need to get there early to get a good view - but it is a once in a lifetime experience. After sunrise - instead of visiting Angkor Wat - we visited other parts of the park first including Bayon and then went to Angkor Wat after lunch. This was a much better way of doing it - as you miss the main crowds in morning leaving it easier to explore. Bear in mind - it does get very hot, so make sure you have lots of water with you, and some of the temples have lots of stairs which can get very steep so not accessible to all unfortunately. There is so much to see that you will never see it all unfortunately but I imagine it would be good to space your visit over a few days. Absolute must see if in Cambodia!!
Amazing!. Absolutely amazing. Could not recommend this attraction anymore. Try not to see all the temples in one day- it's exhausting!

Lara Croft no where to be found. No temples of Doom here. What a fantastic place to visit. My wife and I visited this area as part of our Viking Cruises trip to Vietnam & Cambodia. Elephant rides and a visit to as many of the temples is a must. Especially Angkor Wat & Angkor Thom. We visited them by organised transport but do try the tuctuc's. Reasonably priced.

THE Reason to Visit Cambodia. I knew only Angkor Wat before coming to the place. But in fact Angkor is a region of it's own. Angkor Wat was amazing, but so were the many other temples in the park, notably Bayon & Ta Prohm. They are popular for a reason. Perfect for those who love history, art, architecture, adventure (imagine you are a tomb raider) or photography. Your camera will not stop snapping.Just be prepared for1) the crowd, loads & loads of people, but you can avoid them by visiting less popular temples or make your visits during hot hours, speaking of hot...2) the heat, though I went there during the 'cooler' season, it was still awfully hot & I found myself sweating like crazy just 5 minutes under the sun. Be sure to bring a lot of water, can buy bottled ones in the park too which are everywhere & not expensive3) the many stairs to climb, most big temples are built in tiers, & the stairs get steeper as you climb higher. You really have to climb them as some are more than 60 degrees steep & not all have rails to hold on to.Recommend a visit to Beng Mealea (another temple engulfed by the forest, quite a distance from the park / Siem Reap) too if you have time.

Very big park!. Angkor Archaeological Park consists of many of the main temples found around Siem Reap. Many of these temples can be accessed via car, tuk-tuk, tour bus/van, motorbike and bicycles. We decided to visit via bicycles which are available for rent at most travel/tour offices found in Siem Reap at US$2 a day for a normal bicycle and US$6 for a mountain bicycle. Make sure to rent one with a basket and check brakes and set height before leaving with the bicycle as they can adjust the bicycles for you. A deposit of passport of cash (preferable) is required for the duration of the rent.The admission booths for Angkor Archaeological park is located along Charles de Gaulle highway and it costs US$20 for a day pass. All visitors must queue up to purchase the ticket as they need to take a photo to be used on your ticket. The ticket purchased allows you to visit the park for the evening in which you bought the ticket and the full day for the date on the ticket. Most temple sites have small souvenir shops and a little security guard area where you can park your motorbike or bicycles while you visit the temple. Public toilets are located only at main temples. I've only seen them at Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom.Please see my review for each temple for the individual temples.

Visit the temples with the nicest Tuk Tuk driver in town. Our highlight in Cambodia was those three days passed visiting the beautiful temples with the nicest/coolest Tuk Tuk driver in town. We met Mr Dara after a long bus ride from Kratie and needless to say he made our journey worth it! We organised three days with him including Sunrise at Angkor Wat, Sunset, Roluos Temples and Banteay Srei (Temple very far at 35Km) for only $60. He was picking us every morning at our convenience and then showing us around all day. He bought water for us and also negociated our food at a restaurant in order for us to pay a 'standard' price instead of a 'tourist' one. We enjoyed a nice picnic with him along the East Baray where we got to know his life and his culture. The experience was incredible and we felt we could really understand how the cambodians were living. The least we can do is to put his number on Trip Advisor hoping more people will experience the same way than we did: +855 8132 8348 or +855 3149 54222 (You can ask your hotel to call him so he can meet you there to organise a trip)

3 Temples of Cambodia. The Angkor Archaeological part comprises of three important temples of Siem Reap. The Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple and Ta Prohm. It costs 20 $ for a day pass and 40 $ for a three day pass.

Easily Lost. My family and I did the 3 day tour and it was really fun. Although Angkor Wat is the main attraction I enjoyed Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm. Angkor is really crowded and not as interesting as the other smaller and underrated temples. The first day we went we went to Angkor Thom. It is like a maze. I went one way and then went back but forgot how I got there. I wandered through it and finally found the rest of my family. It is highly recommended to have a rickshaw or bike to get around to the different temples because it is very hot. We stayed until sunset and went to Phnom Bekheng. You can get elephant rides up the hill but I do not recommend because the day before we went to a Elephant Shelter, and the elephants at Angkor look worse than many in the shelter, which says to me they do not take care of them very well. Watching the sunset up at Phnom Bekheng is beautiful. There are a lot of people up there as well but they do keep track and let people in in waves. Make sure to were pants because I wasn't allowed to go into certain temples because of my shorts. Also carry a scarf if you're a women to cover your shoulders if needed. You can by flow pants and scarfs inside some stalls around to area. Don't be afraid to go some of the random little temples because they are also amazing. We walked a bit off path and found a cluster of temples with some Cambodian boys playing on them and these temples where small and unpopulated but amazing. Also don't be afraid to climb on them because there are more great views and little adventures built into that one.

Spend more time. Whatever time you have allowed yourself, my one piece of advice would be to consider if you can afford to spend more time. My friends and I arrived at the beginning of Nov expecting it to be the off season. But there were still frequently crowds in most of the places that we explored. My best advice is to spread out your visits more than you intended, and the places that you really want to spend time exploring in solitude, do so in the mornings when everyone else is huddled en masse at Angkor Wat waiting for the sunrise or when they are all gathering on hills for the sunset. The park is massive and diverse and worthy of all of the time that you can devote to it.

Huge huge park. Angkor Archaeological Park is a huge park. We hire a tuk tuk driver for our temple tour. If you are not a fan of temple, just purchase a one day pass. You don't have to visit all temples around as it will take several minutes to reach with tuk tuk.
Enchanting!!!. Simply enchanting, magnificent! Not visiting this while in Siem Reap is mortal sin and total waste of your stay in Cambodia.
Nice park. Not much to see. But get a guide to explain things or you dont know what you're looking at. Nice walk and views.

once in a lifetime sight. I would recommend hiring a car and driver to take you around the sights as it is a long way between temples and and in the heat of the day it is very tiring to do it on push bikes.
Temples. Amazing sights but pace yourself if like me you are over 70. Maximum 3 temples a day and drink a lot of water.

Amazing architecture. We have 4 days 3 nights in Siem Reap. It's amazing town, full of history and heritage place. We bought 3 days pass cost USD 40. It's cover all temples that you want to visit. It is fantastic and brilliant architecture and engineering. You can't miss it! We hired a tuk tuk, driver name Chea Leem ( Tel: +885 93 299 133 ). He is a safety driver, friendly and kind. We enjoy the service of him. He bring us to Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and other temples. Two days cost below USD 30 only.Beside temples trip, you must visit to pub street, old market and night market. Try local Khmer food. It's delicious not spicy like Thai food. Viva is my favourite pub restaurant. Great to have frozen draft beer and frozen margarita there. The weather of Siem Reap really killing me super hot and humid. Must drink more water and bring sun block. Overall, it's fantastic trip. We love it so much!
Amazing place, amazing history, picturesque!. Definitely a must-see. Angkor Wat is a special place. The history of the place, the temples, the intricate details --everything was just beautiful. :)

Travelling Back in time... If you are visiting angkor on a 1 day pass and then move on to next country or city, it is certainly not worth it. You need a minimum of 3 days to explore the angkor archaelogical park. Upon your arrival, the first thing you need to do is to book tuk-tuk driver and negotiate on a price for 3 days. Dont try to strike too much of a bargain because most of them are extremely poor and their ancestral land forcefully taken so this is their only way of making a living. On day 1, inform your tuk tuk driver for picking you up at 4 am from your hotel. Once you reach angkor archaelogical park entry gate, get 3 day pass and then move to angkor wat. You can see hundreds of people jostling for a perfect spot to take that magical picture of sunrise at angkor wat. Take all the pictures you need, and then come back to hotel to rest or you can use that early morning nice weather to your full advantage to explore angkor wat, ta prohm and bayon. All this try to do it on day 1. Day 2 is for lesser known temples like banteay srei, banteay kdei, pre rup, phimeneakas, elephant terrace and terrace of the leper king. On day 3 you can continue to explore angkor or visit local artisan places and angkor national museum and shopping in pub street.

Highlight of one's visit to Cambodia. One should not miss this, or at least visit the 3 main temples (Angkor Wat, Ta Phrom, Bayon) when they visit Cambodia. It's an interesting attraction that is unique to Cambodia. It is a little bit too commercialized nowadays but if you just relax and wander around the temple grounds away from the big crowds, you'll still get to appreciate the serenity and history of this place. I've visited this place for the 4th time already so my visit is a bit more relaxed and I get a slightly different experience each time as I try to explore other nooks and crannies where I have not seen in my last trip.

Fantastic . When i saw this in the picture, i was really amazed by it. When i saw it in person, i was really mesmerized and in total awe of the beauty if the place. I really appreciate how the locals were able to preserve the culture and history of the Angkor Archeological Park. This is totally breath taking and i assure you that if you are historically and culturally inclined, you wont regret coming here

It is worth the visit if you like history and arts!. Date: 5 - 12 November 2015. What to bring: Hiking shoes that protect your ankle. As it rained, there were many puddles. It is not advisable wearing normal waking shoes. I even saw some tourists wearing high wheels. It is really bad when some of them accidentally walked into puddles. Not to mention that you will have steps to climb and some route became muddy.Please do not bring selfie stick. Enough said! Self stick should be banned!I bought a 7-day pass for $60 on 5 November 5pm at the ticketing booth. I reached at 4:30pm, by the time there were a handful of visitors waiting. I wanted to take my time to visit as many temples as I could and I decided to buy the 7-day pass. There were different counters / lines for different passes, i.e. a few counters for 1-day, 3-day passes. 7-day passes counter has the least tourists queue. In retrospect, it is worth it as "temple fatigue" could happen if you rush through visiting the temples during the first three days. Moreover, having the luxury of pacing myself for 7 days allow me to choose when and which temple to visit for the purpose of 1. Avoiding large crowd of tourists group. 2. Visiting at the right time allows me to appreciate the sunset / sunrise and enjoy the tranquility. If you have time, I encourage you to spend 1 week and buy the 7 day pass. Watching sunset at Angkor Wat is no longer as comfortable, in my opinion. First of all, by the time of my visit, tourists were no longer allowed to climb up to the "peak" of Angkor Wat and there were simply too many "like minded" tourists there. By 6pm, we were asked to leave as the site is closing for the day. However, it gave me a glimpse of how Angkor Wat is like and I could prepare my itinerary to visit for the next day.6 Nov. Watching sunrise at Angkor Wat is over-hyped. First of all, I reached the temple by 5:30am and there were already 2 dozens of tourists gathering around the 2 famous ponds to view sunrise. Secondly, it really depends on the weather. During my visit, it was too cloudy to actually see the perfect sunrise that everyone is talking about. However, the nice thing about reaching that early is that after a while tourists started to go back to their hotel for breakfast or rest. Angkor Wat became much more quiet and I could actually spend good time visiting the entire place with only a handful of visitors. There are many quiet spots prior to 9am, that is when large tourists group arrive with their guides. In summary, it is fine to insert a morning or two to view sunrise at Angkor Wat. But it is not a must. After all, it is your holiday. If you want to appreciate the temple with a peace of mind, go before 9am or during noon. Also, try to buy the pass by 5pm previous day as buying in the morning is too crowded. When I passed the ticketing booth by 5am, there were many buses with dozens of tourists waiting to buy the passes. Locals informed me that March to August is low season for tourists. However, the pond might be dry if you are looking to capture the "perfect picture". I left Angkor Wat after 3 hours and proceed to Angkor Thom.A visit to Angkor Thom involves viewing Bayon, Baphuon, Phimeanakas, Royal Palace, Terrace of the Elephants, Terrace of the Leper King, Preah Palilay, Tep Pranam, and smaller temples around North and South Kleang.My tuk tuk driver allowed me to alight after entering through Bayon and waited for me at the end of the Terrace of the Elephants. The site is huge but walkable. I appreciate the time I spent there after visiting Angkor Wat. By the time I left Angkor Wat, it was 10am and it was the time where large tourists group arrived. They usually would visit Angkor Wat prior to coming to Angkor Thom. I spent around 3 hours at Angkor Thom. What I like: The different temples that offer unique and individual characteristics. As it is more spacious, it allows me the space and time to visit according to my pace. 7 Nov.Visited: Small Tour Circuit (Phnom Bakheng, Thommanom, Chau Say Thevada, Ta Keo, Ta Prohm, Banteay Kdei, Prasat Kravan, Sras Srang.From: 9am to 3pm.What I liked best:Phnom Bahkeng in the morning. It was a nice hike to the mountain with no one else! I understand from locals that Phnom Bahkeng is becoming too touristy as people rushed there to watch sunset. If you prefer to appreciate nature, go in the morning with good hiking boots. Other smaller temples. The temples by Small Tour Circuit are less visited my mainstream tourists with the exception of Ta Prohm.Sras Srang is a nice spot for sunset! And not a lot of tourists.What I liked least: Ta Prohm. By the time I was there, it was near noon and there were too many large group of tourists with their guides. It was impossible to walk at your pace and they have designated walking path that you need to follow. There were simply too many people competing to take photos at the designated infamous spot. I even saw a tourist sprinkling her loved one's ashes at a particular tree while her partner took her photo doing that. At the same time, other tourists were forming lines behind them to take turn to take photos of that infamous tree, with roots over a temple...8 Nov.Visited: National MuseumGrand Tour Circuit (Preah Khan, Neak Poan, Ta Som, East Mebon, Pre Rup)National Museum was unplanned but it rained. So, naturally, museum provides a good shelter and by the time I finished touring the place, it stopped raining. What I liked best: Again, it is the tranquility that some of these temples offer. Go early, before large crow arrived. Pre Rup is also a good place for sunset. 9 Nov.Visited: Banteay Srey, Banteay Samre, Landmine Museum, Butterfly Center. Pre Rup and Sras Srang.I would leave my review on Landmine Museum and Butterfly Center at the right place.Banteay Srey and Banteay Samre are further away and I took tuk tuk to reach there. It was a good experience for me as I could enjoy the scenery along the way. However, be mindful that the journey took 1-2 hours and it was dusty. Again, Banteay Srey is a touristy spot, try to be there as early as possible. Again, large crowd arrived by 11am.These two sites are worth the journey and visit. They offer different perspective that other temples do not.This is when I enjoyed sunset at Pre Rup and Sras Srang. They are nearby. If you do not mind climbing steps, go Pre Rup. By the time I reached by 5pm, there were only 20 people. Throughout the experience, it was not too bad. Definitely better than Angkor Wat and Phom Bakheng. If you do not want to climb steps, go Sras Srang. It is good!10 Nov.Visited: Preah Ko, Bakong, Lolei (Rolous Group). War Museum. Angkor Artisans.What I liked best: There are further away from the mainstream temples and it is worth the visit if you still feel up to it. Their entrance is included in the Day Pass. Less tourist, more tranquility.In summary, the sequence of temples I visited was:Day 1: Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom.Day 2: Small CircuitDay 3: Large CircuitDay 4: Banteay Srey, Banteay Samre.Day 5: Rolous Group.It provides a different flavour after visiting the larger temples like Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom when you proceed to visit other smaller temples.

Angkor Visit. Jaw dropping and stunning archeological site/s. A must. It shows the peak and sophistication of the Khmer Empire. So many awesome and spiritual sites and temples to visit. One must spend at least 4-5 full days. Many beautiful things to appreciate, see and take in at Siem Reap (which in itself is a lovely S.E.Asian city). Go for the bigger sites (like Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, etc.) but also do Not Miss the tranquil and less visited temples (the older Roluos Group with Preah Ko and Bakong), Banteay Kdei and Banteay Srei and Koh Ker. If you go for longer then visit the Preah Vihear breathtaking site next to the Thai Border (which is still disputed even though the International Court found for it belonging to Cambodia).
Cultural Heritage. Captures the true essence of the temple complex at Angkor. Gives you the history and construction of the temples as well
Makes worth the trip from anywhere. This is the reason to be for Siem Reap city, its restaurants and hotels, but you knew that already, didn't you?

A fantastic exploration of Cambodia nancient history. We were lucky enough to have a fantastic guide - Mr Pok Samnang - Sam! Sam was an amazingly calm, gentle, knowledgeable charming guide. His extent of knowledge of ancient history, modern history, natural history and politics was amazing! Angkor Wat was beautiful but in Angkor Thom I could see life as it was a millennium ago. Amazing to think of the bounty and sense of community in those days. Bantea Srei was also just beautiful, the pink sandstone looked like it was lit from within. In each temple, the use of perspective to show reverence, give the impression of a long journey or reveal unexpected connections was inspirational and impossible to capture on film. The temples are a must - see as many as you can...

A true wonder of the world.. You can spend days at this place and you need to in case you want to see it all. Recommend buying the seven day pass and hiring a guide to get the max experience. I was expecting the temples to be fantastic but the nature around them us equally stunning. Lots of great food to be had in the area too though the prices are quite high. Don't forget to bring loads of water, it gets super hot in the middle of the day!

Outstanding and stunning, must see!. A life-long dream of mine was to visit Angkor and I found it to be everything I expected. I spent 3 days touring the park which allowed me to revisit my favourite sites for the sunrise/sunset experience.The temples outside the main area are spectacular and you get to see the country and forest as well.I missed out on the sunset from the hill because I got there too late - started the climb at 4.30pm but the queue was already quite long. Start at 4pm.

Culture and History at it's Best. This is truly an amazing national park. It is a UN world heritage site and should not be missed if history, culture, archaeology, ancient architecture and jaw-dropping amazement are your things. It is a huge park and really should be appreciated with the services of a professional guide - hired either on-site or in Siem Reap before you go to the park. You can buy a multi day pass and I highly recommend that you use a guide for one of those days. After that, maybe hire a tuk tuk in the city to take you to the park just to stroll among the amazing places to just enjoy without being overloaded with a whole bunch of history. Make sure you have a big capacity memory card in your camera!

MUST VISIT. When in Siem Reap do as much as you can seeing the temples here, they are just awe inspiring. Hard to imagine when you are there and looking at these structures that they were built in the 10th, 11th & 12th centuries. The works are just wonderful and the bas relief found throughout angkor wat is just mind boggling and startling. The amount of details that went into these structures - wow!

So many temples, and lots to see... We traveled by private car with a private guide. However, it is probably also good to see it by Tuk Tuk or even by bike done by some adventuresome young tourists as there are multiple temples

why not bike from temple to temple. Ok, everyone knows thus is one of the world's greatest highlights. But what you may not know, it is also one of the best managed UNESCO sites in the developing world. For those used to other south Asian countries, you will be pleasantly surprised by the cleanliness of the sites, roads, toilet and seemingly endless green reserves that wind through the enormous region where the dozens of temples are located. Those supporting the Cambodian Government in managing this incredible treasure have placed considerable energy in ensuring that the infrastructure is in place to cope with steadily rising numbers of tourists. And well managed it is!I would recommend those with cycling skills to consider bike rental and heading from temple to temple (there are dozens and everyone is different and special in their own way) by bike, The starting point at Angkor Wat is only a few km out of town and once there the riding in roads meandering through the jungle is a great experience in itself. It is incredibly safe as, unlike in Australia, all traffic respect the slow moving bikes and treat you accordingly. Actually, all the traffic is pretty slow moving! Plus, the truck and long distance traffic are located on other roads away from this tourist area. Bikes are readily available to hire in Siem Reap. We had a couple of old clunkers with no gears which was no issue as the terrain is effectively as flat as a billiard table. Best to bring a bike helmet from home if you are worried about falling as I didn't see any available locally.Another issue: how many days and how many temples? We like to potter around, see things at our own pace and hence we spent nearly a week in Siem Reap. At first we worried this was too long. But to be honest, it was no challenge to find new activities every day as there are so many temples and they are scattered around a reasonable large area. Every temple is different, with its own charm, style and features. Another plus in having more time is to help avoid the busy periods of the day especially 10-12 each morning. Dont forget an umbrella as it seems to rain every day for a while.

Enormous and Fascinating.. A park that houses History within the 40 km radius is like a miracle in itself. Just let this park encapsulate you in its beauty. Taking a guide along is a Must to understand culture, life and beauty.
Surrounded by more than 1000 Years of History. An amazing display of Ancient Khmer culture from both Buddhist and Hindu eras. It's worth it to hire a guide to make the most of your visit.
Mesmerising. Beautiful and fascinating and easy to get to by tuk tuk. Just make sure you check out the dress code before you go!
A "wonder" not to be missed.. We had the added benefit of being able to cycle around the incredible park and with a very good guide. The whole experience was something never to be forgotten.
Stunning. Just a beautiful 3 days of exploring these ruins taking your time to absorb the atmosphere and take in history.

Amazing....... Amazing place...Enjoy this place by going early..
Tip:Take water and umbrella it can get very hot and humid during the day.

Amazing place. Truly amazing place, one of the highlights of my life. Do it by bicycle across a few days as that's the best way to get around. I had a look at then one and two star reviewers for a laugh, I think those people are genuinely a bit crazy, this is one of the worlds greatest places of visit and I implore everyone to go

Entry to Angkor Wat. The local village market inside Angkor Wat, does take away some the mystic and splendour. So this made for me a bit of disappointment. Although I do appreciate people need to make money, but not right beside it..
Magnificent. Magnificentgo early to avoid crowds I mean about 5 o'clock am take your drinks with you and your water as it's very hot now be prepared for a long day

A jumble of temples, many damaged by earthquakes. Stunningly beautiful.. Visited by far fewer people than the main Angkor Wat site, this is atmospheric and beautiful. The whole site had a myriad of butterflies flitting on the wild flowers in this clearing in the jungle. Only very small areas have been restored but the site is magical. You can wander anywhere, which is such a privilege. Many of the temple buildings are huge and you can see huge piles of stone pieces [like a big jigsaw] waiting to be reassembled. What a job that will be! The sun was nearly setting as we wandered round and the feeling of history was palpable.

The Center of the Universe. Angkor Wat is considered the Center of the Universe. When you visit here, you do kind of feel like you're being watched. There is an energy that is focused on this place in the jungle, the temples, the trees, the lakes, ... It is not scary, though; more exciting, exhilarating, and joyous to see all the tourists. We hired a tuk tuk for the day, wanting to experience the outdoor feel as we went from temple to temple. You're going to sweat anyway the moment you step outside, so why not just enjoy the fresh breeze blowing on your face (or back) as your tuk tuk driver takes you to each temple. We did hire a guide at Angkore Wat, who explained about all the temples, not just Angkor Wat. See Angkor, it's worth the trip!

Spend a day or three. From the elephant ride to the ruins to the tuktuk ride around and back to the city, this is one of the few places I've been (I've visited over 50 countries) where the NatGeo articles and pictures were insufficient to adequately present the site. See the sun rise, climb the stairs, visit many (even though some appear the same). The 3 days here were the best part of our 3 week trip.

Large scale historical site. This site has many monuments, some such as Angor Wat of a massive scale. It is very busy at most times. You can join an organised tour or hire a tuk tuk driver for the day and go at your own pace. The best way if you are reasonably fit is to hire a bike at your hotel or in Siem Reap and do the smaller or larger circuit by cycle. One out of Siem Reap, the roads are relatively quiet and you can go at your own pace, and spend as long as you like at each monument. It is all flat so easy cycling. Grasshopper tours do a very well led day trip.

Anither Bucket List Item Completed!. Three friends and I booked a private excursion to Angkor Wat from a Celebrity cruise of Asia. We engaged a car with driver to pick us up at the pier in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam to take us to the airport there flew to Siem Reap, Cambodia where another car with driver met us to take us to our hotel. For the next two days, the driver showed us the wonders of Angkor Wat, driving us as close as possible through the gates, with permission from the guards, to the temples themselves and explaining the sights, providing us frequently with cold bottled water. He gave us an excellent history of his country and stories of his personal life. This small group tour was the perfect way to experience this mysterious place.
Must see. What a spectacle of history, architecture and beauty, where nature has taken back the stones. Absolutely enchanting, like something off a film. A must see for any visit to Cambodia.

Number one temple complex.. There are enough reviews about Angkor and for many people it is the one reason to visit Cambodia. I have nothing to add or remark on the excisting reviews. It is the number one temple complex and it is absolutely worth a visit. One important note though. Many reviewers write that you need at least three days to visit this place. I do agree that you can easely spend three or more days here. I did not find it absolutely necessary. The 'small route' including the most important/impressive temples can easely be done in one day and everything after that is surely impressive but adds little to the first day experience. I spend about 8 hours in Angkor and found it enough for me personally. I did not rush anything and used a tuc-tuc for transport. I do not feel bad for a second that I did not have more days here.

Amazing!!. The whole archaeological park is an amazing area. There are many temples from the C10th - C12th and the variety of styles is intriguing. I would suggest not trying to do too many temples in the one day, but perhaps choose the ones you are most interested in first, and then perhaps have a break. Apart from the temples themselves, there are many carvings and statues that add interest. There are a variety of day, three day and weekly passes that can be bought.Be advice is to pace yourself and enjoy each site.

Good if you like temples..... Believe it or not it is possible to get 'templed out'!!!Costs $20 to get into the park - there is no greater concentration of architectural riches anywhere else on earth. Includes the world's largest religion building - Angkor Watt, and a temple uniting Hinduism and Buddhism - Preah Khan.
Tree root. It is a wonderful place to visit. Lots of great sightseeing to visit, you will not regret it. I visited multiple times when I was there.

Wonderful.. This huge area contains numerous ruins of temples from the 10th to 12th century. Some are being reconstructed and others have been left. All are very interesting as they are different. The carvings are wonderful and the lotus shaped towers are impressive. A must see on the bucket list. The passes are $20 one day, $40 three day, to be used within a week, and $60 weekly to be used within a month. You must carry your pass and produce it at every temple.

Well preserved and very accessible. The system to get into the park is super simple and easy to understand. We chose a 3 day pass for $40. They click out the date and you get 6 days to use 3 days. We used up one of our days on the flight of the gibbon because it's in the park. So that left two days for temples. Therefore we've had two huge days. The park it's self is very clean. There are toilets for free if you show your pass. Do not loose your pass. They check them at every temple. Next time we would go by bike and we would get a 6 day pass. Then choose the temples we won't to revisit. They all have a very different ambience.

Find the smaller temples. There are some real hidden treasures in this park. The main temples are awesome in their history and architecture, but the smaller temples have more to offer intimately. The butterfly temple, located near the flight of the gibbons, had no visitors when we went. Also, if you geo cache there are a few geo caches hidden in this park, and it's incredible to find them! It's definitely an unforgettable experience.
Amazing. Just loved this place, try and go towards the end of the day when the crowds have left and just winder around, just magical. Its a must while in Siem Reap.
Truly a wonder of the world. Small circuit has the highlights. Consider going to another temple early in the morning beside Angkor Wat to beat the crowds.
love those roots. Cambodia is very cheap, the roads are not the best I remember very dusty roads, but the temples looks very different than others in the world
Must do!. We rode pushbikes around the inner route on the first day and this was not hard at all. The roads are flat and there is plenty of room to move to the side if needed.

Amazing, Magical, Beautiful...a must see!!. The temple complex is huge hence three day pass for $40. probably more of a wonder than the Giza pyramids and that's saying something!!. Try and see around areas that are slightly off the main tourist track, there are wonderful things to be found, just keep your eyes open and explore. Be careful though as there are snakes...it's a jungle out there!!!!! Yes it will be busy at the main hot spots, but you will still be able to marvel at the complete awesomeness of the place. The "tomb raider" doorway and tree area being the most popular. You can get some good shots avoiding the tourist being in them, get in line if you have to and wait your turn so you can get that shot. Three day pass....I could have spent three weeks there looking around.
The extent of this park is mind boggling. It is outstanding to think that all of these structures were made by man and elephant without the aid of CAD drawings.

Incredible - not to be missed!. I don't think I can add anything that you haven't read already. I would highly recommend a tour guide - do not attempt to go to any of the temples or parks without a guide if you want to learn.

Very Popular. Angkor Archaeological Park was rated the number one place to visit in the world and unfortunately as a result you will be sharing this experience with thousands of people at a time. We were swamped and this was apparently the quiet season. On the plus side, the Cambodian government have done well to keep stray vendors from hassling tourists and you are likely to only experience any on the entry to a temple. There are some spectacular sites here, my favourite of the lesser known ones being East Mebon
Beautiful silver treet. It is unbelievable to see such huge trees standing in all the temples. strong big roots becoming the trees themselves, as they are so huge. Beautiful historical park.

Life changing!. If you have even the slightest chance to go take it!!!!!!! It is an archeological wonder, you actually feel the past permeating and it is definitely and experience worth having. Now onto the practical aspects of visiting:- You are going to walk. And the walk some more. So choose appropriate shoes.- Its going to be hot and humid so I suggest sun block and a hat.- Ask your hotel to arrange a tutu for the day or however long you plan to go to the park as it is the way to get around, they normally carry water they sell you and keep it cold so that helps and is totally worth it- You can do one day or more to visit and just ask for advise to the hotel staff which places to choose. Even if its just one day its worth it and doable- Shopping in the markets outside the temples is completely worth it, in town you won't get better prices and the merchandise will be different so take advantage of this. Remember though to bargain as prices go down up to 50% (at least)What else, just enjoy and really my sister and I trusted the locals advice on which places to visit and it worked out just perfectly.
What a tree!. Amazing ecological abundance our GOD showered to Cambodia. Its worth seeing the magical formation of these tress covering the ancient temples.
Unforgettable. As you already know, here they make some parts of movie Tomb Rider. It's amazing place, but full of Tourists.
Unbelievable Temple, So secret and gives me really awesome energy.. Love the tree grows just right on top of the temples and it must be so old. How amazing the histories here began.

Just magical.. A trip to Cambodia is not complete without spending a few days exploring the temples. We traveled during August and while it was really hot, the crowds were quite minimal so we were able to take quite a few photos without other people in background. Highly recommend booking a tour guide to make the most of your experience. What a magical place.

The quintessential jungle encroached temple. Do not miss Ta Prohm just because you've been to Angkor Wat. This is the quintessential jungle temple experience (was used in Tomb Raider film), and shows amazing jungle and fig tree incursion into the stonework.

One of the sights of the World. Just a stunning experience. Our second visit and just as good. The variety and size of these temples is quite awe inspiring. I would like to have seen more, but we have 4 days under our belt and all good.

A Grand Day Out. I have visited this wonderful temple complex twice now with visits one year apart and find that I prefer a one day pass to the 3 consecutive days as 6 hours wandering about in 33 degrees can be a bit tiring.You can hire a bicycle and ride to the temples which is an easy ride or rent an electric bike if you don't fancy pedalling.If you can ride a motorcycle you can rent one with a guide and visit some of the more isolated temples where there are no tourists as the whole temple complex covers a vast area encapsulating many villages. This is best after a visit to the main temples.The motorcycle tour will take you about half a day and cover about 60 Km. there will be no entrance fee to pay as you turn right before arriving at the Angkor entrance, this is mostly gravel road and sandy tracks so best for those with some motorcycle experience and provides a glimpse of the real Cambodia.Definitely worth a visit and should be on everyone's bucket list.
Trees are worth the trip. Go see this if you're in Siem Reap! Impossible to believe how large the roots are until you stand under them!
Lara Croft's dream. Wow... talk about Tomb Raider... lara croft eat your heart out. I had always wanted to visit here ever since I saw Angelina Jolie doing the splits over that old tree

Great to see with a knowledgable guide.. Best to go with a guide. Very crowded and lots of walking. A guide will tell you some history which will make the place more interesting. Otherwise, it will seem like rocks with trees growing from them.

a must see and must experience. We got the 3 day pass and did the small and the large circuit. Added a few monuments from the outskirts and were impressed with the historical feats the Khmers built. This is amazing history and the fight between preservation and the jungle makes it hard to pick sides. Looking back it would have been better to split it up over more mornings, like 4-5 days. The heat, humidity and crowds get to you after spending the entire day there. We were thankful to have selected tuk-tuk transportation. People were cycling and I think they must have been crazy. This distance you have to travel and in this weather leave me thinking they could not have been having fun. One can also feel bad for the crowds stuck on the tour buses. They miss so much being shuffled from one place to the next on someone else's schedule. To truly appreciate this park strike out on your own.
Film site for Tomb Raider. Visiting this historical park was the highlight of my trip. Angkor Wat is the world's largest religious structure. It was built by the Khmer people and is being restored.

Must see!. You cannot go to Siem Reap with out visiting the Angkor Archaeological Park. The temples are amazing. My four must see temple within the park are... Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Phrom and Bantreay Srei.

A unique experience partially ruined by (lack of) management. Yes visiting these temples is an experience that should not be missed by any visitors, but the management leaves a lot to be desired. The tours are all marketed as two distinct types regardless of the method of those tours (tuk tuk, tour group, guided tour, etc.) - the 'grand tour circuit' or 'small tour circuit'. This funnels the same groups of people around the same few temples in generally massive groups of rude (generally - particularly the guides), uncompromising people from mainly Asia, if our visit was any example of the trend.If that were not enough it's about time the managing authority helped the tourist hawkers to get out of these temples and the general area with the wad-loads of cash they're raking in from tourists. The experience is utterly ruined by constant harassment and bombardment of locals looking to screw over ignorant, 'rich' and naive tourists. I was literally followed for 500 metres as we left Ta Prohm being asked the same 'you buy, you buy' question. This is the indelible, lingering memory I have of the big temples here - it's time this issue was managed.I understand the cultural significance these sites have to the locals, as I do with those who have lived in these areas since before tourism was made possible here, but something has to be done. Why stalls and houses need to exist in such numbers and in such close proximity to these significant, historical sites - many times within the temple areas themselves - baffles me. This would not be allowed in most countries.Lastly, signage needs to be improved and perhaps an effort needs to be made to stop locals riding their scooters everywhere inside the park. It's difficult to take in the experience when you're funnelled towards hawkers being surrounded by market sounds and whining engine noise. A real shame as this is only going to get worse as tourists increase. Bad as it already is, see it while you can! And go in low season, seriously.This is my second visit as the first was 3 years ago - be aware that many areas are currently under 'construction' and/ or closed off for safety. This WILL alter your experience based upon when they are working.

Indulge. Immerse yourself in the most amazing place. Wonder at how it must have been. Fanatically restored. Or not restored adds to the atmosphere.I visited in August (not as shown) low season. Fewer crowds or even if you're lucky have it to yourself in various parts. Don't be put off by monsoon season. It probably won't rain. If it does its soon over. Wonderful place

Must see !! . Even though your like me and want to avoid big turist attractions this is something you should not miss when your in Cambodia! You need atleast two days to see all the temples. Go early in the morning so you avoid the big crowds, it will also be cooler than in the afternoon witch is a big plus because it is A LOT of walking . Pay for a tour guide or walk by yourself its upto you, I would have preferd a guide that knew the history of the tempels but just seeing them is very impressive .

One the must visit historical sights for the world traveller!. Admission is pricey at $40 for 3 day pass but then again the area the park covers is massive, more temples that you would ever want to visit! Recommend the "Top 5" - Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Phrom, Preah Kahn and Banteay Kdei together with the Terraces of the Leper King and Elephants (next to each other pass the Bayon).

AMAZING!. A must see on everyone's bucket list! A place with so much beauty and great energy. The place is huge and includes several temples and you need a 3 day pass for this is you don't want you feet to fall out. Catch the sunrise over Angkor Wat. You will not regret it. And visit Spiderboy's (local young vendor) terrace for a refreshment. Receive a blessing from a monk and take many many pictures. If you want to climb to the top of Angkor Wat you need to have your legs and shoulders covered otherwise no entry. Book a tuk tuk to take you from one temple to another. costs 15$ per day.
Simply Amazing. Simply Amazing, so many things to discover, a world of history lost in time for you to uncover, a must see for anyone looking to understand the Khmer culture
Great experience and unforgettable!. So many wonderful temples around Angkor Wat park to explore. Have to see all the temples between sun rise and sun set. And then in the evening head to pub street.
Good for children and adults. A must see in Siem Reap, walking fresh air, elephants, monkeys, loads of archeological history plus local flea markets
The "tree" . His is quite impressive, since years I was hoping to get to visit this exact location, to be honest it didn't disappoint! Great experience

A MUST. So much to see throughout this whole park, including of course Angkor Wat etc. Too much for one day, but if that is all you have then pick your main three and off you go. One day was all we had, and a one day pass is USD20. Tip: these actually go on sale at approx 4.45 the day before - line up, buy one, and then you can actually use it that afternoon as well as the next day. We bought our pass in the afternoon, and headed straight to Angkor Wat for sunset. and then had all the next day to use it as well.

Amazing . The whole Park was truly magical. An experience that I'll never forget. Relatively inexpensive for a whole days activity. Hire a tuk Tuk and have him take you around all the attractions. Guides available on site if you choose to use them. Must see
This is AMAZING!!. Wow wow wow!!! A must see whilst you are there. Walk around. Get a three day pass!! Three days not really enough. Hire a guide. Soo much info to absorb!!

Worth travelling thousands of miles to witness. A truly majestic experience of more than 30 temples across a vast area of jungle and sculpted entrances and surrounds. Hard to fathom that this whole system laid undiscovered, overgrown by the jungle for more than 700 years. At least 2 days if not 3 required to soak it all up.

The reason why you are here in Siem Reap!. Like many reviews, people gush over this place. And it is worth gushing over. And here's why:Angkor Archaeological Park is HUGE. Within the park, there's easily more than 10 temples or ruins to explore. To see each and every one of them, you would probably need to take about 2 whole days hopping from one temple to the next on a tuk-tuk as it is the most convenient way to travel about in the park. But taking a half/full day tour of the place and seeing the main 5 - 6 temples is really enough for you to go home with a good experience of the place. Not to mention, cramming so many temples in 2 - 3 days will leave you overwhelmed and less likely to remember most things you experienced and saw.The drive in the park is amazing. You see thick trees on either side of the road and if you are on a tuk-tuk on a mildly hot day, there will be a nice breeze. Most tuk-tuks can be hired through your hotel (which is the preferred method of hiring a tuk-tuk to guide you through your temple hopping day) and most of them are very accommodating, providing you with cold water and a cold towel during your tour. The temples are amazing and beautiful, with thick trees and forest surrounding it. A lot of the temples are quite similar and if you've seen one, you can expect to experience the same thing in the other temples. There are of course a few more distinctive and popular ones that most tour guides will not leave out, so don't worry as you won't miss out any of these. Remember to wear proper shoes as some of the steps leading up to some of the temples are quite narrow and steep. I remember I had to literally crawl up one of them to get to the top and the crawl down was equally as daunting and tiring. The most memorable temple for me was Ta Prohm because it was very big and it's like a maze inside! Almost at every turn or corner, you can imagine how magical it was like all those years ago. Especially when there's light shining through the overgrown trees above the temple, you could really appreciate its beauty. Not to mention it's great for photo ops!Angkor Wat was beautiful too. My tip is to go during sunset and NOT sunrise. Wayyyyy too many people at sunrise and you will find it hard to snatch the perfect spot to take your mandatory "Angkor Wat reflection against the pond" photo. Plus, sunset colours are absolutely breathtaking compared to sunrise. Even taking photos during mid-day will give you an amazing postcard-like photo feel. There are 2 ponds in front of Angkor Wat, guides would usher everyone towards the left pond, but I realised that the right pond has more water and the reflection of the temple looked nicer ;)When you enter Angkor Wat, there's a lot of interesting carvings on the walls and it would be handy to pay a guide at the entrance to explain all these for you. But if you like exploring by yourself, you would still find it an enjoyable experience without an official guide. It's very peaceful inside the temple. But BEWARE of unauthorised scammers (shady men) hiding in dark quiet corners inside the temple waiting for tourists to step in and explore those narrow corridors. They will shove you some incense sticks for praying, ask you pray to some former statue of a buddha for good luck and health for your family and ask you to pay a donation to them in USD. They are not monks or workers in the temple but are there to take advantage of tourists. DECLINE them at the very start. Give them back the incense stick and say it is against your religion or you're not comfortable doing it (while doing this, try to be polite about it but be VERY firm and INSIST you want nothing to do with the prayers). The temples have their own donation box guarded by a monk near the main entrance. If you want to make a donation, make it there. And even after we told those men we already donated at the entrance, they came up with some silly excuse and insisted we pay them. They usually hide at the very remote corners that nobody would really walk by so be very careful when you see these people. Other than that, it was a nice place to visit. If you are there in the afternoon, temple hopping under the hot sun and humid weather, don't miss the coconut ice cream stick sold by road side vendors near some of the temples. They are simply the BEST thing to cool you down and the refreshing milky coconut flavour is just the perfect accompaniment to your day.

Amazing building. It is a hurt and sold of Cambodian. gkor Wat lies 7 km north of the modern town of Siem Reap, and a short distance south and slightly east of the previous capital, which was centred at Baphuon. It is in an area of Cambodia where there is an important group of ancient structures. It is the southernmost of Angkor's main sites. There is no concentration

Amazing Temple!. Amazing temple! rich in history and lots of different species of trees! Be sure to visit the temples early morning, it will be extremely hot in the late afternoon and crowded. Unbelievable trees that naturally grows and were not purposely planted by man. Be sure to bring lots of water while visiting the Temples, there were vendors selling water and snacks but a bit pricey, so just bring your own if you can. Also umbrella/hat and sunblock. :)
Angkor Archaeological park. A history that speaks for itself. It is unlike what you read online or see on TV. To understand the history, one must step foot into these grounds.

Take time to savour this wonderous place. Simply stated - Angkor Wat is one of the most beautiful and remarkable built environments in the world. To truly appreciate this treasure 2 or more days are needed. Consider the heat when planning your trip - so very early morning & later in the afternoons are valuable tips that made our trip far more enjoyable. Also consider hiring a guide who will provide you with a more memorable experience than just reading from a guide book or journal. Your memories of what is vividly explained to you will last a lot longer that the memory of how much you spent. :-))
Must do in Cambodia. Must do while in Cambodia. Great place to take pictures for a photographer. Make sure you have water with you as can be warm...

Temple under trees. Breathtaking sights of temples covered with century old trees. Roots of the trees are so vast and huge that they resemble Anaconda. Disturbed stones lying around are numbered for restoration in future, hopefully.

So much to see. There were so many temples in Angkor that we couldn't see them all despite having a full day pass. It was extremely hot by about midday when we left and even though we had been there since 5 am we had only covered Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm. Would have taken a 3 day pass if we'd had longer. The temples are breathtaking and it was really great to see how well they were being taken care of and how well they were being preserved despite the millions of tourists that must visit. The smaller temples had many less tourists and sometimes we were the only ones there which made them quite special as they were equally beautiful.
Worth a visit. If you are visiting angkor wat take a stop there were the famous tomb raider film was filmed. it is worth a visit.
Take it easy. Always start before breakfast and do no more than three sites per day planning to leave by noon or 1 as it does get hot. You need no less than three day for a nice visit.
A must Go Park. its a must go park,Angkor Archaeological Park is a nice time to spend your full day. its a history lovers Paradise. A better place to visit in the winter for beating the sun out
WOW factor. prepare yourself to be taken away by the beauty of this place. Its worth the effort to get there. I was impressioned and happy!

Must go in Siem Reap!. Even if you're not into historical-lover type of traveler, this place is still a must. Hire a local guide during ur visit here or else u will just looking at the ruins with a totally blank pointless face, unless u did ur research in Google beforehand.
