There are 1/3/7 days passes available to chose from but I personally recommend 1 day tour is fairly enough. After all, the temples look the same to me at the end of the day. USD20 per ticket. Keep ur ticket securely with urself all the time. Bring shades/cap/sunnier & lots of water with u. Weather is so humid.

pic and title don't seem rite. pic and title don't seem rite well following the caption -
this park consist of all temples in Angkor area to enter the park must buy the day pass usd 20 per day

Angkor is everywhere. The park is so so huge..well maintained..every temple has its own story..take a guide..otherwise you'll be tired of broken stone structures very soon. The ticket counters are open till 5:30 in evening. If you get a ticket in evening for the next day, you can enter the Park in this previous evening for free.

Angkor Wat in Sunrise. Spectacular!I never expected that there's such a huge temple around the city and amazingly beautiful. Okey, set your date of your travel its best to be there on summer so that when you visit the place and decided to see it whether sunrise or sunset it will be the most beautiful spot to capture the temple. It's so picturesquely incredible. Be there earlier to get the best spot in place. Bring water and hat. Food and souvenirs are available around the area. It's also a good thing if bring your own. Just don't forget water. It will be a long temple run if you may... Hehe. Reading books is fine but I'd rather see and know all the details of the architectural designs and structure of the temple. I guess it would take a day or more to experience the sight. Anyway, it will be the best highlights of Cambodia Tour. It is also known the film location of Thomb Raider starring Angelina Jolie or as Lara Croft. Enjoy and make the most of it. Travel is Love. ❤️✈️❤️
Giant Tree. This tree was from seed about 900 years ago they left it to grow not knowing it would grow all over parts of the temple, in parts the tree roots have destroyed parts of the temple.

Wonderful experience -- but do your research!. Everything about the Archaeological Park seems magical -- you are in complete awe of everything of all the temples.One key thing to keep in mind -- research, research, research before you visit! A friend and I booked a last minute trip here from Hong Kong and my biggest regret is that we didn't do enough research to 1) really appreciate what we were experiencing and 2) know which temples to prioritize on our trip.

Trees Taking Over. If you haven't see Tomb Raider (as I haven't) then this tree will not look familiar. But if you have, this is the Bayon temple, in Angkor Thom, and its 54 towers, each bearing four enigmatic smiling faces. The most spectacular temple of all, entwined with enormous trees, where Croft encounters the mysterious girl, is Ta Prohm.

Most productive day!. Here are my tips to do Angkor with young kids and still have a gala time!We got up for a sun rise and had the most productive day doing the whole circuit until 5 pm. My kids even drove a pony (extremely expensive) and elephant (again alarmingly expensive) but they deserved it for the all the enthusiasm they showed for a particularly adult attraction and endurance in walking without a complaint in the heatPeople asked me not to bring kids - 6 and 9 years but I was amazed how well they enjoyed. We took enough food and whenever they got bored asked them to take notes and photos. The guide was good and kept us regaled. But by 5 PM we were completely tired because of the heat but totally worth it. One of the most productive and overwhelming days as a family. Kids were off to sleep with my in law like logs while my hubby and I got some time alone at Pub Street. Everyone warned me against it, when I planned this trip with kids - Dont let it deter you. Kids love it if they understand, have some fun (elephant ride, pony, cameras for pics). They also had gone to musuem previous day and I had ignited their imagination already! That helped too! But ensure you take lots of food, hire a good guide, keep some entertainment handy, if possible provide individual cameras even cell cameras will do. Kids really enjoy clicking the pics in some unique places. Carry lots of water/juices,choclates, wear sturdy shoes, carry a change of clothes (it gets very sweaty) and changing our tshirts mid day enthused some fresh energy into us after a splash of ice cold water. And most importantly carry along your sense of pride for the culture. If affordable, please travel in AC car to provide some respite from the heat with kids rather than tuk tuk. That helped a lot as we were able to store a lot of things there for the whole day trip back in the car spaciously

Simply amazing. The park was so huge, theres a lot of activity that you could do there from watching sunrise to sunset, taking awesome pictures at all the Temple, learning the history of cambodia, one could even go for a picnic there like how the local does

Taphrom. Awesome place in the silence forest with a big big tree on the side of temple, always called Tom Raider. we spent over 3 hours to see this amazing temple even it is going to ruin because of tree but that looked strong with itself.

Stunning. Absolutely amazing place. We took 2 days tour and we didn't regret it. While most people go only on one day tour (small circuit) with Angkor Wat included, big circuit offers more misterious and less crowded temples, equally if no more beautiful. Beware of monkeys, especially in most popular places (Angkor wat, Ta Prohm), you may lost some of your belongings - we lost cookies...Sunrise in Angkor - must see, it's worth early wake up.
Magical. One of the must fascinating place I have ever visited in my life. If you want good photos , take your time and wait for tourists to clear out.
famous just because laracroft was there :). worth every penny waiting for taking picture. not that far from a.wat.just 10-15mins by tuktuk. weather just nice cause its lowseason in siem reap now :D

Truly extraordinary. The Angkor Archaeological Park is a truly remarkable place that will take most people at least two days to explore, and even more to truly embrace the historical significance of the area and see the most fascinating and quiet temples. Of course the area is extremely popular with tourists (as some of the more negative reviews have pointed out) more so around the more famous temples such as Angkor Wat, Praeh Kahn, Ta Prohm etc. However, this does not take away from the experience of travelling around the huge park and being perpetually surprised by how astounded you are by the majesty of the park. The $40 ticket covering 3 days of entry to the park is more than reasonable, while tuk tuk drivers seem to all charge a similar rate of $15 a day to drive you from your accommodation in Siem Reap and back while also bringing you to every temple you could want to see. All in all, the Angkor Archaeological Park is a completely unrivalled experience and a must see for anyone who has the opportunity to visit.
outstanding. We liked Angkor Archaeological Park and Bayon Temples the most of all the things we done in Siem Reap

a must see. the whole park stretches for miles and miles, we drove about 3 hours out of Siem Reap and were still in the park area, choose wisely which bits to see as you can easily get templed out- and it is VERY HOT in Cambodia in July.. also the temples in and around town can get super busy with tourists, try some of the temples further out if you have time
Marvelous. It's an amazing place!! One of the nicest places I have ever seen, it shocked me more than Egypt or the Mayan temples in Mexico

It makes you wanna sing the jungle book soundtrack over and over again.... I actually preferred the smaller temples (such as Ta Prohm) way more than Angkor wat. We were lucky that we visited in low reason, as this place is usually even more swarmed by travel groups.Easy to reach by bike or simply by TukTuk. Loved it!

Angkor Wat plus other Magnificat temples.. My husband and I went to the sunrise at Angkor Wat the. Onto Banyon then the one pictured where Tomb Raiser was filmed. We loved the Banyon one with all the smiling faces. It had a lot of character. Angkor wat is certainly huge. The tree root one is quite different to the others and quite amazing. Beautiful place to visit the whole area.
explore Angkor Wat. its like playing in tomb rider movie and i am acting as lara croft..so amazing place. you must visit this herritage.
Incredible. My far my favourite- although most visited by tourism due to the movie it is still incredible and my top choice

Be patient for that picture. Great place to see and plenty of photo opportunities, just be patient as you are far from alone. Downside, you guessed, kids hassling you in some places to buy something, be firm.

This is why people visit Siem Reap. Being an Indonesian, i'm used to temples such as Borobudur and Prambanan which are beautiful, majestic, and one of a kind. But.. this park gotta be one of my favourite place on earth. Everything was so photogebic that i can't stop taking pictures, everything was given huge detail that i can't stop admiring it's beauty and art. I feel like i wanna visit all the temples but i only managed to visit three which are Angkor Wat, Bayon, and Ta Prohm. I also had the best lunch in Cambodia here. A bowl of delicious Fish Amok which was just $5 (the restaurant is near Ta Keo if i'm not mistaken) this is why people visit Siem Reap

Beat the Heat & Tourist- go early!. Truly a must see, we were so thankful that we got the 3 day pass. We went into the park 2 days. We were there in the spring, late March. I would highly recommend going early for the sunrise and being back at the hotel by the pool by early afternoon. To beat the heat and the tourists.

Just go!!!. There is nothing to discuss. One have to visit this place. It is stunning. The mysteries. The lack of information. You go around just woundering. Amazed. Bring something to covers sholuders. Good shooes. Water. It gets hot walking around in there. But just come and see for yourselves. You want regret it!

beatiful to see, photos are a must. Another place, where pictures just take themselves. This is a place, where nature has taken over ancient ruins and created a marvel. This is a must see for those, who want more than the obvious touristy experience of Angkor Wat.

Take at least a week to get around this park.. When planning your trip, set aside a week to really take in this spiritual place. I was so honoured to see a lot of the temples, and it is an archaelogical marvel. Please remain respectful to the locals, and cover your shoulders and knees up. I was appalled to see many westerners not appropriately attired. This park MUST be properly protected by UNESCO.
Wow!. A must see when in Cambodia! I booked my tour with 'Happy Angkor Wat Tour' and would highly recommend them.

BEST BEST trip! Its Disney for history lovers-. Each of the Temples (Wat,Thom, Prohm) deserve highest accolades- while they overlap in features, their is uniqueness in every temple and each is worthy of a visit. The entry fee of $40 apurchased us a 3 day pass and Beyond Unique Escapes guided us efficiently and made history come alive. There really no signage so get a guide (or have a book). We braved 100 degree heat and 100% humidity to climb- trek and admire- we are better for each step taken there!

Best Place To Visit. It is one of the Beautiful places in Angkor Wat to see .. it is bound by massive roots of huge trees. Back in the days it was very different: one could see walls decorated by precious stones and roots of Silk and Ficus .
Amazing place. Unbelievable place,pictures do not do them justice. when you see all these tree roots growing over these ruins you realize how old these places are. A must see place.

Amazing . Even if you were never a history buff, get ready to be amazed by how amazing the park is (and also how enormous it is, in size!). Of course, rich histories come along with every building of the park, but for those who just like to see beautiful architectural, this is a good place to go. Be sure to bring a fully-charged camera! And also LOADS OF WATER ;-)

Park Family trip to Cambodia, June 2015. My family and I booked an all day van reservation and a driver to take us to all the local Siem Reap temples, one of which was Angkor Archaeological Park. Out of all the temples this was my favorite. The temple had much restoration done but has much to go. I loved seeing the trees and tree roots appearing to take over the temple remains. Our driver was knowledgeable and kind. I would advise visitors to especially go to this temple.

Visit of a lifetime. The temples contained within the Angkor Park are some of the most archelogically significant in the world. Visiting them offers a window into a world that none of us can even imagine. If you are ever fortunate enough to make it to Southeast Asia, make it to Siem Reap, so that you can visit the temples of Angkor.

If you have money, go.. I was there last year. It was a good ride. How I was alone the cost of Tuc-Tuc was expensive: U$15.00 (ideally go in groups). The entrance, if I remember correctly, was around US$ 20.00 (I think that now it is more expensive).One nice thing about Siem Reap is that you can find very good and cheap hotels. And the night in the city is very good and cheap to drink, that's why the city worth a visit.

Amazing places, awful managing. Angkor temples deserve ten stars! This is one of the best archeological spot all over the world.Unfortunately the management is terrible.Tickets: 20$ one day. 40$ three days (to be spent in one week). It is a fact that only a little part of this money goes to the preservation of Angkor.No info point or describing board around the huge site, neither a map when you buy the ticket. Everybody, from the receptionist of your hotel to the driver of your personal tuk tuk will tell you that the ticket is valid after 5 pm and the day after, in order to see both the sunset and the sunrise at the Angkor Wat, and a whole day to visit the site. Unfortunately it is impossible to see the sunset, since you could see it only from the top of a temple which can host few tens of people, result: if you go after 5 pm you will find a queue of people one kilometer long and nobody will leave the roof of the temple at that hour. Anyway, if you want to try, remember to bring with you long pants, otherwise you will be stop at the begin of the 15 min walking path to reach the top.Sunrise instead is very suggestive and it worths the early wake up. The small lake in front of the Wat is the best place for seeing it.The best way to visit the site is rent a tuk tuk driver for the entire day. Prices should be 15 dollars for the small tour, the best one, including Angkor War, Angkor Thom and Tha Phrom, and 18 dollars for the long tour, which not includes the previous ones and includes other minor temples.Do not go to Kbal Spean, there is absolutely nothing to see.

Worth seeing!. This park covers many many different places that are worth seeing. It is good to find a tourguide who can go around with you and explain the history behind all these sights. I have reviewed many sights individually on this site.
MUST SEE!. Clearly this is a must see for anyone visiting Siem Reap. Many, many spectacular sights to witness and appreciate.

Tree Temple - now also know as the Angelina temple. The tree roots are breathtakingly big and encircle the whole temple. I think that it is standing because it has been encircled and embraced by these tree roots.
Best Photographed at Sunset. Take your time and allow plenty of time to get the colours and light on the Temples, don't go at midday if you can avoid it.

Angkor Wat. Angkor wat is one of the biggest temple in Cambodia, it is my first time to see Angkor Wat temple, it is so so great time for me and my friends, i will tell my friends to visit cambodia again

Bounds beyond expectations. I'm a bit biased about the whole park because I've been a fan of fit for 9 years before I was even able to step in it. So it was way better seeing it in person. The most amazing thing I've ever seen in my entire life.

The trees are simply amazing. Make sure you bring your camera because you can find beautiful spots in almost every step you take. Don't do like me and spend more than just one day in Angkor since there is so much to see and so beautiful.

Amazing!. Everyone should visit this place once in their lifetime! The temples are amazing and the nature around them is luxurious. It takes minimum 2 days to see it all, so it is better to buy the 40 dollars ticket.

No words can describe the wonder. There are no words to describe the wonder that is this place! After visiting it for four days, you can close your eyes and realize that your are now totally impregnated by that beauty. Nice to think that man not only can destroy our planet but is also capable of creating beautiful things.

Hauntingly beautiful. Even if you're not a culture buff, Siem Reap is a must see. I've been 4 times and am always caught struck yet again of this beautiful area. Firstly you're driven along narrow roads in wooden nature. You get a glimpse of Cambodian life as many schools and homes are set within the park itself. Secondly you get to explore ancient artifices and buildings under restoration. I just hope visitors treat things with respect and don't take away little souvenirs.Don't feel you have to squeeze in too many temples, just enjoy the ride. Entry is well organised with a compound divided into booths for 1,3 or 7 day passes so do your homework and decide beforehand. A new development since 2 years ago is that the pass has now been digitised. No need to bring a passport photo, they'll take a digital shot. Alert your tuktuk driver if you want a restroom stop, the toilets are few and usually away from the temples or restaurant areas.

Top of the list of UNESCO Sites I've seen. Amazing amount of history to be learned. So much we in the West don't know about Southeast Asia. blend of nature and historical sites was impressive. Get a guide like I did with Yous Sopanha.

One of a kind.. Thought it would be one of those places where you'd see one temple you've seen them all...but it's the complete opposite. Each temple is unique in its own way. 3 days were enough for us. The sunrise is worth every minute of waking up early. We had cloudy weather twice and still it was nice. Reserve some time to visit Banteay Srei which is a tad further out of the whole park too.We also had a good tuk tuk driver. His name is Ny...Ask for him at the giant ibis station. Very friendly and patient guy who speaks excellent English and knows the temples well.

Surely a must-visit place when in Cambodia. The temples were breathtaking. We bought a 3-day pass for $40 and rented a tuktuk for around $45. Each temple we visited had its own distinct features. Being within nature and these temples made our experience an unforgettable one.The trip was well worth it!We brought our insect-repellent spray, sunscreen, and bottled water to make the tour more comfortable. You'll be under the sun and walking throughout the day so it's best to make sure you're protected and hydrated to be able to enjoy the experience more.

Battle of nature and man-made. This place was my husband's dream come true. I am so glad that we were able to visit it now. Who knows what it will be like in the future, perhaps not so easy to access.
WOW. The temples are not to be missed as there is such amazing history here to be experienced. Can be very hot so take plenty of water.
Incredible. We didn't have enough time to explore everything. Highly recommend visiting here and spending a week in Siem Reap. Its majestic beauty doesn't compare.

Nature takes over. This is a wonderful place to visit, having been left to the jungle for so long it is amazing to see how the tree's have intertwined themselves in to the and through the buildings, it is a must see simple as that. We visited the temple with hanuman travel and our guide Pheat Sinath, he really knew his stuff and knew exactly when to visit here, so after watching sunrise at Angkor Watt we came here in our private chauffeur driven car as the hordes left Angkor and headed for breakfast, arriving around 7am we had the entire place to ourselves bar 2 or 3 other visitors, walking around this place was amazing the quiet only adding to the magic of what we were looking at.A great place to visit and a great tour company to visit through

Must Visit Or You'll regret.. With all the good accessibility, Visiting the Angkor Archaeological Park is simply a place you can't miss. Great location for Greater Ancient Architectural Structure. Loving It!
Majestic trees keeping watch over the temple ruins.. This is a not-to-be-missed part of the temples experience. The trees outshine many of the temples in demonstrating the force of nature.
AWEsome. You would think that there are only so many ruins in a jungle you could visit and see... but each and every one of them is well worth a visit and leave you in awe and inspired

Awesome day. Definitely a must do! We got a tuk tuk driver and got to Angkor Wat at sunrise (5am) spent about an hr relaxing and watching, then spent the next 2hrs walking around Angkor Wat. Purchased a guide book for $8usd (could pay anywhere between $2usd-$15usd depending on time of day and your bargaining) back to the tuk tuk, toilet break (the ones where you will meet your driver outside of Angkor Wat are alot better than the ones inside at the markets) and went to Angkor Thom. Started with Bayon and it's amazing! If your unsure whether you want a guide, when you get here people will offer to take you around for a donation ($10usd ish). If you love hearing about history then I recommend you get one otherwise just wing it and appreciate the temples and intricate carvings! Had an early lunch, food is very good and not that much more compared to in town and still cheap considering! Ta Prohm was excellent and definately a highlight. Go in the afternoon for the best photos and if you lucky like us it won't be busy, although be prepared to line up for some of the famous 'tomb raider' pics. Time wise - we did the small circuit and large circuit in one day, starting with Angkor Wat at sunrise and ending with Ta Prohm. Enough time for us as we were templed out and saved us $ ($20usd entry pp at the entrance gate).

Different from other temples. This temple shld be visited by many as its different from the rest of the other temples. The uniqueness about this bayon temple is that you can see the nature like the tree roots passing through the temple and toppling down the actual structure of the temple. Definitely a must place to visit other than angkor wat.

Wonderful place. Amazing, no wonder it's world heretige listed and one of the top tourist attractions in the world. There are many temple ruins within the park we visited 4. Remember to allow plenty of time as it is really hot.
Isn't it what we all go for?. Absolutely stunning ,it takes your breath away. You could spend days looking and still not see it all. It has to bee seen to believe.
Cambodian highlight. NOT to be missed!! All the sites I visited are awesome but my favourite was Ta Prohm which demonstrates clearly how nature so easily claims back what humans have built. Stunning.

Amazaing.. Undoubtedly one of the top places.
The archeologists have removed one large tree because of the dangers it poses to the structure but even then the remaining trees are so good that it makes you wonder how a civilization as big as this one could get wiped out!
Unique! Fabulous!. We could not believe our eyes! It is so spectacular, that you hardly believe that this place is real!
Worth seeing. Excellent tour, guide friendly and knowledgeable, bus ok. Had a small tour which was good, unfortunately can't control that

3 days - not enough. 3 separate day visits to this park. The temples are magnificent. The steps at Angkor Wat steep and difficult (my aging knees are not in the best of shape), but otherwise a very interesting complex. The other sites/temples (Bayan, Angkor Thom, et.al) are easier to navigate. This site should be on everyone's bucket list.

Take your time. Spectacular constructions and carvings and the jungle is trying to reclaim it all. Be patient if you want photos of the buildings etc, lots of tourists with selfie sticks but worth the wait if you have the time. Make sure you get a 3 or 7 day temple pass, you'll need to take your time.

One of the Top 3 templs to visit. It was a true experience to see the trees and the roots eating all over the temples and keeping ruined. We were very happy to see all the restoration works. One true moment in one temple there to beat your chest and make a wish, it was a fun part.
Wonder Trees. Wonders of Trees along the the park, touristic, very attractive & worth to witness the nature wonders
Amazing Place to go.. Very interesting place to see how a tree and grown on top of another tree. The strong thick roots of the trees were amazing.

Simply a must see. Words cannot do justice to the sites here. Yes, it is packed with visitors at certain times of the day but if you are lucky and get up early you will be treated to some priceless memories which you will never forget.

One of the greatest sites on earth. The whole Angkor complex of temples deservedly is one the greatest sites on earth. It is amazing the artistry of these 1000-year-old temples that disappeared for 400 years into jungle and mostly survived brutal war in the 1970s.
it is breathaking but overcrowded. the time we visited the angkor wat is very crowded and you cant even move ! too bad the place is great but tourist here are piling up
Stunning!!!. Just the temple alone already stunned your mind, having an excellent tour guid is extra ordinary, paying a $20 to those person to walk you back to hundreds year is what i call amazing.

Simply Stunning!. Without doubt one of the most awe inspiring places I've been. The scale, the detail and the condition of the temples (Especially Angkor Wat) is simply mind blowing.We hired a tuk tuk driver for the day for $18 USD - could probably pay around $12-15 if you bartered harder.They will stop at the ticket booth on the way where you must pay $20 USD for a day's pass or $40 for a 3 day pass. Personally I would get a one day, see if that left you all templed out. If not then a second day should suffice.At Angkor Wat I'd recommend hiring a guide (you could always try and get a tuk tuk driver that doubles up as a guide). Guides seem to have a uniform and badges. About $10 should be reasonable for a couple of hours tour. Angkor Wat is a must see. Sunrise is said to be sublime, with the reflecting pools offering amazing photos. I was there in July, so too cloudy and overcast but the photos came out nice nonetheless. There are many other smaller temples in varying degrees of restoration - from piles of rubbles through to near immaculate. They have before and after photos and you won't believe that its the same thing. Theres plenty of shops and restaurants around. Not extortionate prices: $1 for a soft drink or large water, so don't feel you need to bring loads with you. Restaurants are a little pricier at around $5 for most thingsIf you're up for a bit of a workout then I'd thoroughly recommend hiring bikes to have a pedal around. Really gives you the chance to immerse yourself in the park. Bikes can be rented in Siem Reap for upwards of $2 a day (or more if you don't fancy leaving your passport as deposit). Its then a 7km straight road to the park. You can sneak in past the toll booths but that would be naught, so don't! ;)An absolute must see if you're in Cambodia

Allow plenty of time. Angkor Archaeological Park is a must visit and I was thrilled to have at last seen this wonderful place for myself. Had a three day pass and still did not see everything. Do yourself a favour and allow more than a few hours to appreciate this place.
Crowds can be scary. Plan your trip carefully and be flexible there are so many bus loads of package tourists it can be busier than time square. Do what the guidebooks say backwards

Beautiful, yet ruined by the overwhelming amount of tourists. The temples of Angkor are a definite must see for all travellers, however many will find themselves a bit disappointed by the masses of tourists that storm the temples and distort the 'holy' atmosphere of this sacred place. It is without doubt that the time has come to establish entry-limits per day. It is understandable that due to its world-wide fame, you cannot really expect anything other than large sums of visitors, but many of them I found very disrespectful and showed 0 regard for the local culture and customs. Many people crossing lines, touching carvings that are clearly not allowed to be touched, and going into areas they are not supposed to. It also seems that most tourists go there to take pictures and find their new facebook profile picture rather than appreciating the history that surrounds such an amazing place. It is clearly stated that you should be quiet and respectful when entering the temples, however most people show absolutely no consideration towards this. Disappointing. A World Heritage site that is well preserved, but that does not help when the atmosphere of the place is ruined by its visitors!

A Must See. This is a very beautiful temple and there are so many beautiful carvings, bas-reliefs and sculptures to see. The way nature has reclaimed the space is amongst the more wonderful things I have seen as trees, roots, and moss have become a part of the temples life. There are many great photo opportunities. Be prepared to run the gauntlet of people trying to sell you musical, instruments, postcards, books, badges, art work and more. They are very insistent upon your need to buy :)

Crowds. Second time I have been here last time there wasn't too many tourists and I had the place pretty much to myself. This time the place was packed with tourists and it certainly diminished the experience considerably. Your best friend at Angkor is rain or lunch time as the crowds tend to disappear at this times. That said nothing can take away from the majestic ruins of Angkor

You've heard it before. Because you have looked up this site you must have heard of this location before. All you have heard is true. The place should be on the list of 'places to see' for all those who visit S.E. Asia. Get a friendly cab driver from Siem Reap and negotiate the price with him for a whole day, be careful of the mid-day sun though and bring a fair amount of water. To get the most out of it I would recommend a guide who can explain the history of each site, or buy a good guide book, in Siem Reap, the day before and have a good read. Payment and photo ID must be obtained prior to entry, your driver/guide will take you to the office. The other way to travel is to hire a bike and just cycle around the temples. The roads are all flat with no hills, but because it can get really hot I would not recommend that way for kids. Also to see the main sites takes a lot of walking and cycling. The tourist busses arrived about 4pm, so beware!!!Just go and enjoy

Tomb Raider..I believe?. Came and walked round, was frustrated at points by how rude other visitors can be. Please understand that these are ancient ruins and not walk where you are asked not to. Some areas are narrow, so banging into others I find can be avoided with a little patience. Maybe they were on a short time scale.......... sadly they ruined it for me

Truly one of the great wonders of the world. Put simply, this is somewhere everyone should visit at least once before they die. It's completely unlike anywhere I've ever been before - and I have a big passion for ruins. Quite a bit of the site has been carefully restored, though there are still lots of original parts. In particular, the towers with faces inside Bayon are stunning, and the city-temple of Angkor Wat is really the crown jewel, though there are loads of different architectures to see from different periods of Cambodian history. Fascinating stories, gorgeous structures. We went during "rainy season," but actually we didn't get rained on once during the two days we were at the temple, and even the rain we did see on our trip was of short duration. There are a lot of people visiting, but the space is so massive it really isn't difficult to suddenly find yourself alone scrabbling over tree roots and masonry, even at Ta Prohm.

Beautiful place.. Fantastic. A must see. Easy to organise transport from your hotel. Possible to buy cold drinks en route. Go early, before the crowds. Best time is sunrise. Very serene. Smaller, less famous temples Are more interesting that Angkor itself. The crowds there are horrendous.

A must see in Cambodia. This is should be in every travelers' list of the places to visit. The whole park is filled with history and tidbits as you go along the way. One might be surprised on how big the park is and how the khmers lived before. There now temples that are being restored.. :) Do catch the sunrise ( for the early birds) and sun set there. Its breath taking.

Simply Amazing !!. Angkor Archaeological Park is a vast landscape to explore. Must for every traveler visiting Cambodia. Ruins of Angkor Wat, Bayon, Angkor Thom, Ta Phrom, Phnom Bakheng and many more will make you inquisitive. Ancient scriptures & carvings on wall will amaze you.

Why else would you go to Siem Reap?. Cannot find 100 words to describe it. And no tips are required because I doubt anyone would go to Siem Reap and not check out the Archaeological Park. So do go. We did the small circuit and the grand circuit and both are amazing. The only tip I can give you is start your trips the earliest possible in the day, have a big breakfast beforhand and the skip the usual tourist lunch time to have the majority of the temples mostly to yourself. We started each trip at 6 am and could end both of the circuits (one each day) by as late as 1 PM. So if you do this, not only do you outrun alot of tourists and get alot of temples to yourself but you also have the rest of the afternoon to rest and enjoy the simple things in life at Siem Reap. Go and have a blast. You won´t be dissapointed. The only downside is that I found the tickets very expensive and if it rains, you have to protect your ticket. Mine got cut in half because of rain and they made me buy a new one. So make sure you protect it well.

Magical Mystical Wonder. I have visited The Taj Mahal, Walked down the ancient city of Jericho, Been camping under the stars in Rajasthan, gazed at the stars in the night skies of an African jungle, this wonder left me speechless and gob-smacked.
Tomb Raider Temple. Another amazing temple, with tree roots growing out of the walls. Incredible sight, & wonderful history.
A must see!. One of the most important archaeological places in the world. The main reason for someone who's visiting Cambodia. What can someone say about this place? AWESOME!
Amazing place . Make sure you allow yourself plenty of time to appreciate this place and how amazing it is. It can be quite busy with lots of visitors so your patience can get tested.

There is just so much to soak in!. You can probably spend a month here and not see it all! This place is testimony to a great culture of the olden days. Collosal temples, beautiful, instricate carving, massive ruins, enormous trees and a very generous serving of history, very few things in this world come close!
Beautiful. If you are a history buff or temple enthusiast you will not be disappointed. The tree and layout is beautiful.
Must go. Love this place so much. Huge and so amazing. A must visited place in Siem Reap. Everyone can go. 😍

Where Ruins Meet Nature. An amazing place, the trees growing out of the ruins give this place a magical feel. The site has been left in the condition in which it was found, making it a photographer's dream with the atmospheric combination of trees growing out of the ruins. Get there early as it gets very busy.
This is what you came for. It is not to be missed and if you can spend a few days here and get a multi entry ticket, then I suggest that you do it.

Did not expect we would love it so much. We are a French family, currently living in Singapore and travelling with a kid who was 5 years old when in Angkor.Before visiting Angkor, we heard a lot but nothing really precise about it. We are not particularly fond of ruins. We also feared that our son of 5 would get bored.Surprisingly, we all loved it, especially our kid was so happy to climb and climb. Ankor was a huge playground for him. We visited the temples at our own pace and went for elephant rides every other day. We rent a car and driver/guide. In 3 days we did the must visit Bayon, Ta Prohm and Angkor Vat, that are really worth the trip. We then chose to see smaller ones, not at all crowded, except maybe Banteay Srei. These are Preah Palilay, East Mebon and Thammanon. Some are well restored, some are less so, but all have such peaceful atmosphere that we were feeling extremely well visiting these temples. Maybe the nice weather (sunny but not hot) helps as well. We spent a wonderful time discovering this UNESCO world heritage! Everything went smoothly while we were staying at a very pleasant hotel as well: Shinta Mani Resort.

A Magnificent Place to Visit. A magnificent place to visit. It showcases a part of world history that few westerners know about. Give it at least a day, with a local guide. I have recommended one in a separate review. Two days would be better. There are thousands of different temples, in different stages of restoration. Don't miss Angkor Wat itself of course, along with the Bayon temple and the Ta Prohm, where parts of Tomb Raider were filmed. We only had one day and wished we could stay longer.

Amazing. What an amazing place. Much more intriguing than the main Temple. Spectacular with the trees groing out of the buildings as nature reclaimed the site. I hope they do not do much more restoration as it is fasinating as it is

Must Visit. What a magical place in the middle of the Cambodian forest! It's a must to be visited and travel into time. Angkor Wat is just a magnificent complex!! but in Ta Prohm I love how the trees have grown up around the temple walls, it gives a dramatic atmosphere and makes it more charming.
Superb experience. A superb experience best shared with a good local guide such as Dalingh from Angkor Happy Tours so they can take you away from bulk of crowds etc

One of the most iconic places in the world. Its a must place to visit. You can probably see what you need in one day, but there is a lot to take in.Dont miss Angkor Wat, but you must visit Bayoun and Ta Prohm as a minimum.Take a guide, and as good a guide as you can afford.
Just the view of a giant tree on the ruins speaks for itself!. The beauty of the ruins with the giant trees are a sight to behold! The visit would have been perfect if not for the heatwave

A 6-Day Pass - Well Worth the Money. We were part of a tour and were taken to an official ticket counter where we were photographed, paid our $40 fee, and got our official park pass complete with lanyard and plastic envelope. Our pass was always around our necks and guards at several of the temples we visited checked these for validity. The fee for the pass helps to maintain the Angkor Archeological Park and, for this alone, it's well worth it. We were told that there was such a thing as a counterfeit pass - not sure about that - but it is wise to buy these from the official source.These World Heritage Sites are among the most exciting in the world and I will cherish the memory of this visit for the rest of my life. I was astonished at the scale of Angkor Wat; I loved the 54 towers and 216 enigmatic stone faces of the Bayon. Ta Prohm was unforgettable partly because I'd seen images of the strangler figs and Banyan trees sprawled across the ruins of this temple and monastery complex. I also visited Bakong, somewhat earlier than the more famous temples; and I loved the South Gate into Angkor Thom. Take your time; wear comfortable shoes; and bring bottled water as the sites get quite hot and dry. Enjoy.

One of the most beautiful places in the world. The Archaeological Park is simply immense in its beauty with the Angkor Wat its main temple and attraction. The staggering park includes many other temples such as the main ones (Ta Prohm, Bayon Temple) and underrated temples such as the Preah Khan and Ta Som. All of the temple is unique in its own way and simply picturesque. About USD$20 to get a pass, you have an option of one day, three days and seven days. Totally captivated our imagination. An amazing place indeed.
very tiring. the temples are good but too many steps for oldies especially in the heat. Would be good for younger travellers

Very interesting architecture and history. Very interesting history and architecture. Very warm, bring lost of water and sunscreen and wear good walking shoes. More meaningfull to visit with a good guide than without.

One day was enough!. Really awesome! Did a lot of temples in one day and found that to be enough. I really hate to be "that guy" and say this, but they all look the same! Even with the different stories behind each one, I couldn't imagine going back a second or third day to see the same architecture and statues over and over again. One day was perfect!

Worth the Trip to Siem Reap. An incredible time seeing 800ish year old temples. You pay $20 USD to see Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon Temple, and Ta Prohm. You'll need to pay for a tuk tuk, which will be around $5 USD for the day. Do this! Also, it is probably worth it to pay for a tour guide. I got one for $10 USD (maybe overpriced, but that was after I negotiated him down) for Angkor Wat, and it made the experience much greater.Additionally, Women have to wear pants and sleeves when entering the Angkor Wat main temple (the part with the 5 pillars). If you forget to wear some, don't worry, there are bargaining shops by the entrance of the temple to buy some. You can negotiate them down for $3-$5 USD.One thing to note, if you are someone who lives in America or regularly spends USD, Cambodia accepts USD (at least, in Siem Reap). Some ATMs only allowed me to withdraw USD. This is very handy so you can bring cash with you when you visit to avoid ATM withdrawal fees as well as not have to worry about paying charges for currency exchanges.

Well worth the visit!. An excellent few days had here, so much to see. Some temples are along way from others and in the heat it can become rather tiring. We hired a tuk tuk driver for the days we were there and that made the whole trip far more enjoyable. A brilliant two days I must say!

Visit an amazing lost civilazation from anceint times.. I love Cambodia in general, Angkor Wat is so amazing and full of ancient beauty. I read about when I was 8. I got to see it when I was a senior citizen, do not wait that long!

a wonder. it is one in a lifetime visit if you can. spend more than 1 day there (at least 2 full days) wondering around visiting the most famous and the less famous temples. pay for a guide, it's well worthy it as it will explain all you need to know and advice when to visit each temple to avoid corwds.

Get there Early and Hire a Tuk Tuk. I got there at 6:45 a.m., and I was the only one in line to pay my admission fee ($20 for one day; $40 for three). They take your picture, so the admission ticket is personalized and non-transferable. All in all, it took two minutes at Admissions and I was on my way. I saw about five temples in as many hours. I recommend mornings to temple (5-11 a.m.) and then take a rest for lunch, and return at 3:00 p.m. to spend the final two hours at two temples of your choice. The park closes at 5:00 p.m. Starting at 4 pm most of the temples empty out because all are heading for Bahkeng to view the sunset. That is the time to go to the other temples to experience them in peace. Great, great site seeing.

Magical Angkor. How do you not get swept away experiencing Angkor! This is living history. My personal favourite site is Ta Prohm and it was interesting to learn that it was the Treasury. Three is definitely not enough time!
PHOTOSHOOT IN ANGKOR. Hi travellers! If you like history,culture and photography,you should go there! It'so many BEAUTIFUL SPOT in there.

Highlight of Siem Riep. The park is traveller friendly and easy to tour. I had a three day pass and each day was packed with beautiful walks and temples. It's definitely worth staying that little bit longer. The 'long tour' and 'short tour' are both must-see and take a day each. We used the third day to explore farther afield. Start early to avoid the tour busses.
Absolutely amazing. You have to go here. $20 a day or $40 for 3 days. 3 days was plenty for us, and we loved every minute there! Absolutely amazing!!

Must see for every traveller!. Absolutely deserving of being a wonder of the world! Every person that sets foot in Cambodia should go here. Crowds are thick, so go early. Wear good hiking shoes - not suitable for thongs or flip flops!
Taphrom Temple. You will enjoy the famous temple in Siem Reap Small tour.you will see the all of them. Best regardMakara

Not to be missed.. Mark it off my Bucket List! If you go, do get a guide as we were able to adjust our plans based on what was interesting to use and our guide was a tremendous asset it getting to those places and learning the back stories.

Breathtaking and Life-Changing Experience. We spent just one day exploring the temples of Angkor Archaeological Park, kicking off with Angkor Wat (for the larger part of the day) then venturing on to Bayon Temple, Banteay Srei and finishing the day off exploring Ta Prohm as the hot April sun began to settle down for the evening. The overall experience was humbling and life changing and something that can never be forgotten. Each location was breathtaking in its own right and a must see for any traveller to SE Asia. However visiting so many locations in one day was exhausting, particularly in the 40 degree heat, so spreading the experience out over a few days could be a better option. That said, it was a real highlight of our month-long tour through Cambodia, Laos and Thailand.
great historical refurbishing of the temple. Huge trees with huge roots growing in the walls and inside the temple .A sight that will be remembered forever

Spectacular, but do your research or get a guide first. No need to repeat too much of what has already been said below, but can't emphasize enough the importance of researching and planning your visit, or at least getting a good guide. We decided to do it on our own for a number of reasons using the approach guide Temples of Angkor by David and Jennifer Raezer. It served us really well providing itineraries, ratings, history, and helpful commentary explaining the reliefs and what to look for at each Temple. A guide may have added more, but we tagged on to a couple of guides every now and then and many we overhead were honestly sub par and hard to understand. However there are some good one's out there. As someone mentioned below, I also found going to the National Museum beforehand very helpful.The weather didn't cooperate for the sunset on Phenom Bakeng or sunrise at Angkor Wat, but the upside was that we were able to go for two full days without overheating. We actually did the Elephant ride up Phenom Bakeng which was more for the experience for the kids.One major piece of advice, make sure you bring toilet paper with you for the bathrooms!!! They only have a trough of water and a pale.

Big place. Tuk tuk from hotel cost 15 us for the day, take us to differents temples.Resto available on site .Need long pants and over the shouder shirts, no renting.Day pass:20$ per day per pers. 5-6 hour forthe whole park, cannot walk , very big park.A must.

This is not to miss!. This complex left my awe struck. It was hard to believe that it exists. Although it can be busy, there was still places to wander around and enjoy that Indian Jones kind of feeling.
A Great Place. It is an importance temple that we cannot miss it. The beautiful tree grow on the nice place to make the temple special. Very good and long life temple in Cambodia.

TA PROHM THE HIDDEN CITY. No one should leave Cambodia without seeing this unbeleavable site so close to Angkor Vat and still less visited! I was really thrilled, have been there a few years ago and still when I see the picture I fill again the same emotion.....don't miss that.

A life-changing experience that will stay with you forever!. This is my third time visiting the park and it is no less magical now then it was on my first visit in 1999. Having had the opportunity to visit Tikal, the Pyramids, Machu Picchu, Palenque, the Taj Mahal, Petra, Stonehenge, Parthenon, Colleseum, Ek Balam, Tulum and others I've forgotten - this is most amazing in my opinion. Well worth the price of admission. Get a guide and make the most of being in this stunning surround!
Amazing place. Spend a few hours walking and climbing around this amazing place.Take a guide to explain things.Marvel at how soon the jungle encroaches on man made structures
Gorgeous! . This is a gorgeous temple! There are so many gorgeous temples in Siem Reap and I like them all. This one is one of them, especially it has an awesome views and trees!
Fantastic !!!!!!!!!!. I have travelled to many ancient sites in the world but this site is awe inspiring. Well preserved and managed.

Just astounding.. Never seen a collection of monuments like it and I've been to the Pyramids & Petra recently. Just breath taking. Allow yourself plenty of time and rest if you can as a bit of trekking is required. Watch the Mosquito's too!

Magical. Prepare to be stunned upon arrival.... hundreds of statues to visit, there'll be a difficult choice to decide which to visit first. All are phenomenal, so take lots of photos and take a small wet towel from your hotel to wipe away your perspiration as you walk this amazing area. You will get very sweaty and very tired feet but it's so worth it! Stand and stop for a bit to imagine back in time to the former days of glory in this area.... take time to admire when you are photographing... it really helps to accomplish a strong memory of your visit. So many others would like to visit and do not have the means, consider yourself truly fortunate!

Out of this world. There is not much to say except that this has to be seen !! It is wonderfully magical and gorgeous, there are hundreds of temples to visit. The only reason I am writing this (because all the other reviews already say what has to be said) is that I STRONGLY recommend to go to the Angkor National Museum before starting your tour of the temples. We unfortunately went after and I regret it. There is a wealth of information at the museum (which by the way is very well done) that will help you understand what you are looking at when you visit the archaeological sites..... And believe me the museum is better than your guide book.

Astonishing trip. The temple group and its precinct is clean but ridden with hawkers trying to sell you anything and everything. the temple ruins are having a sense of enigma and enchant you to explore them at a slowe pace. we were very impressed with the guide service and also with the temple care takers.

Great Engineering Achievement. After visiting most of the monuments in the Archeological Park of Angkor, as an engineer, I would say the engineering achievement is awesome. From the drainage to the waterways, from the structures to the architectural planning, everything represent the peak of human civilization in 11th & 12th century. Definitely worth paying the visit.
My Personal Amazement. I was stunned and mentally almost overcome by the condition anddesigns of these incredible statues and their areas.

Amazing archaeological site(s). A whole complex of temples and worth spending time looking around these. Angkor Watt is a must see site for any visitor to the area. Tickets to the site cost us$20 for one day or us$40 for three days, take a tuktuk between the sites, will cost us$15-20 for the day.

One of real wonders of the world. Architecture is really amazing and one needs time and some pre reading about the structures may be useful. A site that should not be missed in one's lifetime - if at all ;possible!

amazing. We visited this park as part of a tour. The temples are amazing, the people there very helpful. We had one of the site folks show us the best pictures (and requested a donation) but it was worth it as they had great insight. There are not washrooms at every temple site, so best to ask. Water was extremely cheap at Angkor Wat (2 / $1 USD).

Here's a quick tip on kids under 12 and pants.. So, turns out kids under 12 are free. That's nice BUT some of the taller sites like the top of Angkor Wat and the Baphuon are off limits to kids under 12, I suppose because of the steep steps although it's silly. Anyway, our 11 year old is close to 12 but quite small, we were able to go ahead and buy her a pass after persuading the clerk. This allowed her to see all the sites with us as previously they were denying her entry to some.Also, they will turn you away from some sites if you aren't appropriately dressed. Keep your shoulders covered and bring a pair of pants or long skirt that covers your knees and you'll be good. You can pull the skirt/pants off afterward and enjoy your shorty shorts as you walk to the next site...

Nice to stroll around. As many travelers already mentioned, this place definitely worth a visit. No need to spend your entire day there, but strolling around for an hour or two is a transcending experience.

WOW. spent 4 days here going over and under and through..be aware the monkeys bite and attack.3 peoplewe knew had to get rabies shots from the scratches they received and bites...wished I had gone there in afternoon then sun would have been in the front of it....however it was still great.....we saw everything!!!!! I have bad knees that didn't play up ONCE and my husband couldn't believe that I....could climb up and down all the stairs....but you do!!!lolMake sure you go to the "Lady temples' and out to the Lingas..its a walk through a rain forest to a different sort of art works...

impressive how the jungle took back the area. you should not miss this area within your 3 days temple tour.Take a private tuk tuk driver for 3 days for 15 $ a day, he will take you from temple to temple and you have fresh air and better view then with a taxi
Amazing, obviously. Definitely recommend getting the three day pass to get the most out of visiting at different times and avoiding the heat. Sunrise is spectacular and well worth an early start!
Loved it Magical. The locals selling their wares can be a little too much, but its part of most travel experiences. GO....GO.....GO
Amazing adventure!. If you love history, you should plan a visit here because the historical stories from the temples are fascinating!

Must Do. I purchased the 3 day ticket and it was needed. This is such a unique site and there is so much to see. I attempted to cycle around the site but found it difficult in the heat so ended up doing a tuk tuk tour. I actually enjoyed Ta Prohm and Bayon Temple much more than Angkor Wat which was very crowded, although the sunrise is spectacular. I wish I hadn't visited during the hot season as everything was very dry and the heat was at times unbearable. I recommend organising a group tour where the driver will pick you up from your accommodation and drive between the many temples. Stay hydrated and absorb this spectacular site.
A unique place around the world!. Absolutely unbelievable!!! This is a "must see" around the world! A unique place where nature is perfectly integrated to an amazing archeological site!
BEAUTIFUL!. Definitely the reason for visiting Siem Reap. This park has Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Bantay Srei. Simply: BEAUTIFUL.

A must visit. Do some research about the temples before your visit and you may not need a guide. It was very hot and humid when we were there in July so it was good that we saw the temples by car with a guide.

A once in a lifetime experience. If you go to Siem Reap and don't go to the Angkor site I'm not sure why you've gone there. It's a major archeological site and you get great access to the each of the temples with very few areas unable to be seen or walked over. Be aware Ta Prohm (the temple that has trees growing over/under/through it) in particular is currently being worked on at the moment, so while you can still see sections of it, the main section is inaccessible.

A Must Do Experience, Amazing Architecture. An Amazing piece of history that you can experience up close. We did the sunrise tour via Tuk Tuk, it is very crowded but it is best to go early in summer to see as much as possible before it gets too hot. The park is huge, we did not take a guide but I wish we had. We saw the major temples and local wild life, monkeys and birds. I must have taken a few hundred photos, the details of the architecture are incredible. We ate on site, it was ok, you could bring your own but best to help out the local merchants. Definitely bring water for the extensive walking, there are a few places to get snacks, drinks and souvenirs. You could spend a few days here for sure, we were time limited, but I would return here if in the area.

As amazing as you expect. It is really worth doing the long circuit and seeing some of the other temples as they are really spectacular and the landscape is very interesting. Also if you have an extra day venture out to one of the temples outside the city, as they are even more amazing.
"Truly a world wonder". The Angkors - Wat and Thom are truly world wonders on a massive scale. The Khmers where master builders and these monuments live on in their name.

MUST!!!!. I recommend at least a three day ticket as this park of temples is one of the most amazing, breathtaking and stunning places on earth.Next time I visit I'll take more time and spend at least a week among the temples!!A must if you love ancient buildings, history, temples and countryside. Only down point is the pollution caused by all the tourists. In my eyes the park authority tries to avoid pollution but not hard enough. I think big fines might help ...

MUST COME HERE ONCE IN YOUR LIFETIME. The BEST outdoor trip ever! If you are someone who is adventurous, outgoing, history and archeology lover, seek this place out. If given the choice, I will spend at least 3 days here: go for both the Small Tour and Big Tour. And also I would get a local tour guide, though it's not cheap, around USD35. Stop at every temples and ruins because you will never know what you find unless you are there. There are small wonders along the road and stop by to take pictures. Different seasons will give you the different feel, dry season and raining season. Note to self, to revisit here again during the sunny season.

The best day ever. Our four sons, aged 16 to 9-years all agreed this was the best day ever. What an amazing opportunity to show them these incredible sites. We figured our kids would tire quite easily, so decided to be guided by their needs with what we saw. It was HOT and getting around the temples is strenuous… but we spent 8 hours non-stop on our first day, exploring these incredible sites. Our sons loved it.They just kept going. And so did I. In over twenty-five years of travel, this was one of the greatest things I've done.

One day with a guide is more than enough. Obviously, if you're in Cambodia, you must see this stunner. However, we found that one day with a private guide is more than enough. Split among a small group, a private guide with a car is highly worth-while and very efficient. The three-day pass was overkill for our needs.

A Trip into the past in Siem Reap. Amazing to see the ancient temples, and to try to imagine the work that must have gone into the buildings and carvings.It feels like a different world.Very unique and an experience not to be missed

worth the tour guide. We took the option of paying for a $15 tour and feel this was worth it , this puts the rest of the park into perspective. We had a young tour guide and though good I feel and older one would have given a better perspective on the recent history of the day
Gorgeous. Amazing place, wonderful temples and people are extremely educated and knowledgeble that can guide you around for an extremely reasonable monetary contribute.
Breathe taking.. Allow full days to see these amazing temples. Easiest way is to get a tuk tuk - $15 a day and they take good care of you.
Wonderful!. Really incredible place. One suggestion; add to the "usual temples" the "womne's citadel"; it's about 1 hour from Angkor Wat, but it's really nice and well preserved.
Incredible. be prepared with bottled water and a fan or umbrella for the sun. Its a lot of walking in very hot and humid weather.

Wonderful. What a gem,the History spanning centuries is amazing,the degree of skill used in creating the Temple is astounding,I particularly enjoyed how nature has taken over,huge tree trunks and roots covering many parts make it spectacular .On our return to the UK,I have purchased Laura Croft Toomb Raider to show our Grandchildren,very enjoyable.It is very important to take plenty of fluid whist visiting the Temple,as it can be very hot and humid,also good walking shoes,as the flooring and many steps are uneven and in places dimly lit.

Features Spectacular Architechtual Treasures Not To Be Missed. Angkor Archeological Park has been set up to showcase and protect the many ancient temples in the Siem Reap area of Cambodia. There are too many temples to discuss each one - but several stand out from the crowd and should not be missed: Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom (an ancient city - not a temple), Bayon, Ta Prohm, Banteay Srei - to name just a few. Each one is different, with it's own personality and story. I suggest using a guide as there is too much to know about each temple to make a go of it on your own. The information and history adds so much to the visit. These temples are very majestic and beautiful - amazing to see and think about what they must have been like when they were just finished and in their glory. But - nature and tourists are taking their toll. I am guessing that sometime in the near future, access will be limited - so go as soon as you can. We were able to enter all temples and climb several levels on many - an amazing experience in itself. The sight of the fig trees and their roots growing over and through the temples is mind blowing, and while this added to the atmosphere of these temples - they are destroying them as well - nature is slowly reclaiming the area. We visited in the rainy season and there were fewer crowds. Still lots of people but not as bad as in the high season. Try to get a sunset cruise in the moat of Angkor Thom - very peaceful, no crowds and the possibility of a stunning photo op. Work with your guide or hotel for their recommendations as to the day and time to visit each temple to minimize the crowds - they are better seen and appreciated with less people.

Yes Angkor is amazing but do something to help Cambodia too. Of course Angkor Archaeological park is amazing (although be aware the money for the park goes to a Vietnamese company not a Cambodian company?), its rated No 1 in Asia and the world. It is one place that should be in everyone's bucket list. I have been lucky enough to visit twice and I am still seeing new and amazing things. You don't get bored with Angkor and chances are you wont even see all of the Park unless you are in Siem Reap for a couple of weeks. I suggest you visit the Angkor museum before you go to the park you will have a much better understanding of what you see. Remember both Angkor Wat and Angkor Tom are still religious sites so be respectful in your dress and behavior. We were very lucky to have Mr Panha from Siem Reap Angkor Car and Tuk Tuk Service as our driver during our ten days in Siem Reap. He provided us with both an air-conditioned comfortable car for those sites further away and fun tuk tuk for sites around Siem Reap. As two women travelling alone in Cambodia, it was good to have Panha as we know he is honest, trustworthy and reliable. He took very good care of us, making sure we had free cold water when we needed it (it was 38C some days). He has a chilly bin full of bottled water with ice in both the car and tuk tuk. No matter where you want to go, Angkor Wat or Tom, Roulens group, Mt Koulen, Phare, Tonle Sap or the killing fields he knows about it and will give you great advice. He does not do Angkor Archaeological park guiding but he can guide you at Mt Koulen etc If you have time, take a walk around the local psar with him, it’s an eye-opener and very educational. If you want a safe driver and English speaking guide Panha is your man. He will drive you to see the sunrise at Angkor at 5am or to the Phare circus at 8pm no matter what you need he’s there. He will help you get tickets for all of the attractions including the Angkor Archaeological Park. (+855) 12 86 45 81, (+855) 975085708 or E-mail and face book panhachhouk@yahoo. You want to travel responsibly try this idea. On your way into Cambodia you are unlikely to have your full quota of kgs of luggage. Most airlines offer 30kgs but most people take nearly empty suitcases into the country and fill them while they are there. Don’t take a half empty suitcase into Cambodia, fill it up with children’s books, educational toys (no battery operated toys), toothbrushes, soap, shoes, technology items and other useful things. The items don’t need to be new, just in good working condition. Please don’t take lollies or sugary stuff and don’t offer religious items, Cambodians have a diversity of religions available to them, let them choose. You can ask your hotel to distribute the items or take them to the Children’s Sanctuary. If you are lucky enough to have Mr Panha as your driver, then he will know where the most need is and help you get your items to the right place. You don’t have to go along if you don’t want to, just hand the stuff over and then you can fill your suitcase with amazing t-shirts and other souvenirs. If you want to go when there is hardly anyone there try the off-season May to August its hot and can be very dry or very wet but there are no tourists and less pressure to buy stuff as there are less sellers. Prices are also a little better for souvenirs but make sure you pay a fair price as it's the peoples living your bartering away.

Amazing. Incredible sites. Pictures do not do this place any justice. Must be experienced to comprehend the enormity and detail of these old buildings, We went end June and whilst it was busy, none of the sites were too crowded. Admittedly, it was extremely hot,Definitely hire a guide. Without a guide we would have wasted time and not had the detailed explanations even though we had guidebooks and visited the museum in town. A guide is essential for first time visitor, and a small expense in the scheme of things.

Lara Croft to the rescue. Stunning temple to visit, smallest out of the big 3 temples to visit in Siem reap but no means boring.Some scenes from tomb raider filmed here and you can see why, amazing historical temple with beautiful craftsmen ship to it, over the years the tree roots have become apart of the structure of the temple and makes for great photos.Make sure you visit this temple as its a very memorable experience.

Amazing. The trees that seem to be taking over the temple are amazing. While we were there, some places were being restored but there was still plenty to see. Plenty of fantastic photo opportunities, and beautiful nature.

Mind Blowing. I chose to go to the park specifically as I am a History Teacher. Spectacular. I did not get a guide rather drew on the guide book I bought. Be aware there are many who want to sell you books, keyrings, postcards, fridge magnets and of course cold water.Be aware also of locals assisting as though they are full of informaation, they also push for a 'donation' at the end even if you asked them to leave you to your own devices.Also, the stairs at times can seem a challenge but they are worth the climb.

Wow and wow!!. It is not until you see what nature has done to the buildings, that you realise the beauty and destruction nature can cause. A very big area to explore, take your time and best to do it with a tour guide so he can explain all the details of the temples etc. We went first thing in the morning and the early morning sun on the buildings was extraordinary. Well worth a visit - it would be a real shame if you didn't get here. Lots to see and just relax among the ruins.

Explore the early life of Cambodia. This is a fantastic part to see the early stages of Cambodia. There are several site withing the park so I highly recommend having a guide. You can get 1, 3 or 7 day passes to the park.
Must visit. If ever in siem reap this is a place that you must visit. The temples are very unique to each other.
Angkor Wat. Allow plenty of time to walk around as this is a huge complex and much architectural detail to enjoy.
Amazing site. Really quite amazing. It is quite huge and can require a lot of walking. You can purchase a 1 or 3 days entry tickets. We spent 2 days inthe park.it was the right amount of time

Number 1 attraction in Siem Reap. We bought a 3 day pass. Passes are also valid for the evening before they begin so make the most of it and consider seeing a sunset at one of the temples.It can get very hot during the day. I recommend trying to visit the temples starting in the early morning, or waiting until the afternoon so it's slightly cooler.I visited with the guide book Ancient Angkor which I highly recommend. A guide may be useful on the first day to explain the history, or at some of the bigger sites like Angkor Wat to explain the bas-reliefs which have very interesting details.We hired a tuk-tuk to drive us around. Our driver was TT, he was very friendly and funny, took us to lesser known sites and always kept the esky stocked with icy cold water.For some one day may be enough, but I personally think at least two or three are better!Cover up in appropriate temple attire to be respectful and comfy walking shoes are best as there are A LOT of steps and plenty of uneven ground.Highlights included the small circuit (of course Angkor Wat and Bayon), and Banteay Srei.

Amazing!. This place is amazing! It is an architectural paradise. There is something very special and magical about this place. You can wonder from temple to temple for days. Actually you can see the major ones in just one day. It was definitely worth the 14 hour bus trip here from Ho Chi Minh city.

Exploring Angkor Wat. what can be said: if you love temples...that's the place! W e loved every minute, people are friendly as well and that is a great bonus!every morning we were exploring Angkor Archaeological Park, late afternoon relaxing on the pool and shopping at night in the local markets: a very calibrated holiday :)!

Amazing Architecture and Engineering Feats. The temples within the park are simply amazing. To think that many of these temples were built a thousand years or more ago is astounding. The carvings, the stories, the devotion of the worshippers to construct such monuments to their Gods...again amazing.We enjoyed our time exploring each temple we visited. We would recommend visiting in the early morning or late afternoon, when the heat of the day has lessened. I wouldn't recommend doing this with young children as their are lots of stairs and it does get hot.

Will visit my next visit . 6days stay in Siem Reap, we didn't know there was a park like this. After back to Malaysia, one of my friend told me that I should have visited this place. So, I'll make sure visit this place on my next visit.

Amazing. just amazing, I am so glad I visited.. one more on my bucket list. I did 3 days of touring and loved every bit of it.. I suggest you take frozen water and let one of the Tuk Tuk drivers show you around.. Mine spoke great english and shared so much of the history of the place
Amazing. Amazing area with lots of temples to explore. The largest, Ankgor Wat is the best one to see. Take a tuk tuk, not a bike or taxi. Cheap and a lovely drive.
Interesting, but gets old pretty quickly.. One day is enough. Just book a one day tour - it'll be enough to see everything. Don't waste your money on a 3-day pass.

Beautiful!. Although Angkor Wat is by all means the main attraction, I liked Bayon Temple the most and found it the most beautiful temple. Be prepared for MANY tourists at certain temples, some of which are VERY NOISY. They just ruin the experience. You might want to go to some of the smaller temples at the Big Loop, such as Ta Som for a quieter experience.

Fantastic. Angkor archaeological park is huge area which included the "Angkor wat", "Bayon temple", :Ta Prohm" and many other temples. All these reflect the Khmer architecture and rise and fall of Khmer kingdom. The architecture and caving seen in various temples were fantastic. It will not be enough for a day to explore all these temples. Definitely top in the list of must go place.

Ankor Wat is a photographers heaven. I visited Ankor Wat for photography and I was really thrilled to be there. A "Must Go" place. Just try to visit there as early as possible to beat the crowds if you're going there for photography.

ANGKOR WONDERFUL. the weather is too hot . but surround of angkor and another temple have too many of big tree and wildlife so look too wonderful and especially taprom temple is too attractive on it because the tree and vine are claim up on the temple until the top but could be fall down or destroy someday in the future if the apsara authority do not cut it off.

Hire a licensed guide!. Temples are amazing, but the best way to understand the history and purpose of these structures is to hire a licensed guide. Signage is limited so it may be difficult to know what you are looking at without a guide. Rates run at about $30 USD for a full day 8am-3pm at the temples.
Temples and ruins. it was an amazing experienced to see the well-preserved ruins of palaces and temples. start your trip very early to avoid the very warm weather

Must Do. One of the big 3 temples connected to the Angkor Wat. This one is a bit different as the tress have taken over the entire temple which makes it pretty special to look at. As it is smaller can get a bit crowded with the tour groups all being bunched together. Well worth a visit.
History!. It was fantastic to see how the Khmer kings could build all this in the 12th century. Despite the huge number of tourists, everywhere was clean and the locals were very polite.

Tomb raider movie sight. The picture is inside the Ta Prom temple. This is where scenes from the original Tomb Raider movie were filmed. This is a must see of my top three, Angkor Wat, Ta Prom, and Angkor Thom temples.
Overwhelming. There is just so much to see here you can get templed out. Fabulous temples and architecture. The carvings are amazing.

Get a three day pass. I could only fit in 2 days at Angkor Archaeological Park, but if you have the time, it makes sense for you to get a three-day pass so that you can explore the area in full.Also note that a three-day pass is a better bang for your buck than buying one-day passes. Moreover, the three days need not be consecutive, and you can choose which days to visit within a one week period.

Fantastic history tour. One could spend hours on this site just absorbing the ambience and history. It's worth taking your camera along. Go with a tour operator like Travel Marvel of Victoria Australia. It was a wonderful experience.
One of the highlights of the tour. If you are on a Siem Reap tour, you shouldn't miss this. You've seen the pictures, it was in the movies. Now take your own pictures, and be amazed.

Historical Delight. Cambodia is such a great place and the people are wonderful. This is one of the best places I have ever been at. To think of what went into creating these places is mind boggling. Don't miss this.

Take a few days. This place is amazing, you need a good 3 days to appreciate the whole park.Do early morning, relax for a few hours in the shade for lunch then go back in the afternoon. Buy the black guide book that you see on sale, it is expensive at $30 but it is a really great guide, and better and cheaper than hiring a guide. No point paying the earth for a guided tour, buy the book and go by tuk tuk. Tuk tuk should be $15 for the whole day.

Must see. I went to Siem Reap to see the Angkor temples. They did not disappoint. I rode my bike from town which was a pleasant 6km ride since it is all flat roads and most of the roads are shaded by surrounding forest. Tip: The road parallel to the main road that arrives at Angkor Wat's south west corner requires you to have a pass already. They will turn you around and expect you to go all the way back to town. There is a little dirt track short cut through the forest. Its across from some shops that sell drinks. There are monkeys living within the forest so keep your eye out. Some of the monkeys will come right up and take food from your hand. Remember, a three pass lasts for a week so you can take a day off between each visit.

The best advice I recieved was to take a tuk tuk and go anti clockwise around the loop. Taking a tuk tuk should not be more than 15 USD for the day, and starting with sunrise you should skip Bayon and go to the "tomb raider" temple making the loop in a anti clock wise direction. you easily skip 70-80% of the crowds.

Fascinating.. Absolutely fascinating, we spent the whole day there, and still didn't see it all. Of course we left the big one till last. By this time my energy was fading fast. However, well worth the effort. The history is mind boggling.
Amazing. Amazing temple visit. How can such a huge tree exist? Please avoid rainy days. The place was a bit slippery..
Awe inspiring. This place is amazing, busy at times, June is the beginning of the monsoon season so less visitors, and if you don't mind getting wet then go for it, you wont be disappointed.

Hot Hot Hot in May. Temples simply amazing, we did Sunrise as heat of day is extreme at this time of year. Had a lovely breakfast at local restaurant then explored some more. Angkor Watt and Angkor Thom were my favorites.

5 Reasons to visit the Angkor Archaeological Park by bicycle.. Since I have been a part time resident of Siem Reap for around ten years now, I have visited the Angkor Archaeological park by tuk-tuk, by car, by van, by 4WD, and by bicycle. I am now past my mid 60s and if I can do it, pretty much anyone can do it. Not that I object to using a motorized vehicle (air-conditioning can literally save your life on a really hot day) but the bicycle can take you places and give you an experience that no other form of transportation can provide. 1. Everyone you meet in the Angkor Park is friendly to bicyclists, the drinks and shop vendors, tuk-tuk drivers, guides, park officials. I usually park my bicycle next to the officials who stand outside the temples asking to see your ticket. They remember me and offer to watch my bicycle for me. Same thing goes for the girls who sell drinks and souveniers outside Angkor Wat, they stop their hard sell and want to know everything about the bicycle (I travel with my own touring bike).2.
