You can go places that larger vehicles can't and would take a long time to walk. For example the top of the Angkor Thom city wall has a 12 Kilometer path that is easy to navigate with a bicycle. Locals live in the Angkor Park, so there are many small paths suitable for bicycles.3. The bicycle will make you independent and able to change your itinerary as you go. If you have a vehicle and driver, you will basically be adjusting your schedule to your driver's needs. I have had drivers (of private hire vehicles) refuse to stop where I want to stop and take me where they want to go (too many times).4. You can start out alone but it is easy join other bicyclists as you travel through the Angkor Park. Every time I am bicycling through the temples I end up talking to other bicyclists and then travel with them for a while, to show them something they asked me about. Often joining them for lunch and drinks.5. It is great exercise. Just remember to find some shade every once in a while and drink a lot of water on a hot day.
What can I say. It's AngkorWat. You have to go. Go with a guide or without, it's just one of those places on earth that speaks for itself. Spend an hour or a day, or a week.
Freaking amazing. Go early to avoid the crowds ...walk to the furthest entrance at the rear of the complex & make your way back to the entry thus avoiding the congestion at the most popular areas.

The reason to go to Siem Reap. Lets be honest, the reason everyone comes to Siem Reap is the Archaeology. Temples are amazing. Recommend one goes off season June/July /early August for crowd avoidance.
It is not just pile of stones.... Walking among the ancient yet magnificent temples really switched on the Indiana Jones' theme song in my mind. Go see the wonders for yourself and unleash your whip!

Three Day Pass. We had our own guide called Chan. He was just great not just his excellent and accurate commentary but his photography skills - knowing where to get the best shots and we have some stunning ones. We were there for a week ans going to the Park every second day was perfect for us.

A morning of interest. A trip round here is great to put more relevance to your trip to Ankor Wat
Fab gift shop strangely. But can be warm in the communal areas.
$12 entry fee

Amazing! Must see!. This is a life time experience! You must to visit this place. Ancient buildings and whole environment drives you to thousands of years ago. Fantastic.
Tip: Avoid the raining season (Oct-Dez) due to flood. It is dangerous.

Extensive and revealing park. I love the history of the region. This is where I got to see the transition from Khmer Hindu religious practice to Buddhist practice. The best time to visit these sites is early morning. It is cooler and more comfortable until about 11 AM. Then the hoards of package tour tourists start arriving and the experience becomes a crowd avoidance dilemma. Buy the 7 day pass if you plan to be in Siem Reap that long. Take in a little bit each morning and plan on seeing the out of the way temples that are infrequently visited and are still pretty much as the were found before World Heritage status began the restoration efforts at the most popular sites. Spend your afternoons poolside or getting a two hour massage. The evenings are best dinning near the night market and possibly taking in some of the Expat entertainment. There are many shops and market vendors with a huge variety of the usual stuff and the occasional rare and exceptional stuff. Angkor Handicraft Association and it's affiliated shop Angkor Artisans is well worth the visit.

Be in a movie in the past. Those things you only see in movies, but you are part of it now. Take many days two visit completely. You can buy a 3-day-pass and have a whole idea of the place. Rent a bike of you are healthy and resistant to hot weater
Alot of great things. At the very beginning when you first step in the temple you will surely feel so cool in the middle of this temple.
Breathtaking. Be sure to make the effort for sunrise tour and see if you can get to the top of the temples before the crowds hit - once in a life time!
3 day pass is enough. It's fantastic, 3 days pass is enough. The major temples are not as crowded during lunch time. I paid 15$ for an official guide at the gate for Angkor watt, definitely worth it.
An Archaological park. This is an amazing place where you have to see. The most interesting place that I can't forget and the only place that no whereelse better than this.

small temple full of giant trees. the trees colors is grey and gold and i dont know why... u feel as if the trees wil lturn to a real monster and walk.....the temple is nice but is kind of destroyed from the tree roots

stunning on earth. we spent three days and nights in siem reap still not enough to explore the complex city of Angkor area , the well known man made monuments like Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, jungle temple and Banteay Srey ..etc .For those who like history and culture should spend more time here! We will come back some day to visit another jungle ruins.highly reccommended !

Must visit. Well, what other reason would you have to come to Siem Reap really? This place is a must see, do it over a couple of days though, at least.. APRIL is not the time to go though, 44 degrees and 99% humidity!

A maze of roots. The trees that are unbuilding the temple are fascinating and are a good contrast to the other ruins, where they are keeping the vegetation from altering the look of the stone structures.

Brilliant, Amazing and moving. Step black in time to the past and see one of the best wonders of the world, the jungle reclaiming its space and man made temples celebrating the gods. Sunset, at the temple is stunning. Wear comfy shoes, and be prepared for the heat... Ancient temples, a real wonder...
must know the history. Every who ant to visit the angkor.. must know the history.. hiring a local tour guide more indulge with this amazing archaeological park

See as much as you can. Have spent 2 days and have 2 to go. We wondered at the beginning if we had too much time but with each temple or palace with its own story one can not say any is more important or interesting than the other. PLEASE don't just come to see Angkor Wat by itself! The whole World Heritage Area is a must see to appreciate its grandeur and importance.

Incredible ruins that will not disappoint. These ruins are truly magical and worth the visit, even amongst the crowds. I now I understand why they are one of the most important ruins in South East Asia. The entrance ticket is very well prices considering the complexity and size of these ruins. All the staff that work at the ruins are very nice and helpful. At many of the major sites there are places to buy water, snacks, and toilets. It is also easy to hire a tuktuk on the street or from your hotel that will take you around the ruins (hired for half day or full day). Although very touristy, there are still areas to explore where you can get away from the crowds. I spent three days here and could easily have spent more as there is so much to see. The top 3 ruins are a must see (Angkor, Bayon, Ta Prohm), but it is worth taking the time to visit many of the others: that are many others that are equally as amazing. Although the early morning and evening are the best times to visit for better light and to avoid the heat, I would recommend doing one visit late morning when the crowds get a bit lesser to enjoy the ruins without the crowds (but bring a hat and plenty of water)If you are in or near Siem Reap, this ruins are a must see!
Relax. Please explore this area with alot of good things to see. You won't be disappoinnted if you first step in this plae.

Incredible experience. The complex is huge. One day costs $20, and a week costs $60. I wish we had more time, and spent an entire week slowly going through each temple.The whole complex has probably hundreds of temples and archaeological sites in clusters.The best time to visit is in winter, and renting a cycle for $1 a day and exploring on your own. We however had gone in the summer so had to take a tuktuk for the whole day for $15.The temples are built into crazy forest area, and you can easily get lost(in a good way) in them.

Sunrise at Angkor Wat. To see how beautiful Angkor Wat with sunrise like a backdrop you need to sacrifice a couple hours of sleep and it's worth it. You really want to go in side the wall to see the temple reflection on the water.

It's amazing, but don't go in April, it's too hot according our guide.. For family travelers, it's best to buy a three days pass, spend morning walking in the temples, you can do at least 2 main ones, maybe plus a smaller one on the way. Then have great lunch somewhere and rest in your hotel enjoy the pool.

Stunning Architecture. We hired a tuk tuk for $15 a day but gave him $20 when we realised the places we wanted to visit were so far away. They usually recommend you to do the small loop for day 1 and day 2 but we chose the temples that we wanted to visit instead. Angkor Wat itself was huge. Definitely worth visiting. Other recommended temples would be Bayon Temple (my favourite!) and Ta Phrom (where they filmed tomb raider). Please be reminded not to buy from the children there as they are not going to school because of this lucrative business of selling to tourists. It was really sad to see them selling their wares desperately.

Like no place on earth!. A must for every bucket list----the temples are so well preserved and majestic. Amazing testimony to a grand culture of the past....take a lot of water, it can get very hot out there. Having a guide is almost essential to understanding all of the temples.
Remarkable experience!. This almost 1,000 site is truly an amazing sight to see. . One cannot explain it thoroughly enough. . you MUST see this if you are visiting Cambodia, or even SE Asia itself!

Great day. Spent a wonderful day visiting the park. Make sure you ask for the free map when you purchase your tickets. We only found out later there was one on offer. The park is very large so you need transport to get around most of the temples. Take plenty of water as the day we visited, June, was very, very hot. We crammed around 6 temples in during the day with a break for lunch.
Amazing. Truly a special place, one that must be visited. The ruins are awesome, but plan to spend a few days there at minimun, there is so much to see.

A must see, but pick your sites. This is a huge area which contains most of the main sites you will want to see. If you are not likely to get “templed out” then you could easily spend a week here. There are a couple of well trodden routes; one is short route taking in three or four of the major sites, such as Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple and Ta Prohm where a day pass would cover this. There is also a longer route taking in more of the sites where you would want to spend two or three days. It is worth hiring a tuk tuk driver (we did this through our hotel), for your time here as they can be really helpful in identifying the best of the sites. We went in May and it is very hot at this time of the year; you shouldn't let this put you off unless you have problems with heat. The plus side of this time of year is that the crowds are much smaller.
Amazing, amazing. You have to go there!!! Angkor Wat, Ta Prom, Bayon. They all have something different about them... Better in Dec/Jan when cooler, but you have to go there!!!

Eight tips when planning your tour around Angkor Archaelogical Park. The Angkor Archaeological Park covers 15 square kilometres and there are also a few temples included in the pass not inside the park. A tuk tuk driver will cost around US$18-25 for a full day. We had a great one who had cold water waiting for us just when we needed it.First tip is decide on what pass to buy. There are three types of passes. The seven day US$60, three day US$40 and one day US$20. We bought a three day pass which is valid over one week which means in the hot weather you can break up your touring with rest days if your there a week or five days. Make sure they give you a map when buying a ticket. We did not get one and our guide said we were supposed too. Second tip, go to the Angkor National Museum if you are like us and do not know much about the history and background behind the building of the temples. The museum fills in a lot of gaps. Third tip, buy a dust mask if your using a tuk tuk some of the roads can be very dusty and if your allergic a mask will help. I would suggest you get a laniard for your Angkor Pass. This will help avoid having to whip out the pass for checking everytime you go into a different temple. An umbrella or shawl is good for those who have sensitive skins to the sun as well. We also had hand held fans which were brilliant.Fourth tip is to decide on whether to do a grand tour or mini tour. We mix and matched with our tuk tuk driver and tour guide. Some of the best temples were the smaller ones. They do not take long to look at and also are not as visited as the main ones such as Angkor Wat and Beyon Temple.Fifth tip is go one day with a guide and the other without one. A guide is great to explain and show you parts of temples you may not know about. They are also good for showing you good photo angles. Our guide cost us US$45 for the day and he was well worth it. Just make sure they are accredited and legal. We booked ours through our hotel.Sixth tip is to remember to rehydrate. We stopped several times for coconut juices from fresh coconuts at a buck each. We also drank lots of water.Seventh tip is to leave your guesthouse or hotel by five am for the sunrise viewing of Angkor Wat. Make sure you have bought your pass the night before to avoid queuing. When you get there cross over the causeway and we headed right to the pond where we got some great shots of the sunrise and the reflection of the towers. The left side seems to be a lot busier.Eighth tip is to remember to stop a while and just soak up the atmosphere and enjoy your surroundings. We were lucky to find one temple without any people and spent a quiet half hour exploring it and enjoying the peace and tranquility. Hope some of these tips make your trip an enjoyable one to the beauty of Angkor Wat and the other temples.If you found the review useful I always appreciate a helpful vote.

The Machu Picchu of Southeast Asia. Ok, nothing like Machu Picchu but my point is that despite how hard these places are to get to...they are well worth the trip. There is an air of magic or mysticism hidden in the history here. The highlight, as most visitors will tell you, is the people. Wonderful, smiling, Cambodians eager to share their world. I can't wait to go back.

A place you will well remember. Angkor Archaeological Park is made up of magnificent temple ruins n aged trees. They include the famous Temple of Angkor Wat and, at Angkor Thom, the Bayon Temple with its countless sculptural decorations, a place full of mysteries. A place you must visit when you are in Siem Reap.The temples ruins contained within the Park represent the remnants of the millennium-old capitals of the old Khmer Empire, you will learn a lot if you prepare to walk and sweat. Don't miss this World Heritage site.

amazing angkor. Loved everything - thought we would only go once but ended up going back again. !st time was to see sunrise - awesome experience although there's always heaps of other people there. 2nd time we went at midday/afternoon - it was very hot but not many people around so you could see so much more. An experience not to be missed.

Better than exoected. Lets be honest your coming to Siem Reap you're probably going to go, but I think it will be better than expected. I walked around with my camera for a little under 3 hours and had a great time and got loads of great pics. Wish i had done a tour with a guide as there is a lot to learn about this place but maybe next time

Part of an adventure. Since my last visit the park didn't change much. Kids and too small children selling stuff almost entirely wanished from the streets which is a good thing. The youngsters are learning English having superviced by adults.The ruins and tamples are constantly maintained. We saw construction nets covering parts of Angkor and Ta Prohm. Security is present. There is still a lot you can climb and walk but now it is restricted for the sake of future generations. Annoying but I call it development. Still renovating everything from sponsor's money and effort.Visiting hours# From 7.00 till 17.00. The announced visiting hours are 7 till 17.30 but they start to empty out the sights at 5pm. Tower of Angkor Wat is not visitable after 5. If you arrive even 1 minute later they won't let you go up. There is no more Sunset or Dawn viewing at Angkor Wat. Only from outside. You can stay on the bridge over the moat and at the 2 ends of the bridge, also you can walk around the inner city day and night.

All that you expect and more. I have been looking forward to this since the start of my travels and it did not disappoint. I did sunrise and stayed for nearly 11 hours just doing the small circuit am going back for sunset and some of the other temples wish i had more time to do them all.
It seems tripadvisor got the wrong temple here. This is a place I not visited, it looks like Lara Croft movie but I am not sure of if it is true or not

Hot tips. When I first arrived I didn't know what was the best way to get around, nor did I find anywhere that would explain it clearly, so here goes:All or most of the historic temples/wats/sites are in this park - including Angkor Wat.We went to the history museum first and learned some of the history of the main sites. That meant we could go around these more on our own and avoid the crowded areas of Angor Wat and Angor Thom. Also, we hired a tour guide for a day and having done some of our own learning on the site, meant he could show us more of the other interesting and beautiful sites which aren't so clearly explained in the museum and are less crowded.You can find official guides through the tourist info who are reliable on their info or through your hotel or trip advisor recommendations. The ones at the sites may or may not know their history of the temples and, if someone walks up to you in the temple and starts to chat with you about the place you are in it's highly likely they are expecting a tip at the end of it in the price range of a tour guide, so that can be $10 that you may part with when you had not agreed to anything.There is a one day pass $20, 3 day pass $40 and the week pass $60. The multi-day passes work over a week or, longer for the week pass, but confirm this when buying. I read you can go and buy your pass for the sunset first and it will not start till your first day, again, confirm this when buying, as I would have gone for this option if I'd known, it would have been a great day to get in without losing a day to watch the sunset as doing it in the 3 day pass makes the day very long by having to go back and forth to the site. Be sure to get a map of the park when you buy your pass. Buy the pass at the park only, anywhere else and you may run into problems.I suggest you bring a laniard to hold the pass in, as you will be showing it for every place you enter, as well as entering the park itself.There is a small tour circuit and a grand tour circuit, both are great to go around just depends on your time frames. You need a very full day to make it round the grand circuit, so if you want to do it slower then break it up, as the heat can get very hot at noon and later.Make sure that your Tuk Tuk driver or tour guide or you has enough water, as it saves you having to waste time buying it outside the site. An umbrella can be nice to provide shade in those spots where there isn't any.I believe it's only a matter of time before the access becomes more restricted to these sites, as a lot of people ignore the signs which tell you not to go into areas, plus the wear and tear on these ancient sites will take its toll over time, as the popularity of this place grows as a tourist destination.Beautiful and very interesting park - just loved it!If this review is helpful, please tick below:
beautiful ancient ruins.... I was amazed at the size of the trees and roots growing over the ruins. It is very beautiful. I love that they are rebuilding.

Must see. The Angkor temple complex will take your breath away. Each temple has a different dimension to it, so it is a bit difficult to not be impressed (except that the heat can get to you). Try to leave early and make the most of the morning before the heat starts to set in.

Holy moly this place is huge!. Angkor Wat was on my bucket list and it was totally worth the visit. It is huge with multiple temples within the Siem Reap site grounds. Ta Prohm is the famous Tomb Rader temple with the giant overgrown trees. Unfortunately, there are so many tourists there it is hard to really appreciate it and get good photos. Bayon Temple will give you some amazing photos that look as if they were straight from Indiana jones and the temple of doom. Even though a lot of people will be clambering at dawn to get photos inside the park for photos at Angkor wat, you can just as easily get amazing shots from outside along the reflecting pools without fighting the crowds. You will need bug spray though! There are monkeys at Angkor, so animal spotters be on the lookout. I would recommend getting a map if you can find one before you arrive, because the place is like a maze inside and easy to get lost in, there are no signs, and after you have spent time in Asia you realize that brochures and maps are a thing of The West. You can, however, buy cheap packets of postcards from the kids following you around the entrances for a small amount. It is very hot there even in the cooler seasons so expect to sweat a lot. That being said, the views are breathtaking. I would not recommend going with a large tour group if you want to get the full effect and not the rushed and not be crowded out. It is a site you may want to take several days to visit if you have time.
Part of the Angkor Wat tour . Again part of the big tour this was fantastic as you can see them doing the reconstruction and the trees on the structure of the walls is amazing

beautiful trees on top of temples. I love looking at the places here in Cambodia with trees literally growing on the temples. There are alot of people taking pictures but do wait for a good chance to have a solo picture.

Amazing!. Wear non-slip shoes and be ready for steps and climbing in place - lots of uneven ground. If you aren't good with heights avoid temples with high climbs. We saw Ankor Wat at 6am and it was worth it for the peace and coolness as well as views. Day two we did the large circuit stopping off at many smaller temples which were more interesting than the bigger, more cleaned up ones. Swot up on Hundi and Buddist religions to get the most out of the trip. 3 day tickets can be used over the course of a week so we had a day of no temples and then used the final day's admission. Tuktuk took us around the large circuit on day too and this was great as it rained hard and we had children.

A True Ancient Wonder. A must-see for everyone! Would recommend visiting as early as possible in the morning to avoid crowds and heat. If visiting for 'sunrise ' you'll need to go fairly early and 'claim' your spot with a mat (can be rented for a small fee) as late-comers will try to take your space (you've got to experience it to understand how ridiculous people can be).
Amezing Tree on Top Temple. you can see many tree around temple and on top roof of templeAmezing and beautiful place Tomb rider here.

The Amazing Temples of Angkor Watt. If you are in Siem Reap area, these temples are a must. They are spread across a wide area, easily accessible by tuc tuc. You will be amazed at the size of these temples and the intricate reliefs as well as the larger carvings. A real must if you in the area.

Incredible experience like no other. An amazing day! If theres one thing I'd do differently I'd arrive at the ticket office at 4:45am to be at the front of the line when it opens at 5am as we waited in line for 20+mins and missed the first 10mins of sunrise over Angkor Wat.

Awe inspiring temples well worth a visit!. Pros: Gorgeous temples some famous and huge, some small and unknown. Went on a great bike tour with Grasshopper Adventures to visit some smaller temples deep in the forest where we were the only people there. Once in a lifetime experience.Cons: Very hot year round, many locals will pester you for tuk tuk rides or buying water. I fully support the local economy but being constantly yelled at/pestered was a bit annoying.

Best way to see Angkor Wat. The best way to see this world heritage site is to visit it by mountain bike (and a guide of course). The main gates are narrow and can only let one car at a time through but on bikes you can circumnavigate the long rows of Tuk Tuk's and cars and hit the single track trails to get you to the heart in a matter of minutes (once you arrive at the gates).

AMAZING. Most amazing thing you'll see in Cambodia. Like many others, we were there are 5am to see the sunrise, but we didn't return to our hotels like they did. We stayed and saw several temples while it was still cool and were done by mid-morning. Make sure to cover your shoulders, knees, don't wear a skirt without something underneath (tons of stairs), good walking shoes, hat/sunscreen. LOTS of water. Drinks and such are sold along the way, but if you're feeling sick, grab a fresh coconut for electrolytes. Don't go into the small temples if you feel that you may be putting yourself in a situation to get ripped off. Just personally. Have a good day, be nice to your driver (if you have one), and just generally enjoy yourself, but respect that people still go there to worship.
Sunrise at Angkor wat. We went for sunrise and then stayed on to view the temple while it was quiet and not too hot. A majestic place.

Must see if you visit Cambodia. This is a must see if you are anywhere near this part of Asia. It is truly an incredible sight to see. Don't even try to see it all in one day. It is a bit overwhelming the size of the sight so if you are not specifically interested in every inch a day will do to see the main temples. Arrive as early as you can. Tickets are for 24 hours so if you want to go back to the hotel once it is hot and come back later as it starts to get a bit cooler is advisable.
Amazing place. What can I say that hasn't already been said. A fantastic experience. The merchants are quite annoying but the scenery is second to none.

One of the best sites in the world!. Being here in the off peak season, is fantastic as there are times when you are completely alone in one of the most magnificent spots in the world. The bad side is that it is dangerously hot, drink lots of water and bring an umbrella or hat. The temples here are truly amazing, i dont feel that my words are adequate to explain that to you. We hired a guide and he was worth every penny, took us to each site and gave background and the history of each temple. He showed us the best places to take photos and which order to go temple to temple to avoid the tour bus crowd. The museum was a great place to spend an afternoon, as it is air conditioned. I learned a lot of interesting things in the museum that I looked for the next day as i toured more of the temples. The 3 day pass is worth it, time and money wise.

Ancient Impossible. The Architecture of this place is admirable to say the leastDon't just go for a day to take pictures. Stop to Smell the roses and feel the energy of this place. Hopefully you have done some history reading before coming here, will help to enjoy more of what you see, touch,smell,hear and experience
A must do in Cambidia. Great in all the meaning of the word: magnitude, atmosphere, carvings, beauty. This is something people can not miss when visiting Cambodia.

Monuments of a Great Civilization. Fantastic art and Hindu / Buddhist Culture of the Khmer Empire. Go at sunrise and beat the heat and the crowds, take a mid-day break and return in the evening. Tuk Tuk transportation is highly recommended, book the same driver for your entire stay.

Just amazing! But so, so hot!. We went to the museum the day before which had a fabulous audio visual explanation about the temple as well as some beautiful artefacts from the various temples so it is well worth a visit before you go trekking in the heat. We also had an English speaking guide on the day of our tour who made everything easy. Tourists do need to make an effort to cover their shoulders and knees if they want to climb the central pagoda and that's not always noted. For the two outer pagoda areas it seems to be more acceptable to be in a singlet or shorter skirts/shorts but I had to buy a tee shirt for the hawkers on the way in if I was intending to climb the central and most holy of the pagodas and I saw many younger girls in very short shorts and singlets who were forbidden by the attendants from climbing the very steep woo dent stairway that now gives access to the holy pagoda tower. We bought a daily ticket but you can buy a two day our three day ticket which allows you to visit at various times of the day to enjoy the sunrise/sunset and helps to break up what is a very hot and long walking tour.

Just mind blowing. I have never been anywhere of this scale before. I just loved the place. I would take a three day pass if I went again. Watching the sun rise was a life experience. One Vistula is not enough to see everything. Would love to go at sunset

Amazing. It;s one of the top 20 places to see before you die! I have visited 3 times and can go again and again. I love the reflection of the temple in the late at sunrise. Although the last time the late was almost dry and swampy without the red water lily.For the 20$ day pass they should invest some to keep it in good condition.

One of the main reasons to go to Cambodia. Of course is Angkor (Wat) one of the main reasons to go to Cambodia and yes it is beautiful out there. We were there before June 2014 but that is the lowest date I could fill in. Also try to go to the other temples that are more faraway !!!
Must see. Amazing how many ruins there are and the detail in the carving. We only had a short time frame but would have loved to cycle on the forest roads and explored a lot more.

Amazing temples. We did four temples in two days, including sun rise at Angkor Wat. Ended exhausted, we probably would have needed a 3rd day, but it was all really worth it. Regret not having contracted a tour guide ahead of time and through trustworthy references. We ended up hiring one of the many guides that stand at the entrance of the temple because we realised there is so much to take in.
Incredible !! . Buy the 3 day pass it's really worth it. With so many fascinating things to see you will need it. Keep your pass with you @ all times. It will be checked @ every site.Enjoy !!

Three Days Wasn't Even Enough!. We booked with a guide and driver when we got there. The three days cost us only $150, and it was well worth it! We paid the park fee for three days, separately from the guide of course, which was a much better deal than the one-day fee. The area has so much to see. Having a private guide kept us from being packed into a huge group like people on the buses, but it also gave us insight into what we were seeing that we would not otherwise have had!
A absolute must see while in Siam Reap. The best archeological I have visited. The sheer scale of the temples and how they were build was amazing. A must see while in Siam Reap.

Worth going to see. Amazing, beautiful and wonderful. The site is huge with so much to see. There are places to eat here but you could take a picnic. It would be worth spending a couple of days here. Wear comfortable, sensible shoes and take a hat, water and a fan.
Interesting place. The month of May is too hot to tour the Wat but overall its a interesting place to travel. Amazed of the great buildings from ancient time.

Worth the time to see more than Angkor Wat. It is well worth buying the three day pass so that you can explore more of the many ancient structures in the park. Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom are amazing places, but there are in fact more than 60 other ancient buildings available for tourists to see, some much older and quite different to them. The pass is quite good value, and you can always get a tuktuk for transport. We hired a local guide - well worth it since there is not a lot of signage to explain what you are seeing.

Must visit. If you're into history, architecture, photography and archeology, this is a must-visit. Among the temples, I would highly recommend Bayon, Ta Phrom, Preah Kahn and Angkor Wat. There's not much to see further down the Roluos group, especially Lolei, where the lone temple is currently enclosed by construction poles which is presumably doing some maintenance work. The Angkor Wat, usually the highlight of the Park, is a must visit, but the high number of tourists make it a tiring visit. If you can go there in the lean seasons, perhaps you will have a better appreciation (and view) of the Angkor Wat. Otherwise, it's crowded and very very hot. Most hotels have straightforward tours to save you the stress of planning, so I suggest to avail them. Anyway, you will pay more or less the same rate because you will be hiring a tuktuk driver. If you can get a driver who speaks English well, or can serve as your guide, much better.

Simply amazing. We went there at five in the morning to see the sunrise over Angkor Wat. I've never, ever experienced anything more astonishing than when the sun climb over Angkor Wat in the silence of the morning.

Photographers paradise. Angkor complex is a must do for any traveller with a keen interest on exploring the cultural abundance of Cambodia. The lesser the said is better. However please be advised there is plenty to walk and explore. Best to keep a 4-5 days to explore in detail!

Magnificent temples. This was an absolute highlight. Nevermind the scorching sun, this is a once in a lifetime experience. Angkor Wat is of course the most well known and magnificent of them all. We went here for sunrise and to explore early in the morning - great to beat the crowds - BUT we had to return beacause some of the inner temples only opened at 8:30-9:00. Bayon temple was also another highlight, Angkor Thom looks so other-worldly and surreal and further afield Bantey Srei is just so intricate and beautiful. If you go here and see nothing else, see these.

Hot in may. I chose to ride my bike rather than pay for a driver. It was fantastic, but hot. Rode out in the dark of the morning at 4;45 to get there before the sunrise. Was spectacular. Favourite temples were angkor thom and angkor wat.
Hot - go early to see the sunrise. Great to go via tuk tuk. Lots of crowds as expected, however heat beat us by lunchtime so would suggest to go as early as possible
Start early!. Start early.We watched the sunrise from the outside and then worked our way in. By noon we had walked 7 miles. Bring water and snacks. Get a good guide.

Incredible Structures. Cannot really add to what has already been said about Angkor Wat. It is truly breathtaking. Got up early to see the sun rise (blocked by some cloud) along with several hundred others. And this is the low season. It was good to be there early before the temperature soared. As well as Angkor Wat saw several other temples and palaces. Just awed by how these structures were built and are still well preserved. Do go early or late as it is much to hot in the middle of the day.

The temple complex of Angkor Wat is huge, awe-inspiring and truly breathtaking.. the temple complex is truly wondrous, the local people are charming and delightful. It took me a whole week to truly see, enjoy, and appreciate these most wondrous and magnificient man-made architecture. I am in love with Angkor Wat and the temples of Cambodia

Truely magnificent. We went on a tuc tuc day tour, as we had only one day to see the temples. There are so many different and equally impressive temples that it is very difficult to chose which ones to visit. The tour (small round or large round) cover the most 'important' temples. It is definitely worthwhile either reading up on the different temples prior to the visit or getting a guide. The guides will wait for you at the entrance to Angkor Wat and will try to sell a tour hard. Some of them have better English than others, with a good English speaker, the history will come to live and you will get a lot of additional information compared to just wondering off on your own.
If you dont like walking, dont go. Lots of walking involved, stair climbing, heat, sweaty body all day, But its all worth it! but if you cant get around very well don't go

Amazing temple. this temple was amazing temple we use spend our time to this temple for 3 hours that is longer than another temple. the temple is biggest of anther temple like Bayon, taphrom. but we like angkor wat than another.
Angkor Wat. Great historical site. A must see in Siem Reap. Multiple places in the park to visit and good to see at Dawn and/or Dusk. 2-3 days to see it all so buy the 3 day pass is best

Cycling there is probably the best thing to do in Siem Reap. Regardless of the fact that it was insanely cheap, Renting a bike for a day ($1) was a great experience, but definitely not for people who don't cycle for long distances occasionally. The total distance for a mini tour could easily reach 25-30 km. If you start at 5 am like me, be ready for really hot ride. Sunscreen is definitely a must and you'll also need a lot of water, which you can buy easily everywhere along the road.Beware of taking Sivatha Road instead of the road by the river. If you continue straight to Angkor Wat you will be required to cylce 4 km back and turn left to get your tickets. It's a really disappointing thing to hear if you want to catch the sunrise.A lot of khemr people especially young girls are selling traditional scarves or postcards or bracelets. It would help them a lot if you buy from them especially in low season. Even though those whom you didn't buy from will get more pushy after that.The place itself needs no description. If you don't want to stay in the hot sun for so long, you can plan your trip beforehand and go to selected temples only.

Monuments are made by human hands but inspired by Divine.That is why Khemer kings are called Devrajas ( Divine kings). Send me your email...I can send few pages of my photo book (PDF).Monuments are reflecting Hindu Gods & mythology.Let me know your interest & nos. of days you are planning to spend.My email is mayurrs@yahoo.co.inMayur Shah

Like a dream.... We spent two days in Siem Reap and got time just for the "small tour" (Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayom and the Lady Temple. Made a stop by the Landmine Museum (amazing interesting for military and history freaks...

See one temple, seen them all . I hate to say it, but it's true. See one temple, seen them all. If you can't arrange for a tuk tuk to take you around or if for any other reason you can't see all the major temples, then you should at least make an effort for Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm. We did both a tuk tuk tour (30-60mins) as well as an all day bike tour around with Grasshopper Tours (which can really be quite strenuous on a warm day).

Away from the Temple overload. Trees Water walk with space to breath. Was it a good swap to leave the Landmine Museum, and Beng Mealea Temples unvisited and enjoy instead Kbal Spean and Phnom Koulen NP. Climb to remove your shoes and onward to where the Buddha lies, { He must be tired after the climb - joke!]Enjoy the waters and the easily found Peace . Shop if you have a mind to, Eat at the many places if you have a need to. Enjoy the Fun of the Waterfalls and Yes it is worth going down to the bottom just be aware the route is not the best.Our afternoon was completed by our exo travel guide finding a place to Laze on the way back to Siem Reap. That was at a fishing and entertainment lake. We so enjoyed the "packed lunch and the Bottle of Wine we had picked up and kept cold lazing in hammock even just for the few minutes we had to totally unwind

The reason you come to Siem Reap. Yes, it is amazing to see this temple complex dating from the 10th century. There are so many ways to visit -- on bike, with a guide, on a tuk-tuk. Worth it to try a couple options as every time you gain a different perspective.Bring lots of water. Various places to stop and eat along the way. Restrooms impressively clean.No matter when you go, there will be lots of other people there. But don't let that hinder your visit.
Amazing Place!. Even though it is VERY old, it is still in amazing shape. Lots of people when we were there but still if you plan it right, you can get some very quite spots.
Without words. It is amazing and there are moments in wich you'll stay without words. If you can go to the smallest temples and a litlle far, with luck you will be alone and you feel the atmosphere

Wow!. You can easily see why it's one of the 7 Wonders of The World. The sheer scale and complexity of the site,so many temples to explore and the intricacy of the carvings, it's truly incredible! Catch the sunrise also. Breathtaking!

Everything I hoped it would be!. This was everything I hoped it would be! So amazing, so breathtaking! There is a modesty dress code - and I can understand this. I have respect for the site and its importance. However, you see people all over the place with their t*ts and a*s hanging out. Its very disrespectful and I hated seeing it.

A breathtaking temple! . I have always know Angkor Wat through historic books, when I reach here, I spend 3 days to tour around the 12th-13th century built temples. It is breathtaking and amazing that all these temples were built with blocks of rock, with sculpture and crafting that is so beautifully craft. Each temple have shown the historic stories behind the crafting on the wall in each temple, to see the progression and transition of Hindu temple to Buddhist temple. Not to miss when you plan to travel to Cambodia.

What a temple!. Firstly this is absolutly stunning. Get yourself lost in tomb raider. There is conservation work at the site atm therefore some areas are closed of to public. There are lots and lots of large stone work and advise walk with caution. Note there are plenty of people trying to sell you $1 bits can be a pain but other than those 2 things enjoy P.s. Take extra batteries for camera

A fantastic visit!. There is so much to see here, and all of the temples, whether you visit Angkor Wat and Bayun Temple with all their grandeur, or one of the smaller temples, like the Lady's Temple, you'll be happy you took the trip!

One of the main archeological sites in the world. What to say about Angkor that has not been said already? I had been waiting to visit this place for many years and when I finally visited here, it did not let me down. It is simply amazing. I visited around 20 temples with my family in 4 days in Siem Reap and did not get tired. Temples are quite different in general and offer excellent opportunities for photography.

the right people will make it great!. I spent 5 days in Siem Reap and had a great stay, thanks to the honest people I metI got a 3 day pass and visited the temples solo with the guidebook Ancient Angkor bought from the first temple I visited. It is cheapest actually from the touts at Angkor Wat who give an opening price of 1USD. I bought my copy for $6 from Ta Prom. It gives you a lot of info, can't replace a good tour guide but is much cheaper and flexible. you may want to hire a guide for the small circuit though, it is easy to spend too long in one place or miss the highlights of a particular site if you don't know what your looking for. I know I did at some places.The tuk tuk driver I used was Kim, honest and punctual guy, you can checkout his website at cambodiandriver.com, he is reviewed on TripAdvisor also.stayed at Angkor Voyage Villa, great staff and location.my remaining two days I spent with bees unlimited combo tour and triple a adventures.I can also recommend temple club Apsara performance, great night out.

Take Your Time it's going nowhere. An excellent place to visit but given the heat and humidity you have to take your time. Visit over a number of days as there is a lot of walking and a great deal to see. Don't be surprised if you are 'templed out ' after two or three days!

Ancient city in Cambodia. ... I am local people in siem reap and i have been to visit alls place here and out of angkor area..as preach vihear it's mountain temple and kuk ke temple it's pyramid. .I think in siem reap province it's number one and mush famous in Cambodia. ...because these area have alot of temple. ..and safe for tourism travel around these area.....So that why i love siem reap Angkor. Thanks.
Nothing to say.... ...you are not going to Siem Reap and not visiting Angkor!Stay at least three days and bike around...

Must see in Cambodia. Historical highlight, but plan well your trip. Long distances and hot weather ist not a good combination (April). Better arrange a Tuk Tuk Tour or E-Bike. :)Two days are enough if you want to see the highlights (small and big tour). If you want to go to Banteay Srei it will take a day more.

Counting down the days until we can visit again. This was my second visit and it was just as breathtaking as the first. We spent 3 days in the park, but could have easily spent more. You could spend days wandering through the ruins and just imagining what it all used to be.We booked a tour this time and I think it was an excellent choice. Sam Tuktuk tours were reasonably priced (by Australian standards) but I would have paid double the price! The tour guide was amazing. He had so much information to share. We had both a guide and a driver and went to places not usually visited as well as all the popular locations. Sunrise is beautiful and well worth the 4am start. Can not wait to return.

The temple you can't skip. In fact this is the best temple with alot of big tree inside and all the temple was more than our expectation. It looks unbelievable that the people could this kind of temple./

nothing in the world like it.. getting a bit pricy and overcrowded but still one of a kind. I like it better 4 years ago before many of the restorations, but what can one do, times they are a changin. And 90% the Cambodians know how to do it! I liked the nature ruins part better but...

Wonderful ancient ruins. If you have time buy a 7-day pass and spend a week here to really enjoy and experience these wonderful ruins. Hire a tuk-tuk or car from Siem Reap and explore each temple on your own. Don't join a tour group as you wil be rushed. Beside Angkor Wat, temple that should not be missed in my opinion are Bayon, Ta Prohm, Preah Khan, and Banteay Srey. Then we can also do day trips to Preah Vihear, Koh Ker, Beng Mealea etc.

Absolutely Incredible. Breath taking temples and architecture. Just walked around on my own so didn't learn enough to really appreciate it so would recommend that.Just got a tuk tuk to take me round all day, pretty cheap.Wear a sleeved T-shirt to make sure you can get in everywhere
The World Heritage Site of Angkor Wat. A must see, get a 4 day pass. hire a Tuk Tuk driver. Mr B from Angkor Spirit Palace is very good, nice place to stay out of town.

Still Suitable For Adventurers. Obviously, the times are gone when one can explore the temples like Lara Croft, and there are places and times when matters get a bit crowded (I pity the Chinese who have to 'do' Angkor in a day in large groups). However, pick the right time, start your day early, trust an experienced tuk tuk driver and find your own paths and you will find a world full of magic, spiritual energy and amazing beauty!

Amazing trip!. Enchanting! Professionalism and honesty from the very patient tour guide, the best in business! Absolutely amazing sites and cultural attractions, culinary delight and amazing friends! Wonderful time! Can't wait to come back!

Worth every minute of it. Cycled my way to the Angkor park (went to the wrong entrance and couldn't buy the tkt but was fortunately helped by a guy on moped who ferried me to the ticket booths while the guards watched over my bike ..made it in time for the sunrise ) very beautiful and being Indian i was actually amazed by the details of the picture carvings and the accuracy of narration of the historical and religiously significant events. i purchased a ebook and my kindle 3g with Wikipedia formed a good guide.the full temple run can be a drag if you are not into this sort of things but anyways it is a must visit for the sheer grandeur of construction. the sunrise is beautiful but too many tourists so gets a little anticlimax as your expectations of a peaceful temple visit are thrown offtrack. mobile phone coverage is available here so use your 3g local sim for doubts ..lots of guides overhyped and overdramatized interpretations (yes there is still room to do that to indian history )

Everything you imagine and more.,. Lots if walking and climbing but worth every step! We were unlucky withe the weather as it was very cloudy which prevented us seeing the famous sunset. But we cannot predict the weather!

Once in a life time experience. The temples and ruins are something out of this world. They are something to be preserved and experienced. I had my 6 year old with me, and even he can appreciate the magnitude of the place.

An absolute must. Our tour guide took us through the middle from back to front and then we returned next day to look at the BAS reliefs which was a really good way as we visited twice and gave us time to absorb the complicated history.

feel history all around this place. start with sunrise Angkor Wat visit, take couple of good photos and leave for other temple if you want to enjoy them coz it is very touristic place. come back to Angkor Wat at the end of your tour. Frankly speaking, i loved other templets more than Angkor Wat. Do not forget to feed monkey by road but be careful coz they might steal your banana. I am still wondering how they managed to create such beautiful templetes with all those details. well crafted stones

Do Homework and Enjoy a Self Tour. Definitely a sight worth visiting once in a lifetime. 3 full days there is ideal to me.I recommend the Kindle book "The Temples of Angkor" by David Raezer, very utility friendly. It can easily be kelp as a cheatsheet in smartphone or tablet when reaching a spot. Trust me, there are so many temples with non-English names, quite easy to get confused even reading ahead. Another recommendation is to get an E-Bike if you are experienced with a scooter which is popular in southeast Asia. The speed is faster than bike, slower than cars and perfect for sightseeing. The range is ok to make a tour between the Angkor Park and the city. Tuk Tuk is cool but sometimes it could be a bit tricky when negotiating the price. I rather save my time and jump for a ride whenever I want. Bike is nice but it is super super hot here so not cool to exercise outdoor. One thing not so cool is the heavy battery if you need to move it to hotel room for charge over night.

Must-Do Bucket List Item. If watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat isn't on your bucket list, your bucket list sucks. Make sure you get out there when it's still pitch black (check the sunrise times and aim to get out there about 45-60mins before) and watch the silhouette of the temples appear as the sky begins to glow. Incredible. Take a torch.

great. we enjoy the place. Its good to know the story and the culture of old Cambodia. Well done !! Tuk tuk the local transportation facilities are easy to find also cheap. 2 - 3 $ we can reach to almost interest destination.

Massive and Impressive, Must See Once (or More). The entire Angkor Wat Complex covers a huge area and needs many days to explore with a hired vehicle (a Tuk Tuk). Better begin your exploration very early in the morning (or late during the day) to avoid the scorching uncomfortable heat.
Impressive. It was just the extremely strong sun that made the visit hard. Nevertheless I would always repeat that experience!

Wow. This was really amazing. To see live what I had onlhy read about was such a wonderful experience. Thank God we had perfect weather, hot as usual, but no rain whatsoever so we were able to enjoy our visit. It is so close to town that some people travel by tuk-tuk. We took a private tour.

Angkor Wat. Must Visit Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. A good tour guide makes a big difference. Try contact Mr Kea, recommended by Travel Loop tour agency. But I do not know why tripods are not allowed at Bakheng Mountain, photographer needs tripod for sunset view shooting.

Of course it's a must see. Everybody comes to Siem Reap to see Angkor Wat (at least for first time). It's a beautiful place to see and there are so many other sights around in the Archaeological Park, you will be very tired by the end of the day, but it's a must do!Be prepared tough it's very crowded.You can get souvenirs on good prices if you know how to haggle a bit, we got 2 beautiful paintings of Angkor Wat and the price was much better than on the markets.
the best place. This temple is known as tomraider movie. the great shot in the world that you have to explore. NO where else like here a very big tree grows on the temple which is stick to its tree

A feast of old Angkor sites.. The rulers of Angkor in the 11th and 12th centuries must have been very very busy. Within the park there are beautiful trees, mahogany, kapok, teak and rosewood.The sites include Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, The Bayon and the fortified city of Angkor Thom.A fascinating archaeological site.

Fantastic: much better in life than in pictures. This site needs much more time than the day that tour companies usually like to do it in. We were only able to do the main bits, albeit in good depth, but would have liked to explore other less frequented parts. An early start is definitely needed to avoid the heat and most of the crowds.
Of course, a must do. Pick up a guide (person) for a few dollars at the temple. Guide books - too hard to follow. Some had printed off Google information - which seemed more relevant and up-to date.
History recovered. Amazing! Such a great history revealed through fantastic architecture. Unbelievable that they constructed these temples without cement or modern tools.

Sunrise tour. I did a sunrise tour in April for around 5 hours. It is really spectacular to get up and see the park then. My guide was outstanding and provided a good level of detail without going over the top. I wish I could remember his name. In particular I was impressed with Bayon of the temples this was the most impressive to me, but everyone will have their own favorite as there are many to choose from. I would recommend a couple visits as the complex is huge and the amount of detail could be overwhelming in one visit.

must-see. it is a must-visit place of the world. The Angkor Wat is mesmerizing. There are just so many temples that I get bored after the second stop. I visited in May and it was hot and made me drained. If you like arts, or can appreciate architectures, you should plan to spend as long as you want. for me, I visited just to see, and i feel like one day is enough. There are 1 day pass, 3 days pass and 7 days pass. I purchased the 3 days pass, and I should just have bought the 1 day pass as I could not enjoy it anymore after seeing several wat in Day 1. So plan ahead and think if you can enjoy all temples. I ended up visiting more temples just make the USD40 pass worthwhile.Nevertheless, i love Angkor Wat.
Interesting. This temple is Angilina Julia film Tomraider. The best one in Cambodia. Don't forget see it. The best view with the big tree grow on its top temple

Take plenty of water and go early. We went for the sunrise but sadly very little water in the lake but glad we went early as the day just got hotter. We did the one day pass and I felt that is plenty. Once you have seen one temple ruin most are very similar.
Bucket list. This world famous site is incredible value for money with a 3 day pass costing just $40 per person. The cost of hiring a tuk tuk driver to get you around is equally inexpensive.

Some of the coolest things i have ever seen. Fantastic temples- all different. Recommend buying a multi-day pass as you definitely cannot and dont want to see it all in one day. Plan on half days, either in the morning or late afternoon as its far too hot otherwise.

Yes Its Possible To Visit It All In One Day. People say take 2 or 3 days to see all the sights, but its possible as I did to see it all in one long day without rushing around too much. I saw Ta Prohm, Angkor Wat, The Terrace Of Elephants and Bayon in one (hot) day without too much difficulty. Of course it all lived up to expectations, and its all good.

A real wonder of the world. Go for sunrise at Angkor wat. Make sure you get to see the happy temple and the one with the faces. It's so very hot here, plan what you want to see and take plenty of water. Don't eat in the restaurants in the park ( worst meal we had on our 4 week holiday) take a lunch or head back to Siem reap.
Phenomenal. Apart from the crowds, there is nothing to dislike. It is worth going early in the day, allowing plenty of time, and visiting some of the "lesser" temples.

Amazing once in a life time experience. I truly enjoyed this place i had a great time and amazing experience. Its a bit pricey i think to get in $20.00 a day and make sure you dont loose your ticket as they will ask for it everywhere you go , but it is a once in a life time experience and you really do get to see some great historic temples.
Wow. It was a great experience visiting these marvelous creations of human kind. However, be prepared to deal with the extreme heat and dust.

Better than Athens or Rome. You need transport don't think you can do this walking you'd see nothing, but you can get a tuk tuk for 12 dollars whole day. Tell him before hand exactly were you want to go and what you want to see. Refuse to eat at the restaurant your tuk driver recommends and prices there will drop by half

A must see . One of the ten wonders of the WORLD !. Visit all the temples. Take plenty of time to wander in the parks. Don't miss the sunrise in Angkor : having a picnic breakfast sitting in the temple and watching the sun rise is an unforgettable experience.

Enjoy the journey. The temples are obviously amazing but this park is about so much more than that. We decided that we would bike from our hotel there and do the grand and petite loops on two subsequent days. Cycling around the park was a wonderful way to appreciate the size and scope of it all. You could feel closer to nature, see the locals who live in the park, observe the wildlife. All in all it was a wonderful experience accentuated by the presence of all the beautiful buildings.

Over crowded, but still some gems left to photograph.. Dammit. I love the Angkor temples, have been visiting for 15 years now, but sadly they are becoming terribly over crowded (yes, I'm as guilty as everyone else there). Each year there are more ropes and barriers (bad for photography) and some of the restorative work is just plain bad and out of place. Better left unrestored in many cases.Having said that, do your homework before you go. There are still plenty of gems to be visited, you just need to know where to go and most importantly, at what time of the day. For photography and to avoid crowds try the terraces, Phimeanakas, Palace area and Preah Phithu early in the morning - 7am - 9am. Suor Prat towers brilliant in late afternoon light.Phnom Bakheng for sunrise (forget it for sunset)Ta Som (rear gate) and Banteay Same (central sanctuary) are brilliant in the early golden light.Angkor Thom gates - Nth Gate late afternoon. Spirit gate mid morning.Bayon always best (and quieter) from 4pm onwards.North Gate of Ta Prohm and South Gate of Banteay Kdei mid morning. Tuk Tuk drivers generally have no idea about latter two gates, so make sure they understand where you want to go.Plenty of others, but you'll have to stay a bit longer and discover for yourself.
nice. its nice to see them once you're there. but seen one, seen them all. vhoose tha day tour costs only 20 dollars! dont go for the 3 day tour!!

It takes longer than you think. The many sites of Angkor are so widespread, it takes much longer than you might think to get around. Depending on the heat and your fitness, you may need at least 3 days.
good for visit. i love to see a round the world and some thing is different natureplace like angkor archaeological park , and just the border of thailand

Temple hopping is great fun!. Spent 3 days hopping around the temples of Angkor on a bicycle was certainly the best thing I've done in my whole life! I get to stop wherever I want and spend whatever time I want at each location that I am interested. The downside of not having a tour guide is that I don't have much insight into the history details of each temple, however the information board display does give me some quick history lessons! If you intended to do a bicycle tour, a local SIM card with data is your best friend to navigate using Google Maps. Toilets is not readily available at all the temple, so plan your break time!

Amazing!. Angkor Wat and Angkor Tom are a must see! Very impressive and awe inspiring! Hundreds of temples, palaces, ruins, statues and monuments. A two day stay is a minimum and even then you will only see the most popular spots. It is massive so long walks with lots of stairs are involved and it is either dry and hot or wet and hot. Bring plenty of water, good shoes and an umbrella if you can.

A must see - truly amazing. What a great park to visit... more than a day should be spent here- and highly advise to go early in the morning when its a bit more quiet. Also worth visiting some of the temples that are not as popular as some of them do get very busy. But truly breathtaking.
Amazing architecture. The whole Park is incredible, different locations are all interesting, you just have to go and see for yourself!
relics in need of urgent restorations. Sad to see the crumbling of structures all round these places but still it's worth the visit as it is extraordinary!

3 days in Angkor Archaeological Park. We visited Angkor Thom and the 'Tomb Raider' Temple on our first day, Angkor Wat on our second, and Banteay Srei (the Ladies' Temple) on our third day. There are so many other temples that it would be easy to spend even longer exploring. March/April are the beginning of the hot season, and we found it was best to start our touring very early (6:30AM) so that we could get in before the crowds and the heat. If I had this trip to do over again, I would go in December/January/February when, we were told, it is much more temperate. Go to the National Museum before going to the Park, as it will help you understand what you are looking at. It wouldn't hurt to do a little reading up on Hindu myths and legends, too, as well as some brief history of Cambodia.

Temples everywhere. One of the worlds unique places. We only concentrated on the Bayon, Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm but there are umpteen other ancient buildings littered around the area to be be explored if you have the time. For me my favourite was Ta Prohm. Just the three of us arrived in a tuk tuk from Siem Reap around 4 in the afternoon and it was relatively quiet. Even though in parts there is scaffold there was still a peaceful feeling to the place, apart from the chatter of monkeys and screeching of birds! Of course the Bayon and Angkor Wat are wonderful as well but they were busier on our visits but not too bad if you visit around 7 a.m.
Fantastic structure. Breathtaking scenery and well worth a visit, but depending on the month you travel, be warned it gets extremely hot.

Amazing -. go in the late afternoon followed up by getting up for the sunrise, also since there are so many people in the front, explore the towers form the back. still amazing views with hardly anyone
Amazing!. The early start to see the sun rising over Angkor Wat is well worth it.The elephant ride around the temple is also worth doing and you must go to see The Temple of the Tomb raider
Wonder Temples with greenery. I want to visit here because I want to see the beauty of the temple and the same time I love the big, big trees around this area.

Huge site with so much to see. Everyone thinks of visiting Angkhor Wat when they come to Siem Riep, but this is just one of a multitude of temples on this site. I don't know the size of the park, but we spent two days there and moved between temples in a small coach, and we barely scratched the surface.The temples are as amazing as you could wish, but there is a lot of walking or travelling to do between sites, and in hot weather an umbrella is a good idea as there isn't a lot of shade.The only downside is the number of young children trying to sell trinkets. They are very insistent and their plaintive cries of 'only one dollaaaaar' stayed with us for a few days.

Must see before it's too late!. Go see before it disappears.Bayon & Elephant Terrace my favouritesSome people are making a lot of money out of Angkor.I cannot see this being invested in protecting the sight or indeed reducing the daily damage from visitors scrambling on the archeology to get a selfie to prove they have 'been'.I can understand locals needing to make a dollar to survive, this is a poor country.Someone needs to effectively plan for long term sustainability of the site otherwise it will become even more ruined and lose the attraction and wow factor it still has. Siem Reap will then lose its reason to be and a lot of people will have no work.Merely raising the admission prices will not solve any of these issuesWe explored over two days and that was sufficient in the April heat. Agree with other postings. Take plenty of water,enjoy

Great Park. Brilliant to see all the ruins and all the restoration going on. I particularly enjoyed seeing that different countries are helping out to restore aspects of the ruins. Definitely hire a guide, they're well worth it to tell you all the interesting details you'd otherwise miss.

Must See. We hired a tuk tuk driver to go around the temples and had an amazing day. Hiring a driver is the best way to do it! There were a lot of locals selling things in markets and they will hassle you if you don't make a purchase, but the temples are definitely worth spending the day at.

Plan carefully, bring lots of water. The entire Angkor Wat experience, including its associated temples, is truly a Must See on a global level. To appreciate that this was once a city that was larger than London, Paris, Rome is hard to fathom today, but the various ruins tell the story. With your tour guide, you should plan carefully, depending on your fitness level and your ability to tolerate heat. In the latter regard, always invest in one more bottle of water than you think, because it is hard to buy inside. And do not miss the sunrise over the main temple. You and thousands of others will be treated to a special sight, if the weather gods smile favourably on you. I have had the experience twice, one year apart, and I would do it again if I visited for a third time. Along with the grandiose, pay attention to the small details, like the engravings. Fascinating.

Angkor Wat will not disappoint. I am in Siem Reap now, it is 40 degrees while you are learning about all the temples, and walking up endless stairs. It is very interesting and the fact that they are so old is amazing. Around 1000 years old. The work to restore them is endless, and with all the looting over the centuries it is impossible to complete. I would recommend to anyone with an interest in Cambodia.A cooler month would be better!
Spectacular experience. This is a must visit place. One of the most interesting places on earth. Give your self at least three days to explore.

the great tour of Angkor Wat. all most the temple especially Angkor wat taphom bayon takeo ta som bontey srey and all so tonley sap lake specially floating village and boat riding and our next trip are around town and night market and pub street and all so old market

Best part of Cambodia. Excellent architecture and wonderful views. Take a good guide who can make your Angkor tour memorable. The shops in the temple complex are quite expensive, but you can haggle. Better to visit early morning so that you do not experience the scorching heat.A lot to walk

A Must See in the World. Learn all about the Khmer people and the fascinating culture who build Angkor Thom, a city where over one million people lived. Visit the temple of Angkor What and the so called Tomb Raider Temple Ta Promh!

Hot hot hot but loved it. If I had a do over, I would visit in cooler weather. The temp neared 100 degrees F, with no shade. However, this archeological gem is so richly interesting that is was still a great experience. It needs so much renovation that parts were closed due to safety concerns. The structures, detailed carvings and monuments were incredible. Make sure you go with a guide to explain the historic significance of each location. I hope they get more internatinal funding to restore this world class historic site.
Must see!. Only few man-made monuments in the world can compete with what you can find Cambodia. Fascinating! I can not imagine how this was build 1000 years ago in these weather conditions.

Crumbling ruins. For such a popular destination, one would think that more would be done to preserve and restore the archaeological sites for future generations, rather than milking (rather poorly) their present value. A much more robust curation of the sites would stand to make more money now, and would permit effective business operations into the future. Cambodia is punching below it's weight here.
angkor temples. Visited all the major temples did it in 21/2 days, will go back to visit the waterfall with shiva lingams etched into it and some of the remote jungle temples

You have to!. If you're in Siem Reap, you are here for the temples. We spent 2 full days (7am-2pm) which was just right considering the heat and crowds. Hired a tuk tuk each day (around $15) so had a lot of flexibility with how long to spend at each temple.

Amazing sight to see. Wear comfy shoes and be prepared to climb (some people didn't and suffered). It is a large area and worth seeing. My husband felt a little 'templed out' but I thoroughly enjoyed it.
Many facilities near by for rest and food etc

Get up really early. Fantastic temples but to see them get up at 5.00am it is really worth it. The air is cool and you will be on your own with your guide. At that time the place exudes mystic charm . You can see a lot more and get those atmospheric phot shots without the hordes. Once the big tour busses arrive the place becomes a big traffic jam in the main sites. A lot of the Huge groups appear to have no respect for the place or culture.

A place, what have to be on your bucket list.. People who’d like to visit the Temples of Angor in Cambodia, choose Siem Reap as a base because of its international airport.Before the rediscovery of the temples Siem Reap was hardly more than a village, but now is a busy town with countless hotels, pubs, restaurant, etc.When we decided to go and see the famous Angkor area, of course we went to Siem Reap as well. The big mistake we made was that we didn't listen to our readings „ Angkor is the place to be savoured, not rushed...”Since we’d like to see more and more places, we can’t afford financially and in time, to spend weeks at one place. For the result, there is a good expression „grasp all lose all”.Our Choice was a three-day exploration. Spend one day in Siem Reap , the second day visit 8 „less important” (it is ridiculous!) temples , starting with Prah Khan , and after Neak Pean, Ta Som,Eastern Mebon, Pre Rup, Tah Prom, Banteay Kdei, and finally Srah Srang. On the third day we started at Ankor Wat, and after Angkor Thom complex, with Bayon and after Baphoun temple, Phimeanakas temple, Preah Pranam Temple and finished with the Elephant Terrace and Leperd King Terrace.It is long even to read the names. Isn't it? Just imagine to explore all of these temples with their countless of stairs, chambers, courtyards, etc.Yes, if you’re young, healthy and in top condition, it would be all right. But to be over 70, and after one spine and three knee operations, I’m not ashamed to confess, that the end of the day, my only wish was to lie down and die peacefully.Luckily Ant, the tuk tuk driver, who took us everywhere and was our guardian angel, advised me to have a massage. He introduced me a fantastic massage salon (if I just could remember the name of it), where a nice girl was working on my exhausted body for an hour , and for US$ 15.- I've got the very best , invigorating massage in my whole life.To go to a Mexican pub and polish up two excellent Margaritas was the worthy finish of the day.The conclusion is that if you’re in an advanced age, try to spend there more time, have a more comfortable pace, enjoy it fully.Our plan is to go back, stay longer and visit no more than 2 or three temples per day. Even Ta Prohm, the beautiful jungle temple is worth for a whole day visit, not to mention Angkor Wat.We hardly can wait to go back!

Amazing Ancient Temples. I liked all of the Archaeological Sites. I found the Angkor Wat amazing but also the other temples: Bayon Wat, Baphoun Wat (which includes the Elephant Terrace) and my favourite, Banteay Srei, Citadel of the Woman or Lady's Temple. I was impressed by the thousands of carvings on walls which depict the history of the area, wars, occupations, even the history of the building of the temples!! The region should be on everyone's bucket list.
Go prepared. sun rise at ankor wot is well worth waking up early for, remember ladies..cover the shoulders and knees.
Mystical place. We loved every bit of our trip to the temples, simply stunning. It was very hot so people visiting during the month of April, stay hydrated and wear hats.

Unbelievable!. Walking through Angkor Wat, or cycling through one of the gates of Angkor Thom is just a unbelievable experience. The sunrise at Angkor Wat is breathtaking, but arrive early to get a good spot and carry bug repel!

Breathtaking. The scale of Angkor Wat will take you aback. It is not just the one famous temple but dozens of them spread over a huge area. The park is very well maintained and operated. Not at all suited for disabled. Allow at least 2 days to see the best. Go early because heat becomes unbearable fromm 1100 am onward. Go anti clockwise to avoid huge crowds

Magical. I especially loved the main temples at Angkor Wat, we bought a beautiful big painting to take home with us as a reminder, it's stunning. We hired push bikes on the first day which was great for seeing the closer/main temples, on the second day we hired a tuk tuk, which took us about an hour to get to one of the temples further out, honestly it wasn't really worth it after seeing the main temples. If I was going to do it again I would hire a car and also check out the floating city which is apparently out that way.

The Temples. A wonder of the world. How did they build this all those years ago. It is well worth prebooking a Guide with a car and driver as you learn far more in comfort.Prepared for heat and lots of climbing and walking. Make sure shoulders are covered with short sleeves, a shawl is not sufficient in places.

This is why I came to Siem Reap. Make sure you take a tuk tuk. Way to big to try to walk, way to hot to bike. Our tuk tuk driver always gave us a bottle of cold water to drink, and a cool cloth for our neck after each temple we visited, all for only $15 dollars for the whole day.

Do NOT even think of missing this!. Wow - absolutely jaw dropping! Had a fantastic guide in Thuch Vanak (thuchvanak@gmail.com) - excellent English, very knowledgeable, very friendly and very reasonable ($40 for a day long tour).
A must. Angkor Wat has to be seen to be believed. It is huge it takes a good couple of hours to walk around. The views from the top are amazing.
Magical place. The ruins of Angkor are simply stunning. You MUST go here. The views of the temples are breathtaking although it can be SUPER HOT. Bring a towel and drink lots of water

Join the Crowds!. In our tour we were kept standing and listening too much. Far too much information to absorb in a short time. A fascinating place to visit. We were amazed by the number children selling before day break. Some told us they work in the morning to pay fees to go to school in the afternoon.
Unbeleivable History. We had 1 full day exploring in the very hot sun but was worth every minute. Wonderful memories, lots of walking with amazing history
Visit to Angkor. Angkor Wat is really worth visiting, try to go at times with fewer public and you can be alone in the corridors of the temple

Awe inspiring. I feel so privileged to have visited this amazing place - it is absolutely awe inspiring. I cannot recommend it highly enough. Wear comfortable shoes, take water, and lose yourself in history.
big and very historical. a lot of history to be seen you must visit. The park is quite big and contain a lot of history in every corner.
Just as well expected. The scale of the site was impressive as was the whole complex. It was very crowded on the day of our visit
Just go. No review required.. Spiritual. Amazing. Go. Of the UNESCO sites that I have visited in my life... this is one of the best.
GREAT PlACE. This whole area has so much to see and do, a Must in Siem Reap, but would advice getting a local guide as the whole area has so many temples to explore
Amazing Angkor Wat. Liked everything about Angkor Archaeological Park, just wish we could have had more time. It is truly an amazing place to visit.

Totally Awesome!. If you are going to Siem Reap, it is probably to visit this park. You could spend weeks here visiting all the various temples and sites. This is an absolute must for anyone who appreciates history, religion, and art.

Don't miss the 3 most important temples. Angkor wat, Angkor thom with the elephant terrace and Ta Prohom are an unforgettable experience. Be prepared for the hight temperature and humidity, with long distances to walk, but deserves the sacrifice
Legend. It's very very interesting. Felt like I'm in a legend, touching real History.Great feeling. Highly recommended.

Such conflicted feelings.... I'll not beat around the bush, Angkor temples and grounds are exceptional. If you cannot marvel at the ingenuity of our people then you are not seeing the constructions here with true eyes. The scale, the grandeur, the megalomaniacal devotion to usurping the efforts of those who had gone before. Simply treading on stone slab steps worn almost to 45∘ by thousands of feet before is fuel for the imagination. Seeing the jungle and how it has invaded and become one with the temples, dark cornices and hidey holes, bats and buddhas; it all made for an Indiana Jones-esque trip.But...I am not the only one who revelled in it and I admit I am part of the problem. Angkor and Siem Rheap is where uncontrolled tourism is really screwing with the natural balance of people.
