On one hand you have thousands of tourists who barely even see the true beauty of the environment because they are vainly taking selfies to say look at me. Then you have the discrimination of good honest Cambodians, so saturated with exposure to Westerners that they no longer see/value you as a human being. Elephant rides, dancing monkeys, thick pollution, ticket nazi's, etc,. - So, a mixed occasion, but, I am 100% glad I went.
Amazing. Could not get over the age and the beauty of the temples and how they built them - you will be in awe of them

Ancient Angkor,- a very large area with Ankor Wat and many other temples. This is a vast area and it requires several days to see the most important temples and also an archeologic interest to a certain degree. Otherwise one will soon be saturated by all impressions and tired of all walking.It is a fantastic area and of course a must to see,- at least Angkor Wat, Ankor Thom and Ta Prohm (Tomb Rider site).We spent a few days at several temples and also had a balloon-ride to get an overview of the area. Impressive!
Incredible!. AMAZING temples frozen in time...Great history and photo opportunities in every inch!Worth doing it with a guide, for a better understand of everything.

Incredible park. The temples are large and extremely impressive. The many old trees surrounding some of them add to ancient experience of this world wonder. It's just hard to compute how something so grand was built so many years ago!

Angkor Wat's magic. An astonishing landmark, amazing to imagine the true magnitude of these temples in their time. Worth visiting again and again, with always more to explore. We purchased a three day pass and did not see an eighth! March was VERY hot and apparently April/May there are many festivals that brings the local crowds. Worth seeing and experiencing!
Worth seeing. Definitely get in early, you don't need to pay for a guide to enjoy all that the temples have to offer.

Stunning. As good as all the hype, worth a full day at least. I loved Angkor Wat and took some lovely photos. It is very hot in April so if you're not used to the heat early is best for the climb to the tower.

Simply stunning. There is little to add to the thousands of books and videos/documentaries that exist. Go and see for yourself. Surely, things will improve further in the next years and decades as conservation and repair works continue.
One of the Wonders of the World. What is there to say - it is Angkor - have a tremendous time. It is one of the wonders of the world.

World class experience. The entire park is a wonder and full of surprises.Our family with two teenage boys spent a full day in an air conditioned van with private guide visiting Bayon, Banteay Srei and Ta Phrom. The following morning we visited angkor wat for sunrise in tuk tuk also with our guide.This itinerary was perfect as we had a huge variation of experiences and avoided temple burn out.Biggest tip is to get a guide. His expertise added enormously to our experience and ensured we visited at times which avoided major crowds. He also helped find the best spots for photos.Also having an air conditioned van for the full day including Banteay srei really helped recharge everyone on very hot April day.

Dawn delight. The dawn visit was the best time to visit before it got too hot. Good catering at the nearby food stalls and very impressive architecture. Very cool once you get inside and worth the trip to the top for a great view.

An experience of a lifetime. If your in Siem Reap, you already know how wonderful the Temples are. Despite our expecting them to be magnificent, we were surprised by their level of magnificence! A note about how we visited the archeological site: There are a number of areas of interest, each with its unique characteristics, each one a wonderful experience. We hired a guide and a taxi (that is an air conditioned taxi) driver to spend two days with us. We found it ideal to be able to tailor the schedule to our own needs, and focus on the the parts that most interested us. Our hotel (Golden Butterfly Villa) made excellent recommendations for the guide and driver. Both worked our very well. My wife and I were especially taken with our driver, Mr. Vanna (vannabeng@gmail.com) He is a lovely, soft-spoken young man who grew up in a poor farm family. After spending few years in a monastery, he learned to read. Since then he has taught himself English and Chinese.He spoke English beautifully (better than our guide's.) Although he is very knowledgeable about Siem Reap and the temples, he has no hope of ever being able to qualify to be an official guide. He is a wonderful resource!

THE BEAUTY OF HISTORICAL STONES.. Visiting the Temples of Angkor art and love of the builders is detected.We can see completely original temples and other magnificent trees which engulf some of its parts. Definitely a complex that passionate travelers should visit sometime in their life. We already did.

Best archaeological site I have been to.. The temples are mind blowing. The detail, the intricacy, the size. Everything is amazing. Do not try to squeeze it into one day. That will not work. 3 days minimum, a week if you got it. Pace yourself. There is a lot there.

A must see, but it is exhausting. There is a lot of walking in the heat to get to fully appreciate the splendours of Angkor Watt.However if one has travelled that far to see it all then it is to be expected. Tickets have your own photo on so that no one can pass it anyone else. Makes for agood souvenir.
Always worth the trip!. This is certainly a check of my bucket list! Angkor in its grandeur, its mystifying, age-defying details is really worth a trip to Cambodia.

Amazing. Angkor is full of history and totally amazing. Angkor Wat is probably the biggest draw and is beautiful at Sunset or Sunrise which I would recommend but get there early as it is really popular. A Gondola ride on the moat around Angkor Thom is also a lovely way to finish the day.
Awe inspiring. We did sunrise there, it was incredible. We had a tour guide tell us about the history and the structures and meanings of the carvings. It was a great experience.

Amazing. All temples are just breathtaking! You will need a lot of time to be able to visit all the major temples.. You will not be able to see all of them as there are hundreds in the province and over 2000 in the whole of Cambodia.

Absolutely amazing!. Even though I had read about the Angkor temples.....nothing prepares you for the number of, or size and uniqueness of them all. Over two days we managed to experience fourteen of them with a very experienced and knowledgeable guide, which I'm sure makes a huge difference to one's understanding and enjoyment. What a fantastic and unique place to visit....highly recommend, just as good as Machu Picchu in Peru but of course quite different.

Temple Ruins. Visiting these temples was an amazing experience. The access to everything was amazing. The fact that we could walk on, sit in, look at and wander through these archaeological wonders was truly humbling. Watch out for the heat and come prepared (water, sunscreen & hats - or an umbrella for shade). Don't forget to visit the market stalls set up at each temple for great tourist shopping.

Absolutely amazing!. I've always wanted to go to Cambodia, and in particular to see the temples.What an absolute joy - the area these temples are located in spans kilometers, and the individual temples are amazing. Angkor Wat - The size of this temple blew me away - the reliefs along all four sides of the complex are incredible. I could go back and spend longer just looking at these. No two faces or creatures are the same. Incredible!Bayon - I've wanted to go here ever since I was young, and it lived up to my expectation 100%!

Ancient and awe inspiring. We hired a tuk tuk for a day and traveled around the ruins of this ancient and awe inspiring civilization. It is amazing to see how developed the culture was so so long ago - older than the ancient trees that have sprouted in the ruins. The mind boggles.

The chmer dynasty. The visit to the chmer dynasty temples is amazing and surprising. Of course, it order to visit all the places one may need weeks or even months. So, for someone like ourselves, that all they had was 3 days, it is all about impression and feeling of the greatness of the chmer empire from the ruins. During these three amazing days we had seen (among others) the strength in the many stone faces in Bayon, the tenderness and gentle carving in Bantaey Srey; the Nature fighting for its dominance in Ta Phrom and the structural completeness of the Angkor Wat city temple. But to put it all in a nutshell it is the atmosphere created by this concentration of temples that makes one to want to come back to this again/
crowded but good history. Definitely hit the larger temples during lunchtime when everyone else is eating! The day is exhausting, there are so many temples in a small area.

Amazing Tour with Amazing Tuk Tuk Tour Guide. These temples/ruins are absolutely amazing, and we have seen a lot of archaeological ruins. There is a strange peace and beauty about these that we just loved. We woudn't have had as good a time though had it not been for our wonderful tuk tuk tour driver Vantha, of angkorfriendlydriver.com. Don't miss the sunrise at Angkor Wat!
Must Do. Had a great day private tour. Amazing history and architecture. Wear sneakers as it involves a lot of walking and climbing of stairs. Take lots of water.

Truly a bucket list item!. I was wowwed by the imensity and granduer. It is several locations, Ankor Wat the temple being the best know but Angkor Thom and the other sites were awesome. We did it wit a guide (two people, $80 dollars for three hours) and I strongly suggest the same. Just the pickup/drop off convenience is worth it but the history lesson and Q&A really helps you understand the culture.

Half day temple tour. It was the hottest time of the year to be here, so half day in the morning was enough. Saw the two primary temples, loved it, but it was so hot I'm glad we did not sign up for a full day.

If you want to enjoy serenity, go as early as possible. All the temples in the Park are different and fascinating in their own way and Siem Reap has been one of my favorite destinations thanks to Angkor Archaeological Park. Just one remark: It's crowded... Really crowded. So try to start your temple visits as early as you can, possibly at 5:30 am when the park opens. That way you can enjoy sunrise lights reflecting on the wall of temples and calm & quiet atmosphere. Then you can go back to your hotel for a nap at mid- day when it gets really hot (it was 40 degrees in April).
TOTALY awesome. It was hard going as I'm not young any more but so worth doing. the history is amazing and the work they have done to restore the temples is great.
As Time was and Is.. Amazing tour provided by Vespa tours, read feed back provided at Vespa Tours, we had a magical, majestic tour and will go back again and again.
Yeah, it's that good. Big, good pedestrian flow of us tourists. Hawkers not in the actual temple. Generally we were a well behaved, respectful bunch that allowed a great experience.

A must see. Angor Wat is a must see, but start @ 5 a.m. It's a happening. It is a spectacular setting, especially at sunrise.
Amazing that such a structure was built for prayers only, but it is a different culture than North Americans are used to. That's part of the education of travel.
Seeing history up close. The ruins were very interesting. You can vision how it must have been. It is quite big with a lot to see.

Very Interesting. It was all you would imagine. Amazing site, well cared for, definitely worth the trip. Not too many vendors. Lots of steps so visits by the mobility-impaired will be challenging. Grounds are large so crowds are not a problem.

A Tour Not to be Missed while in Siem Reap. This archaeological park consist of a numbers of temples / wats / ruins to be covered over a period of time which you can decide upon yourself according to the number of days you are in Siem Reap. Normally it's a day tour from morning till evening. This tour is published in travel brochure as the Inner Circle Tour or the Smaller tour. The main places covered will consist of the Angkor Wat, The Angkor Thom/Bayon, Ta Prohm and surrounding smaller temples.There are many options to do this tour. Cheapest will be by rented bicycle without tour guide. That means you rent the bicycle for the whole day and explore on your own. It is safe but you may be clueless of where to go but you have all the time in the world. Next will be by chartered tuk tuk. The tuk tuk driver will bring you to all the places mentioned and could also give you some basic info. Cold wet tissues and mineral waters are also provided. If you want comfort, rent an airconditioned car, SUV or MPV according to the number of people in your group. Almost all drivers speaks English and will also provide you with much needed info. Wet towels and cold mineral waters are provided after every stops. You determine the length of your stay at each stop. If you have a company of four with senior members and children and you want some comfort, this mode is highly recommended. The most expensive mode will be guided bicycle tour. It is charged individually. A guide will cycle along with you throughout the 8 hours' 28 kilometers journey. You will be guided along some very challenging routes. Be prepared for a sore buttock at the end of the days. Drinks and fresh fruits are provided at stops. Lunch is also included in this package. Therefore although slightly expensive than other modes of transportation, it is well worth the dollars.

A must see - but soon. This is one of the cultural wonders of the world and we were delighted to visit it and explore. But we were not prepared for the vast number of visitors we encountered. Our visit for our second day started at 8am and already the ticket plaza was awash with coaches and taxis and a seething mass of tourists. Our visit to Ta Promh was just like exiting Wembley Stadium at the end of the Cup Final.The authorities are predicting a threefold increase in visitor numbers by 2020 - the prospect is horrendous. They are obviously happy with the tourist numbers now and in the predicted future, but if they do not do something about the organisation and infrastructure this wonderful site will be overwhelmed.If you are thinking of going - DO IT NOW!!

Most jaw-dropping place on earth. My initial love with this place came when I saw it on the first Tomb Raider movie, but it is absolutely breathtaking to see yourself. A trip to Cambodia is not complete without a visit to this park.

Spectacular!. We have been wanting to visit this mystical place for so many years. Finally getting the opportunity, we were in awe, every temple even more incredible than the last. We only had 3 days and only got to see about half because it's a lot larger than expected and one can only fit so much info one day. A day of rest would be a good idea if possible, with temple exploration on either side. Going early or late in the afternoon helps to avoid the crowds.

Exploring the Angkor Archaeological Park. The temples are amazing, such an incredible experience to visit. Angkor Wat is just impressive, such a big place. We visited the two other main ones right on sunset and this was also amazing.
Early morning. Good view in the morning when the sun comes up, we were on a tour holiday, so the tour was arranged for an early arrival

A miracle. I spent there three days and it was not enough. I met there two sunrises and it was not enough. The story says it was built between 12 and 14 centuries but i guess it is older and not discovered enough. I have no idea how did they build it. Strongly recommended place!
breathtaking. Gotta try the Elephant Tours! I recommend you make reservations for this or arrive early (tickets go on sale 7:30am) to make sure you get a spot. They get fully booked pretty fast.
breathtaking!. I love everything Siem Reap offer to tourist ...even tuktuk drivers are friendly...I dislike freaking hot weather.

Amazing!. As what i've said in my other reviews, you can hire a tuktuk driver for $20 and drive you to all the temples near Angkor Wat like this Angkor Archaeological Park. You can definitely see how amazing these temples were built and how earth became directly connected to it. But please don't forget your water and an umbrella or even a sunglasses because it will definitely be HOT. Also, wear a rubbershoes cause we saw some tourists who wore sandals or something that is really not comfortable.

Breathtaking!. The Angkor ruins are a must-see in your life if you are interested in old civilizations. They are fascinating - so fascinating and truly awesome - that lots of people want to visit. So, we tended to report for tourist duty in the park before 6 AM so we could get ahead of the crowds and wander quietly in the cool of the early morning. The experience was better than I dreamed it would be and I'm so glad that we visited even if the arrangements are a bit challenging because of the location. Wow!
unbelievable. nothing to dislike! What an experience! The history, the archaeology, the engineering, and the majesty of it all.
Biggest Temple Complex in the World. Incredible temple sites all over Angkor. Not just Angkor Wat, but Angkor Thom and the smaller sites in the area as well.

Exhausting. I had understood theoretically but not practically before this holiday just how huge an area Angkor covers in terms of places to visit. It is overwhelming especially in the heat we experienced.Our guide took us the Angkor Wat itself after lunch in the hottest part of the day & in full sunshine - madness. I had to give up & sit in the shade which felt dreadful as it was supposed to be the highlight. Most of my companions looked utterly exhausted to the point of illness when they rejoined me & indeed some were quite poorly later. We had a 3 day ticket & I suggest, unless made of sterner stuff than I am, that you spread your visits out choosing early morning & late afternoon. A return trip by tuc-tuc costs next to nothing for the distances involved & you will get much more out of your visits.We went back to Angkor Wat on our third day taking a tuc-tuc from out hotel at 7:00 am & entering from the EAST gate. This was a quiet, wooded approach with monkeys to enjoy & the temple emerging slowly from trees - magical. We exited from the west as the crowds arrived, had a leisurely coffee & our driver picked us up as arranged. One of the best experiences we had this holiday.

Breathtaking but very hot. A magnificent site. We were amazed by the scale and detail at each temple and also by the sheer number of temples. Highlights were Angkor Wat, Angkor Tom (inc The Bayon) and Ta Phrom (the famous overgrown one)

One of the wonders of the world. Our group got here early for the sunrise which didn't really turn out. There are many temple and you can spend days here exploring. It is fascinating to say the least. It would be helpful to have a guide that knows the history and speaks good English!

One amazing day. This was the highlight of all of our trips. My husband really wasn't interested, but after our one month in Asia, he said this was the number one experience.We spent a day here. Got up for being at angkor at 5am (up at 430). We learnt that our tuk tuk overcharged us at $25, but given there were 4 of us, we didn't feel that bad (I recall it being $14 if booked through the hotel). Our driver didn't really tell us much about the ruins, but he brought us a lot of water!We spent only one day, and we did get our full of walking to all the ruins. Some people say min. Of three days, but since we are not the meditative type of history buffs, one day was spectacular! Our tips:- have lots of water on hand! - make sure to bring a sarong or have pants that cover past your knees. This is required for only one of the temples- watch out for the monks! They'll try to act like you need to go a certain way and then hassle you for money. There are lots in there doing different things, or even students asking you for money as you go through- waking up early was worth it. Even just for the fact that you're not in the scorching heat- I would recommend having a tour guide or some history. We were all a little bummed that we didn't know the meaning of different buildings and such. We tried to listen in to other groups!- wear comfortable shoes! We did all the walking in flip flops, but some people who aren't as comfortable may want to wear sturdier shoes or sandals- really high stairs - great bum work out!We saw lots of people bike riding, so we can understand how you could make a multi day experience. But on an 8 hour day, we got our full and didn't feel too rushed or that we missed certain temples. We were a group of 4 30 year olds, not in the fittest shape - but we did it!

Amazing site, hundreds of marvelous sculptures. Angkor is not only tha Wat ( Temple ), it encompasses hundreds of sites, some big, some small, almost ALL of beautiful architecture, and more than a thousand years of history.
You can't miss it, one of the greatest historical sites of the planet.

3-day pass a good bet. My mom and I bought the 3-day pass for $40 per person which was valid for 7 days. It was very good value because it was more than enough to visit all the major temples plus a few smaller or farther ones without feeling rushed. We also had the leisure of going for half-day tours then retreating by lunchtime to take a nap at our hotel during the hottest hours of the day.On our last day, we went to Banteay Srey which was a bit further afield, but is highly recommended because of the intricate inscriptions of the temple. We also had a chance to visit the Landmine Museum on our way back.

Temples of Angkar. Lovely three days of touring beautiful ancient temples. We were able to get some fantastic photos and although it was blistering hot we had a great time and a super guide. Just wish there wasn't as many mainland Chinese touring at the same time, very crowded and sometimes they were obnoxious

fantastic. we got the best out of our visit by using local guides, we booked happy angkor wat who are friendly, knowledgeable and great with the small children. they know the best places to take you when it is quiet, at each stop they provided cold towels and drinks and toured at our pace, we never felt hurried and nothing was too much trouble
Great on a bike!. Consider a bike tour. Cambodian Cycling is a excellent choice and maybe do more than a one day tour.

It is really one of the wonders of the world.. The ruins need to be seen with the help of a guide, they are awe inspiring and having a guide to explain the historical context is amazing. We had no choice but to go at the end of the day which ended up being good as the park emptied out a lot in the last hour of opening. There is much to take in here and the scale of the ruins breath taking. I thought that this the most impressive archaelogical site we have seen including those elsewhere in Asia, in Europe, Central, North or South America.

Pace Yourself.. Don't try to do 100 temples a day. Try 1-2 per day. That's more than enough. Don't go to Ta Phrom for the 'Tomb Raider' tour, appreciate and respect the temple. Try the smaller, obscure temples.

Encore Angkor... give me more!. Immerse yourself into the finest (Cambodian) Khmer culture, the largest religious monument in the world! As the best-preserved temple at the site, it is the only one to have remained a significant religious center since its foundation. Angkor Wat lies 5.5 kilometres (3.4 mi) north of the modern town of Siem Reap. You can easily reach it in a short drive. You should definitely buy a 3-day-pass to visit as many temples as you can within this magnificent Complex, UNESCO World Heritage Site, established in 1992. Try to either do a sunrise or sunset specifically on Angkor Wat, which is a great experience (even though very crowded with tourists). It has become a symbol of Cambodia due to its popularity and beauty, appearing on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors. A MUST SEE!

Great temples - rip off cafes. The temples were awesome but the food available was an outrageous tourist rip off. The dirty cafe complex in the middle of angkor thom near the elephant terrace sells food at 5 star prices and serves street cafe food. No choice all the cafe have h same menu with the same over inllated prices.
Must See!. Spent 3 days and toured 12 temples...loved them all. Remarkable and well worth inclusion on everyone's bucket list.

Incredible!. Such an amazing experience. Seeing Angkor Wat at sunrise was so beautiful, and exploring all of the various temples, especially those off the beaten track down the dirt roads, was like stepping back in time. It makes you feel like Indiana Jones (or like Tomb Raider which all the locals like to reference).

Magical. After reading many many of fellow travellers reviews, yes yes yes i agree with it all but i cant put into words the feeling of seeing these temples first hand so i will just say one word.
BREATHTAKING!

Great to do on a bike. Theres a lot of ground to cover here, so definitely pick out a few key temples you want to see. Spending a whole day here can be kind of exhausting but if you've only got a day (or only want to buy a day pass) then you should try to squeeze in a lot! Angkor Wat is the best early in the morning for the sunrise (although you'll be sharing that view with tons of other people) but its also good at sunset. Bayon is famously covered in faces and its worthwhile. There are other smaller temples that arent as popular and are good places to go and wander around. Having a guide is nice, especially since most of the guides are wonderfully knowledgable and have an endless supply of stories for you- but this can get kind of exhausting in a day. Still worth it though if you've only got a day and are trying to soak up as much info as possible. Theres places to eat inside the part was well.

Trasures in the Cambodian jungle. The Angkor Archaeological Park is a world heritage site. It's a beautiful and powerful reminder of the Khmer empire at its height, as well as how all empires come and go. Visit the excellent national museum in Siem Reap before exploring the park to get a sense of the history represented by the temples. March/April are very hot months to visit. Entrance fees to the park are well worth the price.
Angkor Wat at Sunrise. Another check off my bucket list seeing the sunrise over Angkor Wat! Beautiful setting for a magical adventure

Amazing Angkor Archaeological Park. This park is worth the price of admission and then some ($20 USD for one day). The temples are well maintained/restored. The play of light and shadow is magical. Truly one of the wonders of the ancient world. Visit the national museum in Siem Reap before you go to any of the temples so as to gain a sense of the history and context of the temple complex. It's very hot in April so pace yourself if you go then.

Tranquility in the jungle. The whole archaeological park is a UNESCO World Heritage site, and deservedly so. Dozens of temples to visit, though the popular ones can get a bit crowded. The ticket system is impressive, and efficient, and remarkably good value, particularly for a long visit.
It's amazing!. The art and architect are amazing! This is a real hard work! Super professional! We can't believe this if we don't see it.

Huge, busy but well worth a few days. It is slightly weird knowing that everywhere you go once you arrive in Siem Reap was once a huge city. The whole thing is massive, so plan your visit & make sure you can see all the temples you want to see. Hiring a car & local guide is probably the best way to do it & stay cool, whilst making the most of the guide's knowledge of the history. It can be a bit overwhelming as you can't possibly see everything, so concentrate on seeing your priorities. Restoration is constant, with multi national groups working to restore/repair/protect as much as possible - but the scale of the site is so huge it must be a daunting (& expensive) task. The cost of your pass will go towards this work. Using the local registered guides will get you through the visitors centre/pass process much faster than without. Don't worry about taking a photo with you for the pass - they will take one there & then & instantly transfer it on to your pass.An amazing place.

It's all true. Just an amazing place, and so many things to see. I don't think I can add much that others haven't already, except for one bit:Our guide, Kear, was awesome. Super-friendly, smart, and had fun with us... I would recommend him to anyone who is eager and interested in the people and the culture. I'm really glad to see that others have name-checked him on TripAdvisor as well. He deservers it. His email: kear0204@yahoo.com

Awesome. Angkor was an incredible experience , perhaps too hot ( in March ) , but the play of light and shadow to the photos were really exceptional .
I take tuk tuk for 3 days , it was amazing , I have no other words .
Breathtaking. This should be close to the top of everyone's bucket list. To think that these people could create such a masterpiece in the dense forest. Reminds me of the work of the Romans.

Amazing Sights, But Can Get Tiring, Go Prepared. There is no doubt this has to be one of the highlights to any trip to Cambodia. The entrance fee is quite high by Cambodian standards, but then again, Cambodians aren't their target market. A one day pass is $ 20 and a Three Day Pass, which is valid for a week, is $ 40. It is best to have a tuk tuk booked for all day and depending on how good you are at bargaining, the prices range from $ 12 to $ 15 for the full day, worth every cent/penny/riel. The whole site is massive and when you have finished you will be well and truly 'Wat'ted out. Go prepared, the heat can be intense and the humidity is high this time of year. Take a hat to cover your forehead and neck and good SPF sunscreen. Drink plenty of water, I drank 6 litres during a full day at this site. You may also want to pack a change of clothes and leave them with your tuk tuk driver as you will sweat profusely in the afternoon heat. The sights are amazing and you will be taking 'photos from arriving to leaving. A Magnificent complex to visit and a must see for any tourist to Cambodia.

You better go see it. If you're traveling through Cambodia, this is probably already close to the top of your list of things to see, but if it's not then you should change that right away. I would recommend getting a copy of Ancient Angkor from one of the people selling them you'll encounter on your way around to the various temples. You can get them for a few dollars. It really is helpful to know what your looking at and enriches the whole experience, which is nice because if you're not familiar with the archaeological aspects of the area the temples can start to blend together after a while. I'd also recommend getting the 3 day pass as there really is so much to see here that you could easily fill the time and still not see everything. Hiring a tuk tuk is probably the easiest way to get around the park and isn't very expensive. We got one for 12 dollars for the whole day. We did also spend a day going around on bicycle which was also really enjoyable, though also pretty tiring. Going early for the sunrise over Angkor Wat was very cool, but it gets pretty crowded so get there early if you want a good seat. My only complaint was that to get to the very top of the temple in Angkor Wat you needed to be wearing a sleeved shirt and they wouldn't let you simply wrap a sarong around your shoulders to cover up, which caused a little frustration for our group since that had been acceptable at many other temples we had visited. Though we just did a little shirt swapping and took turns going in. But keep the dress code in mind to save yourself some trouble.

Go early chose lesser temples and monuments. Hordes of tour groups after 8 a.m. Best temple Ta Prohm- before 8 a.m. Angkor Wat like Central Station at 5.30 am from the west gate- enter through the east gate. find the less traveled options. We went for a walk on Angkor Thom's wall between two gates- not a person around just bees and birds. Heaven!

Bigger and Better then you can imagine. I traveled alone with 2 small boys to Cambodia. They read a little about the history, carvings and meanings of the different temples and as much as we looked at photos we were still amazed at the sheer size of this Park and the size of the temple complex. You need several days to really see everything, and lots and lots of water. My kids had certain carvings and places they wanted to see but if you are unsure what you are seeing, get a guide. Knowing the history and meaning of the carvings enhances your experience and you will leave with the feeling you left a temple and not just a site. There are local villagers living in the complex, their homes built along side the ruins. It is an amazing experience.The 3 day pass is good for 3 days within a week,..they do not have to be consecutive as long as they are within that week. Kids under 12 are free but bring your passport to prove their ages. We broke up our week with a market and village tour with Bees Unlimited - great choice if you have kids so they don't get templed-out. There is great food to eat within the complex and drinks for sale everywhere. We ate lunch near the elephant temple at Vendor 38. Each stall is owned by different local families. Vendor 38 was delicious, and had a large choice.The temples are spread out, lots of ruins to climb over and lots of stair cases. This is not a wheelchair accessible place and if you are having trouble walking,go after you are better. If you cannot walk around easily you will be limited to the outer areas.If you go in March or April it is very hot and if you have kids, they will last longer if you can break up your day in a cool place. We left in the mornings and went back to the hotel to cool off in the pool around 1230 - then headed out again after 330. They temples close around 530 -6 but and hour or 2 is enough for the smaller temples.USD are ok just about everywhere, bring lots of 1$ bills many places don't have change for bigger bills. We were surprised to see some people drinking beer and trying to smoke - the temple security stopped them when they could. It is important to remember that this is a holy site, not a picnic ground. It would be the same as someone cracking open a beer and lighting up in the middle of the vatican.
Temples Galore. We hired our taxi driver and a guide who took us where we wanted to go, when we wanted to go around this amazing once in a lifetime trip.

Awe inspiring. I was amazed by the size of the park and the amount of temples. Very well maintained and managed. A bit pricey to enter but well worth it. Rent a tuk-tuk for the day. Where comfortable shoes as you walk and climb a lot. Also take a sun hat and sun block as it gets very hot. As with all tourist attractions, expect some touting and souvenir sellers.

Wonder of the world. Purchase a 3 day pass (it lasts for a week) you dont require a passport photo, they take your photo there and then. Have cash ready for purchase as it gets busy. - first time go during the day like after 9am, do a tour with tuk tuk to experience the main temples (Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom & Ta Prohm) - then 2nd day use pass another day for other temples or as part of a Flight of the Gibbon experience or southern temple in Quad bike tours etc.... 3rd day use go for a sunrise (now you already have your pass so no waiting in giant lines with other sunrise tourists & you can suss out best spot for photos)... now this is roughly 6am (aim to get there for 5:30 to get a good spot), when we went there wasn't any amazing sunrise, but at about 7am a gorgeous red sun rised over the top of Angkor wat (beautiful photos especially reflected in the water) yet all the sunrise photographers were long gone. So if sunrise is not impressive then wander the temple and keep an eye out! Also be careful in morning crossing bridge into Angkor Wat as there is no railing and its pitch black, take torch or use phone light. Dress respectably, it is a temple - tshirt and capris or loose pants (they sell these all over the markets so there is no excuse) and they do have dress code for climbing the temple so you wont want to miss out. Lives up to all expectations as a wonder of the world, must do if visiting Siem Reap.

A magical expirience. Although frequented by many tourists, you still can get a sense of all the splendour of the Khmer empire. You can't stop wondering how people were capable of building these structures almost a thousand years ago, at a time that Europe was slowly emerging from the dark ages. Try to visit the temples at a quiet moment ( in the low season, or very early, or even around noon ).

all that you want. the best was the Little tiny temple Ta Nei, nearly mentionned in no travvelres giude, you can only go there with Tuk Tuk or bicycle, so no mass tourisme. There I found mystik of a lost temple in the djungle

Truly remarkable ... a must adventure. We absolutely loved this place with so much to see and discover. We sadly picked wrong with the tour operator - Siem Reap Shuttle Tour - there was eight in our group to start and by the end of the only my husband and I remained. It started off well with a very enthusiastic guide particularly about his own life! After we refused to buy the very expensive over priced lunch on offer it all went dramatically down hill. The guide practically ignored us...he would drop us off at a site and say when and where to be back...no information about all the amazing historical sights. We have since watched many programmes about Angkor Wat and feel very aggrieved that we paid good money for nothing more than a rip taxi service. TOP TIP use a much cheaper took took company tour and watch the many utube programmes available before going. Wear comfortable footwear, cool clothing with sun shield umbrella and make sure you have knee covering trousers or skirt as sarongs are strictly NOT accepted. Shoulder covered too with blouse, t shirt again scarf or wrap not admitted to the sacred temple areas. You will not be disappointed with this magical wonder.
Hot and Humid as Hell. Superb site - it truly deserves it's reputation as one of the archaeological wonders of the world but it is too crowded (and this was not even peak season)
Wonderful by bike. Wonderful place!!! By bike even more and not that hard even if it depends on personal condition! One of the best place in n the world

Childhood dream. Always wanted to visit Angkor since I was a child and it did not disappoint amazing temples... Be aware it takes days to see these temples. There are so many to see and all of them are unique so allow enough time, I would allowA bare minimum of three days,

Finally!. i have been waiting to visit here for years so this was the culmination of a dream. All very fascinating,but of course the downside is the hordes of tourists there, so you just have to fight your way through them to get to see what you want to see. I really do not like all the hawkers and traders just outside the main temple, why cant they be kept outside the complex?
Literally awesome. The main and only reason to visit Siem Reap, this is a wonderful collection of monuments to a past and glorious civilization.

Go early to fully appreciate this historical treasure. Stunning!!. Early bird catches the worm and that is certainly the case for Sunrise at Angkor Wat. Get up at 5am and head to the temples to see the Angkor Wat in its true beauty as the sun rises behind it. The majority of tour groups arrive around 8am so you get to walk around the temples without the masses, plus it gets VERY hot at the day's peak.BEST VIEWPOINT - Do NOT follow the crowds down the middle. HEAD TO YOUR LEFT HAND SIDE. Here you will be able to see the sun rising from behind and capture the reflection in the water which is in front of you. Another thing to note.... When it gets light, quite a lot of people will leave thinking that is it. They are wrong! DO NOT LEAVE BECAUSE IT IS LIGHT, WAIT FOR THE SUN TO ACTUALLY RISE, trust me it will and be worth the wait. Get lost wondering around the mesmerising temples to which they are NOT all the same. There are so many ways to go from temple to temple.... Walk, cycle, drive, Tuk Tuk, guided tour and more. They offer one day, three days and week entry tickets. I hired a Tuk Tuk for the day who took me around the 'big and small circuit' for $20-25 and was worth it. This was great for me as I got to spend however long I wanted without being rushed by other people. If you plan on doing it this way, buy a guide book to learn more about each temple as the Tuk Tuk driver's knowledge was limited. Wear comfortable footwear to walk around and climb stairs all day, would recommend against flip flops. Also remember to wear or bring something to cover your knees and shoulders out of respect. Charge your camera battery and bring a spare.
Amazing even with the crowds. Beautiful site. I recommend taking a one day cycling tour with Cambodian Cycling to see the site in a different way.

Have a Good Guide. Visiting the Archaeological Park, which is huge, requires a well versed guide and pre-arranged transportation. Fortunately, we had one. The only negative, but one that comes with some understanding, are the droves of children begging. Some are very young and the experience is heart wrenching.

A magical huge place. Something everyone should experience in their lifetime. We all hear about Angkot Wat a lot, but once you get there and see the magnitude of the archaeological park ....The Khmer culture in the 10-11-12th century was just unbelievably evolved. A city of 1 million when Europe was still in the dark ages, London had 50.000 citizens! Imagine that.Angkor Wat is nice, but my favourite temples were Ta Prohm (Jungle Temple), Bayon and Banteay Srey (amazing carvings).
FAN-TASTIC. This is one of the most beautiful places you'll ever visit... Especially the "Tomb Raider" temple is the most stunning work you'll ever see. A great complex, you'll need a day or two.
Outstanding!. It is absolutely amazing.Make sure to book a guide and go very early in the morning - from noon on the temperatures are so high it is practically unbearable.

Historical treasure. This site was remarkable in its history and setting. Having a guide who could provide background was key! Visiting later in the day helped us avoid the heat of mid-day and enjoy the late afternoon sun's play on the stones.
Angkor Wat. we like all.. we never see something like that.We recomend to all nour portuguese friends visit Angkor

Bring shoes. Where to start.this place is huge so bring comfortable shoes and a guide. There are many temples. Some arnt even on the map. Some are more touristy and some are not. You really need 2-3 days to soak it all in. I spent 7 hours just walking round looking at the spectacular contructions. A must see in siem reap

Amazing. Absolutely nothing to dislike, loved all of it. Amazing to see something so old, with so much history spread over such a huge space. The boys loved history and absorbed so much more than they ever did at school! It was awesome.
what a view!. Amazing place, an experience I will never forget, saw sunrise over Ancor Watt, climbed to the top & learnt some of the history of the spiritual place.
This is what you came for. Guess this is the reason you came to Siem Reap - fantastic - one of the great places to visit in the world - what more can you want?
Angkor Wat. Sunrise time is good for photography and less hot. Too many hawkers who followed you arounnd wanting a sale. LOts of steps to climb, but interesting architecture.
Amazing. Amazing and beautiful temples of which Angkor Wat is the best known, but others are as beautiful and interesting. Dawn at Angkor Wat is great if conditions are right.

sunrise. A bucket list must. there are a lot of people who get up early to watch the sunrise.....definitely worth it especially if you are a keen photographer. Rany our tour guide knew the best spots to get that magical moment

Angkor Splendor. My second visit to Angkor, my first to see the sunrise. This is a magnificent and awe-inspiring site, worth the 4 am wakeup call. My favorite temple remains Ta Prohm, the Jungle Temple. Such a juxtaposition of nature and the best accomplishments of humans.

Amazing experience. Many temples in the complex.. This is a World heritage Site. Wonderful experience in ancient History, Architecture, Art and current social culture. The park is extensive. You need to walk , climb steps and be able to tolerate the heat. There are small local restaurants and shops through out the park. I would suggest a local tour company to assist you from your hotel the first day. Passes can be purchased for 1-7 days, $20-$60, they do not need to be consecutive. If you find your interested in temples not on the tour ,you can easily hire a driver with a car approx. $45 or a TukTuk $10-$20 .Tour guides are available for hire at each site from $2 -$15 . Very safe area to travel in. Go early in the morning for sunrise, its awesome,and cooler , rest for lunch and shopping, start back later afternoon for the sunset. Very affordable .

visit to angkor itself was a bit dissapointed,weather wise and crowd that spoilt it but still enjoyable could be better. got to angkor in the afternoon and was hot and very crowded,couldnt got to the top, the crowd is so intense and the heath but still walk around exploring but really enjoy lot more temples beside angkor,bayon and beng maelea was the highlight for me.

You have to see this before you die!!!. You have to see this before you die!!! Please go there between December-November or other months that are not a summer season, because it very hot! Rainy season isn't recommended either, due to the road/street that mostly a soil and it is probably hard to travel.

Fascinating Site!. Ta Phrom is utterly unique in comparison to other temples in Siem Reap. Putting aside the fact it was made popular by the movie, it is a site to be behold. There are parts of the temples that were destroyed by the trees and it adds much to the character. It's an 'AWE' effect, just observing the beautiful and humongous trees are really awesome. It is a must visit in Siem Reap!
what an amazing trip. Perfect view to learn about the temple and very breathtaking view. The weather is very HOT!!! but still love it

Very Interesting. Seeing Angkor Wat was just awesome. We went through March which was a bit hot, but as long as you keep the water supply up is no problem. Make sure you have a guide to explain it all to you, cost a little extra but well worth it.

Magnificent temples!. Magnificent temples to explore. Spend at least 3 full days to explore the park. A three-days temple pass is US$ 40, a value for money. Have a great exploration in Angkor Archaeological Park!

A must see. There was three temples we went to see it was not what I expected I knew it was large but you would need a car and driver or a tuk tuk there is no way you would walk from temple to temple bring plenty of water

AMAZING!!!!! What else can one say.. Took my son to Siem Reap, Cambodia for his first overseas trip. The heritage and atmosphere was amazing. To walk through the ruins is to be transported back in time. Two things to take care with though for any traveller, 1. Police officers will try and sell you badges off their uniforms, I have been told that this is a scam (we said no' and kept walking.2. Locals will offer to give you a 'guided tour' we accepted one as he was honest with us up front and VERY knowledgeable and asked for money at the end if we were happy to do so, others ill follow you and demand money, keep walking and ignore them they will get the message and go away.Overall loved it and cannot wait to go back.

Make sure you have a younger guide les political!. Sometimes the guides give you too much information rather than let you enjoy and feel the moment. Very crowded at certain times don't follow the usual route and it is better and less stressfull. Don get behind the Chinese tours as they tend to be big groups and noisy,

Absolutely stunning. Hired a tuk tuk for the day and the driver took us to the temples and waited for you to take you to the next one. Ensure you have comfortable footwear and plenty water. There is so much to see and it can involve a lot of climbing and walking to get the full picture of the vastness of the temples. There are also lots of stalls all selling the same things but very useful for drinks which are definitely needed. We had the same tuk tuk driver for 2 days who was happy to advise on the best way to get around the temples so that you get the best out of your day. Entrance fee is $20 or you can buy a 3 day pass for $40. Tuk Tuk is $15 per day. Well worth the money.
Trees are fantastic!. This is a great place and you must visit. The trees look like they're taking over and you know that it takes a long time for them to grow like that it just seems surreal.

Great structures. The park is undoubtedly beautiful with some temples more unique and beautiful than others. There has been efforts to refurbish the place. I saw notices that Japan, India and China have contributed to these efforts. Worth a visit.

Angkor Wat is definitely worth the trip and should be on your "bucket list". The temples built in the 12th century are all amazing. Beautiful Bass releifs with detailed features and at the same time a very grand temple complex

Better in real life. I feared the many photographs and documentaries I'd watched would prove to make the actual place a let down. Not a chance. Thoroughly interesting and so much to explore, with knowledgeable and multilingual guides. Timing is everything at the main temples, and there are so many lesser temples that you can have a quiet moment to sense the spiritual essence of the complex or imagine your are exploring anew.

It was moving. It can be hot during the day so go before dawn the sunrise is worth it. We entered via the east gate not as busy and a nice walk into the area. Crowds are an issue. We went back for sunset the same day spectacular. The grounds and riuns are very interesting and our guide knew his stuff.

A SIMPLY AMAZING COLLECTION OF TEMPLES. Its big - really big. We took 3 days to explore just a few temples because they deserve the investment in time and they reward your effort with stunning features. You need comfortable walking shoes, plenty of water, a small towel would be sensibe as its hot and humid. We visaited in the dry season with temperatures around 37C but fewer visitors. There are crowds but only a little congestion at pinch points and stairs. We used a guide for the first visit. Its not cheap and ours bombarded us with information (our fault) we said we wanted lots of detail but it provided a good background for later visits. Decide for yourself what you want to see as they tend to plan for a second tour. If you have a good Tuk Tuk driver he will give you advice after your first visit and take you to the places the guide missed. How much you see depends on your age, resilience and interest in the history. Don't feel ashamed to admit Wat fatigue because although each temple has unique features you need to balance interest against fatigue.Try to visit Angkor Wat after lunch when the sun will be behind you and you will get better photographs. We did the sunrise because we had the time but in the dry season there is not much water at the front for the classic reflection shot.
Angkor Wat. Enjoyable tour of Anggor Wat with Mr Arun our knowledgable guide from Insider Tours. Knew all the spots to go to at the right time to avoid some of the crowds

Amazing and diverse temples galore - historical grandeur, beautiful carvings, atmospheric and much more. Angkor Wat is the most famous of the local sites and is said to be one of the wonders of the modern world. It is amazing and a must see. The largest complex is Angkor Thom. Ta Prohm (of Lara Croft tomb raider fame) is probably the most atmospheric. Banteay Srei has the most beautiful carvings. There are so many more.You can get 1 day pass for USD 20; 3 days for USD40 or 7 days for USD. Almost all the temples are readily accessible by Tuk and there are good toilet facilities in the park. Take plenty of water and sensible walking shoes. Shoulders and legs should be covered or you might not be allowed entry to the temples. The main sites can get busy and noisy with tourists which can spoil the experience and photos but with a bit of patience you will find a quite space. Hire a guide to ensure you get the best out of the history and design – you can’t possibly get this from a guidebook.
Awed. I suppose most people come here for the temples but i was on business and was taken here. I am so glad. On my next visit i will opt for a 3 day pass.Amazing is an understatement

This is where you came for!. The stunning temples and ancient atmosphere is what you came to Cambodia for. Although sunrise/sunset feels like a visit to Disney World in a holiday weekend, it's a lot more quiet to visit temples during daytime. It's so big and all tourist are spread, so you can manage to take pictures without other people standing in the way. A tuktuk is the best way of transport in and arround the park.

Nothing like it!!!!. This is an absolutely brilliant place to spend a few days- there is nothing like it- I suggest sunrise Angkor Wat- it is thrilling!!!!I also recommend a few days in Siem Reap- there is so much to take in and absorb!!! There is nothing in the world like this siteEnjoy!!!

Many many historical places to see. Plenty of things to see of ancient historical places. So many sites it takes many hours to completely seeing all. Be prepared as the climate is very hot and humid. always wear a cap or hat.

EXTRAORDINARY!. a privilege and an honor to visit this remnant of ancient civilization. It was annoying to be badgered by people selling their wares. Although interested in what was for sale, the pressure and persistence was too much.

Adventurous unlimited. The 3 days pass is 40 USD and child below 12 years are free. The pass includes all the important temples except Beng Mealea where the entry fee is 5$ per person. The temples can be visited in 2 to 3 days time including far away temples like Banteay Srei (Citadel of the women) and Banteay Samre, Beng Mealea (5$), Batung Temple. One day could be for the small circuit, 2nd day could be for the grand circuit and the third day for outskirts temple. There are Angkor personal in front of every temple to check you tickets so be very careful not to lose your tickets. There are plenty of small restaurants, souvenir shops and toilets to ensure that you have a comfortable visit. The food inside the park is very expensive including water/ coconut water/ beer etc as the same is transported into the park from Sieam Reap. The best temples to visit are Angkor Wat, Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Preah Khan where a local guide is recommended. You may negotiate with a local guide @ 10 USD for each temple if available. You save time and get to see relevant places inside the temple which you may miss out if visiting without a guide.

As great as I had anticipated. One of the wonders of the world. Wear good shoes as there is a lot of rough walking and climbing to get to see as much as possible. I do hope that sufficient money will be found to conserve this marvel for the future.

Sunrise at Angkor Wat. Amazing to walk through the darkness and stand with unseen crowds as the sky turned grey, the cicadas all started at once as if switched on and the red sun appeared above the towers. A once-in-a-lifetime experience.

Two days is not enough. A great experience! Yes, they charge you on everything a great deal in the temple area, but nevertheless it's worth seeing and it is one of the world's big miracles. The temples are amazing and they differ from each other temple by temple. It was quite hot in March, but still bearable. We had our hotels tuk-tuk driver taking us to the main temples. One can explore the main sites in two days, but you easily get a kind of "temple-fever" and could want to visit them all. One week should be enough.There are some restaurants within the area and your tuk-tuk driver will happily show you the places to have lunch and a short break while exploring the sites. Prices aren't cheap cambodianwise, but not too expensive, as four people can easily get their lunch and drinks for about 30$.Temples are, of course, very busy with tourists so getting your pictures without crowds is impossible.

Amazing. One of the world's treasures. A great view into an amazing historical culture. These ancient temples weren't looted by a church (like ancient rome), but by the jungle itself. A great view into Cambodia's place at the border of Hinduism and Buddhism. The park Crowded, with the occasional loud tour group, but still amazing. We found some of the smaller temples were more inspiring than the big ones. We hired a guide who was helpful, but you could figure it out with a tour book if need be.

Early Rise. If you get a chance to get up early and go BEFORE sunrise and stand in front of the temple close to the waters edge (it will be busy) you can get a brilliant photo reflection at sunrise!!!! Do not forget to go to Angkor Thom as well the fig trees in the walls are amazing, well worth a day out. If there is no haze go for the balloon ride...

It is more than what you see on the pictures. It is more than what you see on the pictures. The place itself is a total masterpiece. The $20 entrance fee is worth it (for me) as compare to other paid places or amusement parks that I visit before. I would suggest that if you are planning to visit the place, warm up your feet because you will walk a lot to visit temples. Do not forget to bring the following: umbrella, water bottle(s), face towel(s), extra shirts, a rugged slippers or sandals as these things will help a lot. In addition, do a little research before visiting places as it will give you a little history and it may also saves you money for hiring a tour guide.

That's why you come to Siem Reap. This place is breath taking. You can spend few days visiting many temples. It's worth the money you pay. You can rent a bike, car or tuk tuk to travel between temples.And don't be cheap - hire guide to show you around, tell you many interesting facts and show you good photo spots.

A Marvel. The main attraction of the park is Angkor Wat. The size, scope and beauty of this marvel creates a centerpiece for other temples and attactions found in the area. One of my favourites though is the Bong Thom homestay nestled inside the park. Being an easy 10 minutes from Angkor Wat it is perfect for lunch, afternoon snack and cold drinks after temple touring. The homestay features a variety of orchards and a fish farm. It also has a small school in the grounds for the children of local farmers to learn English - a pathway to a better job. You can also stay over if you want in traditional Cambodian style.
An absolute must see.. Visit this place once in your life. You'll be back for the country and its people. Beats anything thailand has to offer.

fabulous!. Nothing like this anywhere. It can be hard going (very hot and humid on our March visit) but worth it. Tickets come as 1, 3 or 7 day passes. Get the week if you have time. No facilities or adaptations for anyone not fully mobile.

Cambodia is super-special. Walking into history. Wow. Helpful guides. Great transport whenever needed. Helpful people but not pushy. Smiles. Knowledgeable guides and tuk tuk drivers (not common everywhere in Asia!!)

Cycling tour of Angkor complex and more of Cambodia. We experienced the beautiful, haunting and ancient temples and cities for the first time this year, via a cycling tour.- in my opinion the best way to see the real Cambodia. In the now very popular Angkor complex , we avoided the hoards by entering through the West gate to Angkor Thom first. I highly recommend using this entrance, not just for the quiet but it felt like we were stepping back. You pass through jungle and ancient stone surrounded our ride, intermingled with village life. Our whole Angkor and trip experience was enhanced by our wonderful Cambodian guide Bunwath Tes from Buffalo Tours and bike mechanic/driver Proh. Awesome guys! Bunwhatv had an intimate knowledge of the art, architecture and culture that allowed you to look past the crowds and embrace the experience as it should be . Grab a bike , a decent guide like we had and your three day pass is worth it. Don't try and go it alone, you won't get its full worth. Take time to understand the intricate carvings, symbols and meanings behind the complex. architecture and art .

Go off the beaten path!!. We got a full day ticket (which is all you need in my opinion) which allows you to go in for sunset on the night and then early morning sunrise the next day and until 5pm. I was more impressed with sunset at Angkor wat as it was less busy than sunrise.We did all the main temples but wondered around all the outskirts too and saw some smaller temples that were really quiet so don't be afraid to go off the beaten path for some nice surprises!The only problem is you do get hassled a lot to buy things there and it's hard to say no!

Great to tick this off my bucket list. Liked it all. It's hot at this time of year. This is a must see for all travellers, it's a very popular tourist spot so go early in the morning, when there are less people and its cooler.

Amazing experience. Hire a guide,wear appropriate footwear there are sooo many stairs to climb, it's a very long hot day. Bring plenty of cold drinking water. The entrance fee was $20 usd for 1day or $40usd for 2/3 daysWear appropriate clothing you won't get in to certain temples if your shoulders or knees are showing.You need to just take your time and go at your own pace to absorb everything about this amazing place in history.There's food/drinks available to buy in different parts of the park.
Time stood still. What a beautiful place. You need to let your mind go back to the glory days of Angkor. The Cambodians have much to be proud of.

Grab a pass and explore!. The Archaeological Park encompasses all the major temples best known around Siem Reap. There are different options with buying a pass, you can buy 1-3 day passes depending on how much you want to see.Even if you brought a 1-day one, you can easily fit in some amazing temples, especially Angkor Watt and Ta Prohm. Join me in my adventureshttp://www.monicawong.com/2015/03/projectmcambodia-siem-reap.html

Wow those trees. You must visit this site to see the interaction between the trees and the temples, the trees are like giant tentacles trying to smother the stone work. Again there will be children trying to sell you souvenirs you will need some $1 dollar notes thats all they ask. Sad to see there little faces.

This is what you came for. It is an awesome sight, worthy of a 5. It is not, for me. the most amazing thing I have ever seen, but still, to be around Angkor Wat at 5:30am, waiting for the sunrise, is quite special

Angkor World heritage site. The Archaeological Park encompasses all the major temples best known around Siem Reap. The site has a fee that covers all the temples on the site US$40.00 for a 3 day pass. Some of the outer temples have there own fee. You need 2 days if not 3 to see all the Major sites in this park, if you plan to take your time and have a good look. Easy to get around this park on well made and maintained roads. You will need some form of transport unless you are a real keen walker. Hire a bike, Tuk Tuk or a car and driver all well priced in Siem Reap. Plenty of food, shops and rest rooms in the Park.

Haunting.. Absolutely a must see; one of the most spectacular and haunting architectural and spiritual wonders on Earth. Be nice to the kids — get some food from the market to give them. Be friendly to local guides; at the main temple complex, pay a few dollars and use one. Basically, practice etiquette and support the locals in any way you can. And by all means visit the outlying temples. That's where the spirits still dwell.

If you plan to visit, do it sooner rather than later. It has only been 4 years since my last visit to these ancient Hindu and Buddhist temples, but the toll of the thousand-plus visitors per day is now dramatic and dire. Some I didn't recognise, like Ta Prohm for example, is undergoing huge restorations. Some may argue that the trees have done more damage, however allowing people walk and climb over these ruins I believe to be the real culprit.

Hot to watch!. An incredible achievement by the 11th and 12th century Khmer empire, millions of people must have worked on this. And that in temperatures of around 35 degrees centigrade, it is already pretty hot to only watch! We saw one or two families with small children, they did not have such a great time. Very impressive for older children though.We had a great classic private tour organised by Sam Sophea which took us to Angkor Wat, Banteay Kdei, lunch at Caco's restaurant, Ta Nei (a temple hidden in the jungle, we were the only ones to visit, this was very special), and finally the big city of Angkor Thom including the terrace of the Elephants, the Baphuon temple and as piece the resistance the Bayon, arguable the nicest to visit although Angkor Wat was most impressive. The guide first of all took us to the entrance were we paid our 20 dollar day fee.

All the superlatives are true. Just amazing site, beautifully clean. The different buildings are so varied and although people sometimes think that after seeing Angkor Wat the others will disappoint, we really loved the jungly ruins
Awesome Experience!. It is an amazing experience to see how stones are so intricately carved and the temples are so skillfully built about 1000+ years ago!

impression to Angkores. The great national park I am impressed. This is a place you need to go once in your life. It is Historical and artically combind. I went there alone but was worth acceptable.Only took took "cheat" you have to be careful. They will try to get more money in every tricks. Sure I was loosing too.
Beautiful nature and architecture as one!. This place is worth the visit no matter what the weather is like. The atmosphere and the beauty of the temple is amazing with its rich history.

Banyon trees. I love these trees....creeping along not letting anything get in their way..Here at Angkor Arch.Park they have fallen over the temple walls as if waterfalls.They make their way into every crack and crevasse. Mother nature at its finest.

So many temples!. The park is so huge and you have plenty of temples to visit. And there are also eating places and souvenir shops. Be sure to bring water and sun protection during a tour in the park. It can get tiring hopping from one temple to another... At the end of the day, it's a fun adventure.

Worth the heat!. This was my first visit to the temples of Angkor and I found the whole experience quite amazing. I did two days' worth of touring around the temples and enjoyed everything I visited. It does get hot and so take water etc and dress appropriately. I will definitely try and get back.

Come at least once in your life. Angkor Archaeological Park is huge. It will depend on the time you have available and your resilience to determine how long you spend here.It's easy for temple fatigue to set in, especially as the park is always crowded, always hot, and someone is always after money from you in some way (begging, sponsor my child so they can learn, etc).The park houses some fantastic structures and we found a day to be plenty for us. Others seem to get a three day pass and that just seemed to much overkill for us.Don't expect a romantic or serene experience unless you go out of your way to remote temples at very early times. It's always busy here because it is impressive, a true world wonder. It's a little like the pyramids in Egypt in that regard.You should come at least once in your life.

Amazing archaeological park. Well worth a visit and definitely not to be missed. You need at least 2–3 days to appreciate and visit the numerous temples and archaeological sites in the huge complex. Best to get a 2-3 day pass which costs 40USD, and you can use it any 3 days within the week. Do go with a guide who can point out a lot of things that you would otherwise miss if going on your own. Many guides would even pick up and drop off at the airport if you are short of time. If you are adventurous you could hire a bicycle or tuk-tuk, but an air-conditioned car with cold water is most welcome in the heat. The must do's are Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and Bayon, but the other smaller temples are different and fascinating in their own right. You need to be fit as there are lots of steps to climb to get amazing views of the countryside from the 3rd level in a lot of the temples. Well worth spending the time to do it properly, and try to visit Bantheay Srey which is slightly further out as the carvings are beautiful.

Not enough if 1 day visit. Really huges site ... never enough if you visit fullday here. The most ideal is 3 days.visit. per visit the charge usd 20.Rent a tuktuk of you have short time visit. If you have longer time stays better rent a bike. But prepare your self because it site is far each other. I have temple in my country but angkor is really special because its temple was carve with the story of this anchient. You wont see building of temple without carving the story of each temple in the century. The admission booth open at 6am. Better come early to avoid queeing. When you buy also with take a picture, so ensure all members are in queeing.
Amazing experience.. Unbelievable temple complex. A unique place to visit. Please be respectful as it is a temple so need to dress modestly.

Stunning. Absolutely breathtaking. Just make sure you guide speaks English or your language properly. And try to take the 3 day pass because one day is not enough to explore the splendours of Angkor !

Second Visit. It's a huge complex and I've visited most of the temples in the park itself so on my second visit, I went to the Roluos Group temples which are not in the compound but included in the Angkor pass. So remember to bring yours as staff will check before you enter the temples. I also visited Banteay Srei and was pleasantly surprise at how it is a complex on its own. You can find rows of souvenir huts, restaurants, public restroom and gallery.Angkor passes should be obtained after 4 pm one day earlier if you want to watch an extra sunset! E.g. - buy passes on Monday, get in park to see sunset on same day and have full-day visit on Tuesday.

An incredible opportunity to see and walk through history.. The historical park is absolutely incredible. There is so much to see and learn. It is strongly suggested that you have a good pair of walking shoes, hat, good sunglasses good camera and a bottle of water as the park is huge and the sun is very strong. There are plenty of excellent tour guides available who speak many languages. You should arrange the Guide through your hotel and do plenty of reading about the history of the many temples. You will need a number of days to really see and enjoy the park and understand why it is considered one of the Wonders of World

Amazing, need to regulate crowds more. Spent 3 days at Angkor, and it's completely amazing and totally impressive. Three days was a good amount of time for us, we were able to see a variety of different temples (favourites - Angkor Thom, Beng Mealea, Banteay Samre, Angkor Wat). Many of the temples seemed very crowded, which seems like it would degrade the ruins. The temples are still very enjoyable even with the crowds, though.
Once in a lifetime. It featured in the 1000 places to visit before you die and it worth its value in gold. Sunrise and sunset is a must do.Must visit

Wonderfull Park of Angkor. I came here 9 times and every time I am always so happy to be in a such wonderful place. I will come again and again I have been travelling for 40 years , the Park of Angkor is the most wonderfull place I have seen.

awesome. very interesting but this is dependent on your guide unless you are aware of the history and significance of Bhudism, very tiring in the heat and crowded as the day went on. would suggest early start and not too big a party
Must see.. Tranquelity and nature just surrounds you. After 30 minutes here you can cope with anything. Take a tuktuk round the lake, not far from there.

A journey back in time. Love the history, the view and the architecture! A tip for those going there for the first time, wear long or knee length pants and shirt that covers your shoulder to avoid disappointment of being denied entry to the temple
Nice place. Avallon Boutique & Spa is very excellent place to stay, clean room, helpful staff, nice landscape. The host is very kind.

Amazing,as expected!. We got the 3 day pass and a local guide through our travel company with car accompanied us; this was well worth it as he gave us a clear history covering the complexities of the 12th century Khmer kings and their battles, one of which is illustrated at Angkor Wat. This along with the religious narrative are illustrated on the carvings and with his guidance. We saw details of the story we would otherwise have missed.The park covers several. Other temples so the ticket for 3 or more days is worthwhile, but you MUST carry it with you as they are inspected. As with any Buddist temples wear up revealing clothes and skirts/pants covering your knees and reasonable sleeves on your tops otherwise you may be refused entry.It is also very hot and crowded, so patience is a virtue (though some people forget that!)' there are bins provided so most of the plastic rubbish ends up in them, but there always the ignorant who fail to use them.

Angkor . Angkor should be something everyone should have the pleasure of seeing just once and if you are coming give yourself time. Stay in Siem Reap for a week at most and buy the three day ticket. You will not be able to do it all in one day and while your here you might as well do it all.
Incredible. Along with some temples in Egypt, these are probably the most incredible ruins in the whole world. One must visit this park before dying. A must for pretty much everyone.
something not to miss. I was one of my dreams come true: Angkor Wat. Go there and inhale the sheer greatness of Cambodian history which at one time was home to the biggest city on this planet.

Magnificent. Angkor Wat does not disappoint, even though it's overrun by tourists. Sunrise is amazing, but the crowd opposite at dawn resembles the paparazzi stalking a sex-scandal-accused politician. Hire a professional guide to give you all the history. The better ones also know how to avoid the worst of the crowds and to help you set up good photos. Give yourself at least 2 or 3 days to take it all in.
Awesome!. Angkor Wat and the story of the four influential kings of Cambodia is a historian's dream. Truly a wonder of the world.

You gotta like falling down temples. Wat = temple. Angkor Wat = Angkor Temple. It's one of many massive temples on this massive site.Liked: I've never seen anything like it so the IMMENSE size and "differentness" of it was interesting. It's HUGE! We hired a tuk-tuk for the day and recommend it highly given the heat and humidity and dangers of riding bikes along the narrow and busy roads. $15 for the day for a chauffeur who knows where he's at and where he's going and who will keep track of you.The temple that starred in one fo the Indiana Jones or Lara Craft movies was pretty cool. That is, it was interesting to see huge trees tearing down the temples. Most of all I was amazed by the amount of work that went into excavating massive water works and into building massive temple complexes. You can't imagine how big it is by looking in a book or watching a video. You have to spend a day or more there.Not really liked: Personally the trip to see the sunrise was a waste. I'd rather have had a couple more cups of coffee and spent more time over breakfast.Hundreds of people vying for the "best place" to see the sunrise yet not knowing where it was going to come up. We see more amazing sunrises everyday from our east-facing window in Oregon as the sun rises over the Cascade Mountains so I'm jaded.An endless parade of people annoyingly trying to sell you stuff you don't want. Many probably took the sales course from some excellent trainer!Most of the ruins were pretty ruined.Most of the ruins were in some state of repair.Most of the "best" ruins were overrun with other tourists so we were pushed along often by the throngs. Too many tourists were disrespectful of the religious nature of the place and whined when guards wouldn't let them in with tank tops and short shorts and flip flops. Maybe the Vatican would, but I doubt it.It's all pretty dusty in the early part of the year.Toilets -- go before you go and don't drink water while you're there. Scarey!

Angkor Wat - One of the most amazing sights to see. We had been planning to see this site for a long time and we had the chance to visit in February. It is one of the most amazing site with temples and ruins that boggle your mind. Who had the vision to build such intricate temples with so much work and craftmanship.

The real marvel in Indochine.. After one month visiting thousands of attractions of all kinds, temples and pagodas throughout Indochina, Angkor is the real marvel of this corner of the world. Most of the other supposedly great sights are either not that great or just rebuilt in the 20th century.Walking through ancient temples in Angkor park is an amazing experience. With little effort on your side you feel transported to the 12th century, surrounded by rivers, big ponds, lush jungle eating what magnificent man built 9 centuries ago. Kings and servants and priests and people like me wandering and living their lives while sending this impressive stone built all-time human landmark to the future, for us to enjoy and admire.I enjoyed every rock I climbed, every Buddha face carved in the stone, every demon, every god, every elephant, every pool, every outer wall, every dancing figure, every tree interlaced with the structure, ..., everything. In my opinion it is comparable to Machupichu in proportions and magnificence. And Angkor Wat is the jewel.It is important to hire an official guide so you can get all the important information about the park, the history and the ultimate reason these temples were built this way.

Most amazing site ever. Other reviewers have covered the important matters of how to avoid the crowds, how to get around, and the absolute necessity to have a good guide who speaks your language.This makes the Great Wall of China look like a stone wall, and the pyramids look like a pointy heap of building blocks.What I have to say is that you have to spend the time here to feel the history, feel the spirit, feel the sweat of the labourers, slaves and elephants that built it in 38 years, with stone dragged from the distant mountains.
