Examine every corner, crevice and stone carving, and ask yourself "how, why.... did they do that?" Then buy a book about it from the pesky kids, read it, and go back again for another look. Don't just walk across the mighty causeway - climb down alongside it and look at how they built it, and how every single piece of stone was carved, or painstakingly shaped to form joints that you couldn't pass a cigarette paper through.Visit the museums in Siem Reap and Phnom Penh to find out more about what went on behind this massive monument to one of the mightiest of the ancient empires.If you get really carried away with the magic and the history of the architecture and the culture, you can go to what is now Thailand, and visit Prasat Hin Phimai, Prasat Muang Thom and Prasat Phanom Rung that were built on the ancient roads that spread out across the Khmer empire across all of Thailand, Laos, part of Burma and Vietnam, and all led back to the site of Angkor Wat and Siem Reap. There are loads of others to see, but those in Thailand are well preserved and easily accessible by bus, and not so crowded.Finally, ask yourself... "What happened to the empire ... what happened to Cambodia ?"

Amazing. I could spend the rest of my life wandering the temples. The most amazing place I've ever been. Get the three day pass - one day is not enough. Visit some of the smaller, less popular temples so that you can explore and get away from the crowds.

Awesome place for history buffs. The place is just huge - you might need several days to cover all temples but my adventure was made easier with Tuk Tuk drivers driving around to several must-see temples.

The size of the archaeological park amazed us!. We first-timers were amazed at the sheer size of this park. There are so many temples here that you have to do some picking and choosing of exactly what you want to see. Everyone has different ideas of how many days to spend, whether you should or shouldn't have a guide, whether to have a car, tuktuk or bike, and how much detail you should see. I would say to relax and enjoy at the pace you want to and the length of the visit that you want. We had a three day ticket ($40 per person) and you keep that and get it punched for three days, not necessarily days in succession. We visited the South Gate of Angkor, Bayon Temple, the royal enclosure, Phimeinakas, Elephant Terrace, Terrace of the Leper King, and the Temples of Angkor Wat for most of a day. The second day, we saw Banteay Srei and Banteay Samre Temple and then went to Ta Prohm. The third day wewent to the three Roulous temples. This, for us, was a good amount of time. If we went back, we could certainly see other temples. We were overwhelmed by how busy the entire area was. I had read about when to go for fewer crowds, and we had a wonderful guide, but there are just an overwhelming amount of tourists, so the crowds are inevitable. We had sunscreen, hats, and bottles of water, but we went back to the hotel midafternoon to relax. For us, this workied. For other people, you'll have to find your own tempo for your maximum enjjoyment.

Impressive culture. I took a sunset tour to Angkor Wat via a private tour guide. For someone too busy these days to be a proper Rough Guide traveller armed with all the information, he was very informative and helped me find a spot for some photo taking as the sun rose. The authorities should make it clearer via the tour guides that visitors should not shout or smoke. There are rules but they are not properly enforced.

Magnificent Temples. Be prepared for lots of walking and lots of steps--you will be rewarded by a site that ranks with the Pyramids and the Great Wall of China. Hire a guide or you will be lost among the hundreds of temples.
Great park. I am a Christian, but very interested to go to temple. However, it is a historical Park. A lot of building to see.

Too much to see in only two days. I think you have to pick and chose what to see - if you really want to see it all maybe a week makes sense or at least all three days of the pass. Not sure what kind of visiting you want to do or how much ruins you can stomach. For light visiting I'd say the main five temples is largely enough (your choice 1 or 2 days) and the main two are a not-to-miss (Angkor Wat, Bayon). After a while it becomes a bit of déjà-vu and might be too much of a good thing doesn't make it better. Overall we enjoyed it but it does not make the Fabulous mark in our book as before this we might have been a little bit over-templed-out with Sri Lanka then Thailand's temples especially Ayuthaya and Sukkothai. Overall great for history aficionados but a large bite for us commoners.

Catch the Sunrise and Bike the Temples. Angkor Wat and the many, many surrounding temples are an archaeological must-see destination. Yes, word has gotten out about this amazing place so it can be pretty crowded with other tourists like yourself, but 100% worth the minor hassle in my opinion. Entry into the park costs $20 for one day or $40 for any three days in a week. This gets you into Angkor Wat as well as many other temples in the area including Bayon, Ta Prom, Banteay Kdei, Baphuon, and many more. I highly recommend getting up early for the sunrise over Angkor Wat. It was spectacular. Our hotel arranged a half-day tuk tuk driver that took us there at 5am and drove us around the rest of the morning to see other temples. I also recommend seeing the temples by bicycle. We did an all-day bike tour with Grasshopper Adventures that rode though the main temple complex of Angkor Wat, the Bayon with many face sculptures of buddha, Ta Prohm the jungle temple, and through the countryside to see some other minor temples and ruins. It was a really great way to see the area from a unique perspective, get away from the crowds a bit, and get to see some structures that are only accessible by bike trail.

How to avoid the largest croweds. Angkor temples attacked a huge number of visitors, mostly bus tours of Korean, Chinese and other Asian tourists. My recommendations to individual travellers how to avoid the worst crowds:- rent a Tuk-tuk with driver for the whole day. This should be done in the evening before your tour. Tuk-tuk is much better to experience the atmosphere than a car. Roads in the park are very well maintained. No problems with e.g. dust. Travelling by car will also not be any faster than tuk-tuk. - arrange for the tuk-tuk to pick you up from your hotel around 5am to make it to Angkor Wat for sunrise. You will stop at the ticket office on the way.- leave Angkor Wat immediately after sun-rise, and postpone the visit to its interior to the end of your visit in the afternoon.- move on from Angkor Wat to Bayon and neighbouring temples right after sun-rise, hence, you will be there around 7am, when its still cool and calm, ahead of the crowds. - Plan for a long lunch break, and/or a visit to one of the less popular temples (e.g. one that is only part of the large circle, not the small circle) in the time 11 to 14.- visit Angkor Wat in the afternoon when most visitors have moved on to other temples.

Just amazing. My advise, if you have time, go to the Siem Reap Museum first for some back-ground. 1 day is not even close to enough to appreciate Angkor Wat. You need a guide for at least 1 day, The certified guides are very knowledgeable, well spoken and cheap. If you don't know yet this is a Unesco heritage site and the worlds largest religious site.

Amazing Ankor. We flew to Siem Reap from Phnom Penh by Anchor Air on an early flight. We had a tour car pick us up from the airport and deliver us to Anchor Wat. The whole Archaeological Park is Huge and if you wanted to look at every temple I am sure you could spend a month these. We just wanted a 'taste' so picked Anchor Wat (the most preserved of the temples) to do in a day trip. Firstly, it was Hot and I mean Hot. Take sunscreen, a hat and a bottle of water. To enter the Temple complex you have to walk down the causeway which is a long way if you are not used to walking. There are numerous steps to clime once you get there but anyone with average fitness will have no trouble. The Complex is awesome. It just goes on and on and every corner there is a new surprise. A lot of preasure from the local walking guides to hire them to explain everything and what all the buildings mean but we just wanted to enjoy the experience so we declined. Like the Pyramids in Egypt and Machu Pichu in S.America its a must visit site. You will be glad you did.

Must see. This is probably the reason you are going there -- temples, ruins, Ankor.Together with milions other tourists you fly to Siem Reap to see the biggest archeological site in the world. Wake up before sunrise and you will enjoy the trip.Practical advise. If you buy your 3 days ticket in the evening after 5 pm you will get one sunset at Ankor Wat for free.Very recommended destination.
Fascinating reconstructions of the temples. We spent two days with our tourguide and a Lexus Suv. Just right, if you are not specially interested in Hinduism and Buddhism.

Hire a "Certified Guide". Angkor Archaeological Park is huge! It was so much larger, in area, than we could have ever imagined. Therefore, you must have transportation to get around the different temples. Our hotel (Diamond D'Angkor Boutique Hotel) provided us a "tuck-tuck" driver for each day we were there. We also obtained the services of a "certified guide" for the first day. All "certified guides" were the same yellow-orange shirt signifying they took the state-issued exam for history. Obviously, they knew their information (too much!). But, another great advantage is they know where to go at what time to avoid the huge crowds at the most popular sites. It was such a great feeling not worrying about where to go first, next as well as where is it?

Putting the Wow in Touring. Angkor Wat is a Unesco heritage site and the biggest religious building anywhere in the world. We were in awe and inspired by this world treasure. We also went to Ta Prohm and Angkor Prohm. In half a day we toured ourselves and purchased a book to read up on the history and details of each temple. Some tourists visit for 3 days to a week depending on the depth that they would like to go into and the number of temples or ruins they would like to see on the site. Made my whole trip to SE Asia a huge success.
Fantastic. I'm amazed that you can still wonder through these ruins, they are wonderful and if you sit back and relax you can have a true spiritual experience

Great experience. Loved it. Amazing place. Make sure you hire transport for the day (and possibly a local official guide) as distances from on temple to other are unmanagable by foot or even bike due to the heat.

A miracle!. A miracle of humanity! Different temples, scenic nature.Feelings of pure happiness being able to visit this magical place. Avoid crowds by visiting the temples very early in the morning, try also the smaller ones.

As fantastic as hoped for!. Is Angkor Wat ever not busy? It is great at sunrise and sunset though. If you're not with a group, hire a bike and take yourself around, missing the crowds. This is such a wonderful site, with so much variety, it did not disappoint.
Dislikes? The, predominantly, Chinese and Korean tourists blocking the amazing sights to take selfies!
Take your time. Plan carefully. It's enormous. You need transport. Chinese New Year so it was too busy, losing some of its charm.

Early and off the main attractions. Amazing site, but very crowded. It is better to see smaller temples in the early morning if you would like to get into a more authentic atmosphere and not into the tourist business.

Amazing complex. While we all have seen and read about Angkor Wat, it is not until one is physically there that one realizes, not only the size, but the amazing intricate carving, writing and scened depicted in the monumental architecture. One really needs more than a few days to visit it all, but 4 days gives you a good overall impression. Key is to get there early - when it opens - to avoid the crowds and heat.

Incredible!. This is my 2nd visit to the Angkor Archaelogical Park! It is still as amazing as it was but a little disappointed that some tourist are disrespectful and do not respect the rules and regulations for dressing in the Angkor area.. we all know it is HOT in Cambodia.. but please people, if you're visiting a temple, don't wear shorts. It's a holy place. Would you wear shorts and spaghetti strap tops to a church? Would you wear shorts to a wedding ceremony? or would you dress like an idiot to work? No. Be mindful. Be respectful. It's a holy site. Don't behave like rugrats.

Should be on everyone's bucket list. This immense collection of temples is awe inspiring. This is like the lost city of Atlantis, instead of swallowed by the sea, this one was devoured by the jungle. There is so much to see, I highly recommend the 3 day pass as a minimum ... that will seriously temple you out, hitting all the main spots with enough time for each, while you still leave out many smaller locations. It is also amazing that each temple appears to have a unique feature worth checking out. The ticketing process has gotten easier, you do not need to bring a PP pic anymore to skip the PP taking line, they now take digital pics on the spot when you buy the ticket. Super easy. Bathroom facilities are all over the park, at each major attraction and surprisingly clean (-ish).You will be offered pirated copies of guideBOOKs everywhere. They look pretty convincing and could safe you some money, if supporting this kind of business is your thing.

Angkor is a must visit for everyone!. We spent three days exploring the various sites and were never bored. The guides were great. Beware the kids selling school supplies as they know you will just donate it back.
Impressive. About 3 hour to visit this ancient park. Very impressive. Good time to visit is morning , to avoid the high temperature during noon. Be prepared to have water , and good shoes .
Amazing experience but very hot!. Wonderful area to visit, recommend morning trips ie, 6am - 10/11am. Sunrise at Angkor Wat is very busy and the insects are very biting!

Private tour with a guide is best. The whole Angkor Wat experience is almost overwhelming and In my opinion having a guide is more than helpful. Our guide, Ny Danith, was incredible. He got us in and out of places with ease, knew the best view points, how to minimise the distractions of other tourists, had great knowledge of the temples, spoke very good english with a quirky sense of humour and has such a great empathy for this wonderful part of the world that it affected us deeply. I would happily go back to Siem Reap just to spend time with Danith.

Angor Wat. Went here for sunrise at 5am pretty busy and not as magical as I had read but still nice. We spent the morning and went to 5 temples here, I recommend hiring a tut tut as the temples are a long walk apart.

Awesome!. I like the park especially when its not hot. I dislike the admission cost to the park but those fees sure help Cambodians with revenue so much that the 20 bucks a day fee is necessary. You should hire Tuk Tuk driver from tour agency to take you to the most area within a day since because the park is very huge.

Spectacular. Visiting the temples is a most do here. Star with Angkor Wat then work your way down to all of the others, you can easily do 4 or 5 temples in one day. They are all unique and offer something different. The settings in the jungle is beautiful and peaceful, there is always a lot of shade so don't have to worry to much about the sun. We did it by bicycle which is awesome but only for the fit, it's a long day.
Amazing. Loved strolling around the ancient ruins. Amazing photo opportunities. Spend at least 2 to 3 days and don't forget to catch sunrise over the Angkor wat.
Not to be missed. There's more than can be seen in a day or even a week. It's worth visiting some of the less visited temples too so you can experience it quiet and peaceful.

Yet another visitor to the Archaeological Park. I can only reiterate the comments written by hundreds of past visitors. It is much more than just Angkor Wat. The whole experience is fantastic. It is a bucket list destination. The professional guide and hotel tuk tuk were, I think, essential. Great in a tuk tuk, better than a car!

Coconut! Cold Water! Maybe later?. The title is the soundtrack to visiting the Angkor archeological park.We hired a tuk-tuk driver some friends put us on to $15 for the day. He explained everything about the temples to us once we arrived at each one and was promptly waiting for us when we exited. We did 2 days but in hindsight should have stuck with one. The first day we did Bayon, Angkor Wat, another bigger one and a few smaller ones. If you're really into temples do the 'Grand Tour' as well it shows your all the smaller temples.Just be sure to be careful around the kids trying to sell you stuff.

Too Crowded. It was a chore trying to stay ahead of all the tourist buses and hordes of people.  We found it worked to spend alot of time at each of a few well chosen temples, rather than try to see them all. It was disappointing that there is scaffolding around alot of the temples. also they close the park at 5:30 so you can't really get a sunset photo inside the park. the grounds are lovely. It is worthy that they are renovating and caring for the temples now, but it sometimes makes it difficult to navigate the temples.

With a bit of research you will get a whole lot more out of your trip. Angkor Park is GIGANTIC! Absolutely massive, it contains more ruins that you can imagine - they are spread out and incredibly beautiful. My advice is to do a bit of research before you go - figure out what you want to see. There are a few recommended routes - but I would recommend looking the sites figuring out what you think looks cool and going to those.They are beautiful but if you are going day after day you might find it gets a bit same-ish. A good guide will help point out what is unique or special at each. Two days is enough to pour through the main stuff - don't rush and do take breaks - it is gigantic.Only buy tickets from the designated ticket office, and get your hotel's help booking a guide. Agree on the price and route before you go. We saw and experienced people trying to add on extra costs.

$20 tuktuk for one day. We hired a tuktuk from 6am 'til 6pm for $20. We had, and still have, no idea if this is a decent price but we haggled down from $25 and settled at that.We thought it was a good price and found the journey around by tuktuk to be much more fun than by car. The whole Angkor experience was amazing!

Angkor Archaeological Park. Brilliant! Each Temple was just as amazing and beautiful as the next from Angkor Wat, Angkor Tom to Bayon Temple and many many many more. I recommend you spend a minimum of 3 days and have $US to pay in cash.

Amazing Experience. we booked a tuk tuk for the sunrise and tour the whole day at Angkor but got back to the hotel around 2 because of the intense heat.Although we didn't get a nice sunrise that day, it's better to go very early in the morning as it get very and extremely hot during the day.Visit Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Phrom at least. Read some history about temples before going and get ready to sweat a lot.

The reason for visiting Cambodia. This is the reason visitors come to Siem Reap, certainly lived up to expectations. Tickets available in for 1 day, 3 day and 5 day? visits, it takes 3 days minimum to see all that is available. A good tuk tuk driver and plenty of water are essentials for the visit.The temples on the short (1 day tour) Angkor Wat and Bayon are crowded, especially at certain times, the temples on the grand tour less crowded. Both Angkor Wat and Bayon are quieter later in the afternoon.

Stunning. I was amazed at Angkor as it was so stunning. I had heard really good things about it but until you see it for yourself you don't realise how stunning it is. The whole complex is over 70 square metres in total and contains over 70 tombs, monuments and other ruins. We hired a taxi and driver to take around the complex doing the Great Circle one day and the Small Circle the next. Even so, we didn't get to see all of it so would love to go back.The monuments are amazing and although in various stages of ruin you get a real sense of their majesty and impressiveness. You're able to explore the monuments and complexes and so are able to see the ornate carvings and bas-reliefs up close.I feel so lucky to have been able to visit Angkor

So much to see, walk through time.. You can take days or weeks to thoroughly explore the Angkor Archaeological Park. Tuk Tuk your way around and explore. Don't forget your camera and water if it is summer. Of course there will be many tourists but pace yourself around the Park and realise you are all tourists fortunate enough to experience this magnificent area.
Amazing Wat park. This area of Angar Wat has many temples that are easy to visit and picturesque with very large old tree vines intertwined within the ruins.

Get ready to Smile!! =). Your driver or guide will take you to the main entrance of the park. Unless you bought a tour pack that includes the entrance fee, you will have to stop here to get your ticket. THIS TICKET IS NOT TO LOSE!! They take a picture of you when you buy the ticket and it's printed on your ticket! Do not lose because before entering any temple, a person will ask for your ticket. If you have sun glasses, cap, mask or headband, they will ask you to remove them to make sure your are the one on the pic. Another advice! Girls! In some temples, if you have bare shoulders, a tank-top or bikini top on, they will not let you enter the temple! In the park it's not a problem, only to enter the temples, so have something to cover your shoulders with you. It would be a real shame if you missed out on the beauty of this place for a sun tan! =)
Nice piece of history. This place takes a person back in time and can enjoy all the different mythological reliefs and scenes.

Spectacular. You have to be amongst these ancient ruins to experience the archaeological beauty of something constructed so long ago. The park has been cared for but still left rural. There are many tourists but if you plan well and get a good guide and tuk tuk driver you can see many without experiencing to many tourists.

Angkor Wat. Your first view of Angkor Wat, from across the moat, is breath-taking. I was unable to be there at sunrise, alas, but was there in the late afternoon. There are hoardes of tourists from all over the world, but the grounds are so large that you can find a quiet spot to enjoy the architecture, statues and carvings. I'd like to return to spend more time as my group visit was very rushed. Don't forget to see Ta Prohm and Angkor Thom, 2 other temple complexes.

Getting extremely touristy. Angkor will always be an incredible place and one of the marvels of the world. It has an energy that really is found in only a handful of places on Earth. But this energy is slowly dissipating away. Compared to when I was at Angkor three years ago, it is now so heavily overcrowded that it near impossible to get a photo without some person ignorantly walks in front of you... to also take a photo. It is an absolute free for all dogfight for photos at Angkor, which is a massive shame. Angkor will always be Angkor, but the extremely large amount of tourists being pumped into the Archaelogical city is ruining the ambiance and mystery of the region.

An Experience not to be Missed.. The Angkor Park extends over 100 square miles (?). It has 100s of temples, palaces and other ruins. It is an incredible site-nothing in the world like it.Make sure that you take plenty of water, walking shoes, hat and hire a tuk tuk for about $10 for the day.

Truly an excellent historical experience.. If you're into history and culture, this is the trip for you. I enjoyed Angkor Wat and the breathtaking sight of these ruins in the tropical jungle. However to avoid crowds, consider going about the tour circuit in the reverse order or just visit the further out temples. Those are less crowded, and much for conducive for some quiet exploration without being disturbed!

Go there early for Sunrise. You can't miss this while you're in Siem Reap. Get to the main temple at about 5am to get a good spot for the sunrise, and bring along a torch because it's total darkness. If you arrive after 5am you're gonna find it hard to get a good spot for photography. Not every sunrise will be amazing, so prepare yourself for cloudy days where the sunrise will leave you underwhelmed (still a good experience nonetheless). Leave after the sunrise and explore the temples straight so you can avoid the tour groups that start coming in at about 9am..bring along your breakfast and drinks in your backpack!

One of the 7 man-made wonders of the world. It must be on everybody's bucket list. It's so immense and with so many stories. I think walking with a guide is a really good way to see it and ensure you have some insight to the history.
Doris Nicholson. We visited this magnificent place last August and its a place not to be missed. We were taken to three of the famous temples and each one of them was unique in their own way.
Takes you by surprise. You don't realise the magnitude of the park until you arrive. It could well take many days to see all the sites. A remarkable place.

Title says it all. Liked everything but the fee, Im cheap though, however the girl at the desk said i have a nice chin, this has never happened before. If youy already dont know Angkor is amazing then you have been under a rock.

amazing place to be.. i like the angkor wat..its a big place best to go is early in the morning like 5:30 to see the sunrise behind the temple..i really dont like is too much vendor selling clothes and drinks.

Use a private guide if you can. It is a developing country, kids all over try to sell you something... You must stick to a budget.Beautiful place to visit in a few days, with a bycycle, a tuk tuk or a car and walkWe did all with teenagers...

AMAZING. A must see of course when in Siem Reap!
Hvving a driver or transportation is almost mandatory - this is so big!
A guide is a good option too to learn more about the Temple and the site. They speak many languages...

Top tips for visiting Angkor Archaeological Park, Siem Reap, Cambodia. - Yes it is stunning just like everyone says. Totally agreed but i gonna give you some tips on what to prepare for the trp- Which temple to visit? There are tonnes of temples around but tell ya, after a while you will get so sick of all the temples. Choose only 3 temples. Angkor Wat, Tombraider's temple and Bayon Temple. Leave the rest out and dont even bother going to the sunrise. Who pays to watch the sunrise and sunset in this world? Go figure! There are free sunset and sunrise back home, dude!- Bring lots of water and forget about a hat. Bring an umbrella. Oh boy, Cambodia is hot..truly hot. Hotter than Bangkok. I can tell you i have never been in such hot country in my life, Cambodia hits the spot. Also if you could bring a fan or those electric fan, by all means, bring one. Put some sunscreen on,- Not a lot of people mentioned that you will need American dollars wherever you go. It is all about american dollars here. The entrance fee was charged in American dollars, street sellers charge you USD$3-$5 for a Cambodia t-shirt. Make sure you have enough American dollars. - Food...yeap pretty much you dont need them. You need water the whole time. The weather gets so hot that you cannot even bring yourself to eat. You will only want water the whole time. - Wear a really really good pair of walking shoes. This is the one thing that everyone should know. It does look like there are lots of good pavement to walk but when you want to climb up those stairs to the top of the temple, you need good pair of shoes.- Be prepared to be harassed by street sellers the whole time. They get on to your face so close that you cant do anything about it. Just turn them down politely. If you think my reviews have been helpful to you, please click 'Yes' for 'Was this review helpful?'

The Ultimate Ruins. Angkor Wat and surrounding temples is truly one of the wonders of the world, though somehow it's missed that official,designation. Through our hotel, La Niche D'Angkor, we hired a private English-speaking guide - Thim (pronounced Tim) and tuk tuk driver, Mr. Tek, for three days of touring the Angkor complex, including a drive south to Kompong Pluk, a fishing village on high stilts. There are two standard tours - long/big (includes Preah Kahn and Ta Prohm ... think Angelina Jolie/ Lara Croft) and short/small (Angkor Wat itself) for those on a two-day itinerary; the third day enabled us to see some surrounding countryside en route to the fishing village and visit the further afield pink sandstone, intricately carved temple Banteay Srei. Sunrise and sunset were non-events for us as it was too hazy, but worth it just to see the throngs of tourists, and maybe you'll get lucky with the lighting! We highly recommend Tim - he knew so many stories and rich history, and even knew where to stand for the best photos.

stunning architecture. the angkor wat is very beautiful and impressive. The time you visit make the difference. If you visit in the morning, you will see the mist, dew, everything so green, nice and cool weather. But if you visit in the evening, the sunlight turn things to orenge, dust, and heat that make you sweat.

Jaw dropping.. How on earth did they build such structures, the place has an eerie feeling about it ,but stunning at the same time. Not a place for the faint of heart as their are a lot of steep steps and stair ways,which take you up very tall and high places. I loved it!

HUGE!!!! and Stunning!. It's impossible to get around by foot. Need a tuk-tuk to get from place to place. it is NOT overrated: GORGEOUS! It's a good idea to visit the National Museum at Siem Reap before hitting the park, as everything will make much more sense. Angkor Wat and Bayon are an absolute must see, rest is optional and only if you're really into temples. Be careful of what you wear, they wouldn't let you enter some temples if you re a lady and wearing short shorts/sleeveless top. Beware of the souvenir sellers, especially the kids who run after you. Do NOT get convinced to buy anything unless you actually need it (they can sell you even air :D ) Do bargain, you drop prices by 50% in most cases. Sometimes even more than that.

A world class wonder!. Sure there's lots of people and lots of locals trying to sell you their magnets and postcards but that's all part of it! If your in Siem Reap, you're there for the temples! Try to go early to beat some of the crowds as we definitely noticed it get busier in the afternoons. We took a tuk tuk from our guest house and our driver didn't speak great English. Depending on how much you want to get out of your days you might be better booking an actualy tour guide, we were just happy stopping off at each temple, reading a bit about them and soaking up the atmosphere. We were in Siem Reap 3 days and did the temples on 2 of the days with a day off in the middle. We felt this worked well as you might get a little 'templed out' otherwise!

Must visit - don't skip the smaller temples. Although there's not much to see at the smaller temples, there are also not as many tourists which helps restore some balance, allowing you can appreciate the beauty and cultural impact of the whole park without feeling like cattle.

Enlightening. hard work visiting the different sites but well worth seeing, you need a good guide to help so we have a friend who the best name Nang, phone 081816029, so if you thinking of coming to Angkor wat try him

incredible!. This is an incredible place. If you like archeological sites, this is the place to visit. There are 100 temples in this park. When you tour, you will see the top three. Angkor Watt is the most spectacular site I have ever seen. It is huge and mostly complete. You can go inside, climb around the building and generally explore to your hearts content. It is a highlight to my visits to south east Asia. Highly recommended, an unforgettable experience.
Wonderful. If you are in Siem Reap, you are going for this. And it is worth every step, stair and sweat. I have no words to describe how amazing Angkor Wat is.

Heavenly Ruins. It was like traveling back in time as I walked through the corridors of Angkor. I was reliving in my mind, those grand days, as I pause and admire the stunning work of art exhibited through the walls, the posts and the towers.
It was euphoric! :)

Excellent day out. I visited 5 different locations in the park in 1 day. Your pass, at $20, allows you to visit the full park. It is as you would expect, lots of walking so I wouldn't advise flip flops. You also need to have shoulders and knees covered. There are plenty places to buy cheap water and food. Keep an eye out for the monkeys!

Everything you expect and more. First of all, Angkor Archaeological Park is a massive site and you'll not be able to cover it all in a single day. There are two "routes" that most tour agencies and tuk-tuk drivers will cover. The basic route covers the main sites, such as Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Phrom. The grand route goes further up north and covers some lesser known temples like Phreah Khan and Ta Som. I had only a single day at Angkor and I did the larger route, but it was a bit of a rush. Make sure to get the clothing right. You'll want to ensure that whatever you're wearing covers the knees and shoulders. At the same time, they had better be durable and flexible as well. There are quite a number of temples where you can climb up on very weathered steps and tripping or falling would definitely be injury-causing, if not fatal.
Don't miss it. With 4 million visitors to Siem Reap a year, you will readily find out why when you se Angkor Wat. If you are in hot weather season - got early - like 6:30AM .
Angkor Wat - AMAZING. Angkor Wat was an incredible experience. A place I will never forget. So much history. Amazing ruins.
Amazing y. After watching the rather disappointing sunrise at Angkor Wat we got here at 7 am at it was one of the most stunning sites we have ever seen.The highlight of our visit to Cambodia.
Excellent. One off the bucket list .... and well worth the early start. Well run and because we were early it wasnot too busy. Its a huge site anyway to wander around in but it does get very hot

Paradise for photographers. A perfect place to plan a trip to. Ticket bought after 5pm is valid for the next day - use it to see the sunset on the first day and to get an idea of what the site is. Wear comfortable clothes and shoes; knees and shoulders should be covered for the temples (sarongs and pashminas will not work, only proper clothes!) Negotiate prices with street vendors. And make sure you have your camera with you, this place is a real paradise for photographers.

Magical temples of Ankgor. We had two magical days in the archeological park, we arrived early to avoid the crowds, and it was worth the early start. All the temples offer something different and all have their own special atmosphere. There is still a lot to do at the park and there is some really impressive renovation work going on. The Cambodian government need to take some advice from other major historical attractions to preserve the fabulous temples and manage the ever increasing visitors that have the potential to wear away these precious monuments. Cambodia is a very special country with lots of potential, it's people are so warm and friendly, the food is great, and it has so much to see, go and enjoy a fabulous part of the world, and spread the word.
A must see!. It's one thing to read about it but seeing it live is very impressive. Make sure to hire a guide to help you understand the history of this amazing place.

Stunning. Best way to see the park is to hire a car or tuk tuk driver who will take you to the most important sights. We booked a driver through our hotel for the first day, but on the second day cut out the middle man (the hotel) so we all benefitted. The driver was very knowledgeable with good English,self taught, and was a pleasure to be with.

Worth the trip. If you go to Cambodia and find your way to Siem Reap, this place is beautiful, haunting, historical, full of tourists and awe inspiring even in its crumbling ruins. You will need at least 2 days to have a glimpse to the beautiful integration of culture and nature in the park. You should get there in a Tuk Tuk and the driver can gently wait for you the whole day or take you to different areas in the park.

Fantastic!. It truly is one of the wonders of the world. It is visually stunning at sunrise or sunset and the architectural and engineering feats are so impressive considering it was all done by hand.

A wonder of the world. A visit to Angkor is an unforgettable step back in time. There are so many ancient temples and cities to choose from, all of them beautiful and unique, from its probably worth getting a three day pass ($40) just so you're not templed out on the first day and have the luxury to visit everywhere you want! That being said, if you're stretched for time or money, a $20 day ticket is available and gives you access to every site - so if you're up to the challenge of seeing everything in one day GO FOR GOLD!Visitors should bare in mind whilst visiting that Angkor is an important cultural, archeological and religious site. It is a source of great national pride to the Khmer, and it only takes the actions of a few to ruin something for everyone. Remember to wear clothing that covers your shoulders and knees, don't shout and be careful of touching the walls and statues. On a more practical note, pack a good pair of walking shoes, bring plenty of water and be prepared for crowds, heat and dust.Nothing compares to these beautiful temples, there is simply nothing like them on earth. Definitely take the time to visit, you cannot regret it - no matter how tired wandering around all day will make you.

Not to be missed. Simply a must for all travellers. A humbling experience when you see the complexity and superiority of the Angkorian empire. Around a thousand years ago these people were building structures that still remain awesome and breathtaking today. Add to that the incredible blend of nature as at Ta Prom and you have something that is a must visit for everyone remotely interested in life outside their own country.

Simply amazing..... Not much to say about the Angkor sites.... We were looking forward to visiting Angkor for years.We spent 4 days visiting 14 sites almost without being "templed out". They are all different and have their own features.Most important advice : get up early to avoid the chinese/korean groups as they are disrespectful and cannot talk without yelling....

except for the dust, marvellous experience. Love the UNESCO site....but maybe too many people around, even in the mornings. In terms of the structures, maybe Indonesian have better legacy from the past in terms of Borobudur and Parambanan. But, undeniably Angkor was really worth the visit.
Journey back in time. What an amazing and awe inspiring place. The temples are just so fantastic and took me back to a life much more simple in the past. Lots of history. Well worth a visit

Unesco World Heritage site. Angkor is the most important archaeological site in SE Asia covering some 400 km2 including the forest area . It has the remains of different capitals of the Kymer Empire from the 9th to the 15th century and is magnificent .It includes Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and the Bayon temples, terraces and so much more.A definite must do when in SE Asia.

A MUST SEE!!. Incredibly beautiful!! I came in January and loved it! I wish that I would have had time to enjoy more than just one day here, it was really quite lovely. It's quite crowded though, but you can escape the crowds. The views and architecture are absolutely astonishing, and I am so grateful to have been able to spend time here! Truly magnificent, a must see before you die!!
Wow!. I don't think I need to say anything on this. A wonderful place. And a lovely one too. Everyone must go there at least once in a lifetime.

Step Back in Time. Our trip to Siem Reap was specifically taken to see Angkor Wat. This is a place that is definitely not to be missed if you are anywhere in SE Asia. It is unbelievable that this was once covered by the jungle. To see the other parts of this World Heritage Site,that are still covered by the jungle really brings it all in focus. The way the trees grew through the stones is amazing. The wonderment of how this area was built so many years ago without modern day tools. It is not an easy place to visit with all the uneven ground, and so many steps that are not easy to climb. All in all it was worth the effort.
Awesome experience. This is not to be missed. Amazing structures and lots of well preserved buildings. Awesome locations and exceptional historical sites. Highly recommended.

Wonders if the World. We travelled to Siem Reap and Cambodia specifically to visit the temples in this enormous UNESCO World Heritage site and it was definitely worth the trip. Definitely one of the wonders of the world. It's incredible that such amazing buildings were created hundred of years ago using the most basic tools, at a time when the rest if the world was so backward in comparison.

The archaeological park was exciting.. The archaeological park was exciting both historically and artistically. To visit the ruins involved lots of walking on irregular ground and there are no railings at most steps. However difficult, it was well worth the effort.

Heritage visit to Angkor Archaeological Park. Very well maintained sites. Integrated ticketing - Apsara Pass, is handled very well and highly professional. The licensed guides are very helpful and knowledgeable.

amazing places. The whole angkor wat complex is amazing. I have 2 negatives. One is the amount of tourist. Yes I came during high season but wow. I know this will never happen but they really should put some limits to help perserve the temples. The other negative is all the people trying to sell you stuff at every temple. Even after you politely say no they still keep asking. If you plan on seeing the sunrise for a great pic near the pond I have 2 recommendation. First use a car not a tuk tuk. Tuk tuk are great but slow. Even after arranging to leave eariler I was passed by a lot of buses. Next try to get the pass the day before to avoid the lines the run to the pond when dropped off. You will be shocked by the amount off people around when the sun comes up. If you dont getA good spot be prepared the have photos with atleast 10 people holding the cell phones up
Lost in time , culture and history. Dream come true to visit this place...watched it from sunrise to sunset and taken some awesome memories back. Hindu mythology all over the place...great stories
well worth the trip. If Angkor is all you see in Cambodia you will be happy you came.The ancient ruins give a sense of ancient splendor and the dedication of the people

Sunrise over Angkor Wat a must.. I loved the History of Angkor Wat. It was very spiritual for me. These temples were built in the 12th century and they are still standing. I felt that I was walking on sacred ground

What is left to say?. It's Angkor Wat, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. What if left to say that hasn't already been said? If you're in Siem Reap you simply must go there for at least two days. Bring lots of water.
The whole Angkor area is amazing!. Get a multiple-day pass and visit as much as you can. We were here 4 days and it was barely enough time. Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and Ta Prohm are the "musts."

FAB. Just go and do at least 3 big temples, get a guide (about $15-20USD)
Go in the late to mid afternoon, as much less people there.

Great!. You will need at least 3 days to have a glimpse to the beautiful integration of culture and nature in the park.
You can get ther in a Tuk Tuk and the driver can gently wait for you the whole day or take you to different areas in the park.

Siem Reap - World Heritage Site - Nuff said. If you go to Cambodia and find your way to Siem Reap (and why wouldn't you if you're there?) then this place is beautiful, haunting, historical, full of tourists and awe inspiring even in its crumbling ruins, (or maybe especially because of them).I visited as part of a small tour group in February 2013I expect early in the day and late in the afternoon would be the best times to go.We went with a guide who could explain aspects of the history but there's so much to see, it's really just about taking it all in and absorbing it as best you can.Can be fantastic to get there early in the morning, before sunrise and watch the sun come up behind the main temple in front of the large lagoons. We did that. The sunrise didn't cooperate that day but that didn't stop the place from being packed first thing in the morning, just before the sun came up.

Cosmic view. I was expecting wander in Angkor...But I found more.It is cosmic view ..These temples huge, ancient.Trees and walls.It is better than Gisa Pyramids .Even Hindu having anything looks like...I will return.

An iconic place. I wanted to visit Angkor for over 30 years and this was IT. Its so much more than you can expect. 3 days of visit that we enjoyed immensely. Memorable sites and images. A must see once in a liftetime

An insight into the Mythology. It would be an amazing experience if you pre-read a bit about the the history of the temples and the depictions of the carvings and sculptures. Absolutely worth visiting.
Bucket list. I waited 14 years to come to here, and it was 100% worth it. Sacrifice sleep to catch sunrise, just prepare for ungodly crowds. An incredible place all around.

if theres somewhere you need to visit in your life.... Incredible, eye opening, wonderous, a treasure to be seen, from the incredible trees and vegetation that meanders through the fascinating ruins to the artful sculputures faces and attentive carvings, wherever you look , theres always something new to see.

Angkor Archaeological Park. This is one of the most fantastic collections of ancient ruins in the world. Various temples are breath taking. The downside is that to really see the ruins involves a lot of walking and climbing

Artistic architecture. This park consists of ancient temples or wat from the Hindu and Buddhist period dated around 1000 years ago. Most parts are original but some have been reconstructed. Visitors will be amazed to see the intricate carvings on the buildings
wow. what can we say beside go and see everything. each temple is different and enjoyable, even the smallest of them. beathe, feel, absorb the place.

Take time out for this one. Amazing experience. My husband is unable to walk more than 100m at a time but was allowed in by police in our tuk tuk (at our drivers request) to get very close and take numerous photos. Our two daughters ( aged 40) who are keen photographers however climbed all over and took some amazing shots. They went back for a second day, leaving our hotel at 5am for sunrise. When they arrived, visitors were already in prime positions ...the moral of the story ....take a three day pass which can be used anytime over a week, and be there very early if you want a good position for sunrise. Sunset is again worthwhile. On a different level clothes shopping out there is much cheaper than in town if that interests you.
Need more. It is far more than you can visually and mentally take in on one trip. I will be going back for a second "slower" look around

One of our favorite places in the complex. I wish we spent more time here. This is the 2nd or 3rd stop along the "half marathon" tour of the angkor complex. The first step is Angkor Thom and it is so big that if you are not careful you may spend too much time there and have to skimp on time at Ta Phrom or other places. The complex closes at 4pm, use your time effectively.The Angkor complex is not really stroller or wheel chair friendly, but your Tuk Tuk driver will drive all of the long ways and then it is up to you to walk/climb everywhere else.

Unique unmissable life experience. This is a completely unique and powerful experience with few limitations of your exploration or time to enjoy this area. Its quite a remarkable area and a few days to roam free and take it in is a privilege not to be missed

An awesome time! If time is limited, do the short tour. The park is great with all its amazing architecture and history. If you plan to spend a couple of days there, get a one week pass that lets you into the park three times on different days. If time is limited to one day, i would rcommend the short tour, which takes in the most well known temples. We prferred to take a private tuk tuk for,the day whoch cost 17 us dollars, as opposed to an organised tour. You can get all the info you need from guide books! BEWARE, there are a lot of steps to climb if you want to see the top of all the temples!
A Must See!. On everyone's bucket list. If not, put it there. Go with a private guide. they will steer you away from the hordes of Chinese tourists. Well worth the cost. Stunning place

Best done with a guide. It's not hard to imagine life a thousand years ago in Cambodia...thanks to the architects, the engineers, the artists and the legacy left by the Kings. It is literally in stone to wander and climb and stand in awe! The amazing carvings on the corridor walls are breathtaking in their detail. The stories being told on the walls will go on and on for centuries to come. The park is always busy, but it never disappoints!
Awesome. Everything, although the locals can be a little pushy on selling their wares! Take a driver for the day and go to the less touristed temples, we had them to ourselves in peak season.

Just Wow!. Pictures alone cannot do this place justice. One of the most amazing wonders I think I have ever seen in my travels. Well and truly worth a 4:30am wake up call to go there for the sunrise over Angkor Wat

must see. A true wonder of the worldWe did 2 days in a tuk tuk. Saw about 8 temples. Cost $20/ day for admission to all temples and $33 for both days in tuk tuk.It would be possible to cram it into one day but better in 2 or 3
One of the wonders of the world. Not to be missed. A wonderful place to take time and experience history. It tends to become crowded late in the day - so go early.
amazing. i wonder how they built it up. it so amazing. can not say enough about it. the temple told us about the rich story of Cambodia. many beautiful temples and crowded tourist.

A must in live. Ancient asiatic culture, there is so much to see and learn. Any words can help to explain it, just go. Bad: -to many tourist-price of restaurants in the area 7/8 $ pp min-the heat and the sun can be stressfulGood: -its big like los angeles, you can always find the place and the moment to enjoy the view, the temples and the nature-transport between temples with tuk tuk is the best option to really enjoy it-you can get a 40$ pass for 3 days in one week-there are some far away temples really special

Well worth a visit. Really enjoyed our time exploring the sights, a must do if in Siem Reap. Buy the 3 day temple ticket and spend 2 days around the Angkor Wat complex and spend one day at Banteay Srei, which was a hidden surprise.

Awesome . You have a choice, there are 2 ways you can enter this amazing temple complex. 1.the main entrance, amazing entrance, the only trouble is it is full of visitors, everyone coming or going 2.the north entrance, just a handful of tourists use this (have to ask tuk tuk/guide to take you there).a lot quieter route,I would say that you get a better view as you walk past the gate up to the temple, very peaceful (avoiding all the stalls and hassle)you will reach the main temple first. I would say if you have a few days to do these temples,get a guide for the first day.leave early and try and do as much as possible, then get a tuk tuk for the rest.as you can take your time and leisure to go around the temple complex 's.their is a lot of temple's to visit.

The historical and cultural wealth. It was a large surrounding cover all by the old temples and it was a fantastic visit to the site. We have three days here but feeling that we should have longer time to visit all the temples in the archeologist park of Angkor.
SUNRISE OR BUST!. Go early for the sunrise and then peace out. It gets incredibly crowded later in the morning. Watching the light illuminate the temple from darkness was absolutely magical.

Definite Worthy of Bucket List Status. We visited the park over 2.5 days which was a reasonable pace. We started early and tried to finish by 13h00 as the heat really wears you down. Save Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom for last as they are truly spectacular....if you do them first the other temples will be a bit anticlimactic.
Hordes of Mass tourism. A place that would deserve everything spoiled by loads of mass tourism. Chinese take over with their cheap, loud and uncivilized way of travel
Just awe inspiring. My third visit and it is still as magical as the first time. This was my first dawn experience which was great though the clouds could have been a little more helpful.
Wonderful Mother Nature artwork.. The view is amazing as the artwork of Mother Nature on human architecture over time is too amazing. Visit on January as the weather not so hot. Nice experience.

Great guides. Anyone looking for a tour which takes the stress out of travel but is at the same time personalised need look no further than 'ABOUTAsia travel' . This local company which uses 100% of all profits for rural education programmes delivers a tour totally geared around your personal interests. You can even use their suggested hotels or select your own . We had 5 days with our knowledgeable and personable guide and not only felt the magic of the amazing temples but travelled by car, tuk tuk, ox cart and boat to experience local life. Every day brought a new little surprises. It couldn't have been better.One thing not to miss is the 'Phare' , the Cambodian circus which is actually a music/drama/art experience
beautiful.has to be seen to be believed. nothing to dislike the whole area was amazing.we even had a rainbow over the moat.we were lucky to see this as our guide had never seen this before
amazing. wonderful place to visit. everybody should go see it. it should be in everybody's bucket list. worth every penny & time.

Truly Wonderful. Where do you start. It is a 'must see' location with so many temples and sites. Don't expect peace and quiet at the main sites, which are on every visitors list. Get a good guide and visit as early in the day as possible to miss the crowds at the big name sites (Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, Ta Prom, Baphuon). We left hotel in Siem Reap at 5.45am each day and stayed ahead of the tour groups on their circuit.If you have time do visit the less known, further afield sites which will be quieter. Our favourites were Roluos Group (Preah Ko and Bakong), East Mebon and Banteay Srei. Sunset from the hilltop temple of Phnom Bakheng was also worth the climb.

A must see wonder. My second visit to Angkor Wat and ready for the third. In my view it is one of the wonders of the world despite not being included. The whole complex is full of beauty. Make sure to stay for the sunset where one can see the reflex of the temple on the lake.
Magical. Such a large compound. Pay $2 to take the tuk tuk from the ticketing place to inside. There are option of one-day, three-day or one-week tickets.

Spectacular! Must-see in Cambodia. Best tips we received and were happy we followed include: 1. Book a tour of Angkor Archaeological Park with a private guide. You will have tuk tuk service (the park is massive - you'll want a ride!)2. Plan to arrive before sunrise. Hike into the park and arrive to Angkor Wat just before sunrise. Stay until 30 minutes after sunrise so crowds will enter the park and you will have unique photo opps most others will not capture. *Alternative plan is to arrive just before sunset, at which time you will have the opportunity to capture sundown over Angkor Wat. Equally breathtaking, but likely warmer.3. Be sure to go deep into the park and see as many temples as possible. We almost skipped Angkor Ta Prohm, since it was far flung. It was by far our favourite to view (it's actually the temple pictured in the thumbnail above - with the tree roots growing over the temple). Ah-mazing!!

Quite simply the best place in the world.. Are you seriously reading a review of Angkor? There's no need. It's just the best. You won't regret it. And get there soon before all the new hotels drain the water table and the temples all collapse.

Excellent lady tour guide. We arrived at Siem Reap bus station and we were surprised to be greeted by a lady tour guide with warm smiling face. For the next 3 days, Makara had given us an excellent service, nothing was not too difficult for her. She was knowledgable with history of Angkor Wat temples and always answer any questions. She even takes us to places when it was not in the itinerary. We would highly recommend her service should anyone wants a personal service.

A Once in a Lifetime Experience. The Angkor Archaeological Park is one of the most incredible historical sites on the planet. Having so many temples and structures located so close together allows for a remarkable experience, admiring the evolving architecture and learning about the events and culture that shaped the structures as they appear today. We booked a one day tour with a guide and thought it was totally worth it. We saw all the main temple sites, but there were many smaller ones that we would have loved to spend a little more time with. The Archaeological Park makes the trip to Siem Reap well worth it no matter where you're traveling from!

Angkor Wat and Beyond. Spend some time visiting Angkor Wat and then rent a bicycle and get away from the crowds and explore the many temples that surround the Angkor complex. There is so much beauty to behold!
Best bit of Cambodia. Do it with a local guide - the history and stories were really nice and we would have missed half of it if we did not go with a guide.
WOW! A must see.. We took a private tour with Happy Angkor Wat Tours and were delighted with the service. We saw 4 temples with appropriate time in each.

One of the world's great places. Magical, intriguing, beautiful and evocative of lost kingdoms and civilisations. Visit early in the day to miss the crowds, though there is enough space for all at Angkor Wat.
Amazing. I loved this place! My favorite temples were Bayon, Tah Phrom and Angkor Wat. Hire a tuktuk driver that will take you everywhere!
On everyone's bucket list. Go early in day or later in afternoon. Expect crowds regardless. Least crowded midday but temperatures can be oppressive. Best time to visit is Jan/feb during dry season.

The best of the Best. There is nothing I would say I have not liked. Angkor Archaeological Park was one of the most magnificent places I have ever visited. It was clean and very well looked after. It is also ‘the place’ Cambodia where one can have a better idea about history of the country. So “Must be done”!
Surreal experience. Having a guide really helped to understand all that you are looking at. Two days was great to see a range of temples. Nice to have some time sitting at quieter ones to relax.
Lost World. This is a very expansive area to cover and a must see if you are in Cambodia, it will take time to see it all so allow plenty of it, go early in the morning before it gets to hot.

Huge place get a tuk tuk. Get a tuk tuk driver this place is huge we passed many cyclist whom I think underestimated how massive this place really is they were doing it really tough in the Cambodian heat one cyclist had a young kid about 10 yrs of age with him whom was every upset about being there. For seventeen bucks our tuk tuk driver took the four of us to all the different temples and waited for us at each one he supplied us with water and told us a bit about each one he was awesome.

Stunning and awesome experience. The temples in this area is everything and more compared to pictures and documentaries that I have seen. Give yourself enough time to see all of the worthwhile temples though, I would recommend a 3 day pass. You can use one of the days to watch a sunset as well. Jan is a great time of the year to visit as its not too hot. I would also recommend using a guide to take you through the temples. There aren't many toilet facilities at the temples, but you still need to hydrate. A truly worthwhile experience on the whole.
Hidden Gems. Brilliant history. Some are easy to navigate others quite difficult. Stairs on Thom are extemely steep and one needs to side step to get down them.
In awe of Angkor. Loved the different temples, carvings etc but also the park itself is stunning and driving through the small villages and tree lined roads was a pleasure by tuk tuk.

Get a guide!. It's incredible and clearly why you came to Siem Reap I recommend a guide to explain, because you'll get templed out and not get as much of an experience. Go to the museum or read up a little history before hand, and do the less "wow" but equally amazing (Bantay Srey, etc) temples day 1, and save Angkor Wat and Bayon for day 2, otherwise you won't want to do any more temples after the first day. Save the best for last!

Beautiful archaeological site. Tourist flooded.. It's definitely worth seeing but be prepared to deal with the big number of tourists heading the same way as you. We got a 1 day ticket and wondered if it weren't better to get the 3 days pass. After a full day of wondering around we were happy with our 1 day tick. The high temperatures, the dry and dusty climate plus the great number of tourist take away some of the excitement of visiting Angkor Thom.

My second visit. The temples were amazing, each one had its own unique style. Very well worth while visiting, but do visit other temples besides Angkor Wat. Crowded, yes, but the temples are spread over a large area and we managed to get away from the crowds. Don't forget the mandatory sunrise photo of Anghor Wat temple.

This is the reason to visit Siem Reap. I saw seven temples while I was in Siem Reap. I arrived around noon on a Friday. I visited Ankgor Wat and Ta Prohm on the first day. The next day, I visited Ankgor Thom (including Banyon, Elephant Terrace, The Leper King Terrace), Preah Khan, Bentay Srie, Pre Rup, Ta Keo. On Sunday, I saw sunrise at Angkor Wat then church before heading to the airport.I got the US$40 three day pass -- I only used it for the sunrise on the third day, but that was worth it. It's US$20 per day otherwise. The ticket gives you access to all of the temples in the area. Your ticket is checked at the entrance to each temple area.The temples are not close enough together to walk between. You need a bike, tuk-tuk or car/driver. Once they check your ticket at the gate, you can wander anywhere in and around each temple site. Everything is done in US$; only small change is done in the local currency.I did it all of the temples without a guide. Get a guide if you want to hear the explanations and stories about the temples and the carvings. You don't need one if you want to just wonder around.I got people asking me if I needed a guide, but it wasn't as bad as I expected. Between waving them off with certainty and having headsets on, I didn't get bothered all that much. There are people selling at every temple, mostly at the entrance and exit. Again, I didn't have too much trouble, though it is hard to say no to the kids, and sometimes I didn't But, I did it when there weren't a lot of other sellers around, to avoid getting swarmed. I read about being asked to buy milk formula for children and then the formula being sold back to the shop. I was caught off-guard, though, when a official-looking man in a uniform and "police" starting helping me. It was another way to offer guide services and trinkets for $US.The tour groups make it hard to get pictures sometimes, but I generally was able to go where they weren't.

History, Archeology, Hindu and Buddhist Religion. Some 200 temples are located in and around this large World Heritage site. Some have been restored, some in the process and some in need. All exude history and mystery. One can almost feel the ghosts of the ancient kingdom swirling through the ruins. While the "short" day-long tour to Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom is the most popular, the "long" tour is well worth it.
very interesting. Though I was there ten years ago, I still found it interesting. I fell they could do more to improve the road conditions given the price they charge for entry fee.

Loved every minute!. We spent 1 full day in Angkor Archaeological park, from 5:30am for sunrise until 3pm. We rented 'Green e-bikes' (electric bikes/mopeds) from Siem Reap town (google them, great company!) which we think was the best way to get around the park at our own pace at the same time as being really fun! In that 1 day we managed to see all of the temples on the main site, which was 9 in total! We also didn't feel like we were rushing around at all, and even had time to charge our e-bikes for an hour! Its such a nice, relaxing place, seeing all the temples and then riding between them in peace and quiet. Would highly recommend seeing the temples at your own pace in this way. On reflection, a 3 day pass might have been nicer just to spend more time in the peaceful Angkor complex, but if you are short on time or money, 1 day is sufficient. We also rented green e-bikes for a second day, to ride the perimeter of the West Baray (a more difficult ride, on mostly sandy track!) but a really great and exciting day out! Would love to return to Siem reap and do it all again!

Temples of epic scale and proportion . An absolute must see. Watching the sunrise over Angkor Wat is very impressive especially if you can catch the reflection in the pond. Crowds can get huge so make sure you get in early (before 5am).

Everything you may have imagined!. Just huge and so many wonders. We did the big circuit one day, the small circuit the second day and Angkor Wat the third (sunrise and then the visit - a really good idea as not many people at all in the early morning, after sunrise). You will need cash for the tickets (not credit cards) and worth having a good map.

Get There Early to Avoid Crowds. There were so many tourists at this World Heritage spot that it was almost impossible to get an unimpeded view of the sites. UNESCO currently is financing the restoration but this results in heavy equipment everywhere which also mar the majesty of many temples.Upon arrival, even if you have a prepaid ticket, you must get on line to have your photo taken and affixed to your ticket. This creates a bottleneck at the entrance to the park.During the visit you may be asked to produce your ticket...this ensures that everyone pays their admission fees. Cambodia is a very poor country and this park is a major source of income for the nation, thus the need to safeguard the admission process. ..
A must visit. The highlight of any trip to Cambodia. There are lots of people, but with a good guide you can see all the best spots at the best times.
Cambodia Treasures. Walking around this area is a true privilege. So many things to see, so little time!Try and go for a week to Siem Reap..
Impressive temple. I went to this temple this morning. It is majestic and beautiful. To see its facade during sunrise was a magical experience. I enjoyed my visit.
Take your time.... This is the cleanest part of Cambodia. Try to avoid the tour groups and busloads of hoards and herds with selfie sticks, smart phones and iPads.
preview before going to Angkor wat. Very nice museum with exhibit halls. Loved who much room they allocated in each hall to showcase the treasures

Visit Number 3. In September 2014 I made my 3rd visit to Angkor Archaeological Park. If you are fascinated by history and want experience the feeling of exploring ruins of a bygone era you want be able to get enough of this place.To do it properly research research and research workout what you must see and what would be good to see Talk to the front desk of your accommodation and get advice on a personal guide with car, it's not expensive. Then talk to your guide tell him where you must go and where you would like to go. Check out the guide for Angkor knowledgeSetup your plan for as many days as you can then do itI will not recommend which ruins that you must workout for yourselfFor inexpensive food and people watching I do recommended Pub Street and if you have any energy left after climbing through ruins all day definitely visit the night market remember to bargain hard as the stall holders will never sell at a loseWill I return the answer is a definite yes but I never tire of experiential travel

Temple Ruins At Its Best!. Some may say after seeing one more temple, they will have enough! But in my case, I will never get enough of the temples around Angkor; each and everyone of the ruins have different taste to them for example Bayon in Angkor Thom with its stone faces, Angkor Wat with its famous five towers (and sunrise! Word of advice - come early to get the best place!!!) and Banteay Srei with its well preserved red stone carvings. To make the most of it, take the three day pass ticket ((USD40) and use either tuk tuk driver (negotiate the price - we use the guy called Teddy Watts and he is in facebook and he's very good!) or rent a bike.
Kids Beg. Be ready to get hustled. There are kids everyone begging for money whereever you go.They will not leave even if you say no. and if you give a dollar you get swarmed by more kids.
must see. one of the best unesco world heritage sites.!! worth seeing and going. wear socks and rubber shoes. it gets really dusty.
nothing to say!. All I could say is. Go there!!!! You wont be disappointed. Can be done in three days if you're in good shape.

What wat was That?. Having only had 24 hours here previously I was determined to comeback with enough time to climb every temple and wat, ford every moat and baray, follow every tiny pathway until I'd experienced all the treasures Angkor has to offer. We spent a thrilling week tracking down even the tiniest temples. Deserving of its heritage listing as one of the wonders of the world. Should be on everyone's bucket list. Thrilling architecture and many spiritual moments - brilliant!

Try to bicycle around angkor. We depart early in the morning to catch sunrise. Riding a bicycle from the guesthouse is a good option for us to explore not only the angkor, but the village near the angkor. it was really good experience to ride a bike 8 hour non-stop to explore the angkor.
Impressive beyond words. A walk back in time through spectacularly impressive ruins and amid the untamed wilds of nature. Bucket List!
Angkor Wat. Magnificent place. Large area. Take your time. Don't do like me, and rush things in 1½ days. It was very intense! Spend at least 3 days here.

awesome.... "Temple running" was such an awesome experience. It was a journey to a better understanding of the Cambodian culture, civilization and faith.
Siem Reap is definitely a wonderful and exotic getaway that must be savored and enjoyed!

Breath Taking!. The whole Anghor area is totally amazing with its temples and simply the history is just astounding. My family visited this area not only for the scenery but we spent almost 2 weeks teaching English at CCAHA. If you want a mind changing experience I recommend you not only do the tourist thing but go behind the scenes. The Cambodian people and kids are so beautiful and giving.

One of the wonders of the world. I had been wanting to visit Angkor for over 30 years and finally made it. You really need 2 days to do it justice although the highlights can be easily accomplished in a day. Try to get there about 7am when it is not so hot. Take plenty of water! Angkor is vast and fascinating. Either read up about it beforehand as we did or make sure you have a knowledgeable guide. We did both
Incredible. Really incredible heritage. I am sure this place is must-see spot in the world.
Good Complex. so beautiful temple complex, good gallery, and meaning full and when i entered and go straight to the temple, my felt so wonderful that i have never been before. But so crowded.

the whole reason for being in this aarea. it is a totally awesome experience to see that ruin sitting there . an unbelivable experience. take your time and dont rush this. It is well worth allowing the whole day to see then just day dream about
Amazing World Heritage. It's such a great experience to explore the world of wonder. A wonderful history and an exotic vacation getaway.
Unbelievable! One of the highlights of Asia!!!!. This attraction can match with any other one in the world... A Must See!!!Try to take at least the 3 days pass... One day here is just not enough...

temples and ruins galore. While we found this whole complex to be absolutely awesome, the crowds were dense, and movement limited by the number of sightseers. If it is possible to find a quiet time - maybe early morning or late afternoon, the whole experience would be more pleasant. However this is clearly a must-see, preferably with a knowledgeable and passionate local guide

Awesome!. We spent 3 days visiting various temples with a private TukTuk driver, but without a guide. Read up each night before we visited specific temples and downloaded a guide to bring with us. SOOOO many tourists, and LOTS of people taking "Selfies" it was quite humorous. I would recommend visiting Ta Nei Temple, it's a bit of a walk into the woods near the Flight of the Gibbons location, but hardly anyone goes there, so you have the temple to yourself, with trees growing into the structure! It's quite magical.
World class and getting even better. Great place to explore the past through temple and building ruins. Feel like an explore. Make sure to visit some of the lesser sites too for a private feel.

As spectacular as you could expect. Angkor is as nice and as good as you might expect. The key tip is to hire a guide that takes you there avoiding the crowds. Angkor has more than 4m turists a year, every sunset and every sun rise are hugely popular with thousands of turists EVERY DAY. The idea is to get a real guide that allows you to see it with a bit of intimacy, and discover those romantic corners of the complex. I certify that is possible...

Angkor. Loved it but it was very crowded. We went at 5am to see Angkor Wat during the sunrise and I was amazed at how many others were doing the same thing! We explored all day and the crowds never diminished. It's worth fighting the crowds though. Beautiful!!!!

Fantastic. This is an incredible place, one that I could have spent days and days at. We did a sunset here and it was beautiful and quite thought provoking. While I sat in awe of this magnificent place, I found myself surrounded with Monkeys. Sunrise was another incredible experience, although many people come here to witness the sunrise over Angkor, I found a quite place where I was able to meditate and take in the Majesty of this temple as the sun illuminated it. This was a once in a lifetime moment, do not miss it!

Impressive 800+ year old constructions. A massive complex of temples and archeological remains spread over a very large part of the Siem Reap province. For the average tourist the limitation is time, the thre-day pass (usable over a week) gives more scope.

There is no way anyone should miss this. I would recommend at least 3-4 days exploring as many of the Temples as you can in this complexHire a driver for the whole time and plan where you want to go (he can help and tell you where is the best place to go and in what order) but they will go where you want so make sure you have a plan or else you will miss out on some really amazing Temples!Highly recommend hiring a seperate guide for Angkor Wat complex as they will guide you through and explain the history, if you want to go on your own take a good book with maps and make sure you know where you are going as its full on, you will need a tuk tuk or bicycle to get from one temple to the nextHighly recommend sunrise at Angkor Wat - make sure to get a good spot in front of the water (see my pic) as it gets crowded
A sight to behold!. The Angkor Wat temple and Angkor Thom were amazing! definitely a must see, preferably with a guide unless you read about the temples first or go to the National Museum.

Spectacular. We had a 3 day pass and a couple of bikes and it was wonderful, the whole area is well maintained, good toilets dotted around and lot's of eating places. One tip, ladies make sure you have a dress that is to the knees and a blouse that covers your shoulders as this is the dress code in some temples (Angkor Wat for instance) Scarves are not acceptable as I found out luckily on day 2!

A theme park of historical wonders. I got the 3 day pass because I am a history buff and like exploring every temple in the spread out archaeological site. There are restored temples and unrestored temples, there are forests and jungles, there are rivers and villages. Your pass gets you in. And the gem in the collection is Angkor Wat itself. A true 7 wonders of the world. The sunrise camp out at 5:30 am with hundreds of other visitors in the dark (you're never alone unfortunately) was an amazing experience. The break of dawn over the temple towers was awesome and followed by hours of prowling the temple grounds and climbing to the top.

Amazing. One of the great sites of the world - unmissable. There isn't a lot to dislike apart from the fact that you have to share it with other visitors. The quality of carving and the amount is astounding. There are plenty of documentaries on YouTube to watch before you go so you can understand the context.

Absolutely Amazing. My friends and I had an unbelievable time visiting Angkor Wat. We visited several temples across our trip, climbing over ruins and up to the highest point of each temple. Angkor Wat is a must-see for anyone visiting Cambodia. Our tour guide made the weekend an incredible experience - adding historical context to everything we were seeing. See my review of him, Kamsan Sreng, in the activities section of Trip Advisor. Be sure to get up early to see the sunrise over the temple!

Amazing. Surpassed all expectations - wonderful! Our guide took us through starting at the exit and working our way to the entrance so we missed most of the crowds and were able to take photos with no-one else around for the first hour or so.

For the history buffs. Entrance to the park is available in 1/3/7 day passes. You don't have to do multi-day passes sequentially but there is a certain period of validity. One day will set you back $20 USD, three days $40 and seven days $60.We did three days traipsing through the temples. I loved it for all the musings about who must have lived in these places, the history and the differing architectural styles. My friend would have preferred only one day covering the best parts. But then I love architecture and she's not into that as much.Guides are available to show you more about the temples.
