If you can't afford a guide, I'd suggest going to the Angkor Museum in Siem Reap first as a great deal of the history is explained here (about $12 USD for entry).Be prepared for being hot and sweaty. Even in the dry season the weather is warm and you'll be walking a great deal. My friend and I are both very fit (she runs half-marathons and I'm a body-builder) but we were both exhausted after three days climbing up and down stairs in that heat. Make sure you hydrate sufficiently!You will be harrassed by small children trying to sell you postcards for $1. You will learn to ignore this and keep walking. They know how to ask in multiple languages but don't understand much of what you say, so no reasoning or logic will work with them. It feels cruel.Overall this is a very worthwhile adventure.

What you come to Siem Reap to See!. The ruins of Angkor are what everyone comes to see, and they do not disappoint, although at times they are very crowded with visitors. The park surrounding the ruins is lovely. This is truly a world-class attraction. We loved having our own tuk-tuk driver to take us from place to place, and sometimes visited in the morning and again later in the day to avoid the mid-day heat. We made the mistake of visiting Angkor Wat just before closing time, thinking we'd miss the crowds. Not so, because entrance is free just before closing and tour buses took advantage of that, so there was wave after wave of groups.

Sunset ticket gets you in the next day. if you buy your 20 dollar ticket at 4:45 pm or later (the temples start to close at 5:30 pm) the ticket is good for the following day. You can get a 2 or 3 day ticket as well as the one day, check if it makes sense for you price and timing wise
The temples are remarkable. Other than the Pyramids the most spectacular thing ever built by humans, this is a must visit there is so much to see and do
Must visit. Its a good place to see beautiful pieces of Vishnu(Preah Nare), siva(Preah Eiso) and Khemr Architectural pieces of historical importance.

Amazing temples. This was somewhere I had always wanted to visit and it exceeded all expectations for the sheer size and beauty of the temples. It is an amazing place to spend a day and then revisit as we did, this time returning on bicycles to travel more slowly through the beautiful forests surrounding the temples. The restoration work being done will make some temples even more accessible. This is definitely the hi light of my trips to Asia.

Stupendously interesting and beautiful. AMAZING sites. Well worth two solid days to visit both the Angkor Wat/Thom etc loop and the special, earlier sites. Wear your best shoes, bring plenty of water, sunscreen, and bug spray. Women must have their knees covered to enter certain temples, so wear a skirt or peddle-pushers.
Best place in Siem Reap. I loved all the ruins there in Angkor Wat. Better if you have enough time to visit all the complex since it is extremely huge!

don't miss the sunrise!. we went twice to see the sunrise, and each time was worth it. Once, opposite the main canal separating angkor wat from the main road, and the next day, within the temple, on the left hand side of one of the pools just in front of the main building. The reflection in the water amidst the lotus flowers was stunning.

Amazing Place. I've wanted to go to Angkor Wat for years and it did not let me down. We went during peak season, so the crowds were large. But the weather was perfect and the place is amazing. Make sure to see some of the "outside" sites.
crowded, but still magnificent. the busloads of rude disrespectful tourists were a downer. Go very early for best peace and quiet. a guide is very helpful.

A 3 day pass is not enough. There is so much to see - not only the Angkor Wat temple, but all the other temples too. Pace yourself, and take your time because the heat, humidity and lots of walking is tiring for the fittest! Beware the Fire Ants, and take lots of water.
Incredible. The entire UNESCO park has so many temples its impossible to see them all in a day, it is well worth taking your time as there is so much to see
Amazing sunrise. Angkor Wat is a must see in Cambodia (Siem Reap) its totally worth waking up at 5:00 to see the sunrise.

Hire a local, Get a Pass!. April is HOT! Needless to say! Stay hydrated. High season is Dec. We hired a tour guide with a car for a full day thru our Hotel Shinta Mani Club for Angkor Wat and major sites. We went with tuk tuk and bought our ticket in the late late afternoon on our travel day (ask hotel) to go buy our 3 day pass which included us to get in for the sunset. You need your ticket with you every time you enter into this big park! Don't lose it! I think we showed an ID too and took a picture for the park. Do the Sunrise at Angkor Wat, but there are so many temples to see! Go early. Avoid crowds and the heat. Use a tuk tuk driver to help you on your other days. Just map out what you want to see. Many Tuk Tuk drivers speak English. Ask your hotel for help. Have fun and EXPLORE!

awesom. It was even more botuil than we had expected. And also huge with so many temples. Actually we liked Angkor Thom the best of all. We had a guide for the first day and because of the information he gave us were able to visit on our own the second day. We rented a bike in town, but beware, the distance to the temples is far and the temparature is high.

Must see!!!. This is why you come to siem reap! The temples are beautiful but they are slowly deteriorating, so there is quite a bit of restoration occurring. Highly recommend visiting here as it is fascinating to still see the temples standing. The one downside us that the main temples have a lot of tourists (it is very crowded).
Very Historic!. Nearby Angkor Wat & Siem Reap Town. Can take tuk-tuk to this place. Nice historic buildings with old trees. NIce place to visit with family.

return visit. The ruins themselves remain spectacular and inspiring. Be careful of the ticket staff at the entrance trying to pass off to you for replacement, old or damaged US notes they claimed you just handed in to pay for entry.I witnessed 2 examples in another line in as many minutes and then got caught myself though I had handed in crisp new bills instead of the old worn 50 they tried to pass back. The huge numbers of people in line pressing to get through to obtain the photo-inclusive entry passes to quickly access the ruins in the early morning works to their advantage of finessing this very unattractive fiddle, and leaves a bad taste in the mouth of those finessed into handling what you hope is only worn rather than fake currency.

Awe inspiring. Staggeringly impressive showcase of the achievements of the Khmer empire, with the most impressive structures I have seen anywhere in the world (31 countries and counting…). The cooperation between the Cambodian authorities and outside sponsor governments and organisations had led not only to superb restoration and maintenance, but also an avoidance of touristy over-commercialisation around the temples and the whole archaeological park. There are clean, free, well-maintained toilets outside every major site. Just give yourself as much time as you can, if possible visit very early morning and from mid-afternoon onwards (or you will melt), and relax in your hotel in the middle of the day. You will have a much more enjoyable experience if you can book your own private tour and time your visits to the major temples to avoid the tour groups. Well worth visiting some of the slightly less popular or more distant temples to really absorb the echoes of the past without the distraction of crowds.
Crowded. Liked: well preservedDisliked: too many tourists. Mainland Chinese tourists behaving badly. Crowd control needed.

This is why you vist Siem Reap. If you are in Siem Reap, you are obviously here to see the temples and it is well worth the trip. Organize a private car as you can tailor your visit to your liking. The temples are very spread apart (too far to walk) and the air conditioning is a nice break from the hot sun. A one day pass for us was enough to see the big 3 temples. We got the idea of it after that and we were good.

One of best things I've ever seen, travelling.. Best time for visit is two days, with pass costing 40$. If you have enough time, buy the entry beforehand, and try to catch Angkor Wat at sunrise or sunset. The park is open for visitors from 6 AM to 6 PM.

Amazing. I did this in one day but you need two days. It is an amazing experience. I loved every piece of my trip. Try to go in the off-season. I could not take clear photos because of the sheer number of tourists.

What can I say... incredible. The temples of Siem Reap and surrounds are simply spectacular. We came back 3 times and spent 3 days the first time, and then 2 individual days later. Our favourites were Angkor Wat, Preah Khan, Banteay Srey. We took our time exploring, rather than rushing through with a tour group. Our tuk tuk driver even brought a hammock on the 2nd day. :)The beauty and enormity of these temples are incredible. An experience of a lifetime. Tip: Go at times when the tour groups are having meals (breakfast / lunch) when you'll pretty much get the temples to yourself. We got to sit in the central Angkor Wat courtyard on our own, which was a very special experience.
visit the wonderful temple in the world. I like it so much with my wife because it is the first time for her. she say it is very wonderful place

Fascinating. The various temple are all different and we wish that we could have stayed at least one more day to see more. Although Angor Wat is the most famous, I actually enjoyed Banteay Srei more and my daughter preferred Angkor Thom.
Temples in Angkor. Sunrise at the Angkor temple is an awesome sight. This is a very large place with lots of steps. So good walking shoes and a bit of stamina are essential
Wow!. Everything that we saw here took our breath away. Angkor Wat and Thom are marvels of architecture and beauty

Spectacular. Hot and sweaty as it could sometimes be, the kickass Khmer civilization made temple going at Angkor Archaeological Park worth my while. Angkor Wat was just the tip of the iceberg. There are dozens of incredibly preserved temples to tromp around and gawk at, with trees climbing out of stone, looking like bony giants' hands grabbing at these extraordinary creations of man. If you're lazy, like me, I'd recommend taking a tuk tuk on the grand tour and maybe even the short circuit routes. But if you're taking advantage of a three-day park pass, ride out to Angkor Wat on the last day. It's not very far, and it's an easy flat ride. I enjoyed the entire experience, but especially taking a long last look at Angkor after a breezy bike ride on my final day in Cambodia.

Must see and be preserved for future generations. Could not have imagined so much treasure that could be lying relatively undiscovered for so long. Cambodia is so poor yet has so much to offer! Amazing is much overused word these days but such an apt description to Angkor complex!

Unbelievably beautiful. Do not skip!. This is is easily one of the most beautiful historical sites in the world. It is a pleasure to go to because it is well organised and clean. Water and food are available easily, and it was not difficult to avoid the touristy local guides that hang around. We went by tuk-tuk- highly recommended if you want to see a lot, fast. But some of our friends did the entire complex by bicycle over 3 mornings!The sunrise(5am) is totally worth it, despite the crowds. Recommended to start the tour from the last temple, and go backward so you are flowing against the current and have the temples mostly to yourself! There is much to photograph, so a full battery, and polaroid filters are highly recommended!Things to watch out for: do organised bathroom breaks, while there are toilet facilities scattered all around the complex, sometimes you may have to walk 10-15 minutes before you can get to one.Also, its extremely hot so stay hydrated and sun-screened! In addition, there are many activities inside the temple complex that require entry ticket into the actual complex, so if you interested in zip lining, or ATV tours or hot air ballooning(and several others), you sohuld plan and buy multiple day tickets!

Love IT. I feel incredibly privileged to have come to this site, we only did two days both the temples inside and outside the park. We used the tuck tuck for inside then booked a minivan with our lovely driver for outside the park.Perfect for families, I plan to return one day and visit all the temples.

Great Simply Awesome. What a wonderful site, simply amazing and breathtaking. I extended my business trip and got the family along for the weekend. We visited most sites with a guide, it was a great experience for us and the kids.

Relive the Khmer History. Not much to elaborate since UNESCO declared it as a World Heritage Site. Just my stepping onto the bridge brought me back in time. The Angkor temple is one of a kind for me. It will usually take days to properly visit all the ruins of Angkor. The price is as following: 20$ (1 day), 40$ (3 days), 60$ (1 week). There are plenty of lodgings around Angkor Wat so need not to worry. Don't miss out the spectacular sunrise view of Angkor Wat!
Must See TV. Park is very tourist friendly with increased investment in infrastructure. Easy to obtain access to the parks and temple sites themselves are amazing.

A magical place. This was our second visit to Angkor. It is an amazing site. I still can't believe that you can walk all over and around such amazing temples. Visiting Angkor Wat at dawn was a definite highlight and worth getting up for. We bought a 3 day pass. You do not have to visit on consecutive days which was ideal for us. We hired bikes to ride around on one day and then hired a tuk-tuk for the others. An awesome experience!
Angkor Wat tour. Disliked the dust and the crowds. Historically the temple ruins are amazing and very well maintained to ensure safety of visitors.

Give Yourself Twice the Time You Think You'll Need. Angkor is fantastic, but it can be fatiguing. Even in the so-called winter/dry season it gets very hot and humid, and traipsing through the temples can drain one of energy. We began intending to tour morning and afternoon, as suggested by some of the itineraries in the guidebooks. But we found ourselves drained after 4 or so hours and needed to repair to the hotel to relax and swim. We would then go out for a short sunset visit before dinner. So,if you want to see all the sights in a so-called 2 day itinerary , give yourself four or at least three. Only the true fanatics of ancient Khmer architecture and culture will require more than four days -- the temples begin to resemble one another after a while and the returns diminish after the "biggies" (Angkor Wat itself and a few others) have been explored. My advice is to stay four nights, giving you three full days. Otherwise you will get worn out. And one more thing: unfortunately the authorities allow vendors into many of the ruins themselves, so you are pestered by them as you try to tour the sights. This is unfortunate but nothing can be done.

Majestic Angkor. We really enjoyed the tour of the Angkor temples. We went without a guide as we could not get one on time, but having read ahead and armed with a guide book, we got by. We were blown away by the architecture and the sunrise at Angkor was simply magnificient. Although Dec is supposed to be a cool month, it was still hot, humid and dusty. Bring a lot of wet issues to wipe your dusty face and also a small towel to wipe the sweat.The bit we did not enjoy that much was that it was impossible to get a picture without it being photo-bombed by one of the thousands there at the same time. There was no crowd control and people simply did what they wanted to there. I am concerned about the preservation efforts at the Angkor Wat, and hope it will still be there for generations to come.

AMAZING. Had been wanting to go for ages and it did not disappoint. Such an amazing place. We visited popular temples at off times and had a lot of success avoiding the crowds. One day, we were the only people at three of the temples we visited. And, other temples only had a handful of people. It sucks to get up at 5am, but get there at sunrise and hit the temples you want to see most while the tours are at Angkor Wat for sunrise. Then, do Angkor Wat during lunch when all the tour groups are eating. One day, we were there from 5:30 am - 1pm and the next 6am - 10am. The second day we avoided the heat and all of the crowds.
Awesome. As good if not better than I imagined. Pace yourself if with kids as a lot to see. I would finish with Angkor Wat and explore some of the other sites first.

Pick you time. If you bother with sunset or sunrise, TAKE EARPLUGS.Banteay Srei - get there before 7:30am. Tour buses start arriving around 8am. If you go after 8am, take ear plugs if you want any notion of serenity.Hire a bike and go to the small temples not on the circuit, they have a much more "just discovered" feel - go early and you might even get them all to yourself.

Super touristy, but don't let that stop you from visiting. I visited during the super-high season of end December and boy, was it chock-a-block full of tourists from all over the world. Nonetheless, it is an awe-inspiring place to visit. Angkor Wat, Bayon and all the many ruins in the area are just amazing. Get a good guide, don't just go by yourself to stand there and gawk stupidly at the ruins. You won't appreciate what you're seeing unless you have someone to explain every detail to you. A guide book just won't do it. The guides are relatively cheap to hire (about USD40-50 for a full day), you'll be contributing directly to local jobs and you will walk away with a deep appreciation of the place, its place in history and the magnificence of the ancient empires. Highly recommended.

Exhausted but very satisfied. We did not realize that the park is huge and it consisted with so many great and beautiful temples. We took the 3 days pass, yet we felt that we still missed so many interesting sights.

Unmissable, but try to avoid the crowds for a better experinces. I'd avoid seeing the popular rising sun at Angkor as it is overcrowded and not really worth it. Use instead the dawn to start your visit early which is the best time to go inside the most famous ones (Angkor Wat, Bayon or Ta Prom)When the crowds start to be intense, opt for the least famous or farer, like Bantsey Srei. Dont settle and dont contract bus tour, that are bad for pollution and dont give you a real sense of the park. Op for a tuk tuk service (up to for people) or even better, rent a mountain bike and look for a good map, you will be slower, but thankful.

Amazing. What more is there to be said. Maybe wait 20 minutes if you see a chinese tour bus pull in at the same time you arrive at a temple. Otherwise, can get massively crowded. But what do you expect at one of the worlds most important and amazing sites.

Temples are awesome to see but.... If you are planning to see the sunrise/sunset only go if there is a cloudless weather forecast - we tried both but saw neither. Consider taking your own food, the restaurants onsite are awful! Be warned there are very few toilet facilities around the site and when you do find one they are are filthy. For the high entrance fee and the huge amount of visitors they could do with improving the facilities.

Yes yes yes. Buy a three day pass, get your bikes out and go explore! The first day we went to the more famous and touristic places. First ta phrom (the tomb raider temple), where we arrived early in the morning. It was beautiful and exciting and still pretty quiet. Then we made our way to Angkor Tom and obviously Angkor wat. The second you see it appear you understand what it's all about. The view is majestic and I can't believe it's that impressive. Inside there were too many people, but it was still impressive and made me feel very humble and awed. The next day we did the bigger circuit, with smaller temples and way less tourists. For us his was actually so much more awesome than Angkor wat itself. Some temples and ruins we had almost to ourselves, we climbed stairs, explored hidden rooms and felt history with every step we took, without being disturbed! Definitely go to all these places, you won't regret you did. They're impressive and they're yours for the exploring and admiring!The third day we went to a few smaller ruins and repeated some of the ones from the day before, like ta Phrom. This time there were buses and buses full of people (as it was later on the day) and we enjoyed it a lot less that way. So go as early as you can and you'll be able to experience these amazing structures without disturbance and without having to imagine what the look and sound like (peaceful!) without the hords of tourists. Loved it, loved it, loved it, loved it! Get your bike out and explore. It's been a few days ago now and I can still feel the thrill and happiness of being there.

well worth the trip! Astounding!. That human kind so many hundreds of years ago could build such an amazing temple to house God, no doubt God lives through humans! So grateful I could experience this first hand! Pictures could never do it justice.

Sunrise. great place go at sunrise but go to the back to photograph with the light behind you, if you are photographing from the front it will all be back lit as well as there are about 1000 other people trying to do the same thing.

Go early or late and miss the crowds!. Words can't do it justice. A shame about the crowds though - we went at the crack of dawn and it was gorgeous and quiet. Remember to wear modest clothing (cover shoulders and knees).

many temples. We visited 4 temples in the Angkor Archeological Park in 3 days. There are many similarities among them. Seeing how bright the Big Dipper was while waiting for the sun to rise at Angkor Wat was memorable. Ta Prohm Temple was unique in that it is overgrown by huge trees and Tomb Raider was filmed here.

A must see. Take care if going for sunrise, especially if like us, you forget to take a torch!! stone slabs are uneven. Lots of steps to go up & down throughout, but a small price to pay to see this wonderful structure
A must visit. If you love history and if you love nature and the power of nature, you must visit this place. This was unforgettable experience and i would go back again..

Awesome and mystifying. Angkor Wat, Angkor Tom and the tourist circuit are well worth doing with a guide by tuk tuk. Buy a pass for 2 days plus as having visited with a guide it is worth returning under your own steam and spending time soaking up the atmosphere especially early morning, late afternoon and simply walking away from where the crowds gather. A guide book can help fill in gaps in the guides knowledge or language.

Too crowded, better wear mask. This is really a special place, you can see the natural power nibbling historical building by time. But due to repair and maintain project, the visit area is narrow down. And too many visitors came. Besides, during the dry season, dust is everywhere. Better bring mask.
Must seen. The entire Archaelogical Park can be visited by a tuk-tuk and can be organised for 2 days. It is useful to hire a local guide.
Magnificent!. It is just unbelievable, unreal place. One of the must-not-miss place if you are dropby in Siem Reap.

Amazing!. These archaeological sights are breathtaking. Visit the National Museum in Phnom Penh before hand to get oriented.Four full days there required going at a fairly quick pace, and braving the exhausting heat (90+ degrees/60% humidity in December). However, we managed to explore 19 sites in 4 days, thanks to our wonderful driver Mr. Pon Puthy ("Thom"). We would strongly recommend him (ponputhy@hotmail.com). Starting out early (7am or before sunrise), is a wise idea, to avoid the crowds and the heat.If you have the time, take a few more days, and take a mid-day break back at the hotel for lunch and the pool, before heading out again till sunset.
Stunning. Set in a jungle area, the temples here are divine. Well worth the walk to see them all. Avoid the local markets as they are very pushy!

Mysterious place. There is no question about it. If you have possibility, take a plane from Bangkok (BMK - Air Asia) and go and see this entire area. We have landed at 14:00 and took taxi for entire day (30$) where we seen three wats. The next day we have seen 13 places and went to the air port back to bangkok. It was enough for us. ON top, food is quite good, but instead of hotel go outside.

Magnificent!. A huge complex full of architectural wonders. It is a must visit place if you are in south east asia.I would recommend getting there early in the morning to avoid the crowds.You can easily spend 2/3 days here exploring all the amazing temples. Taking a tuk tuk is a great way to get around as the temples are spread out. We hired a driver for the 2 days, who was very nice, good value and was happy to follow our itinerary or suggest temples himself. His name is Mr Neang, and he can be contacted on +855 12 24 2619. This is a breathtaking part of the world.

amazing!!. This was an eye opener and full of interesting history. The scale of the temples is something you have to see in person. Go with a guide who can fill you in on why these were constructed as they were.
BEST IN WORLD. One of best places I visted in World. Fantastic anthient temples in jungle. Amazing temples loacted on huge area best to see by tuk tuk or bicycle for 2-3 days
Awesome. Quite simply the most spectacular place I've ever visited. The thrill of wandering Indiana Jones-style throughout these ancient temples, amid the sultry tropical forest, never wore off.

A Magical Place. Go to Angkor Wat. Spend more than a couple days there. Take your time to soak up all of the history that has been left behind. There are so many temples and that all seem to have different characteristics. Visit the main temples, but if you have a chance, go father afield and see some of the lesser known temples. Climb to the highest points if allowed and look out at the beautiful landscape of Cambodia. Even after three visits, I would return. There is something magical about the temples and ruins of Cambodia.

One of the highlights of my trip to Asia. . Where to start....... This place is amazing. So beautiful and varied. I could have spent days here but had to cram it into a day. The sunrise over Angkor Wat was amazing and the faces of Bayon were serenely beautiful. Loved the tomb raider temple and enjoyed generally strolling around. A must see.

Amazing stuff. Must do when visiting Cambodia. We had two full days of visiting, and the third day we went back to visit our favorite spots again. It would be good to hire a guide at least for one day, and try to get a guide that speaks English well. Tickets are quite expensive, $20 for one day and $40 for 2 and 3 days.

Amazing. I am just going to review the park as a whole since there are far too many great individual temples. The temples are just awe inspiring, and words cannot describe.However if you intend to go without a tour guide ( which I did), I would recommend that you watch some prior documentaries on Angkor wat and the Khmer reign to gain some insights into the buildings.

must do in cambodia!. most hotels offer tours - either the grand one covering the outer circle, or the smaller one covering the main ones which was really cheap with a tuk tuk! if i remember correctly, it was about USD$14 and it was split between the 2 of us. the tuk tuk can fit 4 ppl but be prepared that it will be dusty! at the end of the day my shoes were covered in dust haha. We did the smaller circle with angkor wat > bayon > ta prohm then headed to phnom bakheng for sunset. We only got the one day pass for usd$20, most of the tourists wear their ang kor wat pass in a lanyard but that seems to be useful cuz most of them do check it at the temple. We started around 12 plus so it was really hot at angkor wat and there was quite a lot of people still! We thought we could cover it really fast but by the time we came out 1.5h had passed. There were people selling palm juice and it was supposedly cold so I gave it a try but it tastes quite strange!! The top tier of ang kor wat requires tourists to be appropriately dressed - shoulders and knees to be covered. Then we headed to bayon, the temple with lots of faces! This temple is really pretty and there are plenty of nice photog spots and can be covered in a short time. Then lastly we went to ta prohm where tomb raider was filmed where the trees are growing viciously into the temple, pretty cool.Finally we headed to phnom bakheng for sunset and reached around 4.45pm, the climb was pretty mild. But it was really crowded at the top! The sunset was okay, would not be a huge loss if you miss it!

There is so much more to discover!. This whole area is vast, with archilogical work being done all over this huge site. I just hope that the treasures that are undoubtedly being discovered here are handed over to the Cambodian people & not lost to corruption??

Take a gondola ride on the moats! Ride an elephant! Preferably at sunset!. As part of our adventures by disney trip we had gondola rides for all 30 of us on the moat at sunset. Beautiful photos, birds, monkeys, men fishing in the water with nets beside you...wonderful way to step back in time. We also had TEN elephants that gave us a 20minute circle ride to two temples (the 'drivers' have a pocket for tips in the back of their jackets) and at the end of the ride, buy a pineapple from a local woman (always standing by) and take photos of feeding the big guys!
Unique. It's really unique and amazing! Go there at the sunrise and try to stay in the first line, cause there's a lot of people.

Amazing history, get a guide to go with you!. You need to see it to experience the grandness and beauty of it. No words or pictures can describe how I feel after the whole experience. A word advice, come early to visit the temples where it's less crowded. I would recommend watching the sunrise in Angkor Wat and continue the day visiting temples, as opposed to going back to hotel for breakfast. Most hotels can pack your breakfast for you. Bring energy bars, water, etc as theres not many stores in between. Different temples have different charms and attractions to it; ask your tour guide for recommendations!
Interesting. Lots to see and do - better to visit the main sites very early morning. Be sure to take some solid shoes and a hat!
Must see. This is a very large temple, on this occasion marred by a large helium balloon with a video camera being flown in front of the main temple, ruining the view. Otherwise, well worth visiting.
Amazing, fantastic, unique. Nothing like it anywhere. Worth it with guide although crowds are annoying. Return visit was worth it to further absorb the "vibe".

Temples for Indian stories. Dislike: people crowding at the sunrise time!Like: everything including the history. For an India, it is a surreal experience to walk around the temples. Indian mythological stories abound on the temples. It's an archaelogical wonder, that is hardly preserved in India (say Hampi or Warangal- around the same time period), but much better appreciated in Cambodia. A must see for all enthusiasts of Hindu mythology and archeaology.
Stunning. A must see for world travellers, the sites here are quite incredible, try and get a personal guide as it will enhance the trip
Angkor Wat: A Three Day Visit. Made it to all the temple areas in three days. Anything less and you will not get the full experience.

Unbelievably fantastic. This is a must-see if you are any kind of a traveller at all. The world-famour Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, which you have heard so much about, live every bit up to their billing and more. The vandalism takes a bit out of the charm with headless idols and missing statues, but some of the frescoes and statuary are remarkably well preserved. Hats off to all the conservation efforts that have gone on.
An amazing and beautiful history site. An amazing and beautiful history site worth spending time to explore and enjoy. You may spend as little as 1 day but you could also spend 3-4 days as well.

History in the Jungle. I came to Siem Reap the first time in 2001. At that time, there were still warnings about safety in Cambodia. The town had a few dusty streets, many of the guides spoke only Khmer, and any organization around the temples was not apparent. Now, 13 years later I am so impressed with the Cambodian people and their efforts to preserve, highlight and share their cultural and historical wealth. Angkor Wat is not to be missed, Ta Prohm is a testament to the power of man and nature. The story of Bayon is one of a great love for a ruler. Bantey Srea will move you with the beautifully preserved Apsaras and other reliefs. If you travel to South-East Asia, make the time to see the temples in Siem Reap.

Ahh the Crown Jewel of Siem Reap!. Lovely, lovely visit. Went to four of the sites in this vast Archaeological park, and each were a story of their own. There is no visit to Siem Reap that is complete without a visit to this large treasure complex. Whether you appreciate history, culture, architecture or simply breathtaking sights, there is something for everyone here (unless you are a jaded heart)

Go see it all..... Make sure you have a few days to see the temples as there are a lot of them. Ankor Thom and the Bayon temple, Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm and the pink temple to name a few. Take your time and if possible, I would highly recommend taking a guide in order to get the best out of your trip.Its quite fascinating, especially once you get a bit of an insight into the wavering dominance of the Hindu and Buddhist religions.

So much to see. Wow I loved the entire park. I wanted to see Angkor Wat of course, but had no idea how much there is to see in the entire park. I recommend the 3 day pass even if you're there for only 2 days. It's worth it. I visited the park 3 times in 3 days. A full day tour, came back the next day for sunset, and the following morning for sunrise and more exploring around what I didn't see the previous days.

Eye Opening Ancient Architectures. I enjoy visiting all of the ruins/temples in Siem Reap. They're packed with history and detailed carvings and impressive structures.One thing I have to share about my own personal point of view is that if one wants to take their time, otherwise, it only takes 2 full day to visit most of the big and nice temples. After awhile, all of the small temples start to look like a pile of bricks piling on top of each other. If one really want to learn about the history then it's can be done by reading about them through books or online research. I'd say a better way to spend the extra days if one want to spend more time in Siem Reap is to visit the villages and spend time with the local families.

Get a good guide!. Visiting in the afternoon was hot and humid. Get a 3 day temple pass. We found the guide recommended by a Tul-Tuk driver very difficult to understand. We did not make that mistake again.The temple complex includes several Wats and palaces and is in beautiful gardens. This is the place we traveled do far to see - it did not disappoint The site is very well looked after.

Worth the wait!. Although there is a bee line going into the park, it's worth the wait. Just be sure that you have enough power bank on hand as there are just endless photo taking opportunities in the area. Great place to spend a couple of days while in Siem Reap.

Wonder of the Ancient World. Angkor Wat is one of the wonders of the ancient world and is a "must see" once in your lifetime.If your time is limited the main attractions are Angkor Wat itself, Ta Prohm (better known as the "Temple of Doom", the Bayon, and the Elephant Terrace. This will give you a good taste of what the rest is like.If the weather is right and the skies are clear is is a good idea to get to Angkor Wat before sunrise and watch it come up behind the towers of the ancient monument.I have been to Angkor many times and try to imagine what it would have been like in its heyday, with Hindu and later Buddhist monks, the king and his household, the palace officials, the bureaucrats and the common people who commanded an empire that stretched all over present day Cambodia, Laos, pasts of Vietnam, most of Thailand, and right down to the Malaysian border.

A must see. Liked everything about it, the beautiful way to see how nature works really. We found some very quite spots within the temple. It was so nice to just sit there and soak all the surrounding. Definitely a must see. Nothing to dislike.

What an experience. It really did tick all the boxes. If you love history, architecture, photography, asian culture and all else in between, you will, like us love this place. We spent two full days exploring this area and felt like we could have easily added an extra day. Hired a driver which made it far easier than trying to cycle on a hot steamy day. Superb.

this is the place that has all the temples you've heard of. Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, Bayon, and numerous others are in this park. Allow a full day for these three temples. To see all the temples in the park, multiple days are needed.

Simply Incredible.. Rather than review each monument individually, the place as a whole can easily be summed up with one word: WOW. If not Angkor Wat alone, how the zone as a whole isn’t formally designated as one of the manmade wonders of the world is baffling. I would recommend renting out a bicycle (preferably the mountain bike style which will cost you $4-5 in Siem Reap) and riding out to the park yourself. It is not far and the freedom you get from the bicycle is truly rewarding, it has the added bonus of being able to park up nice and close to the temples as well. In contrast to many claims, I wouldn’t say that sunrise at Angkor Wat is essential. Unless it is a rare perfectly clear morning (hard to deduce before you arrive) it can be fairly underwhelming, as it was for me.

Memorable trip. Visiting Angkor was a dream come true. The rich history and the amazing architecture made all the bumpy roads, walking and dust worthwhile. Our itinerary included Angkor, the Kulen Mountain, Koh Ker and Bang Malea. It was a wonderful trip, and the agency's promise of "temples without crowds" was indeed true. Plus, we had a fantastic guide who made the Angkor story come alive.

Amazing piece of history . This a truly breathtaking experience ; it is amazing to see the people managed to build with the most rudimentary tools. Fascinating the change of hands from Buddhist to Hindu throughout the centuries. A must visit by far.
Too many tourists. Impossible to get a real sense of the place as it is so overrun by hordes of tourists from all over the world, starting at the crack of dawn.

Not hype at all!. Ticked one off the bucket list and it was even better than expected. The temples are lovely, and with mix of restored ones and ruins and over 200 temples to see it wasnt as crowded as I would have expected. I did a mountain bike your with a private guide and he led us away from the usual crowds. While Angkor Wat was crowded, it wasnt overwhelmingly so.
Best one . Don't even bother going to the others Lol this one was simply amazing! We wish we went there in the am instead of afternoon due to people

The worlds greatest monument. Seeing Angkor Wat made me speachless (I would like to go back in time for just one day, to have a look at Angkor Wat when it was build, there are still reliefs in good shape, but how must they have looked thousend years ago)

Excellent - guide important.. We had only one day to visit the area but in hindsight actually felt it was enough.Sunrise at Angkor Wat a must see, and further visits to several other of the sites were interesting and a great way to spend a day. After 9 hours in the heat we did feel a bit worn out, and unless you are very interested in the background history, sites do become similar. It is dusty, so make your choice between Tuk-Tuk and Car carefully; and we would recommend getting a guide from a recommended source - ours greatly increased our enjoyment and was well worth his fee and a good tip.

Incredible display of skills by man and nature . When you see these temples and ruins you are just struck by how these structures where built without machinery. Men and elephants ! Unfortunately man and then nature also has caused taken its toll and I'm happy to see that man has taken up the reins once again to restore them.

Mind blowing. THis is a must do on any bucket list. The drive through the forests, through the moat of angkor wat to get to other temples, each so incredibly unique and beautiful in its ruins, absolutely worth the hot midday sun. I cannot wait to return to visit all the rest of the temples.

expensive but worth it. It costs about $20 a day to enter the park but there are many temples and ruins to see, we spent three days exploring which felt right for us. There are many land mine victim bands playing khmer music which adds atmosphere but the stall holders and kids selling trinkets are annoying!
Plan for twice as much time as you first thought. This site is huge, plan on a lot of walking. Book air conditioned car and driver from your hotel to get you around, a tuktuk will batter you

Amazing place, worth more than a day of your time. We were only in Reap for three days, with the first day exploring the town followed by two days in the archeological park. We paid a tuk tuk extra to drive us around for three days. The extra was to discourage him from keep taking us to the places where they clearly get commission on sales - overpriced and overbearing shops and 'attractions'. Worked a treat and he was more communicative about the area and history rather than focused on commission. The archeological area is amazing. You need to bite the bullet and do the dawn at Angkor Wat - unfortunately we hit cloud but hopefully you'll be luckier. Despite leaving the hotel at 05:00, the crowd was too big for us to get near the pool for photos. If you want the classic sunrise reflected in the pool shot, you need to be there even earlier. Everyone has their favourite temples but, for what it's worth, my top three are Bayon, Ta Prohm and Preah Khan. Even smaller ones hold real surprises, however, and there are many spots to just sit and contemplate. Key advice? Don't rush to see as many as you can. Pick a few each day and enjoy each one's unique character.
Wow!. Some amazing architecture! Mind the steps if you are game to try them... and don't forget your sunhat!

A surprise at every turn. Just when you think you couldn't see another temple that will take your breath away, you will be amazed. The saddest thing though is that the steep ticket prices of 40 USD for a 3 day pass doesn't go to Cambodia much (only about 10 percent). Vietnam has been given the ownership of Angkor for 90 years or so (facts are a little iffy) and you would think you could support a deserving economy but you end up supporting a private organisation and a neighboring company (it's something Cambodians are sore about and might prove a conversation starter with your Tuk Tuk driver). I managed to get around the park without a guide pretty ok but I am sure having a guide has it's perks (there are many nearby). Some temples are more crowded than the other and I strongly encourage trying to avoid the crowds to get the best experience (this means trying to get into the temple while everyone competes for the sunrise shot and avoiding) and trying to max out even your afternoons once everyone heads for lunch. I managed to get into some temples more than once and was amazed at how I kept finding new things that amazed me.

Visually stunning. I spent a full day exploring some of the temples and areas in the park: Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, The Elephant Terrace and Ta Prohm. I could have spent much more time, if I had it. I was very surprised at the remarkable condition of most of the temples, and the level of detail still visible in various carvings. You can still walk around just about anywhere without restriction, and that's the way I like to do it: at my own pace, exploring those areas that speak to me. An inspiring day.

Mother natures beauty. A stunning surprise. What we experienced was covered for man years, you will be very impressed, by natures art ability. A nice walk, and many photo ops. Use a guide, Trails of Indochina works.

Angkor Wat. Angkor Wat is as impressive as its reputation. However, it is really crowded with tourists. Our guide took us into the temple in a part that was not crowded. It is hard to get very many photographs without other tourists in them. Some of the other temples in Archaeological Park are not as crowded as the Angkor Wat itself. If you have enough time and a good guide you can see other temples that less crowded.

Temples galore. We took a day trip but really that after visiting 3 we could have missed the others as very similar but we heard of others who spent 2 days there so probably just us - will not forget the thrill of arriving at the first temple.

Incredible. I spent 3 days and saw 15 temples. And boy! what an experience, I did get very tired walking up steps, but I it was worth the pain. Amazing sights to see. And I can cross Ta Prohm off my bucket list. I see so many pictures of this famous tree over the temple, now I have my own to brag about. I had a very good tuk tuk driver to take me to see all of the temples. I suggest its the best way to visit all of them. I got a tour guide for Angkor Wat which you can pick up outside the temple. Would have liked an elephant ride, but ran out of time. I think allow yourself 3 days to see them all without rushing through. Your national park entry allows you 3 days and that can be broken up over 5 or 7 days to use it before it expired. This has been the high light of my 6 week trip so far. Can't be missed!

You have to see it with your own eyes. Pictures nor words do this place justice. We spent three days exploring and hit several of the highlights, but maybe saw 30% of what this place has to offer. Absolutely do the sunrise at Angkor Wat, the memory of the temples reflecting in the water is worth the early wake up and crowds. Get your own tuk tuk driver for the day and simply explore.

Where does the ticket money go?. I agree with Patrick B. and other reviewers that a 3-day pass is essential. We took a 1-day pass because we had many other activities planned, but it's very difficult to spend a lot of time and fully appreciate each temple when you have to fit it all into one day - especially with children aged 12 and 9 who get tired and need a break. I agree also with the comment that the many children hard-selling postcards and other goods was upsetting, but it was also a good lesson for our children about the pampered lives we in Western countries lead.Having said that, what was even more upsetting and extremely discouraging was to hear a number of locals say that 90% of the ticket money goes directly to a single wealthy family in town - not the upkeep of the temples! As you'll see from signs at various temples, there are many government-funded organisations and NGOs from Japan, Korea, China and elsewhere which restore and maintain the temples. If this is true, then it's no wonder that children are forced into selling postcards to tourists while a corrupt elite get rich on Cambodia's remarkable heritage. Pretty disgusting, really.

Not hugely overwhelming but none the less amazing. It was obviously beautiful, but having read all the history and how it got really ruined by the Indians with acid etc it really showed! there was also lots of scaffolding around the place that underwhelmed me a bit obviously its still a must but packed to the rafters full of tourists! i thought it was incredible but wouldnt probably go back!

Spectacular. Angkor Wat is beyond our poor power to describe, but represents just a small part of the once mighty capital of the Angkorian Empire. We bought monthly tickets giving us 7 visits, 60 dollars each very well spent. So much to see!
overwhelming. It's so amazing and big that there are lots of places to get away from the crowds. don't bother with the 'sunrise thing'.

Awe inspiring. Amazing park, if you have time then definitely spend at least 3 days here if you can so as not to rush anything.We used tuktuk's to take us on the large and small circles on day 1 and 2, then on the third day (which was cloudy) we cycled so we could be a bit more relaxed and see the bits they didn't stop at i.e. gates. The third was by far our favourite day.Do be prepared for some serious heat and a lot of hard selling at every temple, including children which can be upsetting. There are toilets dotted around the park, also don't miss out on Banteay Srei as it is beautiful, but a long ride out which still needs a Angkor Wat ticket.

Blown Away. Booked a private guide for day 1, which was well worth it. Unbelievable how beautiful it was, the history and atmosphere, hard to believe when this temple was built with the moat around it, amazing. Need to try and dodge the huge crowds but your guide has the best knowledge of what times and where to go first. Will take you to a nice restaurant for lunch, then off again to another temple maybe the well known modern name Tomb Raider. Day 2 went on our own and did the outer route of temples visiting the famous ladies temple, built well before Angkor Wat the carvings were exquisite, well worth the trip. 2 day pass is the same price as a 3 day pass 40 US, must show before entering any of the temples. SO happy I was able to see these wonderful sights.

Phenomenal. The ancient temples, the reflection of the temple the main temple in the water. Sitting on top of Shiva temple watching the sun set. were wonderful experiences. The limbs of trees entwined lovingly against buildings astounding and awe inspiring. Just try and ignore the peddlers selling things for a dollar or more unless you like to bargain.

Amazing historical site. We really enjoyed our tours of Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and some of the others in the Angkor Archaeological Park. Angkor Wat is very large, so expect a lot of walking. It's also very hot and humid, so bring a fan and wear comfortable clothing. It's amazing what the people built back in the 9-12th centuries, and so much is still there. The moat around Angkor Wat was about 300 yard wide, and was all hand dug.

Modern wonder of the world. A great remnant of Cambodias rich past.To be honest I think the rush to get up for dawn over Angkor Wat is over rated. Often no great sunrise and unless your an avid photographer why bother.Enjoy the variety of Wats and stop for refreshments along the wayTim tuk the perfect way to visit

Must visit.... The history and atmosphere of just being there is awesome, Took some priceless pictures..:) Try to go there early in the morning so it's nice and cool, as need to walk a little. Comfortable shoes recommended.

One of the 7 wonders of the world. our hotel arranged a private guide for the 4 of us......we went for the sunrise.....amazing.....after that he took us around the back to start to avoid the huge crowds.....it was great.....although we spent only one day....it was great.....the heat and humidity was to much for us for more than that......there was live music....very nice and after hours of showing us some of the most wonderful carvings you could ever see.....we were taken to a small market to get a snack....got something local with coconut...loved it..
beautiful but crowed. i lacked out as it was raining heavily so most tourists went away, start either very early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the crowds

Unsustainable tourism is ruining this historic treasure. The site itself ranks amongst the best in the world. Pity that it is managed so poorly.Armies of tourists are making very visible damage to the artefacts through climbing and touching things that they are not supposed to. Graffiti (painted and carved) can be found in Angkor Wat. Visitors show disrespect to the ancient cultures by flouting the rules and wearing inappropriate attire.I guess that the Vietnamese company that effectively owns Angkor (and gives very little back to Cambodia) is more interested in short-term exploitation rather than genuine conservation. It's no wonder that UNESCO have voiced concerns.

Well, the MUST HAVE SEEN in cambodia. We went for a single day ticket.There are also three day tickets available. From my point of view one day is sufficient to produce like 1k photos of stones ;)There are plenty of natives selling drinks and simple foods.

Excellent in many ways. It is just something that must be seen and experienced. It was better earlier, when you could rent a motorcycle and go around by yourself. Now you have to hire a guide and a car or motorcycle, but still it´s magnificent.

Archaeology at its best. This is one of the worlds top archaeological attractions and truly deserves this distinction. To explain it here would do it no justice. It is so massive, complex, and awe inspiring that any synopsis here would do it no justice.

We stopped by here two times on our visit. We came for sunrise and returned on a different day around lunch time. Amazing both times! Our 5am visit was crowded with early risers but our great guide found a spot away from the crowds where we were able to see the sunrise, we then ventured over area packed with tourists and that was fun as well. We decided to go back on another day at about lunch time and many of the tourists were on break for lunch so it was much less crowded and we were able to get some really fantastic photos. Yes there are many vendors and people but I can't imagine missing this fantastic site.

Living with legends!. If you've ever watched an adventure movie where ancient ruins recovered from the jungle set the stage for amazing discovery, this place is a MUST SEE. You will need at least one full day (better to spend two) and you will be exhausted, but this place ranks near Machu Picchu and Tikal for us. Learn as much as you can before your visit. There is much to absorb and appreciate here. Hint: tuk-tuks for an entire day from Siem Reap are cheap and effective. We started at sunrise at Angkor and the thousands and thousands of people that were there were not what we expected. If you start early, you might start at Ta Prohm instead, and miss the crowds.
Well worth tired legs. Come early to beat the heat and crowds. Angkor is a must do in Siem reap! It is on the tour loop so expect many people. Take time to take in different corners of the compound.

One of the highlights of our wonderful tour of Cambodia. Very busy with tourists, as expected. Good idea to do it with a guide. Need to be good on your feet to come down the areas with steps. No hand rails. Our second visit was at sunrise, and was very special, only spoiled by the persistence of vendors while we were trying to watch and take photos.
Many temples to visit In the same area. Limit the visit to maximum 6 temples because and the end of the day it is ALL the same The forest surrunding the temples is very impressive
must see!. amazing and beautiful -- well worth the money to get a guide and learn a lot about this amazing place!
Amazing. fascinating, the preservation work is incredible, lots of walking and it's always worth taking a small umbrella along, either to protect yourself from the sun or the rain!
Too Much Tourist. Go later during the day is ok as well, the sunrise might not all worth it but do come for the sunset

Fantastic. Brilliant to visit the site - but try not to pack in too much to a day. Stick to 4-5 temples per day to get the most out of it.I highly recommend Angkor Wat, Bayon at Angkor Thom, Preah Khan and Ta Prohm if you can visit in the morning. Ta Som is also well worth a visit if you can manage it too - small but with fantastic carvings and aspara.

Iconic. The number of tourists at the park was, as expected, quite a few. With such an iconic landmark, I didn't think it would be deserted. Even so, with a tuktuk driver, it was easy to navigate the area, and the maps are detailed enough to find your way. I don't feel like a personal tour guide would have given me much more enjoyment, most of the tuktuk drivers seemed to be knowledgeable about the area. It was definitely worth the trip.

Revisit Angkor Wat. 5 years after my first visit, I find Angkor Wat similarly amazing and intriguing. With the help of a tour guide, I skipped the homework of studying the details and history of the temples. Every wall and pillar has a story to tell. Every picture an art piece. It's good to spend more time to look at the details and skip some less important adjacent temples. Just imagine the splendor of the temples long ago when they were filled with dancers, hermits and royalties.Sunrise and sunset are amazing but fully packed.

Unexpected Beauty. I saw it in a movie now I saw it in person. The Angkor Archaeological Park is really amazing. Cambodians were indeed talented and visionary. I can only imagine what's in their mind when they built this temple from scratch. The structure withstand the test of time and for me to see and feel it is unforgettable. Don't forget to bring your camera coz every shot is worth it. Some temples are undergoing some repair but still the place is safe. Must visit this place before you die.
Wow!. Do not try to fit in more than 2 or 3 temples a day as you will be 'temples out'. Instead, take your time and sit and soak up the temple around you.

Should be a must on everyone's bucket-list. I'll admit I didn't know a lot about what I was coming to see but this was truly amazing. Like Macchu Pichu this place left me in awe of what was achieved centuries ago. Although 3 days of temples can get very tiring the variety of the temples continually picked up my enthusiasm. We got a 3 day pass and did it over 4 days with a rest day which I highly recommend to recharge the batteries.It is near impossible to pick a favourite temple as they all have varying qualities but I would put the following on your must see list:- Angkor Wat- Bayon- Ta Prohm- Banteay Sri- Preah KhanPlease remember the significance of these sites and treat them with respect. That also includes wearing the appropriate clothing as I witnessed women in particular not being given access to the temples due to inappropriate attire. Don't complain if you're turned away - ignorance is no excuse.It can be physically demanding as there are a lot of steps - some of which are very steep. It is extremely worthwhile though and a must for all travellers.
Everything is just magic. Brings you back into time! Everything about it is just chained and woven together, the land, the location, the structure and the history behind it is just mesmerizing!

Words can not describe. I have never seen anything so magnificent. I hired a private driver and a guide for two days....very inexpensive. As we were driving out the first day, I kept having the driver stop the car so I could take photos. The beauty is almost overwhelming. You must get a ticket prior to entering. My guide took care of everything except they did take my photo which they put on the ticket.....very official looking. I got a 3 day ticket and the building to purchase in located at the entrance. If you take a Tuk Tuk, they will know where to stop or the guard will stop and guide you to the correct location. I did bike out to the park on my third day but traffic is bad so this can be a bit dicey.
Unbelievable area. The archeological park is far more than Angkor Wat. There is so much to see. Do a little reading beforehand and then look for the features mentioned

Magical experience not to be missed. Spent three days in Siem Reap and it was a unbelievable experience. It would have been easy to stay alot longer as there is so much more to see. There are many ways to see the temples and because there is so much to see we used a guide who gave us a brilliant insight into the history of the area and the significance of each site. Day one we visited Bayon Temple, Phimeanakas , Baphuon and Ta Prohm Temple (where Tomb Raider was filmed) and afternoon at the magnificent Angkor Wat temple.Second day visited Banteay Srei, the Royal City of Preah Khan, Neak Pean built on a small circular island and of smaller temples of Ta Som, East Mébon, Preah Rup.Third morning was the Rolous Group which are the earliest temples in the Angkor area- the Bakong Temple mountain, the funerary temple of Preah Ko and Lolei Temple.It is very hot and humid touring all the temples and there are endless locals selling souvenirs which can get a little annoying, if you buy from one there are 10 more all trying to sell more postcards and scarves.It is just an awesome place to visit and of course Angkor Wat is the jewel in the crown it is worth the extreme humidity, souvenir sellers and crowds. We arranged our guide through a tour company before we got there and although you can get a guide book and do it yourself, our guide had excellent English and showed us the best of what the area had to offer.

Genuinely impressive. Can't really find the words. It was unending and spectacular. Everywhere we turned there was another fantastic temple to explore. Favourites were Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat. Don't ride a bicycle - walking around temples all day in the heat is exhausting enough!Do bring A TON OF WATER and an umbrella or a hat for the sun. We sweat so much that sunscreen couldn't stay on our faces/necks and got sunburns.

totally worth it. the variety òf structures, details, jungle location, accessability, beauty lives up to reputation. skimpy signing, a good local guide very worthwhile (Gate1 guide: Sarnak ễxcellentvery crowded in high season & huge ảrea; stay mỏre dáys ìf you can--town & museum are also nice

History made, make history!!!. I always wanted to step on places that history has made. Make sure you have lots of water for this trip. Best to wake up early and start early. Very hot during noon till late afternoon...
Wow. Having seen it on many a photograph,it was just fantastic to be there,I can assure you it won't disappoint.
Just amazing. Tough to find words to express the magnitude of this place. Try to go at sunset--and sunrise--worth the early rise

An amazing place. What can you say, Angkor Wat is one of the most amazing places on earth, worth the time of any visitor to SE Asia. Other reviews and websites can cover this in much more detail, just a couple of recommednations:- Be ready for the heat, you will be outside and it can be hot any time of the year- Consider a guide - there is so much to see and learn about in these places. Alternatively, get yourself a good guidebook and read up before going.- Go in the off season - feeling like one of the pack detracts greatly from the feeling that you are doing something special- Get their before sunrise - we found our own little small temple, and watched the sun come up, surrounded by a family of lightly aggressive monkeys - quite an experience.- Stay in a place with a nice pool - after a day of exploring, you will need a swim and a relax with a cold drink.Enjoy!
In awe. Great history and story, beautiful location . Must come a time when the site has to be restricted to preserve it but go if you can while u still can - great tourist behaviour

Temple viewing. Spent a day being taken around temple by a local tuk tuk driver including this place, made famous by tomb raider of course. Overall was worth the fee and the cost of hiring the tuk tuk for the day

The highlight of a month long trip. We spent a few days in Siem Reap to visit Angkor, and it wasn't nearly enough. We had an amazing time.We cycled the first day with bikes rented in Siem Reap - be aware that not all the maps are to scale! We were given one by our hotel and it showed it was 8km to Angkor Wat and then another 5 or so to Ta Prohm - it's more like 20km to do both (not including cycling back to Siem Reap), so definitely be aware. Our bikes were pretty badly maintained too, although they did the job.Our second day was by tuk-tuk arranged by the hotel (Rambutan, excellent hotel), which was much easier and more relaxing. It took a fair amount of time to get between temples this way too, which made us wonder how we managed it by bike! We didn't hire a guide, although I think when we go back we'll do that for one day, since there's not a lot of information provided at the temples themselves (either a guide or get a good book with a map).Having a driver for the day was inexpensive (USD15) and was great for finding temples randomly - we drove past one which we didn't know about, so asked the driver to take us there instead for a while.

Angkor Archeological Park - see more by renting a taxi. Is a photograph ever as good as seeing a live butterfly? Say no, and know then you need to visit this sight. First, Angkor Wat is a temple inside this park...as someone else said "think Manhattan". Second, get to the ticket booths in the dark of the morning and avoid the hour long wait if you go around 8AM. Third, I am walking with a severely sprained ankle in a splint so my review comes from that perspective. Sprained ankle?? Am I going to miss Angkor Wat? Never! We hired an air conditioned Lexus taxi for $50/day to take us around. He was not a guide, but his experience in where to go when to avoid the crowds was very valuable. He picked us up at 5AM - Siem Reap is 10 minutes away. I got my sunrise photo of Angkor Wat, and later the crowds we shared the experience with. We left then and went right to Bayon and except for 3 other people, we were the only and first ones there. Every doorway has a threshold (to make it difficult for the evil spirits to cross into other rooms) and the rooms are small, so I had a lot of stepping to do throughout the day; there are stairs with no railings at most places; and the grounds and long pathways are unevenly paved with stones. You can hire a Cambodian guide confidently - they'll be wearing the same shirt and ID tags. These individuals speak multiple languages well, and paid $3,000 to study for two years to become knowledgeable enough and to be able to be licensed. No one pretends to be a guide out of respect for the career. We bought the one day pass to the Park, which includes entry to all the temples and sites. After Bayon (it gets hot and humid quickly), our driver took us to see the Elephant Terrace and Ta Prohm (the tomb raider temple), having earlier passed through the narrow gate (which we shared with folks on foot, on bikes, on motorbikes, in cars, with small buses, in tuk tuks...our driver said in an hour it will take 45 minutes to pass through here) into the Archeological Park. By now some tourist groups had caught up with us, but it was still comfortable enough to have the time to look carefully at whatever we wanted, and get all the photos without inconveniencing anyone. After this, our driver took us to a restaurant in the park where they served Kmer and Western meals for breakfast. Naturally, what was going on outside the temples in these areas were regular working folks were simply going about their work, was at least as interesting as the visit to the ancient sites. At some point, I wondered if much had changed in their lives over the centuries. Off we went then back to Angkor Wat thinking the hundreds there for the dawn photo had dispersed and they had. We climbed up and around and in and out and up again and up again to the topmost tower and I'd do it again. I bought a fuschia and orange prayer bracelet ($1) up there inside the temple from a bodhisattva who prayed over me (and my foot) and it felt wonderful. By the end of the visit and all the steps down and all the walks along the terraces and pathways, I felt the Buddha's healing.The aromatic massage I had the night before helped too I'm sure. By this time, we were soaked with sweat and our driver was always ready with cold water bottles and my husband was done. It was 9AM. You can say we only glossed through the places, but we saw, we felt, we experienced it and it was great. I could only think that if I were a child living close to there, I could have played endlessly through those hallways, getting lost and found again and again, pretending and pretending to be kings and queens involved in endless intrigue. I continued on with our driver to the pink "lady temple" Banteay Srei and the sights through the villages we passed were uncomplicated and a view into daily Cambodian country life. After arriving back to the city, it was now around midday, I asked to visit the National Museum which houses and protects a great many statues, friezes, carvings, etc from the temples. (Entry $12, gorgeous gift shop :-) After two hours there, that included the Room of the 1,000 Buddhas, I was so glad to have chosen to visit - I learned much about the great Cambodian Kmer Regime (in ancient times) and ended being able to recognize the time period of various pieces and the temples they'd come from. We went to a 'grocery store' (mini-mart) and returned to the hotel (a plug here) the Royal Angkor Resort and Spa for a soak in the jacuzzi and a wonderful late lunch (the chef here understands Cambodian/Asian tastes and Western tastes equally well). So, if you read things that tell you you can't do the Park in a day - they are correct, if you plan to visit many more places than we did, or take things in for longer times than we did, but I am thrilled to have come to Siem Reap and visited what we did. I am so glad we didn't forsake it on account of my foot. This trip was so much more than I anticipated I could do and it's because of having rented the taxi and knowledgeable driver. Thank you, Nang Nak.

Fantastic time!. -I was amazed and speechless by the magnificent temples.I bought a 5 days-ticket and spent each and every day from very early in the morning till late in the afternoon at the temples. I just couldn't take my self out of there! I climbed on every temple (wherever was allowed by the authorities) you need to be physically fit to do that as the stairs in many cases are very steep.-I went there during the low season, in order to avoid the huge crowds, however during my stay the temperature reached gradually 50 degrees celcius!-Be aware and avoid going into the forest late in the afternoon, especially if you are travelling alone as there are reports of assaults.- No matter what transportation is chosen by tuk tuk, car driving, or balloon the place is magical. Optional you can hire a helicopter and enjoy the temples from above literally lost in the jungle.-Depending on the weather sunny or heavy cloudy the temples provide to the visitor a different image and in my opinion i found this very charming as it gives the opportunity for fantastic photos to be taken!

Angkor. Buy 3 day ticket & have a guide for at least one day. We also had a driver but easily done by tuk tuk. Small circle on first day, Grand Circle second day then further out to Banteay Srei. Tonle Sap lake with floating village & school. Very worthwhile- all of it.
A wonderful place on Earth. Just unique, live the experience of visiting a place of History, of grace, of nature and architecture

Sun set view. Nice experience walking up for the sunset view from the hill top.Some new mechanical pathway or escalator, we understand , is under implementation.Hope it does not disturb the natural beauty of the pkace!

Amazing. I visited Angkor in november 2014. I was expecting a lot of people after reading so many reviews. Fear not: there are a lot of people, true. What do you expect? But really, for those who have seen Borobudur in Indonesia, there is far less crowd in Angkor. And the site so huge that you can easily avoid the crowd, for example going to the smaller temples around Bayon. It is trully a jewel of archeology. Peaceful place, a must see for everybody interested in past civilizations.The entrance is fair: 40$ for 3 days.Some children trying to sell postcards or anything (it's still Cambodia) but they are usually nice and not agressive as you would find in other countries.

Fantastic. The temple complex of Angkor is so huge that it is only possible to scratch the surface in a day. The site certainly lives up to it's billing as the 8th wonder of the world. Be prepared for a lot of tourists. However it is easy to get away from the crowds. start at Ta Phrom and move on to Ankor Thom before visiting Angkor Wat. A guide is invaluable.

Gotta spend more time. We started with only wanting a sunrise trip, and ended up staying all the way till dark, that too without covering all the temples. Ta Prohm is the best among all. try avoiding the mid day heat, and if possible, spend 3 days to see them all. there are stories on the walls, and if you are interested it in, a guide could help explaining.

Magnificent!. These temples are more or less in ruins now, after the years of neglect and then the civil wars they have stood the test of times. What remains of this wonderful complex is in itself a grand opulence to watch. Besides the fact that the entire complex is so well maintained and has such beautiful gardens Trees and water bodies around it, it just an awe inspiring place. I did both the big and small circuit in a day and tried to cover as many known and famous temples, but even the smaller temples in this complex are equally beautiful. There are some in absolute ruins as of today but it makes me think of the opulence this entire place might have had when most of these temples were newly made or in much better conditions. I did let go of some temples because it can be very hot in the day time and recommend you do it in two days if you are an avid history and architecture fan. Please make sure you dress appropriately for some temples thought hey allow you to wear shorts but they should be below your knees, if you are in anything that does not cover your knees and above you might not be allowed to some of the temples. Be well equipped with water sun screens and all you need as it can be exhaustingly hot, and I am saying this when I was there in November, which supposedly is the coolest month. If you have all these things in place then you will definitely have fun losing yourself to time.
Wow. What s place. You must go and see this. It's truly amazing. We did 3 temples in 1 day and the sunset the previous evening. An experience I will never forget.

Magical. A once in a lifetime experience. The marvel of what these ancient people accomplished is beyond words.Hire a guide & take at least 2 days to explore the park. Be prepared for crowds, heat & humidity! It can be daunting & physically taxing to climb the treacherous steps but totally worth it!
Impressive Instant. 1 of the 7 Wonders of the World. You should see it by yourself. No words can explain how wonderful it is. What an amazing architecture that our ancient can do!!

Angkor Wat, Bayon and more!. To be clear, the Angkor Archaeological Park is the large area encompassing Angkor Wat, Bayon and all the other archaeological structures that you read about in Siem Reap. There are a few further outside Siem Reap but most are here so consider the individual reviews for deciding which structures you want to visit and how much time you want to spend at each.The cost of entry is $20 for one day or $40 for three when I visited at the end of low season so the important decisions to be made before arriving are - 1) do I want to pack it all into one day or parse it out over a more than one? and 2) do I want to visit with or without a tour guide? Tour guides can be of highly variable quality. I went solo, with just a tuk tuk driver and felt that was enough, but there may have been some nuances to the architecture that I missed. If you want to contribute to the local economy and have the means, hire a tour guide with tempered expectations. If you're on a tight budget, check out the museum instead and maybe bring along a guide book for reference as you meander about. Also consider getting about on a bike if you want to get a workout in, but be ready for a fun and very tiring day!

What to say? Breathtaking. There is not much to say about it, absolutely amazing peace of history. If you are in SEA, simply go there! I have been there in the end of October when the main season didn't start yet so you can avoid crowds.Hire a tuk tuk, rent a bike, whatever and enjoy it.

Amazing. if this is the only ancient civilisations you see you will have seen the best. Definitely worth investing in a tour guide. We visited a few times at different times of day and it was fascinating

Try sunrise over the temple!. We got to the temple at 5;30 in the morning for sunrise. Had to navigate by flashlight but the weather was cool, the sunrise spectacular and the visit to the temple managed without too much heat. We were dne by 9 am--before back to the comfort of air conditioning!

Marvellous. This is the best archaeological site i have ever seen. It is located on a wide area so visiting there takes a long time. You should allocate at least 2 days, 1 day is not enough for that beauty. And dont forget to take you camera's memories and charge :)There are many shops in the area, u can buy fruits, beverages, local clothes etc. But clothes and souvenirs are more expensive than the city.
temple city. many temples SIVA Temple is very nice . very good night clubs beoutifull girls , good food , i love it

Just mazing. I've visited angkor archaeological park twice already but it still never fails me to amaze me. The first time i saw angkor wat and the bayon temple, i had goosebumps.The jungle temple is also amazing, it only shows how powerful mother nature is.Just make sure to put on sunscreen because it is too hot. Also, bring bottle of water to stay hydrated because walking around the temple in the heat of the sun could sap out your energy.
Wonderful travel experience. Really amazing archaeological park with many things to see and experience. One day is really not enough..

Another amazing site!. Very very worthwhile seeing, but it gets very very busy. Lots of work being done to keep the temples up. Visit now....as I would anticipate it will only get busier, more expensive and unfortunately damaged.
Great place to visit~. Lots of history and beautiful temples with intricate carvings to explore! Recommend spending at least 3 day in order to finish seeing the big and small circuit.

the power of nature. This was a high light of our trip. To see how nature has taken back its own is amazing in Ta Prohm. Dawn at Ankor Wat was a bit disappointing because of the cloud cover but still managed to get some great shots. Just the size of the temple with the moat built by hand is mind blowing. We did the helicopter flight over this amazing site. Well worth the money.

A release of heart, and a mind of piece. Have a large amount of space on your camera, phone or something else, MANY of us felt the people were still there working, i WOULD LOVED OF STAYED THE NIGHT, to feel the Vibrations of the area. Some nice area to get a bit of food or a ice cream, have water with you, and enjoy the moments where you walk and go...
