A true wonder of the world!. Pro: You have never seen anything like this place anywhere! It has that "lost temple being overgrown by jungle" vibe. The photo opportunities are endless. Bring a tripod or extender pole for group selfies. Con: Crowds are getting out of hand. You need a good guide.

Majestic - beyond words. I love the beautiful carvings on the walls of the temples. Work was really intricate. Mind boggling to note how the they were able to produce such fine work without technology centuries ago. Walking the complex was tough though. There were many flights of stairs. The steps were very high. It was said that the temples were built for the deities and thus the high steps. One needs to be fit to be able to enjoy the Angkor Temples.
Awesome Angkor. Amazing how Hindu rulers in 9th to 14th century had got this complex made. Shows you the technological advancement and skills of bygone era. Mind Blowing

Photo pass is a great souvenir. For approximately US$20 you get a photo pass to see the wonders of Angkor Archaelogical Park. Don't lose it or you could be fined up to $200! The temples of Angkor are a must see in Cambodia - ruins, towers, terraces of wonder. So old and so incredible. Take plenty of water for drinking and a fan - it's a very sticky, humid place. There are elephant rides available, and also boats for hire. Many tourists were in tuk tuks, which would be a great way to get around, but we were on a bus tour. The carvings on the Elephant Terrace were gorgeous, as was each and every temple we visited. A must do experience.

Angkor. The whole place is worth seeing as World Heritage must-see thing. There is no other place like this. Ta Prohm is mostly what we expect. The rest is amazing as well, but not as i imagined. I also imagined deeper kind of a jungle which it is not. If you are not detail or archeology freak, then one day is enough imo. Renting one of small bike cars with a driver is the best option.

AMAZING!! definitely need more than one day here!!. This place is incredible.. Just be prepared to drink like 5 bottles of water and sweat a lot.. it gets HOT!! in saying this we wish we had more time to see everything than to cram it all in one day. we started about 9am and left at sunset.. while we had our tuk tuk driver drive us around, by the end we were just so hot and bothered we almost wanted to give up and go back to the hotel for a swim, we also missed out on the sunrise. Even though we didn't see the sunrise, we have seen photos and would recommend if you do the one day pass, go see the sunrise instead of the sunset, from what ive seen in the photos the guide showed us (who btw was very informative; guides for just Angkor Wat are $20USD and for the whole day its like $40 or 45USD) it rises above Angkor Wat and looks spectacular, whereas the sunset was just a sunset to me, nothing that amazing.

Don't get sucked in.. My wife and I came here and did our own tour of the Angkor Wat Archeological Park. Am referring to the whole area here, including all the temples you get to see with your ticket ($20 for 1 day, $40 for 3 days). Everyone we spoke to said we couldn't do this in one day and they're probably right. There are a lot of temples and things to see here. HOWEVER...Before we went, we made a list. We wanted to see sunrise at Angkor Wat, Bayon, The Terrace of the Elephants/Leper King, Ta Prohm and Preah Khan (due to the places we wanted to see, we drove most of Angkor Thom too, seeing 3 of the 4 gates). If we had time, we were going to watch the sunset at Bayon (as in go back there). We got to Angkor Wat with plenty of time and waited for the sun. It was less than spectacular to be fair. This was on account of the cloud cover that just so happened to all be in the east. The sun eventually came out around 8am. By this time, we had had a decent walk around Angkor Wat. It's nice and it's certainly huge, but there is only so many things to see and photos to take. As I said, we did the tour ourselves so didn't have anyone giving us history. I don't regret not having a tour guide...We then went to Bayon, stopping at the south gates to Angkor Thom to take some photos. The area where the gates are is quite nice. Anyway, Bayon was probably my favourite temple. It's also number one on TripAdvisor (for a reason!). It is in a bit of disrepair but there is some restoration work going on there so hopefully in the not to distant future it'll be good as new. The third thing we did was the Terrace of the Elephants. It was ok. Not really anything to do or see, just a bit of a walk over the top. Same with the Terrace of the Leper King. We made our way through the north gate and on to Preah Khan. This temple is massive and not initially on our list. I'm glad it was. It's pretty much a straight walk with a whole heap of ups and downs. At one point, you can see quite far through. We were also treated here by a monk and some worshipers praying in one of the side rooms. Back through the North gate and we headed to the east gate towards Ta Prohm. Ta Prohm was my wife's favourite temple and is the one with the trees growing out of it. It is also the one Tomb Raider was filmed at. Again, we walked around here and got some good photos but there was nothing here. By this time we were fairly over temples to be fair. There is only so much stacked rocks you can see. I know everyone will have their own opinion on that but really, I don't believe we missed out on anything after these four places. Don't get me wrong, they were good but I can't really imagine spending a whole day, let-alone three here. We where back at our hotel by midday...What lets this place down is its lack of information. There are no information signs around that specify what's what etc. This would improve the park tenfold. Don't be put off doing your own thing reading my review, it's just my opinion. I just think there are only so many piles of rock one can see in a day (or 3).

Not to be Missed. You traveled this far, you probably have already seen Angkor Wat and hopefully Angkor Thom, so there is no reason not to wander around this area as well. It is well worth it. We toured Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and the Archaeological Park late in October. We started early, it was warm, muggy and we were soaked in sweat most of the day, but it was one of the greatest days ever. Three sites close by, all covered by the same day pass, and all absolutely amazing experience.For those of you contemplating a visit, when you purchase your admission pass, they take your photo and you get this nifty pass complete with your photo on it. Scan it, enlarge it a bit, and you have a great photo souvenir.

temples like no other. It feels like one has been time warped and taken into the time when these temples exist ... Quaint, surreal and just beautiful !! Prepared to be overwhelmed ... I suggest cycling through the park to best admire everything around

A total ripoff. Absolutely overpriced. One doesn't get anything for ones money except one is allowed to walk around in the area.No information boards, just nothing. Instead, you have crooks of the worst kind wherever you go.

Would love to visit again. I bought the 3-day pass for $40 (the one-day pass is $20). I only got to spend 2 days there this time, but I hope to return real soon. There are many many temples inside the Angkor Archeological Park, I'm sure you can read about the specifics of each temple ruin under it's own heading (e.g., Bayon, Angkor Wat, Preah Khan, etc.). This is just the review of the Park itself.The park itself is very beautiful, serene, tranquil, and clean. Lots of trees and small lakes/rivers(?). This place would be great to visit even if the temple ruins do not exist. It is a wonderful place to walk around, enjoy the scenery, and relax. I know most people come here to see the temples and probably have to rush from one temple to another (like I did), but if you have the time, slow down and enjoy the park itself.

Tranquil beautiful setting.. This is a beautiful park. It would have been wonderful to have come back on another day....maybe cycled in, with a picnic basket and spent some time on the banks of the moat under the trees drinking in the lush, delightful green setting with the temples in the background. MInd you...we visited in the rainy season so everyting was green, not sure if it is so green all year round.

Amazed. Includes the Angkor Wat, and Angkor Thom complexes. Amazing that these sites are still standing. Disappointed at how poorly people are treating them (we humans are quite disgusting at times!!!). I've seen that folks are recommending up to three days to visit, but 1 day was definitely enough for me and my friends - by evening we were "templed out" :)

Great experience. Fantastic 3 day experience which is a once in a life time opportunity to visit such a unique world heritage site. I bought a 3 day pass at $40 which I think is good value for all day acceess. Yes it could be run better, the touts that are everywhere are annoying and there is some questionable restoration work that has been done but appreciate it for what it is, which is a historic site.I recommend doing the Angkor wat sunrise at least once, and also having a guide or at least having properly read about the site before visiting to get the most out of the experience. I had a tuk tuk driver each day and on reflection would have greatly benefited from a proper tour guide, despite all the pre reading I did.Lessons which I learnt is to pace yourself. There is such thing as temple fatigue and as you go from one temple to the next they can all blend into once, and I need to look at my photos to remind myself of which ones I visited. Whilst planning 3 days of sightseeing may look good on paper, it doesn't take into account the weather. I can not emphasise enough how hot it gets, especially in the middle of the day. The temperature, humidity and the walking/climbing wear you down and everyone you look at is drenched in sweat. It can be tiring and you need to have a lot of water and sunscreen on you, plus good walking shoes. I found starting the days even earlier when it was cooler was a lot better and also less crowded.

Jewel in the Jungle. This is the eighth wonder of the world; and yes it IS going to be popular. Most coach parties go back to their hotel for lunch though and because you really can go anywhere you like it IS possible to find your own quiet bits. If the tuk-tuk that drives you from the airport offers their services for your visit and you feel safe..accept their offer. My driver has devised sensible trips taking into account my stamina and interests and is charging $15 a day. I have seen amazing things not on the tourist route in his company.The distances involved are not something you could attempt in this heat unless you are used to it and fit [and prepared]

Spectacular. With our country Australia being so young - it was hard to accept the age and condition of something so old.But the memory that will remain with us the longest is our interaction with the children. So beautiful.

Perfect at Sunrise. Gorgeos at Sunrise and worth the effort to wake up at 5am!Angkor is one of the most important archaeological sites in South-East Asia. It includes forested area, the famous Temple of Angkor Wat and at Angkor Thom, the Bayon Temple with its countless sculptural decorations.
Great Exploration. We had a three day pass and had three exciting days looking at the different temples. Well worth the trip out to see the outlying temples too.

Wonderful!. Visited in 2004 and again this week. Apart from the obvious restoration activities, it's still a wonderful place and an incredible feat for it's time and today!Visited 3 times over the 3 full days of temple tours by Tuk Tuk and still awe-inspiring! Just hope Cambodia looks after this treasure as the dollar surpasses everything - the amount of tourists here is astounding (over 2 million per year) and everyone can basically walk over most 1,000-year old stones!

A must for sure. Very crowded but of course a must if visiting Siem Reap.$20 entrance fee for a one day pass. Strangely enough you are allowed to climb almost all over the place. If you´re taking photographs it´s better in the afternoon as the light is quite intense and flat in mornings and mid day.

Fantastic Guide & Incredible Experience. A friend and I visited Siem Reap for the first time this past August. After touring three countries in 15 days, we both agreed that our tour with Sokhom was the highlight of our trip. Not only was he incredibly knowledgable (he has 14 years of experience as a guide), his life story was touching; he's smart, charismatic, and funny. I would highly recommend any tour he gives!

Whole area just amazing. Get your walking shoes, sunblock and some cool water!! There is so much to explore here. I purchased the 7 day ticket and visited on 6 different days. Amazing temples and grounds. My tip read Temple of a thousand faces before you go. Gives the place a lot of meaning. Expect a lot of steep climbs and great views. Plenty of low walks though if you can't climb. And wear clothing that covers your shoulders and knees so you are not excluded from the upper temples.

Climbing to the top. The sun rise was great and the temples were all we anticipated. Toilets can be problematic bring 25cents in Cambodian currency. Do not expect western toilets. The climb to the top of templeis very steep and moderate may be an understatement depending on your level of fitness

This MUST be on your Bucket List!. I've been to ALL the "New Seven Wonder of the World". and I have to say this is on the Top of the list. I will only rate the Great Wall of China to be above this.The Entire Park area is very large and vest. Bring a good pair of walking shoes and protect your self from the strong sunlight. We have a private Tour guide and the pace of tour are very flexible. And if you are with a large tour group may not have as much option but stay up with the group.I am most impressed with the stone carving arts on all the walls. every space on wall surface are a work of Beautiful ART. I specially loved the Elephant Wall.A MUST see at least once in your life time!

Amazingly large area. This park actually includes many temples, including Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon Temple, and Ta Prohm. Each has something different to recommend it. You need transportation to get from one temple to another. There is a lot of climbing of steps to see each temple properly. The site is best toured with a government guide and driver (tuk-tuk or mini-bus) If you're young and athletic, you could also tour on your own with a good guide book and bike. Beware the electric bikes only have limited mileage so you could run out of power while touring. You can also travel by elephant on site.

Go now, access is getting limited. Compared to the pictures you see in guide books, there are walkways, ropes, fences and signs everywhere. Go now, because the mass tour buses are causing access to be limited from viewing from a distance. Its a shame, but 50k Chinese tourists a day will do that. In 5 years, this won't be the same place.

When past meets presents in Siem Reap!. The history behind the Wats of Angkor tell it all. All the tiring walking will surely pay off when visiting Angkor Park. THe tuktuk drivers are very kind too which was a plus for me :)
Ancient Temple. the great ancient temple in Siem Reap City. then i went Angkor Thom, Ta prom, and banteay srei temple,

Wonder of the world. I took two full days and hired a driver and a tuk tuk , no problem finding one. He was very knowledgeable and took me to most of the temples large and small. I was considering doing it by bicycle as suggested in guide book but decided against it a) the heat and b) they are so far spread. It was one of the highlights of my tour of SE Asia. The only down side was the amount of tourists, surprisingly, being allowed to clamber all over some of them.
Amazing Place. Amazing. It's best to get a tour guide to take you and show you around. You learn so much more of the history and what the artifacts and statues mean.

AAAMazing... Have wanted to see Angkor since I was a little boy,It met my expectations for sure! We arrived at 5pm and brought our tickets $20 each, which then enables you to stay that evening until dark, then return the next day for a full day!Saw the sunset on the mounting that evening, be aware you need to have your arms covered, I was wearing a gym t shirt and then had to rush to buy a sleeved one so not to miss the sunset.The next day we went back, paying our Tuk Tuk driver $18 for the whole day, we wanted to do sunrise at Angkor so he picked us up at 5am, we took a pack lunch and had a great day seeing the temples!It was very hot so you'll need lots of water (can buy there). We took our own pack up which we had brought the day before and after visiting all the temples we wanted we sat on the other side of the moat at Angkor and had a lovely pic nic under a tree. The whole day was amazing and I feel very lucky to have seen the complex.

One of the great treasures of the world. Like most people we went to Siem Reap to see this park. It is everything that you expect and more. Considering all the tourists, they are doing a good job of conservation with the site. We spent three days exploring the temples. I have to admit the heat and humidity is staggering, but take your time and bring lots of water. For us, it was critical to hire a guide. We wanted to know more than the guidebooks could provide, and he showed us the best spots to get that unique photo.
Take your time. The ticket is for one day or 3 day, take the 3 days tickets and go and return at least two more times haha Perfect beatiful, Try to visit the palace but with your eyes wide open

Ankor Wat.. Really beautiful and other worldly. Few things in life exceed our expectations and Ankor Wat does this,with ease. It does,get hot and some of the places you need a head for heights. It photos well take a camera a small towel and some mosquito repellent and you will love it . I have no doubt.

Fascinating. Look at the tempel and read his history instead of taking hunderts of selfies!
Merited reputation. Look at the sculptures (bas reliefs) on the walls of tke imnnererimeter walls.
must see. Obviously if you travel to Cambodia you must come to this site. So many amazing ruins to explore! Ta Prohm is my favorite advice Angkor Wat.

A journey back in time. I liked the activity that was going on in the park. The lakes, the ruins, the tuk -tuks, the Cambodian people were so friendly.
Didn't like being hassled by people selling local wares

unique place in the world. the hydrological city of Angkor was the engine of the most powerful empire at the time. After tasting the glory, centuries of loneliness have built a whole complex of magic and architecture which shares its living with the wild forest, the villagers...and now you: enjoy discovering Angkor, it is a real pleasure.

amazing!. would recomend to go with tuk tuk for the first day and then take a bike for the second day. that way, you see everything and do not get too tired from cycling for many kilometers two days in a row

Absolute must see!. Amazing site and absolute must see in a life time. Ticket prices are not cheap and services could be better (including having audio guides for instance for rental). It's quite time consuming to visit. 2-3 days are needed for a proper visit. Major/main sites can be seen in one day, but it'd be very tiring.

Mandatory when you are in SR. We took the 3 days pass and it absolutely paid off. Recommend to go their by bike giving you a more direct (and independent) encounter with the park.... The park provides sufficient temples /sights to explore for > 1 week ...

Good for history and architecture buffs, a photographer's heaven.... Good for history and architecture buffs, a photographer's heaven...
Highly recommended...
Good to have a guide here to explain the scriptures on the walls of the perimeter surround it.

Breathtaking. I have always been interested with ancient civilizations, and as with great ancient structures, Angkor Wat lives up to it's legendary name. I still could not fathom how it's built! How large the whole complex was and how tall the towers & walls were, up to the intricate carvings on the stone walls...simply breathtaking
Wonderful. Another awesome place for exploring. So much to check out that the one hour I spent on it was simply not enough. Definitely worth a second visit.

En mi Bucket List. Since at least 20 years I´ve had Angkor in my bucket Llist... It didm´t disappoint me!!!
The place is astonishing... and not only Angkor, but also all the ruins in the area.
Camboya is really a place to go! It´s people, the food, the sightseeings on the rice fields... the food are part of an incredible experience!

The entire park is wonderful. This place is amazing. The trees have grown to overtake the buildings. It is both beautiful and eerie. You can see why they make movies like Lara Croft and the Tomb Raiders in this area. You could not conceive of a better set for this type of adventure movie.

Ankor is a wonder of the world!!!. So much to see! Worth getting a guide for the day - the average cost per day is $25US and they are definitely worth the money.
You learn so much more about the architecture and history that you would by wandering aimlessly by yourself.
Angkor. if you do not know the history of the place, and you dont take with you a guider, its kind of waste of time.

Awesome place, so much to see. Spent three days traveling around the park (two days on bicycle--one on the mini loop and one to the Roluos Group; and one by tuk-tuk to catch the sunrise over Angkor Wat) and loved every minute. There are so many temples to see, so many stairs to climb (haha) and if you can I really recommend doing it in three days. Two days were nine hours and one was about four and I can't imagine how anyone can see enough in one day. At only $40 for three days, if you have the time it seems like a no brainer.

All you've imagined. Yes, it is worth the hype. Get a three-day pass and take in the temples by tuk-tuk and by bicycle. If you can only get to the temples for one-day, then you must see Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm, and Benteay Srey, even though it is a ways out there. Absolutely worth the drive.

Utterly fantastic. Like many, I have heard about this place for many many years. I was not ready for such a huge and impressive archaeologic site. It was staggeringly beautiful and interesting in the extreme.The size is simply incredible. It was all that I expected and far more. No one should visit Cambodia without seeing this place. It is Integral and important to the culture and the world civilization.

Must visit when in Cambodia. While the heat can be overbearing in the 'low 'season, still would not have missed this for anything. The detail and majesty of the buildings is something not to be missed. I was told Dec/Jan are the most temperate months to visit, however this is also when the crowds arrive. I visited at the very end of September, and the 'feels like" temp was 101, but the beauty of the park surmounted any discomfort from the heat!

worth a one hour visit. this newly constructed museum really is a useful introduction to the meaning and themes of the temples, from a religious and cultural point of view. There is nothing about the construction of the canals and tanks though, nothing about the irrigation process, the wars with neighbours, the historical analysis of rise and fall.....

Unbelievable. We didn't realise how much area is covered by this wonder a guide is a must.Visit the temple were Tomb Raiders was filmed for some fantastic trees growing through the temples.Arrange to go early and eat lunch early to avoid the crowds.
A once in a lifetime experience!. Simply breathtaking. Everyone needs to see this place in their lifetime! It's ideal to get a tuk tuk to take you around to the different temples.

Worth a look see!. Amazing place. Park is enormous so best way to see it is by tuk tuk. Can buy one day, three day or seven day tickets. 3 day is probably plenty of time to get your fill of these wonders if the world.
Amazing. The complex is big and you need energy and probably more than one day to see it all. Go early in the morning, before daylight to see the sunrise over the complex- worth getting up early for.

So much to take in.. Knowing a little of the history meant I thought that I had a good depth of knowledge before the visit. Then I discovered the carvings on the terrace surrounding the palace, it's astonishing! The wall has been carved, in appearance, in the same style, in amazing detail for hundreds of metres. If you can, I would recommend a visit there for anybody.
cambodia. awsome you must go to this wonder of the world our guide johny was great nothing to much trouble never stopped being amazed

Awesome but can be hard work.. We did all apart from 2 of the small temples around the area today. We got there what we thought was early (7am) and it was still pretty busy. There are some truly amazing things to see here as is expected. I'm shocked if people leave here not feeling impressed. It can be very challenging if you want to see everything and it's a hot day, as today was. I'm in the peak of my fitness and I was sweating buckets after climbing up many very steep steps (the steps aren't essential so those that would be put off by this shouldn't be but to see everything you need to climb a lot) Overall it was a awesome day, however a shower and lay down was appreciated afterwards

Breathtaking Sunrise ! must see. Don`t forgot to see the breath taking morning sunrise from Angkor wat. Lots of tourist so better find a good place for your picture. I loved to capture in front of the pond so i can see the shadow, The temple and rising sun. It was another beautiful sunrise :)
Superb!. Visit early in the morning for sunrise or for sunset. beautiful and breath taking.take an umbrella it will help if it rains or for the sun.

Once is not enough!. Such amazing archeological remains can't fully be appreciated in a few days. We bought the three days pass and managed only to visit Ta Phrom, Bayon Temple, Baphuon, Terrace of the Leper King, Terrace of the Elephant and of course the grand Angkor Wat. Prepare for lots of walking and climbing. Wear proper clothes (t-shirts, pants) Ones that you won't mind getting sweaty and dirty in them. If you're going to be there at noon to mid afternoon, hats and sunglasses are important. The sun can be really harsh. You'll turn beet red in minutes. To get the best experience, read up a bit of its history before hand or hire one of the guides. Having these knowledge will make a difference in your tour. I felt like a kid in a candy store trying to find the secret carvings in these temples. Didn't notice the time passing by. If you're there between 8am-4pm, there'll be lots of crowds. If you don't want to feel pressured, its best to start early (circa 530am) and normally you'll finish one of the circuit by 930-1000. That's what we did. At 10, we went back to the hotel to recharge (napping, eating) and explore the town at noon/ evening. If you want to continue your exploration, you can either do it in the evening or early the next morning.
A Must. I could spend days at this place the history and culture it's fantastic and really quite user friendly on the whole ( unfortunately Anjolina was busy

Fascinating. Ankgor Wat was extremely interesting with the various temples, carving and location.
I particularly liked the reflection you can get from the lake in front of Ankgor Wat.

Stunning but overcrowded. I have been there in Oct 2014 and was absolutely breath-taking, I would have loved to have the temple to myself to explore but unfortunately there were hundreds of people visiting the same time as me, so it was constant standing in queues inside the templeIt is also very confusing to find your way through the temple as the tuc-tuc drops you at the eastern side (or western side, can’t remember) and wait for you on the other side, so you have to make your way through the ruins on you own with no visible signageBut it is fantastic to see how nature is slowly reclaiming the areaThe spot that was used in the Lara Croft movie is virtually impossible to get close to, every tourist visiting wants a photo of them-self at that spot, so it was quite a wait before you could get close enough to take a picThis was the temple that I was really looking forward to see and it was absolutely worth the stampede to see itThis is in my view one of the must see temples
Wow!. Pros:Affordable admissionAmazing restorations on templesCons:Too many "supposed" guides (you can ignore them)
Needed more time.. There's so much to see. We had 3 full days with a tuk tuk and still there was so much more to see. Its somewhere you have to go in your lifetime.

A must do. This is a once in a life time sight, a must do for everyone, it is amazing all the temples here and you could spend days looking around, a tour guide would be very helpful and god shoes as you will be doing a lot of walking around. Do some research on all the temples and decide which ones you wish to see

Incredible Temples~ !. Yes, the place is crowded, but extremely worth your visit. I've been to temples all over Asia, and Angkor Wat is the most impressive and massive you can find. Hire a tuk tuk, drink fresh coconut, local coffee, and explore the site for at least a couple of days. The only downside is pushy vendors (and very sad and depressing are kid vendors), but note Cambodia is a poor country and no matter what the people are extremely kind.

WOW. Amazing place and well worth the trip here to visit.The temple is astonishingly old. The symmetry of the architecture is amazing, every diction you look and the building is completely symmetrical. Amazing.
Awesome. The temples are beautiful. The old tree and envirnoment there make them much even greater! You will enjoy it as it is beautiful likes a painting!

world heritage. awe some. how an indian king came here and established the temple complex, city , gateway etc is astounding.the complex was hidden from public and therefore preserved, because of overgrown trees and the surrounding jungle.the main temple complex is surrounded by galleries. the four walls of the gallery have carvings of hindu mythology and what carvings they are!!exquisite.some area are dark so that one has to be careful lest one falls.(government should consider lightening up such areas and approach roads especially of bayoun temple.)the complex was abandoned because of shortage of water. at present it is surrounded on all sides by deep(once infested with crocodiles)motes running to almost 1.3 km. on one side.should have plenty of time to see and study the archeological park. be prepared for steep climb at few places.well worth visit and trouble.

So much to see. An extraordinary place, so much history, architecture and culture in one area. If you have the time buy the 7 day pass that can be used over a 1 month period for the $US 60. I just wanted to keep going back, sitting down and staring at it all.

A Must-See. This archaelogical park is an absolute must-see. The temples themselves are grandiose and impressive but the forest and river setting is also in itself just beautiful to travel around. It can get expensive (entrance ticket + transport + guide) to visit but a minimum one day visit cannot be missed.

Green and green.. This park covers about 80 km. There are a lot of different types of trees there. It's so nice to go there early in the morning and at the sunset time. Don't forget to take your family to have a pinic lunch or dinner there. It's very nice.

One of the wonders of the world. A magnificent experience, one of the places one should visit in his lifetime. The less impressive part is the quality of detail in certain temples, far inferior to the gothic period in Europe

Days of exploring to be done.. Let's face it, this is why people go to Siem Reap and it lives up, if not exceeds, expectation.The size of the park just goes on and on and i'd guess that all the popular temples on the tourist trail are just the tip of the iceberg.$20 for a 1 day pass per person or $40 for a 2 or 3 day pass is fantastic value for money when you consider the sights to be seen.A must for anyone thinking of going to Cambodia.

Great park with one entrance fee, decent restrooms and locals. Angkor Archaeological Park is very well run with nice people working there and many locals walking around (although many kids and ladies try to sell you everything under the sun). Having one ticket price and at only USD 40 for 3 days, it is a great price and nice that so many temples are nearby. I highly recommend a tour guide with a car. Although it is more expensive, the driver with cold towels, water and air con transport was extremely worth it if you visit in the hot summer or rainy and hot fall (best guide was Sokpee from Siem Reap Adventure Travel).

Take your time to see it all. The whole park is full of sites and beauty but the only draw back are the local hawkers all trying to get some income off the streams if tourists. We didn't mind but some can be a bit full on and don't hear no. You just have to keep walking and they get the picture and move to the next tourist. Don't let it effect your visit to this wondrous ancient icon.
A must-see. The size of these temples and the sheer scale of the whole area, not to mention the history, both ancient and recent, makes this a must see on the bucket list. Just ticked of one of mine!

Breathtaking. It is enormous and very hot. The place is a must see and the entire reason we went to Siem Reap in the first place. It is well worth the cost of a driver as it covers a vast area. There are so many hawkers there and the little kids trying to sell souvenirs is sad.
Lost World. The Angkor Wat temples was if you had gone back in time. If you think all temples start to look the same, it is a must you visit these temples and about the history. It is simply amazing.
I could spend a month alone here.... What an incredible, beautiful place... They myriad temples and buildings are absolutely fascinating. Make sure you hire a licensed guide.

Everything was excellent - and worth $20/day. In order of my favorite temples: Bayon, Preah Khan, Ta Prohm, and Angkor Wat. IF YOU HAVE LIMITED TIME (or don't want to spend $40 on a two-day pass), just visit these four. Bring an umbrella for rain or shine. If it is rainy, keep you pass in your wallet – or bring an ID card holder with a strap to put around your neck – every temple you need to show your pass…
Amazing place. A must see - unbelievable. Who would have guessed this even existed and brochures don't do it justice.

A must do. The history and how the many temples have withstood time, overgrowth for hundreds of years by jungle and the civil war makes this place amazing. Don't do it without a guide as you will not get the true meaning of each temples gallery. I did a day bicycle tour with Grasshopper adventures which I highly recommend. It also allowed you to bypass the people trying to sell things to you. It also provided access to some of the areas within the temple walls where no one else was. Many temples in different state of repair, makes you appreciate the work that has gone into them.Take plenty of water and explore.

Just Magnificent. Words can not describe this area, it must be experienced.Guaranteed not to disappoint The only downside is all the sellers of "trashy" stuff, turn it into a game and you will get trough unscathed Everyone should experience, but do use a reputable guide to enhance the experience

Words are sometimes not enough.. Revisited the Angkor Park and began planning any excuse to come back. The place is stunning, breath taking...use any superlative you like but it won't do justice to the place.The only reservations we had were the huge crowds there this year unlike last July 2013. Thousands of Chinese now enjoy touring and this has had some negative impact on others visiting Angkor. They can be loud and very pushy. One is tempted to respond in kind but sometimes its best to bite one's tongue and remember why you are there! Spend one day or two or... It seems that there is never enough time to explore this magical site, especially dawn over Angkor itself.Enjoy...

Most incredible place. Defiantly start early, we did the whole park in one day, it was tiering but very do able! Ta prahom was incredible, our favourite by far, starting there in the morning is amazing we were completely alone for sunrise! A tuk tuk is really useful, can be done by bike but in the wet season i don't recommend it and it gets very very hot!
Majestic. A lots of walking needed. Its windy in the higher part of the temple. Wear bucket hat would get you through the scorching hot weather.

It should be one of the 7 wonders of the world. This place is Uaaauuuu! Save at least 2 days to visit it. Do the sunrise and skip the sunset, it's overrated. The entrance for one day cost 20 USD, 3 days 40 USD and there is also a ticket for 7 days visit (don't remember the price). The ticket will have your photo (taken at the entry), so its not transmittable to another person.Rent a tuk-tuk for the visit, its the best5 way to visit the temples.

Worth am extended stroll.... Covers a huge area, it all depends on your stamina and wish to look at lots of old stones and holes in the ground. The great thing is you can do just as much as you want - and there are some wonderful parts where history envelops you - some of the wall carvings are gripping - but once you get twitchy, cut loose into Siem Reap for a cold beer and a swim. Two days of old stones were my limit. Steve Riches, Northampton, UK.
Beautiful place. This is what most travel magazines refer to when they write about Angkor Wat. Pretty much a must-see if you go to Siem Reap

Breathtaking!. The whole park complex is huge and full of history so it is worth having a Tour guide to take you there and explain about the ruins as you go. The park is wonderfully maintained and the facilities good.

Blissful. Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, Ta Phrom are the major temples you MUST SEE when visiting the Angkor Archaelogical Park. These monuments not only showcase the artistic depth and genius of the Khmer Empire, they also envoke the spiritiual self in you :)

Don't whinge about the ticket price. We heard some people complaining about the ticket price - 20 dollars a day or 40 dollars for the week ticket. Just suck it up and remember that 40% of Cambodia lives on less than a dollar a day, and that half of the country's income comes from tourism such as this. The Angkor park was remarkably clean and well maintained with lovely forests and virtually no litter or trash that often spoils other bucket list destinations. Hats off to the Cambodian people for their hard work so no whinging, please ! :o)

must see. i cannot believe that this place has been around for so long its amazing that it still stand and that so many people get to experience this beautiful structures. Congratulations to the Cambodian government to continue doing works on this park and improving the longevity of the temples.

Worth a visit . We did a day tour to the temples and they are amazing....but be warned.....there are a lot of stairs to climb and many are very steep.I made sure I had long pants on as well as my shoulders covered which was required only at a few spots. Many females were not able to climb to the top of the main temple due to their clothes not bring considered appropriate.

Absolutely amazing. It usually takes a full 3 days to see all that Siem Reap has to offer, but it is worth every second. It's like stepping back in time over 1000 years ago. I was truly left in absolute awe.

A must do for every Cambodia traveler. No one should come to Cambodia and miss the Temples of Angkor Wat. You can choose either a one-, three-, or seven-day ticket. I did three which is enough to see all the main Temples.

Any other reason to be in Siem Reap?. Yep, that's why you've come. To see these amazing old buildings. Some are crumbling, some are in a state of repair, some are being restored. All are magnificent.We saw the main temples in a day-our 10 and 8 yr old would not have coped with a day 2. Grateful for the air con car with ice towels and chilled bottled water we hired for the day.

Should be on everyone's bucket list. What can I say other than you must come and see these ruins. Easy to access, though some really steep stairs at some sites, friendly locals always sharing smiles, chilled tourists even in crowds and spectacular photo opps. Rent a tuk tuk for the day as distances can be deceiving. It is over several miles to each site, so forget thinking of walking it in this heat and humidity. You will be happy you spent the $20 a day from your hotel to have your own driver at your beckoned call. Or rent a bicycle but it can get very hot or you get stuck in a torrential rain storm and will not be able to cover all sites in a short time period.

Must do!. If your in Cambodia and you don't come here you've missed out.The park itself is so huge. Try to plan your trip ahead of time and give yourself two days to visit the grounds. There is so many different sites and temples and each have their own story an beauty and it would be a shame to miss any of them.This is one my favourite places I have visited.

5/5 for enthusiasts, 3/5 for everyone else. Every temple and shrine in the park is unique, but it is impossible to see them all in a day. Even the best of us get mental fatigue after 4 or 5 sites, so spread them out over at least 2 days. The vendors and their wares are almost everywhere, which will annoy your friends who don't care for ruins. Do the three big sites with them, and leave them in the city while you explore the rest.The little and grand loops can be done on a bicycle as the terrain is pretty flat. You'll take in sights such as grazing oxen and farmers working in paddy fields in the latter. Do it even on a hot day. The vendors will be there when you need a sugar hit and it'll be the one moment you're thankful for their presence.

A must to visit place at least once in lifetime.. If this is one of the many beauties UNESCO there is a reason, if the tourists are in this remote place there is a reason. Angkor Wat is undoubtedly a huge archaeological complex, so large and extensive that it is impossible to visit all in one day. To do this accurately you would need at least 3 full days. Between a complex of temples and another you move by taxi or tuk tuk distances are sometimes a few kilometers, even while some temples are located more than 20 kilometers away from the main temples and the most popular. The ticket price varies from $ 20 single day than 3 days. The procedure for purchasing tickets is fast enough, the ticket name and your picture made instantly applied on top of the ticket with the scanner. I made the one-day ticket and I could see much but not all, from 10am until 5pm, enough to appreciate this fantastic place. Within this colossal archaeological site you can also find numerous restaurants and hips of stalls where you can buy water, drinks of all kinds, small souvenirs. Needless to describe this wonderful attraction, you just have to go to visit it.

Gorgeous Place!. You have to go there! See this great human artefacts and the amazing trees.Take your time, go for a walk and enjoy this beautiful area. If you like to make a pic with a monk - please ask them.Food and drinks ae available around the corner.

Nothing to compare. This is the most important monument in the world. This would be the most importany thing to see before to die like the tipical turistic book would say. There is nothing like walking around the forest an discover hidden temples suroounded and devorated by enourmus trees.. If somebody tell you that in his country are the best monuments is because he hasn't travelled to Angkor.

For Every Kid Who Dreamed of Being Indiana Jones. I hadn't done much research before visiting Siem Reap so I thought Angkor Wat was just the one giant temple but it's a giant park. You can definitely see a few temples in one day but you will barely scratch the surface. We initially bought a 3 day pass then had to buy another 3 day pass (should have bought the 7-day pass Fromm the beginning). The park is about 7km from the city so you can rent a bike and ride there. Once you get into the park you won't have to worry about the city traffic. If biking isn't your thing then hire a tuk tuk driver for about $15 a day. I recommend Sopheak (cell 092534185). If you like the out doors this is a place to go for a picnic by the River or lake, or climb ancient temples, and explore back trails through the jungle. If your up to it you can also buy fruits from the street vendors and feed the monkeys on your trek. If you have time take another day to hire a driver (no tuk tuk) to get you to Kulen Mountain and swim in the waterfall. Angkor Wat is one of my favorite sites of this trip. Hope this helps your planning.

Awesome architecture. What amazing feats of human achievement! Book a tuk tuk driver for the day. Makes life much easier. We hadn't realised how far it is between the temples, several kilometers. We foolishly had considered cycling but then most of the day would have been spent peddling in the heat. We did the recommended small route in reverse, thus avoiding the crowds on coach tours.

Wonderful. Visiting Angkor is a travel in the past history of the Khmer people and an adventurous walk in the jungle. You feel like being Indiana Jones and everything around makes you feel really small compared to the strength of the nature. If you are not an archaeologist it's worth to get some information before the visit, or hire a guide, for just a little information is provided on the site. We went both at the sunset and at the sunrise. This particular light gives an added value to the view of the Angkor Wat. If you choose the one-day ticket, buy it before the sunset (5pm) for it lasts 24 hours and you avoid queuing the following morning.

Angkor - go there.. We had three weeks. For Vietnam. Our friend recommended us to go to Cambodia and see Angkor. We went there and we do not regret. We spent about 4 days to go there. 4 days out of our 3 weeks trip to Vietnam. It was one of the brightest moments in our trip. Angkor is outstanding. No way to find the wards to write this review. Go there. See it. Learn the story of this place and this nation. Europe just seems so small and distant. Angkor once was a biggest city in the world!
TOO EXPENSIVE. Far too $$$ rip of every where you turn! Avoid tuk tuk and food vendors / restaurants. And the blaintent corruption... GIVE IT A MISS

So impressive!. You couldn't even imagine how enormous Angkor Wat! Extremely impressive in size and the impact when you first visit, especially if you're able to see it with it's reflection in the moat. Pretty crowded (and it was low season when we were there). The steps look daunting but it's well worth the climb. The history of this whole are is so interesting. We also visited |Angkor Thom and that should be on your list as well.

Amazing. The Angkor complex is just amazing. I recommend the 3 days ticket, it's totally worth it. If you have to pick between the short tour and the long one, I recommend the short one. The best temples are there.You can't miss: Bayon, Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom (especially Bayon temple) and Ta Prohm. The first day I went there rather late (reached the place around 4 pm) so when I visited Bayon temple it was almost empty. It was impressive. If you are patient enough, and you are travelling during the low season (eg. July), I would recommend to stay there late and visit one of the temples when there's no one around.A bit farther away, a driver can take you to Banteay Srei, the pink temple. I personally think the long trip to get there was totally worth it. Also, tuk tuk is better than car, not only because it's cheaper, but also because you can see more from the tuk tuk. The wind will be enough to make the trip ok, you won't need the air con.

A trip back in time. An incredible experience! It's best to plan a few days for this adventure into Asia's past. At least two days to take in the overgrown temple ruins in the middle of the jungle. The area is vast, so it's wise to venture a bit deeper to discover less touristy temples!

Awesome. This is the biggest temple. Wear comfy shoes. So as not to disrespect the monks wear shirts with short sleeves (cover your shoulders) and shorts or pants the cover the knees. You will need a hat. Huge place and will take hours to see all. Went to the dawn tour and was ok but anytime of day there would be perfect. Amazing place for photos.
absolutely amazin. I was overwhelmed. Angkor Wat is SO big and absolutely fantastic. Splendid view - a once- in-a-lifetime experience.

Outstanding. The park is filled with various temples and sites for you to see. The price is reasonable. I started my day at 0500. The wait for the ticket was short. You pay, get your picture taken for your ticket. I was on my way in less than 5 minutes. The temples are breath taking. They are in various states. Some temples have been restored while others have not been preserved. It was amazing to see trees growing through buildings and stone fences. I was amazed at the detail. If you have viewed photos of the area they are accurate. You get a real feel for history and the effort that was taken to construct these temples. It gets hot. Wear comfortable shoes and clothing. Take water. You can purchase inexpensive souvenirs at the sites.

The most impressive historic site I have visited. This is definitely on the list of 'must see' places. The sheer scale is amazing and the detail of the carving remarkable. I had seen many photos of it but nothing compares to seeing it in real life. Would recommend highly - makes sure you have a great local guide like we did.

So vital that preservation efforts are successful. Recognised by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site for its cultural importance, the Angkor Archeological Park spans over 400 square kilometres. Uniquely characterised by temples and city structures that date from the 9th to 14th centuries, these represent the remains of the Khmer empire at its highest glory. Some of the most iconic buildings are the easiest to visit but take the trouble to visit some of the less famous (and more isolated) sites and you'll benefit from experiencing them with less tourists around. You can get around by arranging your own transport (taxi, tuk-tuk) but having a local guide is invaluable if you want to get deeper in terms of understanding the history of the time and the importance of the various sites. Unfortunately, looting of artifacts sometimes still goes on, so it's important that ongoing efforts to preserve and improve the safety of the sites are successful.

Must see in Siem Reap. It was truly amazing. We hired a tuk tuk from our hotel for the day. It worked out great because we could move easily around the huge complex. Also we hired an English speaking guide at the entrance of Angkor Wat for $16 USD, less than half the price the hotel was charging. The temples were amazing. Wear good shoes as there is a lot of slippery rocks and wood to walk on. Also note that if you want to go up to the third level of the temple you must have long shorts on and sleeves. They would not allow short shorts or skirts or exposed shoulder to enter. A scarf wrap was not enough. Children under 12 are not permitted to go up either.

Really should be one of the Wonders of the World!!. So many temples with so many sight to offer. One really should get the 3 day pass because it'll be really difficult to see everything in one day as some of the temples are 45mins away from Siem Reap by remork. The weather in Siem Reap tends to be very very hot and I touring from 11am-3pm may not the most pleasent of experiences. Some of the temples require climbing steep steps.I only visited Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm and they were brilliant! I personally felt that they were on par or better than other Wonders of the World eg. Chichen Itza, Christ the Redeemer..

Wow. Though we saw many temples in India and aren't always fond of the super touristy sites, Angkor Watch, Angkor Thom and the rest were really amazing. We only went for one day (for 6+ hours) and we're completely satisfied with what we saw along the short track. It is definitely worth seeing, even just for one day, and I can understand why people spend numerous days there. Climbing up and through the temple ruins was a lot of fun. It was too bad that it was cloudy in the morning so we couldn't see the sunrise, but supposedly it is worth the 5am wakeup. Highly recommended.
Go see it!. It doesn't matter how much you have seen or heard about this place it will still capture your imagination!

Come and see "Wat" all the fuss is about!. doesn't need an explanation - just go and spend a few days to really get the most of it! Tuk Tuk driivers will be more than happy to guide you from temple to temple and give you a bit of insight before entering (only official guides can take you around the temples - be careful with these though, we paid for one in Angkor Wat and were deffinitely short changed, he said he had finished after 30 minutes and we had only seen half of the grounds and had not been up to the central temple, he also did not make eye contact, spoke very fast and was a bit "shifty". Just chat to a prospective guide first and set out clear goals, maybe book ahead and look them up on here!).

Very different from some of the temples.... The overgrown ruins can give one the sensation of being the first modern person to see the site in a thousand years. It's an amazing feeling. Definitely worth a visit if one is already in Siem Reap.

All the temples and ruins. This is the collection name of all the temples and ruins in the Siem Reap area. You buy a ticket that gives you access to all of them. Definitely a must-do when visiting Cambodia. There are two different standard routes - the big and the small circuit. I would recommend spending one day per circuit to really have time to see the important temples and get a proper guiding. I would also recommend taking the extra time to visit Banteay Srei and Pre Rup when doing the big circuit (if you enjoy small adventures, go to Kbal Spean as well, a shrine located in a river in the rainforest).
So many temples and so little time..... Angkor has 2 main circles that you can drive, cycle or walk around. The sites are incredible. Visit it soon before it gets too crowded and overrun.

Second visit to Angkor. We only stayed for one day and saw only Banteay Srey. It is beautiful but quite a way out of town and beyond the main site. The tour guide/ driver was reasonably priced and very good about giving us a few photo opportunities on the way out and back

Fantastic. Come and see for yourself before it is too late. The trees are amazing but will be the eventual down fall of this easier to navigate amazing place. History and construction of old and not like modern day buildings which will go the way of the dodo long before this wonderful place

An ancient city. I had always wanted to visit Angkor Wat, but I had never understood the scope of the entire Angkor complex. There are so many amazing temples to explore. It's like living through Tomb Raider (without the shooting). It's really better than anything I had imagined.
Wonderful site!. The temples are splendid, carved walls, carved columns. The site is huge and you can spend days admiring the details.

Awe inspiring. Everything I expected from one of the world's great wonders. A couple of days cycling (hire at $1 per day) in the hot, humid, beautiful countryside was a great way to get from temple to temple (50 km each day) at a leisurely pace with the opportunity to use very quiet back roads/paths away from the masses. Angkor Wat at sunrise a disappointment as very cloudy - cycling in the dark with weak lights was fun. Sunset thunderstorm with lightning over the temple was magnificent though. Cycling back in a torrential downpour with lightning all around was "interesting".

its why you're here to begin with. The temple complex at Angkor is probably why you are in the region in the first place so a review is a bit irrelevant except to say you wont be disappointed and indeed it will probably surpass your expectations. An individual one day ticket is 20 dollars with three days costing 40 and I think a seven day one is available, I recommend the multi day passes and just visiting for the earlier part of the day before the temples get too busy and it also gets too hot which can turn your day into a slog and spoil the experience. If you are going it alone a decent tuk tuk driver will set you back about 15 dollars a day and will be able to to tell you the temples to visit and also how long you will need in each one.

A must. One of the most amazing place in the world !A must for people who love history and nature.In the park there are 52 archeological ruins and temple, need almost 3 days to vist only the most important, if you want visit all 52 you need almost 5 days.The park is very huge, you must rent a tuk tuk or a private motorbike, some people rent a bike but i think that park is too big to visit with bike.You can choose among 3 type of tiket: one day, 3 days or 5 days, i raccomand the 3 days tiket at price of 40$

Still as magical as ever. This is my fifth time here and the magic is still there. We were here for a longer trip this time so we bought the 7 day pass for USD60. The tickets are plastic and the pass lasts for a month or 7 visits. It was a leisurely trip to the temples. We visited in the early mornings and took a break at noon. Still so much to see and do. It amazes me how much it feels like a homecoming and I look forward to my next visit. View my previous posts for tips on temple visits.

Angkor's Temples : wonderful moments !. I have had the great pleasure to visit the whole Angkor's temples in July 2014 (19th to 23rd) and these moments are integrated in my mind and for a long time.The temples are for a large part of them included in the jungle and the connection between the nature and the trees to the stones and the monuments creates at any moment a very strong and precious atmosphere.For advices, you need to go to Angkor Wat at different moments of a day to see carefully the lights of the sun and the reflection to the water which organize different amazing views and you need to go also to Ta Prohm and to stay there a long time to wait for silence and to appreciate the spirit of Khmer civilzation.And don't forget to go also to the Bayon to look for the smiles of the bodhisattvas and to be part of them.And take a tuk-tuk for a trip to the one thousand lingas' valley (about 65km on the north of Siem Reap), you have to climb on the forest but the landscape is marvellous and the river with the statues and signs of religion are very interesting.So go in Siem Reap, buy your Angkor passport for three days (the entry of the temples are free after and you can return back several times to visit them) and enjoy the visits which will stay in your head a long time.Éric
Angkor Park. An amazing day. We took a tuk tuk up in the morning for sunrise with our bicycles and then rode around all day. Awesome day. Amazing sights and incredible photos. You must do this.

Mesmerizing. Visiting Angkor is an absolutely mesmerizing experience. The amount of workmanship that went into building these phenominal temples is mind boggling. We hired a guide which I highly recommend. He was able to narrate all of the stories that were depicted on all of the temple walls which added to the appreciation of our overall visit.

Very Cool. I am not really a temple person but was completely blown away at the size and intricacies of these temples. However was this place forgotten for so long? It is a photographers paradise. If you don't want to know all the history then you wont need a guide but they are very knowledgeable and will make sure you get to all the main sites and have the best photo ops. Travel around by Tuk -Tuk it is a fun experience.

What an awseome experience !!!. Be a part of 1200 years old history....how can you beat that. Loved the temples. Architecture was fascinating. I walked about 15 kms in two days but it was worth it. Sunrise on the Angkor was a lifetime experience. It is definitely a bucket list item.

A true marvel, one of the best places in the world. No words can prepare you for the lost city of Angkor.Temples of stones were made for Gods, for people lived in wooden houses.Be sure to spend at least 2 or 3 days in Siem Reap to properly visit this place, as it's a lifetime experience.Check as many temples as you possibly can. Cycling is probably the best way to move around, but a tuk-tuk will do anyway.

The Place You Must Visit. Angkor Archaeological Park is one large circle of all the individual temples you read about in separate reviews. My husband and I bought a 3-day ticket, which was worth the cost, and we went all 3 days. We hired our tuk tuk driver from our hotel who knew great spots inside the park. He was with us from sun up to sun down for around $20 USD. There are restaurants to stop at in between temples along the road. You can also rent bicycles to explore the park. Highlights: Of course you don't want to miss the iconic Angor Wat for a classic snapshot in front of the small pond with the temple in the background. We enjoyed walking around the grounds of Angor Wat and we actually sat in on a class of monks who were learning Thai language. They have options of tour guides, but we explored the temple on our own. Be prepared to hear lots of "hey lady"'s and be pulled on by small children trying to sell various goods such as postcards, clothing, and other souvenir items. We did break down and buy a book guide of the park, which has made for a great coffee table book in our home. Our favorite spots were Bayon, Pre Rup, and Ta Som. We watched the sunrise at Srah Srang and the sunset at Phnom Bakheng.
AMAZING. Beautiful place! Went to siem reap and stayed for 6 days! We were able to explore all of the sites in Angkor Archeological Park! Everything beautiful!

Stunning!. We only had one day to look at temples, and we made the most of our time. The complexes are simply stunning. I hope to visit again one day. We hired a driver through the hotel to take us around.Many of the places had wooden steps with hand rails installed just above the stone steps, which made it easier to navigate around. Some places have super steep, narrow steps with no rails (where you have to step sideways). There is a dress code, and if you're a woman, long pants (or past your knees) are probably easier to climb steps in than in a long skirt). If I recall correctly, we were told no long skirts at some areas of Angkor Wat or shawls to cover up shoulders, so it's probably easiest to wear the pants and short sleeved shirt that covers the shoulders so you are not turned away.Be prepared for lots of people asking for money around and inside the temple complexes. Some are selling books, etc. Others try to pull you into a dark corner, ask you to burn incense for Buddha, then ask for $10 USD for Buddha. There is a western toilet near one of the food stands in the area. If you buy water at a stand, you can bargain them down. Someone wanted over $1 for one water bottle and we started walking toward another stand and we were able to bargain down. At one stand we paid 50 cents per bottle after negotiating.Bring water and a hat as the heat can be intense. It does get crowded at many spots, so it is hard to get a great photo without people in it, but it's very much worth the trip here.
Majestic. We took half a day to look through this area. It is magnificent and interesting.We went here on our 2nd day. Glad we didn't do it the first as it may have made others look ordinbary.
Oldest temple of a Hindu religion. Atleast whenever you visit it pl read the history ofthe temple then you will enjoy more/best. And engage guide well in advance.

Amazing!. Fantastic temple sites all around Siem Reap - they are absolutely breath-taking. Make sure you allow ourself several days to visit them all. Try to get there at sunrise too. The two main sites are very touristy, so worth visiting all the smaller ones to avoid the queues.

Cycle through the jungles!. If you are active and like a little adventure, I would suggest hiring a private guide and cycle through the sites. We found a fantastic guide called Sam who brought us solid hybrid Merida bikes to trek through the jungle trails and lead us right up to the temples to explore. There were so many more places to see with a bike that you can't see traveling by car (which I did last time I visited).

Visit Now before its overrun. The Park overall is well run, well maintained and clean and safe. Of course it contains absolutely unique sites that hardly allow description. However as accessibility and popularity soar, maintaining standards in Siem Reap will be a challenge. Absolutely go now !!

First time visit. Wow what can we say, we spent the best part of 3 days tracking around this area, so much to see, lucky for us we had a great guide and driver, and did just about everything there was to see and do.
Unique. An amazing place. Well worth seeing! Need to be fairly fit to do the many stairs you will encounter. But worth the effort.

Huge Park and Impressive Structures. This park is huge and to get the most from your limited time is to hire a private tour guide who knows the area and history of these massive structures. You could easily spend hours or days admiring the size of these temples and the way nature is reclaiming its original location and get lost and feel overwhelm by it. It is also depending on how much time you have and what level of your interest are. There are dozens of temple ruins in the Angkor Archaeological Park spread across more than 400 square km. I took 3 days tour and it's still not enough time and felt that there are much more to see even with the private tour guide and my itinerary that I stick with it and did what my tour guide suggested. Best is do some extensive research before coming to this park and know exactly what you want to see or do around this area. The temples are too far apart to make foot travel practical. To make my visit to these temple practical, my tour guide had a driver dropped us off and picked us up base on my itinerary. We started with Angkor Wat, then Angkor Tom from the front, then to Angelina Jolie Tomb Riders in the back of the park, then moved to Bayon Temple, West Baray and lastly Ta Phnom Bakheng ( NOT in order of the locations rather with our priority and that way if we run out of time, we wouldn't feel we miss what we wanted to see). Without a vehicle, it would be a lot of walking to do and it's extremely hot and humid that will tire you out quickly( you might not enjoy it as much)Fee for 3 days is $40 and children under 12 is FREE. Open from 5 am to 5:30 pm everyday.This is a must do for everyone, it should be in you bucket lists for sure and it worth every penny I spent on this trip:-)

Well worth a few days. There are so many temples that it's well worth spending at least a couple of days here. The pass is $20/day or $40 for 3 days. You can come and go on each day so I did more little trips of a few hours each rather than trying to cram it all in in one giant day. The heat does get to you after a while. Don't miss going to the smaller temples as they're where you'll get away from the crowds and get the chance to actually just enjoy the place. The sheer size is amazing.

Breathtaking. The trip was fenomenal, probably one of the best places i´ve been to.you get the feeling that you´re being taken to another dimension... Be sure to hire a Tuk-tuk for the entire time you´re there. Negociate with any driver locally, and that´s all you´ll need. In the morning get ready to leave the hotel early and vist whatever temples you choose, and return mid afternoon.Most of the hotels are nearby but you need a tuk tuk to drive you to the city center for some dinner. Be sure to enjoy the city night life which is amazing!Having said that, the park has duzens of temples to visit.. Depending on the time you have available, choose what you want to visit! I´ve stayed for 5 days in Siem Reap and saw it all. If i hadn´t, most likely I´d have enjoyed it more! First you´ll get to tired, and second, your brain will start to ignore it.. it´s human nature.

Don't try to do too much. Many temples and palaces in the park. All world class. Recommend a guide but don't try and do too much as you can get a bit templed out. Worth staying a few extra days and wish I had researched more before hand. Instead I have been  researching in the evenings to try and appreciate more..

Must see before you die!. This is such an amazing place! A must do for everyone! There is so much more in this area than just Angkor Wat and all the temples are equally as beautiful and magical but all have their own unique atmospheres. I was with a tour group so only had limited time and visited three temples (Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple/Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm) but would have loved to do more of the other temples in the area. We had a local guide which I loved as he gave us a lot of great history about the temples and I felt I got a lot more out of the sites than if I had been without one. He was an official one for the park (they all have uniforms on so can be easily spotted). He also had good English so there wasn't too much of a language barrier.While a few of the areas were very touristy (I visited in wet season so is the quiet time... I was told it is very busy at the peak season) there was still the odd quiet place I found for some great photos and exploring. If you have a cloud free morning it's worth getting out of bed very early to see the sun rise of Angkor Wat.
Recommended. Amazing sites, tuk tuk recommended. A lot of walking and climbing so wear comfortable shoes and ladies bring shawl.

Mesmerising. Merely talking of the beauty, the majesty of the place will not help any of the readers. You just have to be there to experience the grandeur of the place. The park is huge and as such you cannot cover it in just one day. The one day ticket to the park is 20 USD, for 3 days its 40 USD and for 5 days its 60USD. The 3 or 5 days do not need to be consecutive, its any 3 or 5 days in a week. To enjoy all the sites, without hurrying through like a tour group, you need 3 to 4 days, so it makes sense to buy the multiple day tickets. The same ticket is valid for entry to all the temples, so keep it secure. The main attractions, of course are Angkor Wat and Bayon. You can easily cover both along with Ta Prohm (the jungle temple where Tomb Raider was shot) in the same day. In fact, there is a readymade itinerary followed by all tuk tuk and car drivers called Small Tour, or Small Circuit. It starts from Angkor Vat, then goes to Banteay Kdei, Ta Prohm, Prasat Kvan, Ta Keo, the Leper King Terrace and Elephant Terrace and finally Bayon. You can pass the Victory Gate on the way back to the city. On July 2014, this was worth USD13-15 on a tuk tuk (excluding ticket price of course).Then there is the Grand Tour, which takes you to Banteay Srei, Pre Rup, East Mebon, Ta Som, Preah Khan etc. The road to Banteay Sreai also passes the Landmine Museum. Its a very evocative place, consider checking it out on the way back. Ticket prices were 3 USD, from September it would be 5 USD but its worth it, and the money goes into taking care of victims of landmines, so its a worthwhile visit. On another day, you can go to the Roulos Group of temples. You can combine it with either Tonle Sap or Beng Melea. Take a guide on the first day just to get a sense and bearing of the place. For the subsequent days you can go on your own, the tuk tuk drivers know working English and with the help of maps (freely available) will take you to wherever you want to go. If you don't want to depend on tuk tuk drivers and if you fit, you can get bicycles (many hotels give them for free) and easily ride to all the temples in the short tour. Wear good comfortable sneakers and shoes and carry/drink plenty of water and you will be fine. Remember that these were religious structures so don't disrespect the locals or the structures. Wear normal clothes and you are fine. Shorts and t shirts are ok almost everywhere except the inner sanctum of Angkor Vat. Both men and women need to cover up their shoulders and knees to enter the inner sanctum. The Cambodians are very very friendly and helpful people, so don't take advantage of them. Its a must see place and I absolutely loved it and will go there again whenever I have the chance.
magical. the history and beautiful temples so big with many temples and parks to visit you need at least two days to explore very relaxing and we loved Seam reap will be back for sure

Enchanting. The temples in this complex are beautiful and impressive--truly one of the cultural wonders of the world. Don't miss them if you can possibly see. $40 for a 3 day pass. Would suggest getting a guide for the best experience.
Amazing. History is interesting and to see it gives a different opion,photographers greatest images , lighting ect.

The main reason for a visit to Siem Reap!. The park is huge and best seen with a guide (in a motorized vehicle). The distances between the temples are long and it's best to go with an experienced guide who knows the timing of the giant tour groups and can take you to the temples when they are least crowded. The temples themselves are incredibly interesting and just amazing. Definitely worth a trip across the world to see these massive structures and learn about their history.
Must see!. Very crowded but very different from other temples in SE Asia. Really impressive and so much to see! Truly worth the money and time. Just beautiful in its own way.

Crowded But Worth It. We did both the sunrise "photo op" visit at 5:00 am and a more relaxed "walkabout" in the afternoon. We thought we would be avoiding crowds at sunrise (who would be up at 4:00 am???), but boy were we wrong! The afternoon visit was less crowded by boy was it HOT. Guess you can't win at this temple...

Love this place. Grab the us$40 pass and make your tour. Hire a tuk tuk to bring u all over :) best sight seeing in siem reap :)
Like as though it's one of the world wonders. :)

This encapsulates a lot of different sites but they are all amazing and totally beautiful.. This entry does take a lot of individual sites and puts them together but if offered as a tour, take it! We went around on the back of motorbikes with our guide and saw some of the best examples of the local history and natural beauty. Get up to the hill above Angkor Wat for the sunset and watch it in all of its prehistoric glory and the sun sets on the towers. Such a life affirming moment for me and my family.

world class. A must see. Take your time and buy a multi day pass and see at your leisure .read a little before going to help with understanding. A very large area with many temples and areas of interest .

Angkor Park. A trip to Siem Reap would not be complete without visiting Angkor.Some tips - it is hot and (in the high season) very crowded. remember to take drinks, good walking shoes and there are a few places you cannot go if you are wearing shorts / short sleeves. remember it is still used as a temple at certain times of the year and you need to be sensitive to the religious requirements. the buildings and carvings are incredible and well worth time to wander round. A guide is recommended - can be too much information but better than not enough!Definitely a must do .......
Must go. Just go. It ticks all the boxes . It has monkeys big buildings, water, forest lots of pictures can be taken.There is food there and you can do it in a day or week if you want to.

Need a few days to see this. We were only able to spend 2 days but were able to see many temples with a private tour guide. I highly recommend a private tour guide that is licensed properly in Cambodia. They are very knowledgeable of their history as part of their training, we as times had information overload but it was wonderful, I probably took over 1,000 photos in the 2 days at the various temples.

A dream come true. Getting to Angkor was something I had in mind since I was a kid. Now that I finally made it happen, I have to say it has not disappointed me at all, it is the great place you expect it to be. But the government should do something about the exploitation of the ruins if they want Angkor to keep amazing visitors in the future. The way the ruins are exploited for the tourism industry is not sustainable, the conservation of the buildings is far from being acceptable, in spite of being a World Heritage Site by Unesco. The authorities must do something about it.

Awe Inspiring. Having read and heard some much about Angkor it still could not prepare me for what you truly experience when you see it and walk through it first hand. Around ever corner is another marvel of human ingenuity. You could spend hours admiring the size of the temples and the way nature is reclaiming it's original location.

one of greatest historic sites on earth!. We spent one week here visiting the park in July. Three day pass gave us enough time to see all including sunrise at Angkor Wat. This entire park is fascinating with rich history and architectures. We rent tuk-tuk each day and it is great way to stop at any temple at your own pace.

Love this place!!!. Been here twice in 2 years and still have not seen it all. Love the carvings and the history that goes with places like this. Amazes me they built and carved this stuff thousands of years ago.

Only wish we had more time to spend in this park.... I noticed that one can give reviews of each temple in this park but that is too time-consuming and while some temples definitely are must-sees, others can be fun to just wander around in. Although I read up on this place before we left on our trip, I was still stunned at what a huge area it covers...it can be overwhelming. We only had two days to visit with our Tour Group and one day on our own. We would have liked to have spent a minimum of a week to be able to tour things more closely and see more temples. On our first day the tour took us to Ta Phrom (the Jungle Temple - trees growing over the ruins) and then Banteay Srei (elaborate red sandstone carvings), both very different from each other. On the second day we visited Angkor Wat (got there at 5:45 a.m. to watch the sunrise...hint if you do this on your own...try to sit on the inside of the outer wall for a great view...you are above the people on the ground and get better photos, too) and saw all the amazing bas-relief carvings in some of the galleries. Later we visited Angkor Thom but mostly concentrated on Bayon (with all its smiling faces). The day on our own we visited Preah Khan - hired a tuk-tuk to take us out and bring us back. There were so many other temples we would have loved to see but no time. Things to keep in mind...you MUST have a pass to enter the park and visit the temples...they take your photograph for the pass (line moves quickly). You can get a 1 day, 3 day, or 7 day pass (we had a 3 day one $40).Also the park is located quite a distance from Siem Reap and there is a lot of traffic.
