And it can take time to get from one temple to another so don't plan on seeing a lot of temples in one day.

Pure awesomeness!. Just pure awesomeness. The temple complex is HUGE and has many temples with different styles. Get yourself a tour guide to explain the history of the complex and you will be amazed by this site.

Will go back again!. The place is full of history and is a true architectural wonder considering it was built hundreds of years ago. Angkor Wat, Bayon, Banteay Srei and Ta Prohm are the most popular and perhaps the best temples. If visiting during the rainy season, it is advisable to take along a rain coat as it will be needed.Hire a good guide to beat the crowds and to know interesting local stories. Cambodians are fantastic and extremely nice. Give a good tip and you will get a heartfelt response!All in all a great experience!!!!

Surreal. This whole place is quite large and magical. There are a lot of temples to see which cannot be done in one day. If you're the type of person who wants to say ''been there, done that'' Then you could most definitely see the more popular temples in one day. However if you would like to take your time or see many more temples. 2 or 3 days are needed. The beauty of this place is indescribable. A truly magical and unforgettable experience which you wont regret!

Amazing Place!. Just being on place that existed for over a thousand years is enough reason to visit this place. Just make sure you choose a good tour guide, who will take care of you, who will make you laugh and will not bore you. Touring Angkor Wat for a day can be a Temple Overload so make sure you have fun while doing it.

From the variety to the scenery. So impressive.. The fact that it is so close to town only makes it better. From the Surrounding moat and HUGE GREEN space around Angor Wat to the surrounding jungle and other temples. Don't rush, but take it all in!

Nature at its best. One must read about Angkor before visiting the sites.The prosperous Khmer civilisation between 8th and 13th century sent emissaries to India to find out why India was more prosperous."They pray at Temples" was their observation and the kings made temples for Vishnu, Shiva,Hanuman and Apsaras few of which were replaced by Buddha (Sakyamuni of the Hindus who is the 10th incarnation of Vishnu) in these beautiful temples.Nature's fury did not destroy these architectural wonders saved by God Himself between then and the 19th century, that we witness today at the Archeological Park where the roots of the century old trees serve as canopy to these excellent monuments.Have a good camera to take beautiful pictures.Be prepared for walks and climbs in the tropical heat. You will cherish the memories.
The reason to visit Siem Reap. Must do activity for visitors to Siem Reap. The history, craftsmanship and beauty are not to be missed.

One of the most interesting temples worldwide. I can't imagine visiting during high season (probably much too crowded). At low season the crowds were not so large so that some peaceful moments could be found inside. It was a pleasure to explore the carved walls and learn some of the Hindu / Buddhist history relating to the temple.

Angkor wat. Extraordinary and beautiful site. Could not recommend highly enough. One point we were not aware of beforehand. You need to buy tickets to enter park. They have no visa machine. CASH only. And dollars only not local currency. We had just about enough with us so be warned. I was surprised that this major national attraction would nt accept its national currency.

Angkor Park. If you have time visit the park in planned schedules in at least three different days. It has so much to offer and putting them all in a day's time is not advisable and very tiresome. Would like to go back and explore everything
Lots more work. People management needs improvement. Cambodian local vendors need to be trained to be less obtrusive and more effective. Are those kids hawking of age?
Beautiful sunrise. Beautiful temples, excellent sunrise, locals trying to sell their goods, get a bit annoying. Go early to beat the heat.
Incredible, just incredible. This is quite incredible. Just watch for the little kids trying to sell you things. Definitely a bucket list item

The reason to come to Siem Reap. We spent 3 days visiting the complex - just amazing like going back in time. I would recommend a guide to tell you the stories and the history along with the many myths surrounding the complex. The price is steep at 40.00$ per person - and sadly the government leased the income rights to a vietnamese corporation so none of the money you pay for a ticket comes into Cambodia - down right horrible ~ however it is an amazing place to see and truly a transport back in time! Don't miss it!

Soak in the sights and breathe in the fresh air. One of the cleanest archaeological sites I have ever seen in my life. The whole complex has been neatly kept, and restoration of torn down parts are all over the place. Learn from the rich history and marvel at the gorgeous architecture. The temples aren't far apart, and there are lush forests that can pique your interest in between. I recommend taking a tuk tuk to soak in the entire experience -- fresh air, vibrant weather. I've seen many buses and cars drive by and couldn't help but feel that they're missing out. Bring water reserves and sunscreen on warm days, you might get exhausted and feel "templed out" in the end but the experience is truly worthwhile.

Three days in the Angkor Temples. Visiting Cambodia on our honeymoon, Husband and I had an amazing time everywhere but capped off by the Temples. Magnificent of course and so glad we got to see them. Take your time, be sensible about travelling and of course respect the place and the people around you and you'll love it. Full review / post and photos here: http://sunshineandgin.wordpress.com/2014/07/08/honeymoon-in-cambodia-angkor/

Amazing sights and history. So much to see and learn in this huge reserve with all the beautiful temples. Hard to choose a favourite as they are all beautiful and different - bit like saying you have a favourite child. If you don't want to feel rushed I would allow 3 days - we went with our 2 boys - 7 & 9 and they really enjoyed it. Of course if you have an interest in history and Angkor culture or photography you could easily spend much longer.Go with a knowledgeable guide as hard to see how you could appreciate such a large and complex site without one. The history is extremely interesting and there is so much to learn in the detail.

This is Why You're in Siem Riep. There are several ways to view the many temples in the Park. I recommend hiring a private car and driver. It's more comfortable than at tuk tuk and you will appreciate the car's Air Conditioning as you ride from temple to temple.
Drivers are available in the language of your choice.

AWESOME. Eye opening architecture of bygone era.
Did Not ever realize Hinduism was there in that form. Ramayana unfolding right in front of your eyes. Restoration work is commendable.Bargain well with tuk tuk drivers and be careful of scamsters at the border should you do a roadtrip from Thailand..

GO EARLY!. We went on the small circuit for sunrise. It was a rainy day, and clearly there wasn't going to be a dramatic sunrise, over Angkor Way so we just headed into the wat instead of waiting for the sunrise. This was definitely the right move! We had the whole complex to ourselves (just one other couple) for a good 20 minutes of so. It was great to be able to explore without any around! On thing of note, the stairs up the main temple do not open until 7:45am, but I man is standing there saying you can go up for $5. If I had to do this over: Day 1: Do sunrise at Angkor Wat (but go in instead of waiting for the sunrise. Then go to Bayon, and then Ta Thom. All of them were amazing. So different and each unique. We did not have to deal with crowds at all - and were back to our hotel room by 10am. Day 2: We went to Koh Ker and beng Meala. Both were impressive, and a taxi to both cost us $100. Both were great, unique places to see. (Note, both have separate passes, your angkor pass does not work at either). Day 3: Do the Roulus group in the morning (takes about two hours). Go see Bantrei Srei and the Landmine Museum in the afternoon. Things we did that were missable:- The large circuit. The temples became "same, same but different." Nothing really unique about them. -Kbal Spleen: It's okay for a hike and to get away from the city. The carvings aren't that great. - DO NOT WASTE your time/money at the National Museum. Totally overpriced and underwhelming.
step back in time. one of the most historical sites in the world, its fantastic to see that the people are taking steps to protect their heritage

Just keep going back!. This park holds so many of the famous temples and relics as well as the Flight of the Gibbons zip line and restaurants and stalls. You can visit by bicycle, tuk tuk, taxi or organised tour. If you have the energy and time it is lovely cycling around and looking at it all at your own pace. Early morning is a good time to visit before the crowds. Angkor Wat itself gets very busy, but the large tour groups tend to go back to town for lunch, so this can be a quiet, if a bit hotter, time to visit. The restaurants at the front of Angkor Wat are nice and cheap and a good place for a rest and toilet stop. If you really went hard you could see a lot of this area in one big day, but much nicer to spread it out over a few and really enjoy it. Once you get your entry ticket you are free to visit your choice of temples at your leisure. I would recommend a guide for your initial visit as you will learn and be shown things you otherwise wouldn't see or know. Ta Phrom is quite small and gets really busy so I would plan this one for a very early. There are some less known and less visited temples in the park that are much less visited and worth a look too. You will never forget your visit to Angkor so make the most of it.

A vacation highlight. Rather than write individual reviews for all the temples including Angkor Thom, Bayon, Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, they are all located within the Angkor Archaeological Park - Siem Reap.We visited this area during June 2014. This is low season for the region and by all accounts from the locals, is the best time to visit as it gets crazy busy around Dec- Feb.We are so glad we made the effort to visit this place en-route to Vietnam.it is widely believed that Cambodia is the "soul" of South East Asia and it's easy to see why.The Khmer people are gentle and beautiful, the food is great and the environment including the fascinating historical temples is worth every minute spent there.There was a certain vibrancy and charm about Siem Reap that left us feeling very warm about the place and we can't wait to go back again and soak it up a bit more, it truly is a world treasure.

Archaeological heaven!. Allow at least 3 days for this amazing complex of temples, and hire your own tuk-tuk to take you around, as the distance to some temples is considerable. A 3-day pass can be used over any 3 days within a week. Start early in the morning to avoid the heat and crowds, drink lots of water, take a hat and please don't give sweets to children begging or selling postcards. Their parents can't afford to take them to the dentist!

A must see historical site. The pyramids of Egypt shrink in comparison to Angkor's sprawling acres of temples. Constructed out of various stone, some of many tonnes in weight and quarried many miles away, it is was a massive construction project over a relatively short period.Allow a minimum of one full day just to get a taste of Angkor, 2 would be better + another to enjoy Siem Reap... a great little tourist town!

Possibly the best archaeological site in the world. 'Do' both the grand circle and the small circle, so you get an appreciation of the magnitude of the Khmer achievement. Then go back and look at the different sites again in more detail. There is so much to see and appreciate in the small details. Some sites are being left in the same state as when they were rediscovered. Others have been restored with the help of various universities, governments and other agencies from around the world. Even a week is not long enough to see everything and appreciate the more intimate details of the architecture and decorative features.

Ankor wat park Trully amazing!. We had a magical day here. There were many many tourists and many many hawkers but that did not take away at all from the wonderful day seeing amazing ancient temples. The highlight was when a women gently took me into an alcove of the main temple in Ankor Wat and gave me incense and showed me how to bow to the shrine. There was another gentle movement toward a donation box. Once I placed a dollar in there she placed a cotton friendship band on my wrist and wished me long life. I still wear it 6 mths later and remember that experience with fondness.

See Everything!. Grand circle or small circle? See them both! There is so much to see here - allow at least half a day for Angkor Thom - it did used to be a city of a million people and although in a state of ruin now is still amazing and you can grab lunch here before you head off elsewhere. Make sure you wear T-shirt if you plan to see the temples around Angkor park - basically no vests, covered top part of your legs, no short shorts. Just respect this is an active temple site still, you are not on a beach holiday. We saw a Russian guy walking around topless, showing no respect to the culture at all, he did get told to dress!!Save Angkor itself until last as this is the best and otherwise everything else will not be as impressive.

Take several days.. This was the reason I came to Siem Reap, and even though it is possible to see the majority of the park over a weekend, take your time. Take several days to visit the temples, and go back to your favorites at different times of the day. The experience will be completely different. Also, because the park is so extensive, make time to travel around a bit more. Take in the countryside and the local villages to get a look at a different side of Cambodia.
Say Wat!?. One of the most beautiful places that I have seen in my entire life. Everything in it is just so astonishing and beautiful. Would definitely comeback!
Amazing Experience. This is why you come to Siem Reap and the visit did not disappoint although nothing prepares you for the heat. Wonderful time exploring and a must see.

Unbelievable, magical, ethereal. We were not sure the children (age 7 and 8) would want to wander too far in amongst the templates, but they came alive. Everyone is moved by the sheer quality of this park and the oozing of history throughout all the temples. Should be on everyone's 100 things to visit in a lifetime.

Go for the Sunrise. The sunrise silhouette is the best picture you will take if you are lucky enough to get a good sun/sky combo. The complex is large and sprawling so try to start your day early before the rush of the tourists. Obviously, this is the must go to spot so every one will be there. The iconic towers make a great picture reflected over both the pond and the moat. Make sure to climb to the top for a scenic panoramic view from all the corners of the temple. This one is probably the one one most well restored and complex buildings of all of Cambodia.

Magical. The main attraction of Siem Reap that houses all of the temples in "Things to do" list. Costs $20 per day or $40 for 3 days. The complex is enormous and not possible to see every temple in one day, but I felt as though they all looked rather similar after you've seen Angkor Wat and Bayon. But I know that many people advise three days. It's your choice!

Never ceases to amaze!!. I have visited Angkor numerous times over the years and the place never ceases to amaze me. Just the shear size and architectural majesty of the temples,and the detail of the carvings. Definitely something that should be on everyone's bucket list. Outstanding!

A wonder of the world. Simply amazing... words cannot describe it. You simply marvel at what was built so long ago - the architecture, the fine intricate details, the symmetry and the ambience.. I also loved and respected that the Cambodians (other than doing much needed restoration work) have managed to keep the Park in its natural state with a welcome absence of vendors and tourist shops etc. You wouldn't visit Siem Reap without visiting this place - its awe-inspiring.

You must go once in your lifetime. This is probably the best archaeological site I have ever visited. The park itself is huge with so many temples spread out that you could easily spend a week there and still be seeing something new. You need a driver, we used a tuk tuk for the four days we were there (a man called Mr Smeeth - thoroughly recommend him) and we found that the going rate was $15 for half a day and $25 for a full day, with an additional $15 if you want to visit sites out of the park (this covers the extra fuel / time etc). The other thing you need is patience, don't try to do too much, pace yourself - especially pertinent if you are after good photos as you need to frame your shot then wait for the crowds to clear. We went in the rainy season and found that it was fine in the morning but stormed for an hour or so around 3pm, we quite liked this as it cooled off substantially after the rain (bring a rain coat and a plastic bag for your camera). The other benefit is lower crowds, but this is balanced with a lack of spectacular sunsets as there is a lot of cloud.

The reason you come to Cambodia. You cannot help but be caught up in the history some so very ancient and others not quite so. Angkor park has a past that leaves the observer looking in awe at the architecture and the sheer brilliance of the massive nature of each temple. How they managedto construct these enormous buildings defies belief, a must see

Angkor Archeological Park: a place to explore and find hidden treasure. You will love this place if you love history or temples. It is a big complex of temples in Angkor Era...I guess it was the most glorious era in Cambodian History. I explored this place for 3 days and I guess it is the best duration for visiting this place. I paid $40 for 3 days pass and worth it. I used 3 different kinds of transportation: tuk tuk for Small Circuit in the 1st day (sharing with Indonesian who I met in Phnom Penh International Airport), biking around Ground Circuit in the 2nd day and motorcycle (with cambodian rider) to watch sunrise in Angkor Wat, visit Banteay Srei and Banteay Samre for the last day. It was super fun! Combining between adventures and exercise. The temples I like most are Banteay Srei and Banteay Samre. So when I visited those temples in the morning of my last day in Siem Reap, I feel like getting big surprises. It was beautifully standing there under the sun ray...full of details, feminine, compared to another temples in both Small and Grand Circuit.I did love biking there because the park is surrounded by trees, jungles and has flat track. The only challenge was a very hot-humid weather... It felt like 40°C..a free sauna!Overall, it is a great place to be explored...

One on the bucketlist. Awesome experience. The visit did not disappoint. We traveled with young kids and nothing prepares you for the heat. Wonderful memories and a must see if this is what you fancy.

thirsty work :). Incredible temples but beware the "very helpful and knowledgeable young men who approach you full of information and follow you around" if you dont send them on thier way at the beginning they will demand money from you later and can become quite angry if you refuse even if no agreement was made. Also take plenty of water with you otherwise you will be mobbed at the market stalls.

Enter for free after 5.30, it doesn't worth your money. The review score is very high, I saw no bad reviews at all. We bought entry pass for 3 days for $40. But even one day was too much. All the temples look the same.Remote temples can be visited without any ticket. All the site can be visited for free after 5.30 pm. Just wait until the guards are gone. Don't support this corrupted country buying the ticket. Your money don't go for conservation purposes.

spectacular. We used about Asia travel tour operator to organise our visit of Angkor and the guide was amazing making sure that we saw all the best bits when there was the least number of tourists (definitely worth having a guide when visiting as there is just so much to see and so much details that you can easily miss!)

Very nice - bring a guide. We did the sunrise....breathtaking. loved it.We had our own guide, its worth it and make the big diffent to understand the stity of the history that is in those walls. Amazing

Cambodian pride and heritage and largest religious buildings on Earth. Needless to say Angkor and its temples are one of Wonders of the World and it is one of the primary attractions for tourists in Cambodia, place of pilgrimage of many buddhists and hinduists.20$ tickets gives you opportunity to visit any temple within 24 hrs.One of the opportunities for improvement could be more toiled facilities (at least portable biowaste ones) and give the ability to go by scooters for tourists. I understand government tries to take care of locals by giving them change to drive tourists on tuk-tuks and private buses but more flexibilty means more tourists. I like to be independent, explore and read myself.Anyways, must see in Cambodia for everyone who likes adventures and real life Indiana Jones experience.
Fantastic Historical Place. Take your time while you walk thru these ancient ruins and try to imagine how people built it and how they lived in those years.

You have to do this..... I have no idea how to review this. You can't go to Cambodia and not see it. Plan on spending a couple of hours exploring, try to go early to avoid crowds and heat. Be sure to wear the appropriate clothes (sleeves and legs covered to knees).

Amazing Angkor. Amazing at sunrise, but you need to get there for 4.30am, to see the sun right behind the Angkor temples. It is not worth going for sunset, as the sun does not set behind it, but this is a good time to go to the temple, as there are less people and everyone else has gone to Bakheng Mountain for sunset.Wander inside, spend time looking at all the intricate details, remember for any temple, to cover shoulders and above the knees, it is bets to wear t shirt, long shorts, pants or definitely covered sarong and shawl over top, no sleeveless and bare legs to fully respect the religion and culture of these sacred places of worship.Although worth doing for a good 1-3 hours, depending on how much/less, quick/slow you like to wander around there, I actually felt that all the other places on the grand circuit and small circuit aside from this were more memorable.

Everything one would expect and more. You've seen seen it in Tomb Raider, National Geographic and the History Channel, this preparation means you know what is looks like but being there walking over rubble, makes you feel like an real explorer (if you pretend the hordes of tourists walking around taking pictures and yelling loudly are not there), heat and humidity included. If you go to the smaller less popular sites, it's a timeless experience.We went to the ruins at 6am, went back to the hotel for lunch, swim to escape the heat then went back out again at 4pm when it was cooler. This worked out really well for us and allowed us to enjoy the sites more.The people are really friendly, lots of people selling you books, postcards, etc but not really pushy. Our tuk tuk driver was extremely nice and always smilling. We bought prepaid mobile SIMs at the airport, this allowed us to wander through the ruins at our own pace. Also useful to let your driver know you are ready to leave. For USD5 each, why would you not get one for everyone in your group. Some carriers offers free calls to each other.

The pride of Cambodia. The Angkor Archeological Parks is laid on a very large space, and some of the temples are really far from each other. Of course the magnificent Angkor Wat is the king of the Park, It is the biggest Hindu temple ever build in the world, and with its basreliefs , its statues, its stories depicted on stone, it introduce you in a forgotten world of past times. Actually everyone is thinking first of the Angkor Wat when saying Cambodia!

Before you get your pass.... The park is well worth the entrance fee but rather than wax lyrical about the temples (which have plenty of reviews) I thought I would mention what I wished I had known BEFORE I went:1. Flight of the Gibbons ziplining adventure is actually in the park. You can book this AND your one day pass on their website. I didn't realise this until the day after I'd been to the park therefore it would have cost me an additional US$20 to do this activity.2. Monkeys - I didn't know you pass groups of wild monkeys on the way to the temples. Buy some bananas and take them with you and ask your driver to stop so you can feed them. They are very cute and will take the banana from your hand.3. Elephants - I also didn't know that there are 3 points in the park where you can get an elephant ride for between US$15 and US$20.4. Do yourself a favour and go to the Museum and do the audio headphones self guided tour for US$15 the day before you go to the park. We learnt so much we felt we didn't need a guide for the 1 day we were in the park. We also saw the best relics as they were preserved in the museum.We paid US$30 for an air con car for the day and it was so worth it due to the heat.

Indiana Jones!. I had a 3-day park pass and was taken around daily, by a local, Chea, on his motorbike. (I was even invited for a proper lunch with his family - a wonderful experience). Each day I was out for at least 8 hours. The sights are incredible, especially the off-the-beaten path ones. Some of the lesser visited, but in my opinion, most rewarding sights were: The Roluos Group, Banteay Srei, the Cambodian Landmine Museum, East Mebon and Preah Khan. The famous sights of Bayon and Angkor Thom, however, are not to be missed. With few other visitors (particularly in the more remote/far-reaching sights), I felt like I was actually 'discovering' these ruins.
Amazing craftmanship. The stone craving is amazing. Cannot imagine how it can be built in so many years before. It is a really good place to take photos, light and shadow, a beautiful picture

Truly Amazing. You are captured from the start. Looking at pictures you cannot wait to see this beautiful place. When you see it, it takes your breath away. I could not believe I was actually here. Such an amazing place, I could not stop taking photos...It is amazing to see and hear the history of Angkor Watt. Be prepared as there are lots of stairs and it can be quite tiring, take plenty of water to drink.Do not miss going here as I am sure you won't be disappointed.

Divine!!!. Please visit this place. Whatever you saw on Nat Geo, Discovery and History Channel is true. No wonder this place is always in the list of places to go in the world while you are still alive.

Love all of Siem Reap. I was just here last week for 4 days. Still can't stop thinking about it. The sheer beauty and the warm people and the great service at the hotels and the food. Yes, this is more then just temples. But when you do set foot on any of these very well kept historical parks you are suck in in totality. At first you may not get it, the weather is always hot and there are some places with too many people in tour groups. But in the end you will be in awe of the power of it all. You keep asking the same questions over and over: How did they do this 1000 years ago? We can't come close to doing it NOW. And after you leave your life do change in some way because of this place in the Cambodia jungle. I love everything about this place. I will visit again soon.

I enjoyed the temples so much!. Marveled at the architecture. It's a brilliant masterpiece! So proud of the ancient Asian! Angkor Archaeological Park is a must come whenever you visit Siem Reap. Advise to get a tuk tuk driver to drive you around as they know which temples to bring you. Unless you do your homework well then maybe you could hire a bicycle. Tour guides with different languages are there for you. They will explain every single details about the temples. The park is very big, I think a three days pass is good enough. The ancient city trip was one of the highlights of my trip to Cambodia. Awesome UNESCO site!

Fantastic Ankor Wat. Great historical experience.
Beggars were the only thing to dislike.
Ambiance of the place is breath taking.

Quite an organised area with clear signs and maps.. The park is very spread out and a bicycle is sufficient for most of it as the whole area is flat. There is over 20 temples I think. The enter the ark there is a fee of $20 for one day, $40 for three days and $60 for 7 days. You only in my opinion need 3 days in total to see 90% of it.

Truly UNESCO worthy. I have been coming to Cambodia for family and biz visits for years, but finally gave in to the 7 hour bus ride (each way from Phnom Penh) and summer heat to check out Siem Reap. Being that I have always traveled and visited UNESCO sights (last year spent 4 days in Siena) I did not think I would be easily impressed. But man was I wrong. Angkor Wat, the jungle temple (forgot the name), Bayon Temple, etc., did not disappoint. I never realized this part of the world had achieved this heights and scale of civilization, so early on. And how nature can still impose its will in reclaming it. Not only were the sights awe inspiring, but definitely take you back in time.

Siem Reap is the gateway to Angkor. Really a must see... easy to get ripped off by tuk tuk drivers, but almost necessary to have one. of course there are other ways to do it, we thought about renting a bike, however the distances are quite long in between temples, as this is an ancient city. It also gets really hot during the day, with not much shade in places... so getting back into the tuk tuk to go to the next one is a welcome breeze. We almost got duped for a 40$ return trip, until our driver was late for sunrise and we decided to wait until the next day, where we arranged a 15$ (18$ for the wider circuit) round trip through a different hotel. We highly recommend going early!! (its about 15km from town) Sunrise was so peaceful, the light is great on the temples for photos, and the crowds only got worse as the day went on.

historical... Pros- very peaceful and serene...historical architecture... we hired a guide which is very well verse but u hv to bargain the price. We bargained to 10usd but in d end we paid him 15usd..Cons- insufficient info about the temples and d building itself. D guides are as high as 20usd/hr.. d books, detail maps and reading material are not available at the ticketing.... n please bargain whn ure buying from the locals, u cn get books as low as usd1, fridge magnets- 3 for 1 usd or a bag for usd1.... beware of kids asking for foreign currency as souvenier...Suggestion-electronic guided audio tour, example like in the killing fields...
Immense Archeological Site. We only had one day to explore and you need two or three to do it justice. Our favorite was Ta Prohm or the famous Tomb Raider temple.

wonderful. a lot of temples to visit!but a lot of stairs to clum also!may be they should make night tour to viit it!and also the price is expenssive: 20 dollard for one day and 40 dollard for the three day!you have to add the tuk tuk driver money!if u take it from the guest house it' 40 dollards more!so you need 80 dolard to visit this park!and add the supplements oof surise and flotting villages and the boat!

The fairest of them all!!!. It is like stepping back in time.I like this more than the other temples because it's not too huge to go take a look around every inch but at the same time, not too small to get bored. Somehow Bayon is more personalized in such a way that you get to explore tunnels and be surrounded by huge smiling heads that are just breathtakingly spectacular. You are up close and being just next to them - words cannot explain. The visitors here are not as packed as Angkor Wat, hence you get more time for yourself. :)Choosing a great tuktuk driver as well can either enhance or make your trip really bad. I recommend Pech Vanny. Search for him in facebook :)))

Just amazing - There is no other word for it. This is THE thing to do when visiting Siem Reap. The complex is absolutely amazing and if you want to do all of the temples you will have to stay for weeks. The temples are quite huge and if you want to see it all and explore it takes time. I would recommend a guide to tell you about the temple and its history as it will increase your experience. It is also busy, lots of tourists and its hot and dusty but that is to be expected in a tropical country Just prepare yourself, do half-day tours, bring plenty of water, take breaks, sunscreen, snacks etc. The temples themselves are just amazing, there is no other way to describe it. The amount of buildings, the detail, the construction of them... it is so hard to fathom the amazing culture that is behind it all. To stand in the middle off it all and just look around and try to take it all in, its hard to describe. You can get 1, 3 or 6 day passes. You have to go in on consecutive days and the prices are $20 (1 day), $40 (3 days) and $60 (6 days).

It is awesome. This place is like taken put of a movie, make sure you early if the day is too hot so you can really enjoy it. The trees grown on the walls, its just amaizing. You can't missit if you are in Siem Reap. Just beautiful.

Fabulous temple ever seen. I went to visit temples in Angkor.
I was very happy and liked it because it was so amazing and made excited.

World class monuments but.... I worry about the corruption and preservation of these historic temples. During our trip we learned that much of the money from the park ticket doesn't ever filter back to the park or the communities in the Siem Reap area. The companies that run the park are either owned by a hotel chain or senior politicians. UNESCO should do something to encourage the government to do more to protect and preserve (rather than exploit) the site.

Pictures do no justice. I was here near the end of April. I got a 3-day pass but only used 2 days. Everyone’s different – some can spend days checking every nook and cranny, while others only need a walk through. It didn’t matter – it’s $20/day or $40 for 3 days, so I didn’t lose money by only using 2 days of my pass.I went the day before at 5pm to get my pass, having been advised via other reviews that the entrance can be a zoo in the mornings. It took 3 minutes to get my pass at 5pm (you are also granted free access for sunset if you go at this time), and the next morning there was almost nobody at the entrance. I think this is luck of the draw though.I paid my driver $15 per day (as advised by my hostel) and tipped him $2 each day. He was more than happy with this. He picked me up both days at 7am and I was finished by about noon each day. I really liked having a tuk tuk. After the intense heat of walking around the temples, it was nice to sit in the back and feel the breeze as we drove to the next one. In a car, the AC wouldn’t be cold until you are already at the next stop.I didn’t have a guide. I felt it would hold me back. I’m much more visual than audio, so listening to someone talk was not for me. I did my research before I came and kept my notes with me.It is so incredibly hot, even early in the morning, I was going through a bottle of water an hour, and I’m a small person. So definitely be prepared for that. Also note that some temples require climbing. Some are easy, but some are downright intimidating because they are so high.At Angkor Wat, you can go on the grounds of the temple, but you cannot climb the main temple if you are dressed inappropriately. I was wearing a t-shirt and loose fitting capris and was allowed in but asked to remove my hat. Baphuon won’t let you in at all if you are dressed inappropriately. I was not allowed as I was wearing shorts on my 2nd day.Pictures do not do this place justice. Nor do they give any real concept of just how big these stunning temples are. Regardless of your exploring style, I can’t say anything others haven’t already said – it’s just incredible.

Must see. A must see note of caution if u are unsteady on your feet be sure to take a stick very uneven paths and potentially a lot of steps some can be avoided, if you are going to see the sunrise a small torch will help you find your feet as it is dark

Stunning. If you visit Cambodia, Angkor is a must. This is one of the most beautiful places I've seen in my life. Go ahead and get the three day or the seven day pass. The one day pass is just not enough to visit the temples.

Easy trip on a very hot day. On one of our days in Angkor we decided simply to drive round the sights by tuk tuk to get an overview of the different sites we could return to later. Very enjoyable, as the temperature went up to 40 degrees C and the roads in the park are shaded by tall forest trees. Would strongly recommend this if you have time.

The best archaeological site in the world. Overwhelming in size, scale and beauty, the Angkor site is basically the world's best and most impressive site - and the single best site in South East Asia. One tip - get a guide and an air-conditioned car (via your hotel) as this will allow you to escape the crowds and see more - and learn more about the fascinating history of the Khmer empire...

WHAT A SIGHT!. I've wanted to go here since I was a little girl and saw a picture of Jackie Kennedy touring the site. Angkor Wat did not disapoint. It is an absolutely fascinating place with so much history and culture. We spent three days here and it was not enough to see it all. We had a full time guide who was wonderful. I would recommend several things - go to see the main temple 1st thing in the morning. It is incredibly hot(110 degrees) and the heat will take every ounce of energy out of you. Bring sun screen(50+), plenty of water and wear a sun hat. Wear cotton or linen clothes or those wicking fabrics. . . . take plenty of breaks and carry an umbrella for the sun. I had a small portable $4.00 one and it was a lifesaver. I also bought a fan from a vendor which really helped. Cambodia is very poor and you will see beggars both children and adults in dire straits. I am glad I went.

Jaw Dropping!. Simply put, no words can describe all that is here!!! Once you’ve seen the photos of the forest slowly overtaking the ruins, it’s hard to not want to spend some time here.Being a history/religion and architecture enthusiast I was excited to have the time to visit Angkor Archaeological Park. My personal thought is to hire a Tuk Tuk for the day, for about 3-days, and travel from Wat to Wat. Having your personal Tuk Tuk will help you when wanting to enter from one side of a temple and exit from the other side, plus it does not hurt to have some insider knowledge.There was one out of our three days we decided to do a lot of walking and found that it gets annoying when drivers are hassling you to take their Tuk Tuk for $2 - $4 one way. You also have the option to have a car drive you around, but it is not the same feeling as an open air Tuk Tuk that does not go too fast.One great experience was hand feeding wild monkeys!!! We had passed a lady who follows them around while selling bananas... so we stopped and bought some and gathered some amazing footage with our cameras. BUT, be cautious of leaving your items on the Tuk Tuk, a monkey might go through them or take them.We had visited a month after the Angkor Wat International Half Marathon, which runs right through the famous ruins. The race markers were still out and this helped grasp the size of this place.There are plenty of places to eat and buy beverages while in the park. We relied on our Tuk Tuk driver to take us to some good eats where not many people were at... again this is a plus for having your own Tuk Tuk driver. By the way, you can find any Tuk Tuk driver in town to do this for you, or your hotel can set it up. If your hotel offers it, take it so you get someone who will not short you of time by rushing you. They are very trust worthy and only cost about $20 for the entire day.Low cost service for a great experience. Well worth it!!! You can pay $20 for a day pass, or $40 for a 3 day pass. Afterwards I was very thankful we chose the 3-day because of everything you can do

Two day tour. You definitely need two days to do the wealth of sites here justice. Day 1, get a guide to show you the highlights Angkor Wat, The Bayon (4 Faces Temple), Ta Prohm (Jungle Temple) and the outlying Banteay Srey (Pink Temple). Day 2 return with a Tuk Tuk and see some lesser sights on your own. Don't under estimate the heat, it will slow you down. If you are determined to see as many temples as possible, take note. Waking up for an Angkor Sunrise and walking up lots of steep monuments soon takes it toll. Luckily there are two famous routes around the sites. A map in a free Siem Reap guide you can pick up hotels shows a red "short tour" circuit, and a green "grand tour". Drivers may be familiar with these. There are drinks vendors at each site, keep hydrated, I asked for blocks of ice to carry with me - which helped a lot.

Outstanding history lesson.. We visited all the temples in April for the second time. It continues to amaze us with the architecture and fine hand carvings within the temples.Remember to take your time exploring the grounds and if you can organise a guide to give you the low down and history go ahead and do so.It can be hot and very tiring so make sure to take bottled wart with you to rehydrate.If you are lucky enough to visit Siem Reap make sure you spend a good couple of days in the ruins!!

Breathtaking!. $20 for a day pass, $40 for a 3 day pass. This place is breathtaking. You can visit the temples by bicycle, car, Tuk Tuk or bus trip. Two of us rented bicycles whereas the other 3 hired a Tuk Tuk driver for the day. However, the tuk tuk drivers are a bit temperamental and wanted to know exact times. Bicycles is a great way to get around and less restrictive. We saw 13 temples in one day by bicycle and cycled 50km. We arrived at the park at 9.30 and stayed until 6pm to watch the sunset At pre rup. Pre rup is a beautiful temple but if you want to Get decent pictures, go about 3pm when it is quiet then return again at 5.30 for the sunset. the sunset there is beautiful but Very busy so any temple pictures are ruined by thousands of tourists. Also Ta Phrom is ridiculously busy with Korean and Chinese tourists that are obsessed with the fact that Angelina Jolie stood in a certain spot, so pictures there are ruined by hundreds of tourists also. We only had a day pass so we tried to cram in as much as possible. Obviously a 3 day pass would be better if you had enough time in your holiday.

Magnificent! This is a must-go.. We visited in April which was the hottest time of the year! It was indeed and my husband and I were drenched in our own perspiration. It was so hot and humid that we had to take several breaks in between the tour throughout the day. Nonetheless, the temples were amazing, beyond words can describe. Dress comfortably and light; a dry fit t-shirt and a pair of bermuda or cotton leggings is perfect. My husband and I engaged a guide and a driver, cost us USD65 but it was money well spent. I would recommend getting a guide as the place is huge and extremely rich in history. Moreover, the guide knows how to avoid the tour crowds and most importantly, as I was nursing an upset stomach, the guide is able to locate a toilet for me whenever I need to answer nature's call. We bought the 3 day pass which cost USD40 and it includes entrance to the remote temples like Banteay Srey and Kbal Spean which we visited the next day. As there are too many temples, I have listed down a few temples which I personally recommend - Angkor Wat, Bayon, Baphoun, Terrace of the Leper King, Terrance of the Elephants, Ta Prohm, Ta Keo, Banteay Kdei, Banteay Srey and Kbal Spean. If you have some extra time (day trip), please visit Preah Vihear temple! It is not within Angkor Archaeological Park and it is 3 hours drive away from Siem Reap town. This temple is my personal favourite. It is located on top of a mountain and the view from the cliff at the end of the temple is beautiful.

Must be on your bucket list!!. I guess all the words are necessary. It's enough to see the pictures and know that some list is as a wonder of the world. If you can travel to Asia, visiting Cambodia cos of Angkor is a MUST!

Great. We took a tuk tuk and driver for the day here. the first day we had a guide as well. the second day we did the flight of the gibbon and more temples.It costs $20.00 US for a one day pass and $40.00 US for a 2 or 3 day pass.if you have children (i had my 11 year old) take your childs passport with you as children under 12 are free but you must be able to prove their age.This area is massive and you cannot walk around it. Tuk tuk's however are cheap to hire for the day. it is also quite hot and a lot of walking so wear good shoes.If you also wish to do the flight of the gibbon (zipline) this is also in this park area and you need the passes to get into the park. We also did an elephant ride here.would highly recommend all of the above.
It is indeed good.. The place is nice , but needs some directions , boards and should be protected. It is vulnerable to local festivals and other small events, which should be avoided.

A must see if you are in Cambodia. The Angkor Archaeological Park is a "must see" if you are in Cambodia. The site is vast and there are many temples to visit. We were taken by a private guide but you can also go by tuk tuk. I would recommend you taking a tuk tuk or similar transport, don't be fooled into thinking that you can walk between temples.The cost of entry is 20 USD and the site is open from 5.30am to 5.30 pm. When you go to purchase your ticket they will take a photo of you to put on your ticked so the ticket is non transferable.If you have mobility issues there will be certain areas that you will not be able to see. However if your mobility is very restricted and you only stay in the tuk tuk and view the sites from the road, it is still worth going.All in all, it is excellent value and is definitely not to be missed.
A visit to Angkor Park. What an amazing experience specifically sunrise over Angkor wat. A must see - it is absolutely worth your while getting up early.

Huge architectural feat for its time. I only saw Angkor through pictures before. I was in awe when I finally saw it! Although they say it is best to visit the temples during dawn or dusk, the details and the history around it made it up to me. They were astounding! Too bad it was quite damaged by the Khmer Rouge; you can see evidence of gunshots around.

The reason for visiting Siem Reap!. This is why we went to Siem Reap. The Angkor temples are fabulous. There are many more than Angkor Wat, the most publicized site. The park is huge! If you are not with a tour, be sure to take a tuk-tuk or car. It was very hot when we were there, and we were thankful to have an air-conditioned car and driver.

Too hot but worth it. What an amazing site to see. Go there either early in the morning or after 4 pm on super hot days. Read about it before you go, there is so much history that your guide cannot cover in a few hours.

400 Square Kilometers of Beauty!. Its amazing to cross from side to side of the Park and see temples and buildings all over. Spectacular scenery and lovely graders. The conservation of the temples is great. Even the small ones that are not famous.

Once in a lifetime experience...... Words can not really describe how mind blowing the Angkor Archaeological park is. Do not hesitate to engage the services of a guide.....you will get soooo much more from the experience, money very well spent. Highly recommend to include some of the more remote, less visited temples during your visit as well. Awesome!

Fantastic Ruins. Wow! We've been looking forward to this trip for years and we weren't disappointed. The entire Angkor complex is simply fantastic. Well preserved ruins and you have access to wander though almost all of them. Plenty of opportunities to spend your money, so be careful. If you prefer to not carry your water there are vendors everywhere selling it. Be prepared for incredible heat and I recommend sturdy shoes, not flip flops. Traveling with our 2 children, 16 & 9, we opted for a taxi to drive us from location to location. That little respite from the heat was a life saver.

Magnificent . The temples may look the same, but it's really worth exploring each one. Lovely temples, and very interesting and beautiful carvings. Better bring something to cover up the skin as the sun can get scorching hot during the day time. Be careful with the children selling stuff as they can get really pushy. I ended up buying 2 sets of keychains for 20USD, which was 5USD a set in the market.

The history totally blows you away. This is the most amazing place and really worth going to. You need a few days there to really get the feel. Hire a Tukituki driver to take you around, usually your hotel will get one for you. Unfortunately one day we weren’t allowed to go to one temple because of a dress code so just make sure you don’t wear anything too short, a low top or a tank top. Go to Pub Street at night and put your feet in the Dr Fish tank, not sure if I liked it or not but I did it and it is part of the experience.

Stunningly beautiful... but crowded. Despite the hordes of tourists, the temples were simply amazing. The lack of quiet spirituality was balanced by the stunning construction and stone carvings. With my 3 day pass, I was able to escape the crowds after the first day when I joined the masses for the Angkor Wat sunrise and the small circuit tour by tuk tuk. I found late afternoon to be great as most folks are burnt out by then, figuratively and literally (it's hot!). One day, I toured by bike and really enjoyed the quiet stretches of the park and some very uncrowded temples. I also purposely did not try to see every site. I plan to return to see more.
Nice place. I think it is nice place to visit for one full day. I would be tired to stay there for two or three more.

Best tempel experience ever. Spending two days in environment of angkor wat. Unbelievable! Absolute one of the major must sees in south east asia. Spend 2 or 3 days there. I hink the best way to do that is renting a motorbike becak for one day (10-15 use) The main reason to choose for that is that in between the temples yopu get some fresh air while driving.

Huge park with tons to see. . My husband and I hired a tour guide for a day tour of the main temples. It is unbelievably hot during this time of year so we were lucky our guide had a car with air con. Bring tons of water or dollar bills for buying water from vendors. We paid $1 for 2 bottles. Some temples require you to cover your shoulders and knees if you want to go to the top. The stairs are extremely steep and quite scary but it was worth going up. Also you may want to pack an extra shirt or hand towel to wipe your sweat. We were literally drenched after standing outside for 10 minutes....It is that hot! We rented bikes the next day to see more of the temples on our own. We found a back entrance into Angkor Wat which only had few tourist so it was nice. Biking could be a bit scary since they don't really observe driving rules but the cars and busses and motor bikes just honk at you then go around you, sometimes a little too close for comfort.

Good and Bad. it only charges usd20 for entrance fee and is a nice place to look sun rise. Those ancient buildings are unique and amazing. But,some steps are difficult to climb and may cause accident. ( SO BE CAREFUL) Also, some parts of temple still under conserve/maintenance.... (Remind: FOR FEMALE VISITOR, there is a temple where female visitor with singlet or short pants are not allowed to enter )................AND i used to suffer heat stroke at there ==! CAREFUL..haha

Magical Experience. Super hot during this time of year, but what a magical place! I highly recommend arriving in time to watch the sun rise over the temples. I also recommend going with a guide on your first day, because they have so much wonderful information to provide. On day 2 or 2 and 3 go on your own and take your time exploring. There is so much to see, its simply amazing!

Great experience, even for one day. We did only one day, we saw Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm, Bayon and went for sunset to Pre Rup temple... we came around 10 in the morning and left after sunset, managed to have lunch in between, we took tuk tuk for whole day for 20 dollars.... Amazing experience.... we were tight on our schedule so we could not stay longer....

Majestic archeological heritage. This is an amazing structure of the bygone era. Angkor Wat gave us a glimpse of life during the 9th-13th century. How great to walk and tread each stair in this marvellous temple. The murals are inspiring that Khmers contributed to our world civilization. On the way to Angkor wat is lush lined trees which give relaxing feeling to visitors. Exploring the temple in early morning is a good idea to avoid the stunning heat in the midday sun. Kindly bring bottled water to keep you hydrated and it's good to explore and walk this way.

Loved all of the Temples and historical sites!. Everything is the same as we seen in the photos. I personally LOVE Bayon temple & Ta Prohm! These place is the must visit whenever you're here to visit for Historical Tourism. It is best to have an experienced tour guide to bring you around. and at the same time story to you the history and what happened with the craving of the stones.
honeymoon. fabulous experience,our tour guide took us here for sundown and sun rise,he knew when to miss the tourists it was a spectacular experience

Best. One of the best trips of my life has been to visit the Angkor Archeological Park. There are so many things to see and explore. If you are even a little bit interested in going, I recommend you go and go now! 3 days is enough time there to see a lot so I recommend the $40 ticket.

Amazing Place!. this is certainly one of the most beautiful places I've ever seen. History and magnificent architecture touches your heart! The place is huge and two days only (that's all we had) are not enough. Our most favorite were of course Angkor Wat, Baphuon (nice garden), beautiful Ta Prohm, and Preah Khan too (it's nice and quiet, most of it still unrestored). Sunset at Bahkeng was nice but the amount of people with cameras waiting for the good shot, steeping on each others head just shocked us, so be prepare for it. March was very dry and hot; therefore, it would be nice to see it in different season too. Overall, beautiful and must see place!

EXQUISITE. What can i say more, it is huge place to explore, great kingdoms from thousands years ago with amazing architecture and constructions! Spend your time here at least 3 days or more so that you have enough time to explore all of temples. Each of the temples has their own story and different architecture.

Should be in your bucket list. Had an enjoyable adventure here from 10am-5pm. One of the most physically-exhausting activity I've done this year, but I am so glad I did it. Certainly one of the places you needed to see before you die.I bought a one-day pass and managed to cover Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm, Banteay Srei. I hired an English-speaking Cambodian tour guide for USD15 at Angkor Wat and it was worth it. The guy was very well-versed with the history and friendly. He also insisted that we hired him at Angkor Wat so that when we traveled to other temples, we don't need any guidance since the story behind the wats are pretty much the same.Nevertheless, at one of the temples, we got conned by a fake tour guide who insisted on following us throughout our time at one of the temples (even though we did not ask for him), telling us bits of information and then asked us to tip him USD15 also. We only paid USD5. So be careful if you go to other temples, nothing comes free and stick to official tour guides. We also noticed another fake tour guide trying to approach us at Bayon and we quickly ran away.Do travel with tuk-tuks in this park, it's more enjoyable. Equip yourself with light clothing, comfortable shoes for climbing and walking, drinking water, hat, sunglasses and sunscreen.

breathtaking. an unbelievable experience. quite breath-taking. A hidden wonder of the world which provokes lots of searching questions. Who designed it who built it. Why is it so much like Peru and other similar constructions around the globe of that era,

Awesome place. Me and my partner spent 2 an a half days in the park an we spent 5 days in siem reap. Best experience of our asia travels so far...a must do for everyone! We traveled in early april and man it was hot...plenty o people selling bottles of water for $1 stay hydrated and take your time and you will have a blast!

Magnificent!. i never thought Angkor would be that BIG! One day is not enough to explore all temples and sites... huge temples, wide pavements made of huge sandstone blocks, gigantic trees, vast jungles, magnificent lake surrounding the iconic temple, peaceful monks, wild birds, monkeys, elephants and other animals, food, souvenirs, friendly locals and amazed tourists... all these and more are there.Going to Angkor was a dream come true... i've only seen it in movies and in books, but last summer i was able to see the place and enjoyed every single step on those ancient pavements of that gigantic wonder... Tuk tuk is the easiest means of transpo in there... be ready to wake up before sunrise and be there to watch it... you also need to have good sunglasses, sandals or comfortable shoes, sunblock, hat or cap, a map of the whole area would be very helpful if you want to wander and explore more than the usual tourists' route, and of course a good camera... short shorts are not allowed in some temples, so make sure that you're wearing something of kneel-length or longer..get yourself ready to experience the wonders of ancient khmer civilization as depicted in their fantastic architecture, arts and culture... all at Angkor.

Angkor - Southeast Asia's archaeological crown jewel. For anyone who wishes to call herself/himself a traveler, even a short visit to Angkor is a must. Although I have to say that there is more to the Park than the Big and Small circuits, as some of the best temples are outside the beaten path. Be prepared! Climbing the scary steep steps of Angkor is not for the faint of heart and legs. Temperatures can soar and before you know it, your shirt is soaked in sweat. The sun is fierce and unforgiving and will burn unprotected skin. But for those who are prepared the views from the top of these temple-mountains are stunning, the scale and layout of the temples astounding and overwhelming, the sculptures are so unbelievable that you will pick your jaw from the floor, and the Cambodian people, the proud inheritors of this gigantic heritage, a happy and beautiful people with ready smiles.History buffs would find the Angkor Archaeological Park a dream come true - temple after temple stretching deep into the dense woodland, each with a story, most surrounded by a moat or even a giant reservoir or, in Khmer, a baray, which makes them even more interesting. The temples are in varying states of decay - some are superbly preserved like Angkor Wat and Banteay Samre, while some are pretty ruined like the Baphuon. A seven-day pass for 60 USD will probably be your best option. Mix it with a tour of distant Angkorian sites like Prasat Preah Vihear and Koh Ker and your Angkor experience would be complete.A definite must see!

Awesome experience!. The entire park is an amazing trip into Cambodia's history and the time it was the dominant force in southeast asia. There is so much to see that you should allow three full days to do it justice.

Why else did you come to Siem Reap?. Why else did you come to Siem Reap if not to see the Angkor Archaelogical Park? Unless you have vast knowledge of this ancient Khmer civilization, I would definitely hire a driver to take you around. Mine had a guide book as well so I could read about the places he was taking me. One full day is sufficient to get the gist of it, but if you have more time and particular interest in archaeology, then you should definitely stay longer.
Worlds Best. You are reading about this for a reason, it is everything and more than you expect it to be! So fascinating is the history of this beautiful country with it's beautiful people! Enjoy!
Met my expectations and more. It was helpful to have a guide share the different time-lines for the temples and related buildings. Three days would have been better than two

Had a great time w/a great driver Sochet!. Visited in mid-march and it lived up to/exceeded all expectations. My wife and I got the three day pass and covered the small and grand circuits, plus kbal spean and banteay srei. We also went to the land mine museum, Phnom Kulen and Beng Mealea (all great experiences as well, though Kulen is admittedly pricey for what you get to see - 20 bucks a person; though the cooling swimming hole/waterfall was a welcome respite). Was just great fun and a great history/art lesson at every turn. Highly recommend biking at least a portion of the small circuit, if not all of it. Biking the wall of Angkor Thom was a real highlight, as we were alone (minus the monkeys!) the entire time. Angkor Wat at dawn was another great sight, as were the other usual suspects: the Bayon, Ta Prohm, Preah Khan, Bakheng, Baphuon (this one more for the view at the top). Though there were a lot of people as always, we did find plenty of quiet spots given the size of the place. We even had a whole small temple (Ta Nei) to ourselves at one point. It was down a dirt road quite a bit, but was very cool to find this secluded spot at the end of it. So glad we were able to visit this great complex. And, as mentioned in the subject, our driver was one of the reasons why our visit was so enjoyable. Sochet was prompt, knowledgeable, spoke english very well (and he's self-taught!) and made us feel so welcome in his country, showing us around the countryside as we went. I'd recommend anyone looking to book someone trustworthy and affordable in advance to visit his website: http://www.driveangkor.com/home.html. Thanks again Sochet!

Fabulous. Almost unbelievable place. The first view of it through the forest is magical. Such a shame that the passing of time has not been kind to the buildings. The thought of this place being hand-built all that time ago is amazing. One of THE places to visit in the world

Wow! three day ticket is a must. I have been waiting for such a long time to visit the Angkor temples I really enjoy and loved it all. Just for your knowledge, you can only purchase a one single entrance or three days ticket you can use within 10 days (please confirm it) from the first visit even in non consecutive days. If you buy the entrance ticket after 5pm, you get a sunset visit for the same day for free. I did the Angkor Wat complex and Angkor Thom complex in a full day, minor outside temples in one more day with the amazing sunrise in Angkor wat in a second visit plus Prasat Banteay Srei (my very best one), and river carvings (a very nice trekking in the forest to reach it) plus other marginal beautiful ones on the third visit. The best way to visit Angkor temples in my experience is with a tuc tuc that will be at your disposal for full day and especially to move around in the huge and very hot area.

Surely on everyone's bucket list. We only spent a day at the temples and this was enough for us. It was a long day as we arrived before sunrise and it became very hot work walking around all the temples on the short circuit. It is definitely worth getting up early to see the sunrise at Angkor Wat. We did the circuit in reverse to avoid the crowds, starting at Angkor the on to the tomb raider next which we think worked well. Also, if you can stand the heat of the midday sun this is the quietest times around the ruins when most day trippers stop for lunch to get out of the heat.

Beautiful, once you get past the crowds & humidity. First of all the cost of the park is 20 US dollars each so not sure why it says free. But the money is worth it :) Our first mistake was trying to walk to the park- we got there, but you need to buy tickets in a specific area so once at the check point (and after much laughter from the friendly gaurds at our attempts to walk the park) we got a tuk tuk, which took us around the day for 15 US dollars. The first stop will be the Angkor Wat. I was honestly dissapointed. In reality there is a lot of glare and dust in Cambodia. There were hundreds of other tourists. If you aren't massive on history then give going inside a miss. There was nothing to see but stone and sweating hoards of people. Our first enjoyable move was to grab an Angkor beer each and continue on with our tuk tuk. The other temples were much less crowded and enjoyable. We got to the park around 10am so perhaps try and get there on opening time if you enjoy photography and want to beat the crowds (if that's even possible). I loved Ta Prohm. The tree roots are spectacular. All in all once you get past the discomfort of the bustle and heat, the park will leave you with some incredible photos of the temples.
So Big. You would need a month or more to see all there is to see here. What an amazing experience for our family.

Way more than Angkor Wat!. Get the three day pass and come several times, seeing multiple temples at various times of day. Angkor Wat is best at sunrise, but everyone else is there, too. Don't miss the other Wats, like Angkor Tom. They are all so different. This is one case where I would try to hire a guide. The guides are required to dress in a uniform, so you will know if they are a licensed guide (probably you will need to book in advance). Be forewarned: there is extreme poverty here so the hawkers are quite forceful. I've been to a lot of tourist places and I was still caught off guard the first day. The way nature interacts with the ruins is quite unlike anything I've ever seen, and the variety is quite impressive. This site likely will not be as accessible in 10 years time - or maybe not as preserved. See it while you can!
It's one of a kind!. Magical, breathtaking!I would advise getting there early in the morning or late in the afternoon, if possible with a tourguide, to avoid the crowds.

Do Yourself a Favor and Hire a Guide. The park is huge, and a good guide can not only tell you what you are seeing, but also help you minimize entanglement with the hoards of tourists in buses. It is possible to have a reasonably quiet, personal experience in the park. If I were to do it over again, I would buy a multi-day pass and visit the park between 5:30 a.m. and 10:30 a.m., to avoid the worst of the heat and crowds.

An amazing work of art, architecture and history. Best advice, go at 5:30 am, no crowds, it's cool and the light is beautiful for photography. Also if you can before you go see the National Geo. documentary on Angkor Wat it is very informative

Expansive temple complex - give yourself time. You'll need time to enjoy Angkor Wat in an unhurried way. The most popular site in Siem Reap, there will always be a lot of fellow travellers here - even to catch a glimpse of the rising sun over the temple. Parts are very steep and this may present issues for people with access difficulties, but for most who are agile and reasonably fit there should be few if any problems. Take your time to enjoy this - there is history everywhere and some of the friezes seem as though they could easily spring to life.

Must see!. The scale of the overall site is amazing, and it is surprising how difdferent in construction and character many of the temples are. A day visit ($20 per person) probably won't be enough, 2-3 days ($40 per person) should be sufficient. It is well worth hiring a private driver/guide on the internet or from your hotel so that you can visit the main temples at quieter times, and visit the less popular temples at the busier times. We were able to avoid the worst of the crowds throughout our visit.

tickets and tour. The daily ticket is $20 USD, or you can get a 3-day for $40 USD. The "large loop has the smaller" more significant temples, I'm told, but does NOT include Angkor Wat itself. I was able to coax my driver to start there, then do the rest of the large loop.

Plan for three days. Depending on how keen you are on temples, plan for a good three days to be able to get around and see the great variety of monuments.I would recommend, however, that you cherry pick the temples you would like to see based on the following factors:a) How popular each temple might be (and associated crowds slowing your ability to move around).b) How interested you might be in the actual features of the temple. i.e. Do you like to look at all the carvings/etchings and fossick in dark corners, or are you a quick glance/main temple only visitor?c) Are you on a prescribed route (covering 12 temples a day) or are you able to find the temples that may not be popular but are still stunning and interesting?My only other comment is that the hawkers can be quite aggressive and you should prepare for that. I understand that they are trying to make a living in a competitive environment but I did feel stressed at being harassed every time I arrived or left a temple location. Be prepared to be calm, firm, and polite to deal with this.Even with my enthusiasm and interest, I was feeling very "templed-out" after three days (and my feet hurt)... but good luck and enjoy!

Photos don't do this place justice. Spend days not hours exploring the temples. We paid our Tuk Tuk driver Mr Leang US$15 per day to wait to take us to each temple, and supply copious bottles of water ... it was hot!

Something everybody should see. I knew that Angkor was a place I had to see in my life. I made it my goal to see it for my 49th birthday trip...and I can't believe I waited this long. This is a MUST SEE part of the world!

Must see !. You can not come to Siem Reap & not visit the temples. The 3 main temples are spectacular. Allow at least a half a day, take plenty of water. It is very hot walking around the temples. If you do it yourself without a guide expect to pay $15 for a tuk tuk driver to take you around & he will wait for you at each temple. If he is good - give him $20. It also costs $20 for a 1 day pass (each person) to enter the park.Definitely a must see !!

What a place. But there is masses of it and you could so easily be temples out. The crowds are a big issue . We did not have a guide, but a Tuk Tuk with an English speaking driver who dropped us at entrances ... Great as we were not being hoarded along! You can always hear guides giving explanations if you want t ... In fact you cannot avoid it!Enjoy the ambience.One day was plenty for us ... Tho we did do Angkor Wat the evening before

Angkor Wat - off the bucket list. I was surprised to see that this attraction had several recovered temples and buildings, not just Anchor Wat. The facility is amazingly busy so be prepared for crowds.We hired a car and English speaking guide from our hotel. The car was fully air conditioned and after each stop the driver supplied us with chilled towels and cold drinking water for which we were extremely greatful as March is hot in Cambodia.The guide provided us with the necessary history and information on each temple, statues and wall carvings. With out this we would have enjoyed our visit but come away knowing little about the Kmer and the Wats and the religious history of the merging of Hindu and Buddism.The guide also knew the short cuts to keep us away from the tour groups as much as possible.In all it was a great experience

Really amazing!. Seeing Angkor Wat was the primary reason for our trip to SE Asia, and it did not disappoint! It is fabulous and lives up to its hype. We had an excellent guide who explained all of the carvings and images. I think it's imperative to know what you are looking at or it could just seem like the same old same old. He took us from the back of the complex to the front so we avoided much of the crowd.

You can't loose it!. This is a magnificent site that is still in its full natural state, without much intervention. Make sure you have a good guide to avoid our bad experience with a tuk tuk driver that could speak only its native language. The only reason we faced this situation was a poor travel package made by Tong Chai Tour 2 from Bangkok - by the way, stay away of this travel agency!

Not of this earth. I've only Mayan temples and ruins of Europe to compare to, but this site felt as if it were from another species at times - it is remarkable and humbling and majestic and amazing. I had 2 days and wish I'd had 10.
Fascinating. Angkorwat is not to be missed.This is a masterpiece of architecture. Don't miss visiting and spend time. A lot of walking and climbing steps but it is worth.

Wow. Overwhelming in size and awe. Do your reading beforehand not while there.
There are lots of tour groups and they are loud, but it's hard to avoid them because they were everywhere.
Next time, I will use a proper guide and avoid the large tour groups.
Incredible.... Lots of walking, lots of steps, make sure you have great walking shoes! Not handicap friendly.Our ticket was called an Angkor World Herritage Pass, included most of the area.

Expensive admission. $20.USD for a day pass is expensive for Cambodia... but glad we got to experience the park. Walked (approx. 8km without diversions around each temple) from Ta Prohm to Angkor Thom and then to Angkor Wat sightseeing other temples along the way so experienced a good portion of the park!

Buy at least 3 days pass. The place is huge! To cover most important buildings you need at least 3 days pass. If you really really in tight schedule and purchase 1 day pass, I would recommend must visit Angkor Wat, Bayon Temple,Terrace of the Leper King and Ta Prohm. The remaining time you can choose randomly.

Very Worthy Visit!. It will be better to have a tour guide to brief you on the history of the temples. Otherwise, google can help. We researched some brief history of the different temple before we went Siem Reap for Angkor Wat and other temples around it. A great place for photos. If you are not a person who is interested in history/temples, 1 day may be just enough for you. If you would like to know more about the place and history, get the 2 to 3 days pass because the place is huge. =) weather is surprising cold in the day in January this year. Tuk Tuk is a great way to get around (and cheaper too), if you are not afraid of dust. Very great experience in tuk tuk, LOVE IT!
Amazing man made. The temples were so great and strong even they were almost 1000 years old. The park is so big that you will not be able to visit all in one day.

Very Impressive. I had 3 days to explore the Park, but could have easily spent a week there. that would have made it more possible to avoid the heat of the day, and to get to different places for sunrise/sunset.Still, 3 days was a good compromise.

Well worth the long journey. Loved the sunrise trek to Angkor Wat, and viewing the ruins. Liked the bands that played at the sites. English-speaking travel guide was not all that we were led to believe. Made up facts and sometimes unable to answer our inquiries. Did not like the begging children.
Its big. I think you cannot finish touring it the whole day for its size. you should alot like 2 or 3 days for you to go all the places in this place.

Incredible!!. Going with a guide by Tuk-tuk early in the morning to the temples we got overwelmed by the grandeur and expanse of the complex! Incredible that people were able to build this for 900 years ago! An absolute 'have to visit' being in Cambodia!!

Majestic,but..... Where do you start,I may well review individual temples later,but this one is solely based on what I visited in the whole day.I will admit I am not a mad temple buff,but to see this place is amazing,maybe the only time I will,we just took a one day tour,starting early to see the sunrise,although I not quite sure what all the fuss was about.We did not hire a guide,nor go with a tour group,we just wanted to amble around doing our own thing,& for us,it worked fine,we did hire a tuk tuk,which really is a must,the site is so big.The temples are an amazing sight,at anytime of the day,the sheer scale of them & what it took to construct them takes some believing,Angkor Wat was my personal favourite out of the sites we visited.(we did all the major sites,& our driver took us to a few away from the crowds)Bayon is also very impressive,although as stated above,take some time & go see the smaller temples,maybe not as grand,but when you are on your own there,you can sit back & appreciate them a little bit more.The downsides,unfortunately,we can be our own worst enemy,& make these places what they have become,tourist traps,I am not sure if when we visited was 'peak' time,but there were thousands of people there,even at 6am,& at 9am,the countless tour groups arrived,which can be noisy,rude,& seem to think they are the only people there.(note,we observed many individual tour guides,with only 2 or 3 people with them,these were the exception,calm,quiet,knowledgeable)Before anyone shouts at me for saying this,I am aware the monthly wage in Cambodia is low,& they work hard for what they get,but the constant demands for money,buy this,buy that,drinks,food,clothes,books,wears abit thin after awhile,& the scams that go on,detract from your day,we were offered guide books at the entrance for $20,then $15,by the time you get further inside,they were $1!!,one tip,however annoyed you may get at this,please don't,just smile,say no thankyou,keep walking,unless you really want something,although after 10 hours of this,its hard!!Tip 2,Observe the 10minute rule,if there is something you wish to see,& take pictures of,but its very busy,wait around away from the herd,large tour groups can have a short attention span,wait & they move on,leaving you with less people around.The temples deserve 5/5,but some of the goings on away from them means 4/5,just try not to let them irritate you,it is a place to see when in Cambodia.
Spectacular. Definitely one of the highlights of our tour.Our local guide very good and brought the place to live.It does involve a considerable amount of walking in searing heat but not to missed.
Angkor with Victory Lucky Day Tours. We visited Angkor three days with mr Bunlem Nhem Victory Lucky Day tours. He is an excellent guide we recommend him very much.Bram Elffers en Tonny Nelissen
