an unmissable site. over run with tourists yes.but this is Angkor one of the wonders of the modern world.Amazing temples, some still covered in jungle others set in almost garden like surroundings.with so much to see some of the remote temples are rather empty of tourists which is a big plus, while angkor way is just crazy... we tourists must be damaging the temples just by our numbers and erosion.

simply amazing. An ancient beautiful city with gorgeous buildings.It is a special place with history, art, nature, architecture, engeneering..3 day time seemed not enough to apreciate all that. no photo or post card can be compare with the personal experience of witnessing all live!

Absolutely amazing, mindblowing. We hired bicycles from the main town and cycled to the park. This took around 30 minutes. I'd advise checking and double checking a map. We followed a road and should have taken a right turning, theres a huge white board that has no English. Take this and it leads to the ticket office where you buy entry passes. We cycled round to another entrance and had to go 6k back on ourselves to find the ticket office. We should have took the turning with the white board.Once getting our passes and getting into the park, the sights and ruins were mind blowing. It has to be seen to be believed. We cycled around the park for about 5 hours using a map and following signs around the bike. It is very easy to do and the park is flat. It was a great way to see everything we wanted to see at our own pace and get a great feel for how big the park is!An amazing day! I would highly recommend this!!

Amazing, Absolutely Amazing. Most visitors in Siem Reap are here to see the gorgeous temples in Angkor Park. You can buy a one day ticket which can actually be purchased at sunset one night to view the sunset then includes the whole next day. There are also 3 day, 7 day, and more passes. As people who were excited to see the temples, are very interested in history, and love exploring, we found the 3 day pass to be enough for us. There are people who will tell you a week isnt even enough but those are extreme temple enthusiasts as many people find that the temples can all start to look alike after a day or two (or even a few hours for some) if you are not extremely into their history and meaning. I recommend taking advantage of sunrises and sunsets as often as possible as they are the most beautiful, cool, and least crowded. There is a sense of calm and solitude at the temples during these times and the large tour buses are not present.The pass you buy will have your picture on it and they are checked regularly at the temples so do not buy tickets from anyone on the streets - they are frauds.There are an absolute ton of drivers to choose from; their prices are all pretty comparable; and they do basically the same routes around the temples. You can find a driver through your hotel, in town or at the temples and agree on a price and route for the day. Some people find a driver online and book in advance but most wait until they arrive. I was unsure which to do but we waited and had no issues. Guides and drivers are separate individuals and costs for guides/tours vary quite a bit based on group size, company, and transport used (tuktuk, aircon car). I found many people who loved their guides but others who would rather have roamed the temples on their own. We decided to use a guidebook and driver and found this worked well for us. Prior to our visit we ordered Ancient Angkor (Freeman & Jacques) and found it to be insightful and useful. We read some in advance but having our own driver also allowed us the flexibility to find some shade at each stop and read about the temple while we were there. My husband also downloaded some podcasts/ebooks that he listened to while at the temples. He also found that downloading and doing some guided meditation at the temples during sunrise/sunset was very soothing - we really enjoyed it during the calm times we found at the temples.
Not to be missed. These ancient temples are amazing and not to be missed. Try to arrives early in the day so that you can get an elephant ride around the temple.
Even if you're templed out, visit this one. Really cool temple ruins that you can climb on and through. If I recall correctly, you have to buy a separate $5 admission ticket.

Amazing! I want to go again.. Unfortunately my friend let me down last minute so I ended up going on my own. This was simply an amazing experience from start to finish. Both days felt magical. I just wished I had someone to share it with. On the second day, I went to Angkor Wat for sunrise, which was amazing - really recommend. I then went round some temples straight afterwards. As it was so early - about 6am, there were no tourists about and I was a little scared at times walking round the temples, but there was nothing to worry about.I also had a giant, Indiana Jones-stylee stick insect fall out of the trees and land on me. I screamed so much and a local lad had to get it off me. :-)The big three were my favourites - Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm. I went to all the temples in the circuit but because I was on my own, I did find myself getting bored on the second day and just wanted to get back to where there was people. I would go back tomorrow if I could.
It is a must, impressive and beautiful. If you try to imagine the work and difficulties to get it build it is even more amazing. Lots of details and stories in them. Beautiful

Lots of temples. A lot of different and same same but definitly well worth seing.We took a weeks ticket at 60 USD - was pricey but had the advantage of being valid for a month so you can travel the country and come back to see more instead of being all templed out in one go.should think a normal 3 day ticket would do really and it's valid for the whole week

Spectacular. This is an historic site that overwhelms you with it's magnitude and beauty. The stone structures and carvings are breathtaking and you feel the need to take a picture with every few steps you take. Bring extra digital storage cards for your camera.
Angkor Wat and surrounds. Impressive scale and iconic buildings which have become the national symbol of Cambodia. a MUST SEE - but hav a good guide to explain the carvings

Incredible. Everyone has used most words to describe this place...What do I say differently? Not a great deal...I'll say one thing, it was supposed to one of those places that you think is incredible (which I obviously did) but I'm no good with things people have already told me I'll like, I get grouchy and try not to like it just so I have my own opinion. 8-9am there we are rocking (pun intended) up to the site with me intent on not enjoying it, I couldn't.Angkor Wat is so vast, intriguing and in it's setting one of the most beautiful places I have ever been to so, enjoy it, I challenge you not to.Advice- go early, in doing that we were leaving as the bigger tours arrived.

Awesome place, best seen with a guide.. Angkor park is huge, I would advise that for your first visit, at least, to use a guide (a guide should cost no more than $35 for a full day.)Then when you have a good background on the area and have seen the best temples you can visit on your own, just try not to get lost.Tickets to the park are bought in 1 or 3 day packages, the days do not have to be used consecutively so put the dates on as your first day at the park and the end date as the date you will leave Siem Reap.Enjoy

Grandiose experience, worth its value and more. The first tip i would give for anyone who wish to visit the temples is to wake up early everyday... even if you do not go for a sunrise as it gets really crowded and hot during the day.We had a strategy for the visit that we believe made us maximize the experience for the 3 day access. First, get a TukTuk driver that is willing to be flexible and allow you to adapt the order of temples you wsh to visit. We always woke up early, but we actually never went for the famous sunrise at Angor Wat temple. Instead, we beat the crowd and while everyone who woke early went for that temple, we went for Ta Prohm and Bayon in the first two days... And we were practically alone in these temples... This magnify the experience by a factor.Why we did not go for Angor Wat sunrise, we thought it is very touristy, hard to get a spot for a good view. The fact that everyone goes for that temple actually went to our advantage.Our itinary:1st day: departure at 5h00 Sras Srang, Banteay Kdei, Ta Prohm, Ta Keo and East Mebon Return to hotel at 11h2nd day: departure at 5h30 Anghor Thom (all the complex, starting by Bayon) Anghor Wat Return to hotel at 13h3rd day: Departure at 6h30 Preah Khan, Neak Poan, Ta Som, Banteay Samre Return to hotel at 11h30We generally paid our tuk tuk driver 20$ for each day, except the last where we paid 25$ since we had a temple more distant (plus a dollar in tip each day).Note. We enjoyed a bit less Anghor Wat in comparison to other temples. We felt that Anghor Wat felt more like a palace or a cathedral rather than archeological ruin. It is a matter of taste, i liked it more when the temples are lost in the jungle. There is however a good National Geographic documentary that can be found on you-tube that provide a lot of neat history on that temple. It is nice to see it before the visit,Overall, This site is a must see in Cambodia.

Be sure to get a guide!. We came to Angkor Wat at 8am in the morning, and absolutely thought it was amazing. I would highly recommend going with a guide, because it's amazing how practically everything has been built purposely (Eg. How long walkways are, and how many corners there are). The most surprising fact our guide told us was that it took 30+ years to build and over 300,000+ people to construct.

We didn't see Angeline :(. do not miss this trip , I will remember it forever , it should be the 8th wonder of the world . Take your camera and a bottle of water and get a good guide ..... travel by Tuk Tuk from Siem Reap but you will need the mask .

Amazing. The temples at Angkor Wat are spectacular. I would definitely recommend getting a guide it makes the temples more interesting. I loved hearing about the way they were built and the different rulers responsible for their construction. Angkor Wat, Bayon, and Ta Phorm are the major temples and they are impressive. Some of the lesser known temples are still worth a visit.

I know, I know...... I know, I know.... this is going against all the other reviews probably in the rest of the world ever, but I'm being honest. I do like history, I've been interested in archaeology for decades and have visited sites around the world, but I found Angkor only moderately interesting. I'm not at all spiritual so perhaps that's to do with it as many comments seem to imply spirituality or something like that, which I don't believe in. I did find the tourist park set-out less than fascinating, but realistically it's undoubtedly hideously expensive to maintain the ruins and millions want to see it all, so that's simply the way it is. I had no desire to see the sun come up there and still don't. I'm not saying it's not interesting, and impressive, Bayon Temple especially, but it's a theme park now; just a real one rather than an invention. I imagine those who want to spend a week there live on a different planet than I do; which is fine, I also imagine we don't want to visit each other much. Much more enjoyed riding a horse out the next day across the fields at dawn to a distant temple. Not over interested in that temple either, but the horse riding was brilliant.

Historic beauty. Brilliant, full of history and wonders. Recommend the sunrise tour, can get a tuk tuk from your hotel for about $20USD and the driver will take you on the mini tour which coves most of the sites inside. Set aside 5am-3pm or so, can stay longer too (1, 2 day or 1 week passes available). Take a hat, sunscreen, water though only the toilets near Ta Prohm are OK.

How to avoid the big bus tours. The temples of Angkor are definitely a once in a lifetime experience. I felt this way 20 years ago on my first visit and it is still true today. That said, today (20 years later), the chaos, loud talking from the various tour groups competing to be heard, and the sheer number of tourists can detract significantly from the experience. Every neighboring Asian country must have been represented in these big bus tour groups. Many of these tour groups tend to be loud, disrespectful, and create a circus-like atmosphere. Although it is impossible to totally avoid the crowds and big bus tours, here are some tips that will help:1) Hire a good local tour guide and driver. They will know what times to visit and what areas of the temples to take you so that you will have some peace and quiet to enjoy the temples. Make sure you tell the guide that you would like to avoid the worst of the big bus tours. They will know what you mean as these tours have taken over the temples.2) Avoid visiting at peak tour hours. Some notorious times to avoid are: Angkor Wat at sunrise, Phnon Bakheng at sunset, Bayon immediately after sunrise, and Ta Prohm during mid to late morning.3) Get a three day pass so that you can pick a few temples each day, visiting at off-peak hours. We visited Bayon at sunset and did not see one big bus tour group. We visited Ta Phrom at 7am and managed to get an hour of peace before the tour groups arrived.4) Get your pass the evening before your visit at 5pm. In the morning, the ticketing area is, literally, a zoo of big bus tour groups.5) Visit some of the less popular temples. The big bus tours often do the same circuit of Angkor Wat at sunrise, Bayon, Ta Prohm, Preah Khan, Banteay Srey, and Phnom Bakheng or Angkor Wat at sunset.6) Many temples have multiple entrances. Have your tour guide take you to the entrance with the fewest tour buses.7) When you see a tour group coming, head in the opposite direction. Getting caught in the middle of a group makes it impossible to enjoy the temples.8) Instead of waiting in a long line to climb the steps of Angkor Wat, try climbing Pre Rep instead. We passed by this temple on three different occasions and it was never overwhelmed with tourists.We give a solid 5 stars for the temples because they are truly magnificent and worth the trip. The masses of big bus tour groups cannot be avoided and they do detract from the experience. However, you can still take some measures to circumvent the worst of it and be able to appreciate the experience of being at the temples.

Plan a visit over several days. This vast forested and wooded area contains many temples and numerous other unique structures. If you want to visit at a relaxed pace and see as much of the antiquities as you can, plan for a stay of at least a few days.

Amazing. This was one of the best places ive ever been to for shear scale and adventure. I loved walking around taking it all in. Got some superb photos and saw a nice sunset. I did 14 of the temples in one day (apparently the best ones) As great as it was one long day was more than enough or possibly two shorter days if that what you would prefer. Try and go/get there in the quiter seasons or times of the day. So many people was the only slight downside

Wat an amazing experience.. It may be full of tourist and you may need to find a different path to avoid everyone. But you are in a very spiritual place, so why not shut off and marvel on the amazingness of this wonderful park.

This, like the pyramids of Egypt, or the Taj Mahal, is incredible!. This is a great archaeological site. The structures, relief carvings, the grounds.... and the history are what make this place a must see if you can get there. Also, explore some of the overgrown ruins that have not been restored. Amazing!

Why else go to Siem Reap?. A unique experience. I've seen the archeology in Israel an this was so different. Suggest using a guide for the first day then explore on your own with a relaxing tuk-tuk for subsequent days. All of the temples are so different.

You must visit once in your life!. Angkor Archaeological Park is one of those places you must visit at least once in your lifetime. It is so much more than Angkor Wat, and is worth the time and effort to explore! Temples like Ta Prohm, the Bayon and Preah Khan are must visits, but also take some time to relax in the parks beautiful jungle environment,watch kids swimming and fishing in the moats; and try and avoid buying souvenirs from the multitude of 10yo business people. It's all part of the experience.I always visit using a tuk tuk, it's just the perfect way to get around the park. You'll find a million tuk tuk's vying for your business at the airport, bus station, and hotels. I've used the same driver for my 3 visits, and wouldn't hesitate to recommend him. Navuth, at ou_navuth@yahoo.com

Highlight of Cambodia. What an amazing area, so many temples set so close together and such differences between them. Hire a tuk tuk driver to take you around as easier access than a car plus nice to get a breeze and a more interesting experience.

Words almost fail me. Our visits here were the highlight of our fantastic trip of over 3 weeks to Vietnam and Cambodia. So much amazing history to learn and see for ourselves - it certainly helped to have our very well-informed English speaking guide with us throughout to answer our questions.It was such a huge contrast to the rest of our trip, which focused naturally more on the horrific events of the last 50+ years.
Big , Detail. I just learnt that the Khmer had such a huge power in the past from this thing. Don't miss it. Oh see the sun rise is a must.

Experiencing history that's 2,000 years old. The Angkor Archaeological Park is worth the trip. We've been planning to see the complex for years and we're very happy that we finally did. We didn't hire a tour guide because we like to discover things as we go, but should you wish to do the same, it's best to read a bit about the temples, or visit the National museum first.There's plenty of reasons to visit: look at ancient architecture, wait for the sunrise, wait for the sunset, learn of different cultures, or visit the place where Tomb Riader was filmed. Whatever tickles your fancy, this is such a wonderful place.This was a new experience indeed for one to be able to walk through halls, that were built by ancient civilizations. To be able to walk along the halls that's nearly 2 millenias old is truly fascinating, The craftsmanship is also crazy! Just imagining how people were able to build such places is difficult. So much has been said about Angkor, yet no matter how good the pictures are, how well the words have been written, nothing beats being there share the experience with so many people.Do bring the following:1. Water - it gets quite hot during the day. And when you're inside Angkor Wat or Angkor Thom, the stores where you can buy can be quite far.2. Comfortable shoes3. Light clothing - do wear t-shirts, and avoid anything without sleeves. Also wear shorts that go beyond the knee pr buy those pants in the markets. Temples are sacred places so dress modestly.4. SunglassesLots of temples have steep stairs, so prepare your legs.I did find a lot of tourists talking really loud. As much as these are "attractions" they are still places of worship.

Well worth the hype and the visit . This entire place is amazing and well worth the trip. Be sure to get a toot toot and pay the extra money for a guide. Be careful climbing the pyramids they are steeper than the look.
Worth the visit. its worth the visit! If you get the chance you should GO!!! The locals are very friendly and the sights are amazing!
breathtaking. Absolutley stunning. there isnt much that can be said that hasnt already been said. if you are in this part of the world, take the time to grab a guide and go visit the park.

Worth the Hype. I only had 2 days in Siem Reap, and wasn't sure I could take 2 full days of temple walking, so just did one full day tour through my guesthouse. This was more than enough for me - and the day was well worth it. Each and every one of the temples is unique and with its own quirks (although go to enough of them and they'll start to blur in your mind), and you could spend hours at each one just going over over nook and cranny. Our highlight was going off the busier paths and coming across some smaller temples our driver hadn't told us about.Sadly it can be busy - head into the temples rather than watch Angkor Wat's sunrise if you want isolation, or be prepared for tourists in your photos because its a very popular place to visit. Also, don't wear any kind of sandal - the red ants in this area are vicious.

Great pics. Some of my favorite pictures are from this site. I was fortunate to be able to enjoy this temple late in the afternoon and there was hardly any people around... I had time to take great pictures and enjoy the solitude, the sounds of nature and the sights... another MUST for those visiting the temples.

Exceeded expectation!. No matter what you saw on tv, the Angkor sites are going to blow your mind! Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, Bantay Srei and even the little ones were all impressive in their own way. Try to keep Angkor Wat and the Bayon for last so you can appreciate the smaller ones first. Try to divide your visits to several days so to not overdose on temples. We had a private tuk tuk driver (Mr. Orn +855 17841617) who lived in Siem Reap all his life so he knew the best time to see each of these sights. He doesn't have an email so ask your hotel to book him for you. He's reasonably priced and very punctual.
Worth a vist. Each temple was different and we saw wild monkeys on the way, we brought bananas for them and they were all over my husband eating them.

Young and old will love it. . As a family with two small kids it was great for us adults to see a bit of history and the kids had the chance to run around thru the jungle. With small kids we think to take it easy and don't try and pack the whole site in by trying to see as much as possible. We always visited in the mornings and left the afternoons back at the hotel by the pool. This way the kids didn't get so tempted out and looked forward for the next day. Might not be something for everyone, but it worked great for us.

This is why you are here right?. I think it was in Ho Chi Minh I ran into a guy that had already been to the Angkor complex, where I was still to go, who said that inevitable you will feel a little bit like Indiana Jones. I would say he was right. Later in the same city I ran into a guy giving me a schedule of exact times to be at exact locations, I didn't write anything down and did go about it my own way.Many say you should see the sun rise, myself I didn't, did not simply see the meaning of it. There is always a certain length you will go to get the perfect photos for your album and I concluded that to be to far.Depending on how big your company is there is a few ways of doing this. That guy with the schedule said to go by bike and that was what I decided for, many seems to do. A little pointer though where my MTB was excellent for 90% of the visit, it was also horrible for the rainy last 10% if you get what I mean. But bigger groups may choose tuctuc instead, I guess there is a breaking point where that will be cheaper than bikes. The bike though is a peaceful way of just biking around the temple ruins.While the Angkor Wat is the best kept and most known, I actually thought many of the others gave me more, but that's maybe just me.The only downside of the visit was two things, at Angkor Thom this ticket controller tried to hook me up with a tour to some other temple the next day, I got a fishy feeling about this guy especially as he asked where I'd parked my bike. The second thing was in one of the last temples I ran into this duo of tourist policemen that threw a guide tour on me in the temple, as i was western and their uniform said police I was taking a little by surprise as he wanted a "donation" upon finish. He sad I didn't need to pay, which I didn't. It left me though with a creepy feeling and ruined my exploration of this specific ruin.

Allow yourself to spend more time. It was fantastic to be in the Park and it would be best if you had more time to walk around the ruins and admire the different views in detail and from different angles

Visit them all!. Go early. Hire your own private guide and set off at the crack of dawn to appreciate the magic. Private guides can probably be organised at your hotel, or do it before you go if you are part of a tour as the magic is definitely lost if you are one of many and have to wait for people in the loo!!

Incredible heritage site. This met and exceeded my expectations. The temples and scenery are beautiful. Hung out with monkeys, rode an elephant. The temples have a great feeling to them while walking around.

Deserves to be one of the seven wonders of this world. The architecture, the carvings and the history of this great complex is awesome. The more you saw the greater is the craving to learn about the history and culture of the Khmer empire.I am glad to see that the local authorities are maintaining the park clean and regulating the tourists to preserve this for a long time to come.
Lives Up to the Hype.. This place was truly amazing. There is a reason there are so many superlatives floating around to describe it.

"No one, no one should die without seeing Angkor". The quote is from Somerset Maugham, and I have to agree. Our two daughters went to see the temples about 10 years ago, and they put this visit on our 'bucket list'. And we made it. This is an amazing place, unforgettable and up there with the top wonders of the world. Angkor Wat alone is just stunning, particularly knowing the age of the place and the fact that it was all built using plain manpower, including vast water courses and lakes. Then there is Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm plus several easily accessible smaller temples. We had a guide and an aircon car for two 5-hour morning stints, starting fairly early in the morning to beat the crowds, and this proved a great option, better than one long day. You could rapidly get exhausted with the walking if you don't have motorised transport between the sites. For those younger and fitter than us, bicycles might be an option. We were impressed that the site is now well controlled and policed such that the risk of damage from tourists is minimised to some extent.

One of the wonders of the World!. Having spent four days here you actually need many more days to see this place! Seeing the Angkor Archaeological Park was one of the highlights of my life. After seeing Chichen Itza in Mexico I though there was nothing better but this is it, a real cracker from the past. We hope that the various charity organisations keep maintaining this place for the future generations. It was a pleasure being here!!

Fantastic,but over run with tourists now. Very good, but didn't like the huge tour groups...really took away the good feeling of the place. The short cURCUIT TOUR IS all most people need to be happy, but if you love archeology, then the outside temple are interesting too...but similar.

Interesting history. The three main sites are vey interesting buy you need a tuk-tuk to get around to each of them as it can be stiflingly hot. Unless you're nose deep in Khmer history and want to know about every stone, buy a $20 one day pass as you can easily see the sights in a day. Angkor Wat is fantastic and the highlights of the trip and equals the magnificent Borobodur in Java. Unfortunately, some guides are referring to places as "the Lara Croft temple" as if Angelina Jolie was around there 1,000 years ago..
Can't say enough about the park. Go Go Go here. Every temple is great and every temple is worth visiting. A definite place off my bucket list!

You have to see this. You wouldn't come to Siem Reap if Angkor weren't on your bucket list, right? So despite sometimes obnoxious crowds, just do it, see as much as you can, including the bullet holes.

Top Quality. Get a guide, take a tour and then go back and see it again on a bicycle or in a TukTuk at amore leisurely pace. Where else can you do and see so much in one day for $20???!! An absolutely amazing and enthralling place.

must see if you are in Cambodia or Thailand. We came to Cambodia only to see these temples and spent a full day walking. There are a lot of stairs and walking so be prepared. Always wear comfy shoes and bring water. We got a guide through our hotel and he did things backwards so we wouldn’t be overburdened by other tourists at the most popular spots. You really should hire a guide or go with a tour since there is so much detail to be seen and understood. Our guide was great and he was born in a refugee camp after the war. You can see bullets holes in some of the walls in this park. We took soooo many pictures that we now have to sift through over 300. But when we look at the picture we remember how beautiful it was.Paid U$20 for a day pass that has our picture on it. And they do check for passes along the way.Must see.

Once in a lifetime. The area and surroundings of Angkor Archaeological Park are well-tended, clean, and filled with unbelievable treasures of another day. If there were more than seven wonders of the ancient world, this would truly be one of them.

a treasure to enjoy and protect. Angkor is one of the great wonders - but with an explosion n visitor numbers it is important that visitors accept they need to be very conscious of the need to protect this wonderful site not simply consume it ! Visitors must respect the very meagre visitor management systems in place and resist touching, climbing, clambering just for a photo ! just stroll, enjoy and employ a local guide - give back don't just take from this fragile place.
A Must Visit. Loved the Wat's - takes your breath away especially at 5 in the morning! Disliked the harassment by kids and parents at every Wat entrance and exit - like running the gauntlet.

good time to visit, but well organized. This was a relatively slow period between two giant holidays. Even so, there were lots of bus tours. Nevertheless, the park is clean, orderly, and the process for getting and checking passes very professional.
breathtaking. take a map with history on it so you can enjoy the view and understand the story behind the temples, there is no need for a tour guide.a great experience to get in touch with history

The draw card but far from the Diamond. Sunrise or Sunset is all you need to see of Angkor Wat. If you really want to experience the beauty of the temples choose to venture out to the outer complexes of Beng Meala (63km North East) or Bakong (13km East). Angkor Wat is too commercial and a lot of the beauty is lost in the thousands of visitors, but worth a sunrise of sun set for best photo oportunity.

A magical journey into the past. Pictures or videos can not do justice to this glorious archaeological marvel, a must visit,the view, the carvings and its massive scale are absolutely breath taking, the sunrise and sunset were just awesome.

Easily the best. Absolutely mind blowing. Here's a tip, leave the kids behind. There is a lot of climbing narrow steps etc. specially the 'stairway to heaven' is quite narrow and two floors up. Wear sneakers or really comfy walking shoes. We lucked out on the weather but I believe it can get very, very hot. It's really beautiful and you can't miss all the references to Indian culture.

Amazing park. The entire area is mind boggling. Endless buildings and sculptures and vistas, coming alive with our guide's commentary. There seems to be a pattern to the park visit but just wandering is delightful.

Reserve a great guide in advance!. It cost $45/day for a private guide and private tuk tuk. Our guide was Dahling -- a fantastic guide and former educator with great English, recommended and arranged by our guesthouse (Seven Candles). Dahling gave us all the historical and archeological info. we could possibly have wanted, but more importantly was great at gauging our interest and allowing us some quiet time for exploring or contemplating. He also shared his interesting family history with us and, on the way to one of the outlying temples, took us to a roadside village and explained the plants and tree and how the people live, how much rice production is needed to support each family, and quite a bit about the politics of the various political party affiliations. Having the private tuk tuk allowed us to be efficient in our visits -- our guide phoned the driver as we were readying to leave one temple, and the driver picked us up exactly as we walked out to whisk us off to the next temple site or to lunch.The Angkor complex is spread over several areas. Fascinating and can be spiritual if and when it is not overrun with tourists. Great photo opportunities. Well worth a full two days of exploration, maybe more if you just love this sort of thing.

Truly an unforgettable experience!. This is absolutely a must if you are visiting Cambodia! I only spent one day and i am usually not the kind of person to go to historic or cultural sites for touring but the Angkor Archaeological Park was absolutely unforgettable. I hired a tuktuk which are usually 10-15dollars for a full day with extra charges for sunrise/sunset and other further temples like the banteay srei. I recommend the tuktuk but you can also rent a bike for 2-3dollars for a day which is also find. One thing to note is that if you buy your ticket after 5 o clock for the next day you get a free sunset the day of the purchase of the ticket. But make sure the entrance guy doesnt stamp you ticket on that day since you will need it for the next day.I would discourage people from going to the angkor what in the early afternoon as the sun was on the other side of the temple and there where not that may good opportunities for pictures. I ended up going back in the evening to get better photos. Also take advantage of the small temples. Most people only go to the main temples and the main temples can get really packed while the small ones you can have them to yourself, literally (When i went to the minor temples there was no one). The entrance fee is 20 for one day 40 for three and 60 for the one week pass. There also is extra fee for some temples such as the Phnom Kulen ( USD 20 ), Koh Ker ( USD 10 ) and Beng Mealea ( USD 5 ).
Bucket List Item Completed. Amazing. You should definitely visit Angkor Thom along with Angkor Wat. Definitely hire one of the licensed guides to fully appreciate the history.
Fantastic. Fantastic , a unic place in the world heritage places.The Quality and the amazing quantity of monuments.

The problem with tourists!. Having visited the Angkor park 10 years ago and being shocked by the number of tourists visiting in 2004, I was completely blown away by the number of tourists visiting the sites now and the damage that the temples have experienced over the past decade. A place of beauty is now slowly decaying and something should be done to restrict the number of visitors that enter the park each day. I understand that the temples bring incredible benefits to SR and the Cambodian community, but they will soon only be a pile of rubble. Having said that I noted the restoration being undertaken, and adding new heads onto old stone sculptures is not something that is very eye appealing. If you want to visit the temples go late in the afternoon when everyone has climbed the mountain for the sunset. Every temple we visited was abandoned and you have time to sit and reflect on the beauty and magnitude of what is around you.
Amazing Place. The temples are amazing and have to be seen.Didn't like the tour buses full of Korean Tourists that like to get in the way.

Avoiding large tour groups is the key to enjoying these magnificent temples.. Avoiding large tour groups is the key to enjoying these wonderful temples. Reclaimed from the jungle, they offer an amazing insight into the history of the Khmer kings and the Hindu and Buddhist religions.Angkor Wat is incredibly impressive, as is Angkor Thom. Elaborate and wonderfullly preserved bas-reliefs depict Hindu mythology and historical battles with the Cham. Angkor Thom's wonderful Elephant Terrace is massive and Ta Phrom boasts the roots of enormous strangler figs engulfing the walls. Hundreds of tourists flock to Anghor Wat at sun-rise and Phrom Bakheng is a favourite for watching the sun set. We enjoyed the sun-rise from the other side of the moat at Angkor Wat, with only a handful of others, which made for a very pleasant experience. We then visited this magnificent temple as people disgorged from its gates in search of breakfast, so were able to climb to the top levels and study the incredible bas-reliefs before the next wave of tour buses arrived about 9 am.Some of the smaller temples are in a poorer state of repair, but are incredibly atmospheric. Sanskrit carved into the walls and columns gives historians detailed accounts of the background and purpose of these wonderful temples.January is a great time to visit at the the temperatures are moderate and the weather is dry. Allow a few days so you can visit the more popular temples at quieter times of the day. A 3-day pass can be purchased for the same price as a 2-day pass.

A must when in Cambodia. Cambodia is nothing without a visit to the Angkor Archaeological Park. Bring plenty of sun block and wear a hat. If you can, use a bike. A guide is not necessary if you have the many guidebooks about Angkor with you. It is best to hire a tuk-tuk for the day to be able to go around the temples, some of which will require you to ride the tuk-tuk otherwise you waste your time walking nowhere.

A-MAZ-ING. This area was the reason that drew my husband and I over the border from Thailand to Cambodia. It was the absolute highlight of our trip and I am so glad we made it. High season is exactly what one expects it to be - busy - but honestly, the site is so big that everyone has the opportunity to have a moment to themselves.TIP: Wait to see Angkor Wat in the afternoon if you can. Better lighting for cracker photos.

Go by bike. I haven't ridden a bike in years and the Cambodian traffic seemed terrifying but it was much easier than I feared. It's much greener than a million tuktuks and coaches polluting the place, the roads are really good and mostly shaded and you can generally enjoy the park so much more. Really recommend the grand tour route too as you get to quieter places that are still equally impressive.

Extraordinary!. Absolutely amazing. The only negative was the inevitable fact of sharing with so many, but who can blame them. We (travelling with children and those who avoid getting up early) had to see the temples at peak times, but a little patience goes a long way.The must-do sunrise - some days have better dawns than others! Work out where the sun will be rising and position yourself accordingly, if you want photos of the sun rising behind the temples. Take a folding chair - you'll be waiting from 530 until about 7.I'd recommend a guide, but make sure s/he speaks good English (if that is your best language!). I couldn't understand quite a bit of what our guide said.Finally, if you can afford it, get a driver with a car, not a tuktuk - for $30/day, it's great to sit back in aircon with a cold bottle of water and recuperate from a few hours wandering about in the heat and dust, gearing up for the next temple.

A Must Visit. You come to Siem Reap to visit this historic site. Whilst the restored Angkor Wat temple was great I enjoyed the unrestored temples more. As this is a very popular place we found that visiting Angkor Wat in the morning was preferable to going in the afternoon when most people go because of the sunset over the temple. A tuk tuk driver will do a day tour of all the major temples for US$15. Excellent value.

You'll know why it's famous. Angkor is the best place to indulge yourself in a deep and meaningful historical atmosphere. Get ready to be astonished by its majestic ruins that will leave you in awe. Note to prospective tourists: While the sites itself are enough to take your breath away, I would recommend you to make some researches of its history (or get a tour guide) to truly understand its greatness. You will need at least 3 days at the very least to complete the whole tour. However, a day would be suffice for visiting only the major ones. Personally, I don't think it's entirely necessary to visit every single site in there unless you are really into it because most, if not all, of them looks very similar to each other. A tuk-tuk is a must. Can't travel by foot. Bicycle could be possible if you're "very" fit.

Magnificent and Impressive. The number of visitors is 6x since the last time I was here in 2009. Still this comlpex is something you need to see once in a lifetime. Obviously Angkor Wat with it's towers, but also the huge Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm with it's giant trees grown into the ruines. We went there on our own on a bike. The short route appr. 20km from Siem Reap and the 'Grand tour' about 28 km. Weather was not to hot (25 C) so perfect conditions. Along the way we had a flat tyre, asked a police officer for help, and he start instantly fixing the tyre in 10 minutes!! Cambodian people are so helpful as it is shown again here.If you want to have a good impression of the monumental complex, take two days to explore at least, and learn about the ancient history of these people.

A must-add to your bucket list. Angkor isn't just the Angkor Wat. It's actually the remains of an ancient city, the former seat of the once-mighty Khmer Empire, so spending more than a day visiting the sites is recommended. For our visit, we took a two-day tour and covered most of the Small & Grand Circuit. Hiring a good guide is recommended. Sure, you can DIY using bikes or hiring just a driver but you'll miss a lot of details and nuances on the history and context of the place. Aside from interacting with a local, you won't get lost in the passageways or take the wrong exit and cannot find your driver or your bike. If you don't have a budget for a guide, make sure you have a good Angkor guide book to help you decode the sculptures, murals, bas reliefs and numerous symbolisms in this culturally-rich UNESCO World Heritage site. Without someone to tell you the story behind the ruins, it will all look like a pile of rubble after a while.Since we opted for a tour, we didn't get to haggle on what tut-tuk tour fares should be. Check other reviewers for the ongoing rates or if you want to save yourself the hassle, book directly at the numerous Siem Reap tuk-tuk tours on the Internet. You can DIY using bikes (provided free by some guesthouses) but it can be a hassle at some temples since they don't allow bikes inside. You'll have to backtrack the temple, going back to where you came in, which means losing time exploring the other sites.Traveling by tuk-tuk is the way to go, but for farther sites like Banteay Srei, hiring a car is a better and quicker option.Siem Reap can be hot and humid and you'll obviously want to wear shorts. But ask a local (your guide or your driver) first if there are any dress restrictions in the temple you're going. Some are actual places of worship, so females are required to wear pants or long dresses when climbing the Angkor Wat and Phnom Bakheng. A female tourist in front of us was asked to cover up her tank top before entering Phnom Bakheng. A shawl or scarf can do the trick.Bring water. As mentioned, Siem Reap is in a tropical climate so you'll get thirsty. Most guides and drivers provide complimentary water, but if you're DIY, don't forget it or you'll be shelling out US dollars to buy from the numerous vendors that surround the temple. There are also restaurants in the Angkor Wat, Sra Srang and other temples that range from roadside vendors to street side eatery style to full-on package tour restaurants, if you get hungry. There's a Blue Pumpkin outlet near Angkor Wat but we didn't get to see it.Restrooms are placed on the road leading to the temples, not on the ruins themselves. So keep an eye out for them since you don't want to get caught doing the deed on the ruins. It's free of use when you have your Angkor Pass.If you're still in the process of considering a trip to Angkor, be ready to climb steep stairs (going down is also a real challenge). Sure, you can skip it but you'll miss a lot of the ruins and the majestic view. There's also a lot of walking from entrance to exit and in between temples on dusty (muddy, if it's raining) paths. So if you're bringing over young children, the elderly and the disabled, it can be quite challenging.Still, a visit to Angkor is very much worth it. In fact, every person on Earth should visit this majestic site at least once in their lifetime.

The massive site is amazing. The various ruins at Angkor are truly an astonishing reminder of the power of this civilization in its heyday. While the various temples are in different states of recovery from the jungle, Cambodia is spending a lot of money on the ongoing effort, and it is certainly worth it for us and others who are interested in the advance of civilization over the years. While there is some effort required (generally just walking and climbing), the rewards are well worth the effort. There really isn't anything else like it anywhere.
Must see. Unique example of a little known civilisation and a must see. The only problem with visiting multiple temples is that after a while they all start to look the same.

So worthwhile..spend the time to explore. The Angkor Archaeological Park is massive and encompasses various historical sites, this is a multi-day adventure. To best be sure to hit the many important areas, use a local guide who knows how to detour around crowds and navigate the transportation alternatives within and around the park. The traffic from Siem Reap is heard to believe so try to get a very early start or stay until dusk when the crowds dwindle. We saw so many structures in a two day period of time, it would have been difficult without the assistance. Historically, artistically and culturally rich, be sure to "read" some of the scenes carved into the sandstone depicting the actual events of the time. There are many steps most uneven and some slippery, wear comfortable shoes and watch your step. Be respectful this a religious site, wear moderate clothing, do not touch the carvings and speak at a low volume.

One day in Angkor and some practical tips. I just did this tour hiring a tuk tuk driver. The four of us paid $18 total, but I heard that the prices go from $12 to $15. Our driver was very nice and we were fine paying a bit more, plus there were four of us.Tickets are available as of 5am. You can buy one day pass for $20, or three day pass for $40. Bring dollars. In riels, it cost 82,000, which is more than $20 by 2,000 rl, or about half a dollar.Have I mentioned that dollar - EUR exchange rate does not have anything to do with the world exchange rate for that day? When I visited Cambodia, dollar - EUR rate was: 1: 0.73. The rate in Cambodia was 1:0.90. Do the math. Bring dollars and only dollars, and change some dollars to KHR, since you may get better prices at some local places if you pay riels.ANGKOR WAT for sunrise? Why on Earth is this in every book you can find about visiting Angkor? Guys, it is absolutely nothing special. We had clear sky, not a single cloud, and it was not colorful. It was nothing special, really. We started our trip at 5am in the morning just because of this, and it was so NOT worth it! Hundreds, if not thousands, of tourists come to Angkor Wat in the morning because they have read that sunrise there is magical. Please, go some place else in Angkor for sunrise, and you will have the place almost for yourself, since everyone is at Angkor. 1. My favorite place was BAYON.. It has special energy. Many people I spoke to felt the same. This place just makes you want to stay there for hours and absorb amazing energy that it has. I wish I came to this place for sunrise, and had it for myself.2. ANGKOR THOM - right next to Bayon.3. TA PROHM - east of Angkor Thom. Amazing place. This is the place where huge trees intertwine with the buildings. Looks nicer earlier in the morning.4. PREAH KHAN - north of Angkor Thom. Haven't seen this one, but it is so possible to add it to the 1 day visit list.5. Start heading back to ANGKOR WAT. In the afternoon is great because of the position of the sun, and you can make great pictures then. I saw many Buddhist monks meditating here, so, if you are into meditation, this could be the place to plan this. But, you will end up in the photographs of many visitors while meditating. As did the monks.6. Sunset? No idea where. Bayon again? Or PHNOM BAKHENG hill, which is recommended for sunset. Expect many tourists at sunset. Or visit it during the day.Also, who says that it is very difficult to do the tour ON BIKE because it is far? From the city center, there is about 6km to Angkor. Does this sound to you like impossible or strenuous? Tuk tuk is nice, but then - you have to make your list in advance or you would be charged extra or the driver would tell you that there is no time to go back, or you would feel bad for the driver waiting for you, so sometimes you would hurry, and change your plans because of that. And bikes - many guesthouses give them for free. Next time I would definitely try the bike. Yes, if I go back to Cambodia, Angkor is so amazing that it is worth visiting again.

Worth a tour. This is worth the price, the place is amazing.. So much to see, we had a guide and find this really helpful as they know all the good spots, how to miss the masses, great photo spots and information, even if you forget it after, it is good to listen to at the time.

Interesting but not "have to see". Great place if you imagine how much time and work was needed to build everything there but most temples are similar in many ways so if you are not a fan of this particular culture you may become tired soon. Sunset sightseeing from the top of the temple has a great impact but is overcrowded.Advice: keep water with you at every given time, hot weather and stairs quickly drain liquid from your body.

Awesome Viewing. It's a place you have to see to believe. Stunning architecture not many places left like this in the world.If you can ignore at every site little kids selling you postcards- It's a great place to be.

Never heard of it?. In a little country called Cambodia, theres a town called Siem Reap, set around the site of historical Angkor a national park has been set up preserving and restoring many of the 1000+ year old temples. Everything is good and expected but the price is steep so make sure you have enough cash on you when you get to the entrance, they dont have ATMs surprisingly (the postcard selling kids might).

A must-see place. I was here before with a guide and this time I went on my own. The experience was the same because I could never remember those names and dates. Get a tuk-tuk and a guide book and go, or use a bicycle. For lunch there are outdoor places with Kmer food and cold drinks. One place had some hungry monkeys, sometimes you meet kids selling postcards and stuff. Lots of walking so wear the right clothes and shoes. Bayon is my favorite place because of that smiling face that you see everywhere. The tickets are $20 for one day or $40 for 3 days.
angkor parks. my only suggestion would be to take a guide as so much to see and learn. we arranged through our hotel. Can understand why the area is considered on one of the wonders of the world.

A collection of wonders. Get up early and enjoy it. The Angkor area is awe-inspiring. There are so many beautiful temples! I had dreame of visiting it since a long time.I went all in, bought a 7-day pass and spent every day there (for a half a day). It is really, really worth waking up very early (5-6am) a few times: there are so many people during the day, especially at Ta Prohm, whereas in the morning around 7am the big temples are almost empty and the atmosphere is nothing short of magic. Imagine having the famous Bayon or Preah Kahn all by yourself, sharing it with only a handful of people.Do some homework before going and learn where and when there are fewer people.With a seven days pass, I could afford visiting the big hits, several smaller and quieter areas for atmosphere (Ta Som, Ta Nei, Angkor Thom West gate) and taking the farther trip to magnificent tiny Banteay Srey.

Wear Comfortable Shoes. Incrediable place to visit, it is almost impossible to explain could remain hidden for so long. However you need to wear confortable shoes as there is a lot of walking and climbing stairs. My advice is to go early morning as it gets very busy.

Breathtaking!!!. We had a 3 day pass and I think it is the best. Sufficient and as you can do it within a week, you can alternate the visit to breathtaking temples, with a days break in town or surroundings before going back to this amazing place and beautiful site.

The Khmer Kingdom, in a gorgeous park.. The National park includes over a thousand temples, from the famous Angkor Wat, to many lesser know temples and government buildings, spread out over a huge area. This is one of the most impressive archaeological sites in the world, just on the sheer number of temples. The only thing that might be bigger is Bagon in Myanmar. The word is out though, so there are a huge amount of tourist here everyday. Now that does not mean that you will aways be jumbled in. You can go early and hit some of the lesser temples, and there might be no one there at all. You do need to go early to beat the heat, and the aircondioned tourist buses that show up around 10 am. This complex includes Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, and many more. Take your time with it.You can get 1, 3, and 7 days passes. We got the three day and it worked out perfectly. At the park entrance they take a picture of you, get your passport info, and then print out a photo id for you to use. I recommend getting a good guide and a tuktuk, because there is so much to learn. I rented a bike on my third day which was exciting, hot, but not too hard. You just need to hydrate. Its a great way to see it at your own pace, and since I used guides my first two days, I went to my favorite places. If you want to learn more then you can check out my blog on the park at http://michaelbencik.org/2013/12/31/khmer-empires-and-archeology-theives/
Magnificent. I am not well versed enough in the nuances of language to give adequate description. Look at pictures and come and see for yourself

At least two days for a proper visit. The place is so big and most of the temples are spread across long distances that I recommend at least two days for a proper visit, however if time is a restriction I suggest a privite guide to get the best of the park.Remember that entrance for kids under 12 yrs is free but the valid passport has to be produced when buying tickets and also at most of the temples. My guide was quick to point this out before we left the hotel.

WOW - great for sunset and sunrise!. Lots of places to visit in the park so might have to do over a few days. Guided tours can be interesting, or audioguides (if you can find online) Hope to return for some more interesting feaures!!

Take in the wonders. Angkor Archaeological Park has to be one of the most intoxicating places in the world. You can wonder around the various temples and let your imagine go in terms of what may have happened there at the peak of the kingdom. It's great to get a guide to tour you around the first time and then go back on your own to really soak up your favourite spots. Angkor Wat is truly mind blowing and a real wonder of the world.

Many sites and well maintained. Very interesting and generally clean toilets and water on sale most places. The hawkers are getting as bad as Bali but remember that they're just trying to make a living so stay pleasant and polite. And maybe remember that if you take a photo of the disabled men missing limbs in their bands playing music or the monks or the elderly lady in the temple at Pre Kahn that you politely offer a small donation. They and the kids are not just photo objects. Help them.

Sunrise at Angkor Wat. Went by tuk tuk and arrived about 40 minutes before sunrise (6.40am). Had some coffee from a nearby place (someone next to us ordered it and had it brought to them) There were many people, but it didn't seem crowded. . were able to walk around with no problem. Great experience.

Pay for a guide. We spent 2 days at Angkor Archaeological park. The first day we hired our own tuk-tuk for the half day tour then hired a tour guide at Angkor Wat. The second day we arranged the full day tour with a tour company. I highly recommend both. The tour guides help explain the stories behind the carvings, which we found helpful, even though we had a little trouble understanding our guide's English.

Awesome. I believe every person who has the ability should make at least one trip to the Angkor area in their lifetime. Each temple has something that inspires the soul and just when you are templed out, you see something else that reinvigorates you. The list in Siem Reap is endless. Angkor Wat is justifiably awesome. But so also in Ta Prohm, Banteay Sri, Bayon, Prea Khan - the list goes on. On top of that Wat Bo in downtown Siem Reap is simple and extremely peaceful.We spent 6 days looking around and that is just not enough. We cannot wait to go back. Lovely.
Not enough time.... Angkor wat at sunrise was a dream. The only downfall is the number of people constantly at the site, but it is what it is...

Magnificent. We got ourselves the three days pass, and found it just nice for us to get a feel to these magnificent gems of world heritage. The first day we did the short tour, about USD 15 per tut tut. Highlight: Angkor Wat (we have no luck for the sun rise, it was cloudy. :(, we woke up at 430am for that), Angkor Thom (Bayon! just cant retract myself from the serenity under the gaze of thousand buddhas), Phnom Bakheng (last station of the day, great view of sunset over a borderless horizon. Make sure you go there early, about 430-5pm because you need to take some time to walk to the temple)Second day, long tour plus Banteay Srey and Kbal Spean, about USD 30 per tut tut. Highlight: Prasat Pre Roup (Just another temple... ok, but something that made it sticks in my mind. I think it was the atmosphere. This was the first station. We reached here about 9am. The sky was so blue and the wind was chilly, and the sunshine coated the whole temple in a mysterious golden glow. We took alot of photos here.), Kbal Spean (We came here without any reading about the place. We hiked a long way, and found ourselves a small stream at the end of the hike, we were quite disappointed.. but hey, we found something carved on the stones along the riverbank, and more and more when we walked down the stream. We were so excited. It was a unique spot, something different from all the other temples. Expect a quite strenuous hike though, bring a lot of drinking water!), The country side (We were glad that we chose tuk-tuk, because we could experience the beautiful country side with more senses: smell of sugar palm syrup when we passed some stores along the road side, smell of cow dung, the chilly wind, the dog bark and bird chipping. But make sure you prepare a mask for yourself, some part of the road could be very dusty)Third day, we decided not to go to other small temples, but we revisited Angkor Wat and Bayon with bicycle. It was a relaxing tour, as we were not rushing to anywhere. We stopped by random encounters with local food sellers, and a wedding ceremony in a temple in the town. We decided to revisit to Angkor Wat and Bayon, to try our luck for a better weather to shoot better photos. Well, the weather turned out better than the first day. During the revisit, we paid attention to the details like the murals and the carvings. We felt homey while we were sitting and gazing the magnificent view. Tips: You can get cheaper price for the short and long tour if you take your time bargaining with the tour providers in the town. We took the package from our hotel because we were lazy to look for a cheaper one and the offer sounded reasonable for us. We were at one point indecisive about hiring a tour guide, but decided not to, to save the cost. We found ourselves no problem in understanding the temples by reading books, and by ear-dropping to other people's tour guide. LOL. Bring along drinking water ( you need A LOT) and snacks. Food were a bit pricey there.

Bucket-list material. Visiting this park must be done on more than one day to truly enjy and absorb its beauty and depth. Strongly suggest bike-riding the short circuit and touring the big circuit with a private tour bus. do NOT take cheap tours here as you will not enjoy the beauty of this place with a time limit. Many, many pics can be taken here so do not skimp on costs once here. Recommend the Grasshopper Bicycle tours for the short cicuit and Bunly Tours for the Big Cicuit, please see reviews of those online tripadvisor. Either way, Angkor is stunning and is a must for all in life to observe, if only once, before they kick the bucket. Safe travels all!

Loved it. Needs multiple days and a good guide though.. Loved the whole area and as we had (semi-interested) teens with us we just did the one day, but definitely warrants more than a single visit. We had a tuk-tuk driver who gave us some information at places but I would have liked more detail along the way, so worth checking who is taking you around. At the main Angkor Wat we hired a guide from the front entrance and he was fantastic and gave us lots of background and explanation on the building and reasoning behind everything, so much so that the teens enjoyed it too! Amazing place and we just loved the whole atmosphere, but it was busy most of the time which is the only downside.
As awesome as expected. I had been waiting to visit Angkor for a long time and I was not in the slightest disappointed. It does get very busy and there are some steep climbs
very impressive archeological site. Angkor Wat is huge visit it in the late afternoon when the crowd is less. A guide is very helpful. The site is amazing.

Absoutely Magnificent. The whole park encompasses different structures and complex over different dynasty and centuries. Once golden and beautiful, enjoy your journey as you travel through time over this vast area. Expect to take a few days in your favourite mode of travel (bikes, cars, tuk-tuks) as you visit all the restored sites. Do not rush the temple from point to point if you have a choice. Take your time through the different places, if you have some historical perspective, you will enjoy the visit even more. Some readings or a local guide will help a lot with appreciating all the sites. if you wish to do temple hopping and picture taking routine, just visiting the 3-5 major sites will be good enough as you will find many of the temples underwhelming.
Angkor Wat. Awesome experience. It is a must for all travelling to Cambodia. HIghly recommend a guide, so informative and makes the tour enjoyable.

Visit and revisit. With every visit to the site, the enchantment grows. Purchase the 3 day pass. It costs just twice the amount of a one day pass and is good for 3 visits over a period of 7 days. The Rolus group of temples is included on the ticket.

Words can't describe. Angkor is a very special place but the sheer scale of it blew us away? There are stunning temples around every corner, each with its own distinct atmosphere. The park itself is a pleasant place to wander. Must do!
Huge. Simply enormous and simply brilliant. Was amazed at the architecture and the beauty. Get there early to avoid the queues.
One of the world's wonder. Cannot but visit. it can take one week and there will be still more to visit.The night life in town is animated and there's a plenty of pubs

Deteriorating due to too many tourists at the same time.... I would suggest avoiding the "high season" or avoiding until the park starts limiting daily access. At present you mostly see tourists, there are actual queues inside the temples to pass through. Quite sad compared to what was here 13 years ago.

Unbelievable.... Lots of walking to be done, but truly worth the effort! Beware you will be harassed constantly by selling kids, it becomes very annoying and expensive. Also beware, they even charge to use the loo at most of the sites here.

Great place, great experience. If you are in Siem Reap one of the things you would be planning to do would be to visit this amazing area, and if it is not on your to do list it should most be there at the top.The whole sight is massive and if you really want to see a reasonable amount of it you should plan to spend the best part of two days visiting. There are far too many significant and important parts to this site ( Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, etc, etc) to comment on each one but to say there each tell a different story and are amazing.Buying tickets for the site and getting around is very easy but to get the most out of any visit I would suggest that a properly accredited guide, of which there are many, is a must.

Visit on Sunrise;Take Photo as Many as You can. Get Photo as Many As you Can; different shots and different poses from serious/documentary to fun/jump shots; you'll never know if you might be back again in this amazing place.Also hug the tree to show to your photo how big this big old tree is.Ride is very affordable and choose only the places you want to visit ahead of time. TIP1: get a magazine and search online photos and locate for the place you want to visit. This century old tree is a MUST! TIP2: Visit on sunrise to have enough time, unlike sunset, you will have limited time. TIP3: Bring at least 1 liter of water you always carry. Eat bfast/sandwhich while on your way to the place.
great experience. We booked a guide at the sight making sure the person we used was a properly certified. This made a huge difference to our experience.Fascinating history and a great experience.

Amazing. Minimum time required 3+ hours, we went in late afternoon, if you arrive at 4pm at the small lake then you can capture the reflection in the water, very good photo opportunity, wear long trousers and you cant wear sleeveless clothes when you visit the top of the Temple.

Siem Reap. Access to the Place was easy, and Ticket counter was friendly. remember to plan how many daya you want to use the Angkor facility. USD 20 to USD 60 is the range from one day to one week.Inside the areas are well appointed - we did not use a guide but having one will be best if you need an updated story of the history and the locale. Overall the park is well maintained and well looked after. I wish the tourists would refrain from touching the stone bas reliefs and the statues.
Beautiful must see visit. Get there early - bring a torch and a waterproof. I got absolutely soaked! The temples are gorgeous with so much detail and history.

Angkor Archaeological Park.. Entrance ticket for the "Small tour Circuit" is 20 U.S $'s per day.A photograph identity ticket is issued at the ticket both with a instant camera/computer.The archaeological park entrance gate is approx 7 Kms from Siem Reap city.Private transport is essential for touring this park and if young, cycling is the best and most convenient way of rugged sight-seeing.

Amazing experience. to be able to see such sites and so many of them in one place is an experience that will stay with us forever.From the first temples of the 9th Century right through to the 13th Century we visited nearly 30 of them over 5 days.Yes it is expensive, tiring and in parts very overcrowded but you can still find temples were there is next to no one and you can sit and reflect on the greatness of it all.

AMAZING OF COURSE!. Can understand anyone who would need to read a review of ankor wat as it is a must see... Amazing temples some of the best in the world. Sun rise is spectacular, sunset is amazing too! Spend a min of a whole to really enjoy.

you'll never know if you never go. Worth the trip for certain. Amazing history.As pesky as the local sellers are with their wares do try to buy something. I bought a very informative guide to the temples for $5. I urge people not to bargain below a price you're getting good value at. The sale has to be good for both parties which means they should make a couple of bucks too. Don't be too tight is what I'm saying.

Amazing. The temples absolutely exceeded my expectations, an amazing experience. There is a lot to see, we spent 3 days there & could have easily spent more time there to revisit favorite areas at different times of the day. We did a private tour the first day & got the lay of the land & spent the next couple on our own with a tuk tuk driver & enjoyed the freedom of being to spend as much time as we liked where ever we liked.

So much to see. Next to Angkor Wat, there is so much more to see in the Angkor Archaeological Park. The size of the park is stunning. Hundreds of temples are awaiting you, some in better shape than others, some more crowded than others. To make the most of your visit, recommend that you get a book or information from the internet about the various temples prior to your trip. This will help you to choose what exactly you want to see. It's convenient and relatively inexpensive to rent a tuk tuk or car with driver for the day to get you around to the different temples. A one day pass to the park costs USD20,-, a 3 day pass USD40,-.

This is a Huge Archaeological Park. This is a very large park and can be viewed in a busy day or over several days. We saw sunrise over Angkor Wat and viewed many sites. We hired a tuk tuk for the day which transported us to many areas. The vendors get tiring with their continual attempt to sell you the same things all the vendors have. Many small children follow you in an attempt to sell items also.

A Fantastic Experience. AWESOME. The archaeological park was just awesome. Could not believe just how magnificent the old temples were, despite parts of it in ruins. Just how they were built hundreds of years back with no modern machines was just incredible. Rather than take a private tour, we had a good tuk tuk driver who took us there and stopped us at the right places and was able to give us good information in fluent English. That made the whole experience for us even more authentic. Along the way, we saw happy school children riding bicycles larger than them. The children's sheer happiness as could be seen on their faces was a reminder that there is beauty in the simplicity of life.It was a wonderful trip.
Amazing place!!. It was amazing trip! It seemed back in 400 years ago.i never thought it will be very beautiful place.you need more than one day to visit here.. Don't miss !! I wish to go back agian.
Don't miss it. It is a worth going, the reason for me to visit Siem Reap. Really awesome experience and a wonderful place.

So many temples, so little time. I used to think that Angkor Park was just one place - wrong! It includes a number of temples spread out across a fairly large distance. Many can be seen in ~2 days with a tuktuk and some are far afield in jungles and small villages. I saw ~8 of the temples in 2 days around the Siem Reap area and they were all different, interesting and amazing. The main ones are Angkor Wat (catch it at sunrise - awesome!) and Angkor Thom, plus Ta Prohm (the "Tomb Raider" temple). Plus there are many others to choose from. It really depends on how far you want to go and how much energy / interest you have. I had a 3-day ticket but only used 2 days. The temples are of different ages, for different purposes, built by different kings / leaders. They all have some level of carving ranging from ornate to basic. It is clear to understand why they are a World Heritage Site. I hope that the Cambodian government continues to care for the temples so that many more generations can marvel at the skills of engineering and art. A couple of things to be prepared for - the heat / humidity (water, sunscreen, hats, bug repellant) and the number of locals who will try to sell you something.

World Heritage Site for good reasons. The immensity of the site alone should raise awe and wonder in anyone who has an understanding of construction or religious sites. We were able to visit sites in both Vietnam and Thailand on the same trip and it is clear that they may be financially challenged countries now, but they have interconnected histories to be proud of. Be ready to mentally block out the crowds, heat and vendors and then let your imagination go. A visit to the museum as well as pre travel reading both provide a better understanding of this extended park. There are many opportunities to understand the current culture of this part of Cambodia since there are several different groups who still reside within the confines of the park.

An absolute must!. You have to visit this place! It is easy to spend a couple of days here walking around the numerous temples and a good idea to get there early for the sunrise and stay until sunset! A guided tour would be useful to get the full history and background to everything.

Amazing sights, but ready yourself for crowds!. This place is amazing, but it is a huge attraction, so be ready for big crowds! We went at 6 am for the sunrise and were surprised how many people were already there. The ticket to the park is $20 per person per day. You can get a 3 day pass for $40. They take your photo and put your photo on the ticket, which makes for a nice souvenir. We walked all around, we just got dropped at the main temple by a tuc tuc driver and had him meet us back at noon. We were lucky the weather was pretty cool when we were there (by Cambodian standards). You can definitely walk around, or another great way to get around is by bike. You can also have a tuc tuc take you, but you see much more if you bike and walk. It is tiring, but was well worth it. We saw 5 temples on our walk and then a few more on another day when we went back. It is truly a beautiful place. However, it would be much more pleasant if they allowed no motorized vehicles int he park, this really takes away from the old charm of the place and makes the air very polluted and also creates more noise with traffic jams and people honking. I really wish they would ban all vehicles and just allow bikjes and bike tuc tuc, would be a much more authentic experience and more pleasant all around, as there are ridiculous amounts of tour buses filled with throngs of tourists and putting otu lots of smoke and pollution into the otherwise beautiful and pristine park. That being said it was amazing and we look forward to visiting again next year. There are also plenty of areas inside to get food and drinks, since likely you will spend most of the day there to see all or most of the temples. There are also lots of people trying to sell you guide books, etc, we didn't buy any and you don't really need it. You can get maps on your phoen to guide you around, that is waht we used and were fine. There are many English speaking guides there if you do want one, and that could be nice as well, not too expensive either.
AN exceptional place on earth. While I had read and known a lot about Angkor through books and pictures, but the true experience of being there was overwhelmingly. Before you die you have to see it!

Not to be Missed. I chose to review this rather than all of the individual sites. The park encompasses hundreds of different sites, including Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, Ta Prohm, etc. By all means, hire a local experienced guide who can help to interpret and explain what you are seeing. A stop at the National Museum is also helpful. Quite frankly, this site is overwhelming and incredible. We spent 2 entire days here and saw only a handful of the many wonders. Our guide was very good at choosing sites to visit that really impressed us, and at giving us a broad overview of the sites. He was also very knowledgeable about the history of the sites, and knew when and how to avoid the the biggest crush of tourists. This was a "once in a lifetime" experience. And, while you are here, go into Siem Reap. Interact with the locals, eat at a Khmer restaurant. This is a not to be missed experience.

Amazing Angkor Wat. One of the Great historical place to be. This place is amazing, wonder how they built this without machines in the past. Get at least a 3 day pass for your visit. Is impossible to cover the park in one day. The place is always crowded with tourists from around the world. Do wear comfortable shoes, hiking and walking shoes is highly recommendable. Most of the steps are very narrow and steep. Be careful on your way down.  Keep yourself hydrated during your visit. It is very hot and humid. Sometimes you do get lucky, bumping onto off duty officer trying to be your guide. Don't need to be rude, just smile and move along. Just tell him you want to explore on your own. Kids too will ask for money or candy. smile and move along. Do arrange to see the sunrise at Angkor Wat and sunset and Phnom Bakheng. You are not alone , there are thousands of people doing it with you. Be early to get your perfect spot for photos. For sunset, do bring along a torch light/ headlight. It can be very dark on your way out. (note: Do get a Tour Guide when visiting the temples in Angkor wat. You can get lost easily as there are shortages of signage. To me, the temples look the same inside. They all look the same. You can go in from East and end up coming out from the West side).

Number One Reason To Visit Siem Reap. If you are vacationing in Siem Reap, chances are you came to see the Angkor temples. They truly are a world class attraction; unfortunately, when the entire world feels that way expect to share it with a lot of people. There are three options to visit the park: a $20 one day pass, a $40 three days in a week pass, and a $60 seven days in a month pass. For the casual visitor, the choice is really between a one and three day. Most agree that two days is sufficient to see everything of note. To save money and avoid spending any more time in the crowds than necessary we chose to pack as much as we could into one day and call it good. We started early and caught the sunrise at Angkor Wat. It was cool, but if sunrises standing packed shoulder to shoulder are not your thing you might want to skip the 0430 wake up. We were biking so, to avoid the crowds as much as possible, we ignored the common clockwise progression around the grand tour and, after seeing Angkor Wat, went counterclockwise around the grand tour with one detour to see Ta Phrom. This worked out relatively well for us and we were able to see most of the temples with minimal crowds. I mentioned biking. If you are in good physical shape and it is during the cooler part of the year this is a viable option, just make sure to bring plenty of water. We did the entire grand tour plus a couple detours and my poor wife was really starting to run out of steam toward the end of the trek. We brought a little over four liters of water and ran out just before we got to the end of the circuit.
