There are food and water vendors along the route, however, they will charge you significantly more than fair market value. For the majority of people, I would recommend a Tuk Tuk for transportation. Doing it all in one day we didn't have time for a guide to explain everything to us so we were pretty much going to see the sites, not to learn about Khmer history.The Angkor Historical Park is an amazing place. Depending on the depth, or desired depth, of your knowledge there are multiple ways to go about seeing it. Most of it can be seen in a day, however, taking a guide, doing some research, visiting the Angkor National Museum, and spending a couple of days will give a deeper understanding of the Khmer culture. Definitely recommend a visit here!

mind blowing. I don't see a lot of point in separating out the temples and giving them different reviews. The whole park complex is amazing. I only wish I had the time to see all of them.
To see Angkor Wat emerge from the gloom as the sun rises is something really quite special.
Bucket list check off. Amazing history and architecture very hot and crowded .Glad we didn't wait till we were old to do this trip
amazing. You really had to visit this earliest time in morning possible to avoid not only the heat but the bus loads of japanese tourists.

Take Your Time. We spent 3 days touring the Park and managed to research and organize our visit to make the most of it, doing our best not to be overwhelmed. Each temple offers a different perspective of their lives (and egos). We found some of the smaller temples more interesting. Sturdy, comfortable walking shoes and a good hat are a must since there is a lot of walking and stairs. I would not recommend going without a guide.

Obvious visit if you are in Siem Reap. Start with the lesser temples on your first day and finish up with the big more popular temples at the end and you'll be glad you did. We did it this way because of the weather in the rainy season but it ended up being the best way to do it. If you do the big temples on the first day you are a little disappointed with the lesser temples later. Overall an incredible place to visit and make sure to take some black and white pictures if you like them as the temples lend themselves to make incredible Black and White photos.

Ex Angkor scientia. A place to behold and awestruck! Very safe locals and the street peddlers not too insistent for most occasions :)Do be careful with some "local officials" that gets too friendly and tag along your entourage. They may ask for a "souvenir" from you. Just smile and move along and they will back off. {Note: Official tour guides wear a uniform and name tag and they are very professional... }

Wear comfortable sport shoes. The park is huge. Your feet will still be painful even if you took a tuk-tuk to travel the whole archaeological park, so please do wear a pair of comfortable sport shoes if you plan to see it all in one day. Remember to bargain if you interested to buy the souvenirs sold by the people in there.If possible, go for the sunrise view at Angkor Wat. It's cooling and exciting experience!
Must do for "bucket list". The architecture was amazing. Remember to plan for the weather. In our opinion, a guide is a must if you with to understand what you are seeing.

the reason to visit Siem Reap. I took the shorter tour plus Banteay Srei in the same day, which is incredible, though felt bit "temple burn out" in the end. Still, it is an awesome experience. If I were to do it again, I may drop certain small temple though
just go before it is too late. spent 4 days touring the park with a tuk tuk and a tour guide. Don't do it alone except if you have lots of time. Sunset trip is overrated, but do it anyway!
Grab your bike:. Grab your bike and take a leisurely ride from temple to temple...you may even spot a few monkeys along the way!

a MUST for a Cambodian trip. sunrise in angkor wat.. one check for my bucket list!! i recommend at least 2 days to tour the whole park to really enjoy the rich history of cambodia and the khmer culture.. having a GOOD tour guide can also break or make your experience an unforgettable one. plus, check the weather update before planning your trip, a little rain is welcome especially during the hot season but a downpour can be a bummer.. and lastly, an air-conditioned car may be very convenient but a tuktuk ride gives your temple tour with a different perspective.

World wonder. I have heard of Angkor Wat, the largest cultural complexes in the world. And when I visited Angkor Archaeological Park, it is beyond my imagination. Wonderful, Breathtaking, vast and great Khmer cultural experience. A good tour guide would surely help you understand more abt this heritage site.You should spend about half of a day to explore deeply this place. No one can leave SR without going to Angkor Park, which may be the primary motivation for them to go to SR. Personally, I want to bring my family to visit the mythic wonder.
Well laid out. It was very hot with little shade but it is a wonderful site, take plenty of water and if you are ambitious go to the top for a wonderful view!

Be sure you have time for the pace you want. Amazing and vast! All too often we hear of only a portion of this beautiful area for Angor Wat but THERE IS SO MUCH MORE! Be sure you have at least a half day for this vast area. Many spend multiple days among the ruins. I suggest a guide through angor wat to get asssociated.Also great idea to get a tuk-tuk driver for the full day to pick you up at other side of ruins and get you to the next one or food, bathroom etc

Angkor doesn't dissapoint !. The whole Angkor archaelogical park lives totaly up to expectations. Angkor Thom, Temple of Bayon, Terrace of the elephants and Angkor Wat totally live up to all expectations. Getting up at 4am for the spectaculat Angkor Wat sunrise is well worth it. The fig trees growing over the buildings at Ta Phrom is a photographers paradise.

So many temples to take in. We only bought a one day pass but on the advice of our hotel manager, we bought it on the evening on the day before we planned to spend our day in the park. Our ticket then covered us all the way through. We watched the sunset over Phnom Bakheng (although we had a long queue as it was crowded).The next day we did Angkor Wat, the most famous of the entire site and is the largest religious building in the whole world. You have to have shoulder and knees covered to see the inner sanctum. We then saw the less populated temple Banteay Kdei and the royal bath; the massive artificial lake that is Sra Srang. The former was the more interesting for us and it was almost completely ruined.We also saw Ta Prohm, known as the Tomb Raider temple as some of the Tomb Raider film was shot here. Next was Angkor Thom, then the Temple of the Elephants, the Terrace of the Lepers, Bauphon and Bayon. By this point we were templed out even though we'd seen only the tip of the iceberg for the park. There's easily a few days worth to see.It's fantastic and exploring the ruins are incredible but not a great deal of information about the history of the temples. Would recommend finding a good tuk-tuk driver to take you round to make the journey between temples quicker and they may give you a quick talk about each of them.

A true wonder. Angkor should be at the top of just about everyone's to-do list for South East Asia as it is truly one of the greatest man made wonders on earth. Of all the ancient structures that i've seen around the world this is the most impressive. The architecture and artwork differs between each complex so you're constantly met with unique and interesting designs. Perhaps the most interesting is Ta Prohm which has numerous giant fig trees growing out of the buildings. You've most likely seen pictures of this but you really do have to see it up close to appreciate this odd and beautiful nexus of nature and the artificial.I have read other reviewer's complaints about there being too many tourists here and I cannot argue with that. People desire to go to the most amazing places so that's why Angkor is so busy; the same can be said for the pyramids of Egypt, the Roman Colosseum, etc. That said, the park spans 400 square kilometres so there are plenty of places to go where there are few to no tourists. I recommend getting at least a 3 day pass so you have time to explore the popular and less popular complexes.

Surreal, serene, must be seen.. My girlfriend and I traveled to Angkor Archaeological Park in October 2013. We toured by Tuk Tuk for two days, seeing the big three tourist destination major temples as well as several farther out locations. Each and every place held it's own unique beauty and power. Many of the temples, including the main namesake Angkor Wat, were amazingly devoid of crowds. We felt like explorers of a lost and ancient world. Climbing up a path of massive stone rubble to the top of Preah Khan while the rain began to fall and the sun began to set is a memory will always hold a special place in our hearts. This is a place to be still and to be amazed.

Too Many People. I clicked average, which is in reference to the overall experience. The temples are not average, they are extraordinary; however, there are soooo many people that it kind of diminishes the experience. Oh...try the sunrise to escape the crowds... not gonna happen...thousands embarks on the place every day...ALL day. Chinese, Korean and Russian tourists travel in HUGE herds, and couldn't care less about anyone else. VERY rude.

History at its finest.. We loved taking our time through each of the temples, and we purchased one of the books from a store so that we could understand what we were looking at - which was a good idea as there were not many information signs up. We left Angkor Way until last so that it wasn't as busy, and Banteay Srei was definitely worth the journey.

Nature Intertwining with History.. This temple is best known as the “Tomb Raider Temple” as the movie was filmed here. The real draw for me however were the trees growing throughout the temple. Our guide explained to us that the temple doesn’t completely collapse under the weight of the temple because the trees are actually hollow. It was amazing to see the trees atop the temple and intertwining with everything in its path. Defiantly a must see in Siem Reap.

Beautiful sites and history. My friends and I enjoyed touring the Angkor Wat temples very much. Full of history, mythology and they have put in great effort to restoring many of the sites so that we could enjoy part of the Angkor empire's glory.

World Heritage on a grand scale. The Angkor Archaeological Park is a wonder for sure. The largest number of temples in a single area and the history available to learn is incredible. It seems that everyone who comes learns and sees something new. The ongoing restoration and exploration continues to bring new insights fro travellers. Best value for money you can find anywhere.

Lovely temples. As mentioned in many other posts, hire a tuk tuk driver for the day, it is relatively cheap and if you get a good one, he will explain things about the temples and offer other services. We found our one at the airport when we first arrived. The temples themselves are great pictures of architecture and indescribable. We did find however after 5 hours and many temples we were had it. So pace yourself and take your time. Take lots of water!

brilliant. I am not one for looking at buildings and other man made structures, but Angkor was exceptional.....the intricate detail, the layer upon layer of craftmanship is marvellous viewingI just feel saddened that the buildings may not last....Go go go..
undescribable. hire a TUK TUK for the best way to get around I recommend Mr Ral (855)12713557, $15-$20 per day, it takes days to see all the different temples so give yourself time
Great!. for this kind of old temple, the facilities was great! its very convenience for us to enter and leave the temple safely. Just the matter that the stair is too many but its awesome!

Wonderful Experience. Beautiful Place, Great Experience!!! Hire a tuk tuk for the day and spread your visit over several days. 3 day ticket were 40usd and kids under 12 are free. I think i offended the Tuk tuk driver when i paid him. The hotel suggested 10usd for half a day+ a tip.

Awesome!. Spectacular! I preferred Angkor Thom over Angkor Wat. With such amazing history and architecture of the Khmer people. Everyone must do this at least once in his or her lifetime. Bayon temple is spectacular as is the victory gate in the East. Try and get some bikes and ride through the temple complex as well. It enhances the experience and allows you to see it all from a different perspective.

what an exceptional experience. Park is belittling the area. It is just an incredible experience to visit these temples. Well in for days you will be able to see just the most impressive ones. 2 million tourists per year gives an idea that you will not be alone at the sights. With a good guide you will be able to avoid the biggest tour groups.

Simply mind blowing. If anyone ever has the opportunity to visit Angkor, then do it. For me it's up there as one of a handful of must see before you die sites in the world.We were expecting amazing and it delivered and then some. The scale, the setting, the engineering complexity, the intricacy of the craftsmanship and just the overall aura and ambience of the place is simply spectacular. Myself and my wife were utterly blown away by the place.Aside from the biggies; Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, there are dozens of other interesting and amazing temples and ruins scattered across the vast Angkor Archaeological Park. Whilst Angkor Wat and Thom can get very, very crowded, the further afield temples are virtually empty. It's a much more pleasant experience wandering around them uninterrupted by bus loads of tourists.Try Preah Khan, Ta Prohm (Tomb Raider temple) and Banteay Samrae - all impressive, but less crowds.We visited for two days and to be honest, we could have done another day to enable us to slow the pace a little - we were dashing round at a fair pace. The first day we rented bicycles which was great fun as the terrain is flat and you feel closer to the place when you're travelling under your own steam - although be prepared as you can easily clock up 50km in a day. The second day we hired a tuk tuk which was very affordable, although our definition of what amounts to a full day differed greatly from that of our driver, so agree up front what you're expecting to see and the length of the trip. Loved Angkor, would love to go back and Siem Reap is a revelation too, great little city.

One day tour. One day was plenty for me, as I've seen many temples in SE Asia. However, it would also be nice to take the time to see a few temples each day. Either way, there are plenty of tuk-tuk drivers willing to take you on the "small tour" for $15 for the day (starting with 4:30am pickup to around 2pm). You can realistically see all the major hot spots in one day. Even though you may miss out on some of the smaller temples, it's a lot to take in.

beauty on a grand scale. An amazing place to have seen. Try to get out of bed as early as possible and be out at the park early. Not only does is get crowded with bus after bus load of people, but it gets really hot and in some temples there is not a lot of shade. Tip - take a little folding umbrella that can be stashed in a back back or carry bag. It made a big difference to have portable shade!If you're into photograhy it was difficult to get photo's without strangers in them as the morning went on, but earlier in the day you have a quite a few opportunities. AND the lighting through the 1000 year old temples was beautiful.Be aware that if the monks take you towards a prayer area and help you to pray for your family, you will be expected to provide a "gift". Cash is the only gift they seemed to want.I climbed to the top of Angkor Wat with my 72 year old dad - it's a steep climb up (the "stairs" feel more like a ladder!) but the views were incredible and it was a really special moment to have shared with him.

Beautiful, and well worth the money. Our 3-day temple pass was the most well spent $40 of our stay in Siem Reap. We visited the park at the end of July with our 3 teenagers; rainy season but still a fantastic time to go. The crowds were thin, even non-existent in places, which meant no traffic jams to reach the sites (which happens regularly in the high season according to our tuk-tuk driver), no queuing and often being able to explore a temple (or parts of it) all by ourselves. The rains came mostly in the afternoon so we were able to time our visits. How much we enjoyed the temples (and the atmosphere) was largely dependent on how crowded it was when we visited. Our favourites were Ta Phrom and the Bayon which were both fairly quiet, and deserted in places, when we visited. This was at about 8.30am. Preah Kahn came in a close second. All the temples are special; we loved the wilder, jungle-clad temples, but another may prefer the grandeur of Angkor Wat or the intricate carvings of Banteay Srei. It’s just personal.For most visitors a 3-day pass will allow enough time to get a good impression of all the main temples in a relaxed tempo plus a few extras. You don’t have to use the pass on consecutive days, so you can always take a break from temple touring with another activity. Try to spend at least 2 days here; a one day visit really doesn’t do this park justice.

Exceeds expectations. What a fabulous and huge site. There are so many temples, buildings, gates and fabulous sites. You have seen the pictures, but nothing can prepare you for just how amazing this place is.

The Famous Angelina Jolie site.. While looking at our map, we could no longer remember the name of the temple. So our tuktuk driver (he probably had an idea what we wanted to see, he then said "want to see angelina jolie temple?!?!?!) Lol! Its quite amusing hearing it from a khmer and it was pretty obvious that they are so proud about their khmer heritage and of course angelina jolie. Personally though I thought this part of the temple was quiet and surreal as depicted from the tomb raider film. But lo and behold, there were plenty of noisy tourist when we got there. All in all, it was definitely a site to see! A must visit if you are in Siem Rep.

it's why you come to Siem Reap. Arrived in Siem Reap on late Wed night, and on Thu morning asked hotel (Soria Moria, reviewed separately) to arrange an English speaking guide and a tuk-tuk driver for the next day (Fri). Then spent rest of Thu walking around Siem Reap to acclimate myself.On Fri morning, guide and driver met me at 9am and off we went. Spent next 5 hours visiting the 3 most popular sites -- Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and Ta Prohm -- in the Angkor Archaeological Park. There are 30 some sites in the Park, but 3 in a day were enough for me. Each are wonderful in their own particular way, and the guide offered excellent insight, history, explanation for each. He also knew best photo spots, and we also talked about Cambodia in general. We saw two parks, then stopped for lunch, and then hit the 3rd park. There was time to see or do more, but I was tired and called it a day around 2:30pm. Had a nice massage in my hotel afterward to unwind.The cost was $15 for the tuk-tuk driver, and $35 for the guide; I paid the hotel (by credit card), and they paid the driver and guide. Another $20 for a one day park pass, and $7 for lunch.It was a great day, and an entirely worthwhile reason to come to this part of the world.
Amazing!. Angkor is a must see in everyone's life. It has so much energy and so much history and you're shocked by its imponent structure as soon as you arrive. Simply incredible.

Truly a treasure of humanity. The park encompasses the world famous temples near Siem Reap. A temple pass is required to access the park, and must be shown for inspection at each archaeological site. Passes are available for 1, 3 or 7 days. We bought 3 day passes for $40 each, which are valid for 7 days. It will take about 3 full days to see everything in the park, so if you're not going as part of a guided tour, it would be best to plan meticulously. The temples are rich in heritage, but it's highly advisable to read up about the temples and culture in advance of your visit to fully appreciate these monuments.Touring the temples can be done with guided tours, which are quite pricey, but at least you will be driven in an air-conditioned car and given water on the way (costs around $65 a day). Those who have done their "homework" before hand and would rather see the temples at their own pace can hire a tuk tuk ($15 a day is pretty reasonable), or even cycle around the park ($1-3 a day), but that is a lot of cycling. Another option it to take the helicopter tour. There are several restaurants in the park, though they are a bit more expensive than what one would normally pay for in Siem Reap.

Spectacular size and grandeur. the temples are amazing and Angkor thom and wat are both huge in size with so much to see. I went back for a second visit and stayed in tuk tuk to view temples from outside and drive around the park..gave another perspective ie missed elephant wall when walking thru but had an awesome view from tuk tuk. A truly unique place that deserves world heritage status

Fascinating. The whole of Angkor Archaeological Park is so huge and houses not just temples but a lot of stories behind it. The large monuments, intricate carvings and amazing architecture made me appreciate this park more. You just seem to be on a different world! We started our day early by witnessing the sunrise at the Angkor Wat. Moving around the area entails a lot of hiking but the views and the experiences, I tell you, are truly unforgettable and worth it.

Fantastic. The Ankgor Archaeological Park is truly spectacular and it would be extremely disappointing to have missed it whilst in Cambodia.There are varying access passes you can purchase - we chose the 3 days pass for $40 each. Well worth it to access all the temples within the Park. Outlying temples such as Beng Mealea (quite a drive away) are not included in the access pass price however are still very cheap to access.Although the larger temples such as Angkor Thom and Angkor Wat are magnificent themselves, some of the smaller temples on the "Grand Circuit" are even more mesmerising and memorable due to the intricate carvings and their natural surroundings taking over proving just how old these man-made wonders really are.

Amazing. We hired a tuk-tuk to take to and around the site and after buying our ticket were shown around by the driver. He took us on a circular tour ending at the Angkor Wat complex. The whole site is amazing and it was good to see that preservation/reconstruction work is still going on at various locations. The were a lot of people around but due to the size of the complex it did not seem crowded. There were plenty of officials about to ask questions and they helped to keep people moving in some of the more restricted access parts. We only bought a day ticket and we felt we had seen enough of the site, given we were tuk-tuk'd between sites.Well organised and signposted, we had a great day, despite a really heavy spell of rain, and we ended up taking the obligatory sunset photo which was superb. Well worth the $20 entrance fee.

Spectacular Temples. The temples were amazing, each one had its own unique style. Very well worth while visiting, but do visit other temples besides Anghor Wat. Buy the 2 day pass which covers 3 days. Crowded, yes, but the temples are spread over a large area and we managed to get away from the crowds. Don't forget the mandatory sunrise photo of Anghor Wat temple. Some good local and cheap restaurants available for lunch stops in the temple area.
An amazing site. It was not very busy when we went and so could wanderLeisurely round sometimes without anyone else whereas I hear at other times it can be too busy
Beautiful. Overcrowded with tourists as expected, but nothing could take my eyes off the majestic temples. The 3 day pass was well worth it for any traveller.
What an amazing place. This is a brilliant place to visit, it is large enough to absorb a lot of visitors and quite crowded at times, but the building is amazing and the views from the top gorgeous.

Every bit as good as the temple. The Angkor old city, which is an ongoing archaeological site, has many, many special areas, gates, buildings, vistas in various states of repair and you can spend longer here than at the temple. Every path and corner leads you to another 'wow' moment and being able to climb and touch these relics of the distant past makes it all the more special. I recommend going with a tour guide who knows the history of this site and can tell you the tales and put it all in context

Two to three days is recommended. We did the area over two days but a further day would have been good to cover most of the temples. We hired a mojo at 15us dollars a day and he took us to the best temples for a two day visit. On the first day we saw the more popular temples and on the second day the more outer temples. Without a guide you are really on your own some of the temples have a small history or photo of how the temple was before restoration so if you are doing it this way prior research is required should you wish to understand it more but is still amazing to see, each temple is vastly different and to see the restoration required is mind boggling. This is a must see world heritage listed site.

Unbelievable experience. I've been wanting to go here and see these temples for years, so for me this was truly a once in a lifetime experience. It was really quite amazing, and much bigger than I expected. There's many different temples in Angkor Park and in the surrounding areas, so be sure to give yourself a few days to see them all. Also, it's extremely humid (we went in Sept) and you'll only want to be out in the mornings or late afternoons, so give yourself time to escape the heat of the midday! You can buy 1,3 or 7 day park tickets, depending on how long you'll be there. You can also rent bicycles, the areas are pretty flat so it's not a grueling ride (except for the humidity) and you'll feel like a local! All these temples were built as religious complexes, and so some places won't let you in without proper dress. For women no exposed shoulders and thighs covered. I actually saw one girl wearing a tank top who couldn't go up to the top of one temple bc she didn't have anything to cover her shoulders with. It is very hot and humid! Make sure to bring a hat and sunscreen!

Green organized Park. The great area within so many temple, the base of ancient capital if khmer and community. Easy for access with your private time, but to learn more about history will nothing smooth without guide or driver. Please be some dress code need, so please ask the information before buying the ticket.

Definitely a must see. The whole complex is full of history and culture. You'll be taking a lot of pictures so make sure all your gadgets are fully charged. Make sure to bring lots of water and extra clothes. It could get really hot and expect to do a lot of walking.

A great few days exploring. The complex is vast. Be sure to explore more than just Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. There are some fantastic temples hidden in the complex. We took a three day ticket, better value than the one day ticket and rode around on bicycles.Bicycle is a fantastic way to explore the park at leisure. Relaxing and free, you can go where you want when you want (we had our own bikes - I'm not drumming up business for bike rental companies!).Save the big two 'til last and it makes for a fantastic three day exploration. There are some great eateries towards Baentey Samre that charge normal prices and not the tourist prices that the food stalls around Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom charge.We were here in the wet season and I would highly recommend. Although the main temples were busy, we were often alone in the other temples which added to the atmospheric feel of the place.

Incredible Scale and Diversity of Temples. This region really should be one of the seven wonders of the world. The incredible scale and comparative closeness of the temples within the Angkor Archeological Park is only rivalled by the pyramid region in Egypt.To have just one temple of the quality of Angkor Wat would be amazing, but when you add all of the other incredible temple complexes as well it makes this region a must visit particularly if you have an interest in ancient culture and religious architecture.

Best in the rainy season!. The entire park is an incredible treasure and truly something awe-inspiring to see up-close and personal. Although the dry season is more popular, I recommend going during the rainy season. There are far fewer tourists, the weather is cooler, and the frequent (but short) rain showers are a welcome break from the heat. Plus, the ruins look so much cooler in the rain and wet! Make sure to bring a sturdy umbrella and tevas, though.

Amazing scale and preservation. The Archeological Park comprises major structures built over 900 years ago - mainly under Hindu influence, but later recognized and accepted by the Buddhists. Cambodia has had many wars with neighbours, WW2 and the Pol Pot civil war, but the Siem Reap region temples were not damaged.In fact, most of those that fell into disrepair were as the result of the Cambodian “system” when new kings shifted the capital city to exert their influence. The Angkor Archeological Park is a UNESCO World Heritage area and comprises various locations and it is impossible to classify all structures equally as each structure has very different individual features.The park is well maintained and we were lucky to avoid the tourist hordes by visiting at the end of the monsoon season. The park is reasonably well developed and kept tidy, without the usual Asian trails of garbage. Built in a “jungle” zone, vegetation growth is prolific, but kept under control by teams of local workers. The park provides employment to thousands of local guides, cleaners, gardeners and traffic control personnel .Whilst it is understandable that Angkor Wat is the jewel in the crown due to its immensity and state of preservation, I personally preferred Ta Prohm as my favourite . It has been partially invaded by the jungle during disuse and used as a backdrop in Indiana Jones and Tomb Raider movies and I felt the energy that others have described. After Ta Prohm, my ratings were Angkor Wat, Banteay Srey, Bayon and Angkor Thom. Whilst it is outside the park a trip to Beng Mealea is well worth the journey. At this temple, its only sin was that a new king moved the capital elsewhere. Despite its magnificence, the jungle is taking over (much more than Ta Prohm).The peace and tranquility we experienced would bring peace and harmony to those with troubled souls – this is a truly a spiritual space.Truly deserving of its “top 7 wonders of the world” status.

World heritage site. It feels like you are in a movie set, but very ancient, intricately carved religious site. You feel the peace of this very large compound of structures. It dwarfs the considerable crowds of tourists. One of the sites has not been cleared of the trees and roots which have overgrown the temples. I liked that one best. The Buddhist monks still watch over the temples and the people still hold ceremonies in them, which makes them more symbolic and sacred somehow than just remnants of a majestic and powerful empire. Lots of walking! Some few "comfort stations" in discrete corners of the 1? square mile. Some shady venues, lots of sun-baked walks to the cool stone temples. The artful carvings on the walls, and the huge statues and the architecture itself are all worth the trip halfway around the world to immerse yourself in this ancient culture. We had a trained guide for our pre-arranged tour, who spoke excellent English and was very personable. He was with us for the three day excursion, which included Siem Reap and vicinity. We were a party of four.

Good site. The park is wonderful. Lots of walking and it's very, very hot. Use a tuk tuk. Angkor Thom was by far the most interesting. The sunrise at Angkor Wat was nothing special and not worth getting up for.Best time of the day to go is late afternoon.

Great site, many options, wear sturdy shoes!. When you arrive in Siem Reap you will be bombarded with options of how to see the park. We chose a tuk tuk and both agreed that it was the best choice. If you want comfort and luxury then go with a air conditioned taxi but you'll sweat when your outside anyway, so just have some fun. Almost every hotel will have tuk tuk driver available or you can book one very simply in the town. If you are going for that option make sure you negotiate and pick one that speaks good English. Ask them about the site, what they would show you and how much they can teach. Don't forget to smile and see if they are fun as well, the interaction with your driver is a big part so pick a good one. Quick word of warning, if you are crossing by land from Thailand at the Poipet border be ready to ne scammed, we had 5 attempts to make us over pay for our visa, do not buy one until after you have your exit stamp from Thailand, no matter what they tell you. There are some good posts in forums on trip advisor about the scams.Anywho, the sites are amazing, you can pick a 1, 3 or 5 day ticket. The tickets are valid for 24 hrs from 5pm so if you want to see sunset you can go the day before and then catch sunrise the following day, you will also avoid queuing for you ticket in the morning if you get it the day before. If you are into your temples then go for a 3 or 5 day pass otherwise you will see most of the main sites with a 1 day but, beware, it is hard work. I consider myself above average fitness but after 5 hours I was pretty tired. The temples are a must see, a particular favourite of mine was Ta Promh, but I think that is most peoples favourite. Be aware that you will have guide try to sell you their services, you can buy one for the day or just temple by temple. We had one for the Angkor Wat and would highly recommend it as they point out a lot of stuff that you would not realise on your own, like how the bases of the pillars have been worn away due to years being covered in a lot of bat poo! If you don't want a guide be firm as they are quite tricky and good at selling themselves! Finally look our for the kids. There are a lot of kids trying to sell stuff using all kinds of techniques. As with any major tourist site scams are there. Personally I don't give to kids as I believe it encourages the behaviour and their parents are even less likely to send them to school if they are making money but everyone should make a decision by themselves. Above all, wear sturdy clothes, put your Indiana Jones hat on and enjoy this mystical site with the little spark of hope in the back of your mind that there are more sites like this in the world, waiting, covered in jungle for us to find them.

Angor Watt Archeological Park. Opps. I must have mis-keyed the survey. My wife and I were in SE asia for three months. We made our own way to Seim Reap and stay 7 days and would have stayed longer but for the hotel we were in could not extend our. The park is wonderful. A lot of walking and heat, but inspiring. The Seim Reap museum is also worth the stop for its historical perspective. We did 4 days in the park areas some of which are quite a distance from Angor Watt central. There was a standard tuk tuk tour that $30 a day that we took for 3 days and saw the most important sites. We were on foot being taken from the site locations and loved the having our own pace to explore. We had no problems of any kind on our their. The food was great, the people pleasant, the hotels very nice. We also did alot of bird watching.Sorry for the error in my review. I tell everyone it is a must do trip to Seim Reap and don't stay to short a time. Let me know if you have other specific questions.

Peace and tranquility. Walking through the temples, or through the wooded forests was a wonderful experience. Very peaceful - with array of different sights, sounds and smells. We could have spent weeks doing this without ever becoming bored. An experience that MUST be explored by anyone who is lucky enough to get the chance

The reason for visiting Siem Reap. I can't imagine visiting Siem Reap at not viewing the temples at the archaeological park. They are an awesome experience which tells you much about the Khemer heritage and the ingenuity of ancient societies.Passes are $20 for a single day; $40 for three days; and $60 for seven days. If you only visit for two days, the three day pass is the way to go rather than wasting time standing in the pass line for two consecutive days for the same price.A standard rate for a tuk-tuk for the day including cold water & towels is $15. Add $5 if going to Bantreay Srei or a sunrise or sunset temple trip. Of course, those can be negotiated. To get the full experience and views, we took a tuk-tuk to Bantreay Srei and thoroughly enjoyed the countryside and natural air conditioning along the way. Cars are also available for around $25 per day.Our first day we went with a guide while the second day we spiked out on our own with a guidebook sold at most of the temples for a negotiated $5. We found the guided portion rather tedious with so much minutiae that we quickly became bored and found it difficult to sift through the information distinguishing the characteristics of each temple. Typically, a guide will cost you $25 per day.With the guidebook, we could linger at our own pace and focus on the nuts & bolts of each temple, quickly referencing and keeping them separated easily in our minds for comparative purposes. For a more extensive reference we turned to Maurice Glaize's 1944 classic, "The Monuments of Angkor Guide", which remains the bible of Angkor temples. This can be downloaded free from canbypublications.com onto a tablet for portable reference. This website also has excellent suggested itineraries depending on days spent, suggested times at each temple and descriptions.Exploration can become overwhelming as the day heats up so wear comfortable, appropriate shoes, hydrate frequently, and shield yourself from the sun (a travel umbrella works great). If you have time, break viewing into half days during the morning starting early leaving the afternoons open for relaxation or pool time. It's amazing what you can see in one morning, you often avoid crowds, and you certainly avoid "temple burnout".The Angkor temple sites are a world treasure. Don't miss them.

Shoot while you walk. needed 3 days to conquer all the temples(3 days pass recommended). A lot of walking, bring water with you if possible cause you'll be walking under the hot sun all day long but the views are worth it!

An amazing area. This is an amaziing area and we had only 2 days to see it. It is an extremely large area and one needs to use transport to see it all. There is so much to see and it was crowded even though it is not high season yet.We were on an organised group tour(30 of us) so we are ferried by bus to a main area then transferred to a mini-bus. Our guide tries to explain to all of us the details behind it all but it is quite a task as everyone has different needs or interests.Also doing 2 days meant we had to stop to be photographed and get our passes for each day.If I was doing this trip independently I would try for a 3 day pass($USD50 I think) whilst 2 day pass is $USD20 each day) and have the hotel arrange a tuk tuk for you for the 3 days for a set price. We heard prices of $USD35 - $USD50 for them to be your driver.If you have a book, map, camera etc, you can identify a lot of what you see yourself and set your own schedule.If it looks like rain one can go back to hotel or lunch is near go back towards town. It is your own schedule and as such you can see what you wish to see.Yes, it is hot so plenty of water. If it raisn then the heat afterwards is horrendous.Did not notice any flies or midges.It is an amazing place and worth every minute you have to see it. There are good maps to be found at hotels etc which provide you with all the sites.Note the ballon ride is a tethered ride these days for safety reasons.

My life best experience. It is incredible.. I am speechless to give a review about Angkor temples, but it is totally worth it to have the three day pass and try to do the most temples as you can since they are all different, if you like architecture give it a try, because it get to be exhausting but it is a life experience with all the kids around begging for money, thats the sad part but besides that experience cambodia is a most temple visit!

Dream Come True..!! Must See Place for Temple Architechture Lovers..!!. I can now understand, why a million tourists from all over the world come to this small place...the beautiful temple, and its pleasent village, Extrodinary experience.I dreamed about visiting this place, and i did...finally..!!

Unforgetable World Heritage Experience. My family visited Angkor Wat Archaeological Park in September for two and a half day using the three day pass. Buying the pass on the first day late afternoon was a blessing as when we returned the second day's morning, there were long lines of people from tour groups and independent travelers buying ticket. Come prepared with enough US $1, $5, and $10 bills. You will encounter lots of women and children selling souvenirs, elephant print pants, drinks, meals, post cards, books, etc. And you will hear "What your name?", "Where you from", and "Buy from me" a lot within the park. They are poor and one sympathizes with them. But after a while, it can be annoying. Best is to put on a smile and firmly say "No, thank you" and move on.A very helpful guide is "Siem Reap Angkor Visitors Guide" published by Canby Publications (canbypublications.com). It is free and if you can get hold of one ahead of your visit or from your hotel after arrival, it would provide invaluable information on the park and its many temple ruins. The second full day, we biked from our hotel to the park and visited the main temple ruins within the small tour circuit (which includes Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm). It was a fun day to bike around the park. We watched the sunset over Angkor Wat and biked back to our hotel in the dark. The third full day, we hired a tut-tut to take us to far away Banteay Srey and also the temple ruins along the grand tour circuit. We concluded that Banteay Srey is overrated and not worth the one hour to get there and another 30 to 40 minutes to get back to the eastern portion of the park. Banteay Srey is really small. While the carved stone work is what this temple is known for, we felt the time would have been better spent to re-visit Bayon and/or Ta Prohm. There are some hidden gems along the Grand Circuit, particularly Preah Khan.If you are on your own, suggest visiting the main temple ruins such as Bayon and Ta Phrom early in the morning (6 to 8 am) or in the afternoon. From 9 am to 12 noon, tour groups just overwhelme these places.

History at your fingertips!. A well-priced historical experience that even my 13 year old enjoyed! Not too crowded at this time of year (October) and the administrators are fast and efficient at providing the required ticketing $40 for a 3 day pass. Read up beforehand and take a guidebook or google as you go - amazing photo opportunities - be quick before it all falls apart! Simply incredible structures to which you have almost complete access - a wonderful experience indeed.

One of the wonders of the world. This park is huge, it is impossible to visit everything. They were very organized in the ticket's booths, so it was very quickly to buy the tickets and start exploring the temples.
Highly recommended. Crowds can be pretty large but this attraction is very well organized, the the crowds are herded through seamlessly. . Truly one of the wonders of the world.
Steeped in History. Recommend getting a local guide as it is huge and the local guides are really knowledgeable. Do it over a few days as so much to take in and see

Lots to see and do. many temples in the complex with a good price to discover the area over a few days - $40pp for 3 days entry. You can book tours with hotels and guides or take a tuk-tuk and wander about the complex yourself, returning to your tuk-tuk between temples. There are elephants available for rides which I heard were $20pp however I am not sure. A definite must whilst in Siem Reap and Cambodia.

Unmissable if you're in Cambodia!. It's all been said in other reviews and books on the amazing Angkor Archaeological Park. A 3 day ($40) or week long pass ($60) is the way to go. A day pass is $20, so it will cost the same if you want 4 day or 7 day access.The 3 day pass can be used on any day within a 7 day period, so I'd recommend having a day visiting temples followed by a day relaxing, if you have the time. It gets so hot that you'll most likely be perspiring somewhat(!), so drink plenty of water along the way. We did 3 days in a row in and out of the tuk tuk and were tired out for a few days afterwards.A great experience not to be missed, so make sure you take spare camera batteries, as you may find that one is not enough to last a full day!

Iconic. We decided to take in the sunset visit via tuk-tuk followed by the small circuit via mountain bike the following day and feel we made a good choice. Although there was no sunset, the atmosphere at twilight was good and we still got some good photos as the light faded.We then set off at 5.30 the next morning to beat the crowds - a great decision. We went straight to Ta Prohm, arriving around 6.15am and were the only two there! It was incredible. Then to the rest which were just as incredible and iconic. By no means did we rush but by mid afternoon, we were content with our visit and didn't have to fight the crowds etc so we would recommend this way of doing it!

Will leave you breathless (literally). This park is HUGE! So negotiate with your tour guide/driver beforehand (whether you want to see the little circle, big circle, or the entire thing). If you are not in great shape, please don't try to climb the stairs as most of them are steep and some don't have rails. Try your best to come early because the heat can be unforgiving. I didn't bother to get a tour guide, I simply read about it before the trip. Nonetheless, tour guides are relatively cheap. Please note that most of the temples are having reconstruction/restoration work, therefore not all of them are accessible to tourists.Please bring a raincoat or umbrella esp if you're travelling during the rainy season. Also don't forget the bottled water. As expected, toilets are far from the temple and had some queue so brace yourself for that.Overall,I wasn't disappointed. This place is worth all the climbing up and down the stairs. The only thing that disappointed me were the tourists who were noisy and not observing proper dress code :(

Awesome, but over-priced. Angkor AP is really really awesome and a must see if you are in Cambodia.But it's ridiculously expensive for Cambodia and it's not clear at all were all that money goes. Staff is unfriendly, everything inside the park is expensive.There are comparable sights around the world (in countries that are more expensive and/or developed) that are free or cheaper. If they would use the money and offer free lunch, a picture or guide it'd be more fair.

What We Came to See. The park is the location of all the old Angkor Temples that we came to Seam Reap to see and marvel at. Totally worth the whole trip! Some temple complexes are must sees. And some are merely miniatures of the larger temples. So one must study guide books and read about this on-line to know what are must-sees and which can be skipped.

This is the place to see. The park encompasses all the wonderful temples and you need a pass to get in which is usually included in your tour. You can get a day pass and get a ride in with a tuk tuk but you have to negotiate a price for the trip there and back from Siem Reap.

Truly spectacular experience. Loved everything. Take your time and enjoy it all. Nowhere else on earth like it. Make sure you get the book on the complexes - can't remember the name but has a brown cover. Read up before you go, and pick the temples you really want to see. Some you really don't need to visit as they are quite similar.

Utterly brilliant - don't just do Angkor Wat!. The Angkor Archaeological Park is an amazing place to visit and imagine what the ancient civilisation must have been like all those centuries ago. The most well known temple is naturally Angkor Wat, however exploring the rest of the park was the highlight of my visit. A really good way to do this is by bicycle - we hired some from town ($1 for the day) and rode out to the park, a fairly easy and flat 7km which was very doable. We bought the 3 day pass for $40USD which was a wise choice as there's loads to see and one day wouldn't do it justice. We also did the morning sunrise trip out to see Angkor Wat which was cool (and also entertaining watching the masses of tourists). Our tuk tuk driver drove us around for the rest of the day, another good way to see the park if your legs are a bit tired!

One of the greatest attractions on earth. All credit to all the organisations involved in the restoration / preservation and the documentation of this vast archaeological site. There are pre-planned tours that all the tuk-tuk & taxi drivers are trained in and you can make your own modifications however you like. You can start before sunrise and end with a sunset if you wish or just go for a portion of the day.You will be captivated, enchanted even and you will stay longer than you planned.Unless you do not have the time, a one day pass ($20) is not enough, a 3 day pass ($40) will be a wiser investment.The Tuk Tuk for the whole day will be $10 to $15 depending on the distance covered in your tours. Some drivers will have a complimentary cold bottle of water waiting for you at the end maybe even a cool refresher towel. Some drivers may have limited language skills but plenty of genuine enthusiasm and a map of the park. When planning with your driver to go to lunch, let him know your budget, otherwise he will naturally take you to a restaurant that maybe higher priced than you had budgeted.A trip to the National Museum is highly recommended (with audio guide $15) better before you tour the temples but not necessarily essential.

wonderful!. You absolutely have to go there! Don't miss anything. Just look for the good price for your tuk tuk because the're rising the price very fast! With bicycle is a little far but you can do it if you have enough days.

amazing temple a must see. Another temple visited on 8/9 ,Amazing attraction the trees and architecture is not to be miss when you are in siem reap.It was raining heavily when we arrived as now is the raining season.Pls bring along an umbrella and a good hat as the sun is very hot when it is not raining.Bring a bottle of water along.

Well preserved!. Let's face it. Your in Siem Reap for this. Totally it's a must see in Siem Reap. The temples are all well preserved and the architecture is just simply amazing. Head off around 0500 for the sunrise. Admission is USD 20 for a 1 day pass to see the temples. You can engage a tuktuk driver for around USD 12-20, depending how far and how long you wanna see. You can also cycle but it will definitely be a long ride. Remember to bring drinking bottle and some insect repellent!

Highlight of my life. If you are traveling anywhere within a 1000 mile radius of Angkor Wat, do everything in your power to stop in Siem Reap for at least one full day to explore this one-of-a-kind complex of massive ancient temples set within a jungle of vegetation and wildlife. Nowhere else will you be able to walk on, in, and through such well-preserved ancient spaces with starkly intricate architectural detail and beautiful natural integration as trees have spent centuries reclaiming the area, growing around and atop many of these structures. Bring multiple bottles of water, and expect to drench your clothes with sweat, but do NOT let that stop you from this real-world "Indiana Jones" adventure!
Amazing!. Definitely worth for a visit! The surrounding is beautiful & well preserved. Remember to bring along a cold towel & bottle of water. Expect some walking while visiting here.

Iconic. Angkor Wat is iconic and marvelous. Recommend a visit to the National Museum on Charles De Gaulle Drive in Siem Reap first, as it explains the history and relevance of the structure and puts all the sites into some perspective. Only down side is the number of tourists!! But while I found this site beautiful and intriguing, the best site I think is Beng Melea, about a 2 hour drive east of Siem Reap. This is an evocative site, a ruin unreconstructed, and thought to be the temple that Angkor Wat was based on. Several friends we took around the sites agreed it was the most interesting. Combine it with a visit to Koh Ker, the countryside is beautiful, people beautiful, there is a toilet at Koh Ker and food available. Our guide took us to a restaurant in a little village near Beng Melea and we had a great lunch. Well worth a look.

No Brainer. Of course you have come to Siem Reap to see Angkor Wat and it lives up to the excitment. Just bring lots of water and patience for dealing with the heat and people selling you things everywhere you turn.

Beyond what I imagined. Now I know why so many people flock to Angkor Wat. Even after reading and seeing hundreds of photos of the area I still could not imagine the space and the history you can witness by visiting this site. Definitely worth the effort to get there.

Huge and impressive. I decided to spend 3 days/4 night in Siem Reap in order to visit all the main temples within Angkor Archaeological Park and it was really worth it! Apart from Angor Wat (which is great) I didn't know what to expect for and I've been very surprised by the amazing fascinating atmosphere that you can feel there. Although there are so many temples and at the end of the 3rd day you can start thinking "one more temple", all temples are very different. All of them are in good shape, the maintenance is perfect and in general the staff preserve and takes care of the area in a perfect way. Also the less famous temples are very fascinating, with vegetation growing on the ruins (but being kept under control) adding charm to the place. I only recommend to avoid the elephant ride and the sunset: too crowded and frankly speaking not much to see, not worth the long wait, the effort to climb the hill/temple and the crowd.

Worth the explore. Exploring the park can be done in many ways (big route, small route, combine etc) provided you can get a driver to bring you around and agree on a price prior to the trip. Start at sunrise as it is still cool and if you're lucky, you'll catch a lovely show of lights. There are many temples to explore. They may seem similar but on closer look, each carries their own specialty. It's amazing how "ancient" civilization are able to built such structures. I enjoy going around in a tuktuk but if you're fit, a bicycle is also enjoyable during the cooler months
Excellent place to visit.. Take your time in seeing this wonderful wonders of world.Start early in the morning, it gets very hot during the day, wear comfortable shoes and take plenty of water.

Incredible Experience. The temples of Angkor are truly amazing. Preserved well and worth days of exploring. Many are very different, so it is easy to spend a lot of time exploring. We visited for three days and loved it. One of the highlights of a several week trip to Southeast Asia.

Simply Spectacular. Trekking across the temples of Angkor is worthwhile. I am lucky to have seen the greatness of Khmer civilization. You will definetely be mesmerized by how the ancient Cambodians have perfectly built and carved their temples without sophisticated tools. Learning their history is such a remarkable experience.

Impressive. A whole week touring dozens of temples. Only the accessible ones... what a pity. Bycicle, trekking, tuk-tuk... you choose. The worst, the crowds in those included in tour visits. The best... just cycle a few km and lose yourself in the magic of all the rest.

Awesome World Heritage Site. The park entrance is located 3 km from Siem Reap. The park consists of Angkor Wat, the ancient city of Angkor Thom and various other temple ruins of the angkorian era. With the exception of the Roulous group which is 13km east of Siem Reap, the most important temple ruins are within 6-25 km north of the town. To visit the park, you need to purchase an admission pass either sold for 1 day (US20), 3 days (US60) valid for a week or seven days (US60) valid for a month. Visiting hours are from 5 am to 6 pm. Always carry your ticket with you at all times as it is checked before you are allowed into the temples. Wear light airy clothing as it will be hot. Bring an umbrella or a raincoat in the rainy season. Prepare to walk a lot through uneven passages and loads of steps so ensure proper footwear is worn. Bring along lots of water, mosquito repellent and sunscreen. Don't forget your camera and take lots of photos. Take you time to enjoy this awesome world heritage site!

Great place!. Absolutely gorgeous! A must see! My husband and I really enjoyed wandering around the temples. It did get a bit tiring fending off all the hawkers but they were nice. We had a lot of kids come up to us and ask for money for school. We handed over a couple bucks to the first few but ended up feeling a bit overwhelmed after the fifth or sixth.

A MUST. The temples are amazing! I thoroughly enjoyed our three days in the park. Would suggest that you put a mix of temples in to your tour/days. we did Angkor, Bayon, Ta Prohm, Banteay Srei - the difference is subtle but amazing. we got to the temples early and it was the wet season but it made it less crowded and the colour of the moss against the stone work was so brilliant

Amazing. Angkor Wat was our first stop and from a distance the temple looked huge with the moat all around. With a tranquil ambience, the setting was perfect, a place fit to reflect on life or anything..We had taken a 3 day pass, as we wanted to see the place at a slow pace. This temple was originally dedicated to 'Vishnu' , but now one will find shrines of the Buddha inside. Don't miss the huge bas reliefs showing the 'churning of the ocean' and also the beautiful apsara carvings. Its very different from the hindu temples in India, but the place had a great calming influence on us. For the children and elderly people, the sight seeming may be a little tedious as one has to walk a lot and climb a lot of steps. My six year old daughter was tired by end of day one. Luckily we had travelled during the lean season, so the place was less crowded and the weather was less humid, with the occasional rains.

WHAT?. Absolutely stunning. How these guys had the fortitude and persistence to carry out such large project like this in those days and in proportion is a wonder in itself. We could take a leaf out of their book

Wow!. Breathtaking! This visit was one of my favorite stops. We had the amazing chance to ride bikes around the park and that also made this extra special. It truly is a priceless experience and something you have to see if visiting South East Asia.

YOU NEED TO SEE IT TO APPRECIATE IT. When you see this all you will say is "how on earth did they build it 1,000 years ago ?" See it for yourself you will be flabergasted.we went in the wet season ( luckily it did not rain) so we did not have to fight the crowds. We saw photos in the "high" season and it was packed light an AFL footy final.

Be amazed. Must visit here! For 20$ in a day you can be taken to a world of amazement. The park consists of so many temples and better buy a ticket good for 3-5 days. Will only cost 40$ (3days), 60$ (5days). I cannot say much because i was so stunned with the stones and how they came to be a temple. See it for yourself. A must visit place!

World heritage, a must-see in a lifetime!. A Must See. Take a 3 day pass ($40). A 3 day tour can cover most all temples but not enough to soak it all in(1-2 hours per temple). Be prepared for hours of walking, very steep climbs, humid weather. Best to come late July to September when tourists are few (a misnomer). Best to bring:lanyard IDs to keep the pass handy for inspection (they're truly strict) & to flash for free use of the toilets, comfortable walking shoes, a hat , a shawl or bandana (to shield from the sun or pass temple guards--shorts or bare shoulders are not allowed in the temples, guards require them wrapped up), cold towels, singles or small denomination US$. No need to change to local riel. Not to miss: Angkor Wat, Bayon, the elephant ride uphill to Phnom Backeng. Small item souvenirs are cheapest from peddlers near the site. Try the local ice fruit popsicle (2 for $1), good & refreshing.

Breathtaking. You go to Siem reap to see this. It is beautiful and the pictures often dont do the grandeur of some of these temples justice. Loved them and would go back to see it again if I make it to this part of the world!
Amazing. If you are in Siem Reap you will see this. If you are wondering if it is worth going to Siem Reap to see this? It absolutely is.
Tour. Amazing temple. Very hot day would advise take an umbrella for sun shade. Long walks up and down stairs and ramps. Took 4 hours to do the tour
Breath taking beyond measure. Liked everything, a lot of high stairs with very steep incline that made my wife a bit nervous but easily travelled in the end.

Must see!. A trip to Siem Reap is not complete without a visit! We were supposed to see it at sunset but had to change plans at the last minute, so we saw it at sunset instead and I don't know how the sunrise could possibly have been more beautiful! Wonderful!

A must-see place. A privilege to visit (but a bit sad our guide told us this magnificent 400 square kilometre Cambodian asset with its temple crown jewels and lucrative tourist profits is owned by a private company!!!!)This being said just about everything you go to SIem Reap for is within the Angkor Archaeological Park - Ankor Wat, Ta Prohm, the Bayon etc should all be subtitled under this main heading....Regardless of who owns it and gets the profits, Ankor Archaeological Park is truly one of the most incredible places one earth and, if you have the opportunity to visit, you will not regret the chance to measure life in terms of travel, history, culture, more history, fresh air, delicious food, photo opportunities, and general charm of people and environs

I love the trees which show how strong life is. You can see the historical temple and huge trees grow from seed in the wall of the temple Wonderful thing is the grow of tree can break the stone wall into piece .

You should see one time in your life!. The Angkor Archeological Park is one of the most important historical park in the world, very big with a lot of temples, ruines and beautiful attractions.Main info: park opens at 5.00 a.m. and closes at 6.00 p.m. Some temple closes at 5.00 p.m (Benteay Srei).Three different tickets: one day, three days and one week respectly 20 USD, 40 USD, 60 USD.Park is located 6 km north to Siem Reap.The area is big and the visit can be done only by tuk tuk (not bicycle due to the hot temperature).You can take a tuk tuk with driver (better in your hotel or in Siem Reap) and turn inside the main area in the park. Tipically one day costs 15 USD for the central area of the park (Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and the main temple in this area).If you want to visit Benteay Srei (at least 30 km far Angkor Wat) you have to add at least 15 USD more to reach the temple.An idea of visit could be (in order of importance):Day 1: Angkor Wat (4 hours) - Ta Prohm (2,5 hours) - Benteay Kdei (1 hour) - Ta Keo (1 hour) - Phnom Bakheng (or Preah Khan) (1,5 hours)Day 2: Benteay Srei (2,5 hours included travel) - Kbal Spean (2 hours) (entrance 5 Km far from Benteay Srei, 1.5 Km beatiful walk in the jungle) - Angkor Thom (4 hours)Day 3: Roulos Group (Bakong) far 15 km from Siem Reap and the other remaining sites.In all entrance of the main temple there are local food and beverage. Inside Angkor Thom area there is a restaurant.Sunrise in Angkor Wat is wonderful (5.30 a.m.), sunset in Phnom Bakheng depends of the season (nothing special in August).During all day the temperature is high and with big humidity, so take with you fresh water and an hat.Minimum two days, better three days to visit Angkor Archeological Park.

Amazing complex....a historical landmark indeed.... I was certainly amazed by the richness and historical setting of this huge archaelogical park..So many temples and details to see...so many walks involved as well :D...I managed to arrange my visit with a tuk-tuk driver and got myself a guide book to get all the details regarding the temples, the bas-relief and its amazing history..As I only have one day, time management is the key...plus, I made my priorities to see main temples..I started early in the morning at 5am to catch sunrise in Angkor Wat..after that, around 7, I strolled around the main temples to see the relief...then moved to Bayon Temple, Angkor Thom, Ta Phrom and Banteay Srei...I guessed I managed to visit some small temples as well but forgot the names..Get yourself a map, list of places to visit, and a good guide book if you travel alone...during my visit in March, it was very hot so better be prepared and make sure you are dressed properly with comfy shoes...Make sure you know here you're going, so you won't wast your precious time...drink plenty of water and travel light...I also got a lovely lunch near the Try as well to take a different route from the tourist ones...you'll get stuck on the way and flocks of people will gather in the same place...

Well kept.. This is what is attracting tourists world over to Siem Reap! Its well kept and has more or less all the ruins within this. Costs 20$ a day and 40$ for 3days....they have a price for a week as well.

Grand Angkor. What a wonderful site to see and visit. very long and hot day visiting the various sites but well worth it. Next time will go without a guide and just wander at leisure and just absorb the grandeur of it all.

Amazing history!. The Angkor Park is huge and a wonderful experience. We travelled by TukTuk all through the park. We used a three day pass and spent a day throughout the outskirts of the park and the smaller temples, a day at the main Angkor Wat Temple and a day exploring Angkor Thom. If you like temples and see the beauty in them, you can spend hours exploring.

Amazing to say the least. If you are a real history buff I'd say you need more than one day to explore the area. There is a lot of steep steps and walking involved. We did a 5 hour adventure and looked at the main attractions. We were very tired at the end of the day but well worth it.

Plan on at LEAST 3 days..... At least plan on 3 days to see the major attractions. Wear LOTS of insect repellent. Plan on it being VERY hot. Take water. Wear sensible clothing that breathes well. Shorts are a must. With the steps of these temples, sandals might be inappropriate. Please be respectful of the grounds and dispose of trash appropriately. This is not only a Cambodian treasure, but a world treasure.

It was much larger than I thought. What I didn't know was that the entire Angkor Archaeological Park used to be a city (Angkor itself means city). I was so used to thinking that it's mainly the temple Angkor Wat. It's not. There are so many other interesting temples to see. I recommend Ta Prohm and Angkor Thom. It's a really huge complex of temples. Definitely worth visiting! I recommend getting a tour guide to have a better understanding of the temples.

Amazing experience. You have no idea how beautiful this place is until you see it with your own eyes. Make sure that you have a guide that knows their way around, and you will be treated with some amazing scenery.

Must go!. How can anyone go to Siem Reap without visiting the Angkor temples? It would be best to head there when it is still dark, and catch the sunrise at Angkor Wat before moving ahead of the crowd by going to the rest of the temples first instead of starting at Angkor Wat. Starting early also means the air would be cool and the sun is not so strong. 1 day was more than enough for us as it was really quite tiring after all the walking and climbing.

Beautiful temples. If you're visiting SR, you're most likely going to check out 1 of the temples at Angkor Park. One needs 3 days to see the major attractions/temple of the park. Tips:- Respect the place. Dress appropriately. - A lot of walking and climbing in the sun. Sun lotion, hat, shades, and god shoes. - Appreciate the architecture and in my view, don't go crazy on the photos.

Great, but one day was plenty. It was an enjoyable day and definitely a "must see." Something to think about -- whether to purchase a one, three, or seven day pass. We've been SEA for two and a half months and are "templed" out! So despite being told that we really need several days to see the temples, we opted for the one day pass. This was great for us -- we did the little circuit and saw some of the "different" temples -- most are looking all alike to us at this point. We had a full day 8 am to 6 pm and all agreed it was great, but that one day was enough for us. My suggestion is that if you love temples buy the three or seven day pass, if not opt for the one day. There's other neat things in Siem Reap -- try the Silk Farm for something different!

Waauw simply amazing and unique Khmer art. Angkor was on our long list of UNESCO sites to visit since a long time, and it did not disappoint. It is huge, amazing, beautiful, enchanting, and yes a reason to plan a vacation to southeast Asia around your Angkor trip.The archeological site is large, 400 km2 = 20x20km an that’s just the main site. We rented bikes for 3 days and that’s probably the best way to get around at your own rhythm. The temple remains are all in a different state of restoration. Some are still somewhat untouched (trees growing out of each stone), others give a good impression of how it must have been 1100 years ago.The Bayon Temple impressed us most, we went back 2 times.You need 3 days to really get the experience.

Put it on your bucket list. This place is gorgeous and awe-inspiring! Once you get past the sellers, many of whom are your children unfortunately, it is a really enjoyable experience. Our time in Siem Reap was limited so we did just the main temples. Angor Wat at sunrise was just beautiful, I got some nice shots here.

Tourism overload. Its a shame but the whole ambiance of the Angkor Park has worsened significantly over the past few years as numbers grow and money becomes the driving force.Too many police demanding passports and tickets in every small temple and remote road, too many trinket sellers who just won't take no for an answer. Just too many tourists who are managed like huge herds of cattle.Too many "massage" parlours in prominent places.Where is all the money going?

Amazing!. It's a must to visit while in Siem Reap! You cannot believe the scale and size of these stunning temples! Just beware of quite a few sellers! Quite a few young children which I found a little upsetting

Few quick notes. Nothing can be said in addition to define how beautiful, impressive, gorgeous is Angkor Wat.Just a few easy notes.This was my second visit, first was in dec 2005 (now it's August 2013).First time I had only 1 day, but you definitely need 2 (if you have special interest maybe more).I stayed in Siem Reap, in the city. Means you need a car or a tuk tuk as the archeological area is out. Nevertheless, if you go closer you may have more troubles to find the right accomodation. My (in 2005) was a nightmare.First day to visit Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohn (jungle temple). Means a full day and around 20usd for tuk tuk.But the real surprise comes in day 2, when you will visit other temples supposed to be minor but equally beautiful, big and impressive.These are out of the main group, so you will ride many kms and spend some time in the tuk tuk, but it deserves your efforts and the 15 dollars.Entrance fee is 20usd for 1 day, 40 for up to 3 days.There are a couple of check points to enter the most religious spots: visitors with short pants or uncovered shoulders won't be admitted.
Feeling unwind. We do cycling over the Angkor Archeological Park and we could see the Cambodian daily life and feeling relaxed with fresh air.
Must-do. This is the reason why people go to Siem Reap! This was well worth the visit! Highly recommend it. Beware of tourist crowds and watch your belongings.

Temples..historical places. covered very very large areas...ANGKOR WAT in it...need 2 full days to really explore...need a tuk tuk to transport around bcoz by foot will slow down ..too large the wwhole area..
Bila anda senang mengunjungi candi anda akan terpuaskan disini. It is not enough in a day you can visit all the temples here, if it is a hot day in addition to the many visitors who make a very rowdy

Tour Groups at Sunrise. What's not to like about the temples and Angkor Wat is the largest. Like many others, we went early in the morning to see the temple reflections in the moat at sunrise. Incredibly selfish tour groups from China and Korea had taken over the waterfront and stayed in situ until the sun had fully risen, giving no opportunity for anyone standing behind them to take photos. Thanks to the tall and beautiful American girl who saw how many people I asked if I may step in for a second for one photo, yet refused me. She allowed me in. Thanks so much.

Magical Place. Angkor Wat temples affected me in such a way that I went back the second time and it affected me again in such a way that I am going back again. This is a once in a lifetime visit you can do, your thing to do in your bucket list. Magical place with all kinds of energy. If you are young and love magic, get a 3 day or 7 day ticket..you will not have enough time to see it all in one day. It took me two years! And two trips and more trips are coming! It is worth going to Cambodia for just this..

Not all the temples are equally interesting. Don´t misunderstand me, but in my opnion is not necessary to visit all the temples... i mean, you don´t need 3 days for visiting the park. Ta Phrom, bayon and Angkor Wat are really interesting... perhas some 2 or 3 temples more are also interesting, but after you have seen 8 temples it becomes boring. I would say 2 days is enough.

Amazing Angkor. Beautiful place, a must see!Loved the fact that you can really get in there and explore the ruins. Some are better than others. The only issue is the amount of tourists but that's sight seeing for you.

Very touristy, but worth your visit.. Words come short if you are in Angkor. In my title i said touristy; of course. One of the most beautiful sites in THE world is touristy. But when you take time you can take a lot of pictures without à tourist.

Why is this a must see?. Taking a 8 hour bus from Bangkok, staying one day and taking the 8 hour bus back, going through 2 hours of fan only hassle filled customs border crossing into Cambodia followed by little girls who I can only presume should have been in school nagging you to death to buy a postcard "If you buy one, I'll leave you alone" to my response "Honey, I've got hours of patience, do you have hours of time"? left me with the feeling that Angkor Wat and the area just wasn't worth the trouble. If you're just looking for places to check off your list, go see it. If not, steer clear. It's a tourist trap and perhaps funding corruptions seeing as only about 25% or so of ticket sales actually goes back into funding Angkor Wat (most funding comes stupidly from foreign governments) which makes you wonder... where is that other 75% going??
Absolutely essential!. Awesome place that needs three days ticket. Except for the 'big tour', a little bit far from Siem Reap, the best option for visiting the temples is by bicycle.

Must see! Amazing! Breath taking!. A must see, cannot describe the feeling being there. As much annoying as it was to pay $20pp to enter it was worth every penny of it.
It's just hart to imagine how much time has passed by and how powerful is the mother nature claiming it all back. A truly amazing sight.
Great place and impressive!. Is a must in Siem Reap! The place is amazing and huge you need to walk all around it and look at the walls inside the temple!

A step into ancient time. If you are looking for Angelina Jolie, you wont find her but you can imagine...
The worst thing was the temperature. It's hot and humid and requires drinking water all the time.
Needs a few days. There is so much to see here. Read up beforehand and then be prepared to be blown away by the history, architecture and culture!

Breathtaking. A day's visit is not enough to see it all - but the breathtaking architecture and carved murals are without a doubt part of the Great Wonders of Asia. Pity the French colonists had to destroy so many of the murals . . .
Just brilliant. As an architecture and history buff the temples just blew me away, it was as awe inspiring as the pyramids in Egypt.

A must see!. We got up for sunrise which was amazing. The park is well thought out but very expensive. We managed to see 11 temples in 7 hours! Some of the temples have got stairways that are so steep you are crawling on your hands and knees to get up! We got a guide and a tuk tuk driver which are a must if you want to get round as many temples as you can!
The reason people visit Siem Reap. Impossible to come to Siem Reap and not see Angkor Archaeological Park. The park is so much more than just Angkor Wat.

Such an amazing place. So happy we put Siem Reap and the Angkor temples on our itinerary. It's such an amazing place. I have wonderful photos and memories from our days there but words cannot describe unless you see it yourself. We visited in July and would go to the park as early as possible to avoid the reported crowds and the heat/rain.

Beautiful temples. We started off at Angkor Wat at sunrise and spent just under 2 hours there, we then got food outside which was cheap and tasty. We asked our driver where everyone else typically went after Angkor Wat and asked him to take us in the opposite direction to miss the crowds of people, it worked and we had a lot of the temples to ourselves until we got to Bayon which was over run with tourists but still beautiful.
A must see..... Favs are Bayon and Ta Prohm. Angkor Wat is okay but very, very crowded. Take water and possibly umbrella or hat for shade. Food on site but not very good.

Do not be afraid to take the little ones. We were unsure how children (5 and 6) would do, visiting temples all day. We had an excellent guide (you MUST take a guide!) that kept us all entertained and had the excellent mix of temples, visits, boatrides, siestas at the hotel to keep us all happy. The Angkor Complex is absolutely a must-do. It will have a lifelong lasting impression with me, and i would not mind going back to revisit.
