Cambodia 2013. Well, this is indeed a wonderful place to visit. Had never been to such an amazing site, where nature blends with the 'buildings'. Do visit before more collapse happen. Much support is needed to keep this heritage protected and well maintained.

Wonderful, although aim to dodge the crowds.. This place truly is a must see, however, for several reasons it was not the experience I hoped it would be. Firstly, it gets very crowded at points, in particular at sunrise and in the "Tomb raider" bits. I think it would be well worth aiming to dodge the crowds as much as possible. For example at sunrise it was a relief simply walking 50 meters to right of the main crowd and sit on the grassy field. You miss the reflection in the pool but if you value some tranquility in front of squeezing together with a bunch of people all trying to get the best view - that's my hot tip. Otherwise, well inside there is alot to discover so, at least in the morning, it's not too buzy. However this did not seem to apply to Ta Prohm, which just lost a lot of its Indiana Jones feeleing in the crowds and felt sadly unaventurous. Perhaps going here first thing in the morning would do the trick? Secondly, and perhaps I should not be too surprised, but some of the market bits are atmosphere dampers as they sometimes even seek their way into the ruins. HOWEVER. So far I have been awfully negative, but Angkor IS an absolute treasure and there is so much to look at and explore - I fully endorse the reviews below. As a final word of advise, if you do not have a guide, do a bit of research beforehand- visit the Angkor National Museum, watch a documentary, and it will amplify the experience.

A Wonder In Need of Some Professional Help. Quite an experience esp if you go to the museum first and read enough to understand the basics. More attention to signage and explanations would be make the experience more special. In consideration of the boom in most every venue more money needs to be funneled to these wonderful heritage site.

Very interesting ruins with stunning carvings. Be prepared to walk and climb lots of stairs to get the full experience. Ladies - no short skirts as they will not let you up the stairs and you will miss some excellent vantage points and please, wear sensible walking shoes. It is a real pain to try and get around people wearing bad footwear trying to navigate tiny steps.

You must obviously go!. At first, I was wondering why one would need a 3 day or 7 day pass into the park, until I got in there and spent 2 hours alone at Angor Wat. I think to truly enjoy everything that the park offers, one must take their time, and thus get a 3 day pass. After getting souvenirs at the market near Angor Wat and climbing and adventuring through the temple, we found ourselves a little tired and drained, but we only had a one-day pass, and only one day to visit. There are so many different complexes and sites to see! My favorites though were the ones that came after Angor Wat on the circuits from the map. These were less tourist heavy and you could climb freely; there were hardly any mandatory paths so you can adventure freely through the many arches and pathways. This said, the architecture of these sights is not as put together as Angor Wat. Important things:One needs to definitely wear sturdy shoes: hiking boots or tennis shoes are the bestYou cannot climb to the top of Angor Wat and another temple with a short skirt (must be to knees), or with shoulders exposing. There is a market to buy pants/shirts if needed.Bring plenty of water. Of course there are places to buy some within the grounds, but it is always good to have some on you.

Can I more than 5 points?!. Soul enriching experience it was to visit Angkor Archaeological Park.A little crowded at places but overall too good !All the agencies involved in restoration work are doing a great job and Angkor is definitely the must-see place before you die !

Adventure!. I felt like tomb raider going through the temples, you can actually go to all the places you want even if there is a sing not to do it because there is no one around. So enjoy your little adventure.

Amazing experience / photos - just need more information. My husband and I are travelling with our 19 month old daughter - our visit to Angkor Archaeological Park was a fantastic experience and we have some incredible photos from it. Just note that:- There is some restoration work in progress at the moment, and the scaffolding may be prominent in some of the 'iconic' photos. - Visitors can go almost anywhere, however some areas may be slippery in the wet season or unsafe - our toddler was able to roam comfortably in some grassy areas but she was carried in a backpack for most places (as you might expect). - For women - it's useful to wear trousers if you plan to visit the 'heart' of some of the main sites. I wore shorts and would not be allowed to access the central points.- There is limited information about each site, and I do think that for the price ($60USD per person for a 7 day pass) that some information should be provided to 'unlock' the story behind each building. We had a great reference book, and others have hired personal guides - either or both of these options are helpful to get value from the visit.- Tuk Tuk was the best transport for us - gave us flexibility to go anywhere and anytime. Most tuk tuks have a legal maximum of 3 passengers.- It's highly likely that you will be approached by children selling wares at each site. We were given advice to avoid purchasing from these children because it encourages their continued exploitation. It's hard to say no to these kids, so an alternative way to support them is to give a gift (e.g. a pencil, notepad, wrapped candy) rather than money. We got a 7 day pass, and spent early mornings (5am - 10am) and late afternoons (3pm - 6.30pm) at the temples. This allowed us to capture sunrise / sunset photos and avoid crowds.
it's what makes Siem Rep great. yeah, you gotta go here. rent some bikes and ride around and enjoy it. no place on Earth like it. so old and charming

It really is the 8th wonder of the world. It really is the 8th wonder of the world and it is amazing that it was abandoned for several centuries. The main Angkor Wat is stunning but visitors should at least take in Ta Phrom and Bayon as well. The former being famed' for it's role in Angeline Jolie's Tomb Raider (temples covered by tree roots) ánd Bayon is just beautiful with it's carved faces.

One day is plenty. I had guide and driver, started at 4:45 am with sunrise at Angkor Wat, visited Angkor Wat, Bayon, Baphuon, Ta Prohm and elephant terrace, at very leisure place, missed most of the crowds and finished by 10:45. Went back late afternoon for sunset at Phnom Bakheng but cloud cover appeared.I hd opportunity to return next day for smaller temples but passed.

Busy but enjoyable day. First point - make sure you pay the extra for a local guide - he will tell you so much more of the history and current renovations.We were surprised atnthe scale of the park and temples, if you are expecting a temples you can walk around in 10 minutes you are in for a big surprise - these are huge.A number of the temples are of the same style so are repeated and they have all been Hindu and Budist so the statutes have be defaced in the part but this doesn't take from the marvel.Our favourite was the temple used for Tomb Raider movie - Ta Prohm because of the fantastic trees and roots.If you're going to Cambodia, this is a must see. Remember however, this is a money-making machine! And is privately owned!
Very Big. Its big. I think you cannot finish touring it the whole day for its size. you should alot like 2 or 3 days for you to go all the places in this place.

One of my bucket list wish. This is all the park with all the ruins. I love the way they take a picture of you at the entrance so they put it in you ticket, great souvenir to remember. Definitely the most beautiful thing in the world for me until now.

Don't go with a guide. Unless you are a real history buff, I'd stay away from getting a guide. Ours went at a snails pace and gave us way more detail then we could digest. For lunch he took us to a total tourist trap which we thankfully rejected. The kids were especially bored and we cut our first day short. The second day was SOOO much better without a guide and just taking things at our pace. Loved Bayon and Ta Prohm. The tuk tuk drivers are awesome and wait for you to finish and take you to other temples. They'll even anticipate which gate you'll exit so you don't have to double back.

Beautiful and Huge Park. I loved the park, we drove around it, as we were stopping at every temple, the park is beautiful, too big to visit cycling, too bad because it is so beautiful. But we drove by tuk tuk and saw almost every part of it. It is just so amazing.. Worth the visit, worth the $20. For me one day was enough, The must see temples Bayon, Ta Prohm and of course, Angkor Wat. Too hot and too crowded but definitely worth it !!

A world wonder!. I can't think of a big enough superlative to describe this place & experience! Please do it yourself at least once before you die,(bucket-list stuff!) A good tip though is to visit the Siem Reap National Museum 1st to get invaluable background info & history.It made my 2nd trip even more special.

amazing. just amazing! you might need a guide for this, but mostly we had read about thee places earlier and carried with us a book on angkor and the many temples. the book was sufficient enough! you can get it at the areas near the temples were some of the cambodians will selling it. if you are good at bargaining you can get it for as low as USD4-6

"Blasphemy" - less than one day at the Angkor temples. I know this is complete anathema to other Angkor devotees, but we only spent a total of 6 hours in the park. Please don't think that means we didn't like it...we loved it. We just aren't ones for long detailed guided tours and easily go to "temple overload". We went to the National Museum the day before to begin learning the history of Angkor and spent a couple of hours there. We also watched a video on the history of Angkor provided on DVD in our hotel the night before and I read the historical fiction novel "Temple of a Thousand Faces", which I highly recommend (which tells the story of Jayavarman VII and his queen's recapture of Angkor from the Cham invaders) ahead of time, too. Having this "humanized"connection to a place (even if fictionalized) really enhances the visit for me. We hired a tuk-tuk for the day and completed the Small Circuit by 2:30 pm. I'm sure we missed many beautiful temples and stories about the bas-reliefs, but our Angkor experience was perfect for us. One of the highlights for me were the numbers and varieties of beautiful butterflies flitting around the grounds the entire day. We were planning to go back for sunset that evening, but the rain did not permit that. Instead of a guide, we bought one of the books from a seller in front (retail $27.95, started at $15, bargained to $5) and read our own insights. The souvenir hawking was similar to that around the Forbidden City in Beijing and, while expected, still mildly annoying. I was surprised that they were allowed well into the grounds of the approach to the temples, rather than required to stay outside.But not to end on a negative note - we have loved our visit to Angkor and Siem Reap in general so far (minus our still-missing piece of luggage). On to Battambang today!

Simply stunning. Travel there earlier than what you think to get a good spot to watch the sunrise and then you can take your time to explore some of the park before it gets too hot during the midday period. Then come back in the afternoon to continue exploring the area. If you have a driver make sure you know where they're going to meet you next because it can get really confusing. Don't forget that parts of the park is still a place of worship for some therefore respectable clothing is more appropriate otherwise you might not be able to access some of the sites. Also don't forget to stay around for the sunset!

Excellent World Heritage with 2000 years of history. So many travellers there. I like their breakfast there (bread with omellete) which taste better than the one I bought outside Angkor Archeological Park. I simply amazed and impressed with this size of temple in the park. I cycle around the park from my villa in Siem Reap which you can consider doing so if you are fit, I didn't get a guide but I read a lot of the info from website and enjoy the scenery and surrounding of the temple. For cycle, make sure you have insect repellent, raincoat, sunblock, cap, sunglass and water.
Go early, don't miss Ankor Thom. Huge crowds. Go early (you want to see the sunrise anyway). The crowds at Ankor Thom were much smaller.
Beyond imagination.... Angkor is beyond imagination. People should see this Archaelogical park because words can't describe it. One's need to see this temple before it's gone.
A World Wonder!. Easily on par with any ancient site on the planet! Architechtual perfection, that words cannot do justice.A must see!!!

Angkor Temple - Amazing. Wonderful and impressive the temples area. For sure is one of the best things to see in the world. It takes at least 2 days to visit the whole area and you can choose the style and the temple type you prefer....

Spectacular ! Marvelous ! Outta this world !. You will feel you have travelled back in time in some other world. It's beautiful, & everyone coming to Cambodia MUST MUST MUST visit Angkor...don't go without seeing this.We travelled by overnight bus from Phnom Penh just for the 1 day visit which is $20 per person. Took the night bus back to get to pnh.The bus ride was a killer thou, couldn't sleep properly. It's $10 each way per person.Would advise travelers coming to Cambodia to stay in Siem Reap & visit Phnom Penh by bus instead, since Siem Reap is a much beautiful & cleaner city.
An amazing temple adventure. Make sure you have not only your camera, but a very good pair of walking shoes. go during the non rainy season, there are less tourist, and less bugs

Be there at 5am for sunrise!. Even though it's $20 to get into the park it's well worth it. I arrived at sunrise with many other people doing the same thing but the place is so big that everyone is quick to disperse. It gets hot early on so prepare to sweat a lot! A lovely way to spend the day and see some incredible ruins. If you're not sure whether to buy a three day pass ($40) buy one day and if you need to go back, pick up another single day pass and you're still only spending $40. I managed to do everything in a day so glad I didn't spend $40 initially!
Amazing experience. The scale and enormity of the park is quite overwhelming and an awe inspiring experience. Worth at least 2 or 3 days with one a sunrise at angkor wat itself

Really cool. Felt like i was in the temple version of jurassic park. Really cool, such well preserved monuments from the past. be prepared to spend quite a bit of time 3 temples took us a full morning and we were exhausted by then. angkor wat and bayon are must see's but my favourite was Baphuon, really nice to romp around the place that was nested right in the centre of the forest

AMAZING!!!. It's an absolute must if you are in south east Asia... No excuses. I loved it! Went there for sunrise which was so nice to see but also a plus for doing them while it is still cool enough!! I would highly recommend it, truly a magical experience.

Must visit place as few architecture is simply superb. Specially i love the Bayon temple and Angkor wat. Really nice architecture. But i feel we need minimum two day pass to visit complete place else its very tiring and specially when you have younger kids below 5 thn much more difficult to see those places as stroller will not work every where in this place.

Get lost in the lost city of Angkor.!. I visited Angkor Archaeological Park on 14th June 2013. One of the best days of my life. I started with Bayon whose most distinctive feature is the multitude of serene and massive stone faces on the many towers. Truly stunning. And I ended the day with Phnom Bakheng. Makes you wonder how it was built without much of the technologies available as these days. In-fact you feel the same wherever you go in Angkor.! Its better to have a travel Itinerary (based on no of days) for Angkor before you go there. Here is a 1 day itinerary that followed. Might be useful.Morning:South gate of Angkor Thom, Central Angkor Thom (Bayon, Phimeanakas, Terrace of Elephants and Terrace of Leper King).Lunch: In the food market next to Central Thom parking.Afternoon:Ta Prohm, Pre Rup, Angkor Wat, and Phnom Bakheng for sunset (or Angkor Wat for sunset).P.S: Angkor Archaeological Par closes at 1800. But opens at 0500. Hence be early to stick onto the itinerary.Head back to the pub street to have a chilled beer and talk to fellow travelers about Angkor Wat. Cheers. :-).

Truly breathtaking. If there is one place I urge people to visit in their lifetimes, Angkor might well be it. The rich history, the sense of exploring, and the variety of sights are unbeatable. Those who fear being 'templed out', I am pretty sure this is impossible!

The temples in this park are all fabulous in their own way. The temples in this park are all fabulous in their own way. To be able to experience this culture that was at its height in 12th century and to see the sophistication of the society. law courts, entertainment, engineering, libraries.

Should be on everyone's bucket list. A trip to Cambodia is not complete until you have been here. It is a beautifully mind blowing experience. Take sunscreen, hat water and dress conservatively,long sleeves and long pants help protect from the sun. I don't think you can discover everything in a week but have fun trying.
Days of fun. A most beautiful landscape managed well and with something for everyone. More than enough to entertain for a few days

A memory for life. Once you step into this places you will never forget them. I am not by any means a history junkie, but this place just calls you to learn and listen and behold in awe. The trees in place look as if they were a hand grabbing the structures from the sky. A sight to remember.It is very hot though, take plenty of water, a hat and COMFORTABLE shoes, dont be like most people walking for hours on flip flops, believe me they regret it.

Must experience!. Angkor is an incredible experience! Making it all the more interesting was my guide Lekh Puy from http://www.asiaprivateguideservice.com/.Angkor truly is one of the great wonders of the world. I could go on and on, but you will be better served by googling ANGKOR WAT for a host of information and photos. If your itinerary includes a trip to Cambodia and want to know about the history of this immense complex and the people who built it, or if you are interested in other parts of this great Nation, consider Lekh Puy as your guide. You will not be disappointed!

stunning!. this is why you're in Siem Reap, right? and yes, it is stunning! even all those crowds of tourists (you included) does not spoil the impression. so much beauty all around! yet, I'd recommend to skip sunset / sunrise events: it gets too crowded to really enjoy the experience.

You'll have to pinch yourself. Best trip in South East Asia, this place is bewildering. The sheer size of the park and its temples is something you have to see to take in. Even with all the tourists about you feel like tomb raider walking round these ancient ruins. Worth the trip to Cambodia alone. Not to be missed as there's surely nothing like it anywhere else in the world. Went back 3 days running and there's enough to keep you going for 3 days easily.

Incredible place - you must visit!. There isn't much more that I can add to what others have said. This place is a must see. The ruins are really awe-inspiring. Although it is sad to see some in disrepair - it will take many years of painstaking work to repair many of them which were callously damaged and looted during the war in the 70's. We hired a Tuk Tuk driver to take us to the various temples. We didn't use a local guide as we had done a bit of study in advance and just wanted the flexibility to wander around at our leisure. As you can imagine, the temples are packed with tourists but our tuk tuk driver would usually take us to the quieter entrances meaning we avoided the huge crowds for the most part. In one day, we managed to see three of the main temple complexes.We really loved Siem Reap and when we are back, we will visit the temples again. It is worth it.

I want to revisit, someday.... I only had one day pass to visit this HUGE archeological park. What a pity, I couldn't make it at sunrise. I rented a bike from my hostel which the distance around 7 km from this site, and I explored this Angkor archaeological park by bike. It's around 30km of distance in total, but of course I cant visit all in one day visit. I hope, I will be back to this place..and take 3 day pass to explore it, by cycling is the best way to enjoy this place.

Did a lot in one day!. We only had a day, so we chose a private guide, Vichet who we highly recommend. Got to see the main temples and started with sunrise over Angkor Wat...superb....it was very hot but not crowded as we went in low season. If you don't get a guide I would recommend really studying up beforehand, otherwise you will just be aimlessly wandering around and missing heaps of interesting detail. I have travelled extensively in Egypt and South America, so have seen my share of temples! However unlike other reviewers,I don't see how you could be blasé or jaded about these temples. We had a wonderful, interesting day. One suggestion, go back to hotel and regroup at lunchtime, really helped us get our second wind.

A must see. The ancient ruins vary in importance and are some distance apart so transport is a must. The architecture is amazing and it would have been the pinnacle of Khmer civilization in its heyday.
Great Experience. This is one of the best things my girlfriend and I have ever done. The park is exceptional in every way and the people of Cambodia couldn't be more welcoming.
Breathtaking. The temple is spectacular. No wonder its an UNESCO world heritage. Many other temples to see as well. Take a tuk tuk and see all of the temples.

One of the wonder. 3 time I visit Angkor complex in for the last 13 years, and I can see there is a lot of changes now on good and bad. It is easier to cóme around now, but also a lot of more commercial

A must-see. This was truely a "wow experience" for us! Gorgeous temple complexes very much intact! Obviously, a guide is needed to really appreciate what you are looking at. I suppose a good guide-book can suffice for the budget-minded. Just don't go and gawk. Know what you're looking at.

Must Visit. Nobody visits Cambodia without a visit to the park. I am not a fan of history or museums but this place amazes me with the architecture. Pity we only have half a day to cover the place and we only manage the Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat and the Bayon. A lot of walking to do and not suited for the elderly.
Everything is very well organized. The entire Angkor Archaeological Park area is outstanding. Everything is very well organized, well run and in great condition.

An amazing experience. I visited Angkor at the end of a 3 month trip touring SE Asia. I had stopped visiting temples some weeks before as I did not want to be "templed-out". I opted for the 3 day pass. A 1 day pass costs $20 and a 3 day pass is $40. I think the other option was a 7 day pass for $60 but as I am not a massive history or archeological buff 7 days was definitely too long for me. I think most people agree that the big 3 to see are Angkor Wat, The Bayon and Ta Prohm. It's definitely possible to do these in 1 day and even visit some other smaller temples as well as Angkor Thom. I would recommend a tuk tuk to do this. I think a car just isn't as much fun. Be sure to bring plenty of water, a hat and sunscreen. You also can't enter some temples if you have bare shoulders. Sunrise at Angkor is touristy but amazing and worth the 4am wake up all. I only tried sunset once and it was too cloudy. I hired a tuk tuk to visit Banteay Srei which is about 30km away from Siem Reap. I can't say the temple itself was worth it but the drive was really pretty. On the same day we visited some of the Roulos temples, again not amazing. We also stopped at Banteay Samre which I loved. It was very quiet and had some great photo opportunities. You should also consider renting a bike. Obviously on a bike you will struggle to cover as much ground but its a good option for day 3 to revisit your favorite temple or see a new temple. I cycled the Grand Circuit (26km I think), leaving my hostel at 5am to avoid the midday/afternoon heat. It was wonderful. I visited Preah Kahn which was another of my favorites. Very atmospheric with no crowds. I did not hire a guide. I'm not a big history buff and wanted to just see the key sites at my own speed. I downloaded a great guide on my iPad. Cambodia: The Temples of Angkor. One of the Approach Guides. Written by David and Jennifer Raezer. It has profiles of the temples, tips on key features to look out for as well as photos and detailed directions on finding them (eg behind the 8th column on the left).

A Day Tour Experience of Angkor. Angkor Archaeological Park comprises endless number of temples and sites that it would take several days or even weeks to see them all especially for students of archaeology and history. Major sites however can be seen in one day provided a good plan and spontaneous tour is arranged ahead. The best way is to get an accredited tour guide and a taxi to help you get around. Taking a Tuktuk is a little less expensive but I would recommend it for a 3-day or 1 week tour packages. The exhausting heat, going up and down the temples, long walk plus the extensiveness of the sites are physically taxing and will limit one's mobility with a tuktuk.Fortunately for us, I contacted Nak Seongmo, a college sophomore who drives his own taxi to pursue his studies. He was the one who drove us from the airport to the hotel. Cambodians are wonderful people and Nak was exceptionally polite, honest, warm, caring and safe driver. He had prepared cold bottles of water in the car, would take us pictures, brought us to good restaurants, and tell what would be safe and best for us. He was very knowledgeable of Cambodian history, places (particularly within Siem Reap) and its people. He even shared his own experiences and that of his family and the life in rural Siem Reap. I learned so many things from him about Kampuchea, the Angkor temples, the Khmer Empire, the Pol Pot's regime and present day Cambodia. Its like we had a tourist guide and driver in one :)On the day of tour, we got up early, bring extra clothes, proceeded to get a day tour pass then catched the sunrise at Angkor Wat while enjoying an early morning walk in and out of this impressive temple. After 2-3 hours we took breakfast at the nearby Angkor Cafe just across the road facing the west gate of Angkor Wat. Next we proceed to Angkor Thom and Bayon Temple all the way to see the old Royal Palace going out towards the Terraces of Elephants. Before noon, we proceeded towards Ta Prohm and had lunch in a restaurant nearby after which we spent about 1-2 hours to see giant trees grew within this temple inside the forest. Bantaey Srei was the next destination, some 27 kms noth-east. Here you'll see the pink temple oftentimes referred to as the 'Lady Temple' where carvings and wall designs are ostentatiously elegant & elaborate and stone statues are well preserved. A refreshing snack here plus souvenir shopping was a good option before heading back south towards Pre Rup to see the sunset before 6pm.. A sumptuous dinner after some stroll / shopping at Siem Reap's Night Market completes the day. Nak waited long in the car park and volunteered to drive us back to the airport for our late night flight back to Manila. All these (services) for only US$50 he asked from us. In appreciation of the wonderful experience we had in Siem Reap - Nak Seongmo being a very BiG part of it - we gave him something beyond his expectation to which he was tearfully thankful. I proudly recommends Nak if you're planning to visit Siem Reap soon , contact him at nangnak_angkor@yahoo.com
The reason to visit Siem Reap. and indeed, perhaps even the reason to consider a visit to Cambodia in the first place. Recommend a 3-day pass.

Awesome!! A must-visit destination. It has taken me a long time to finally getting round to visit Angkor Wat with my family. We finally realized our wish in June. We thought it would be really hot but the rain the previous day had cooled the weather considerably. The structures were truly impressive. My favorites were Angkor Wat, the Bayon and Ta Prohm. Some advice for visitors: you can definitely see all the major sights in one day, unless you are an avid historian. Get an accredited guide and a car to take you around. Saves a lot of time. Start off your day at 530 am to watch the sunrise at Angkor Wat. By 830, you should be able to complete all of Angkor Wat. This would be a good time to stop and have breakfast. The next stops would be the various structures at Angkor Thom. Depending on how fast you view the main structures, you could finish them all by 2 to 4pm. Next, you could extend your visit to Bantaey Srei, which would be a good 45 min drive. I highly recommend taking the drive out to see it. It is quite a small temple compared to the others but the carvings and stone statues are really well preserved. Finally, you can visit Pre Rup to see the sunset at 6pm. This would be a good 12 to 13 hour day, but it wasn't rushed, neither was it too tiring. The key to doing this route is to hire a car and guide. Can't do this on tuk tuk, it would be too tiring and hot given the heat. For me and my family, one day is enough to take in all the major sights and learn about the history of the temples and the people living at that time. We went there during what was considered the low season, so it isn't as packed as what was described by some postings. However, being such a famous tourist destination, you will expect some crowd. June isn't as hot as Feb to May, and since its the low season, many of the restaurants and massage places in Siem Reap are rather quiet. Cambodians are generally friendly people and a number of them speak English with an American accent. We went horse riding passing through villages and the children were all very friendly waving and saying hi to us. We left Siem Reap with a really good impression of Cambodia and I learnt a lot of history about the Magnificent Khmer empire of ages past and the monuments of their legacy.

India and middle east more to offer. I guess I am a spoilt traveler as I went to India leh and Iran recently, where there were less tourist but more wow factor.The Cambodian people are wonderful It would be better if the kids were not selling things to tourist and go to school instead.

Awesome to see but to touristy. The temples are a must do thing in Cambodia, but like all attractions, things get just to overrun by tourists. I recommend to check with your local guide the best times to visit the different temples,like Angkor Wat later the afternoon because everyone else tries to get to the sunset mountain. And go to Ta Prohm very very early.

Breathtaking. This was a truly amazing experience. The temples are awesome. Hire a tuk tuk driver for fifteen dollars a day and drive around to see the many beautiful temples. This was unlike anything I have experienced before and truly took my breath away.

One of the most incredible archaeological Parks in all the world.. This is one of the most incredible archaeological parks in all the world. I've spent years seeing all of the Maya ruins (and others in Central/South America) and they don't come close to this one. I can't believe it took me this long to come to Ankor.

The big three; Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, and Ta Prohm.. ANGKOR WAT: Catch the dawn reflection over the pond at Angkor Wat. Be early (before 5 am) to get a good position along the edge of the pond. After the sun comes up go around to the eastern side of the site to get great early morning light for wide angle shots. ANGKOR THOM (INCLUDING BAYON): The biggest site and will take at least 4 hours minimum to do it all properly. Go early in the morning and start at the far end (elephant landing) then work your way up through the complex to finish at Bayon. The afternoons are crowded and hot. The Bayon has no shade providing tree growth and the black stone work absorbs a lot of heat.TA PROHM: Visit at early morning or late afternoon to avoid the package tour hordes. Plenty of shade provided by all the tree growth on the site. ENTRY FEE: Buy the 3 day pass for USD 40 instead of the single day pass at USD 20BEST TIME TO VISIT: Go in May. It's hotter but the crowds are significantly less.
Highlights of Siem Reap. A must visit place if you are going to Siem Reap. In fact, this is the main attractions for visitors. Get a 3 days pass and go to visit various temples within the area.

It's the reason why you're in Siem Reap! Honest Tuk-Tuk info below. -Start early to avoid the crowds and beat the heat (which is impossible). -Bring, or buy a hat and long sleeve white shirt or a sun umbrella. Slather the kids with sunscreen. -Early morning sunrise and evening sunsets are nice but nothing to freak out about. Especially if you enjoy sleeping in. It's nice to get an early start though and sunrise forces you into it.-Get the three day pass, or better yet - get the week pass. You don't have to use your days consecutively, which is great!-We all want the best deal but be sure to tip people (especially your driver!) Everyone is hounding and harassing us because they are that poor. Every cent counts. With that said, avoid buying the postcards from the kids. Once you do, prepare to be mobbed.-The book is worth it, even if you just leaf thru it. In the back is a great itinerary suggestion.-My tuk Tuk driver was amazing! Feel free to use him - (tell him "Becky, like Bakery" sent you and expect VIP serviceHis name is Setha 855 77 73 13 57 or 855 97 912 58 87-Get a guide at one of the temples (Angor Wat is a good place to start) or hire someone for the day, at least once. -Overall, don't feel bad about being scammed. It sucks but these people have so much competition (with all of the other people selling the exact same thing or services) and they have NOTHING. Really. They are so desperate for just .50 cents. Literally, they are just trying to survive. -We are rich in comparison. Yes, haggle with them and play the game but don't feel too bad if you paid a little extra. When you buy a T-shirt for $2.00, know that they are only making .50 cents and in the low season you might be their only customer that day. If you pay $3.00, they just got $1.50-Back in town, the "I don't want your money, just please buy me baby formula" is a scam. They return it later for the cash. I fell for it because I'm a sucker (and the kid looked so hungry!) BUT I made sure to open it and mix a bottle at the counter so she could not return it.-It's lovely. Try your best to support the local community.-Definitely check out the Cambodian Circus one of your evenings. I purchased my ticket at the location. It's fifty cents to a few dollars cheaper if you buy it thru your hotel or guest house, but buying on-site gives all the money to the school. Which ever route you go, it doesn't matter, just go.-If you have a chance, especially if you are from the US, go to the Land Mine Museum. It's small but a worthwhile little stop.-Prepare to fall in love with Cambodia but know that it will break your heart.

A must see. Everyone knows what this place is and that is for a reason. It is magnificent. Also a lot lot bigger than we imagined. If you are into this sort of thing you could spend days and days wondering around. If you are not too fussed about knowing all the history, meanings of engravings etc. it is quite easy to wonder around, generally following the crowds, without the need of a guide. In fact a good guide book would just about do the same job (and the guide we had was very good!). Go early to avoid the heat if you are there in wet season

Once in a lifetime place to visit.. Allow yourself plenty of time, take plenty of water to drink & be prepared for the heat. Hired a pushbike on the first day. A great idea until the afternoon storm arrived and had to ride back in teeming rain, treacherous lightening and crashing thunder. A great adventure.
A must see. Everything at the Angkor complex is amazing. All the temples offer something unique and you could really spend months getting to know them

An experience to treasure for a lifetime. I was excited to visit Angkor and I didn't disappoint. I bought a 3 day ticket for USD$40 and spent 15 hours over 3 days exploring a dozen temples and my only complaint was that it wasn't enough time. Every temple was new and amazing and even in 3 days I wasn't able to see everything I wanted to. In retrospect I should have bought the $60 week pass.My advice is to plan to stay longer and pace yourself. A half-day (about 5 hours) is a perfect stretch of time. Beyond that you may get too hot, tired, or experience temple fatigue. Even if you reach your daily fill of temple fun, the enthusiasm and majesty will return the next morning (at least it did for me).Truly one of the most memorable places I have ever visited.Top temples for me were 1. Bayon, 2. Banteay Srei, and 3. Ta Prohm.Enjoy!

Incredible and wonderful experiences. Angkor Archaeological Park is truly one of the most incredible and wonderful experiences of our life. A must see at least once in your life.The whole AAP area was vastly bigger than we ever expected.We recommend spending at least 3 days visiting the temples.A 1-day pass costs $20, 3-day pass costs $40, and 7-day pass costs $60.
day trip to Angkor. Lots and lots of tourist, but if you step a little off the well beaten path, you get to enjoy the amazing structures, a well informed guide is a bonus.
Archaeological Park. Park very well managed and apart from the heat easy to move around View of Angkor Wat most impressive as is the Moat and wall that surrounds the area.

Worth spending three days. I am from Chennai and there is a similar site called Mahabalipuram near here. I can say Anghor Archaeological Park is at least 100 times bigger in terms of area, locations , architecture and bas-relief.

The must do thing in Cambodia. If you came to Cambodia and aren't planning to do this, then you are missing probably the most breathe taking views. For $40 for a three day pass (totally worth it), you get to see over 600 temples including Angkor Wat.Every temple here tells a story about life in this great ancient society and gives us a reason to be amazed at nature and man. This is a must see.Note to women: These are Buddhist and Hindu temples, which means shorts/skirts/dresses have to be below the knew and shirts have to have sleeves. You will get into the park if you are wearing short shorts and sleeveless shirts, but you can't climb to the top of Angkor Wat or go to the temple on the hill.

100% Worth a visit!!!!. Don't even try to see everything within one day - impossible! If you have the time do it with a week's pass and do it step by step. Most people do too much at the first day and become (as locals call it) "templesick". The roads within the park are flat like a pancake - so rent a bike and enjoy. Avoid Angkor Wat during sunrise and sunset - too many tourists. Be prepared because the steps are STEEP.

Wonderful Archaeological Park. Angkor is really a jewel in this World, it is a mix o Hindi and Buddhist culture full of history and beautiful landscapes/construction.Normally in the middle of nature, organized (you buy a ticket all the area for 40 Dollars and there is control in almost all historical sites).It is a must go place in the world.

Excellent. This is the reason you come here and it is a great experience, it was low season when I visited so not a lot of tourists but none the less very hot take a hat and Sun Glasses, overall a great experience glad i have now seen it worth the $20.00 day pass

This is why you came here, after all :). I will be submitting reviews on all the individual temples, but I thought it fitting to review the park in general. Angkor Archaeological Park is the main reason tourists come to Siem Reap and most of the ruins you want to see fall under it's management. I would recommend getting a seven day pass, even if you only plan to spend a few days in the temples. You may find yourself captivated by the history and you may decide you want to spend an extra day or two wandering around. It's not a great deal extra to get the seven day pass and it saves a lot of inconvenience. They police the pass fairly well also, and there are staff members at every temple checking your pass. Take care of your pass - if it's damaged in any way they will not accept it and you won't get a refund. All in all, a lovely place. I would recommend using a tuk tuk driver to see everything as it's a great way to see things up close and personal, and you can find a good driver for about $15 a day. Many of the drivers in the area can make recommendations about what temples are good to see, but if you are after a guide it is probably ethical to pay a second person. (Mind you there are guides to hire at many of the bigger temples). As a general rule, go out as early as you can (around 7am) and come back when the heat gets too much. Have a nap or a swim in your hotel pool, then head out again around 3pm.A warning though; as many people get temple fatigue, some drivers will recommend you to go to Tonle Sap Lake for a bit of a break. Beware. Take a look at some of the reviews of the lake as there is a bit of a scam going on there.

The reason you are here...see it!. This once in a lifetime destination has now been seen half a dozen times by my road weary eyes. And worth it each time. Yes it is too busy. Yes it has changed...what isn't these days and what doesn't. See it at sunrise....see it at sundown...see it in the rain. Just see it all...

Magnificent. You can spend several days in the park, we did only 2,5 days or so. we rented a tultul through our hotel at 18usd per day, presumably you could get even better deals. Children below 12 do not pay, but make sure you always carry passport (copy) of the kids with you, because they do control also once you are on site. difficult to say which one we prefered as they are at the same time different and sharing common characteristics.

Don't use bicycles if you're here to see the temples. Temples are all beautiful and interesting and could take a long time to cover the grounds. Day time temperature here are above 30c all year round. So it is quite physically demanding to just cover the inside of temples, cycling between temples might be take too much energy out of you that by the time you reach the temples, you're already too tired to discover the inside properly.Highly, highly recommend a private tour with a driver and a guide in an air-conditioned car. In low season we managed an all day deal for $45.

Ancient ruins from a previous era. These ancient temples are the reason why around 3 million tourists p.a. visit Siem Reap. I did some research before booking my holiday. From the internet, I hired a private tour guide and a separate driver with an air-conditioned Toyota Camry for 3 days. This place can get very hot and very dusty. We bought a ticket for 3 days and visited 22 temples at a leisurely pace. The tour guide was very experienced and knew the best time to avoid the crowds. The photos that I have attached in this review and in the reviews of individual temples (Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm, etc) on this forum prove that we managed to avoid the crowds. The tour guide took photos for us and the driver provided us with cold bottled water and cold disposable towels in sealed packets) throughout the 3 days. We took an elephant ride up the hill to Phnom Bakheng to see the sunset. I gave the tour guide and the driver some tips in US$ at the end of the tour, for their excellent service.

Astonishing architecture. Angkor is just beautiful with all the temples, ruins, trees and lakes. A truly unique experience for me. Take a day at least and explore as many temples as possible. Don't forget your sunblock and wear longer sleeves!You have to wear proper clothes to enter some temples too.Bring water and food with you if you don't want to buy them double and triple the price.

A memorable must-see for anyone visiting Cambodia - but read travelers' tips before you go. Ankor Wat is a memorable experience for anyone visiting 400m2 with so many to see (not just Angkor Wat) - you can decide how much you want to see or can take (1 - 7 days). Highly recommended for anyone visiting Cambodia, interested in history or the history of Hindu and Buddhist history. Tips:1) If you can, avoid going in April! Although we have been warned, we went regardless because we live in the Middle East and thought we could handle the heat - we were wrong: it is extremely hot and humid and visiting Angkor Wat from 5am-2pm left us soaking wet, dehydrated, and drained even the next day.2) We were not advised by our guide, but if your children are <12 and you don't pay entrance fee for them to the Site, it means they can't enter 1 of the AW temples without a paid ticket. Our children were really disappointed!3) Consider your young children - the day(s) are long, hot and physically tiresome. We saw parents being angry at their young children for crying and not wanting to pose for photos after a long day - even our young teenage boys and us were exhausted by mid-day 4) The average couple of family can do max 3 temples in 1 day (we saw 3 of the main ones, but I barely made the last one5) Bring and drink lots of water, sunscreen, hat, cool comfortable clothes and shoes (though shoulders and knees should be covered in temples 6) Even if you are not interested in taking photos at sunrise, start the tour at 5am or as soon after that as possible and don't go back to your hotel to have breakfast and then to return. Starting the tour at 5am means you start before it really gets hot. 7) We were glad we had a private AC van to transfer us between hotel and AW and between sights (and not a Tuk-Tuk). It helped to cool down between sights

a must in asia. take your time and forget your tight budgetsleep well and wake up earlystart enjoying any detail of the whole complexyou are in a must-do in asia, spend at least 3 days thereTips: tuktuk is the best transport (pay 20$/day and give tip later), bring tons of water, be the earliest at temples and say good bye before noon, pay a good hotel with pool to relax later, enjoy siem reap bars at night !!!

Incredible. Definately a must see, this is why we came to Cambodia and were not disappointed. The incredible mural carvings are in amazing shape, the facility is so large, and tiring to trek arounc but worth every step. We went for sunrise and were very glad we made the effort.

A must see, magical place... best way to discover it: bike !. Cycling around the Angkor temples, you are amazed by so much beauty and history ... It's quite expensive to enter (40USD/3 days) but it is definitely worth every penny. We realized also that three days weren't enough to explore all the wonders of Angkor. We will be back, that's for sure. This place is just magical. My advice: try to go there in the low season, it's hot, but early and late in the day, you've got the place almost to yourself... there are no words to describe that experience !

Lived up to expectations. You wonder whether you might be disappointed after having heard so much about Angkor Wat and having been to other Hindu temples like Prambanan in Java but be assured you will not! The sheer scale of it is breathtaking and the detail of the cavings and stone work amazing. Don't miss it.

Unforgettable experience. It's a very huge park, normally you have to take at least 3 hours to explore it. Remember to put on sunblock/umbrella or hat and drink sufficient water. Take a rest when you feel tired.

A unique gem. Magic, just magic! Very demanding walks under a scorching sun are a small toll for one of the most charming places on Earth. The ticketing system is nothing but idiotic: only one place to buy your multiple entrances at $ 20. I was travelling with my own transport from North to South and wanted to visit a remote temple (40 kms from the ticket office), no way! The blank faces of the staff at the entrance turned me away showing no regret or comprehension

Really great historical monuments. We visited in December but the weather was sunny and very hot. Still, the experience of visiting the park including the Angkor Wat was amazing. A few observations:(a) There are 1-day, 2-day or 3-day tickets, costing 20,40 or 60 dollars for each person. Well, there are enough attractions for several days but I guess, for most people who just want to experience the view of amazing historical structures (and are not really interested in observing minute historical details), even a 1-day ticket should be sufficient, though a 2-day ticket would be more optimal. A 1-day tour will not allow visiting every structure around but one can manage visiting first Banteay Srey, then Bayon and finally the Angkor Wat. (b) Some temples do not allow people not properly dressed. My wife was not allowed inside Baphuon for wearing sleeveless. Later we came to know that sleeveless dress is not allowed to the top part of the main Angkor Wat as well. So, we bought a new T-shirt before going to Angkor Wat.

Must see!. This park is enormous - it is definitely well worth spending time here and is not to be rushed. It is incredible.A three 3 day pass is $40USD p/p - we had only intentionally decided on spending two days in the park, so opted for this pass in case we changed our minds, and figured it was more cost effective this way. One tip is to arrive early (perhaps travel out - it's ten minutes out of Siem Reap central - over a period of 3 days) to not only avoid the heat, but also a lot of the crowds. It's always more pleasant visiting such sights with fewer people around!

its narnia...but, unfortunately not through your wardrobe.. instead its a 12 hour flight..but saying its worth it is an understatement to the factor of m. angkor wat itself is the biggest religious building in the world, and seeing dawn there with someone i love was one of the most seminal moments of my life. it is so amazing, in the real sense, that its hard to describe...but angkor is so much more..you might think that orlando had theme parks akimbo...but it has nothing on angkor. omg! you drive in a tuk tuk through amazing trees, crickets seething, smells and sounds, through gates with smiling faces big enough for an elephant to pass through...and then you arrive at a temple. and you have no idea what that is going to be. could be climbing to the skies, could be rubble in the jungle, could be a serene water feature, could be something out of a playstation game. there are trees so big you dont even come half way up their roots, there are spiders hanging on webs huge and glittering in the sunlight, there are smiling faces everywhere, appearing out of the jungle, there are bridges to heaven protected by snakes, with men and demons doing a tug of war to keep them here...inbetween us on the earth and the temples of heaven. it is so much the most amazing place on the earth i cant even describe it in words. i have been all over the world...and nothing even comes close to angkor....it is narnia! there is just nothing else in human building that even comes close. yes the taj mahal is most beautiful, but there is only one taj...there are hundreds of temples at angkor..and they are all different....i cant gush more...if you are even slightly considering going, i suggest you do it. how on earth could anyone be dissappointed by the most amazing site know to mankind. just go!
Truly stunning. What to say that everybody else hasn't Except that one day is not enoughTruly mesmerising A must!Take plenty if waterLight baggy clothing A wide hat or a brolly!

No words.... It is impossible to put into words the scope and majesty of the temples. Suffice it to say you will never forget what you've seen. We were in Siem Reap in early May and it was HOT! Word of advice: Make sure you have plenty of water on hand and something to fan yourself with when you head out to the temple complex. Be prepared to walk and climb...but beyond that, be ready to be blown away by all the things that are there for you to see. We had wanted to go to Angkor Wat at dawn to watch the sun rise over the towers, but were told it's really the best at the spring equinox, so we chose not to follow through. This complex is well worth one's time and effort (and possible discomfort in the heat) - I will never forget my time there.
amazing. It is very big and its amazing how it still beutifull almost 1000 years.You have to climb to the top floor.

Amazing. I have wanted tick this off the bucket list for some time now.The sites are amazing and the only downside are the hawkers peddling everything from books to badges,, but they are outside the confines of the temple sites.

AMAZING. Always wanted to visit and it did not disappoint. The temples are hard to describe, you need to see them with your own eyes. The detail in the carvings is second to none. Avoid the crowds if possible and get a good guide, Cambodian Trails is who I used and they were amazing.

Huge park. We visited the Angkor Park for 2 full days and bought the USD40 for 3 day ticket. I think the ticket price is fairly reasonable as we spent 12 hours for 2 full days there visiting the Angkor wat, angkor thom, bayon, ta phrom and a few others. If you're planning to visit any sunrise venues, it's best to get the tickets the day before (around 4pm onwards) as the booth only opens at 5am in the morning and the queue might waste some of the precious sunrise moments!

Awesome. Spent a week in Nov 2012 for my second visit to Angkor, I highly recommend people go and visit! Yes, you should wake up early to watch the sunrise and miss some of the stampeding people that slept in. Personally I'm a fan of the "tuk tuk" experience around Angkor (don't worry, they're much different and less hassle than in Thailand!), my driver in 2006, and 2012 was Peach you can contact him directly at yimpheach@yahoo.com he's a great guy! People that want to take pictures shouldn't ride in an Aircon vehicle, unless you like condensation of course.
Go Early. Head out at 5 am so you can catch the sun rise. Also by 8 am the tour buses come and you'll be heading home so you won't care as you'll miss the chaotic madhouse it will become.

Speechless. This ancient site is amazing, superb.. no words could describe this place.. unforgotable moment.. and I just could understand if there are lots people dont know siam reap.. dont know angkor wat,
Oh meeenn, you just dont know your lost..

If you aren't visiting Angkor, what are you doing in Siem Reap?. Angkor National Park is the top attraction in Siem Reap and the reason the two gets millions of visitors a year. The Park houses a large collection of temples, including the incredibly famous Angkor Wat. Many visit the park for sunrise or sunset but I started my day around 8 in the morning with a private guide. It is hot as Hades in the jungle climate surrounding the temples but it is absolutely worth it. I visited the three big temples (Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm) as well as some of the smaller and older temples in the Park. There is a small city of restaurants and bars inside the Park where you can take a break and eat a quick but delicious lunch. Otherwise, you will spend the day wondering around astounded by the incredible art and workmanship surrounding you. I dreamed of visiting Angkor for more than a decade and I could not be happier that I finally made it.

Outstanding. Well worth 20USDollars to visit park, and to have a ticket with your photo on to keep as a memory. We visited Angkor Wat , Angkor Thom and Ta Prohm. Angkor Wat was as pictures but much much more interesting. Angkor Wat was smaller but very interesting to explore and Ta Prohm gave one some idea of what the temples were like when first discovered. The tree growth and the roots are unbelievable. Gives a 'spooky' atmosphere but not to be missed.

The best Ancient Adventure ever!!. One of the most amazing & awe-inspiring places I have ever been.  THE best way to get around the park is definitely by Tuk-Tuk. We absolutely loved riding in our Tuk-tuk, you get to see everything so easily and experience a lovely refreshing breeze. We saw quite a few exhausted looking people who had hired bicycles to go from temple to temple - what a huge WASTE of time and energy. You need all of your energy to walk around the temples, plus bumpy roads and high humidity = no fun. Taxi's are more expensive and boring - not an authentic adventure experience. For an excellent Tuk-tuk driver we could highly recommend, Vanny Pech. He was genuine, informative, spoke excellent English and most importantly, a safe driver. You could email him at: vanny.khmer1982@yahoo.com & his mobile is +855 1287 6369

Superb. One of the wonders of the world; if you go to Siem Reap this is not to be missed. The temples are all fantastic, the pinnacle being the magnificent 12th-14th century angkor wat although all of the temples are worth visiting. Impossible to do in 1 day, it is worth getting a three day pass and guide

truly a wonder. It would probably take me full day to tour the whole complex and I loved it! It is quite crowded though and you have to find a good spot if you wish to take your picture without everybody else around.

Breath-taking!. If you have the time, get a 3-day pass. We followed some guidebook recommendations of keeping Angkor Wat to the end, but i would not do that again. The argument that one might not be impressed by the rest of the temples after having first seen Angkor Wat does not hold, as each temple is unique and beautiful in its own right. Being the main attraction with Bayon, go there first, while you're fresh at the beginning of the trip to Siem Reap.The compounds for most of the temples are huge and require quite a bit of walking. My family and i ended up spending at least twice the time we'd alotted for any of the temples for that and many other reasons...So, if you're enjoying the architecture, are prone to stop and listen to the music by local artists in the compounds or shop for souvenirs, or don't mind just sitting and wondering at the structures and nature's power, you might do the same! Also, consider the weather, especially later in the dry season, when the heat is draining.DAY 1: I would suggest going to Angkor Wat for sunrise, seeing the temple and then going to 2 or 3 of the smaller temples around, such as Preah Khan, Ta Som and Mebon.DAY 2: Go to Banteay Srei at sunrise or in the early morning; then visit the Landmine Museum on the way back to Siem Reap. See Ta Phrom and end with a sunset at the small temple of Pre Rup.DAY 3: Start at Bayon, walk the grounds and take an elephant ride around the main structure (sometimes, you'll need to check in before just to make sure a tour group hasn't booked them up). Come back in the late afternoon and finish with a remork ride around the Angkor complex, stopping at the smaller temples such as Phnom Baken, Neak Pean and Banteay Kdei or revisiting some of the temples you liked the previous days. The remork ride with a cool evening breeze was beautiful and relaxing.Shopping: We bought some lovely charcoal rubbings on parchment (the local artists might be working off wood blocks) at the Preah Khan entrance. You do have to sift through and check the quality and then bargain down their prices, but it was worth it and made for lovely gifts. However, i'd bought some at the National Museum in Phnom Penh for much less and they were of top quality without the hassle of haggling.

The whole place is awesome. Get a $20 day pass and do Angkor Wat for sunrise, go back to your hotel for a shower and breakfast and return to do the others in this order, Bayon Temple then Ta Prohm and, if you like stay for sunset.,

Well worth a visit. We bought a one day ticket and saw most of the more well known temples. The ancient ruins vary in importance and are some distance apart so transport is a must. The architecture is amazing and it would have been the pinnacle of Khmer civilization in its heyday. A must see.....

Experience of a livetime. If you have the time buy the 3 day ticket there's just to many temples to see in one day. Tickets are 20 dollar for 1 day and 40 for 3 days. If you want to be more independend rent a motorcycle for 1 dollar a day in Siem Reap, its easy to avoid the crowds this way but expect to cycle at least 25-30 kilometers.

Huge complex. I guess this listing refers to the place as a whole rather than individual temples.We bought a 3-day tickets and hired a yuk-yuk at $15 per day and spent two days exploring most of the spots.Some are more interesting than other. Some also require climbing some steep stairs. Seek the assistance of your driver or guide to plan your day accordingly. Maybe better not to climb those stairs at the warmest time of the day. When the sun is at its highest, it is good to hide inside the structures!

Amazing architecture based on astronomical alignments and sacred geometry. Amazing... The architecture is mindblowing, based on astronomical alignments and sacred geometry, very magical place. No doubt about it one of the wanders of the world. Its very intresting to note that Angkor wat itself is one of the biggest religious monuments in the world. There are many other amazing temples that you have to visit if your here, some are prymids very simuler to the prymids in south america. I was told by a very intresting Wize man that the pine cone towers represent the pineal gland ( crown chakra) and that the heads with four faces represent enlightened consciousness seeing into the spiritual dimensions. And these designs bring down divine energy into the meditation chambers directly beneath them, he also mentioned there may have been extra terrestrial contact and help with the design biy wouldn't go into details. Even if you are not a believer still very intresting stuff. Its also intresting to note that most of these temples were Hindu, but have now been claimed as Buddhist temples. Would have been so amazing while they were in use, the architectures muat have been genius. Really amazing. Must come visit in a life time.

No Questions Asked... Take a Guide and Do It!. The largest religious temple in the world is here in Cambodia, 20 min away from Siem Reap by tuk-tuk. You will need to buy a pass: 20$ for a day-pass or 40$ for a 3-day pass. I personally did everything in one day, from sunrise to sunset. I heavily recommend to book one of these official guides so that you have at all times a clear idea of what is under your eyes. You will understand why some older temples such as Angkor Wat -the emblematic temple that you can see on the Cambodian flag- are in a much better state of conservation than less older temples such as Ta Prohm. You will understand the rivalries between Hinduism and Buddhism through what you can see in and on the monuments. And much much more that is to be learnt in here...

A fantastic experience. I am embarrassed to say that I knew little about Angkor Wat until my first visit in 2011.It really is the 8th wonder of the world and it is amazing that it was abandoned for several centuries. The main Angkor Wat is stunning but visitors should at least take in Ta Phrom and Bayon as well. The former being famed' for it's role in Angeline Jolie's Tomb Raider (temples covered by tree roots) ánd Bayon is just beautiful with it's carved faces.

a real treasure. As we were walking around and listening to the tour guide, i reflect on the hard work that was put in to come up with a beauty and grandeur that we enjoy now. The tour guide mentioned about the elephants used to transport materials to build the temples. He said the materials come from a far place.Many have mentioned about the cultural and spiritual significance of these temples but I was brought back to the time of its building where people worked probably day and night, good or bad weather to build this temple. I hope that everyone who goes to visit these temples is not just there to see its beauty but also to remember these people as well...I was touched when the tour guide said that the relief (sculpture) was done and preserved for the young generation to see...a grand intention to be cherished not only by their people but by us who stepped in those temples...

Must see, don't miss this.. I visited Angkor Wat with some friends who had arranged a tour and was really impressed by the sheer size, scale and detail of it all. Take time to go visit this site. I would definitely recommend 2 or more days to see it. I spent one day with a guide and another on my own. I enjoyed the balance of receiving information and just roaming on my own. I had a tuk tuk driver for 5-6 hours one day and it cost $15. Avoid hiring them through someone as the person arranging it gets a cut. I'm not sure if you will be able to get such a good price but try to see if your guesthouse deals with independent tuk tuk drivers without serving as a middle man. I enjoyed the main temple complexes as well as the smaller, less visited temples. It really is a place where you can find interest wherever your interest lies. If you are touring for 2-3 days go for the 3 day pass as one day is $20 and 3 days is $40 (the same as 2 days). There are always lots of hawkers around and you can buy a variety of souvenirs. Guidebooks and postcards for a dollar and even temple rubbings and figurines. The constant "hey lady/sir" can be quite tiring, though. Beware of local boys in the ruins. I was approached by two who asked me my name and where I was from and began giving me a speech about school and whatnot. I think they wanted to get money as they approached me in a remote area of the temple, they were hanging out in the work zone and ran away as soon as someone approached so I assumed they were up to no good.

Do your homework and have a real experience.. As one of the recent reviews said ... "we visited Siem reap for the sole purpose of seeing Angkor Wat not realising that...there are many other sites"... Our initial planning was based on a desire to see Angkor Wat and it was only after some investigation, (how hard is that with the internet?), that we saw the extent of the temple complex area and indeed the history behind the area.We spent 5 days in and around the Archeological park and I would have like another 5 days at least. There is always some thing else to see. We bought the 3 day pass, so we did a section of the main temples area in between our day trips to site further afield. We did a day trip out to Beng Mealea and another day out to the floating village at Lake Tonle as well as further trip out to Banteay Srey, Kbal Spean (1000 Lingas) and the Landmine museum. We stayed at The Rosetree B&B and through them had a great tuk-tuk driver who took us wherever we wanted and was very helpful in pointing out the correct paths and co-ordinating our movements through the numerous temple sites.It was a great experience, made better by some measure of prior information

Must see UNESCO world heritage site.. This is Cambodia's main tourist attraction and rightfully so. The park encompasses not only the most famous Angkor Wat, the largest Hindu temple complex and religious monument in the world, but also more than 1000 other temples located amid forests and farmland near modern-day Siem Reap city . Angkor was the largest pre-industrial urban center in the world, founded by Khmer king Jayavarman II in the 9th century. Many of the temples at Angkor have been restored, and together, they comprise the most significant site of Khmer architecture. I've been wanting to go there since I was a little boy and I must say the experience was overwhelming!

The place to visit in Cambodia. If you're coming to Cambodia, make sure to visit Angkor Archeological Park. You'll have a better understanding of the Cambodian history and culture. I’ve enjoyed every bit of my visit to the park.

Mindblowing. We visited Siem Reap for the sole purpose of seeing Angkor Wat not realising that, while this is the best restored of the sites, there are many other sites that are totally awe inspiring because of their size, their setting and/or their beauty. We had just 2 days to take it all in, no where near enough time but it did give us a taste (and yearning) for more.

No Lara Croft - Just Tourists. This park is so huge that you should stop and take fun photos at the random smaller overgrown temples and ruins because once you get to the famous ones used in the Lara Croft movies, you'll have too many other tourists in your photo.

Whowwww!!!. Traveling with a 17 year old who only thinks of sitting by the pool. Okay, okay more than 50 characters. Amazing Temples to view. I felt sorry for the Elephants so many years ago who had to haul the stuff there. Cambodia needs to be proud it has assisted in making sure it is well taken care of and accessible. They are doing a good job.

A life time experience. A lifetime experience. Worth the effort. Lots of walking, lots of steps, very little shade so take your hat and lots of water to drink. Go early in the morning to avoid crowds and midday high temperatures. Great to go for the sunrise at 5.30 am when they open the park, and leave at 9.30 for breakfast avoiding a lot of tourist and extreme temperatures.

WOW!. Wow. I didn't realise how magnificent the Angkor Archaeological Park would be. It's huge, different and full of history. They are trying to retain these structures. Try and catch the sunrise over Angkor Wat. Amazing!

A short coach ride to the park. As large coaches cannot drive into the park you must transfer to a smaller mini bus to get into the various sites. Also you must have a photo id pass to wear at all times while in the various sites. It is well organized and managed and they process large numbers very quickly. You can also enter the sites from siem Reap by Tuk-Tuk. There are several temple sites to visit each requiring a minimum of 2 hours with guide.

Magical exploration. We visited Siem Reap for 6 days in late January. It was our first time to Cambodia. The trip was simply amazing and we still haven't had enough of it. We would really love to go back some day. We hired a driver before our arrival and were very warmly welcomed by him throughout the trip (we went for air conditioned car because of the heat but you could try his tuk tuk as well). He speaks fluent English and some Mandarin and he is very keen to introduce Cambodia to you and explain things about Cambodia and the temples to you (www.mrvuthy.com). It is a great way to get to know more about Cambodia! We were picked up by the driver at the airport and went to the hotel to settle down. Then we went to buy tickets at the gate (a 3-day pass which starts to count only on the next day since we bought the tickets in the evening) - no time to lose! Our driver was amazing - he knew exactly how to beat the crowds (ie what time to go to which temple) so we managed to take a lot of great pictures without waiting for the crowds to go by (which could seem forever). If you have time, we strongly recommend you to go visit other temples as well outside the park - our driver took us to Preah Vihear Temple (for which Cambodia and Thailand fought for ownership for a long time) which was totally worth a visit and Koh Ker. Overall, an amazing trip with the most wonderful driver!

Amazing – this is what Siem Reap is all about. The park is huge complex of temple ruins. Some people say you need 3 days to cover the whole park. But temple fatigue is quite a common syndrome among travellers especially to some of us who can’t stand the heat. We opted for a day’s pass for USD20. 3-day pass is USD40. We managed to cover 5 temples – Bayon, (most interesting one with the faces) Baphuon, Ta Keo (beware of stairs, they are steep and without holding rails but fun!), Elephant Terrace (enjoyed this one too), Terrace of the Leper King, Ta Prohm (the Tomb Raider temple and my favourite) and Angkor Wat. It took us 7 hours and by the end of it we had enough. We opted to hire a car and a drive for USD30 for a full day. While tuk tuk is a cheaper option, the heat does get unbearable and it is nice to jump into an air-conditioning car from one temple to another. If you can afford it, I suggest you hire a car. Tip: A large cold mineral water bottle should cost between $1-2.
Great days. I cycled around the whole of Angkor for a couple of days and absolutely loved it.Just as expected and more.

Pure magic - magnificent. We bought a three day pass and it was worth every cent. We hired a tuk tuk and did self guided touring. We started with going to Angor What for sunrise - a pure mind boggle. The park area is huge and we could only average around 4 sights per day. This is one of the wonders of the world - if you have the chance treat yourself to a few days in Angor even if you don't do anything else in Cambodia. The pink citadel is magical, Angor What mind blowing, Angor Thom unbelievable and Byon indescribable. The list goes on.

Temple-explorers paradise. I had a three-day pass, and still went back for an extra day later in my stay. Allow yourself lots of time, drink lots of water, have a good break for lunch in the heat of the day, and use an excellent tuk-tuk driver to make the most of your visit'. A highlight was an evening picnic by the Angkor Wat moat with staff from the project where I was volunteering.

Awesome experience. Angkor Wat is just one site within the Angkor Archaeological Park, which covers some 400 square kilometers. It's huge. We hired a driver and guide for two days to tour various sites. Even so, we only managed three sites a day. In March it is very hot and having an AC car to retreat to was well worth the price. Take lots of water and pace yourself. There is lots of walking, stairs and little shade. All that said, visiting the Angkor Archaeological Park is a must do if anywhere near Cambodia. It's awesome!

Be there early. Worth the effort. Lots of walking, lots of steps, very little shade so take your hat and lots of water to drink. Go early in the morning to avoid crowds and midday high temperatures.(40 degrees when we were there) Very impressive site.

A 'must do' in Cambodia. We visited here mid February before it got really hot but temperatures were still mid 30's or more.Take a hat and water everywhere. Remember to wear clothing that covers your knees and shoulders. We had oranised a private driver and guide for the four days we were in Siem Reap which was definitiely the way to go. I would not want to do it without. Three of these days were touring temples. Air conditioned vehicle (faster that a tuk tuk) between temples which was a welcome relief and explanation of temples, history etc. The guide also knew what order to visit the temples to avoid crowds and the best photo spots. We started early every day to avoid the heat in the hottest part of the day when we then had time to go back to the hotel to cool off in the pool and rest for about 2 hours. We could also recharge the camera battery then as you do take an awful lot of photos. Have a spare otherwise!

Worth the Hype. This is listed as one of the World's must see locations with good reason. Whether you are an ancient ruins buff or not, the Angkor temples have to be experienced. We went in a very hot month (March) and the conditions were very harsh but still well worth it. Just DO IT.

Magical place. These are amazing structures and you can feel the history in the stones!We went with a private guide and driver (provided by Buffalo Tours) and I would recommend that you do this if you possibly can. You get a proper conversation about the place rather than having to strain to hear a monologue from the umbrella-carrier!They took us the opposite way to the crowds round the archeological park, which meant that most of the time we had the place to ourselves and this made it even more special. Again - do this for a really relaxed and informative visit.Enjoy!

To be able to walk thru these temples is just amazing. I love the fact that you are able to walk thru the temples and experiece them first hand. There are so many temples to visit so plan it over a few days if you have the time.I would recommend having some kind of itinery of what you what to see, as the weather is hot its easy to over do it on the first day.We hired a tuk-tuk driver who was great, he had a esky full of cold water and disposable napkins.

We wish we had done 3 days instead of 2. We visited SR in March 2013 for three nights and two days. We spent the two days visiting the temples. On the first day we did a bit too much - AT Bayon and AW. We still enjoyed it - but our recollection became a bit blurred (The elephant terrace is memorable but after 5 hours temple walking/climbing in the heat you can miss some of the finer points - like did we go there!)My advice to 50/60 year old travellers would be to split AW and AT/Bayon into two half days in March or any other time when its that hot and do another small temple or just try something elseMaybe the sunrise start helps - its cooler
angor is a place of marvel. my family friend recomended i come here and im so glad i did as this place is amazing is a magnificent piece of history

The fee is well worth it. There is a fee to enter the Angkor complex, but it helps pay for the preservation of the temples, so it is worthwhile. I think only foreigners have to pay, Cambodians can enter for free since it is part of their heritage.
Amazing. I was privileged enough to visit most of the temples in the park. Amazing experience and the park is very well kept.

Very Interesting but very crowded!. We bought our tickets the night we arrived. You are supposed to be able to buy them after a certain time and have them valid for sunset and the next few days but we bought around 3pm as as we only needed a two day pass ($40US for 3 days - US dollars everywhere! we occasionally got local currency 1000riels = 25cents - but we would just give it back at the next transaction). Buy your tickets later in the day if you can, the line up in the morning we passed was crazy. Keep your ticket handy - they will punch it at the entrance and check it at certain temples. Shoulders must be covered and girls need to cover their legs. The tour groups seemed to ignore this, but I saw some girls turned away from climbing some temples because they were wearing shorts and guy had to wear his girlfriend's shawl as he had a tank top on. There are tons of tour groups, a lot of people on bikes and tuk tuks and taxis. We rented a tuk tuk for a few hours to see Angkor Wat on the first day and then a taxi(the guy we got from the airport) for a full tour. If you don't do well with heat rent a taxi as AC makes a huge difference. Our taxi guy was apparently a taxi and tour guide in one.
