It cost about $50 to do all the temples in one day as we went out further. I'm not sure if this was expensive or not but I'm not much of a bargainer. Angkor wat is super crowded, probably because it's not huge and it's the one everyone knows. If you want to climb it you have to be there before 4 or 5pm. If you want to get the iconic reflecting pool shot then walk to the left-most corner of the left "pond" when facing angkor wat and you'll get it. Angkor Thom is quite big. I really liked the "tomb raider temple" because it's got all the trees, it can also get busy but the temples further away from angkor wat are less crowded - unless you go to the ladies temple(banteay srei) and then it's very crowded as the tour buses go for its amazing carvings.Take water with you - though your taxi driver/guide might bring water. There are people(and many kids) that sell drinks at the bigger temples and post cards/books everywhere ($1 for 10!, $1 for a book!) Apparently the kids go to half day school so half the day they spend at the temples trying to sell trinkets. It kind of ruins the ambiance when you see the massive market outside angkor wat(it's next to the reflecting pool) but I must say the drink vendors are wonderful when it is that hot. We didn't eat in the park but there seem to be places to eat near the parking lots. Your guide might take you to a restaurant. Our taxi driver drove us to a small restaurant that seemed to be geared to tourists, the food seemed authentic(and upstairs had AC), but the westerners ate in one section while the tour guides sat in another, still all food is cheap and good so I wouldn't worry about it.I'm not sure if Angkor is ever not crowded, perhaps during rainy season. We didn't do sunrise so i can't comment on that. We got to the outer reaches of the park around 9-10am and people were there. Angkor Thom is big enough that it doesn't feel super crowded. We were at Angkor wat later in the day and stayed until the sun started to go down, the colours didn't really change much so I'm not sure what the draw is, at which point there is a mass exodus from the park as everyone goes into Siem Reap to have their feet massaged ($1 for 10 mins) and eat dinner.Just remember that it is hot. I can't stress that enough. You will be climbing temples in the sun all day so be prepared!

Awesome, but overwhelming!. Incredible place, but don't expect to get pictures without hundreds of Chinese tourists. Don't try to see too many wats in a single day as they start to look the same and the heat can be brutal.

This is why everyone comes to Siem Reap!!. There is no question that this is one of the most important places in Cambodia and the tourism industry in Siem Reap flourishes because of this park. I would say, there is nothing wrong in that!!The government have spent quiet a lot of time and manpower to keep this place safe and secured and ultimately making it pretty tourist friendly.The costs for entrance for foreigners is around 20$ for a day and 40$ for 3 days. You have a huge area to cover, which you can do on your own or with the help of a guide. Another option is liaising with a tuk-tuk who can offer good rates to go around the park and show you the most famous places!! Cycle tours and bikes are also a good option!!Overall a well maintained attraction with most of the facilities in place without disturbing the environment!!

The reason you visit Siem Reap for the first time. Of course it's the temples that attracts the tourists for their first trip to this part of Cambodia. They are fantastic! Possibly in my opinion, which has limited research, I think they (rebuilders sponsored by other countries) are going too far with the restorations. Replicated worn and broken stone blocks and carvings can go too far, especially when carvings are not even of the century the temples were built. But, all in all, fantastic experience, I'm glad I experienced it at the beginning of restoration so I still witnessed how the blocks lay, and with the trees growing through. Small tip - take cash because there are a lot of stalls selling bits and pieces. And make a judgement call on buying from kids.....if they are there making money, why would they go to school?

Must See!. Hired a tuk tuk for the day at $18 from our hotel. The driver provided cold water for us all day .I suggest getting the 3 day pass , this way you can see it all and not feel rushed. Our driver was great and took us to the less crowded areas first. The temples really are amazing and some are so different. My favourites were Ta Prohm ,which has fantastic picture opportunities and Preah Khan which is huge and was less crowded. Lots of walking and it is hot! I managed just fine in flip flops . I wore shorts so I wasn't allowed to climb the temple inside Angkor Wat since it still is an active temple. Although there were others who were permitted to go up (??) so if you want to climb it, have your knees and shoulders covered. Very busy everywhere except Preah Khan. My only complaint is that there are tons of people and kids selling stuff outside the temples . I know they need the money so outside is not the issue . It is that they are inside the temples as well, yes INSIDE ! Really takes away the beauty and significance of the temples when you have someone asking you to buy things all the time and have stuff set up inside the temple grounds. Watch out for anyone who is overly friendly who follows you around and is acting like a guide pointing things out or where to take a good picture. A young man (20's) was following us for about 15 mins and offered to take our picture etc . We knew he would want a tip so after we were done my husband went to give him $2 and said thanks . The guy says " No it's $10 a person " my husband says "no" and he says to us " well this is too cheap , I am going to go get the tourist police." He was very very friendly up until this point. We told him we didn't ask for him to tour us around and my husband gave him $5 so he would just leave us alone. I know they need the money but don't enjoy it when you feel scammed. The children are very cute and very good sales people but giving them money or buying from them keeps them out of school. The kids even say " i cant go to school if you don't buy " . Instead spend your money to donate supplies to a school. It's very hard to say no since they stay on you the whole time. We were still very friendly with all of them but firm on our no to buy. Besides that , the temples really are a must see!

Awesome. I only spent one day here, but it was the best one day on my whole vacation. My tuk tuk driver was very helpful in taking me around to see 5-6 temples. They were very great to see and so much history.The only drawback was too many people and too many hawkers. Other than that it was fantastic.

So many temples so little time.. Amazing variety of temples and other artefacts such as the Elephant Terrace. You could spend weeks here exploring. The whole world appeared to be visiting at the same time.

Brilliant. Firstly it seems a pity to call it Angkor Archaeological Park, since it is definitively not that. It- rightly -is one of the seven wonder of the ancient world and we feel blessed for having visited. The scale of the buildings, the majesty of the sculptures, the jungle surrounding it, the steps consumed by centuries of pilgrims are impossible to describe.
Wow!!!. It was very hot that even our local guide said it was hot and this was the at the end of the cool season. But it is worth the heat to see these magnificent temples and soak in the history.

Temple Town. This is quite a large complex to see in a few days. Take 40$ ticket valid for a week / 3 entries. Plan for comfortable tour not so hurry. recommend Tuk Tuk ride to & fro to reach the complex fresh for long walks. Renting cycling (3-5$/day) is an option. Banteay Srei temple entrance also inlcuded in this Angkor ticket. Every ticket has your photo & hence not transferrable.

Excellent, amazing, loved it. We had a car with a driver, $25 first day and $30 second as we went to see the sunrise at Angkor Wat. You can go by tuk tuk or even hire a bike but we were grateful we had a car with AC as after you finish with one temple you are hot and bothered so it's excellent to cool down in a nice air conditioned car. We bought the 3 day pass for $40, you have a photo taken which is put on your ticket...a nice souvenir to keep :)We felt we have seen enough of temples after visiting Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm and Preah Khan but of course there are many more you can visit if you have the time or will.It does get extremely hot during daytime, especially around noon so it's a good thing to go back to the hotel, relax, have a swim and something cold to drink and go back after 3 PM or so.Toilets are hard to find and not many so go when you see one :) The little cafe by Angkor Wat makes amazing watermelon freeze, absolutely refreshing!!!Please do not buy anything from the children trying to sell you postcards and jewellery...your purchase is keeping them on the streets and away from school. If you want to do something buy some school supplies like coloured pencils, sharpeners etc and give it to them instead, also do not give them any money as they won't be able to keep them...someone else will.Next time I would have visited the Angkor Museum in Siam Reap before visiting the temples as it really gives you a good background about them.The entire area is simply amazing and I am very grateful I was able to visit.

Need a week to see everything. We were rambling for 3 days in this park and visit many temples, the ruins of the Royal Palace, Elephant Terasse where the coronations and parades took place. You should visit it early in the morning or after 15:00. After noon the humid heat is unbearable.

Outstanding ruins not to be missed. If you have time, buy the 3-day pass (US$40 p/p) to visit this site because it is huge. We spent one day doing the "outer tour" with a tuk tuk driver (US$20), one day exploring on bicycles (US$5.00 p/bike) and the last day doing the short tour with a tuk tuk driver ($12). If you rent bikes, consider spending a little more to rent the mountain bikes ($5 vs $1.50) because you will travel 20-30 km, and it's much more enjoyable on a newer bike with multiple gears.

A must-see for Indiana Joneses. I visit the site regularly due to work, and it doesn't matter how many times I go, seeing the early mist fade away during he sunrise through the towers of Angkor Wat or the Bayon temple is breathtaking. The temples have a thing for everyone: if you are adventurous, you can climb the steps to the towers, if you prefer to stay on the ground, you can walk around every temple and visit the lower tiers. Do not miss out on the elephant trip to Bakeng or around Angkor Thom, it is really lovely!

Beyond expectations in every way. We visited Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Bayon, Ta Prohm and Banteay Srei over 3 days in the area.Nothing you have read or seen does justice to this place. Do yourself a favour and hire the best guide you can find. It will bring the place to life.Finally go here soon. The crowds are ridiculous and will only grow. See it before it is killed with kindness

Wonderful ancient civilatization. Stunning views, rich history, good exercise. There are a lot of options for dinning in the city. I enjoy vegetarian food, which exist. The roads are bumpy in some spots on the daily drive to the park, but not bad on the whole, and the price is right for a tuk tuk, 15 usd/day.
Stunning. Get here very early (5.30am) to see the temple reflected in the water at sunrise. After 9am there are too many tourists to appreciate it.

Angkor, amazing world heritage. Angkor of Cambodia gave my wife and I so much excitement as well as hundreds of opportunities for taking excellent photos. Although Angkor wat itself is almost perpetually invaded by Chinese tourists, making it exceedingly crowded, it is truly wonderful to behold! And after all, it is the best preserved ancient Hindu temple of the world, as far as I know! Also we loved the Bayon temple with its illustrious, stone carved faces and even better still the complex of Ta Prohm which is totally mind blowing, partly overgrown as it is by huge jungle trees and their massive, winding roots. We payed an admission fee allowing us access to the greater most part of the Angkor region for all in all three days but decided, although the price was rather high, to add in an extra day since there was so much to see, not only including the temples mentioned above but numerous other ancient ruins which may not be quite as spectacular but definitely worth the visit.We hired a tuk tuk with a driver who didn't give us all that much information, which was OK since there is usually a guide for hire at most temples in case one should be needed . There are eaters spread out a little here and there though these are generally overpriced and serve food which we found as being a little bland. And then there are (often very young) vendors everywhere trying to sell you all sorts of stuff, from post cards to music instruments and of course, pineapple, coconut, and bananas like everywhere else in Cambodia.But one item you can't do without when trekking around in Angkor is water, by the gallons!

Cool temples, but far too many.. We did a two-day temple tour, going around by taxi. First we did Angkor Wat, which was really big and beautiful. Angkor Thom was also impressive, with all the faces on the temple. Then we went to the temple that was the reason we went to Cambodia in the first place: the jungle temple. We really like the big tree on top of the building and was very much looking forward to it. What a let down - they were doing construction work and that area was closed for visitors. Very dissapointing. =( But it's probably gonna look better than ever when it's done. The contruction work they have done to other temples is amazing.After those three temples we started to get a bit sick and tired of stone and salesmen. At the bigger temples the sellers are outside and you can walk away from them easily, but at some of the smaller ones they are actually inside the temple area, following you around. Even policemen try to sell you touristy things like pins, or want to give you a tour (not for free of course).The second day of temples felt totally unnecessary. Everything just looked alike, and we didn't really enjoy it any longer. Our taxi driver noticed, so we finished early.I would recommend that (if you're not really, really into temples) you just buy the one-day ticket and go see the biggest ones.

All templed out. My boyfriend and I are from Sydney, Australia and visited Siem Reap in late November 2012 to see the temples. I was quite overwhelmed when I started to do my research upon seeing how many temples there were to see. To simplify things, I found that there were 2 main loops of temples; the big loop and the small loop (often referred to in tour/transport guides). The small loop covers all of the more famous temples, such as Angkor Wat, the Bayon temple (the smiling faces) and Ta Prohm (the tomb raider temples). I completed both circuits, one each day, and organized it through my accommodation (The Kool Hotel). The first day I completed the big loop in an air conditioned car and without a guide, the second covering the small loop in a tuk tuk with a guide, as was recommended to me. I was advised the longer distances would be more comfortable in a car and that the history of the more famous temples would be better appreciated with a guide. The temples were beautiful and well worth the visit. But if I had to do it again, or give anyone going any advice, I would suggest; if you are only going for a few days (like us, we went for 3 nights), do not do well in the heat and crowds and are not particularly interested in the detailed history of each place, than simply do the small loop with a guide or travel book. That way, you see the truly impressive temples Siem Reap has to offer at a relaxed pace. Space them out, and go as early in the day as you can to avoid some of the heat and crowds, then have lunch and relax in your hotel pool or air conditioned rooms. Trying to fit everything in in our short trip, we found ourselves exhausted after the 2 full days, I developed a heat rash out in the sun all day, and by the end we were sadly, all templed out...

Plan for 3-4 nights minimum...... When I found out that "Angkor Wat" was accessible on our trip to Thailand from Bangkok I knew I had to go. Unfortunatly with only 1 full day in "Siem Reap" it proved not enough time to pay hommage to what is one of the worlds great Archaeological sites. Up there with with the "Roman Forum" and "Luxor" in Egypt. Advice pay for a guide....the insight he will give into what was the worlds largest pre-industrial city is amazing. Apart from knowing where all the good photo shots are.

Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!. Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!Angkor Wat is a world heritage site. It was fantastic!

Amazing, unique and fun to explore. Angkor Watt was the main reason we came to Cambodia and Vietnam and we were not disappointed. We spent three days in Siem Reap and wished we had been able to stay longer. The temples are amazing and they are organised well and easy to access with a daily tuk tuk driver. We did not use a guide as we like exploring at our own pace and own directions. We may have missed out on some of the history but we did not feel we missed out otherwise. Siem Reap itself is a bustling tourist town with great restaurants, nightlife and friendly people. Visit as soon as you can.

Experiencing it is a must!!!. If you're into everything from the days of when Angkor was being built, then you'll enjoy this place, things can be repetitive but look closer and things will catch you by surprise and give you a since of wow factor.

Great memorable experience. Loved walking around these tranquil ancient structures - our favourite was Angkor Thom - we received a blessing by local monks here - I will never forget the peacefulness and tranquility.
Can't go wrong. Everything at the Angkor complex is amazing. All the temples offer something unique and you could really spend months getting to know them.
yes yes yes.. It was so nice I will do it again when I m back in the Angkor region so much temple to see and so much more to learn

Huge site with a lot of impressive things!!. The park never seems to end. There's so many things to see. We only went to 3 temples and it took us almost a day. The only thing is that comapare to most of the things in cambodia the entrace fee is expensive. But for what you see it's worth it !!
World Heritage Centre. The Angkor Archeological Park is protected by UNESCO, and not without reason. It's Cambodian's gold mine, and they should protect it well.

Not to be missed. It is hot and physically challenging to go through the whole thing, but is an experience you will never forget. You could easily spend several days here, but you can see some of the main highlights in a day.
A must place to visit. one of the wonderst of the ancient world and its a must see place, you come here really to see this magic old city and see what humans achieved 1000 years ago

Top 5 for ancient Architectural wonders. This site gives me awe at immense grandeur of the ancient civilizations. I would compare the feeling to seeing Chichen Itza in Mexico, Pompeii in Italy, Forbidden City in Beijing and Olympia in Greece.One important note about entering Cambodia, You must have ONE COMPLETELY BLANK PAGE in your Passport for them to be able to apply your tourist visa. Getting the VISA was no problem and done very efficiently at the Siem Reap Airport. Do not bother getting pictures beforehand as they scan the picture in your passport for $1 extra and it adds no time to the process. We had to sign a release for Bangkok Airways in Bangkok as my my wife did not have a completely blank page in her passport and also sign at Cambodian immigration giving permission for them to apply the VISA over on existing sticker. Finally we were asked for "tip" by a different official - a well spent $10 USD!We decided to skip the sunrise and arrived at the park at 8.30 am we had an excellent guide who was fluent in English and French with excellent knowledge of the temples, in fact he spent several years as a monk. His name is Porheng Ieng, send me a personal message if you wish to contact him.We decided to do the small loop - started at Bayon with the wonderful faces defined by the rising sun and a lull in the crowd, some of whom had departed for breakfast. From there we did the rest of the Ankor Thom including the terraces of the elephant and the leaper king ending at Ta Prohm before lunch at 12.30 pm.After lunch we explored Anchor Wat for 2 hours before heading over to Angkor Balloon situated 1 km to the west of main gate of Angkor Wat for different perspective from the air. See separate review but well worth the $15 cost (cash only, no credit card)Couple of practical points, keep your admission pass as dry as possible, a feat in the high humidity, you need to present at the entrance of all the major temples and to use the clean official washroom for free. If the pass is mutilated you will need to by a second one at $20 USD.We had a private air conditioned car that provided a cool haven between each temple - highly recommended - no such luck if you opted for the cheaper tuk tuk.All in all, a long tiring day, if i had it do over, I would opt for 3 days and spread the temples over at least 2 days because of the heat and humidity. I now have new respect for the hardships that the Marines faced as they trekked through the forests with heavy gear during the Vietnam War.

2 days ideal. We've done the park in 2 days. I'd recommend hiring a bycicle for the 1st day and do the "small circle" - i.e. Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, etc... The next day hire a tuk-tuk and visit the more distant temples in the "big circle" (primarily the Banteay Srei, which is really nice).

One of the Most Impressive World Heritage Sites. From a World Heritage perspective, I could only agree that Angkor is indeed one of the best cultural wonders (if not the best), and is an incredible engineering feat the world has to offer. It's definitely a top notcher. For some reasons, I appreciated Angkor Wat better in the afternoon - at sunset - than during the popular and obligatory sunrise visit where all tourists to Angkor are expected start their journeys with. In either case, it was such a delight to see that Angkor still receives a lot of visitors even during off peak seasons! Of all the many temples and ensembles I have seen, I really cherished my experience at Bayon, the 'almost secret' ground alleys of the Terrace of the Leper King, and Prasat Kravan - the last two only receiving a handful of tourists. Prasat Kravan (which has a twin temple as well in Takeo province - the Prasat Neang Khmau) is probably one of the under-appreciated temples in Angkor, but I personally think that it is one of the most unique - the painted murals of the central tower was indeed a find, and it has a history much older than most. Unfortunately, I never got to feel the amazement that people usually claim to have experienced at Sras Srang (the royal bath) as it was under renovation when I last visited. Aside from the enigmatic temples in the area, I find the water system - barays and the canals - to be just as interesting and intriguing. It has to be remembered that Angkor is also a large hydropolis, a water city. TIP 1: I always find that watching a performance of the Royal Cambodian Ballet (Apsara Dance and Cultural Shows) complements well one's visit to Angkor. TIP 2: If I were to recommend, be sure to see and at least spend some time exploring Bayon, the terraces, Ta Prohm, Pre Rup, Banteay Srei, Sras Srang (after the repairs!), Prasat Kravan, Neak Pean, and Angkor Wat.

Angkor January 2013. Exciting, exotic and interesting. We took a driver, guide and reasoned that the cost of getting here justified the expense. The guides must be registered. We have not been disappointed. Ours was first rate, with good English and humour he made the trip memorable and far more informative than the guide books. Entrance great value at $20 per visitor for the single day. We coupled this visit to Angkor Thom with Angkor Wat and Preah KhanPlenty toilets and restaurants in the massive complex and car was essential for transportation between temples and around complex on this hot February day. Recommend spending more than one day here

Stunning experience, fantastic guide. My wife and I did a day tour of the Angkor site in late December 2012 through Urban Adventures. We visited Angkor Watt, Angkor Thom, the "Jungle temple" and the royal pavillion. All the sites were stunning, more so than can be imagined by looking at pictures or on TV. Our guide's name was Sokhom and he was amazing. Not only did he have an extensive knowledge of the temples, his life story was fascinating - from the aerial bombings during the Vietnam War, the "Killing Fields" era, the Vietnamese "liberation" from the Pol Pot regime and being conscripted into the army and finally returning to Cambodia to pick up his life again. After a lot of research we booked the trip with Urban Adventures on the web , and I'm very pleased we did. The price was very reasonable and included entry fee to the site and a very nice lunch in a local resturant in the park. The tour was comprehensive but not overly tiring. Be aware there is a reasonable amount of walking required and some of the steps on the temples are very narrow and quite steep. However, my wife who has a foot injury managed quite well.It's easy to see why this place is world heritage listed and is on so many people "must do" list.I highly recommend a visit and if you choose to book through Urban Adventures, be sure to ask for Sokhom as your tour guide.

Great. This huge area houses several large and impressive religious monuments. Take your time to absorb the enormity of the construction, carvings etc. Not sure they edge out the pyramids at Giza or the Great Wall, but they're right up there.

More than I expected. It was my dream for so long to visit this place, which I found out more than I expected. They really put a lot of efforts to maintain this archeological places. Especially the toilet areas, I was impressed! The temples, of course, were amazing. I am hoping to be back there again in the future. Three days was too short!

Great trip !. Me and my wife enjoy three days in Siem Riep to visit Angkor Archeological Park. The temples are amazing and very interesting ! We got a very special guide : Sophath Sim. He speaks a great english and know a lot about history to teach us ! The best of all, he knows the right hour of the day to go in which temple and site, so we got the right light and angles to take good pictures and we avoid places crowded with people. You can contact him in www.cambodiatour-guide.com.It was a great trip and we highly recommend.

If you are travelling in Cambodia don't miss it!. The Angkor archaeological park (entrance fee 20 USD / day) and 'the city' fortified, the temple of Bayon and all the impressive examples of architectures are an experience that you will never forget for all your life. If you are travelling in Cambodia don't miss it!

Exotissimo Angkor Park Full Day Tour. Firstly the guide (Navy) we had for this full day tour was fantastic. nothing was too much trouble and he was very very knowledgable. Also knew the best angles for photographs without 100's of tourists in them, very difficult to do in an attraction so popular.We have been waiting a long time to see Angkor and we were not disappointed. If you every get the opportunity to travel here take it. We had only one day and visited the more popular temples but would love to have had the time to see some of the lesser one and those outside the general park area. Loved it.

What an amazing area. Although not all temples are here, almost all of them are and within easy distance. A new Tourist Centre is about to be opened in 2013, and only electric vehicles will be allowed, but that creates a problem for all the existing tuk tukk drives sadly.

Even better with a top guide. Angkor Archaeological Park is exceptional and I don't need to add to other comments on TripAdvisor. This is a simply magnificent site and you need at least days to explore Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat and the rest. You can and should go on a guided tour or hire a guide to take you round, as that enables you to absorb so much more and to visit particular temples or carvings that you might otherwise miss. But the quality of the guides is mixed, even though they are licensed by the Cambodian Park authority. On our first morning we had a guide who could not engage adequately in the history, architecture and archaeology, and my wife, having read Lonely Planet, knew more than he did. We asked our hotel for a top guide, and for the next day and a half we had a magical, brilliant and informative experience. This is a fascinating man, just over 30 years old whose mother is Chinese and whose father (a Cambodian teacher who escaped death under Pol Pot) sent him away from his village to escape the Civil War; he became a Buddhist monk from 10 to 15 years old and was then accepted at an American sponsored orphanage in Phnom Penh. He is academically smart and knowledgeable, keeps up with the latest research, and speaks very good English. His name is Lach Kim Chhen, but everyone knows him as Kim. He has just set up a new business with some colleagues called Angkorpura Tour Guide Team, with a website under that name that is just going live and can be accessed through Google. Alternatively, you can email him at kim_angkortour@yahoo.com. I don't normally recommend particular guides or their businesses, but here the exception proves the rule. Kim will add enormously to the curious visitor's enjoyment of Siem Reap. I strongly recommend him.
Angkor!. The entire Angkor Archaelogoical Park area is outstanding. Everything is very well organized, well run and in great condition.

Must Visit. This is the most impressive archaeological site I have ever visited. Spend 4 days minimum if you can. 2 days is not enough! Save the Anchor Wat temple for last. Very crowded in January. Take one guided tour to learn the most and then use tuk-tuk drivers to avoid the crowds. Avoid the sunrise crowd at Angkor Wat unless you are assured of a good sunrise.

An amazing park. Don't underestimate the size of this park. It is huge, I had a tuk-tuk for 2 days and didn't see everything I wanted to see. Each temple has something different to add to the experience. Angkor Wat is the centerpiece, but I'd almost suggest visiting it last.

Awesome. I really dont enjoy temples very much they arent my thing but i went and saw the 3 i was most interested in angkor wat, ta prohm and angkor thom. They were all interesting and beautiful in there own different ways. It took about 4 hours with a tuk tuk and by the end i was done with temples and satisfied... if your not that much into temples you might want to consider something similar.

Everything That You Expected, And More. Four friends and I just spent two full days exploring the temples in the park with a guide, and were overwhelmed by the rich artistic and cultural heritage of the Khmer Empire. In two days we were able to only visit a fraction of the sites, but we did see both major and "minor" sites, and were fascinated by them all. Also, the entire park seems to be very well run and administered.

Awesome Area. This is th area in which many temples are located including Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom.This was better and larger than the Great Pyrimids in Egypt. You can climb to the top of many of these and go inside also. Plan to spend a couple of days here. Take water, it gets warm. There are also vendor where you can buy beverages.

One of the best experiences you will ever have. If you appreciate ancient sites like this then you will be in heaven. An absolute must see. Be ready for some exercise though, bring water, use sunscreen, prepare to sweat, etc. Use a local tuk-tuk driver and he will pick you up every morning and take you on a circuit to see most of the sites. We spent three days touring Angkor Wat sites, then on the fourth day our driver hooked us up with a car and we went to Phnom Kulen.

The whole Park. We spent two whole days exploring as much as we could in the time that we had. On the first day we had a guide and managed only to explore Angkor Wat, The Bayon, Ta Prohm and part of Angkor Thom. On the second day armed with the book "Ancient Angkor" we visited the Leper Terrace, Preah Khan where a tourist policeman showed us where to get impressive photos, Neak Pean, East Maybon and Pre Rup. Even with a tuk tuk at our disposal and good walking shoes we would not have seen more than a quarter of the total sites available.
Great visit. While there are many places to see I would make sure to add this one to the list. Had a great time and there was a lot to see.

Outdoor Cycling or Running. This Archelogical Park is so big that you will need atleast 2 days with proper transportation to visit all the temple..Most of the people that I´ve seen visiting the Temple are riding bicycle..Especially the foreigners or student cause the landscape is beautiful....I had a unique exsperience running inside the park before the sunrise..And I guarantee that you will feel completely satisfied and at peace within you..

Beautiful any day!. You could take a week or more to see everything. It's worthwhile taking time to walk around as much as possible. We had a guide for one morning but found that without a guide we could take our time, stop and smell the roses (so to speak), take photos at our leisure and just soak up the atmosphere! Just do your own research before you go and make sure you have a map of the area.A car with driver isn't expensive if you are wanting to get further out. We did this and found it an excellent way of getting further afield.

Not stroller friendly, excellent nonetheless. With a 2 and 4 year old in tow some of the temples were difficult to navigate but the visuals were stunning and there were elephants and some baboons to keep them excited. They had fun climbing around in and around the various temples.

Angkor - spectacular, crowded. Huge and fantastic archaeological park. It attracts hordes of tourists and you will be propositioned at every turn by local villagers trying to sell you knick-knacks, books, water, etc. One of them offered to find my brother-in-law a girlfriend.

Extensive Temples. The antiquity, although extensive and badly damaged, was well respected by visitors and guides alike. The stories behind their construction, use, demise and recent discovery lost in the jungle is absolutely captivating.

The best reason to visit Siem Reap. Most people, like I did, myself, think of the whole site as Angkor Wat but Angkor Wat is only the best preserved and the most famous of all of the complexes here. The whole Angkor site is massive and you'll need a three day pass, some transportation and a guide to do it even a little bit of justice. (Hint: Ta Prohm, or the Tomb Raider temple, isn't at Angkor Wat - it's closer to Angkor Thom and it took us about 10 minutes by van to get there.) Go early in the morning and later in the afternoon to avoid the worst crowds and heat.
Great Place. Great place for photos and to visit in the afternoon. There are lots of trees to protect you from the strong sun. Bring bug spray.

Incredible experience. The Angkor complex is huge, and 2 full days were really needed to do this justice. We had an English speaking guide for both days, which I would highly recommend so you really get a full understanding of what you're seeing. So glad I got to see this historic gem and would highly recommend you see it.

Best place in Cambodia. The reason to go to Cambodia. You kan make reservation true a travelagency but better is to do it with Tsoi. He speaks English, has a car for 4 passengers, airco and cool water. His phonenumber: 01/7976308. You can also "rent"him for other trips. I used him as a private driver for 12 days (1.200 km). He's not expensive and reliable.

This whole area is full of truly spectacular world heritage sites.. It would take a week at least to visit all the historic sites & buildings in this park. However 'must see' sites include the Angkor Thom walled city & its Bayon Temple, The Ta Prohm & obviously the Angkor Wat.

It's amazing, but why allow sellers inside the temples?. Its a shame that sellers are allowed into the temples themselves. outside the entrances is understandable and running the gauntlet is an accepted part of the experience. However, allowing them into the temples themselves detracted from the experience, understandably they are relentless, but when you're trying to view something, or want to stop for a photo, it's an issue. We ended up rushing through a few areas to avoid it.
Wow. So much detail and so much history. From the top of the tower at Angkor Wat you could almost see the ceremony and the splendour that must have once existed there.
Angkor Park.. Many Many temple to visit, 40$ 3 day ticket, Bayon Temple is my favorite a most do in siem reap, good shoes required.
so much to see. reasonably priced but a huge site to grasp, even in 3 days. It likely should be a week or plan for a repeat visit

If you didn't go here, you didn't visit Siem Reap nor Cambodia!. The title says it all. If you want to experience what Siem Reap or Cambodia has to offer, go to the Angkor Archaeological Park. For you to access the Park, you need an Angkor Pass which can be bought at the Angkor Archaeological Park ticket booth which is a slight detour to the right en route to Angkor Wat. The Angkor pass will be checked at every temple's entrance so don't lose it. The Pass's price depends on the length of visit you want. $20 for 1 day. $40 for 3 days (nonconsecutive, valid for one week after purchase). $60 for 7 days (nonconsecutive, valid for one month after purchase). I always get my Pass punched at the ticket booth area. Remember to make sure the officer at the ticket booth area punches the correct date on your card. You might lose a day due to your and/or his/her oversight. Note that the pass does not include the temples, such as Beng Melea (entrance tickets being sold at the site for $5), Koh Ker (entrance tickets being sold at the site for $10), and Preah Vihear (entrance tickets being sold at the site for $10). In the Angkor Archaeological Park, if only have a limited time to visit, you SHOULD visit just three temples: Angkor Wat, Bayon, and Ta Prohm. Angkor Wat because it is the most massive of all religious sites in the whole world; Bayon because of theunique face towers; and Ta Prohm because of its ruinous state and the many tall trees which grow out from the ceiling, walls, and columns of the temple's structure giving a romantic and virgin feel to the temple. If you have some more time left of your limited time, go to Banteay Srei to view the beautiful pink stone carvings left mostly undamaged by time, nature, and humans. Banteay Srei is farther away and it takes almost a hour's ride from the cluster of temples at the Big Circuit and the Small Circuit and Angkor Thom, give or take. Visiting all four temples should take up a whole day's worth of sightseeing if you just have a day. If you just have half a day, best to view just Angkor Wat and Bayon. If you're in Cambodia for the first time, drop by Siem Reap even for a day to visit the Angkor Archaeological Park. It is definitely worth the journey to Siem Reap, and it is your highlight in your stay in Cambodia.

Get your own driver if you can. There is just so much to see and do. Some of the smaller exhibits are great to visit and strangely if you are lucky you can view them almost alone - so many people just do the set trips and crowd round a few main temples.

Stupendous Site. This site is a must-see for any traveller. The sheer size of the park and the number of temples and other sights is mind-blowing. The art and architecture of the buildings is outstanding and well-preserved. The whole site is in a beautiful natural setting.

amazing temples but can`t hear the "buy scarf" etc anymore. yes the tempels are great and impressive.i am very interested in history and really happy i had the opportunity to visit them. what ruins it that at every temple you stop you will have sellers and beggars even before you get out of the tuk tuk. kids selling postcards or other small things, or they beg "1 dollar, ok", sellers with t-shirts, scarfs...if you say no than they change to "you buy cold drink, you want food,...." and will sometimes run minutes at your side and don`t stop insisting, asking you why you dont buy. hell, i can not buy drinks, food, t-shirts, scarfs at every single temple. the worst is that sometimes you have them also inside the tempel areas which is really annoying. be aware of the "freelancer" - guides, for expample inside the bayon of angkor thom. they approach you with some friendly words and then try to show you the temple. if you want this agree on the price in advance, if not make it clear. the most funny cause was a guy who tried to sell me one of the copied guide books. he was so eager to showme the official price, 27$ but if i buy his its "only" 1000 thai-baht. yes the people are poor, yes they are desperate and for sure we tourists are rich compared to many people here. but at the second day i really began to loose my temper about all this selling and begging. there are other ways to make a difference then to buy from kids or honour their begging.

A Must See. This is the catch all for all the individual temples contained within the park. While exhausting, it is worth doing both circuits and seeing all of the temples, as they all offer something unique.

Prioritize, cause that heat will suck your will to live!. Rather than write separate reviews for each of the individual temples, I'll include them in this overall review of the park. You probably know there's an inner and outer loop through this park that includes a number of temples and of course, you don't want to miss any of them! Real talk: if you only have a couple of days, prioritizing your "must see" temples is your best bet. Cambodia: it's hot and humid, and hiking through temples all day WILL take a toll on you. We had two days and wanted some variety, so here's what we did:DAY 1Take a private car out to the park at 4:45AM (I know; don't be a baby), pay for your 3-day pass at the gate, and then stake out a spot along the pools in front of Angkor Wat; you WILL need a tripod. Shoot the fantastic colors and reflections as the sun slowly makes its way to the horizon. Once the sun has lit up the area, you're done; unless you want to take pictures of the hundreds of other people that are crowding around the same spot. Next, walk around to the rear of the temple and head in to explore Angkor Wat. Once you're finished, hop in your car and head to Sras Srang to eat breakfast; you can pack one or purchase some food from a vendor. When you're finished, head to Ta Prohm to explore the temple; don't be afraid to wander away from the groups of tourists just starting to arrive. After you finish exploring, you may want to consider grabbing a cold coconut from a vendor to help re-hydrate and make you feel fresh again; the Elephant Terrace and Banyan are next. It's late morning by now and the hordes of tourists are starting to flood into the temples; you'll have to navigate through them, but the shadows on the faces of the Banyan still look really nice at this time. Once finished, head back to Siem Reap for lunch and some AC recovery.The remainder of the afternoon to sunset, you should take your private car to Tonle Sap and the floating village. There are fees for the trip (~$30 total) and a bit of a journey across the countryside and river to the lake, but we thought it was well worth it. You'll get to see the lifestyle of the villagers and you can even take a canoe tour through the floating village and water forest; well worth it. End the day with watching the sun set over Tonle Sap before you take the journey back to Siem Reap.DAY 2Take a private car out to the park at 5:00AM (I know; AGAIN) so you can watch the sun rise over Sras Srang. Explore the Bantaey Kdei temple after the light has risen and then have breakfast. Hop in your car and head to Beng Mealea for some really cool temple exploration; the earlier you get there, the more likely you'll avoid seeing other tourists. There are guides that will escort you through the temples because you'll have to climb through rubble and find your way through dark hallways; you'll actually feel like you're exploring the ruins. After your finished, you can greet the tour buses of people as you're leaving. Enjoy the countryside on the drive back and feel free to stop for some bamboo-steamed sticky rice and beans; they're quite tasty.If you have an additional day, I'd say head back to the park to check out additional temples. Take your time, take advantage of the coconuts for hydration, and try to avoid the hordes; it's difficult, but doable...

The place to start your explorations.. The Archaelogical Park includes just about everything you want to see during your trip to Siem Riep. You can buy a one-day ($20), three-day ($40) or seven-day ($60) pass. I suggest the 3 day pass as the best. One day is not enough to see this interesting place.The three day pass is valid for one week so if you need a break from visiting the ruins or head to the lake you can just choose which 3 days during the week you want to use your pass. They will take your picture for the ID. Most guides will gladly help you with the process but it is really easy. After a few formalities you can explore this incredible place.

MUST SEE!. A great look into the past in SE Asia amazing temples ancient ruins and perfect photos yes it's busy but what other great attraction around the world isn't defiantly a must see take your time and enjoy it.

Spectacular!!!. This should be a must do on every world travelers to do list! Incomparable sights! There is nothing else in the world like it! Antiquity at its finest! You could spend a year there an not see it all.

Iconic temple. it is very busy and can get crowded but it is certainly worthwhile you visiting. Make sure you put your pass to good use by re-visiting all the temples.However if ladies wear shorts or short skirts there are sections within the temples site that you are prevented from entering.
Explore it on mountain bike. Explore it on mountain bike ideally with a machete for the thorns and branches. Great fun, there are good trails in there and temples that can only be reached this way.

Large area with many temples. Angkor Wat is the draw. Yes, you must see it. Spend more time and several days to see some of the other temples. At a minimum also see the Women's Temple in pink limestone and the Temple in the Trees.

Take your time and enjoy. We spent 8 days in Cambodia and purchased a 7 day pass so we could come and go to the temple areas. The pass is inexpensive according to standards in most of the world. Where else can you get 7 day access to some of the world's most beautiful sites for under $70! It was wonderful to have the opportunty to take our time and not rush as we saw so many tourists doing. Have fun!
Cambodia's Pearl. I was deeply impressed with Angkor Archaelogical Park, I would love to visit it again... it's like going back in time 1000 years... most beautiful place

Spend your time here. Plane for at least 3-4 days for here. There are lots of things to see, one more amazing than the next. Don't rush it, avoid the crowds and the big tours. Hire a guide for a day, but take your time the rest of the trip to explore all the smaller sites and hidden gems!

A must see for Everyones bucket list!. I travelled here for business in 2011, and have done nothing but think about coming back for a year, so I decided to take a trip with my boyfriend and we are back to experience it all over again in 2012! Definitely worth every penny in flights, and every hardship of the damn travel day from bangkok getting here, lol.

The must see sights in Asia. The visit to Angkor was one of the highlights of my trip. The Angkor Archaeological Park is something mystical, absolutely wonderful immersed in the jungle but with temperatures sometimes unbearable, its comparable to that of Tikal in Guatemale...The monuments are in an excellent state of preservation, restoration and constantly easily accessible. The huge temple complex of Angkor is one of the must see sights in Asia

Must be seen over several days. The Angkor Archaeological Park is vast and you really need several days to do it justice. The heat generally limits people either seeing a sufficient number of the monuments or seeing those they do see properly. The park is open very early, so if you can it would be better to go when it is cooler and then rest in your hotel for the hottest part of the day. It will also be good for your tuk tuk driver to adopt this course.
A place for 4D3N. Angkor Archaeological Park is so huge and the longer time you visit there, the more surprise you get to know about Khmer Empire.

Vast Park!. It is absolutely truly amazing archaeological park and i liked all temple ruins inside. Been looked and walked around different temples and dates with peaceful ambiance that this best experience had never done before. you will love the culture, civilization and all stuffs here.

Worth the hype. You can't come to Cambodia & not visit. It's simply mind-blowing in its size, in the quality & number of carvings, & in the conflicting feelings of mystery, peace, tragedy & awe it generates in the visitor. Loved the funkiness of Ta Prohm, which had me looking over my shoulder to make sure I wasn't about to be encircled by a rogue root.Wanted to have a conversation with the faces at Bayon, which all looked like they had stories to tell.It can also be overwhelming - the size, the hawkers, the heat, the humidity - & after a few hours it all starts to look alike. For this reason, if no other, it makes sense to get the 3-day pass & break up your visit.
Angkor Archaeological park. Awe inspiring. Learn the history before you go to get the most from your experience. There are so many different areas reflecting different eras of Cambodian history.

This is the reason why you visit Siem Reap!. Outstanding architecture and design... place is huge but for the main highlights you can complete in a full day or day and a half. Get a good driver and book, and go at your own pace. Visit Angkor Wat first in the morning, since most tourist groups will hit it in the PM to see the sunset, so you can avoid the crowds.

Space it out. Since you are here for the experience of a lifetime, space it out to make the most of it. We started out early at 7.45 and ended the day by 4. Our route: Ta Prohm to avoid crowds -> Angkor Thom including terrace of elephants, terrace of Leper King, passed by Phimeanakas and climbed Baphuon -> Bayon (superb) and Angkor Wat. Second day: Kbal Spean, Banteay Srey, Ta Som, Preah Khan and Naek Pean. Day 3 ended the trip with a visit to the National Museum.

Wonder of the World. For a 20 dollar entrance fee per day, you have access to one of the most awe-inspiring and unique cultural sites in the world. You have many options for arriving there from bikes to tuk tuks to shared cars and minibuses and all transport and tours can be organized by any one of hundreds of hotels and gueshouses and tour desks in the city. The park entrance is only 15-20 minutes from most places in Siem Riep city. If you only have one day you can hit a few of the major temples but really that is too short a time to see all that the park has to offfer. I have been to Borubudur in Indonesia and it has absolutely nothing on Angkor. A must do in Cambodia!

Facinating. Probably the reason you are visiting Siem Reap, so not to much to add to the other reviews. My only piece of advice is don't overdo the it with the temple tours if you have children or teenagers in your group. One or two days is plenty, as the days are hot and long.

Wonderful. the whole park and all the temples are fantastic, due to the high humidity and rainfall the time spent there is pretty sweaty, so take plenty of water. The views are amazing and occasionally you get a pic with no one else in it!

Marvels of Cambodia. It is so interesting to learn about a civilization that existed more than 1000 years ago, their believes and culture were simply astonishing. It's definitely a must do thing once you are in Siem Reap.

WOW!. Without doubt the Angkor site is astounding and a treasure truly needing protection and careful management. Clearly if you have your sites on this region you will probably have the classic Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm and Angkor Thom on your must visit list. Just some advice to get the most out of your visit I would recommend hiring an accredited guide to take you through the various temples. They have cream coloured shirts with a badge verifying they are trained to show tourist through the temples. They will be able to show you the best temples, carvings and locations for photos. They will also know the history behind each temple and convey this. You can easily get a tuk tuk out there and wander around by yourself but for me you would miss so much unless you have some background in archaeology. There is also a good guidebook that you can get at the temple. It has a brown cover with colour pictures and detailed information on each ruin. It is easy to find as hawkers outside each site try to sell you a copy. Pay around US$5 for a copy.Personally you need at least three days to see the major ruins. Suggest you have a wish list prepared prior to arriving and discuss this with your guide. They will be able to best arrange making sure you can see as much as possible.Remember it is hot so take plenty of water, hat etc and be aware that there is some walking to do. There is really no wheelchair access available and you need to be reasonably fit to take on some of the more strenuous climbs. If you have the time try and visit some of the lesser known temples. Bantay Srei in my view is the best of them all as far as sophistication of the artwork and stone carving. Bantam Samrei is also a lesser known temple but you will be able to visit this without crowds and actually hear the birds in the background. If your'e lucky you may be able to hear some monks chanting in the distance. So make a wish list before you arrive, get an accredited guide to plan your itinerary( the extra cost is worth it), take plenty of water, leave at least three days to see the sites and don't forget some of the lesser known temples. These are the best. Enjoy!

wonderful, part of the beauty of cambodia all expained. like the cultural village, war museum and national museum, but this on your list - you will love it - visit by tuk tuk, take lots of water and small notes for trinkets

off the beaten track. make the effort to travel further afield and see Beng Mealea - absolutly amazing place - less tourists - take a tuk tuk from siem reap to see the temple then and travel back through the rice paddies and country side - awesome day

Bucket List. Angkor Wat is simply amazing. I really cannot believe there is even a ranking for this World Heritage Site. The scale of the temples and the genius of the water management systems boggle the mind. My only advice to anyone is, "Go to Angkor." The ancient Khmer Empire ranks with the Romans and the Greeks, if not higher, in terms of architecture and scale. Gorgeous. I really don't know if I will ever visit someplace as amazing as Angkor Wat.
Awesome!!. If you have been into this part of the world, don't forget to visit this place and you will be amazed of how this park has been formed on what it is today!!!

Can't wait to go back. Four days was just not enough time to explore every piece of this Park. It is overwhelming to say the least. To try and get ones head around how they built these wats, temples and pagodas is quite surreal. This is a definite must see before you die part of the world. Just magnificent !!!

hudge, beautiful and best place to visit in cambodia. 400 km2 of historical park. fee $ 20/40/60 (1/3/7 days) Ticket for 3 days has to be done in 1 week and ticket for 7 days can be done in 1 month.The complex is so hudge and have so much beautifull things inside. Do the small circuit if you have just 1 day. But take your time. Go there early till around 17:00 to see and explore everything. Big circuit can be done in half a day and so is the visite of the surrounding sites like Rolous group and banteay samre. Just hire a tuktuk for $ 12,- a day. There is a lot of walking and climbing inside the temples.If you visit cambodia you can not skip this place.(if you come from bangkok dont book the cheap (scam) tickets from khao san road !!!)

We'll be back as long as we can make the journey... We hired a photographic guide to help us. He took us to so many places and informed us that there were around 100 more in various states of repair or disrepair in the whole of the Angkor region, which I'm guessing is about 80 klm by 100 klm in area. It includes what looked to me to be one of the largest lakes in the World, complete with a floating town of many hundreds of boats, cafe's and houses, all part of the Mekong River complex.Cambodia is quickly joining the modern World so there's little to be afraid of now.

An excellent guide makes all the difference. I have always wanted to visit this site and I was not dissapointed. It was everything and much more. What made our visit most special was having a very competent English speaking guide to explain and help us to understand what everything represented. We spent three days with Sorn and saw most of what there was to see plus the floating Vietnamese village. My wife is 70 years old and at every stage we were save and secure and well looked after.Cold water and cold towels provided by the driver at every stop. Sorn spoke good English and was helpful even when my camera battery failed in getting a replacement. A very easy going, easy paced tour tailed to our needs. Anyone wanting a competent, trustful guide should contact Sorn at yannsorn@yahoo.com

Wonderful, But Tiring Day Out. We only had one day to spend at Angkor and wanted to make the most of it. We were picked up at 7.30am and returned at 4pm; hiring our tuk tuk and driver for $12 USD for the round trip. The drivers know the drill and for a one day visit will work around the petit circuit - we showed him on the map where we wanted to go and he took us. He also stopped a couple of places we hadn't planned on stopping at - one for monkeys on the side of the road, which was much appreciated and different points where he knew to get some good photos.The food inside them temples is on the expensive side ($5 for basic noodles) compared to restaurants in town, but they do have a captive audience and you will need to eat after a few hours of walking round the temples in the heat. Buy your water from the street sellers - large bottle of chilled water for $1 as opposed to $2 in the restaurants - it know it's only a dollar but as tesco say, every little helps.The child sellers are persistent and the teenagers from the restaurants near the lake can be quite aggressive when you say no, just be polite and keep moving.We thoroughly enjoyed our day but felt completely 'templed out' by the end of the petit circuit. If you have the time spread it over 3 days as we found we didn't appreciate the ruins at the end of the day the same way we did at the beginning which was a shame. It didn't stop me taking photos though - I went through 2 batteries throughout the day and filled 3gb of memory - take spares if you have them. We also downloaded a free app about the Angkor complex which provided us with information and insight that we wouldn't have had by simply walking round. Unfortunately a guide wasn't quite within our budget but the app provided enough info to keep us informed on our tour and we didn't feel we missed out by not having a guide.

Very Cheap Price for a Priceless Experience. I don’t understand why some find the admission fee expensive. I believe this is one of the cheapest priceless pleasures one can find nowadays. 40$ for three delightful days of sightseeing and experiencing these temples, each unique on their own, as old as 8th-century (Rolous group). How lucky we are that these temples are still there standing. As if they waited for us to behold their beauty and relive their stories. That amount we pay is probably for the wages of these locals working in the temples in the heat of the sun.What is 20 or 40USD? You go to Singapore and pay Universal Studios 60USD for just a single day of pleasure or 50USD for just a day of magical fun in Disneyland. If you are not into temples and ancient stuffs, Siem Reap is not for you. So we bought a 3-day ticket for 40$. In the morning we trekked Angkor Wat, then Sra Srang, Banteay Kdei, Ta Prohm, Ta Keo and lastly before lunch, Thommanon. In the afternoon we toured Angkor Thom: Terrace of the Elephants, Leper King, Phimeanakas, Baphuon & Bayon in that exact order. That completes the petite circuit temples on our day 1. On our day 2, we woke up at 4 am, left the hotel at 5 am, and reached Angkor Wat still dark but people already swarm the temple for the celebrated sunrise. We watched the sunrise by the reflecting pond, took photos & left the temple before 7. Then off we trekked the grand circuit temples. In the morning we were able to accomplish the grand circuit temples in the following order: Preah Khan, Neak Pean, East Mebon and Pre Rup. After lunch, we went to Banteay Srei, an hour drive from Siem Reap. An hour is enough to explore the exquisite Banteay Srei so we were able to get back to Siem Reap before 3pm. So we told our tuktuk to drop us to our hotel for a break & pick us up again at 4 to watch sunset at Phnom Bakheng. We enjoyed the elephant ride up the temple mountain.On last day of our 3-day pass, we left the hotel at 8 in the morning for the Rolous Group and visited the three temples in the following order: Bakong, Preah Ko and Lolei. Then we had lunch at Tell Steak in Old Market where I enjoyed my paborito carbonara. In the afternoon, we visited the Artisan Angkor with a cool guide, explored the Old Market for souvenirs and had frappe and croissant at a coffee shop at Lucky Mall’s second floor. Get a 3-day pass. You go to Siem Reap to visit the temples so make the most of it.

Mesmerizing. Indescribable feelings beyond words . It will take at least 4-8 hours depending on which site you want to see, so make sure you know which site you want to visit first, cos it will be energy consuming too especially during the hot season. The whole park is simply mesmerizing. The beauty of the ancient ruins doesn't fade with time. Simply beautiful and mesmerizing

A MUST!. If you are coming to Cambodia, you must come to Siem Reap, and you absolutely must visit as much or as little of the Park as possible. It is by far one of the greatest places on the planet I have experienced.

Too expensive.... Here has a lot of ruins.Its really amazing but so expensive,$20.Its good for people interested in ruins,but for me, not worth the time causeits boring for me to visit ruins.But if you like to visit ruins,must go there!

One of My Dream Destinations Come True!. Although we only did a one-day tour of the complex, we were able to see all the main temples. We started out extremely early at 5AM so that we could see the Angkor Wat at sunrise. It was already breathtaking as it is, even if we went during the rainy season so the angle of the sun was not the best for photos. We booked David (Sovann Eath) as our tour guide. He had a car and free unlimited bottles of water, that is why we were able to go to all the attractions within the day in good time. Ta Prohm (the temple with the trees growing within them) was great in the morning. There was a somewhat ethereal or mysterious feeling about the place, like the temples and trees were alive. Another complex near the Angkor Thom gate is the one that houses the North & South Khleang, the Elephant Terrace, Phimeanakas, and the Terrace of the Leper King. All of these can be viewed within 2-3 hours. Each place was absolutely amazing - the wonder of the intricacies of the carvings on the walls and how the temples were built and laid out.A short distance away from this complex is the Bayon Temple. This is a magnificent temple that had two thousand faces. It is easy to tour because you just have to go around and around among the floors. Another main temple to visit is the Phnom Bakheng which is on top of a hill, and is recommended to be visited during sunset. Best to visit this during the dry season, because it rained when we visited and so we didn't really see the sunset, plus we got wet. We got to ride an elephant going up the hill though, and that was fun (also we were already tired by this time after going to all the other temples throughout the day). The day trip costs $20 entrance fee, plus our tour guide for $60 (good for the whole group already, includes aircon car transport and free unlimited bottled water) but I would say that the whole experience was priceless! Must-visit for anyone who wants to soak up some history and culture!

stunning. A must see. Definately one of the wonders of the world. There is SO much to see. Please don't try and 'do' it all in one day.. this place rewards time spent. We got a 7 day pass $60US which is valid for a month (the punch a hole in it each day you go)... you can get 3 day passes too and they are certainly worth the money. Be sure to let your tut tut driver know whether you have a ticket or not as you have to get your picture taken for the pass which they do at the main ticket office. You DO have to show your pass at every temple, there are guards at the entrance to each, and they do really look at every pass carefully! We went for a leisurely approach and did Angkor Wat, and Angkor Thom as separate trips (partly due to the heat) (9-3pm each) and then another couple of days doing some of the smaller temples that were a bit more outlying. The distance between Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom is small... a few mins by tut-tut.

If you love history and culture, the Angkor Archaeological Park cannot be missed. The place is huge in size, with hundreds of small temples along with the Bayon, Angkor Vat, Ta Phrom etc. You need a week of time at least, to explore this amazing piece of history.

Take your time and let it all sink in. Angkor will always have a special place in my heart. We feel we have been given a gift. There are many temples and each one had something unique and memorable. Even though there were many other tourists at some of the temples, we found we could find some quiet and soak up some of the magnificence. A few things we will do next time - get a tour guide for some of the time. We feel we missed a lot despite the reading we had done. And we found we stopped truly appreciating the temples after about five or so hours so we stopped and came back the next morning. I think if we had kept going we would not have got quite as much from the experience. We really want to go back again!

Amazing temples. Amazing temples, and good to see so many countries pitching in to help with the mammoth restoration project. Be emotionally prepared to be harassed by children selling crap at the entrances to every temple and food place. They'll follow you down long walkways bugging you the whole way. Our guide touched a particularly annoying little girl's neck with an ice-cold bottle of water and she stormed off in a huff. Good man!

Every temple is worth at least 15-30 minutes with the highlights worth a few hours. This is one of the most stunning set of ruins I have ever seen in my travels around the world. I put these ruins only second to those in the Sacred Valley of Peru, but the main temples here in Cambodia are much closer together and far easier to access for most people.Hire a tuk-tuk, taxi, or bicycle (my preferred method) for the day and make sure you buy at least a 3-day pass. It is a crying shame, and extremely exhausting, to try to fit in even one of the minor circuits into a single day.

If you don't visit here you are a fool!. This is where all the temples are i.e. Angkor Wat, Bayon' Angkor Thom etc that you can find individual reviews on! There is a choice of day passes either 1, 3 or week with varying prices. We did the one day pass which was enough to see the main temples (mentioned above) but if you want to go further a field to the lesser known temples you will want a longer pass. We would strongly recommend getting a tuk tuk driver for the day. Cost us $20 for 6 hours plus $5 etc for sunset. This extra money was for the driver to get up really early. It is so worth the money. We got a fantastic driver who took us every where we wanted and when we wanted and he knew loads about the complex. We saw people biking around but the complex is huge, properly bigger than you realise. If its hot and with all the steps and walking around we wouldn't have wanted to then have to bike back to the town which we was told could be between 40-1 hour depending on your fitness. But if you have time and like biking then go for this. We had less time so went for the tuk tuk option. We would strongly suggest you visit this place. It is beautiful and such an amazing experience.

Huge - do not underestimate the size. You can bike it, but the park is 10-15 km from Siem Reap town, and even that will take a long time to bike. We visited by hiring a tuk tuk tour guide ourselves (also easily down through guesthouses). We visited two days and went for sunrise both days. Unfortunately there isn't much of a sunrise in the wet season. the first day we visited Ta Prom, Bayon, Angkor Tom, and Ankgor Wat. The second day we saw Srah Srang, Banteay Kdei, East Mebon, Ta Som, Neak Poam, and Preah Khan. Do research and know what you want to see. The tickets are printed with your photo on it. Plenty of food to eat inside the park.

one day pass is enough for me. i traveled a lot and see MANY temple... so when my friend sugest me to do 6 days pass. i was like, "why...." the complex itself was i have to say very impresive but for me one day pass for $20 is good enough. we start at 2pm and finish just before the sunset and we're pretty happy...

Amazing site. This is probably the best site to be visited in Siem Rep. With hundreds of temple ruins it makes an exciting outing.I do recommend you hire a guide to show you te most important sites and explain their history
a long day walking. it was pretty awesome but after about 4 hours it all looked the same. make sure you hire a guide & driver or you will not know where to go & what the story is at each temple.
A must see. What can I say - A wonder of the world... And amazing they keep it up in Cambodia (they try but not quite there yet in a lot of ways)

The reason for visiting Siem Reap. This World Heritage site is a must visit location in Cambodia. We did our trip using a driver/guide Sam Pho and he really made the visit for us as he was very informative on the history and culture of the area. We spent two days visiting the temples but it would be possible to spend a lot longer. We did not rush around trying to include too many temples as we wanted to be able to take in the atmosphere of the ones that we did visit and spend a bit of time photographing some of the amazing carving. This was well worth a visit.

Totally worth the fees and crowds. You can get a one or three-day pass- if you came to Siem Reap for the temples, get the three day so that you can go at your own pace. There are hundreds of stuctures in the area, and all are not centrally located in the larger park, so take your time and enjoy yourself. It's absolutely amazing what was constructed in the area, and many have different purposes, so its worth it to take your time. The buildings are gorgeous and special!

Incredible. This is reason why everyone comes to Siem Reap and deservedly so. The sheer size of the place is overwhelming. We spent 2 days exploring the temples, but to be honest we were suffering from temple fatigue on day 2. My recommendation would be to do 1 big day including sunrise at Angkor Wat, then Bayon and the others in Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm, and Preah Khan. We hired a tuk-tuk driver for $15 dollars a day who was great and explained about the different temples and told us stories along the way.

Huge wonder. The park is one of the best places in the world but make sure you get a few days to see it because most visitors get there for a day and get rush around without really see the best of the park.

Must see. This whole park was incredible. We had a driver through Mr Kriss (Alex) and a guide who he organised (Mr Chang) who showed us through lots of different temples, we would have missed so much with out him. I think I guide is really good idea.

one of many temples ........ if you wish to see the most major temples of angkor , you need a couple of days pass to see it . .. The angkor site is huge and this one is among the must see sites ...... there are tree formations and huge rocks and some ruins on this place ... i think the tomb raider-lara croft movie was shot here, there is some restoration in progress at these sites as well..overall its worth a visit once you there , try to get a guide it would be better to plan all the temple visits incase you have less time to explore or else you can do that on your own at your own time.........
Signage. Not enough signs including directions around the site.

Why isn't this a wonder of the world!. Second time here - just fabulous. The sight of Angkor as you come round the corner is something I'll never tire of! Lots of temples to see and you do get a bit 'templed out'! Key temples for me would be Angkor at sunrise, Bayon, Ta Prohm and the South Gate bridge. All fabulous. You can do them all in a day but it gets incredibly hot. Get a tuk tuk to take you round and wait for you - around $6-$10USD. A 3 day pass for Angkor costs $40USD - I found spacing the visits out a little means you cna relax and avoid the mid day heat! Great place.
So many temples, and all different!. The variety of architecture and style was brilliant.

Excellent!. Amazing place to visit that hasn't been overrun with tourists. I highly recommend hiring a private tour guide. We booked with Cambodia Trails and were highly satisfied! Our guide knew when to take us to top sites when crowds were low!

Must see. 400 km2 of temples in the jungle. Angor Wat and Angkor Tom are the best known temples. In the park you can also follow set out routes into the junge and 'discover' smaller temples. We got a 7 day pass, because it is the same price as 3 day visits. 3 day passes are also available, but then you need to visit 3 consecutive days. Travelling with two boys (aged 7 and 8) we needed to interleave swimming pool days, so a week pass was our best option. Hire a car or tuktuk with driver - depending on your preference for aircon - because the terrain is BIG.

Amazing, a definite must-see!. Wow, Angkor is truly amazing...! Make sure you buy a "more days" pass (4 days will be sufficient), because 1 day definitely isn't enough to see all the beauty.. I especially loved the one where they filmed "Lara Croft" (can't remember the name of the temple..). I went there alone. In Cambodia it's possible to "hire" a guy with a scooter or "tuc-tuc" for a day, he will bring you everywhere for a small fee. The people are also so friendly, I really love that country!

Well Worth the Entry Fee. The park is immaculately maintained so the entry fee is well worth it. Unfortunately the entrance to many of the temples is populated by hawkers who accost you from the minute you get out of your vehicle. Most of them are just annoying but a couple were quite unpleasant and I was glad I wasn't alone. Having said that, they are not allowed past the entrances so you are left alone to explore the temples

Very Impressive!. Try to stay more than 3 day if you want to see everything because is very huge. We stay for 3 days and is little short to many wonderful temple to look at!!!........Trust me you will enjoy a good massage at the end of the day.
A well designed park. A masterpiece of buildings and an area of anquities.
Over priced. Just a temple and at $20 pp very over priced. There are many other temples to visit in Asia at much better prices.

Impressive!!. One word describes it all: IMPRESSIVE!! I particularly liked the most Banteay Srey because of the materials that were used to build the temple. Really incredible. I also liked the Tomb Raider site because of the trees that were hovering above some temples. However, due to the weight perhaps of the roots of the trees, it needed some reinforcement. Metals were seen in the temples. Angkor Wat is also a must see. There were restoration happening inside the temple. Cambodia has a very rich history during the old times. Definitely a place worth visting.

Dont miss!. We did both the "small" and "grand" tours and so glad we hired a guide for both days as he gave us much more insight than reading historical information online or in a guidebook. Von Ven, our guide, spoke great English and you can tell that he tried very hard to expand his knowledge of the language and history of the sites through his tourism training. We loved all if the ruins...perhaps bantey srea.
Incredible. A walk through this park is incredible. There are trees growing on the top of roofs with the tree roots winding down the buildings to the ground. Never seen anything like it.

Grand (Big Circuit) Tour of Temples around Angkor Thom. Through our hotel we arranged to take a tuk-tuk for the "Grand Tour" (Big Circuit - so named because of the distance to be travelled between the temples) of five temples in the Angkor Archeological Park, including Banteay Srey, the "Lady Temple" (late 10th c Hindu). Since Banteay Srey was the temple farthest away, we began our tour there. When we reached Banteay Srey, also the hometown of our tuk-tuk driver, we stopped for a bit to meet his family and drink a young coconut with them, an unexpected bonus. Banteay Srey's relatively small size, pink sandstone construction, delicate almost filigree-like carving, and ornate design give it a surreal “fairyland” ambiance - incredibly beautiful, especially on a sunny day. Next on the list was East Mebon (late 10th c Hindu), a large temple-mountain-like ruin, rising three levels and crowned by five towers, dedicated to Shiva. It has beautiful, well-preserved elephant sculptures in each of the four corners, as well as two guardian lions at each of the four stair cases to the upper levels. From the topmost level we had a beautiful view out over the green and lush countryside beyond, some of which had not yet dried out from the recent mega-floods. Temple three, Ta Som (late 12th c Hindu), is a small monastic complex with beautiful carvings, a large gate topped by a stone portrait head, and is much like a smaller version of Ta Prohm, the “Angelina Jolie Tomb Raider” temple (as all the guides and tuk tuk drivers call it).
