Temple four, Neak Pean (12th c Buddhist), is a small island temple, the central building of which sits at the axis of a cross or lotus pattern of eight pools. Originally known as Rajasri, Neak Pean took its modern appellation, which means ‘coiled serpents,’ from the encoiled nagas that encircle the temple. The setting of this temple is beautiful but when we visited the area was still flooded; we accessed it along a wooden causeway over a lake boiling with mosquitos. After snapping a few pictures, we quickly made our way out again, me covered up with a sarong to avoid getting bitten. Finally, saving the best for last, we visited the magnificent Preah Khan (late 12th c Buddhist), a huge complex which originally served as a Buddhist monastery and school, engaging over 1000 monks. We approached the temple along a grand boulevard and bridge lined with gods and demons struggling, like the earlier bridge we’d seen into Angkor Thom. Here only one head remains; the rest had all been eroded away. Once inside we were greeted with grey, green, and red walls sculpted with bas reliefs of apsara, warriors, firefly-Tinker Bell-like women along the top edges of inside walls, and huge fig and silk-cotton trees growing out of and into the building’s stones.We didn't have a guide, just our tuk-tuk driver, and could spend as much or little time as we wished at each place. The driver also took us to an inexpensive local eatery near one of the temples and waited while we had lunch. At most of the temples food, drinks, and souvenirs are available for purchase. The Angkor temple pass is purchased at the Park entrance and costs $20 for a day, $40 for 3 days, and $60 for 7 days. Our tuk-tuk and driver cost $25. We did this trip without a guide; if you wish, one can be hired to go with you. We left our hotel just outside "downtown" Siem Reap at 8 am and were back by around 5 pm. Make sure you have lots of water, a hat, sunscreen, and mosquito repellent.This tour of Angkor Thom was incredible; the temples, and their setting in a large parklike area with beautiful enormous trees, are breathtaking. I have seen a lot - a lot! - of ruins, and this site ranks right up there with the best ever, a once in a lifetime spectacular must-do. See more information and pictures here: http://lmaclean.ca/2012/01/grand-tour-of-temples-around-angkor-thom-cambodia/

Wonderful Angkor Archaeological Park. The Archaeological Park (Unesco Heritage) comprises a huge area of about 200 square kilometer around the Angkor Wat, consisting of a large number of temples built during about 9th to 14th centuries. A number of temples is a bit further away (o.a. Beng Melea, about 75 km from Angkor). To see the most important temples you need to organize transportation: car with driver, taxi, bike or, most popular: tuk tuk.The park is most amazing and worth at least a few days visit.
Awesome and Majestic. The temples are majestic and it was really awesome! I would suggest to hire a guide to get to know the temples better.
Nature. i loved the big trees. it was beautiful and well kept. what i didn't like was the peddlers trying to pester you to buy their wares and then overcharge you.

Amawzing trip.. The Angkor Park comprises a mutlitude of Citie qnd Temple element from the Angkor region between 8th and 14th century.. Highlights are Angkor Wat, the Bayon, TaProhm and Bantay Kdei. You will see all kinds of things in the park, elephants walking around, and it is the main area which is just outside Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat, the Terrace of the Elephants, etc. It's an open area. Expect to spend a few days if you want to see it all! Is a once in a lifetime historic visit.. and will leave you in awe... Ensure if you do not know the history that you get a guide to truly experience it! fresh air, delicious food, photo opportunities, and general charm of people and environs. Artisans de Angkor offers visitors a free tour of their stone and wood carving facilities, and sells high-quality handicrafts. Traditional handicrafts of the region can be had at the Asia Crafts Center. Do not miss the Old Market and Night Market for some amazing souvenirs. You can even have rides on elephant back, in hot air balloons and in helicopters. have a amazing trip.

World heritage site worthy of lengthy visit. The Angkor Wat complex is worth at least a 3 day pass to visit. Each site is different and quite unique. We visited 10 sites and for 2 days used a tuk tuk and on the third day hired bicycles. Get a good guidebook such as National Geographic, Insight Guide or a book called Angkor available from vendors. Otherwise you can hire a guide to explain the sites. Sunrise at Angkor Wat is a good idea but visit the site straight after this so as to avoid crowds, then return to your hotel for breakfast.Be sure to visit Preah Khan, Ta Prohm, Phimeanakas, Banteay Srei, Angkor Thom and Bayon.
Incredible temples in natural surrounding. Very clear why it is a World Heritage Site. A definite stop on any trip through Southeast Asia.

Absolutely fantastic!. One of the best experiences of my life, the temple complexes are incredible! We spent three days exploring the area by tuk tuk and would go back in a heart beat. The Khmer temples are all very impressive, and each offer something unique. Bayon Temple can be seen from the back of an elephant for example.Expect to run a gauntlet of people selling local handicrafts at each temple, but it's more than worth the annoyance. If you are after a souvenir, you can barter with the salespeople and items are generally cheaper the farther from Angkor Wat you get.

Must spend more than a day for sure. So much to see that you really need the multi day pass as last time I only bought the one day . The grounds are break taking and take you back hundreds of years in a culture that was almost lost
Awesome. It was everything we hoped it would be and more. Spectacular

timing timing timing. to squeeze the most of your siemreap trip, timing is a must. so keep 3-5days, get a good driver (tuktuk or taxi), spend some more on a reliable guide. and time each site - when to go, how much max time to spend there, routing etc.
Unmissable. Don't forget to take water. $20 for a day pass. If you go at 5pm you can get tomorrow's ticket and you can catch Angkor Wat at sunset.

One of the best things I've seen in my life.. Yes is one of the best things I've seen in my life and all Cambodia what a place beautiful people and lots of things to see and do. I will definately go back there and stay more time.

Breath-taking ..... It has been a childhood dream to visit this site. I visited in Feb 2010 and found the heat too unbearable and spent most of the time dashing from shade to shade. The site itself was quite dry and dusty.ReturnMmed in June this time. It is wetter so more humid. Benefit though is it is much greener and less dusty.Previously we hired a guide and did a one day tour. Very busy and exhausting. This time we bought a three day pass and hired a tuk-tuk driver. Allowed us to visit the sites in the morning while relaxing at the poolside in the afternoon. Much more relaxing way of doing it. The tuk-tuk option also allows you to feel much closer to the environment as you drive through sites. Initially I thought the lack of air conditioning would be a problem. Not at all dear reader, the breeze while driving on the tuk tuk is refreshing and has benefit of allowing you to dry off. Strongly recommend this.Benefit of coming in June is that there are not as many tourists. There is the possibility of afternoon downpours but these are shortlived and adds to the Asian experience.Love this place ...

Magnificent. The Angkor Archaeological Park is home of the Khmer temples of Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and dozens of other ancient ruins of the Angkorian era. It encompasses more than 400 sq kms on the outskirts of Siem Reap and is a World Heritage Site.Passes to visit the site are sold in one day (US$20), three days (US$40) and seven days (US$60). The three day pass is valid for one week and the seven day pass can be used within the month and not necessarily consecutively. I suggest getting the three day pass to be able to enjoy the temples at a leisurely pace. It is also important to have the pass on you at all times as there are guards to inspect them at every temple before entry. Wear light airy clothes and proper footwear as it is hot and there are lots and lots of steps to climb. To enter the inner sanctum of the some temples one need to wear clothing that cover the knees and arms. Brings lots of water and mosquito repellent for the sunset tours. The temples are too far apart so it is impractical to walk. Tuk-tuks are cheap and even cycling can be an option. There are also elephant rides especially up Phnom Bakheng.Third trip to Angkor and it is still as magnificant and magical! Looking forward to my next visit.

Angkor Wat. You'll need at least three days to explore. Go early, seek out an air conditioned restaurant for lunch, drink lots of water and enjoy the amazing things to see and photograph here. Skip the sunset, but go for sunrise-crowded but way cool. You'll need a tripod and brings some thing to sit on like a tarp. Get there early it will be crazy crowded.

WOW! JUST WOW!. I had always dreamt of coming to Angkor Wat but even when I got here I couldn't believe how massive and impressive it was. We walked through it and it almost seemed never ending. We had a great tour guide with us (whom we booked through are hotel) who was so knowledgable and fun. We tipped him well, to say the least.A must MUST MUST visit!

Huge green complex to explore, so natural.... This complex is much bigger than I expected! So green, beautiful forest, so natural... Of course I went there for the Angkor Wat, but driving between one temple to another is fun... There's an area with many elephants wall sculptures which is beautiful, in between famous temples there are many other small temples...Unless you know where you're going and have done many researches, it's better to hire a tour guide to save time & avoid to get lost.Different transportation can be used to explore this complex, bycicle for those who likes exercising, Tuk Tuk is a common transportation, or cars.
Superb. It's such a beautiful area and the sites are stunning. Spending time here is a real delight and should be high on anyone's wishlist.

Take 3 days. I spent 3 days touring the park via Tuk Tuk with friends. For one of my friends, it was his 4th trip there and he was thrilled to be back. There is just no place like this in the world. Everyone who thinks about going to Siem Reap knows about Angkor Wat. It is amazing and worth a couple hours at least, more if you want to follow the Ramayana epic in detail. However there are dozens (hundreds?) of other temples in the park. Spend some time reviewing a book about the many temples so you can plan out your day and minimize driving time. Some temples can be as much as a 45 minute drive by tuk tuk from the central Angkor Wat/Banyon temple area, but there are great ones some distance out. Dress appropriately as this these temples are still active places of worship (long pants for men). It's going to be hot, so wear comfortable shoes and cool fabrics (think seersucker, linen, or summer-weight cotton like madras). Drink plenty of water and a few ice cold coconuts.

Biking through Angkor. I highly suggest renting a mountain bike for a day and biking around Angkor! I was in Siem Reap May 2012 and rented bikes from town at the Green Bicycle rental place just across the street from Viva! and the Old Markets. I ended up biking about 40km's in total from town through Angkor's large circuit and back into town. Very nice and relaxing (make sure you take a lot of water- especially in May when it's really hot out!). When you get to the South gate of Angkor Thom you can go up onto the wall and following it along the outside wall of Thom. I saw maybe 4 people in total on the wall- so it's quiet and beautiful! I continued along the wall until the North gate, where I continued from there along the large circuit. Not much traffic on the roads so it was quite safe being on a bike. A must-do if you love biking/staying fit/want to see something not many visitors do!
Incomparable. I had, of course, heard of Angkor, but I had no idea of its grandeur. A one-of-a-kind treasure.
Make me impressive how all temples was built. So impressive for all temples in its park. Angkor Wat is my favorite. if you have time try for sunrise also as it will worth to visit.

Add to your bucket list. Angkor Wat was my wife's idea and initially I wasn't overly excited but I was wrong. This whole park will blow you away. There are multiple complex's (Angkor Wat being the most famous) and each is stunning. The whole park is well preserved and accessible. As a bonus, I loved Siem Reap. We went siteseeing during the day and went out on the town at night. Plenty of great places to eat, cabs are obscenly cheap so you only walk as much as you want, and the people are very friendly. We spent 3 days there, that's about the perfect amount of time. We also hired a local guide. You can probably get away without it if you do some research ahead of time. He tried to take us on some pre-programmed route he had and we really had to push him to deviate to the things we wanted to see instead.

Amazing site, huge, well preserved.. Go in the morning, as it can get very hot in the afternoon, and not much shade. It's great to have a tour guide, as there is much to be explained, but you can also roam freely on your own if its history is not of interest. Take water and a good hat. The climb of the center temple, the largest, is steep but provides a great view of the entire park. If you don't want to climb there is still a great deal to see in the inner courtyard. Pay attention to the engravings; they are remarkable and all are different. The immense moat is remarkable.

Amazing. It's hard for me to choose what temple I like the best. They are all so amazing and beautiful. I loved all of the ones we saw. I would recommend a tour guide. We could have easily gotten lost a the bigger ones without one. It was also nice to hear the history about how they were built and why they were built. He also showed us places for good pictures. We didn't have guide for the Rolous group which was fine because we went after we saw the bigger stuff.

Impressive site well worth the visit. The reason why we went to Siem Reap. I was much looking forward to visiting the main temple (Angkor Wat) and the city (Angkor Thom) and was not disappointed. The structures still standing are magnificent enough to convey the idea of past splendour. The size of the complex is huge. You can easily walk a whole morning just to visit Angkor Thom, which is what we did. We spent the afternoon in Angkor Wat, said to be the world's largest single religious monument. We had a very good guide, who took us around and showed us some remarkable sights and the most interesting bas-relief. The walls of some buildings are decorated with exquisite bas-relief depicting the various gods, goddesses, and other- beings from mythological stories and epic poems of ancient Hinduism. It would take hours to observe carefully just a single one of them.We visited Angkor Wat during a Buddhist ceremony and found the circumstances particularly lucky to take some interesting pictures.It was well worth the visit, despite the oppressive heat and humidity and the crowd. I would recommend you visit with a guide, otherwise you are going to miss a lot.
Nice to see. Enjoyable to wander around for a day. The children begging is very upsetting though
Fatastic. Fantastic Park we loved it here. It was a great tour organised by our Hotel and an excellent day out a must do must see when in Angkor Seim Reap
Words cannot describe the immense beauty and size of this place.. Absolutely awe inspiring place. Be careful of some touts joining you as you walk and try to get you to pay them as a tour guide.
Amazing.... Honestly, the Coliseum in Rome is no longer AS impressive to me! ;)

Archeological wonder!. The temples and ruins making up the Angkor Archeological Park are worthy of all the accolades heaped upon them. Profoundly moving and fascinating, the shear scale of the endeavors of craftsmen and labour of centuries ago is incredible. Everyone should see Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and the rest of the park at least once.

Wow!. My son and I spent 3 day visiting the area in mid May. There is a reason why it's also called the 8th Wonder of the World. Wow! This was our itinerary:1) Beng Mealea -an hour from Siem Reap. Really different: the jungle ate the temple, here. It's cooler and not very crowded. It's big. We did it in 3.5 hours. But, you can do the main part in 1.5 hours. If you like to walk around, it can take you the whole day. In the afternoon, we went to the floating village.2) Angkor Thom, Little circuit (Ta Keo, Ta Prohm.Banteay Kdei, Prasat Kravan) and Angkor Wat. Sunset at Phnom Bakheng. Very crowed, but extraordinary. Very hot, not a lot of places to hide from it. Whole day.3) Sunrise at Angkor Wat, Banteay Srey -35 km North of Angkor Wat-,Kbal Spean -5 km North of Banteay Srey, and Big circuit (Preah Khan,Neak Pean,Ta Som, East Mebon, Pre Rup). Banteay Srey and Kbal Spean (a waterfall with stone carvings) are very different. Worth a visit. Also, whole day.It's very hot and humid, especially in March-May (when we went). We've been told that the good side of May is smaller crowds. Also, there's not a lot of rain.Tips for May.You have to walk a lot in the temples. The heat and humidity are tough on your body. My son lost 7 pounds and I lost 4 pounds. Tips: 1) Hire a car with A/C (around USD 30 per day, though for more than 1 day, you can get it down to USD 27-USD 25 range). You'll get to see more. In addition, the cars provide cold water for free.2) Go to Kbal Spean (the waterfall) and bring a swimsuit. Very refreshing.3) Drink a lot (a big bottle will cost you in the park USD .50. You need to bargain a little bit.)4) Bring white or clear shirts (you may need to change it during the day).5) Sunscream is a must.6) Bring and wear a good hat.7) There were not a lot of mosquitoes. But, just in case, bring a good repellent (15% deet or more).8) If you are not in decent physical shape, it may be a good idea to exercise before going there. I saw several exhausted people taking long breaks.

amazing ! must be done more than once in a life time. take your time at least 3 days and go with one guide, try to avoid the group trips you will losse form the experience! you need to be able to take your time, stroll, take pictures, have explanations, take an elephant ride....group tours are just horrible, they rush you through, and you do not actually exprience the breath an size and details.

Angkor Archaeological park. Everywhere in the Angkor Archaeological Park is amazing i would highly recommend travelling also to some of the smaller temples that are less frequented than Ta Promb, Angkor Wat and Bayon.
VALUE FOR MONEY.. We paid for a 3-day visit. I should say I got the most from my money's worth.

Angkor Archaelogical Park. If someone were to say to me what is the most amazing thing you have ever scene my reply would be the Angkor Archaeological ParkThe experience of going and seeing this place is mind blowing I had seen many photos and also read a lot about the area but seeing it first hand is something to remember for the rest of my lifeAt the advice of others we did a tour of the region with a guide and this was probably the best way to go seeing others being annoyed by local youths made me pleased that we had done soThere is a large area to cover so we had a three day pass this proved to give us plenty of time to see Angkor Wat as well as Bayon and the temples of Angkor Thom It does get very hot so a hat is necessary as well as taking waterWe did not do the sunset tour many that did told us it was lovely but an awful long way to walk

Get cycling, get involved!. The Angkor complex really is top of the agenda for most people who come to Siem Reap and it can be overwhelming deciding what to see and what not if time is limited. Definitely, if you can, get a multi-day pass (3-day should be sufficient if you want to see lots but also spend good amount of time at each) and for the furthest away temples such as Banteay Srei arrange a tuk-tuk to take you there and you can stop off at the other temples along the way or even to say hi to the local farmers if you wish. If you do head to Banteay Srei don't forget to find the musicians often playing at the back of the complex - these people are all victims of landmines who are playing music to better their lives. And do not forget to stop off at the Landmine Museum ($3 entry). It is quite a small museum but well worth a visit for information on Cambodia's troubled past and a good example of a successful community project.The other days you should try to start early and go cycling. It is no doubt the best way to see the archaeological complex and to really engage with the environment - there is lots of opportunity to engage with the locals or make a stop to see monkeys, birds, snakeas along the way. You also notice a lot of the smaller, quieter temples if you cycle and get to really appreciate just how amazing this archaeological site is.Ta Phrom and the Bayon are probably most people's favourite temples: Ta Phrom is where Tomb Raider was filmed and really is a very romantic, awe-inspiring location where trees grow out of temples and just has a really ancient other-worldy feel about the place. The Bayon is a beautiful temple is surrounded in contemplative Buddha heads which form towers everywhere. However, any temple you visit should impress you.If you get hungry don't disregard the local food that is on offer at each of the sites. not only is the food reasonable but you can get the opportunity to sample a lot of local cuisine for a very good price particularly if you use the roadside stalls off of the main sites. If you are at Angkor Wat and fancy a refreshment then visit stall 94:Jastins and look out for the ladies selling scarves nearby too - these people are from the villages on the Angkor archaeological complex (you probably won't see or even notice these villages as they are tucked in and behind the jungle and off the road).These men and women are seriously just trying to make a wage to feed their families - so a $1 scarf that you might not need really can make a difference to people's lives.

So glad we went. Angkor is a must see and should be on everyone's list of places to travel. I recommend going to the temples early in the mornings, before the tour groups get there and when it's slightly less hot outside. We would leave our hotel at 6am and when we were at the temples, they are so big it felt like we were the only ones there and even had to learn how to use the timer on our camera because there was no one around to ask to take our picture. It was really special and I highly recommend a trip to Siem Reap and Angkor Temples.

Ta Prom was the star. We had transport and a guide booked. The one day ticket was sufficient for us to see the 3 main sites of Angkor Wat, Ta Prom and Angkor Thom. All 3 sites are stunning, but Ta Prom was my favourite. Quite crowded but by late afternoon there are very few people about and it is cooler. Wonderful photos to be taken everywhere. The guides, on the whole, are hard to understand but very keen to learn better English. Cambodia is desperately poor, but the people are lovely.

Truly unbelievable.. I can't imagine why you wouldn't go here even once after spending all the time, money and effort to travel to Siem Reap. Angkor Wat is great, but there are certainly other spots like Bayon, which are truly mind blowing. My number one suggestion to prospective visitors to Angkor Archaeological Park is to do your research. There's lots to see and you will likely have limited time. Siem Reap gets very hot and humid especially towards the middle of the day. Depending on your endurance and heat tolerance, you may decide to cut short your "full day" at the temples or else split your day to avoid the hottest times. You may also get Temple overload and require a break from touring.Consult multiple sources including this website, guidebooks, travel blogs, etc... Things that I think would be helpful to know:1) I recommend hiring a driver for approximately $25/day to take you around in a Camry. I've had friends who rented bikes and loved it. Others have rented tuk tuks (look it up). The roads are dusty. Short breaks in an air conditioned vehicle can extend the time you're willing to walk around in the heat. There are some worthwhile archaeological sites outside the park, which require a car to get to. This guy: Rous Kim http://www.taxiservice.comli.com/...treated us fairly, spoke English well, and was eager to talk about his country and its recent past. He also bought us some awesome local snacks. 2) There are officially certified guides who you can hire to personally show you around. Generally, you hire them separately from your driver. We did not hire a guide, and we sort of regret it. You can also haggle a cheap guide book from a vendor. Not the same. 3) Although Cambodia is one of the poorest nations in the world, we saw very few people begging for money. Kudos. Most people tried to sell us souvenirs or unofficial tour guide services. Do not fear, most "vendors" will allow you to view the ruins in peace and will not follow you into the archaeological sites. 4) For those reviewers who say they got "scammed," at the most, they paid the price of a Happy Meal or two. You shouldn't have to pay more than the price of a Happy Meal for any ONE thing except for your hotel room, your driver, your guide, and goods/services at a place that accepts credit cards (e.g. fancy restaurants, nice spas)..

Beautiful Temples. Amazing place to visit if you enjoy ruins. Filled with story, it's even more amazing if you have a guide besides you to explain the history behind each stone. Definitely worth seeing. The best thing around Siem Reap for sure!

Put it on your bucket list. As far as the temples go they are simply incredible, I think there is enough written in other posts to back that up. Just be cautious of the locals.. it's a typical tourist trap and they are out to get our money. I recommend taking plenty of water (min 3 litres per person) and pack your own lunch too. Don't underestimate how hot it is out there and it is a looooooong day. All in all though it is a must see!

Angkor Wat. Impress with the temples , considering it take 37 years to built as compare with the remaining 6 wonders . It was rather hot when I visited this place but cooling weather may means more tourist .I very impress with the carving which also showed the hindu and the overlapping buddist era . There was lot of chinese tourist when I was there .

What a wonder!. It's difficult to comprehend the history surrounding the Angkor Wat Conservation Park. It's best to visit with a guide who provides the stories behind the carvings, buildings and so forth. I've visited three times now and am still learning. It's astounding!!

Give it plenty of time!. There is SO much to see. And it was very hot, so I'm glad we didn't have to pack it all into one day so we could go back to the hotel and rest when we wanted to. We had three days and took bicycles for one full day, then a tuk-tuk once for sunrise and a morning and once for an afternoon and sun-set. Perfect.

Centerpiece of Cambodian tourism for a good reason. In comparison to the Incan, Mayan, and Aztec ruins, I didn't find anything at Angkor that was individually as mind-blowing, but the sheer scale of the ruins guarantees that there will be something that touches everyone. We decided to spend four days in Siem Riep, and bought a 3-day ticket to Angkor. They are smart about the pricing because I think most people would be satisfied with what they could easily visit in two days, but it was nice to not be rushed.On our first day, we took a Tuk Tuk out to Kbal Spean and hit the outlying elements of the large circuit on the way back. This was nice to get perspective.On the second day we rode bikes to Angkor Wat and started off there. I was initially disappointed that I wasn't blown away when I walked in the entrance. Maybe it was the green covering they have up for restoration, or maybe it was the fact that I wasn't yet in the right mindset. We spent the rest of the day walking the small circuit which ended up being much more difficult than we had expected. At the end of the day we came back upon Angkor Wat from the back, as the sun was about to set, and then it was truly breathtaking. No crowds, no green tarp, just a quiet magnificence. Like hiking to Macchu Pichu, maybe part of the experience is making a pilgrimage and suffering a bit before you see the structure.On the third day we rode back to Angkor Wat to see the middle section which was closed the previous day. That is worth standing in line for. Then we rode out to the Roluos Group which wasn't a nice ride on the highway nor were the ruins too spectacular having already seen the rest of Angkor. Maybe a better idea would be to split up our second day into two days for the 3-day ticket holders.

Beware of 'guide scam' if visiting after 5pm!. As suggested in many travel books, we visited the complex after 5pm to see the sunset after purchasing a ticket for the following day.On entering the temple area, we were accosted by two young men who started talking to us about the carvings on the walls. This was a scam! Beware of being 'accompanied' by helpful 'students' who only wanted to tell you more about the site but then demanded money for their services as 'guides'. We felt very threatened by this as they said that unless we paid them they would be arrested by the police. One (possibly an evening security guard with a walkie talkie radio) asked for $20 to allow us to go to the highest tower as it was not officially open. We declined. This practise of preying on unsuspecting tourists should be stopped as it spoils the pleasure of visiting such magical surroundings.After our poor first experience, on visiting the temples on the following day, they were all absolutely amazing. Our tuk tuk driver took us from one temple to the next and, having started out from the hotel at 5am to see the sunrise, we had seen most of the big temples in the group by lunchtime and had a pleasant, cooling drive to one of the furthest out of the temples. This had a much more touristy feel than the others but was equally as stunning. Amazingly, they are all so different but all magical in their own way. It was a visit I had always wanted to make and I was not disappointed!
awasome place. very beutiful place. Must visit when go to Siem Reap

AMAZING!. If you arrive to Siem Reap it is simply because of Angkor Wat. It is absolutely beautiful and amazing! You need more than one day ($20 per ticket) to see the best of it. It is massive and some temples are far away from each other (Banteay Srei is more than 30km from Angkor Wat and it is a must!). We bought a 3 day pass ($40) to have time to explore fabulous temples and to watch sunset over Angkor Wat. I am very happy I went there as it is one of the most beautiful places in the world i have been to.
great temples and history. 3 days is more than enough if you have no special interest

Eight Ancient Wonder!!. If the Eighth Ancient Wonder of the World had an address...Angkor Wat would be it!! Be sure to wake your booty up at 4:30 AM for a sunrise entrance to the park. You body may not appreciate the first call reveille, but your memories & photo album will be rewarded for life!!!

Unbelievable!. I was completely speechless (very rare) when I first arrived at Angkor! An unbelievable site and on such a huge scale! You cannot see everything in one day so I would recommend a 3 day pass. You also need to go to Bakhang mountain to see the sunset.The only thing that would be a slight dislike is that there was quite a lot of work going on to preserve the site, which restricted some of the views. This is a completely selfish reason though.MUST SEE!!!
The Temples. The temples at the Angkor Archaeological Park is an amazing site and has an incrediable history. It´s also very beautiful and worth of visiting.

a world of wonder. We were amazed by the size and complexitivity of the structure. It's history and each temple has a story to make the history very colorful. It makes you wish you could go back in time to see it in all its selendour. I wonder how many structures we have built today would of stood the test of time this has.
Very educational.. This place gave us an overview of what to expect once the actual visiting of each individual temple starts.
Well organised.. Crowded but organised well and clean. There are WCs and restaurants and annoyingly shops, but they need the money so get over the constant 'you want scarf'.

Astounding. Visited 3 times in all. 2 or 3 day passes cost the same, so asked for 3 days. Went up the hill for sunset. At Angkor Wat for the next sunset, and Banda Srei for the 3rd. Also went to Bayon, Angkor Thom, Elephant Terrace and Leper king. Rode the elephant around Bayon. Took millions of photos and still can't believe it. Hired a guide for the 1st morning at Angkor Wat, but not otherwise. Children are annoying, but also very poor, you must decide what to d when they approach you.
Out of this world. Get there early to beat the masses. Feels like stepping back in time, an incredible place and monument to Cambodia's history.

An unforgettable journey. The Angkor Archeological park is truly one of the greatest and remarkable cultural sites in all the world. No book or photo can aptly or adequately capture or describe the breath-taking vastness, awe, and wonderment of this World Heritage cultural site. (Strongly recommend "Ancient Angkor" by Claude Jacques and Michael Freeman) We had read that people take hundreds, even thousands, of photos and we thought we could show restraint. We, too, ended up taking over 1,000 photos over the six days. A celestial apsara here, another apsara there... a 7-headed serpentine naga here; another naga over there... long corridors of bas-reliefs depicting battles; elaborately carvings; trees and vines growing out of stone; some temples in ruin and rubble, others amazingly still standing a thousand years later. The typical organized tours of SE Asia usually only allow a day or two, but that is NOT enough time for full appreciation of the splendor of the Angkor complex. One truly needs a minimum of 3-5 days to do justice... Schedule a couple of day trips to the outlying temples, including and especially Beng Melea. One would think that after you've seen one temple, you've them all. Not true. Each temple has its own unique character: Angkor Wat with its quincunx structure; Beng Melea, truly the "Jungle" temple; Bayon, the serene temple with huge stone Buddha images facing north, south, east west; Ta Prohm of Lara Croft-Tomb Raider fame with trees and vines growing out of the stone structures; Banteay Srei, aka the "Citadel of Women" with elaborately carvings in the pink stone; too many to describe. We hired a private car and driver for Beng Melea some 40 miles outside Sie Reap. For other outlying temples and structures, we booked with VillaSiemReap.com (which coordinates with BeyondUniqueEscapes.com). This well-run company limits the group to 8 people. For the two tours we took with them, there were only 4-5 people --it was just as good as having the private guide and driver for the Beng Melea trip. The visits to Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom and the outlying temples were THE highlight of our month-long trip to SE Asia (Cambodia, Vietnam, Thailand, Singapore). Because of the heat and humidity, some parts can be physically demanding due to lots of climbing, especially over uneven stone steps and rubble. But we saw people with walkers and canes bravely taking one step at a time. Inspiring! Carry PLENTY of water. The heat cannot be understated (and we went during the "cool" time.) There are mosquitos, especially in the outlying areas. Bring plenty of Deet. Long-sleeve light-colored cotton shirts, as well as mosquito nets to cover the face, offer protection from sun and mosquito bites. We found Johnson's OFF clip-on fan-circulated mosquito replellent to be relatively effective -- mosquitos swarmed around other people. Occasionally we would hear an aggressive mosquito zing by us.

A Must visit place in the world. I like the ticketing system where the authority will print your face on the ticket and then the ticket can be a great souvenir for remembrance of your trip in Angkor Wat..

Another beautiful wonders..a must visit... aside than angkor watt.. please visit this place as well..
what captures my attention here is the huge silverish tree with very strong root..
Just be careful when you walk alongside this place , its not really well maintained . maybe because of the cost of maintenance .. but as i said earlier..this place is a must visit !
Not to be missed. See my comments for Angkor thom. A journey to this region is not complete without a visit to angkor. They are some of the most spectacular ancient sites I have visited in the world.

Must see!. This park is clean and well maintained - we could find well toilet, restaurant while we also could drown in their jungle - amazing!
go there with tuk-tuk, it will be more flexible to stop or to enjoy views and temple - sometimes dusty, but you could feel the park - and breeze their smell on your way.

Stepping back into history. Although hot, many of the temples (Ta Prohm & Beng Melea) are covered (trees/ruins) and offer respite from the sun. Eary morning visits to Ta Prohm will ensure your pictures have less tourists in them. Delightful
Angor Wat. Spot repairs seem to have overtaken it. No crowd control or assistance for sunrise spectacle
great place overall. Visit this place and enjoy the past. Bit quieter between 11am and 2pm...... lots of tourists head off to have lunch...a great place to chill and see.
Angkor Wat. Simply Fantastic.Some amazing history to realise coupled with great people. Absolute must see

Bayon & Angkor Wat are a must - but be ready for Disneyland!. We loved Bayon Temple and found it to be the most amazing part of our time at Angkor - even more impressive than Angkor Wat itself! We woudn't recommend going for the sunrise, we got up early and headed to Angkor Wat but not only did we not get a good sunrise, but we were joined by about 500 other people, which meant that from every angle, somebody was walking through our photos or pushing past us to try and get a better shot. Overall Angkor is one of those must-see places, but be prepared for Disneyland in Cambodia, because you have thousands of tourists planning to see the same sights. Also, be sure to get a tuk tuk - more fun and cheaper than a taxi and it's impossible to see the sights without one. Despite the guidebooks recommendations, one day was enough at Angkor for us (& for our wallets).
passion. marvellous... to discover with a guide, when sun rise
Interesting no matter of historical interests. Deeply fascinating no matter if you are historically interested or not.

Amazing - a must see!. What can you say about these complexes - get there before the real crowds discover them! Already they are very busy, but this will just be the start once tourism really takes off. Make sure you go to Meng Melia - outside the Angkor complex (about a 2 hour drive away). It's really worth it and reminded us of what Ta Prohm used to be like - completely overgrown dark and mysterious!

Impressive. Unlike many other archaeological sites you can walk through every site on your own and experience it in such a special way. A MUST for everyone. TIP: If you have a good Tuk Tuk driver you can work out a trip opposite to the tour busses - it is a lot nicer to experience each of the temples when it is quieter...
AMAZING. Amazing, you will love the site, it's huge and spectacular. I would recommend at least 2 full days to enjoy the magic.

even better than i could imagine. very spread out would recommend you use a guide with transport. If hot weather bring sunscreen, hat, etc. totally amazing ruins and stunning carvings and decorations, would suggest you spend at least two days and include a sunrise and sunset. fantastic
simply overwhelmed by its uniqueness. An architechture that was so foreign and yet so accessable to my mind. nothing how could you be picky about a place of such beauty

On my must see list for 30 years. Despite quite large numbers of visitors the site is so large we rarely felt overcrowded. It is a wonderful place and so impressive. Worth going out to Bantey Srei as it is beautiful and the tuk tuk trip through the countryside is really facinating as well. Do drop into the land mine museum for a reminder of what a superpower can do to a country and it's people for pure commercial greed.
amazing. Walking in the path of the past. Just been able to wander and take your time to admire the grandness of the past
Just fantastic. Not a "temple" person, but was overwhelmed by the size and infrastructure of the area. Didn't realise there were beautiful places to sit down in isolation for a picnic.Don't miss it!

Millions of visitors couldn't have been wrong. This place alone has more visitors than other Asian countries get in one year, that must mean something! Your trip to Cambodia wouldn't be complete without a stop at this site. Come prepared with a skirt, a light shawl and a jug of water. Remember to ask for best month to visit as it can be very hot.Remember to go to the washroom when you see one, you don't know when you'll see another one again (I must say that most washrooms in Siem Reap are clean, that alone will make me go back there!).

Worth visiting over and over..... Took our family biking around a couple of the temples. Bike rental was cheap and easy--and we met the delivery guy right in front of Angkor Wat so we didn't have to navigate town traffic with our 10 and 8-year old on bikes. Best way to see the area if you're visiting for the first time with children.

must not miss this..... Tried both small and large circuit. Recommend to get a guide for small circuit as it has couple of important highlight like angkor wat, bayon n ta phrom.
Toilets are clean in the park.
The temple pass is abit expensive but this goes for cambodian schools.
Exceptional, must do b4 u die. Eternal world heritage. One could spend a week, a year, a lifetime there visiting without getting bored. Khmer art at it's peak. Mysterious and inspiring. Awesome.
A must see!. It has to be on any list for any person who has a great interest on the human condition.
Must See!!!. amazing! must see, even if it was very hot take tree day to visit because very large place!!! only sad ting too much tourist group making to much noise :-(

Go soon in the morning, go by bike!. Amazing history alive site!The temples are incredible! Beatifull and great! But there are too many people even in the low season, so go soon, see the sunrising.And if you can ride a bicycle, the place is perfect, flat terrain with a lot of trees giving shade. You dont need a super bike, rent the US$1,00 ones that you can see all around the city, they are very good for the ride!
Love it... Its my second time here, was here 9 years ago also. Its much more fixed up now I would say. Liked it even more before, when you had to figure out for yourself how it looked like.

Awesome site. We got up early to be there at 530am to see the sunrise over the site. It was cloudy, but we still got a great site and missed many of the large groups as well as the worst heat. A personal guide is only $25 and well worth it. Plenty of food and drink as we waited. This is a mike square site but we saw the best parts in about 5 hours with our guide. There are vendors around but they aren't too aggressive. Cambodia is very inexpensive and the dollar is taken everywhere.
Isn't this why you travel here?. BEST decision I made in traveling to Cambodia was to visit Siem Reap and Angkor Wat. The memories/sites/sounds/foods will last through the bane of my existence.

Fantastic. You can't visit Cambodia without visiting the Angkor Temples. We had an unbelievable day. We set out for sunset at 5am and bought only a day pass for $20. If time allows, opt for a three day pass ($40) or a week ($60) there are so many places to visit and we could have used more time here.
Amazing. Must see. This is worth all the trouble. But not do take the van around the site but the tuk tuk.

just very good. I would recommend this to every one. I did 3 temples in one day. Please take lots of water dont drink the palm juice I came back with Gardia a stomach bug . I think its thined with water from the moat

The reason why you should go to Cambodia. The largest religious construction ever built -- some temples are still standing, some are eaten by the forest and a handful are undergoing restoration -- welcome to beautiful Cambodia, once the seat of the most powerful kingdom in Asia. The temples of the Angkor Archaeological Park are amazing. At first sight, you might think they all look the same but that is not the case. if the buildings are awe-inspiring enough, the stories are spellbinding than thought. We enjoyed our trip here, very, very much. We even left some temples unvisited so that we will come back very soon!

Spell binding. A must see when in Siem Reap, how on earth did they build this place all that time ago, and how long did it take to finish? The more you see, the more you are amazed. Take plenty of water, a hat, and sun cream, and comfortable shoes. Take it all in and try not to rush a spectacular place to behold.
What you go there for.. Loved the history. Disliked the touts. We had a private guide, which made the experience most pleasant, as he knew to avoid all the crowds.

Don't miss the smaller temples. Angkor Wat is of course the centerpiece of this park, and of course amazing, but I highly recommend that you don't miss out on the other, smaller temples! I ended up liking several of the smaller temples even better than Ankgor Wat. (I'll look for the names and report back.) There are so many we weren't sure where to start, but our wonderful guide, Sokphai Cham, suggested a plan for our three days in the park and took us to see many wonderful temples. I was reluctant to hire a guide at first, but in the end he was what made our time in Siem Reap such a success - and for $20/day for most guides, it is definitely worth the investment.
So much to see!. Don't forget to visit the smaller temples; they are often at least as beautiful as the bigger ones. Some will give you an "Indiana Jones" feeling. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!
Must do. It's a dream to visit and best done so after some serious reading, a visit to the Museum and hiring a professional guide. Just so much more fabulous.

Majestic and Magical. This site is a must see for a traveler who is looking for adventure. I visted Vietnam before going to cambodia and Im upset that I did not spend more time in Cambodia. Im definitley going back.
FANTASTIC!. This is great site that everyone that like history and fantastic places must go

Lots of cool stuff to see. If you like history or archeaology this place has lots to see. Take plenty of small bills to buy water or stuff from the numerous sellers. Getting change for large bills can be a challenge.

Angkor Wat is Amazing. Do not miss this!! there really are no words for the experience. You can do this in a day if you like to hit the highlights (Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm). They have 1 & 3 day passes. 1 day for $20. buy your ticket the previous day at 5PM and you are allowed in for sunset. Also this will help you avoid the ticket line in the morning when you arrive for Sunrise. Best to go for sunrise and start your day early. we went from 5AM until about 11:30. The tour busses arrive mid-morning and all the sellers trying to get you to buy stuff arrive then too. It is also really hot by then. Best coffee from a food truck right accross from the Angkor Wat at the parking area. Espresso, cappacino etc and yummy pasteries. Our hotel coffe was not the best so this was a nice surprise.bathrooms are pretty good

Beautiful architecture. If you are into ancient architecture, this is a must visit; if you have to choose between the temples in South East Asia, this definitely rank one of the highest. It is really difficult to not awe and gawk at the sheer size of the temples, built not with modern machinery. We visited in February, when the weather is hot. The ground is dusty and at the end of the day, our sunblock-laden feet was covered with a layer of dusty gunk. But we still prefer the hot weather to the rainy season, all the better to visit the open sites without having to worry whether it would rain or not. Do bring a cap and sunglasses in this hot season. Face mask -- to cut out the dust breathed in -- is optional.We took the 3-day pass (USD40) based on the recommendation that a 1-day pass was definitely too short to see many of the temples. Would recommend to hire a local guide when visiting this place to (a) support the local tourism industry, and, (b) so that the buildings do not merge and become one and the same in your mind, after hearing the stories behind the intricate carvings. Our guide speaks English, and the cost to hire this guide and a tuk-tuk driver was reasonable. Do message me for his contact details.The only drawback is the many peddlers selling souvenirs outside the temples. An effective method to not let this bother you is to smile and say "No, thank you" and continue walking your way. Any attempt to touch/feel their wares for sale would mean an interest in purchasing them, which leads to constant harrassment until you are out of their sale zone boundary. Any attempts at purchasing would draw more peddlers in your direction.

Amazing!. Angkor Park is a must see! Amazing temples every place you look. This is really a special treat and well worth the visit. Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat, Pre Rup, Ta Prohm, Phimeanakas, Bayon. So many to see!

Amazing. Visited the site for 2 FULL days. First day from sunrise by tuktuk - i and was t was a lot of fun, but very hot. Second day we visited the Temples further away and so asked our tuktuk diver to organize an airconditioned car. (cost just a bit more but well worth it).

Awesome Park, Terrible, rude staff. Angkor Archaeological Park is really the jewel of Cambodia. The Park is easily experienced via so many transportation options it makes for an enjoyable destination whether you're a tourist, flashpacker, and backpacker. The price tag may seem steep on a backpacker budget but its well worth making the sacrifice to purchase the 3-day pass in order to properly Explore the rich history of this ancient city. Having visited both Angkor and Bagan in Myanmar I feel that Angkor edges Bagan only marginally. With the temples at Angkor being larger, utilizing more impressive architecture, and more offer detail in their bas-reliefs. On the other hand, Angkor's size makes it impossible to get an elevated perspective without some kind of aerial transportation.The people hawking drinks, meals and wares, while aggressive competitive, are actually very sweet and nice. The only negative experience we had here was with the park security and ticket checkers. These people were consistently rude even when we tried to be nice to them. They rarely smiled, often made jokes about the tourists. In one case, one of the security guys had a young son (maybe 7-8 years old) who was peddling post-cards to tourists complaining that he had no family even though he was actually dressed very well. We watched him repeat his same story from tourist to tourist then walk back to his dad, jump up on his moped and answer questions before jumping off to chase down a new batch of tourists. At another temple the police officer was trying to get tourists to buy from a lady set-up inside the temple. I can accept that corruption is a way of life in Cambodia but its still a little disheartening to see it occur so blatantly at such an important site. The rude behaviour of the other staff should be unacceptable. We had one guy tell us to go complain if we had a problem with his attitude but of course there is no place to really file a complaint. Angkor is one of those sites that everyone should visit even if its the only place you visit in Cambodia. I suggest just being polite to the staff and otherwise ignore them or pretend you don't understand them. Cheers and happy travels.
AMAZING HISTORY. go either every early in the morning or in the late night - when the group are not there ....

excellence hundo temple.... Please visit this temple in the morning. in the morning you should visit in the the angkor Thom temple because this temple dont have cored or. it will be so hot if we visit on the after noon. so we should visit angkor thom in the morning and angkor wat in the afternoon.
Amazing!. What an extraordinary place and we are so lucky to be able to visit. The reconstruction is quite amazing considering the age and the destruction that had occurred.
Hot but worth it!. Great temple but take a guide or you will miss everything! It was very hot! Go early in the morning or late in the afternoon
Very interesting. Learning about the history was amazing. I would recommend this to everybody
Captivating Cambodia.. Amazing historical site! The temples are a must see when in Cambodia.

beautiful, but hot!. The architecture is absolutely amazing. Will need at least an hour to do a really quick view of it. More if you want to appreciate it. Come prepared with water and something to give you shade. It is a cooker and can quickly drain you.

better than expected. I was reluctant to visit for many years because of the crowds. I had heard that it was always crawling with people. While this is true at the main areas as you explore the other areas you may, like me be pleasantly surprised. For many years my job entailed travel and research of architectural and design details. Here at Angor Wat there is still evidence of the original work as well as careful restoration and re-creation of the elements sponsored by many different countries.

Full Day Temples Tour Angkor. Well recomended if u hv short stay in Cambodia n stay in Siem Reap, visited lots of Anchient Historical Temples in Angkor Area, not only Angkor watt but still lots of other interesting temples.

That's why it's one of the wonders of the world. Breathtaking temples and sights,make sure you read up on it before you go or at least get a guide as there is so much to know and is very interesting.onlynsaying as there isnt much information there .
The temples were so much more than I expected.. I had no idea that the temples were so extensive. The sandstone had unique carvings and pictures. Our private tour guide told us part of the story.

One of the highlights of our trip to SE Asia. Whilst it may be the iconic towers of Angkor Wat adorning the postcards and guidebooks, there’s a lot more to the Angkor Archaeological Park than one famous temple. Located six kilometres north of Siem Reap in northern Cambodia, the Angkor Archaeological Park – a UNESCO World Heritage Site – is one of the most important archaeological sites in South-east Asia.We were surprised to discover that the ancient city of Angkor offers more than one thousand temple ruins and monuments over an area of 400 square kilometres, and is a photographer’s paradise.We had read some information about visiting the major temples in the reverse of the usual order taken by coaches and tuk-tuks. This proved to be valuable advice, not only for better photographs (because of the position of the sun relative to the temples) but we also remained one step behind or ahead of the crowds (depending on the time of day), often finding ourselves entirely alone in shaded courtyards, free to explore Angkor’s secrets. Amongst our favourite temples were Bayon, the spectacular central temple of the ancient city of Angkor Thom, with it’s many carved stone faces ; Ta Pronh, largely left to the clutches of the living jungle and where, at any moment, you might expect to see Indiana Jones come leaping out at you ; and Banteay Srei, the “Citadel of Women“ where, it is said, that the reliefs on the temple are so delicate that they could only have been carved by the hand of a woman .  One modern engineer has estimated it would take 300 years to complete the building of Angkor Wat today – yet the monument was begun soon after King Suryavarman II came to the throne in the early 12th century, and was finished shortly after his death, thus taking no more than 40 years to complete. Amazing!
mind boggling. The detail on the stone carvings was awsome. It was difficult to remember the temples were built so long ago. The crowds made things difficult.
Angkor Wat. a very big complex indeed,just wear light,and dont forget to wear hat since it is gonna be very hot
Fantastic!. We loved here,very interesting.we did a cycle tour of it,best way to see it. Also rode the elephants and watched the sunset.
Must see. A tuk-tuk is the only way to see this huge area but best taken in small chunks because of the hear.
A great park.. Fully more than 100 ruins spread out around this unique ancient park. We were impressed and how amazing that Khmer people can build of these date from mid 9 century to 13 century.

We had a great guide - Mr Thy. He knew all the best photo spots.
Got there reasonably early.
Local newly weds get all dressed up and go to Angkor Wat.
Well worth the visit.
angkor. guess..........you might want to read up on it as well as US bombing, Russian tanks, Chinese land mines, pol pot and funneling of your tourist dollars while you're at it...is that enough?
Must do!. Spend several days exploring here. Sunrise at Angkor Wat. Afternoon at Bayon. Don't miss them!
Almost a thousand years!. Among the best of the great heritage sites. Fairly easy to get there once you are in Siem Reap.

One of the best archaeological sites. Very well preserved and well maintained. Most importantly well managed by the authority. The central and main ticketing centre is an effective idea. The provisions for 1 -3 -7 day passes are equally effective for various visitors who can customize their trip accordingly. Hats off to the Apsara Authority who manages this extraordinarity large archaeological park excellently. Cambodia being a third world country is certainly poor but it is one of the richest nations for its history and culture.

Wonderful place to visit.. I went with a tuk tuk at 5.30am to watch sunrise over Angkor Wat. It was still dark when I arrived and I hadn't thought to bring a flashlight along but this wasn't a problem as many other people had lights and provided I walked carefully over the uneven path way it was easy to make my way to the lake in front of Angkor Wat. Some enterprising kids had laid out mats on the edge of the lake that you were welcome to use provided you bought some tea of coffee from them for 2 dollars. Sitting on the mat right a the edge of the lake watching the sky lighten and the reflection of Angkor Wat start to appear on the lake really was worth the early start. It was totally mystical. I then set off to explore the temple while it was still really quite which was amazing. This was followed by a wonderful encounter with a troop of wild monkeys playing near the temple. Finally I got to watch a truely stunning sunrise over the temple. All in all an experience not to be missed.

Siem Reap, Beautiful, Fantastic and Magnificent. I was recently here but didnt reveiw straight away as its one of those places that leave such a deep and indeluable impression you want to give it justice. This is one of those sights that you think can't live up to all you've seen or heard but the Fantastic Hotel where I was staying almost insisted and I wasn't disappointed. It is without any doubt beautiful, fantastic and magnificent. Theres alot to do here and i didnt have the time to see much but what i did was Grand. I had i guide and i would recomend that if you only have a short visit as they will point out and take you to the highlights and fill your mind with information. Even with what i did do i was exhausted but in an exhilerated way, it truely was Spectacular.It's hot so keep well hydrated and wear good walking shoes this is not a place for sandels or thongs.A must see attraction

Truly one of the wonders of the world. Covering a huge area it is advisable to visit the most touristy temples as they are the best ie Angkor Wat, Bayon, Ta Prohm and Angkor Thom. Probably the best way to get around is by tuk tuk.

Overwhelming, Stunning, Unforgettable. There are some world sights that you think can't live up to all the images you've seen. The Angkor park is not one of them. It is quite seriously awe-inspiring, fascinating, beautiful, and magnificent. The only thing that's hard is that there are so many ruins to see and only so much energy in one's legs. Drink plenty of water and get an early start. We didn't hire a guide, which was a mixed blessing. We had guidebooks which were helpful, and in a way I didn't want to have someone talking at me all day. But the guides I overheard did seem well-informed and I'm sure they would have added value. If we'd been there longer we probably would have done some of each kind of touring - with and without guides.
Incredible. Better than I expected but also hotter and busier. There are bus loads of tour groups and so many tuk tuks but its understandable that everyone wants to see it as it really is amazing!
Vast Park !. Learned out through our tour guide about this Angkor Park. It was huge park comprised more than 250 mikes the home of many ruins built in different dates and kings.
Have to see!. Watch out for guys handing out incenses. Its a scam to get money from you.
Truly incredible. Took advantage of the "week" pass and toured all the temple sites. Definitely worth it and kids under 12 are free!

Beautiful!. The park is beautiful, colourful, fascinating. When you see the woman sweeping the leaves on the side of the road each evening you are in awe of the effort made to keep the park perfect for the lucky visitors who get to experience it.

Wonderful.. An extraordinary and very large area that really needs a few days to visit. If you have a short time, get a guide (there are around a thousand official guides at present, locally trained and knowledgable) for a modest price. Angkor Wat (a very large Hindiu and Buddhist temple), Angkor Thom (a large ancient city site) and Ta Prohm (a temple with encroaching jungle) are highlights and can be seen (briefly!) in a full day. Certainly one of the wonders of the world. Don't miss it if you are nearby.

Very well run. The temples in this whole area are wonderful, even the ones in disrepair. The hawkers of souvenirs can be a nuisance but this is to be expected in such a poor country. Sometimes, the crowds are unavoidable, especially at popular sites at popular times.

Not to be missed. If you are anywhere in Southeast Asia that allows you to make a trip to Angkor Wat, do not miss it. The ruins are incrediable. I fear that the Cambodians are more interested in getting tourists to come so they can get as much money as possable, than in proper preservation and visitation restrictions that would ensure preservation for the long term. See is while you can, you will never forget the experance.

Breathtaking.. Wow. What can I say. The Angkor heritage area is breathtaking. We hired a driver to show us around and had an amazing time. We recommend going it DIY rather than a tour, as you can have the time and freedom to plan your day, and not feel rushed. Also have a chat with your driver / guide on what the best parts of the day is for each of the locations. Also note that drivers cannot enter the angkor sites, only the roads between (otherwise you'll have to buy them a pass). Ours just waited near the entrances of each place. In all A+.

An unbelievable site/sight. Unesco World Heritage sites are always special places. Angkor should have been one of the finalists for the New Seven Wonders of the World. You cannot appreciate the size and scope of this site until you start driving within and around the park. It is huge amd covers hundreds of square kilometers. Not all temples are create equal either. Some are magnificent and others more like piles of rubble, shadows of their former self. My favorites were Angkor Wat, Bayan, Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm and the further afield Banteay Srei.
Definitely a must go!. Too bad we only had one day to see the site! I don't mind going back and spending a 3 days to see the sights again, including sunrise and sunset at the various temples!
7th wonder of the world. This is one of the most fascinating historic sites I have ever visited. Magical - on par with the Aztec, Mayan and Egyptian experiences.
Majestic. Be there at opening time to get the best postion to see the sun rise over Ankor Wat and don't forget to take a torch and sturdy runners!!
Angkor wat temples. amazing temples, 9000 years old, a great feat in ancient building.

a bit pricey but well worth it. good pics taken will update when downloaded but the attraction was and the temples were brill .but sometimes during the day too many tourists turn up at the same time.. early morn is best as open very early to see sunrise over the temple. and take a torch

The Must Do of Cambodia . . .. To see this I would recommend hiring a Tuk Tuk from town for the day at around $15us, this way you can go at your own pace as fast or slow as you want. Also worth getting up for the 5am pick up so you can get your tickets early before heading to Ankor Wat for sunrise. The Park is amazing but as I am no history buff, just the one day was enough for me.
Hard to Believe How Old Structures Are. The trees growing through existing structures were unbelievable. Also ride and feed the elephants. That was a lot of fun.

book a 3 day pass. There is so much to see and doo.I did it all on a rented push bike.So got off the beaten track and met the villagers 99% waved and where so welcoming Just 1 tried to swipe me off the road.

Amazing place. This is an amazing place, there are so many temples, statues, etc to see that it is quite overwhelming at timesYou could literally spent weeks here and not see everythingRead up before you go, pick a few key temples you want to visit, and enjoy a Tuk Tuk ride through the park on your way to them

A beautiful site. This park is simply wonderful with the many archaelogical sites and beautiful trees that have been growing in the surrounding jungle for many years.
We wished we had more time to find out more on the trees.
The roads and trees are extremely well maintained making travel between the sites very easy.

great place. If you love temple and old history this is a great place! The park is very big, take your time don't be on hurry to visit it. If it’s possible avoid to go with a group and take your own local guide, in this way you help people!

DON'T MISS IT. One day is not enought. You need at least 3 full days to see the complex. Bring your own food. It's expensive and it's not good. Flip flops are ok but if you really like to walk you better wear light walking shoes.You can go by: tuk tuk (US$15/full day)rent a motorcycle (US$8/full day)rent a bike (US$2/full day)The complex it's just a few km away from town.

Tremendous ruins. Huge, expansive and impressive collection of ruins. This is why you're in Siem Reap. Sure it's touristy, but so big there are plenty of ways to escape the crowd. Worth hiring a guide and driver/tuktuk/bicycle to see as much as you can.

Must hire a guide. This is an amazing place and hiring a guide will help you capture all of its glory. We hired Sim Sophath through our hotel, but you can contact him directly at sophat_sim@yahoo.com or www.angkortravelguide.com. His knowledge was excellent and he spoke very clear English. He was able to make suggestions to help us avoid the crowds. Very likable personality.
One of the hundred must do travel experiecnes in life. Simply overwhelmingly brilliant. Make sure you get a guide for this one

Go, see, get off the beaten path. Angkor park is crazy crowded - so go, see the main sights (Angkor Wat, Angkor Thom, but then get off the beaten path and go see the smaller temples and have your own experience. Truly amazing. We did the main small loop with a tour guide the first day, and then headed out on our own (in a tuk-tuk) the 2nd day and loved it (after feeling claustrophobic the 1st day).
A 'must'. It is absolutely stunning an archaeological site on a vast scale

Visit the Khmer Empire. The Angkor park is the major draw to visit Cambodia and Siem Reap. A 3 day pass is $40 or a 7 day pass is $60. I suggest 3 days minimum. In 3 days time you can get a good overview of the Khmer history as it is related to these temples built during the Angkor era. If you have traveled 11,000 miles, half way around the globe to see temples in Cambodia, make sure you plan your days so that you have enough time to appreciate everything you can come into contact with. If you mix and match your activities you wont get “Temple Fatigue” and will appreciate what you came to see and learning about. I would also recommend a good guide. The guide our hotel arranged was a certified guide by the government. Our guide, En Sophal, had a great sense of humor and spoke better English than some of my fellow Americans! Not only was Mr. Sophal a walking encyclopedia for all things Angkor, but he knew of the most interesting photo opportunities using temple architecture and camera position to create some really impressive optical illusions. A good guide will also try and time your visits away from the times that the big buses are coming through. I would recommend getting an early start each day since it is much cooler in the morning hours. At the beginning of each day I would give my guide a list of the temples I wanted to see for the day and he would arrange the order so that we had the best opportunity to see these temples and not get trampled by the hordes of bus tours. It was nice to have some great photos with temples that look empty.Keep in mind that you are in the jungle and it gets hot so keep bottled water handy. It was really nice riding by Tuk Tuk through the forest between temples and enjoying the breezes and awesome scenery. If you intend to visit Beng Mealea, keep in mind there is a separate entrance fee of $5 and this temple is over 1 hour away by CAR. Since the tickets you purchase run consecutive days only, you can save that one for one those days that is not included in your 3 day pass. Angkor Park is an experience that you will never forget. There is something magical about it that feels very spiritual and stays in your heart long after you have left.

So much to see. There is so much to see, don't underestimate the size and get yourself a guide who will take you to right places and most importantly at the right time to avoid the crowds, try to see Angkor Thom, Ta Prohm, The Palace and the Elephant Terraces, they are all special in their own right and surprisingly different. We finished on the Elephant Terraces and were blown away at the sheer size of it and the vista.

A must see, but be emotionally prepared to be harassed all day. You need at least 2 days to see enough of it, don't get a single day ticket unless you really won't get a chance to come back. A tuktuk driver was organised for us by the guesthouse -which we didn't expect- but a good thing it was, the complex is huge and he knew his way around and had a nice little plan "for us". Would have been impossible by foot. Ankor Wat itself was a little overrated, although very beautiful. I enjoyed some of the smaller temples more. The sunrise was nice, was the first time I had ever been in a crowd that gathered specifically for that. The crowd didn't bother me, you just need a little space for yourself with a nice view. It didn't bother me too much but some of the temples have extremely steep stairs. Going up one of them (don't remember the name but it's recommended for sunsets) was ok but coming down was terrifying. Much like a crowd going down a tall, eroded stone ladder. The only thing I hated was the begging and harassment. Not like I can blame vendors for trying -and using their kids to chase down customers. We were constantly bombarded by vendors and children for money. They can also get very rude or emotional if you don't give them anything, they are very intent on making the sale and they are absolutely everywhere. They will follow you. If not interested just politely decline and keep walking. It's just something you have to deal with. The youngest was a little girl, not yet 3 years old, trying to sell us some handicraft. Remember that Siem Riep is the biggest and one of the only tourist attractions in Cambodia and ticket money does not stay in the country (foreign ownership). People come from poor villages all over the country to make a buck there... it's cheap anyway so go ahead and spend a few bucks on food/drink/souvenirs once there...on the other hand, you have to be able to decide regardless of how someone may approach you, otherwise you'll spend all your money out of pity (as well as encourage kids not to stay in/go to school). Female monks (not sure if there's another word for that) apparently there for praying are seated in the temples and will force incense candles into your hand, or insist by gestures that it's rude if you don't light a candle. Whatever the case, they want a dollar. If you go to Ankor Wat for sunrise, expect someone to start chatting with you and give you some information. They are the restaurant workers trying to secure a deal for later. Don't worry about the difference between restaurants, they are all the same. Make sure that if you get something you go to the same person, they will be extremely offended if you go to someone else. They will ask if you remember them from earlier and lead you to their restaurant... go ahead with them, they are really hoping that you come with them and it's not like it's feasible to look around and compare menus or prices. These guys don't harass you too much, and hey, you will need a coffee or good breakfast to set you up for the long day ahead.

Wonderful!. I have many years wanted to visit Angkor with all its temples and I was very happy to see soo many restorations and cooperations between countries (India, Italy, France, Vietnam, and so on) to keep Angkor and rebuild it!

absolutely beautiful and awe-inspiring. The Angkor ruins have been on the top of my must-see list for many years, and it was everything I thought it would be plus more! I went in January, which is supposed to be in the cool/dry season, but it was still quite hot come lunch-time and humid. I recommend hiring a tuk-tuk driver for half a day, from early in the morning until lunchtime, then going back home and taking a rest from the heat. You can buy a three-day ticket for $40 and see a lot, almost everything. We spent a good amount of time at each temple area, but the most pleasant time was early in the morning before it got hot and before the tour buses arrived. It truly is worth it to hire a tuk-tuk driver (between $15-$25 per day), because he knows where he is going and there is a lot of distance between many of the temples. You can rent bikes, but I only recommend that if you are a biking fan and ready to get a bit lost and quite sweaty.There are plenty of bathroom facilities that are kept up nicely throughout the Park, and lots of little restaurants catering to tourists.
Extraordinary. Probably the best historical/archaeological site on the planet.

Angkor Park - Wow!. When I visited I wasn't prepared for the whole experience at all. It is so big and driving through the forests and around the temples was magical - it's great to visit several times at different times of the day to have varying kinds of experiences.
Impossible don]t see it. Fashinating and really interesting acheologic place

one of the wonders of the world - deservedly. The temples in this park are all fabulous in their own way. To be able to experience this culture that was at its height in 12th century and to see the sophistication of the society. law courts, entertainment, engineering, libraries. a humbling experience
Need at least 2 days to see it all. The whole reason to come to Cambodia and you will not be disappointed.
Huge!. The whole Angkor area is amazing from a historical point, especially since it was built 800 years ago. Best way to explore is by bicycle
Unique. This is the very reason why everybody goes to this corneer of the world

You need more than a day.... ... but not in a bad way.
I spend one day and still feel I saw a lot - but I also wanna go back some day.
Rent bikes or a tuk-tuk ($15 for the whole day) and go explore.
a place to see before you die. Difficult to describe the magnificence of the whole area, and the craftmanship from years ago. A must see place

Not to be missed. Dependant upon the length of your pass you could easily spend a week or more here but if you have less time then don't panic. In our case we had two full days and it is quite easy to get a bit "templed out" if you overdo things. The highlights are easy to name : Angkor Wat, The Bayon, Ta Prohm etc..but sometimes its the little temples, the slightly off the beaten track ones that take you by surprise. We visited one called Thomannon and it was wonderful, small, compact, fantastic reliefs and carvings and in a lovely setting.So go with an open mind, pace yourself, remember that there will be (I hope) other opportunities in life to come back and see some more. I count myself fortunate to have visited many of the so-called wonders of the world during my travels, I am sure others have done the same, but the archaeological park is right up there nd believe me, theres much more to it than simply Angkor Wat. I am sure you will love it!
not to be missed. I thought the three day pass was sufficient.....we went very slowly and hired a tuktuk to take us Round.
More than Angkor Wat. Outside of the main Temple are many other temples with distinctive attributes such as the smiling buddas - on the way see the mioneys and other attrractions.

An Indiana Jones experience!. Incredible carvings and fascinating ancient history. The whole park area was vastly bigger than we ever expected! The 3-day-pass was good value for money. Never expected the place to have so much to see.
take a tuk tuke. easist way to get around, hire a driver and a guide, you will get the most of your time.

You need to spend time here - not rush in and out in a frenzy. $20 for 1 day per person, $40 for 2 or indeed 3 days per person. Don't be put off by the cost - the place is magical and deserves being explored at leisure - preferably for more than 3 days...Angkor Thom for sunrise (forget Angkor Wat until about 8am, when all the busloads take their tourists back to hotels for breakfast)Ta ProhmGo further afield and visit Kabal Spean.People do cycle, but if you want to explore further afield the distances are quite large, and a tuk tuk is a better option.

One of the most astonishing places on the planet to visit.. This is a premier league destination and is up there with all the great places that I have visited anywhere in the world. Here are a few tips that will help you get the most enjoyment from your visit.1.
