Get up early and enjoy these fantastic monuments alone; the park opens at 5:30, but is usually over run by coach loads of tourists by 9. You can get 3 or 4 hours of quality site seeing before returning to your hotel for a late breakfast and the rest of the hot day relaxing. 2. Get a good guide, who will give you far more information than you will ever get from a book.. This is the best way to use your time at the sites most effectively.3. Pace yourself; there is a lot to see, and if you do 8 hours of sites per day, for day after day, you will soon be exhausted and "templed out". If your itinerary allows, have a break from the temples and do something different such as horse riding at Happy Ranch or go to Bodia Spa (both recommended by me). 4. Three days will let you see most of the main temples. If you are staying for more than 3 days, I recommend that you buy the pass that allows you to spread your three days site seeing over a week. This costs the same as the 3 consecutive day pass ($40), but is much more flexible. You have to go to the two kiosk windows on the left handside of the entrance plaza to get the 3 day in a week passes. If you go to any of the other windows you will be sold 3 consecutive days. 5. I can recommend our guide, Mr Pech Mony, whose telephone number I publish with his permission. You can contact Mony on local cell phone number 012 898694.
like everything in Angkor Wat. Must see for all, the more this place is in the nature, trees can give you some refreshing moments... but busy all day long.

Wow!!!!. You will be amazed. It was the best thing we have ever done. Beautiful carvings , architecture and craftsmanship. You can't even begin to imagine the scale of this place. temples everywhere and all different.
Angkor Archaeological Park. Already put this in under the Siem Reap reviews. Well worth a visit and at least a day is required. Not for those who can't walk too far.

A little freaky. When you first arrive at the park, you stop at what appears to be toll collection booths. What happens is that you have to buy a pass to enter the park. Passes vary in cost and visit duration, but all require you to stand in front of a webcam and have your photo taken. You are then issued with a photo ID pass that you have to show every time you enter the park or a temple. One benefit of the pass is that it gives visitprs access to free toilets, with western bowls and surprisingly clean.

Truly awe inspiring. The Angkor Park comprises a mutlitude of Citie and Temple elements from the Angkor region between 8th and 14th century.. Highlights are Ankgor Wat, the Bayon , Ta Prohm and Bantay Kdei. Entry to park is $20 per day pp but you can get a 3 day pass for $40. Expect to spend a few days if you want to see it all! Is is a once in a lifetime historic visit.. and will leave you in awe... Ensure if you do not know the history that you get a guide to truly experience it!
Worth the trip alone. Just watch out for the sellers who don't take no for an answer, just walk away.

You don’t come to Siem Reap to not see the temples! A must at least once in your life. Some other notes here also!. Spectacular! You don’t come to Siem Reap to not see the temples! A must see at least once in your life. Some other notes about Siem Reap here too!You will see all kinds of things in the park, elephants walking around, and it is the main area which is just outside Angkor Thom, Angkor Wat, the Terrace of the Elephants, etc. It’s an open area.Some note about Cambodia I will post here.Do you need mosquito spray? Well, you might, you might not. We brought it, only used it in the jungle temple. But we also wore long sleeve light colored clothing. I got bit once the entire three days we were in Siem Reap. My wife got bit 3 times because she rolled up her sleeves. We went in December. There are mosquitoes in the bathrooms, but other places I didn’t see many. We saw people walking around in shorts and T-shirts, we thought, hmmm, ok, those folks are putting themselves at risk, but then again maybe not, it depends on where you go and when you go. I also bought a bunch of citronella patches and wore at least 1-2 on my back, hat, etc. it kept them away. But again this was December.Food, mostly is fine, we didn't get sick, just make sure things are cooked through, and use common sense.Our guide: http://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g297390-d2178241-Reviews-Thoeunson_Private_Tour-Siem_Reap.htmlI think a 3 day pass cost us $30-40 bucks, can’t remember off hand.There are some people who visit Angkor Wat who don’t respect the temples or understand things. There was one guy just in front of us who asked his guide why they don’t cut down all the trees around the Tomb Raider Temple. I just about collapsed. If you cut down the trees, no one will come, this is part of the beauty of Angkor Wat! Why would want to cut down the trees? Some people just can’t understand nature’s value. Please respect the temples and the grounds, period. Also you will see many landmine victims playing instruments to some of the temples, feel free to give them a few riel, the poor guys risked their lives to try to remove these things or accidently stepped on one on their farm and now can’t work and support their families.However, you will also encounter people attacking you and following you to try to sell you something just in and out of the temples. These people are annoying, though I understand their plight to support their families, however, when children are doing it, I feel it’s not good, they should be in school. DO NOT BUY ANYTHING FROM THEM. Once they get a taste of money they will feel why go to school. Do not support them. Talk to them in English, say hi, and then ask them why they are not in school and tell them how fun it is to be there. Maybe one day it will sink in, or they will pressure their parents to let them go, I don’t know. Either way don’t buy from these folks. It gets old and boring after awhile being attacked by them, but be nice. Just remember if you do decide to buy something be forewarned, you will be trapped and others will expect you to buy as well. If there is something you really want to buy you can buy it downtown in Siem Reap at one the souvenir stores, ask your guide or driver to take you there or ask the hotel to tell you where it is. The prices are exactly the same and in this way you are supporting the economy not just one person. Giving to the people here, especially the kids does more harm than good as the kids should be in school. I want to mention something important there. Under no circumstances should you buy something from a police officer! If you are with a guide, they could get in trouble for it. While at Banteay Srei I was approached by a police officer, and he said, “Hey, do you want to buy a genuine police badge, I had highly considered buying it, however, I knew better and politely refused him immediately, I never even looked at it or approached him, I just said no thank you and kept walking. I think it would have been nice to have, but the police officer risks losing his job and our guide would have risked going to jail or get fined. Our guide told us later that if I had bought it, that same police officer may have approached him afterwards and said your customers stole it from him or blah blah blah. It would have not been a good thing. So don’t buy anything you know you shouldn’t have. I laugh at it now, but it could have been quite serious would I have really bought it.At one of the temples, and now I cannot remember which one it was, but on top of one of them you can see Angkor Wat in the distance and some of the other temples from the top. However, beware, there may be a guy up on top that will try to point these out to you and then ask for a small payment. If you can see Angkor Wat at all from the top it will be very small, you will only see a few of the towers in the distance between the trees. You can also see some other temple tops over the trees here. You can probably try to find them by yourself if you have a map with you. If the guy tries to help you politely tell him immediately that you have a guide and that you know you can see Angkor Wat from the top. Sorry again I forgot which temple this happened at, I just remember the temple being surrounded by trees and the view was spectacular.

The Angkor Umbrella. A privilege to visit (but a bit sad our guide told us this magnificent 400 square kilometre Cambodian asset with its temple crown jewels and lucrative tourist profits is owned by a private company!!!!)This being said just about everything you go to SIem Reap for is within the Angkor Archaeological Park - Ankor Wat, Ta Prohm, the Bayon etc should all be subtitled under this main heading....Regardless of who owns it and gets the profits, Ankor Archaeological Park is truly one of the most incredible places one earth and, if you have the opportunity to visit, you will not regret the chance to measure life in terms of travel, history, culture, more history, fresh air, delicious food, photo opportunities, and general charm of people and environs.

An Enthralling Experience. Siem Reap, meaning Siam Defeated, had started life as a cluster of small villages centuries back, each centred around a pagoda. Today Cambodia's second major city, it is small and walkable. (Cambodia's total population of 14 million, is less than that of Mumbai city.) It is a beautiful little city, well laid out, clean, and with no population pressures.Siem Reap's main attractions are its ancient temples, many of them in the Angkor Archaeological Park - a UNESCO World Heritage site - but also widely distributed elsewhere. By far the biggest attraction is the awesome, 12th century Angkor Wat, which had started off as a Hindu temple, dedicated to the God Vishnu, but was later remodelled as a Buddhist temple, which it is to this day. Angkor was the capital of the Khmer empire from 5th to 12th centuries AD, and at one time had a million people. Set up on a one sq-km site, Angkor Wat is the largest religious structure of any type in the world, and was the state temple at Angkor.Angkor Wat is exceptionally well preserved - as good as though it was built yesterday - thanks to continuing conservation and maintenance. The temple has five huge, intricately-carved towers - four at the corners of its rectangular base, and the fifth, towering over the others to a height of 65 m, at the centre. It is an awesome sight, that becomes increasingly so as one approaches. Of particular interest are the very intricate and well-preserved bass reliefs about Hindu mythological epics as well as Angkor's wars with its neighbours. You will need a guide to explain these epics and historical events. Your trip should be of at least four days, with two to three days for the temples alone - by taxi, tuk-tuk or even a hired bicycle. The distances are not walkable. It is best to concentrate on the best temples. Bayon is best noted for its emormous faces carved in stone. The Banteay Srey temples - intellectual gems - are small, but have the most intricate - and exquisite - carvings. Tenth century Phnom Bakheng , the first major temple at Angkor, marks the shift of the capital from Rolous to Angkor. Preah Khan is an ancient Buddhist monastery with multiple, chriss-crossing passages and intricate carvings. Ta Prohm, another monastery, is also an architectural wonder, and is being ably restored by Indian archaeologists. Restoration work on a massive scale has also been undertaken by European archaeologists at a number of temples. There is a lot else to do in Siem Reap. Visit the well-maintained National Museum, that beautifully highlights the history and culture of Cambodia - as does the Cambodian Cultural Village. The Toul Sieng Genocidal Museum is a grim reminder of Khmer Rouge bestiality against their own people. The Angkor Shopping Centre specialises in gems and jewellery. Artisans de Angkor offers visitors a free tour of their stone and wood carving facilities, and sells high-quality handicrafts. Traditional handicrafts of the region can be had at the Asian Crafts Centre. Do not miss the Old Market and Night Market for some amazing souvenirs. You can even have rides on elephant back, in hot air balloons and in helicopters. Siem Reap offers an altogether amazing trip.One request.Many of the people are very poor. Dear little children, some well below ten years of age, eke out a living selling books on Angkor Wat, a range of souvenirs and picture post cards - the latter for ten to the dollar Do buy all you can, and do not bargain too hand with them. It is their only source of livelihood.

Breathtaking views and great guide. Our tour of Angkor started way before we even reached Siem Reap. We had the amazing luck of locating Mr. Kriss. Who had great connections as he arranged for a front seat for us to enjoy the true Khmer dances with absolutely great dinner to match. He even helped us with dining, supermarket, planned our itinerary and even know how to avoid th crowds. When we arrived at Banteay Srei, we were all alone! It's so surreal yet relaxing. must see. One of the wonders of the world; a must see. amazing. visit it over several days - it's huge - 200 km square I believe. yes, lots of tourists but many times, you can avoid them, except perhaps at Angkor Wat temple but the rest of the Angkor Park is so huge, people come and go in waves.

One of the wonder of the world. Angkor Wat park should be number one as the all town of Siem Reap exist because of it!!This is the most beautiful place we have visited in Cambodia. So many great temples, it's almost impossible to see it all in one week and we have decided to come back here in a few month in a rainy season when there is less tourists in the ruins.

The temples of Angkor are the most wondrous ancient ruins in the world. Angkor is so much more than just Angkor Wat, which seems to be the only Angkor-era temple that many people have heard of. There are about 100 temples of Angkor, each about 1,000 years old. Many appear to be mountains of stone rising above the semi-tropical trees and rice fields of northwestern Cambodia. The greatest concentration of these temples reside in the Angkor Archaeological Park, which is several kilometers north of the tourist hub city of Siem Reap.The most popular temples in the park are Angkor Wat, The Bayon with its 216 giant, carved, smiling faces, and Ta Prohm, with giant trees growing out of its walls. But there are many other temples of note, including red-stoned Banteay Srei, which is north of the main temple area, Pre Rup, Preah Khan, Banteay Kdei, and others.The best ways to visit the temples are by bicycle or in a tuk tuk, which is a rickshaw-like vehicle that is pulled by a motorbike. If it's very hot or you're not in good enough condition to bicycle long distances, then the tuk tuk is probably your best bet. You leave the driving to someone else, and you can tell the driver to go at whatever speed you want and to stop wherever you want. Whichever way you visit the temples, bring a camera, walking shoes, sunglasses, a wide-brimmed hat, and plenty of water. You can buy food at the many restaurants within the park.You may also want to hire a knowledgeable guide. One that I got to know is named Kinal MIn, who speaks excellent English, is very knowledgeable about the temples as well as Cambodian culture, and can give you good tips about where to stay and eat in Siem Reap.I recommend spending at least 3 days visiting the temples. A 1-day pass to the park costs $20, but a 3-day pass costs $40. An even better deal is the 7-day pass, which costs $60. Of course, you may want to visit the temples with a tour guide on your first day, just to get yourself oriented and educated, and then visit the temples on your own on subsequent days. Tour guides and tuk tuk drivers charge very reasonable prices.

A couple on their own - a guide who knows how to dodge tourist buses.. My husband and I had just a few days to discover Angkor. It turned out to be one of the most wonderful experiences of our life. We had gone there on the spur of the moment from Thailand and had not really done our homework. We had the excellent luck to find a driver who was polite and highly knowledgeable. His English was quite good.He not only (as we realized later) planned our time for us to the best of our possibilities, but managed to get us to certain very popular sites like the Wat Thom before the buses arrived. He would tell us exactly how long we had to explore quietly, then pick us up and take us to another temple to see, again avoiding the peak times for groups. Angkor is immense. Some people rent motorbikes, or look for the tuk-tuks (which are certainly much cheaper than taxis), but it cannot be explored on foot. Therefore we wholeheartedly recommend our driver, Mr. Sovann MeasTel. +85 512 761486 (Outside Cambodia)012 761 486 (Inside Cambodia) email: sonavy_cambodia@yahoo.com
